DOC.HEADLINE: Philippine workers offered chance to buy houses back home

TEXT.P: Deputy Chief Executive Officer of the Philippines Pag-IBIG Fund Jaime A. Fabiana said Sunday in Taipei that overseas Philippine workers who dream of owning a decent and affordable house can finally realize their dreams.

"The government is looking at helping overseas Filipino workers (OFW) in Taiwan to buy houses in the Philippines, " said Fabiana. To this end, "we are holding the first overseas Housing Fair in Taiwan. Later we will hold other Housing Fairs in Dubai and London."
The fair, held at the Dominican School in Taipei, was the first of its kind organized outside the Philippines by the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) and the Pag-IBIG Fund.

According to information released by the MECO, the Housing Fair is a coordinated effort by government agencies such as the Pag-IBIG Fund, the Landbank of the Philippines (LBP) , Philippine Health Insurance Corp. and the Philippine Labor and Employment Office.
Pag-IBIG Fund is one of the Philippines government's leading housing agencies.
The event in Taipei also featured booths set up by the LBP with the aim of providing an inexpensive service to workers in Taiwan who send remittances to the Philippines.

Fabiana said that many overseas Filipino workers (OFW) dream of building a new house for their loved ones. "We hope to help make their dream come true by hosting this Housing Fair in Taipei, " said Fabiana. "We provide housing loans at rates as low as 6%."
"I think the interest rates for the housing loans are quite low," said Silva Moonyen Ortiz, a Filipina who has been working in Taiwan for three years.
The fair attracted many OFWs residing in areas of northern Taiwan such as Taoyuan, Jhongli, Hsinchu and Keelung.
According to the MECO, there are 85,000 Filipinos in Taiwan and all of them are trying hard to provide for their families in the Philippines.

The housing fair will serve as venue for OFWs and developers to meet and will also facilitate arrangements for the housing projects to be tailor-made to the OFWs' needs and requirements, the MECO said.
Most of the housing projects will be affordable and OFWs at the housing fair will be able to chose from among projects in Luzon, Visayas and Mindanao, it added.

Pag-ibig Fund is the Philippines government's Home Development Mutual Fund that was created in 1978 to offer savings schemes and housing loan packages to Filipinos. It includes an overseas program, which offers Filipino overseas contract workers, immigrants and naturalized citizens an opportunity to save for the future and to access a housing loan of as much as 2 million Philippines pesos.
Philippine citizens working overseas can join the Pag-IBIG overseas program by first applying for membership and paying the required monthly contributions.

Last month, Pag-IBIG officials flew to Taiwan to promote the fund's housing projects among OFWs in Taipei, Taichung in central Taiwan, and the southern port city of Kaohsiung. The Pag-IBIG Fund delegation visited factories and dormitories where they gave presentations on the programs and services being offered to OFWs.
In the absence of formal diplomatic ties, MECO is the de-facto embassy of the Republic of Philippines in Taiwan, handling trade and cultural exchanges between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Passengers from grounded Taiwan ship return home safely

TEXT.P: Fifteen passengers who were onboard a Taiwanese supply ship that ran aground off the northern coast of the Philippines several days ago during a storm returned safely to the southern port city of Kaohsiung Sunday.

According to two post-graduate students of National Taiwan Ocean University (NTOU) who were aboard the You Tai No. 1, the ship ran aground Friday on rocks off the coast of Ilocos Norte in the northern Philippines while it was on its way back to Taiwan from a supply trip to the Nansha (Spratly) islands in the South China Sea.
The Kaohsiung-based vessel was carrying 15 passengers and 14 crew members, all of whom were were taken in custody for questioning by the Philippine security authorities.
They were held Friday and Saturday on suspicion of attempting to smuggle goods or to illegally enter Philippines territory, as many of them failed to produce passports, according to the students.

Through the efforts of the Taiwan representative office in the Philippines, the 29 Taiwanese, including NTOU faculty, officials from the Coast Guard Administration, Republic of China Air Force officers and telecommunications engineers, were released late Saturday.

The 15 passengers then took a flight from Manila back to Kaohsiung Sunday, while the 14 crew members remained in the northern Philippines port of Laoag waiting for repairs to the supply ship, which had been towed to Laoag with the assistance of a Taiwanese cement company.

The students said that the ship ran onto the rocks probably because the captain was trying to avoid the storm and he was not familiar with the waters in that area. This led to the You Tai No. 1 unwittingly entering Philippine territorial waters, they said.

The NTOU lecturers and students onboard the ship were returning from the Nansha island archipelago in the South China Sea -- located about 1,600 km from the southernmost tip of Republic of China territory -- where they were conducting research on rare and endangered green turtles.
The ROC has stationed personnel on Taiping island, the largest coral reef in the Nansha Islands, since the 1940s, and they rely on supplies from Taiwan for their operations and daily necessities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to cooperate on air traffic control

TEXT.P: Top civil aviation officials of Taiwan and China will meet in Shanghai in early December to sign an agreement on air traffic control, Taiwan's Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC) confirmed Sunday.

The agreement will be inked between Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration and the Air Traffic Management Bureau of the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC), paving the way for technical cooperation in managing a new direct flight route between the two sides.

The new flight route was made possible through one of four pacts signed in Taipei in early November between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's semi- official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and his Chinese counterpart -- Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, to allow more direct flights between Taiwan and China.
The other three pacts will allow direct shipping links and postal services and the establishment of a food safety mechanism between the two sides.
Civil aviation authorities on both sides of the strait have reportedly already worked out details on future cooperation in managing the flight route.

Sources at the MOTC said the two sides have agreed on a code name -- SULEM -- for the route's connection point between the flight information regions of Taiwan and China in order to divide air control responsibilities.

MOTC officials also disclosed that Song Dexing, director of the Water Transport Department of China's Ministry of Transport, is scheduled to lead a Chinese delegation to visit Taiwan in early December.

According to the officials, Song will meet with Ying Chen-pong, director general of the MOTC's Department of Aviation and Navigation, to discuss a range of issues, including shipping capabilities, search and rescue work in maritime disasters, ship inspection, pollution control and mediation of maritime disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's homosexual males vulnerable to HIV: study

TEXT.P: A survey on homosexual males in Taiwan shows that 90 percent of the recorded 164 HIV-positive men are gay, and that 46 percent had delayed seeing a doctor until they knew they were affected by HIV, according to the results released Sunday.

The survey was conducted by the Center for Disease Control under the Cabinet- level Department of Health. The results were released on the eve of World AIDS Day, which is observed on Dec. 1. to heighten awareness of the AIDS pandemic caused by the spread of HIV infection.

Lo Yi-chun, a medical doctor at the center, disclosed that some of the gay men did not see a doctor until more than six months after an unsafe sexual encounter, or had waited until they developed symptoms of AIDS before seeking treatment.
He said the 46 percent of HIV-positive homosexual males who delayed seeing their doctors is a higher rate compared with other countries, where the rates range between 24 percent and 45 percent.
A previous study by National Taiwan University Hospital showed that delay in seeking diagnosis or treatment of HIV could increase the chances of death by 20 percent to 30 percent.

According to Lo, in his interviews with HIV-positive patients, many admitted that they did not think they would be so unlucky as to contract HIV in a casual sexual encounter because they had only a limited number of sexual partners.

Statistics on new HIV cases in Taiwan compiled by the Center for Disease Control showed that homosexual males accounted for 46 percent of the 728 cases certified as HIV-positive between January and May this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to address train service problems in eastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou pledged Sunday to alleviate public transport service in scenic eastern Taiwan where train tickets for connections to the bustling western part of the country are often extremely hard to obtain.
Ma made the promise while riding on a Taroko tilting train bound for the eastern county of Hualien on a community outreach tour.

"Providing convenient and comprehensive train services for eastern Taiwan residents is one of the government's priority goals and the first target is to alleviate the dire shortage of Taroko train tickets," Ma told reporters covering his Hualien tour.

The eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung are known for their rich tourist resources, particularly their beautiful mountain sceneries and Pacific Ocean landscapes, but transport service connecting the region with the more developed western part of Taiwan has remained inconvenient.

The existing Suhua Highway is vulnerable to landslides during the monsoon season and a controversial plan to build a new freeway linking Hualien with its neighboring northeastern county of Yilan has remained on the drawing board for quite some time due to strong opposition from environmentalists.
In working to improve the eastern Taiwan transportation system, Ma said, priority will be given to expanding train services.
"First of all, the current problem in obtaining Taroko train tickets should be wiped out, " Ma said, adding that this promise should be fulfilled during his first presidential term.
The Taroko tilting trains, which have an operating speed of 130 km/h, have helped cut the travel time from Taipei to Hualien from three hours to two since they were launched last year.

However, at present, travelers are forced to wait up to 90 minutes for a Taipei- Hualien Taroko train, which has prompted complaints from many eastern Taiwan residents about the difficulty in obtaining tickets to go home on major national holidays or festivals.
Ma said the Taiwan Railway Administration has come up with a plan to purchase 48 new Taroko trains to meet transportation demands.
"When all of these new trains are put into service by the end of 2011, the waiting time will be shortened to 40 minutes," Ma said.
Moreover, he said, the government has decided to complete its eastern Taiwan transportation system improvement plan within five years instead of the originally projected seven years.

According to the plan, various train stations in eastern Taiwan will get a facelift or be largely expanded to meet market demand, Ma said, adding that the plan has been included in an economic stimulus package to spur the country's economic growth by expanding domestic demand.

To galvanize eco-tourism in eastern Taiwan, Ma said, the TRA is also spearheading a "train plus cycling" travel plan by collaborating with local governments to build more cycling paths around the island.

Later in the day, Ma addressed a ceremony for the inauguration of a new cycling path near Liyutan Reservoir in Hualien County's Shoufong township, saying the path's opening is congruent with the government's policy and a prevalent social fad.
With the cycling population increasing steadily, Ma said, the government will flesh out a practical cycling policy to offer safe, comfortable and convenient facilities for cycling enthusiasts.

After cycling along the trail, Ma lauded it as a world-class cycling path that boasts beautiful mountain scenery and eco-resources-rich river landscape. He suggested the Hualien county government advertise the new path on domestic and foreign tourism publications to attract tourists from home and abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung landfill slide leaves 1 dead, 1 missing, two injured

TEXT.P: A series of landslides at a landfill retaining wall construction site in the central city of Taichung left one volunteer firefighter dead, one worker missing and two firefighters injured, city officials said Sunday.
The first landslide occurred at around 9 a.m., burying a construction worker identified as Wu Cheng-wei. The search for Wu is still underway as of the press time.
The Taichung city government's Fire Department dispatched a rescue team immediately after it received a distress call.
While Fire Department staff and volunteers were busy searching for the buried worker, there was a second landslide which buried Fu Chia-sen, a volunteer firefighter.

Fu's colleagues then rushed to mount a new search mission. At around 1 p.m., two Fire Department staff members, identified as Lin Hung-yi and Chen Chieh-chi, spotted part of Fu's clothing and tried to pull him out.

However, another landslide hit, causing the pair to sink into the soft dirt. Lin Hung-yi was rescued first and was sent to the nearby Taichung Veterans General Hospital, where it was found that he had sustained only slight injuries.

Chen Chieh-chi, who was buried in dirt from his chest down, was not rescued until around 5 p.m. He complained of acute pain in his legs and was sent to hospital for examination and treatment of his injuries.

The deceased volunteer firefighter, Fu Chia-sen, was the scion of a wealthy family, according to city government sources. Fu first joined the volunteer firefighting service more than 10 years ago and was cited last year as a role model.

Lin Pao-ching, the contractor on the retaining wall reinforcement project, said the landslides were believed to have been caused by water seeping from ready mixed concrete used in the construction of the wall.
On the project, 19 10-meter-high culverts are being built beneath the landfill. Because of the softness of soil in the region, land excavation is being done manually rather than by machines.
City government officials said they will conduct a thorough investigation to determine who should be held accountable for the tragic accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interior minister visits family of dead volunteer firefighter

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi on Sunday paid a visit to the family of Fu Chia-sen, a volunteer firefighter who was killed during a search and rescue mission at a landfill construction site in the central city of Taichung earlier that day, to express his condolences.

Fu, the scion of a wealth family, was pronounced death on arrival when he was finally pulled out of dirt from landslides at the landfill retaining wall construction site in suburban Taichung, city officials said.

Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Jia-chi, who accompanied Liao on the visit to Fu's home, said that although Fu was a volunteer, the city government will offer the best possible compensation for Fu's family in terms of regulations applicable to formal Fire Department staff members because he sacrificed his life in his efforts to rescue others.
Fu first joined the volunteer firefighting service more than 10 years ago and was cited last year as a role model.
Liao and Hsiao also visited Taichung Veterans General Hospital to extend their regards to two Fire Department staff members who were injured in the landslides at the construction site.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of Chinese tourist arrivals falls short of target

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourist arrivals is not expected to break the 100,000 mark this year, given the less-tha-ideal figure recorded for the first 11 months of the year, immigration officials said Sunday.

In 2006 when Chinese citizens were only allowed to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan via a third place, the number of Chinese tourist arrivals once set a record of more than 100,000, according to government statistics.

Following a thawing in bilateral ties since the inauguration of China-friendly Kuomintang government in May this year, the two sides came to terms on full opening of Taiwan for Chinese tourists and on launch of direct cross-strait charter flights to facilitate civilian exchanges.
However, the number of Chinese tourists has not increased as significantly as expected.
Even in October when Chinese citizens enjoyed a weeklong holiday, the number of Chinese tourist arrivals only totaled 11,797, far below the projected target.

According to tallies compiled by the National Immigration Agency, about 68,000 Chinese citizens visited Taiwan in the first 10 months of this year. If the daily number of Chinese tourist arrivals was estimated at 400 in November, the total number for the first 11 months will be about 80,000, falling far short of the target, immigration officials said.
Amid the lingering global financial turmoil and economic recession, the officials said, the number of Chinese arrivals is not expected to increase substantially in December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Body of buried worker at Taichung landfill recovered

TEXT.P: The body of a worker who was buried in dirt from landslides at a landfill construction site in the central city of Taichung for more than 10 hours was recovered late Sunday after many twists and turns, city officials said.
Wu Cheng-wei showed no vital signs when his body was pulled out of dirt at 11 p.m., and he was pronounced death on arrival (DOA) after being rushed to nearby Taichung Veterans General Hospital.

Wu was the first to be buried in a series of landslides at the suburban site where a landfill retaining wall reinforcement project was underway, but he was the last to be recovered from the dirt because subsequent landslides claimed another victim and injured two municipal Fire Department staff members.
Wu was buried when the first landslide hit at around 9 a.m. Sunday.
The city government's Fire Department dispatched a rescue team immediately after it received a distress call.
While Fire Department staff and volunteers were busy searching for Wu, there was a second landslide which buried Fu Chia-sen, a volunteer firefighter.

Fu's colleagues then rushed to mount a new search mission. At around 1 p.m., two Fire Department staff members, identified as Lin Hung-yi and Chen Chieh-chi, spotted part of Fu's clothing and tried to pull him out.

However, another landslide hit, causing the pair to sink into the soft dirt. Lin Hung-yi was rescued first and was sent to the nearby Taichung Veterans General Hospital, where it was found that he had sustained only slight injuries.

Chen Chieh-chi, who was buried in dirt from his chest down, was not rescued until around 5 p.m. He complained of acute pain in his legs and was sent to hospital for examination and treatment of his injuries.
Fu Chia-sen was also pulled out of the dirt at 5: 35 p.m., but he showed no vital signs. He was pronounced DOA after being sent to the hospital.

Lin Pao-ching, the contractor on the retaining wall reinforcement project, said the landslides were believed to have been caused by water seeping from ready mixed concrete used in the construction of the wall.
On the project, 19 10-meter-high culverts are being built beneath the landfill. Because of the softness of soil in the region, land excavation is being done manually rather than by machines.
City government officials said they will conduct a thorough investigation to determine who should be held accountable for the tragic accident.
