DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 1, or the fourth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: Portugal becomes independent again after the Portuguese under the leadership of John IV drive out the Spaniards.
1887: Portugal secures the secession of Macau from China's Ching court.
1918: The Danish parliament passes an act giving independence to Iceland.
1921: With the United States and Britain as mediators, representatives of China and Japan hold negotiations on the issue of the Shantung dispute on the sidelines of a meeting in Washington.
1922: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Manchu dynasty, and Wan Yung, daughter of Yung Yuan, a former minister in the Ching court, hold their wedding ceremony in Beijing's Forbidden City.
1927: The Republic of China's Chiang Kai-shek and Soong Mayling hold a wedding ceremony witnessed by Tsai Yuan-pei in Shanghai.
1932: The government of the Republic of China, which was moved to Loyang on Jan. 30 due to the Japanese invasion, moves back to Nanjing.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the Kuomintang, the ruling party of China.
1936: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung, Chu Teh, and Chou En-lai, send a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek asking him to allow the CCP to join the war against Japan to save the country.
1951: Communist Chinese troops enter Lhasa, Tibet.
1956: Chiang Kai-shek finishes his book titled "Soviet Russia in China."
1959: Twelve members of the United Nations, including the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, Japan, and France, sign a treaty in Washington stipulating that the South Pole region will be used for peaceful purposes such as scientific exploration and that no military bases will be allowed.
1961: The first nuclear reactor in the Republic of China, installed by scientists from the National Tsinghua University campus in Hsinchu, is put into operation.
1962: India rejects mainland Chinese proposals for a cease-fire and negotiations over disputed territory.
1969: The ROC government sets up the Armed Forces University, with Yu Po-chuen serving as commandant and Chiang Wei-kuo as vice commandant.
1971: A total of 43 miners of the Keelung Coalmine Company are killed in an accident at the Chisingkeng mine in northern Taiwan.
1972: The ROC and Ivory Coast sign a trade agreement.
1973: A total of 14 seamen go missing when the Tatung, a freighter plying the route between the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung and Makung, in the Penghu archipelago, sinks.
1973: The Kuomintang selects 45 candidates for the Taipei City Council election. Sixty-three candidates fight for 49 seats.
1976: A metalworking trade mission representing leading U.S. companies arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: Jurisdiction of the Central Bank of China is moved from the Presidential Office to the Executive Yuan.
1987: Eight people are killed in a fire blamed on arson at a job-training center on the ROC-controlled Green Island.
1987: The Ministry of Education announces that National Chungcheng University will be established in Minhsiung Village, Chiayi County and will begin admitting students in the 1989 academic year.
1988: Benazir Bhutto is nominated to be prime minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman elected to govern a Muslim nation.
1988: The Executive Yuan announces guidelines governing unofficial participation in international academic conferences and cultural and athletic activities held in mainland China, as well as regulations governing visits to Taiwan by overseas mainland Chinese scholars and students.
1989: Mikhail Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit the Vatican and meet the Pope, ending 70 years of mutual hostility between the USSR and the Vatican.
1999: The first batch of the two-in-one lottery tickets issued by the Central Bank of China go on sale, causing a buying spree around the island.
2001: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) loses its position as the largest party in the legislature at the legislative election, winning only 68 seats as compared with the 87 seats won by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Motse's lesson of the day: "There are many rulers in the world but few are magnanimous. For everybody to imitate the ruler is to imitate the unmagnanimous. Imitating the unmagnanimous cannot be taken as following the right standard."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Suspect could ask for protection: chief prosecutor

TEXT.P: A suspect, who tried to kill herself Saturday after being interrogated over her possible role in alleged graft cases involving the ex-first family, could ask for protection if necessary, a top prosecutor said Monday.

Chen Yun-nan, chief of the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, said the division has told the family of Tu Li-ping that if necessary, the division could provide her with abodyguard.

Tu, a board member of Yuanta Securities, attempted to commit suicide by taking sleeping pills and inhaling car exhaust fumes one day after she was released by the Taipei District Court on bail of NT$1 million (US$303,303).

Before she attempted self-asphyxiation, Tu reportedly made a cellphone call to her elder sister to confide what she was about to do. The sister then called an ambulance which rushed Tu to a hospital near her home in Taipei County for treatment.

Upon learning of Tu's suicide attempt, Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng urged her Monday to cherish her own health so that she can be strong to fight for justice and clear her name in the days to come.
Wang also said that if necessary, Tu could file for protection with the Special Investigation Division.

According to Wang, the division extended special protection to former president Chen Shui-bian's cashier Chen Chen-hui after she was freed without conditions Nov. 20. Chen Chen-hui was detained Sept. 25 because of her suspected role in helping to transfer a presidential fund and bribes to overseas bank accounts of the former first family.
Wang also censured Tu's lawyer Tan Hu for disclosing to the media the details of Tu's interrogation after she was released on bail.
The minister said Tan had violated the Act of Lawyers and reneged on the code of ethics and norms observed by lawyers.

Tan told the media last week that Tu, accompanied her Yuanta Securities bosses, visited former President Chen Shui-bian's residence sometime in 2005 and handed NT$200 million (US$6.06 million) to Chen's wife Wu Shu-jen in the hope that the then first family would not intervene in a buyout project in which Yuanta was involved.
"Tu and her boss were just trying to persuade the then first family not to intervene and to allow the market to work. Tu was not offering a bribe," the lawyer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local airline launches Kaohsiung-Seoul scheduled service
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/08 14:36:56 (By Chiang Yuang-chen and Jian Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Mandarin Airlines will begin direct regularly scheduled flights between Kaohsiung and Seoul starting Dec. 1, in an expansion of its current charter service on the route, according to an airline official

Mandarin Airlines, which operates the only service on the route, will provide five regularly scheduled flights per week between Kaohsiung International Airport and Seoul's Incheon International Airport, according to Yiang Tzung-da, general manager of the Korean branch of China Airlines which is Mandarin Airlines' parent company.
The expanded service comes in the wake of Mandarin Airlines' offer of two charters a week on the route from Oct. 29 to Nov. 30 for tour groups.
Taiwan's Uni Air, which previously operated regularly scheduled flights between the southern Taiwan port city and the Korean capital, canceled the route Aug. 16 due to cost considerations.

Industry analyst said that the reopening of the route is important in light of the fact that Kaohsiung will host the World Games next July, which is Taiwan's first opportunity to host a major international sports competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung MRT services to be extended on New Year's Eve

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung MRT's operating hours will be extended on Dec. 31 for the convenience of residents taking part in the southern port city's various New Year's Eve celebrations, the municipal government's Transit Bureau and Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) said Monday.
Huang Yi-chung, director of the KRTC's Public Affairs Department, said MRT train services will run until 2 a.m., instead of the usual 11:30 p.m.

Huang said that although there is no MRT station adjacent to the square outside the Dream Mall where one of the main New Year's Eve activities will be held, shuttle bus services will be offered from the site to nearby stations to accommodate people attending the celebration.
The municipal government has estimated that some 300,000 Kaohsiung residents will take part in the various New Year's Eve activities to be held around the city.
Huang said that the KRTC will strive to offer the best transportation services to and from the various sites of these celebrations, including a planned concert at Kaohsiung Arena.

The New Year's Eve party outside the Dream Mall is scheduled to start at 6 p.m. and run through 1 a.m., with several top singers slated to perform, including the main act -- the legendary Taiwanese rock star Wubai.

The municipal government's Department of Information, which has already begun planning for the event, said the site of the New Year's Eve party along Dream Mall Boulevard between Cheng Kung Road and Chungshan Road will be able to accommodate up to 100,000 revelers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chief economic planner stakes his job on success of voucher policy

TEXT.P: The country's chief economic planner put his job on the line Monday by promising to step down if a shopping voucher program crafted by his office boosts economic growth by less than half of his estimate.

Chen Tain-jy, chief of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, told the Legislative Yuan that he stands by the estimate made by his council that the shopping vouchers program will boost the gross domestic product (GDP) by 0.64 percent next year.

Chen said that although no economic policy can be executed as comprehensively as expected, he would resign from his post if the program failed to boost the economy by less than half of his council's forecast.
He made the promise while fielding questions from lawmakers who claimed that a similar program in Japan in 1999 boosted that county's GDP by only 0.1 percent.
Chen said the difference lies in the fact that Japan's national income is much higher than Taiwan's.

Under Taiwan's program, the Executive Yuan will give shopping vouchers worth NT$3600 to each citizen before the Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 26, to prompt consumption in hopes that it will in turn fuel economic growth.
The country's economy dipped to negative growth in the third quarter of this year and is expected to remain in negative for the next two quarters.

As a result, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics on Nov. 21 adjusted its forecast for economic growth downward from 5.08 percent to 2.12 percent for this year and from 4.3 percent to 1.86 percent for next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: No obvious lay-off trend at Hsinchu Science Park

TEXT.P: There has been no obvious tide of lay-offs among companies in the Hsinchu Science Park in the face of slumping export trade as a result of the global economic downturn, Tu Chi-hsiang, a deputy chief of the science park, said Monday.

Responding to a recent series of news reports on salary cuts and redundancies by companies in the country's science-based industrial parks, Tu said that so far, he has not seen an obvious lay-off trend at the Hsinchu facility, known as "Taiwan's Silicon Valley."

Tu also noted that the number of disputes in the park has not increased this year, adding that the science park authorities received 45 complaints about possible disputes between management and workers in the first 11 months of this year, compared to 47 in 2007.

According to recent business and industrial news reports, major high-technology manufacturers have witnessed slides in their production line utilization rates over the past several months. Among them, United Microelectronics Corp. and Vanguard International Semiconductor Corp. have seen utilization rates fall to a record low of 55 percent.
Chipmakers such as Powerchip and ProMOS have also cut production due to decreased demand from home and abroad, according to the reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC decides to lower cable TV rates of 8 providers

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) decided Monday to lower the basic cable TV rates of eight cable service providers in six counties around Taiwan from the start of next year.

The monthly rates of the cable providers in the counties of Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu will be lowered by between NT$20 (US$0.60) and NT$50 from Jan. 1, according to the NCC decision.
The six counties are the only ones in Taiwan that have not set up committees to regulate cable TV rates, so they are subject to review by the NCC.
The rate cuts of between NT$20-50 will translate into savings of NT$240 to NT$600 per year for customers.

The Taipei municipal government decided on Nov. 28 to maintain basic cable TV rates in the city at NT$530 per month, while reducing rates for low income households from one-third of the regular rate to one-fourth, effective from Jan. 1 of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chaoliao junior high students hospitalized after suspected gas leak

TEXT.P: More than twenty students at Chaoliao Junior High School in Kaohsiung County were sent to hospital for treatment Monday morning after a suspected gas leak in the vicinity of the school.
Kaohsiung Municipal Hsiao-Kang Hospital, where seven of the female students were sent, said that they were treated for nausea and dizziness but were not suffering from any serious ailments.
The hospital said the students were put on intravenous drips and placed under observation, adding that their condition was not life threatening.

Kuo Hung-chu, principal of the school which is located next to the Ta Fa Industrial District, said that shortly after 8 a.m. several faculty members and students on the campus suddenly noticed a strange gaseous odor similar to that of a pesticide and that soon after many students began experiencing tightness in the chest, dizziness and even vomiting.
The more seriously affected students were immediately sent to various hospitals in the area, while those with less severe symptoms were allowed to rest in their respective classrooms, Kuo said.

For safety, all the students were evacuated to the nearby Kao Ying Industrial Vocational High School library at around 10: 30 a.m., while the Kaohsiung City Fire Bureau and Environmental Protection Bureau investigated the source of the suspected gas leak at the school.

DOC.HEADLINE: President meets U.S. think tank officials

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou welcomed Strobe Talbott, president of the Brookings Institution and Richard Bush, former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, at the Presidential Office Monday and described their visit to Taiwan as significant.

Talbott and Bush are visiting Taiwan to attend a seminar titled Cross- Strait Political and Economic Relations and the Next American Administration, arranged by the Epoch Foundation, a local research institution that seeks to integrate the resources of the private sector with the world's best academic institutions and resources. It focuses its research on Taiwanese industrial and economic issues, regional economic cooperation and the region's economic outlook.

"Given that the 2008 presidential election in the U.S. has just been completed and that the new administration will take office in January next year, your visit to Taiwan at this time has a very important meaning for us," Ma said.
He also commented that Talbott is very experienced in media, foreign diplomacy and government work.
"Your work has made the Brookings Institute one of the leading and very important public policy research institutes in the United States, " Ma added.
In addition, he also praised Richard Bush's familiarity with Taiwan issues, Chinese affairs and cross-strait issues.
"Your book, Untying the Knot, has won wide confirmation, " said Ma. "The developments between Taiwan and mainland China for the past three years have coincided with your predictions," he went on.

Richard Bush is director of the Brookings Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies (CNAPS) . His two-decade public service career spans Congress, the intelligence community and the U.S. State Department, and includes a stint as chairman and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan from 1997 to 2002.
CNAPS conducts research, analysis and outreach to enhance policy development and understanding on the political, economic and security issues facing Northeast Asia.
Talbott, an expert in U.S. foreign relations, is a journalist associated with Time magazine and a diplomat who served as deputy secretary of state from 1994 to 2001 during the Clinton administration.
He has also been involved with the America Abroad Media Advisory Board, the American Academy of Diplomacy, the Bretton Woods Committee, the Council on Foreign Relations and the Trilateral Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.055 to close at NT$33.350.
A total of US$675 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.295 and fluctuated between NT$33.285 and NT$33.370.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for December advancing 42 points to end at 4,501, with 106,517 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for January gained 51 points to finish at 4,461, with 807 contracts traded, while March futures increased 73 points to close at 4,435 with 38 contracts changing hands.
June futures rose 138 points to end at 4,451, with 49 contract transactions, while September futures rose 43 points to finish at 4,193, with 10 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 4,459 for December, 4,410 for January, 4,362 for March, 4,313 for June and 4,150 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 57.94 points to finish at 4,518.43, on turnover of NT$66.88 billion (US$2.01 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

December TE futures rose 0.3 points to close at 168.55, with 5,586 contracts traded, while January TE futures increased 0.5 points to finish at 166, with 69 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

December TF futures gained 14.4 points to finish at 555.8, with 5,871 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures increased 18.4 points to finish at 550.8, with 47 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice premier call for cross-strait financial supervision MOU

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said Monday that there is a need for the two sides of Taiwan Strait to sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on financial supervision to facilitate financial services exchanges and cooperation.
Chiu made the remarks in an address at the opening of the 2008 Conference on Cross-Strait Banking and Finance, a two-day event held at the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance.

The two sides already maintain close cooperative relations in economy and trade, and therefore each also has the need for frequent exchanges in the financial sector. However, Chiu went on, the two sides have yet to sign a financial supervision MOU, so that there are still many restrictions on financial business exchanges between the two sides.

Citing government statistics, Chiu pointed out that bilateral trade reached US$56.7 billion in the first six months of the year, and that as of the end of June, Taiwanese businesses had invested some US$70 billion in China, reflecting the frequent capital inflow and outflow between the two sides.

The vice premier noted that the two sides of the strait have opened their financial markets to the world under World Trade Organization regulations. He said it is unavoidable that the two sides will develop closer financial ties, as the number of Taiwan's listed companies with investments in China has reached more than 900, accounting for over 70 percent of all listed companies in Taiwan, while there are currently seven Taiwanese financial institutions and 13 stock traders with representative offices in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese student recruitment not aimed at boosting enrollment: MOE

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Monday that a government plan to open Taiwan's doors to students from China is not aimed at addressing the sliding enrollment rates facing most of the country's privately run colleges and universities.

Ho Chuo-fei, deputy director of the MOE Department of Higher Education, said the ministry has mapped out several plans on the opening measures in response to President Ma Ying-jeou's Oct. 5 announcement of the plan.

He made the remarks at an MOE-sponsored forum held at National Taiwan University on the possible impact on local society and its education system in the event that Chinese students are allowed to pursue advanced studies and sit tests in Taiwan to obtain Taiwanese professional licenses.
A number of representatives of public and privately run colleges and universities were invited to attend the forum, where they spelled out a variety of opinions on the issue.

Some of the representatives suggested that privately run institutes should be allowed first to recruit Chinese students in an effort to bolster sagging enrollment numbers, while others suggested that Taiwan first open its doors to postgraduate students from China.
Sun Shu-ping, provost of I-Shou University in the southern county of Kaohsiung, made a keynote speech at the forum on the institute's own experiences in hosting students from China.

I-Shou is a unique case, as it has since January 2007 accepted students from 12 Chinese universities, including the prestigious Shangdong and Xiamen universities, for short term training and academic exchange programs.
Sun said that after hosting some 300 of the students, the university has found that management of their daily lives, their behavior and their mental condition can prove problematic.

According to Ma, Taiwan will open its doors to Chinese students seeking to pursue advanced studies but will not allow them to sit tests in Taiwan to obtain Taiwanese professional licenses. He added that the policy is aimed at liberalizing and globalizing Taiwan's educational environment.
The president said that while the policy means that colleges and universities will be allowed to recruit Chinese students, the administration will not push or encourage them to do so.

Noting that China now has over 2,500 colleges and universities, some of which rank among the leading educational institutes in the world, Ma said Taiwan will leave itself a laughing stock if it continues to close its doors and turn its back on world opinion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visually impaired runners to take part in round-Taiwan relay

TEXT.P: Five visually impaired runners will take part in a 1,100-km relay around Taiwan, hoping to raise public awareness of the welfare of the disabled and to encourage the physically challenged not to lose hope, the race organizers announced Monday.

Named "See Hope at the Intersection, " the round-island relay will be a challenge for the five runners, said Wu Hsing-chuan at a press conference. Wu is the coach and running companion of Chang Wen-yan, one of the runners, who has been dubbed "Taiwan's Forrest Gump" after the hero of the eponymously titled Hollywood movie who ran his way into audiences' hearts.
Each of the runners will be tethered by the wrist to a sighted running companion who will act as guide, keeping the runners on track.

Wu added that the five blind runners -- all of whom make their livings as masseurs -- lost their sight due to accidents or genetic diseases, at which point they found themselves at an intersection in their lives, unsure of which direction to follow.
"It is difficult to run when you cannot see, but let there be no destination, " Wu went on, encouraging the runners to remember the spirit of the marathon, which is perseverance.
Himself an experienced runner, Chang has competed in many races with Wu in the United States and Japan, and together they have even climbed Taiwan's highest peak, the 3,952-meter Mount Jade.

The runners will start the ambitious relay from the top of the Taipei 101 building -- Taiwan's highest building -- on Dec 13. Maintaining a pace of about 100 km per day, they are expected to arrive back in Taipei at a downtown shopping mall Dec 25.
Each of them will need to run for around 20 km per day, every day, Wu noted.

A documentary team will also accompany the runners to record their 13-day journey, which is being organized by the Taiwan Ahgan Spiritual Development Association and the Soroptimist International of the Taiwan Region, with assistance from the Ministry of the Interior, the Sports Affairs Council and various non-government organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices finished higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 57.94 points, or 1.29 percent, to close at 4,518.43.

Posting gains for the fifth consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,436.12 and fluctuated between 4,567.76 and 4,418.24. A total of 4.20 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$66.88 billion (US$2.01 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial stocks moving up the most at 4.02 percent. Foodstuff issues as well as paper and pulp stocks both gained 2.98 percent, construction stocks advanced 2.5 percent, plastics and chemical shares were up 1.64 percent, textile stocks advanced 1.33 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 0.49 percent, and cement shares were up 0.39 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 943 to 405, with 338 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$3.10 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax deductions from 2008 individual income to be increased

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has reached consensus with lawmakers screening amendments to the Income Tax Act that the four increased individual income tax deductions allowed by the amendments will be applicable in May 2009 when taxpayers file their 2008 returns, Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der disclosed Monday.
Lee made the disclosure to reporters after giving a report before the Finance Committee of the legislature on the proposed amendments to Clause One of Article Five, Article 17 and Article 126.

According to Lee, the Ministry of Finance plans to increase the standard tax deduction from individual income from the current NT$46,000 to NT$60,000 for an unmarried taxpayer and from NT$92,000 to NT$120,000 for a married couple.

A salary or wage earner's special deduction will be increased from NT$78,000 per salary or wage earner to NT$NT$100,000, while the deduction for the disabled will also be raised from the current NT$77,000 per disabled person to NT$100,000.
The proposed amendments will also grant a deduction of NT$25,000 per student in each household for higher education expenses, instead of the current NT$25,000 for each tax return.

The Ministry of Finance has estimated that the four increased deductions would affect 3.6 million families in Taiwan, accounting for 69 percent of the 5.18 million households that file tax returns each year.

According to law, the amendments adopted in 2008 should be implemented only in 2010, making them good for the 2009 income tax returns. But legislators of the ruling Kuomintang said this will not be a problem, because they will introduce another amendment to allow the newly increased deductions to be applied to the 2008 tax year.
Individual income tax is levied on Taiwan-source income of both resident and non-resident individuals per calendar year.

Individuals are considered residents in Taiwan for tax purposes if they are Republic of China citizens or if they are foreign nationals who reside in Taiwan for at least 183 days within a calendar year.
They are subject to income tax on all their incomes which originate in Taiwan and must file income tax returns and pay taxes between May 1 and 31 of the following year.

The incomes of the taxpayer, taxpayer's spouse, and dependents must be consolidated and reported on one income tax return. Resident taxpayers are allowed to claim personal exemptions and deductions on their tax returns.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan donates flood relief goods to Panama
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Nov. 30 (CNA) 12/01/08 19:06:11 (By Raymon Huang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has donated 600 blankets and 600 boxes of dried food to Panama to assist Panamanians who have suffered from last month's floods, the Republic of China's ambassador, Simon Ko, said Sunday.
Ko said he has presented the donations to the office of Panama's first lady, which will help distribute the supplies.
The donation includes contributions from the Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce, the association of Taiwanese expatriates in Panama, and Taiwan-based Mega International Commercial Bank, Ko said.

The donation is just the first wave of Taiwan's relief aid to Panama. Taiwan's technical aid group in Panama will donate self-produced dried fruits and processed foods next week and will continue making donations based on the condition of flood affected areas, Ko said.

According to the latest reports by Panama's national civil protection service, the most seriously affected areas are the Caribbean coastal province of Bocas del Toro in western Panama and Pacific coastal province of Darien in eastern Panama. Indigenous people who lived in poorly built housing in those areas are the worst affected.
Flood waters have left eight dead and six missing. About 11,670 people in the province of Bocas del Toro have had to stay in temporary shelters due to the flooding.

Infrastructure in Panama Province, which contains the country's capital city, was also damaged by heavy and incessant rains that began Nov. 20. Two major outbound highways in Panama City were blocked due to mudslides, and the Panama government is making urgent repairs to the damaged roads, the reports said.
According to Rodrigo Cigarruista, Panama's vice interior minister, the country's relief forces have distributed food, water, medicine and blankets to people in affected areas by plane.
A total of 21 aircraft have been dispatched to carry out relief service, including six helicopters from the United States and two airplanes from Columbia, Cigarruista said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Philippines seeks Taiwanese investment

TEXT.P: The Philippines government has been setting up special economic zones and providing incentives such as tax exemptions in a bid to attract more foreign investors, officials at an investment opportunities seminar told participants in Taipei Monday.

The Philippine Investment Opportunities Seminar was held by the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) in Taiwan and the Philippine Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) in Taipei Monday with the aim of attracting Taiwanese investors to the Philippines.

Speaking at the seminar, Philippine Economic Zone Authority (PEZA) Director- General Lilia B. de Lima, who is also the undersecretary of his country's Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) , gave a detailed description of the Philippines investment environment.

"Over the past years, we have attracted many large investments to the Philippines, " said Lima."Large manufacturers in the world, such as electronics, household appliance, computer hardware and garment makers, have set up factories in our country."

Noting that in 2007, the Philippines posted economic growth of 7.3 percent, the highest in three decades, Lima urged Taiwan investors to take advantage of the incentives being offered by countries in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) free trade group.

"The original member countries of the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA), which includes the Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia and Brunei, will lower their tariffs to near zero, thus removing trade barriers within AFTA in the year 2010," Lima said.
AFTA's four new member countries, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and Myanmar, will do the same in 2015, he added.

"Therefore if Taiwan businesses do not have factories set up within these countries, then tariff-wise, it will be a great disadvantage to Taiwan entrepreneurs," said Lima. "I recommend the Philippines as a great place for Taiwan businessmen to set up factories so that tariffs may be avoided."

According to MECO, other incentives offered by the Philippines government for foreigners who want to invest in the country include a special investor's Residence Visa that can be extended to immediate members of the family and income tax holidays (ITH) of 6 years for pioneer firms and 4 years for non- pioneer firms. After the ITH period expires, there will be an option to pay a special 5 percent tax on gross income, in lieu of national and local taxes, it added.
During the investment seminar, undersecretary of the Philippines Department of Tourism Phineas Alburo said that the country's tourism industry has experienced rapid growth in recent years.

"In the past five years, the number of tourists visiting the Philippines has grown by 12.9 percent," said Alburo. "In the year 2007 alone, the number of tourists coming to our country topped 3 million."
Alburo said that the tourism industry is the biggest source of income for the Philippines.

"Right now, the Philippines' tourism industry is still growing at an astonishing pace," said Alburo."Therefore, the hotels and resorts in Philippines require large amounts of capital investment so that they could expand and satisfy the growing demand."

According to Alburo, business opportunities in the Philippine hospitality industry is on the upswing, as hotel and resort occupancy rates in major tourist destinations reached 75-80 percent on a year round basis.
As a result, investments in the tourism industry have been flowing into the country, he added.

According to statistics provided by MECO, the Philippines Department of Tourism in 2006 approved investments totalling a record high 93.8 billion Philippine pesos (about US$2.08 billion) , and in the first quarter of 2007 approved investments of 9.52 billion Philippine pesos (or about US$ 210 million).
Major international groups such as Banyan Tree, Marriott Hotel and Raffles Hotel are starting to invest in the Philippines, MECO added.

Also, a consortium made up of the Trump Organization -- headed by American business Mogul Donald Trump -- American Westgate Resorts Asia Ltd. and the Korean Heung-A Property Group will be investing in a US$1 billion tourism project in Subic Bay in the Philippines, MECO stated.

Alburo said that the Philippines government continues to focus on the requirements of the tourism industry by putting in place major infrastructure projects such as international and domestic airports, seaports and roadways to connect the 7,107 islands of the Philippines.
In the absence of formal diplomatic ties, MECO is the de-facto embassy of the Republic of Philippines in Taiwan, handling trade and cultural exchanges between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Large number of new graduates still seeking jobs: survey

TEXT.P: Forty-five percent of fresh graduates in Taiwan who responded to a recent survey said they had not found full-time employment, despite many of them having started seeking jobs some considerable time before graduating.

Although 52 percent of the respondents said they started looking for jobs before graduating in June, 45 percent said they had not succeeded in finding a full- time job as of November, according to the results of the survey released Monday.
The survey was carried out Nov. 14-28 by the online employment service provider 1111 Job Bank among people who graduated from senior high schools or tertiary education institutes this summer.

The figure for unsuccessful job-hunters was nearly double that of the year- earlier level, when 23.12 percent of fresh graduates said in similar survey conducted in December 2007 that they were still looking for full-time work.
The poll also found that 63 percent of the new graduates who responded remained jobless as of November. Of the total, 18 percent said they had found employment but had quit for a variety of reasons.
Of the respondents still looking for jobs, nearly 66 percent said they had never worked in a part-time job, representing an increase of 20.5 percent year-on- year.
This figure shows that fewer jobless people have been taking part-time jobs this year than last year, according to the 1111 pollsters.
Of the new graduates now working full time, 42.89 percent said they are planning to change jobs after Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 26, 2009. Last December, the figure stood at 57.73 percent.
Nearly 52 percent of the fresh graduates who are now working said they had not changed jobs, the survey found.

On average, the new graduates who have been in full-time work since graduating but who have since left their jobs had changed jobs 1.67 times over the past five months, compared to two times last year, according to the survey results.
Of the reasons for quitting, 31.44 percent mentioned failure of the job to meet their expectations, 17.85 percent mentioned long working hours and 16.15 percent mentioned excessive work pressure.
Another 15.58 percent mentioned a desire to find another job with higher pay and better benefits, while 14.45 percent said they left their job as a result of being laid off.
The survey results also show that the starting monthly salaries of successful job-seekers averaged NT$25,726 (US$780) this year, compared to the NT$27,974 listed as the average expected salary.
The survey obtained 1,346 valid responses with a margin of error of 2.67 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90 percent of vouchers will be consumed: CEPD head

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chen Tain-jy said Monday he is optimistic that there will be smooth delivery and widespread use of the NT$3,600 (US$180) shopping vouchers that will be issued to each Taiwanese resident on Jan. 18.
Chen said he is confident that as high as 95 percent of the vouchers to be issued would be delivered to the public if no problems occur in the process and about 90 percent would be spent.
The CEPD head made the remarks while answering questions from lawmakers at a joint intepellation session of the economics, interior and finance committees at the Legislative Yuan.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Kung Wen-chi urged the Cabinet to take action to ensure the distribution of the vouchers to residents in the mountainous areas and on outlying islands and to further educate the public about their use.
Kung also suggested the government extend its originally scheduled deadline for the use of the shopping vouchers from Sept. 30 to Oct. 31. next year to give the public more time to spend them.

According to Vice Minister of the Interior Chien Tai-lang's report to the legislature, the shopping vouchers could be given to the public through more than 14,000 distribution spots scattered across the country by Jan. 18, as long as the bill clears the Legislative Yuan in time.

The vouchers will be distributed to some 23.01 million Taiwanese citizens with registered households in Taiwan, as well as some 14,000 Taiwan nationals who do not have household registration but who have obtained residence permission and more than 75,000 Chinese mainlanders who have obtained permanent residence here.

In addition, around 67,000 foreign spouses and 741 spouses from Hong Kong and Macau married to Taiwanese nationals who own permanent residence will also be included in the program once the measure takes effect, Chien said.

As a means of propping up the economy, the Cabinet announced in November that the government will distribute an estimated NT$83.5 billion (US$2.52 billion) in consumption vouchers to the public before Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 26.
All residents in Taiwan, regardless of income level or age, will each receive NT$3,600 in coupons, which can be used to purchase goods at local stores and traditional markets.

The Cabinet has proposed a special bill to provide a legal basis for the voucher policy. According to Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, the special statute has to be approved by the legislature by Dec. 26 at the latest, if the Jan. 18 deadline for issuing the consumption vouchers is to be met.
The distribution of the vouchers is slated to end on April 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese character festival kicks off in Taipei

TEXT.P: A Chinese character festival kicked off in Taipei Monday, with a wide variety of activities designed to emphasize the cultural and educational value of traditional Chinese characters, as well as to promote their use as inspiration for the creative industry, according to the organizers.

Taipei City Department of Cultural Affairs Commissioner Lee Yong- ping told a press conference that unlike various forums and exhibitions on the topic that have been held regularly over the past few years, this year's event also features programs that demonstrate how Chinese characters can be applied to various aspects of life.
As modern traditional Chinese writing has evolved from pictographic characters, she said, their forms "contain a strong artistic sense, " which can serve as inspiration for creative design.

Lee said that with the global trend of learning the Chinese language gaining momentum, Taiwan should not regard traditional characters only as "functional meaning carriers, " but also as a modern artistic medium.

With this in mind, the festival -- which is taking place in various different venues throughout the city until Jan. 11 next year -- includes a creative market, which she said will surprise visitors when they see "the diversity of items evolved from Chinese characters that can be created."

In addition, Lee invited the public to take part in a calligraphy writing activity at the Huashan Creative and Cultural Park -- site of part of the festival -- which she hopes will attract at least 10,000 participants in an attempt to break the world record for the largest number of calligraphers working at the same time.

Lee said the festival also features civic forums on Chinese language, in particular a discussion on the blend of Oriental elements in Taiwan's popular music scene, a trend that has piqued the interest of Taiwan's lyricists and composers in appreciating traditional literature, to which some of them now turn for inspiration.

Temple tours, as well as traditional opera and music performances, are other highlights of the festival, while Huang Chuan-chin, one of the organizers, said this year's program also includes a fashion design show with a concept based on the shapes of Chinese characters or the strokes of Chinese calligraphy, along with the use of traditional design techniques such as printing, dying and embroidery.
He added that the festival also has a section in which foreigners can learn the rudiments of the traditional artform of Chinese brush calligraphy.

With Taiwan one of the few remaining countries that still use traditional Chinese characters rather than the simplified form developed in China, Yang Du, secretary-general of the National Cultural Association, said the country should take advantage of its heritage by developing a branch of the cultural and creative industry centered on Taiwan's writing system.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA encourages donation of secondhand computers to remote regions

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Monday commended several donors of secondhand computers that were used to benefit children in remote areas of Taiwan, and it urged more people to join the resource recycling campaign.

EPA Minister Shen Shu-hung said a total of 19,414 used computers and 15,929 computer monitors, donated mainly by government agencies, universities and private enterprises, have been recycled this year.

The recycled items were reconfigured into 7,210 computers by engineers of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research and then given to children in elementary schools and junior high schools in remote regions around the country.
In all, 4,756 children and 149 social welfare organizations have benefited from the program.

According to the EPA, it was difficult to help install the more than 7,000 computers in remote areas, as engineers and volunteers had to contact potential recipients one-by-one, and access to the areas was often blocked because of the many typhoons that occurred this year.

Hua-yuan Elementary School in Hsinchu County in northern Taiwan and a nongovernmental organization advocating the rights of indigenous people were among those groups receiving the most used computers under the program.

The school and the advocacy group expressed their gratitude for the rebuilt computers at the ceremony, saying that the policy not only benefited the environment but also underprivileged children, who will now have equal access to information from around the world.
Shen said Taiwan's recycling rate has reached about 40 percent this year, ranking high compared to developed countries, and hoped local residents would continue to support environmental efforts.
"Resource recycling is an indispensable way to sustain the Earth for a long time, " he said, while urging more people to recycle resources that are still usable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to invest NT$12 billion in mountain management project

TEXT.P: The government will invest NT$12.6 billion (US$376 million) in a project to prevent natural disasters in the country's mountainous regions, the highest amount ever allocated for the goal, Taiwan's economic planning body said in a statement Monday.

The four-year project, which will run from 2009 to 2012 and extend an existing program, covers mudslide monitoring and forecasting, reservoir conservation, mountain disaster prevention, and mountain slope management.
Designed and proposed by the Council of Agriculture, the project was approved by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Monday.
The CEPD's statement pointed out that Taiwan is prone to natural disasters and suffers from a major disaster every three to five years on average, with serious damage caused each time.

Citing the World Bank's Natural Disaster Hotspots report released in 2005, the statement said 73 percent of Taiwan's people face the threat of at least three of the major natural hazards identified in the report, namely typhoons, floods, and earthquakes.
About 90 percent of the country's residents are threatened by at least two major natural hazards, the statement said, also citing the report.

The statement pointed out that the project, along with the government's flood prevention plan, will contribute to lowering disaster risks and strengthening Taiwan's soil and water resource conservation.

The budget for the disaster prevention project will be allocated over four years, with NT$2.1 billion to be spent in 2009, NT$3.36 billion in 2010, NT$3.49 billion in 2011, and NT$3.63 billion in 2012, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airing of Taiwan-produced film in China might be delayed: GIO

TEXT.P: There might be a delay in the scheduled screening of a locally produced box office hit in China, but it does not necessarily mean the plan has been dropped, the Government Information Office (GIO) said Monday.

The United Daily News, a local daily, reported Monday that China has suspended a plan to show "Cape No.7" prior to Chinese New Year, which falls on January 26, citing Beijing-based newspaper Legal Mirror.

Although the exact reason for the postponement was unclear, it is known that China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, said in a seminar last week that the film touches on Japan's colonization of Taiwan from 1895 to 1945.
The reports suggested that the top brass in Beijing worried that the airing of the film might whip up nationalistic sentiment in China.

Frank Chen, director of the GIO's Department of Motion Picture Affairs, said that Wang Ying-shyang, chairman of Taiwan's Long Shong Film Co., the distributor of the film, visited the GIO Monday to explain the distribution and screening of the film in China.

According to Wang, Long Shong received an e-mail from China Nov. 19 saying that there were still technical problems to be coordinated, and that Long Shong should hold off on sending the film to China pending further notification.
Judging from Wang's explanation, the screening of the film in China should be seen as being "delayed," Chen said.

He said that Cape No. 7, a romantic comedy set in Hengchun, Pingtung that has parallel plots set in the present day and 60 years ago at the end of the colonial period, is a film about relationships between people that will "touch the hearts of all Chinese."
"If Chinese people can also watch the film, it will help cultural exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," he insisted.
Meanwhile, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) blasted China for viewing the film from a political perspective.

DPP lawmaker Pan Meng-an noted that after watching the movie during his visit to Taiwan Nov. 3-7 in his capacity as the president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, Chen Yunlin said "Taiwan's sea is beautiful, Hengchun is beautiful, and the Malasan millet wine tastes good," and he expressed his hope to see Hengchun one day.

But his attitude changed after returning to China, and he has now attempted to ban the film from showing in China, Pan said, which the lawmaker suggested was a decision made purely "from the perspective of a political angle."
As of the end of November, the film had taken in NT$459.15 million (US$13.91 million), becoming the second top grossing film in the island's cinematic history, behind Titanic.

DOC.HEADLINE: Market mechanisms to decide charter flight fares: CAA

TEXT.P: Responding to a consumer group's appeal that fares for daily nonstop charter flights between Taiwan and China be reduced, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Monday that ticket prices should be decided by market mechanisms.

The Consumers' Foundation suggested earlier Monday that fares for the cross- Taiwan Strait charters, to be operated on a daily basis beginning Dec. 15, should be slashed by about 42 percent to reflect plummeting oil prices and straighter routes that will not require carriers to pass through Hong Kong or Macau air space.

Under a 42 percent fare cut, the price of a one-way economy class ticket between Taipei and Shanghai on the weekend could be reduced by between NT$8,100 and NT$10,500 (US$326), according to the foundation.

If the cross-strait charter flight prices cannot be effectively cut, foreign carriers should be allowed to compete in the market, which at present is only open to Taiwan- and China-based carriers, the foundation said.

The group also raised concerns that the fares for the new nonstop direct cross- strait charters operating from Tuesday to Thursday would be even higher than the current fares for flights that transit through Hong Kong or Macau.
The CAA did not dispute the foundation's assertion, saying greater market demand and fewer flights would certainly push up prices, and that it would respect market mechanisms.

The CAA said, for example, that fares for current weekend nonstop cross-strait charter flights (implemented since July on Friday through Monday) are already higher than those for flights transiting through a third country or area.

Prices for charter flights, regardless of international or cross-strait routes, are usually jointly determined by tour agencies and aviation companies without being reviewed in advance by the CAA, CAA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Motorbike owners urged to retire two-stroke motorcycles

TEXT.P: Motorbike owners around Taiwan have until Dec. 15 to hand over two-stroke motorcycles that are at least seven years old in exchange for a cash subsidy of NT$1,500, environmental officials said Monday.

The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has set aside NT$525 million (US$15.75 million) since January 2007 for the program, hoping to phase out 350,000 aged two-stroke motorcycles that are blamed for much of the air pollution in Taiwan's cities.
According to the EPA officials, two-stroke motorcycles generate up to five times more air pollution than the four-stroke motorcycles of a similar age.
The three-year program is also part of the Cabinet's efforts to echo calls by the international community to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions.
Cities and counties around Taiwan have been given different quotas each year on how many old but still running two-stroke motorcycles they can accept in return for subsidies.

For example, in 2008, Taipei County has a quota of 6,000, while the quotas for other districts are 5,000 for Taipei City, 5,500 for Tainan County, 2,000 for Miaoli County, 200 for the island county of Penghu, and 100 for the island county of Kinmen.
The program first began in Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County and Pingtung County in southern Taiwan in 2007 and was expanded in 2008 to cover all other cities and counties in Taiwan.

By the end of November this year, more than 30,000 motorcycle owners in the port city of Kaohsiung and the counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung had cashed in on the program by turning in their old two-stroke bikes to licensed factories for recycling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Science academy heads from around the globe to meet in Taipei

TEXT.P: Heads of prominent science institutes from around the world will meet for a three-day forum beginning Saturday at Taiwan's Academia Sinica in celebration of its 80th anniversary, Chi-Huey Wong, the institute's president, said at a news conference Monday.
A total of 15 academic heads from 13 countries will meet from Dec. 6-8 to contribute to discussions on the "Roles of the Academies in Creating a Better world," Wong said.
The forum's topics include how modern science academies will drive and contribute to knowledge-based development and solve environmental problems.

Steven Chu, a co-winner of the 1997 Nobel Prize in Physics, and Ralph Cicerone, president of U.S. National Academy of Sciences, will each give a keynote speech on the first day of the forum, Wong said.
Wong said this is the first time that the world's academic leaders will meet to focus on issues they all care about.
He said Academia Sinica spent more than a year preparing the forum, and that he and former Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh jointly invited academic leaders to the event.

Wong said Academia Sinica currently has no plans to turn the meeting into a regular annual event in the future. It is more likely, he said, that the institute will send representatives to similar events held by other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers want standard income tax deduction raised to NT$73,000

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee on Monday approved amendments to the Income Tax Act submitted by the Cabinet after further raising the standard individual income tax deduction from the NT$60,000 proposed by the ministry to NT$73,000.
The proposed amendments are to Clause One of Article Five, Article 17 and Article 126 of the Income Tax Act.
The amendments originally proposed increasing the standard deduction for individual tax filers from the current NT$46,000 to NT$60,000 and from NT$92,000 to NT$120,000 for a married couple.
But the Finance Committee raised it further to NT$73,000 for an unmarried taxpayer and to NT$146,000 for a married couple.
The increases on three other deductions proposed by the Cabinet remained unchanged.

A salary or wage earner's special deduction would be increased from NT$78,000 per salary or wage earner to NT$NT$100,000, while the deduction for the disabled would also be raised from the current NT$77,000 per disabled person to NT$100,000.
The amendments would also grant a deduction of NT$25,000 per student in each household to help cover higher education expenses, instead of the current NT$25,000 for each tax return.

Earlier in the day, Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der, who gave a report on the proposed legislation, told reporters that the Cabinet had reached a consensus with lawmakers that the four increased individual income tax deductions allowed by the amendments would be applicable in May 2009 when taxpayers file their 2008 returns.

Lee said the Ministry of Finance has estimated that the four increased deductions would affect 3.6 million families in Taiwan, accounting for 69 percent of the 5.18 million households that file tax returns each year.

According to law, the amendments adopted in 2008 should be implemented only in 2010, making them good for the 2009 income tax returns. But legislators of the ruling Kuomintang said this will not be a problem, because they will introduce another amendment to allow the newly increased deductions to be applied to the 2008 tax year.
Individual income tax is levied on Taiwan-source income of both resident and non-resident individuals per calendar year.

Individuals are considered residents in Taiwan for tax purposes if they are Republic of China citizens or if they are foreign nationals who reside in Taiwan for at least 183 days within a calendar year.
They are subject to income tax on all their income that originates in Taiwan and must file income tax returns and pay taxes between May 1 and 31 of the following year.

The incomes of the taxpayer, taxpayer's spouse, and dependents must be consolidated and reported on one income tax return. Resident taxpayers are allowed to claim personal exemptions and deductions on their tax returns.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC fuel oil prices undergo largest cut in history

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run petroleum refiner, CPC Corp., Taiwan announced Monday that it will slash the domestic price of low sulfur fuel oil by 37.68 percent, the largest price reduction in history.

The price for low sulfur fuel oil will be lowered by NT$5,802 (US$173.5) per kiloliter to NT$9,595, while the price of low sulfur boiler fuel oil will be cut by NT$5,625 per kiloliter to NT$11,092, according to a CPC statement.
The adjustment will take effect from midnight Monday.
CPC officials attributed the price cut to the plunging international price of crude oil, which has dropped to around US$50 per barrel.

Following Monday's price cuts, domestic fuel oil prices will have fallen back to their level of April 2007, and many will be watching to see if the price reductions will relieve cost pressures on local businesses and trigger drops in the prices of daily commodities.
Meanwhile, CPC also announced it will cut the wholesale price for liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) in December by NT$5.75 per kilogram to NT$16.64.
Under the adjustment, also to take effect at midnight Monday, the price for a 20 kg cylinder of household LPG will be lowered to NT$115, according to CPC.

Liquefied natural gas (LNG) , however, was not included in the latest round of price decreases. The company explained it was because the company has not yet received reference price reports indicating an obvious drop in prices.
CPC officials speculated that the long-awaited adjustment to the price of LNG will come in January.

DOC.HEADLINE: Timing of resuming form of short-selling needs more study: FSC

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) will conduct a thorough review before deciding whether the short selling of stocks at prices below the closing levels of the previous trading day should be resumed by the end of this year, the country's new top financial regulator said Monday.
Sean Chen, a former vice minister of finance, made the remarks after taking over as FSC chairman earlier in the day.

The FSC allowed resumption of short sales of stocks at prices above the previous closing levels last Friday, backpedaling on an all-out ban on short selling that took effect Oct. 1 and was to have remained valid until the end of this year.

Some securities analysts have advocated further easing restrictions on short selling, such as resuming short sales of stocks at prices below the previous closing levels, prior to the original year-end deadline.

Chen, who once served as chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, said short selling of stocks at prices below the previous closing levels is not an evil, but the timing to resume such trade is very important.

In his view, Chen said, the mechanism allowing investors to short sell at prices below the previous day's close should contain a "buyback" provision to cushion its possible impact on market stability.

Noting that the FSC has many experienced staff members, Chen said he will listen to their opinions as a reference in determining whether the temporary ban on short selling at prices lower than the previous close should be lifted ahead of schedule or remain in place until the end of this year as originally scheduled.

The FSC imposed the total short selling ban Oct. 1 at the height of global financial turmoil. With world financial markets gradually stabilizing, the financial regulatory body lifted the ban partially Nov. 28 by allowing short sales of stocks at prices above the previous closing levels as part of its efforts to spur market liquidity and trading volume.

After taking over the helm at the FSC from his predecessor Gordon Chen at a changeover ceremony, Sean Chen said his top priority was to help the local financial community tide over the lingering global credit crunch and financial meltdown.

As a first step, Chen said, he will supervise local financial institutions in reinforcing their risk management capability and coordinate with other government agencies to implement the policy of "the government backing banks, banks backing business, and business backing labor" during this time of economic volatility.

DOC.HEADLINE: Security agencies to decide on Dalai Lama's visit: official

TEXT.P: A visit to Taiwan by the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, would be politically sensitive, and will be left to the country's security agencies to decide, the head of the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission said Monday.
Minister Kao Su-po said the commission would like to see his visit, but security authorities will make an assessment and come to a decision first.

Kao made the remarks after the Dalai Lama, in an interview with the Hong Kong- based weekly Yazhou Zhoukan, said to forge friendly relations with Chinese sisters and brothers and to have exchanges with Buddhist followers, he would like to visit Taiwan again if the chance arises.
"The commission attaches great importance to the Dalai Lama's possible visit, given his high profile in the international community," Kao said.

But in view of China's concerns wherever he goes, "when will be the appropriate time for the visit and how to arrange his meetings with political heavyweights in Taiwan will be an issue that requires careful thought,' Kao said.
The Dalai Lama has visited Taiwan twice, in 1997 and 2001, respectively.
