DOC.HEADLINE: Motorbike owners urged to retire two-stroke motorcycles

TEXT.P: Motorbike owners around Taiwan have until Dec. 15 to hand over two-stroke motorcycles that are at least seven years old in exchange for a cash subsidy of NT$1,500, environmental officials said Monday.

The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has set aside NT$525 million (US$15.75 million) since January 2007 for the program, hoping to phase out 350,000 aged two-stroke motorcycles that are blamed for much of the air pollution in Taiwan's cities.
According to the EPA officials, two-stroke motorcycles generate up to five times more air pollution than the four-stroke motorcycles of a similar age.
The three-year program is also part of the Cabinet's efforts to echo calls by the international community to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions.
Cities and counties around Taiwan have been given different quotas each year on how many old but still running two-stroke motorcycles they can accept in return for subsidies.

For example, in 2008, Taipei County has a quota of 6,000, while the quotas for other districts are 5,000 for Taipei City, 5,500 for Tainan County, 2,000 for Miaoli County, 200 for the island county of Penghu, and 100 for the island county of Kinmen.
The program first began in Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County and Pingtung County in southern Taiwan in 2007 and was expanded in 2008 to cover all other cities and counties in Taiwan.

By the end of November this year, more than 30,000 motorcycle owners in the port city of Kaohsiung and the counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung had cashed in on the program by turning in their old two-stroke bikes to licensed factories for recycling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Science academy heads from around the globe to meet in Taipei

TEXT.P: Heads of prominent science institutes from around the world will meet for a three-day forum beginning Saturday at Taiwan's Academia Sinica in celebration of its 80th anniversary, Chi-Huey Wong, the institute's president, said at a news conference Monday.
A total of 15 academic heads from 13 countries will meet from Dec. 6-8 to contribute to discussions on the "Roles of the Academies in Creating a Better world," Wong said.
The forum's topics include how modern science academies will drive and contribute to knowledge-based development and solve environmental problems.

Steven Chu, a co-winner of the 1997 Nobel Prize in Physics, and Ralph Cicerone, president of U.S. National Academy of Sciences, will each give a keynote speech on the first day of the forum, Wong said.
Wong said this is the first time that the world's academic leaders will meet to focus on issues they all care about.
He said Academia Sinica spent more than a year preparing the forum, and that he and former Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh jointly invited academic leaders to the event.

Wong said Academia Sinica currently has no plans to turn the meeting into a regular annual event in the future. It is more likely, he said, that the institute will send representatives to similar events held by other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC fuel oil prices undergo largest cut in history

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run petroleum refiner, CPC Corp., Taiwan announced Monday that it will slash the domestic price of low sulfur fuel oil by 37.68 percent, the largest price reduction in history.

The price for low sulfur fuel oil will be lowered by NT$5,802 (US$173.5) per kiloliter to NT$9,595, while the price of low sulfur boiler fuel oil will be cut by NT$5,625 per kiloliter to NT$11,092, according to a CPC statement.
The adjustment will take effect from midnight Monday.
CPC officials attributed the price cut to the plunging international price of crude oil, which has dropped to around US$50 per barrel.

Following Monday's price cuts, domestic fuel oil prices will have fallen back to their level of April 2007, and many will be watching to see if the price reductions will relieve cost pressures on local businesses and trigger drops in the prices of daily commodities.
Meanwhile, CPC also announced it will cut the wholesale price for liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) in December by NT$5.75 per kilogram to NT$16.64.
Under the adjustment, also to take effect at midnight Monday, the price for a 20 kg cylinder of household LPG will be lowered to NT$115, according to CPC.

Liquefied natural gas (LNG) , however, was not included in the latest round of price decreases. The company explained it was because the company has not yet received reference price reports indicating an obvious drop in prices.
CPC officials speculated that the long-awaited adjustment to the price of LNG will come in January.

DOC.HEADLINE: Security agencies to decide on Dalai Lama's visit: official

TEXT.P: A visit to Taiwan by the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, would be politically sensitive, and will be left to the country's security agencies to decide, the head of the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission said Monday.
Minister Kao Su-po said the commission would like to see his visit, but security authorities will make an assessment and come to a decision first.

Kao made the remarks after the Dalai Lama, in an interview with the Hong Kong- based weekly Yazhou Zhoukan, said to forge friendly relations with Chinese sisters and brothers and to have exchanges with Buddhist followers, he would like to visit Taiwan again if the chance arises.
"The commission attaches great importance to the Dalai Lama's possible visit, given his high profile in the international community," Kao said.

But in view of China's concerns wherever he goes, "when will be the appropriate time for the visit and how to arrange his meetings with political heavyweights in Taiwan will be an issue that requires careful thought,' Kao said.
The Dalai Lama has visited Taiwan twice, in 1997 and 2001, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 2, or the fifth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1804: Monarchy returns to France when Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame, 11 years after King Louis XVI was guillotined.
1815: The Rajah of Nepal signs peace treaty with Britain.
1823: U.S. President James Monroe, introducing his "Monroe Doctrine," warns Europe to keep its hands off both American continents.
1901: King Camp Gillette markets a safety razor with a double-edged disposable blade in the United States.
1908: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is crowned emperor of China at the age of three.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries capture Nanjing.
1923: The Young China Party sets up in Paris, France.
1942: A nuclear chain reaction is demonstrated for the first time by American scientists working on a secret project in Chicago.
1954: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh signs the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty with U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.
1965: The World Health Organization formally recognizes Taiwan as free of malaria.
1968: The Taiwan Power Company signs an agreement with the World Bank for a loan of US$50 million for construction of the Dachien Dam.
1971: Soviet Union spaceship "Mars III" lands on Mars.
1974: The Fifth Asian Congress of Pharmaceutical Sciences opens a four-day meeting in Taipei.
1974: The Young China Party celebrates its 51st anniversary.
1976: The Fourth Asian Composers' League Conference holds its closing ceremony, with more than 100 delegates and observers from 20 countries attending.
1976: The ROC's "Hai Kung" research vessel leaves Keelung for an expedition to Antarctica.
1988: A cyclone packing winds in excess of 177 kph hits Bangladesh, killing thousands and leaving more than 5 million homeless.
1986: The Chunghwa (ROC) Blues and the Chunghwa Whites win 1st and 2nd places, respectively in the Third International Baseball Tournament.
1989: V.P. Singh, leader of the Janata Dal Party, replaces Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister of India.
1989: Elections are held for the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal councils, county magistrates, and provincial- level city mayors.
1990: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition wins re-election in the first elections since 1932 involving all of Germany.
1994: A ferry carrying more than 600 people collides with a freighter and sinks in Manila Bay, the Philippines. Sixty bodies are recovered, and 85 people remain missing.
1995: The ROC elects 164 lawmakers to the Third Legislative Yuan.
1995: A Singapore court sentences former Barings Bank trader Nick Leeson to six- and-a-half years in prison for his part in the crash of Britain's oldest merchant bank.
1996: ROC Foreign Minister John Chang departs for South Africa.
1997: After a bitter power struggle with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, President Farooq Leghari of Pakistan resigns.
1999: The Republic of China signs a formal aviation agreement with Palau as part of its efforts to facilitate exchanges between the two countries.
Motse's lesson of the day: "Heaven is all-inclusive and impartial in its activities, abundant and unceasing in its blessings, and lasting and untiring in its guidance. And so, when the sage-kings had accepted heaven as their standard, they measured every action and enterprise by heaven. What heaven desired they would carry out, what heaven abominated they refrained from."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's Red Cross Society to visit quake-affected areas in Sichuan
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/08 16:01:41 (By P. Y. Kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China will visit areas of Sichuan province that were devastated by an earthquake in May, society officials said Tuesday.
C.V. Chen, president of Taiwan's Red Cross Society, and his group will arrive in Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan in southwestern China, Wednesday night, to join an advance team of the society.
Starting Thursday, Chen's group will travel to cities that were ravaged by the magnitude-8.0 earthquake that struck Sichuan province May 12.
Red Cross Society officials said Chen will sign a cooperation agreement on post- quake reconstruction with his Red Cross Society counterparts in China.
He will also attend a groundbreaking ceremony for a rehabilitation center for the disabled in Abazhou as well as distribute comforters and other relief supplies donated by people in Taiwan.

The society intends to spend NT$1.375 billion (US$41.42 million) in remote parts of Sichuan, Gansu and Shaanxi provinces to rebuild 44 schools, 43 health care facilities and one rehabilitation center for the disabled in the Aba Tibetan- Qiang Autonomous Region.

Official figures as of July 21, 2008, put the number of confirmed dead from the earthquake at 69,227, including 68,636 in Sichuan province. Another 374,176 were listed as injured, with 18,222 listed as missing.
The earthquake left about 4.8 million people homeless, according to official statistics, but that number could be as high as 11 million. Approximately 15 million people lived in the affected area.
It was the deadliest earthquake to hit China since the 1976 Tangshan earthquake, which killed at least 240,000 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Danshui River's pollution on the decline: EPA

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Tuesday that efforts to clean up the Danshui River have delivered tangible improvements, including an increase in marine life in the river.

"The length of the Danshui River that is polluted has decreased by 54.6 kilometers, said EPA Deputy Minister Chang Tzi-chin at a press conference. "The water quality is improving rapidly. The number of fish have also greatly increased.

Chang said that through the joint efforts of the local and central governments, only 4.5 percent of the full length of the river was polluted at the end of October, down from 21.4 percent of the river being polluted in 2002.
We are cleaning up the river by dredging mud from the river's floor and by posting guards to patrol it to prevent people from dumping waste there," Chang said.

One positive consequence of the cleanup efforts has been the revitalization of marine life. According to EPA data, the number of species of fish that can be found now has increased, a development confirmed by the observations of local residents.
"The cleanup of the river has made great strides. I have received phone calls from people who live near the river who told me the number of fish has increased, " Chang said.
He also pointed to progress made in eliminating the river's foul smell that tarnished any visit to the river's banks.
"The stench was especially obvious when the tide retreated. Now, as the river is being cleaned up, the smell is gone," Chang said.

Improving the Danshui River entails more, however, than simply cleaning its waters. It also includes the development of infrastructure such as planting trees along the river and building bicycle paths, the EPA official stressed.

The 159-kilometer Danshui River originates on Pintien Mountain in Hsinchu County and winds its way through Hsinchu County, Taoyuan County, Taipei City and Taipei County before emptying into the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: 13,000 Amway China employees to visit Taiwan next year

TEXT.P: Some 13,000 Amway China employees are set to visit Taiwan on a cruise next March, which will give a boost to the island's tourism industry, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Tuesday.

In a report during a visit to the ministry by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Mao said the visit will be handled as a special case and not be subject to the quota of 3,000 Chinese tourists to Taiwan per day.
Mao said the Amway China employees will be making the tour as part of the company's annual bonus trip and to take part in an overseas training seminar in Taiwan.
The employees will visit in several groups on cruise liners from Shanghai to Keelung Harbor and Taichung Harbor, Mao said.

Although regulations on Chinese tourist visits to Taiwan limit travel to the island to residents of 13 specified Chinese provinces, the Amway China employees taking part in the tour come from all over the country, Mao said.
He added that according to the ministry's understanding, Chinese authorities have also agreed to handle the tour as a special case, separate from the daily quota on Chinese tourist numbers to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer voucher funding bill placed on legislative agenda

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's Procedure Committee on Tuesday placed a bill that would allow the government to fund its consumer voucher program by issuing debt on the legislative agenda for discussion Friday.

The government's plan to provide vouchers valued at NT$3,600 (US$110) to each Taiwan citizen ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday to stimulate consumer spending is part of its efforts to boost a contracting economy.

If the bill on financing the voucher program smoothly passes its second and third reading, it will enable the Executive Yuan to submit the legislation covering the actual voucher program before noon next Monday.

Under an expedited screening process, the voucher program bill could then be approved by the legislature by the end of the month, giving the government time to issue the vouchers by its target date of Jan. 18 -- one full week ahead of the start of the Chinese New Year.
Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said last week that the legislature must pass the bill by Dec. 26 at the latest if that target is to be met.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIV infections through sexual contact rising in Taoyuan

TEXT.P: The number of people who were infected with HIV through sexual contact is rising in Taoyuan County, which indicated a lack of awareness about safe sex, Taoyuan health authorities said Tuesday.

During the first 10 months of this year, a total of 123 new HIV/AIDS cases were recorded in the northern Taiwanese county, 90 of which resulted from unprotected sex, according to statistics compiled by the county's public health bureau.
The figure compares with 91 new cases recorded during the whole of 2007 and marks a sharp increase from 2003 and 2004, when there were around 60 new cases a year, the statistics showed.
Among the new cases recorded from January to October 2008, 40 percent were in the 20-29 age group, and 6 percent were in the 15-19 age group.

Lin Hsueh-jung, head of the bureau, said the situation is a cause for concern as it shows that HIV/AIDS awareness among the general public remains low, even as the government's efforts to control HIV infections among intravenous drug users have been proven successful.

Statistics from the bureau revealed that in 2007, there were 89 new cases in which intravenous drug users were infected with HIV after sharing needles with HIV carriers. The number accounted for 52 percent of all new HIV infections for the year, which totaled 169.
During the first 10 months of 2008, the number of new HIV infections involving an intravenous drug user stood at 27, accounting for 26 percent of all new cases for the period.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA warns travelers to Southeast Asia of drug-trafficking pitfalls

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) urged Taiwanese travelers Tuesday to take the necessary precautions to avoid becoming embroiled in drug-trafficking, a serious crime in many popular Southeast Asian destinations.

Victor Yu, director-general of MOFA's East Asian and Pacific Affairs, issued the warning at a press conference after a report from the Indonesian government indicated 23 individuals -- 13 of them Taiwanese nationals -- were caught with drugs at the country's gateways in the past eight months.
Some of the Taiwanese nationals had been severely punished, Yu said, while others are still in the process of trials.
In addition, over 110 Taiwanese nationals are still serving sentences for drug- trafficking and other drug-related crimes in Thailand, Yu said.

Although the ministrys representative office in Bangkok has managed over the past two years to help some Taiwanese convicts be released early or have their sentences reduced, Yu said differences between Taiwan's judicial systems and those in Southeast Asian limit the potential effectiveness of any government assistance efforts.

To avoid being unwittingly implicated in a drug-trafficking case, Yu suggested that local travelers avoid carrying packages for strangers and pack their own bags when traveling to countries in which drug-trafficking is widespread.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-France Parliamentary Friendship Group established

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan established a Taipei-based R.O.C.(Republic of China, Taiwan) -France Parliamentary Friendship Group Tuesday with the aim of enhancing bilateral relations with France.

At a ceremony held at the Legislative Yuan, Francois Brottes, chairman of the France-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group in France, said that the establishment of the Taiwan-based group will help promote exchanges and mutual understanding in a spirit of cordiality.
He also noted with interest the changes in the relations between Taiwan and China, especially within the context of the current economic slump.

"We follow with interest the evolution of new dialogues between the two sides (of the Taiwan Strait) in the region," he said. "The warming relationship with the continent (Mainland China) seems to be, for us, a new perspective for future."

He further said that, on the issue of public health, members of his group will listen to Taiwan's opinions and make sure that Taiwan's wish to participate in the World Health Assembly can be heard. A ruling Kuomintang legislator, Yang Li- huan, who studied in Grenoble, France, has been named as chairwoman of the Taiwanese friendship group.

Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said that he expects the friendship group to work to promote the substantial relations between the two sides. France is an important partner for Taiwan in the areas of commerce, tourism, culture and technology, he noted.
The ceremony was attended by officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, several legislators and representatives of the French Institute in Taipei, including the director Patrick Bonneville.
The friendship group is comprised of 57 Taiwanese legislators, which represents about 50 percent of the total number of lawmakers in the Legislative Yuan, and 33 members of the French Parliament.
The group hopes to enhance communication and exchanges in the fields of culture, technology and education between the parliamentary members of the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares plunge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 161.45 points, or 3.57 percent, to close at 4,356.98.

Suffering a big drop after gains made the previous five trading day, the local bourse opened at 4,310.50 and fluctuated between 4,356.98 and 4,292.08 during trading. A total of 3.57 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$54.14 billion (US$1.63 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics stocks shedding the most at 4.84 percent. Construction stocks dropped 4.6 percent, banking and financial shares lost 4.33 percent, paper and pulp issues moved down 4.23 percent, textile stocks decreased 1.58 percent, plastics and chemicals shares dropped 1.06 percent, and cement stocks shed 0.03 percent.
Only foodstuff issues gained ground, increasing 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,272 to 157, with 211 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.8 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Another cold snap to arrive in northern, central Taiwan Dec. 4: CWB

TEXT.P: Another cold snap, lasting about five days, will affect northern and central Taiwan from Dec. 4, sending temperatures in some areas to as low as 10 degrees Celsius, the Central Weather Bureau forecast Tuesday.
CWB meteorologists said the cold snap is due to a continental cold air mass that is forecast to move into the Taiwan area on the evening of Nov. 4.

They said early morning temperatures in northern and central Taiwan, covering the areas of Taipei and Taichung, could drop to 10 degrees Celsius Dec. 6-7 before rising slightly to between 12 degrees and 14 degrees Celsius on Dec. 8, while daytime temperatures are expected to range between 21 degrees and 24 degrees Celsius Dec. 6-7, also rising slightly Dec. 8.
Northeastern Taiwan, covering the areas of Keelung and Yilan, will experience lows of between 12 degrees and 15 degrees Celsius during the five days from Dec. 5-9, according to the forecast.
People in northern and northeastern Taiwan should be prepared for inclement weather in those five days because the cold snap could be accompanied by rain, the CWB warned.

Southern Taiwan, covering the Kaohsiung-Pingtung area, will experience early morning temperatures of around 14-16 degrees Celsius and daytime temperatures of between 25 and 27 degrees Celsius under sunny skies, while eastern and southeastern Taiwan could expect slightly higher temperatures under cloudy skies, according to the CWB forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's goodwill ambassadors to China - Formosan sika deers

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Zoo said Tuesday that it plans to send two Formosan sika deers to mainland China as soon as it receives a pair of giant pandas from China, and that the deers will be at optimum mating age.

Zoo official Chao Ming-chie said the zoo currently owns a herd of 10 Formosan sika deers -- three male and seven female -- from which they will select a couple that are both aged between 1 and 5 to serve as Taiwan's goodwill ambassadors to China.

The deer, endemic to Taiwan, enjoys a life span of 20 years, and develops a breeding ability at the age 2. As a result, deers that are 1 to 5 years old are the most suitable to be sent to China, Chao said.
The exchange of animals are seen as goodwill gestures by the two sides as they seek to repair long strained relations.
In addition to the Formosan sika deers, the zoo will also present China a pair of Formosan goat, also a rare indigenous animal, as a gift.
The pandas are expected to be delivered to Taipei's zoo in mid December.
Taipei City Zoo's Chao said a stag will begin to grow antlers on the head at around 2 years old, which will then grow an additional fork each year until it is five years old.
In the breeding season that normally begins in October and ends in January, male deers will use their horns as a weapon in fights for leadership and the right to mate with a female.
The gestation period of a mother deer is over 300 days, according to Chao.

According to the zoo, the grass-eating Formosan sika deer, known for white spots on its back, can grow to 1.5 meters long. A doe is smaller and has no antler. Its coat changes color in different seasons from chestnut red in the summer to light brown in the winter.

Many of the spotted deer were killed during massive hunting in 1624 when the Dutch occupied Taiwan, with the catch volume reaching 150,000 heads a year. Until the year of 1662 when a Chinese military leader, Zheng Chenggong, defeated the Dutch to claim Taiwan, deer skin was one of Taiwan's most important exports.
According to Taipei City Zoo's Director Jason Yeh, the Formosan sika deer disappeared from the wild in Taiwan in 1969 when the last wild deer died.

As part of the country's efforts to preserve the native animal, the city zoo joined a conservation program in 1986, transporting 22 pure-blood captive-raised deers to the Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan in an effort to revive the deer's population in the wild.

Since 1994, the national park has set free a total of 50 Formosan sika deers in the wild. According to a survey conducted by Kenting park authorities in 2003, the number of the wild deers has reached 108-156.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TAIEX Index futures for January lost 268 points to finish at 4,193, with 734 contracts traded, while March futures declined 280 points to end at 4,155, with 24 contracts traded.
June futures fell 269 points to close at 4,118, with 7 contract transactions, while September futures lost 243 points to finish at 3,950, with 11 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,501 for December, 4,461 for January, 4,435 for March, 4,387 for June and 4,193 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 161.45 points to finish at 4,356.98, on turnover of NT$54.14 billion (US$1.63 billion).

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower, with TE futures for December and January dropping by the maximum allowable 7 percent.
December TE futures fell 11.75 points to close at 156.7, with 3,407 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 11.6 points to finish at 154.4, with 41 contracts traded.
March TE futures dropped 11.15 points to finish at 151.4 points, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local university signs academic MOU with Spanish school

TEXT.P: National Chiayi University (NCYU) in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, has signed a memorandum of understanding on academic cooperation with Spain's University of Huelva, NCYU President Lee Ming-jen said Tuesday.
The MOU was inked by Lee and his Spanish counterpart Francisco Jose Martinez Lopez Monday, Lee said.
Lee said the MOU will allow for exchanges of teaching personnel and students between the two schools and cooperation in opening joint courses and research projects.
The NCYU was established in 2000 by combining an existing technology school and an education college.
Today, NCYU has four campuses and six colleges covering disciplines from agriculture and life sciences to art and is especially known for its agricultural programs.
The University of Huelva was founded in 1993. It has 10,400 students in nine colleges on four campuses.

In addition to academic exchanges, the benefits of the MOU will include NCYU gaining access to the Spanish school's resources in art, as the University of Huelva is located in Andalusia in southern Spain which is renowned for its diverse culture, according to Lee.
For its part, the Spanish school will send more students to NCYU, Martinez said, noting that at present there is only one.

The Spanish university has been making efforts to promote eastern cultures and Chinese learning, Lee said. Its Asian culture center, whose director Grace Mun Man Shum also attended Monday's signing ceremony, worked with Taiwan's Education of Ministry to organize a Taiwan culture week on University of Huelva's campuses last October.
NCYU has signed MOUs with 30 academic institutions throughout the world in an effort to access more resources and broaden the international perspective of its students, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Potential cancer drug synthesized at university lab

TEXT.P: A series of experiments has recently led to the discovery of an alkaloid-based compound that can efficiently kill various kinds of cancer cells and could be used in cancer drugs after further testing, according to the team that made the discovery.

The compound "antofine" is made from alkaloids extracted from herbs such as cryptocarya chinensis and ficus septica, said Wu Tian-shung, the project's leader and a chemistry professor at the Tainan- based National Cheng Kung University (NCKU).
Alkaloids -- nitrogen-based chemical compounds -- can be naturally produced by numerous organisms, including bacteria, fungi, plants, and animals.
In laboratory testing, Wu noted, the antofine proves effective in killing tumorous cells of lung cancer, breast cancer, nasopharyngeal cancer, and multi- resistance nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
Wu said he believes the new ingredient may become a powerful anti-cancer drug after further research, as well as more tests on animals and humans.
The team, whose members come from both Taiwan and the United States, has already published their results in the journal Bioorganic Medicinal Chemistry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's AIDS patients getting younger: World Vision Taiwan

TEXT.P: The number of AIDS patients in Taiwan has continued to increase, with more youths falling victim to the deadly disease, the Christian charity World Vision Taiwan (WVT) warned in a statement Tuesday.

Quoting statistics compiled by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health, WVT said a total of 16,968 people were reported to have been infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, between 1984 and the end of September 2008, with an annual increase of more than 1,000 cases.
Most of the victims are in their prime, ages 20 to 40, and the number of HIV carriers in the 10-19 age group has also been increasing steadily, according to the statement.
Chu Yu-hsin, a WVT deputy project director, said many youngsters have come down with HIV through casual sexual encounters or by sharing needles with HIV- carrying intravenous drug users.

Noting that most of these youngsters are from problem or broken families, Chu said the local society should show more concern and care for them and help them value themselves and develop sober judgment.
"By so doing, the youngsters will be less likely to fall victim to drug addiction or the sex trade, which would in turn reduce the risk of them becoming infected with HIV," Chu explained.

Chu also urged local people and business groups to donate money for educational programs to help enhance public awareness and wipe out the discriminatory attitude toward AIDS patients or HIV carriers.
Donations are also needed to finance aid or care for children orphaned by AIDS, Chu added.
Meanwhile, a previous study by National Taiwan University Hospital showed that delay in seeking diagnosis or treatment of HIV could increase the chances of death by 20 percent to 30 percent.

Statistics on new HIV cases in Taiwan compiled by the Center for Disease Control showed that homosexual males accounted for 46 percent of the 728 cases certified as HIV-positive between January and May this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiang Pin-kung reelected as Straits Exchange Foundation chairman

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) reelected as chairman Chiang Pin-kung during its board meeting on Tuesday.

Kao Koong-lian, an incumbent SEF vice chairman, Fu Don-Cheng, a vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, and Rock Hsu, chairman of Kinpo Group, were named as SEF's vice chairmen. Kao was also re-appointed as the secretary general of the SEF.

Chiang, an experienced technocrat who has served as minister of economic affairs and chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, first assumed the SEF chairmanship May 26, shortly after the May 20 inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou.
Many in Taiwan's political circles say that Chiang is an economic and trade expert with hands-on mainland experience. Some even say that Chiang Pin-kung is a SEF chairman qualified to be premier.

In a speech delivered after his reelection as SEF chief, Chiang said that in the future, both the SEF and its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Acros the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- will engage in crime fighting, expansion of mechanisms for food safety inspections and enhancement of quarantine procedures for dairy products.

"The Straits Exchange Foundation and ARATS have reached agreements on the priority issues to discuss in the next round of talks, " said Chiang, referring to a third round of talks scheduled to be held in mainland China in the first half of next year.
Chiang noted that other cross-strait matters that will be dealt with include: financial, investment, industrial, fisheries and cultural cooperation.
"These issues will be negotiated in a step-by-step process. The respective government agencies will engage in negotiations of the detailed agreements," Chiang said.

Chiang Pin-kung , also a vice chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, was tapped to be SEF chairman shortly after the KMT regained power in May. This makes him in effect responsible for the front line negotiations with the mainland Chinese government.

In March 2005, Chiang led the KMT's first official delegation to mainland China since the end of major hostilities in the Chinese Civil War in 1949. During the trip, Chiang promoted opening the three links and economic development between Taiwan and mainland China.

Chiang's experience in cross-strait affairs made him the key man in the last two rounds of SEF and ARATS talks. He is considered by many as the most prominent figure to represent Taiwan in cross-strait talks.

SEF and its mainland Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , are quasi governmental organizations empowered to handle cross-strait negotiations in the absence of formal government-to- government relations between the two sides.
Talks between SEF and ARATS were stalled for years during the previous administrations in Taiwan, which had upset Beijing with their pro-independence stance.
Talks resumed this year for the first time in about a decade, after the more China friendly President Ma Ying-jeou took office.

In the second round of talks held early last month, Chiang and ARATS President Chen Yunlin signed four major agreements to establish direct shipping and postal links, expand flight services and create a mechanism to address food safety issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker wants Kaohsiung port development included in special bill

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Huang Chao-shun called Tuesday for Kaohsiung City's air and sea ports to be included in an airport development bill so to sharpen the competitiveness of the two southern Taiwan ports.
Huang issued the call at a seminar that she sponsored with the aim of exploring public opinion on ways to increase the international competitive edge of the two local ports.

The Legislative Yuan is set to screen a special bill Wednesday on the development and upgrade of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan. However, as the bill deals only with Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in the north, Huang contended that Kaohsiung International Airport and the Kaohsiung Harbor should also be included to allow for their development as an aviation park and a free trade port zone, respectively.

To that end, Huang said, she will propose amendments to every clause in the bill when it comes up for screening by the Legislature Wednesday. The government is hoping that the bill will be passed to develop the area adjacent to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport as an aviation park.
If the bill is passed with the inclusion of the two ports, the Kaohsiung city government will have to make an all out effort to bring the ports up to a level with those in the north, she urged.

Wang Ming-sheng, a professor at National Sun Yat-sen University in Kaohsiung City, called on the city government to seize the development opportunities that would arise with the planned opening of direct shipping services between Taiwan and China.

Taiwan and China representatives inked four cooperation accords Nov. 4 in Taipei, one of which was to establish direct shipping links across the Taiwan Strait. To that end, China will open 28 of its ports for business with Taiwan.

Wang said that the Kaohsiung city government has failed in its efforts to make its sea port into a free trade zone and he suggested that transparent participation by the public in the development of the city and its two ports should be allowed.

Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Lee Lung-wen expressed the view that there is ample room for Kaohsiung International Airport to further develop once its cargo and passenger transportation volumes increase.
The number of commercial passenger flights at the Taoyuan airport is six times that at the Kaohsiung airport, while the number of cargo flights is 25 times that at the Kaohsiung airport, Lee noted.
Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Oliver F. L. Yu contended that the competitiveness of the increasingly marginalized Kaohsiung Port can be boosted by relaxing the special law.

Thanks to its strategic location and large hinterland in the neighboring Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, the Kaohsiung Port stands a good chance of being transformed into a flourishing commercial business district, Yu said.

He said the Taoyuan airport will first undergo development in line with the law, as long as the international airport development special bill clears the Legislative Yuan, and the law can then be applied to the Kaohsiung airport if its passenger transportation volume is large enough.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmental groups call for boycott of U.S. beef

TEXT.P: Several environmental groups in Taiwan on Tuesday protested against the imports of U.S. beef and called for a boycott against the products, arguing that they endanger public health and the environment.
Pan Han-sheng, secretary-general of the Green Party, said the health of the public will only be ensured if U.S. beef is banned from being imported to Taiwan.

Pan noted at a news conference held outside the Department of Health that although the Executive Yuan recently passed a draft bill governing the organic law of the Taiwan Food and Drug Administration (TFDA), in an effort to strengthen the safety of food and drugs, the bill will not ensure the safety of U.S. beef.

An alliance to fight against global warming also staged a skit, plastering a U.S. cattle doll with stickers that read "bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE)", "supervirus that is drug-resistant", and "growth hormones that could induce cancer".

The alliance said that U.S. cattle is raised in a large-scale way and that the cereal fed to them could be polluted with chemicals, posing bigger threat to health than melamine tainted milk products from China.
The alliance called for a boycott of U.S. beef, saying that it will help take care the public's health and the environment as well as ensure food safety.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of BSE was diagnosed in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle aged under 30 months, but the Taiwan government re-imposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the United States.
The DOH lifted the ban on Jan. 25, 2006, but had to reinstate it four months later when bone fragments were discovered in a beef shipment.

Taiwan currently only allows boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months of age, produced from certificated slaughterhouses and without high risk items such as brains and spinal cord marrow to be imported.
The U.S. has called for Taiwan to fully open the market to its beef.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Year holiday to last four days: Executive Yuan

TEXT.P: The 2009 New Year holiday will last four days from Jan. 1-4, Central Personnel Administration Minister Chen Ching-hsiou announced Tuesday.

The announcement ended debate on whether to adjust the length of the New Year holiday -- normally a single day -- after the legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang proposed prolonging the first holiday of 2009 to include Jan. 2, because Jan. 1 falls on a Thursday, a move that would give people the two days plus the following two-day weekend.

The caucus said expanding the holiday will help boost domestic consumption, while the additional Friday -- which would be a work day under normal circumstances -- can be made up by taking away a Saturday later in the year.

The proposal, however, drew opposition from Tsai Lien-sheng, secretary-general of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries, who said the proposal might have an adverse effect on the country's manufacturing enterprises and exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southern park achieves success in boosting jacana population

TEXT.P: The Pheasant-tailed Jacana Park in Guantien township in Tainan County, southern Taiwan has succeeded in boosting the population of the endangered species while developing as a safe nesting place for both migratory and indigenous waterfowl, conservationists said Tuesday.

The conservationists of the Taipei-based Chinese Wild Bird Federation said the population of the pheasant-tailed jacana -- selected as the Tainan County bird -- has increased to nearly 300 in the Guantien area alone, from fewer than 50 all over Taiwan just 10 years ago.

The federation attributed the achievement to recovery efforts by the county government-run park, which was built in 1998 with a subsidy from the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. in response to local activists' calls for protection of the indigenous water bird.
Construction of the railway had destroyed an area of wetland where the birds formerly lived.

The pheasant-tailed jacana, or hydrophasia nus chirurgus, is a beautiful bird that breeds in ponds or wetland areas and sports a long pheasant-like tail while in its breeding plumage, hence its common name.

In Taiwan, jacana usually congregate in water chestnut fields, where their extremely elongated toes allow them to distribute their weight so that they can walk on floating leaves while they hunt for food. This has given the bird the local name of water chestnut bird.

Because of its success in aiding the recovery of the endangered bird, the park, developed on a 15-hectare former sugar cane plot, has become a key ecological conservation spot and a popular tourist attraction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q1 manpower demand estimated to fall by 5,600: labor council

TEXT.P: Taiwan's manpower demand in the first quarter of next year is expected to fall by 5,600, mainly due to contracting businesses, according to the results of a survey published Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

According to the CLA survey, companies are expected to hire a combined total of 21,000 workers in the first quarter of 2009, while more than 26,000 will be laid off, representing a reduction of about 5,600 workers. It will be the second consecutive quarterly fall following a decrease of about 26,000 in the fourth quarter of this year, CLA officials said.
The CLA ascribed the continued decline to lower market demand at home and abroad as a result of shrinking business due to the global financial turmoil and plummeting stock markets around the world.

Around 59 percent of the companies planning job cuts in the first three months of next year said they had decided to do so because of "contracting business, " while 44.2 percent said they would be "streamlining the workforce," the survey results show.

The real estate, leasing, insurance, construction, manufacturing and retail sectors will see the most noticeable drops in business activity in the coming three-month period, while sports, leisure, scientific and technology service businesses will undergo the largest workforce cuts, the survey has found.
The highest number of layoffs -- some 11,000 -- will come in the manufacturing sector, followed by some 1,400 in the construction sector, according to the survey results.
Very few businesses are set to expand their workforces in the coming quarter, with the retail sector planning to hire 3,200 new workers, the largest number of all the sectors surveyed.

DOC.HEADLINE: European Film Festival starts round-island tour in Taipei

TEXT.P: The fourth Taiwan European Film Festival kicked off Tuesday in Taipei, with the organizers announcing that 10 European films will be shown in free screenings at various universities around the country throughout December to promote European cultures and help local people find out more about Europe.

At the opening ceremony and premiere -- a screening of the Italian film "The Fever" held at Chinese Culture University, Guy Ledoux, director of the European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) , said the film festival is expected to help Taiwanese audiences gain a better understanding of European cultures.
"Watching movies is one of the best ways to understand the lives and histories of people in another part of the world," he said.

He noted that recently, a delegation of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits saw the Taiwanese movie "Cape No. 7" during a visit to Taiwan in early November, and said this might allow Chinese people to better understand Taiwanese people, as "maybe a movie transmits a more subtle message than words can express."

Ledoux also expressed hope that through the festival, now in its fourth year, more Taiwanese students will be convinced to visit Europe as tourists or students and discover by themselves the region's various aspects.

The 10 films, from 10 member states of the European Union, will be presented in DVD format in their original versions with Chinese and English subtitles at 14 universities and three cultural institutions around the country, including the Youth Hub in Taipei, the Image Museum in Hsinchu City and the Kaohsiung Film Archive in southern Taiwan.

The festival, initiated in 2005 with the aim of promoting European art and culture, is organized by the EETO and the Infine Art and Culture Exchange, with support from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan aims to be peacemaker: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that Taiwan aims to be a peacemaker instead of a troublemaker in the international community.

Ma made the remarks in a meeting with Francisco Brottes, chairman of the France- Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group, and Rudy Salles, vice president of the National Assembly of France, at the Presidential Office.

Ma said that since his inauguration in late May, the Taiwan government has been trying to create stable international relations by opting for a "very scrupulous" diplomatic policy and working to improve Taiwan-China relations.
Ma referred to his "flexible diplomacy" or "modus vivendi" approach, which he said is a pragmatic strategy to gain more international space for Taiwan.
The aim is to consolidate diplomatic relations with Taiwan's allies and restore mutual trust with other countries without being at loggerheads with China, he said.
Ma said that he welcomed the French friendship group's visit, noting that for many years it has contributed significantly to the development of bilateral relations between Taiwan and France.
The current visit by the group will help to build on what has already been achieved, Ma added.

The president said that Taiwan has had cordial exchanges with France in many areas and would like to learn from France's nuclear waste disposal expertise. France is a world leader in the area of nuclear technology, with nuclear power accounting for 78 percent of its energy supply.
Ma said that both Taiwan and France will benefit as a result of Taiwan's efforts to improve its international relations.

Taiwan's relations with Europe will also benefit as result of the improvement in Taiwan-China relations and French President Nicolas Sarkozy's assumption of the European Union rotating chairmanship in July, Ma said.
The president also expressed appreciation for the EU's support for Taiwan's efforts this year to participate in the United Nations specialized agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Antofine could be potent anticancer prodrug: Taiwanese scientist

TEXT.P: A study by a Taiwanese professor has led to the finding that antofine -- a phenanthroindolizidine alkaloid compound -- can effectively eliminate human cancer cells and could serve as a new anti-cancer prodrug.

Wu Tian-shung, who teaches at the Department of Chemistry of National Cheng Kung University in the southern city of Tainan, disclosed Tuesday that in addition to antofine, his research has found that deoxypergularinine -- another compound belonging to the phenanthroindolizidine type alkaloid group -- also shows strong anti-cancer activity.

Wu has been studying Chinese herbal medicine for more than 30 years. Because his previous studies with several professors at the University of North Carolina showed that the pure compound antofine, which is extracted from two plants -- Cryptocarya chinensis and Ficus septica -- has significant potency against various human tumor cell lines, he and his team at NCKU decided to study it further.
The results of his previous research were published in the June 1 issue of Bio- organic and Medicinal Chemistry, a fortnightly journal published in the United States.
During the process of his more recent work, his team used an organic chemistry method to synthesize antofine, deoxypergularinine and their dehydro congeners.
All the synthetic compounds and intermediates were screened against lung, breast and nasopharyngeal cancer cell lines and the multidrug-resistant cancer cell subline known as KB-VIN.

According to Wu, the results show that antofine had the best effect against all four cancer cell lines, while deoxypergularine also performed well, although it was less potent than antofine. The dehydro congeners showed reduced potency against all cell lines.
The laboratory research reconfirms that antofine has significant potency against various human tumor cell lines, offering the potential for a new anticancer medicine, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition on Silk Road artifacts from Xinjiang to kick off in Taipei

TEXT.P: Some 150 priceless artifacts from the Silk Road era, including a remarkably well-preserved female mummy unearthed in Xinjiang in northwestern China, will be exhibited at Taiwan's National Museum of History in Taipei from Dec. 6, the organizers announced Tuesday.

Speaking at a press conference, museum director Huang Yung-chuan said the exhibition will feature pre-Qin Dynasty metal vessels, textiles from Han and Jin dynasties, Wei and Jin Dynasty wall paintings and Tang Dynasty silk paintings discovered in China's Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, part of what was formerly known as the Western Territories and a vital hub on the Silk Road.

Thanks to the region's dry climate and geographic situation, Huang said, the color and luster of the ancient artifacts are "so well-preserved that they look as though they were just painted yesterday."

The organizer made particular mention of one highlight called the "Loulan Beauty, " a female caucasian mummy dating back around 3,800 years that still has hair, skin and organs that remain undecayed and which created shockwaves in archaeological circles upon its discovery.

The exhibits, which will be divided into five categories based on their cultural features, reflect the grandeur of the desert frontier of the Western Territories and have incalculable academic value for those studying trade, transport, ancient civilizations and Chinese-Western interchanges during previous eras, according to Huang.

Anwar Khasim, an official from the Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous Region Museum, said that other features of the exhibition include China's only wooden guardian warrior stamping on a demon, an artifact that was used to protect the spirit of the deceased, as well as a wool robe for a male mummy with Persian-style embroidery and ancient Greek design.
The exhibition will continue until mid-March next year, according to museum officials.

The Silk Road was a trade route that extended for over 7,000 km, over 1,700 km of which was inside China, which connects Asia and the Mediterranean region. It starts in the east in the Chinese city of Changan and ends in the west in what is now the Turkish city of Instanbul, formerly known as Constantinople, which was at one time the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agenda for next cross-strait meet to be ready by late December

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday the agenda for the third meeting between the top negotiators on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be finalized by the end of this month or early January at the latest.
MAC Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng made the remarks in an informal meeting with the media.

Fu noted that during the second round of talks between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation, and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, both sides proposed an agenda for the next round of negotiations.
As there are still some differences to be worked out, Fu said, it can be "reasonably concluded" that the agenda for the next round of talks will be ready by late December or early January, Fu said.
But he disclosed that a memorandum of understanding on financial cooperation is one issue that is sure to be on the agenda as both sides feel this should be addressed as soon as possible.

The agenda proposed by the SEF included cross-strait cooperation in the areas of combating crime, strengthening food safety, the inspection and quarantine of agriculture produce, and on financial, investment, fishery and cultural and educational cooperation.
The SEF also proposed increasing dialogues between the SEF and the ARATS.

For its part, the ARATS proposed that the agenda include joint efforts to combat crime, inspection and quarantine of plants and animals, financial and industrial cooperation, investment and intellectual property protection, fishery cooperation and reciprocal stationing of news reporters.
Chiang and Chen held landmark talks in Beijing in June this year, reaching agreements on wider opening by Taiwan to Chinese tourists and direct weekend charter flights between the two sides.
In the second round of talks, the two sides signed accords on direct shipping, postal and expanded air links and a food safety reporting mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Remote schools benefit from Web-based English learning program

TEXT.P: Five elementary schools in remote parts of the country that have been recipients of a Web-based literacy program donated by IBM have made improvements rated at over 60 percent in terms of their students' English learning, an IBM executive said Tuesday.

According to Tung Chih-hsiang, IBM-Taiwan's general manager, students at the schools have made progress in English pronunciation and vocabulary ability by using a program called Reading Companion. Their interest in learning the language has also increased as a result of the program.

The five elementary schools, which received the software and related equipment in September, are Jhuwei in Taipei County, Kelin in Yilan County, Jinjhu in Kaohsiung County, Chiangyuan in Pingtung County and Chulai in Taitung County.

The program applies advanced voice identification technology to "listen" to users speaking English and provides feedback, allowing users to adjust and correct their pronunciation, Tung said, adding that students can also borrow equipment from their schools to practice at home.

He made special mention of Jhuwei Elementary School, which is making an electronic illustrated book using the program's Book Builder feature to introduce four foods associated with Taipei County's Tamsui township -- fish balls, plum juice, fried tofu and iron egg.
Teachers will read and record the book and upload the recordings to the program's online global library so that users all over the world will be able to learn something about Tamsui, Tung said.

He noted that the Reading Companion program is one of IBM's plans for education reforms, in which the company has invested US$75 million. The literacy program started in 2006 and has been utilized by over 450 schools and non-profit organizations around the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung hopes for forgiveness of NT$38b debt to central government

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is hoping for debt forgiveness in respect of NT$38.1 billion in labor insurance fees and health insurance premiums that it owes to the central government, a senior city government official said Tuesday.

Lei Chung-da, director of the Finance Bureau of the Kaohsiung city government, said that since 1993, the central government has seized 39 tracts of land owned by the city government because the city government could not afford to pay its share of the labor insurance fees and the health insurance premiums.

According to the Labor Insurance Act and the National Health Insurance Act, the city government, as a special municipality under the control of the Cabinet, has an obligation to shoulder 5 percent of the labor insurance fees and health insurance premiums for certain employees, including employees of publicly and privately owned enterprises or institutions.
Lei said the seizure of the 39 tracts of land -- worth billions of New Taiwan Dollars -- by the central government has hampered many of the city's development projects.
He urged the central government to amend the existing relevant laws to forgive the city's debts and alleviate the local government's financial difficulties.
Lei welcomed a decision made by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan a few days ago that the Cabinet will delink Kaohsiung's debts to the central government from seizure of Kaohsiung's land.

He said Kaohsiung's debt to the central government is growing by NT$5.6 billion annually, and that although the city government has set aside NT$3.6 billion every year to pay back the central government, it will never be able to settle the debt.

DOC.HEADLINE: City government begins site selection for damaged gondola tower

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government has begun the process of selecting a site for the possible relocation of a damaged support tower on the Maokong Gondola system, Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday.

"We have started a feasibility study and evaluation of possible sites for relocation of damaged support tower T-16 in accordance with recommendations by local civil engineering experts, " Hau told a news conference held after a city government policy review meeting.

The cable car system, a popular tourist attraction in a mountainous area of Taipei's suburban Wenshan district, was closed indefinitely Oct. 1 out of concern that Tower No. 16 could collapse during an earthquake after torrential rain brought by Typhoon Jangmei in September eroded the base of the tower, leaving it bare and exposed.

An initial safety assessment filed by four major civil engineering associations Sunday strongly recommended that the tower be relocated and that the entire slope in the vicinity of the pillar be reinforced to make the Maokong Gondola safe.

According to a preliminary estimate by city officials, relocating the tower will cost at least NT$200 million (US$6 million) and will take two years, while simply reinforcing the existing tower in its original location will take only six months.

As relocation would involve a raft of professional technical details, including comprehensive geological and topographic data, Hau said a final decision on whether the damaged support pillar should be relocated or reinforced will not be made until after the city government has received a final assessment from the four civil engineering groups, which is expected to be submitted by Dec. 12.
Hau said he has directed relevant city staff to begin a relocation feasibility study and evaluation of various possible sites based on the civil engineering groups' recommendations.

As to whether anyone should to be called to account for giving the go-ahead for construction of the gondola system on an area of weak bedrock, Hau said the issue will be addressed after the civil engineering groups provide their final assessment.

"If any civil servants are found to be liable for the original site selection and any subsequent construction flaws, the city government will transfer all relevant information to the watchdog Control Yuan, which will carry out the investigation," Hau added.
Residents in the neighborhood have vowed to launch strong protests if the damaged tower is not moved.

City councilors from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party have criticized Hau's predecessor Ma Ying-jeou, who is now president, for what they describe as mishandling of the gondola construction project.
In response, Hau contended that as a mayor cannot decide the location of the support towers, "former Mayor Ma Ying-jeou bears no political responsibility."

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec.3, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

The president said that Taiwan has had cordial exchanges with France in many areas and would like to learn from France's nuclear waste disposal expertise. France is a world leader in the area of nuclear technology, with nuclear power accounting for 78 percent of its energy supply.
Ma said that both Taiwan and France will benefit as a result of Taiwan's efforts to improve its international relations.

Taiwan's relations with Europe will also benefit as result of the improvement in Taiwan-China relations and French President Nicolas Sarkozy's assumption of the European Union rotating chairmanship in July, Ma said.
The president also expressed appreciation for the EU's support for Taiwan's efforts this year to participate in the United Nations specialized agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Antofine could be potent anticancer prodrug: Taiwanese scientist

TEXT.P: A study by a Taiwanese professor has led to the finding that antofine -- a phenanthroindolizidine alkaloid compound -- can effectively eliminate human cancer cells and could serve as a new anti-cancer prodrug.

Wu Tian-shung, who teaches at the Department of Chemistry of National Cheng Kung University in the southern city of Tainan, disclosed Tuesday that in addition to antofine, his research has found that deoxypergularinine -- another compound belonging to the phenanthroindolizidine type alkaloid group -- also shows strong anti-cancer activity.

Wu has been studying Chinese herbal medicine for more than 30 years. Because his previous studies with several professors at the University of North Carolina showed that the pure compound antofine, which is extracted from two plants -- Cryptocarya chinensis and Ficus septica -- has significant potency against various human tumor cell lines, he and his team at NCKU decided to study it further.
The results of his previous research were published in the June 1 issue of Bio- organic and Medicinal Chemistry, a fortnightly journal published in the United States.
During the process of his more recent work, his team used an organic chemistry method to synthesize antofine, deoxypergularinine and their dehydro congeners.
All the synthetic compounds and intermediates were screened against lung, breast and nasopharyngeal cancer cell lines and the multidrug-resistant cancer cell subline known as KB-VIN.

According to Wu, the results show that antofine had the best effect against all four cancer cell lines, while deoxypergularine also performed well, although it was less potent than antofine. The dehydro congeners showed reduced potency against all cell lines.
The laboratory research reconfirms that antofine has significant potency against various human tumor cell lines, offering the potential for a new anticancer medicine, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition on Silk Road artifacts from Xinjiang to kick off in Taipei

TEXT.P: Some 150 priceless artifacts from the Silk Road era, including a remarkably well-preserved female mummy unearthed in Xinjiang in northwestern China, will be exhibited at Taiwan's National Museum of History in Taipei from Dec. 6, the organizers announced Tuesday.

Speaking at a press conference, museum director Huang Yung-chuan said the exhibition will feature pre-Qin Dynasty metal vessels, textiles from Han and Jin dynasties, Wei and Jin Dynasty wall paintings and Tang Dynasty silk paintings discovered in China's Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, part of what was formerly known as the Western Territories and a vital hub on the Silk Road.

Thanks to the region's dry climate and geographic situation, Huang said, the color and luster of the ancient artifacts are "so well-preserved that they look as though they were just painted yesterday."

The organizer made particular mention of one highlight called the "Loulan Beauty, " a female caucasian mummy dating back around 3,800 years that still has hair, skin and organs that remain undecayed and which created shockwaves in archaeological circles upon its discovery.

The exhibits, which will be divided into five categories based on their cultural features, reflect the grandeur of the desert frontier of the Western Territories and have incalculable academic value for those studying trade, transport, ancient civilizations and Chinese-Western interchanges during previous eras, according to Huang.

Anwar Khasim, an official from the Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous Region Museum, said that other features of the exhibition include China's only wooden guardian warrior stamping on a demon, an artifact that was used to protect the spirit of the deceased, as well as a wool robe for a male mummy with Persian-style embroidery and ancient Greek design.
The exhibition will continue until mid-March next year, according to museum officials.

The Silk Road was a trade route that extended for over 7,000 km, over 1,700 km of which was inside China, which connects Asia and the Mediterranean region. It starts in the east in the Chinese city of Changan and ends in the west in what is now the Turkish city of Instanbul, formerly known as Constantinople, which was at one time the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agenda for next cross-strait meet to be ready by late December

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday the agenda for the third meeting between the top negotiators on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be finalized by the end of this month or early January at the latest.
MAC Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng made the remarks in an informal meeting with the media.

Fu noted that during the second round of talks between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation, and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, both sides proposed an agenda for the next round of negotiations.
As there are still some differences to be worked out, Fu said, it can be "reasonably concluded" that the agenda for the next round of talks will be ready by late December or early January, Fu said.
But he disclosed that a memorandum of understanding on financial cooperation is one issue that is sure to be on the agenda as both sides feel this should be addressed as soon as possible.

The agenda proposed by the SEF included cross-strait cooperation in the areas of combating crime, strengthening food safety, the inspection and quarantine of agriculture produce, and on financial, investment, fishery and cultural and educational cooperation.
The SEF also proposed increasing dialogues between the SEF and the ARATS.

For its part, the ARATS proposed that the agenda include joint efforts to combat crime, inspection and quarantine of plants and animals, financial and industrial cooperation, investment and intellectual property protection, fishery cooperation and reciprocal stationing of news reporters.
Chiang and Chen held landmark talks in Beijing in June this year, reaching agreements on wider opening by Taiwan to Chinese tourists and direct weekend charter flights between the two sides.
In the second round of talks, the two sides signed accords on direct shipping, postal and expanded air links and a food safety reporting mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Remote schools benefit from Web-based English learning program

TEXT.P: Five elementary schools in remote parts of the country that have been recipients of a Web-based literacy program donated by IBM have made improvements rated at over 60 percent in terms of their students' English learning, an IBM executive said Tuesday.

According to Tung Chih-hsiang, IBM-Taiwan's general manager, students at the schools have made progress in English pronunciation and vocabulary ability by using a program called Reading Companion. Their interest in learning the language has also increased as a result of the program.

The five elementary schools, which received the software and related equipment in September, are Jhuwei in Taipei County, Kelin in Yilan County, Jinjhu in Kaohsiung County, Chiangyuan in Pingtung County and Chulai in Taitung County.

The program applies advanced voice identification technology to "listen" to users speaking English and provides feedback, allowing users to adjust and correct their pronunciation, Tung said, adding that students can also borrow equipment from their schools to practice at home.

He made special mention of Jhuwei Elementary School, which is making an electronic illustrated book using the program's Book Builder feature to introduce four foods associated with Taipei County's Tamsui township -- fish balls, plum juice, fried tofu and iron egg.
Teachers will read and record the book and upload the recordings to the program's online global library so that users all over the world will be able to learn something about Tamsui, Tung said.

He noted that the Reading Companion program is one of IBM's plans for education reforms, in which the company has invested US$75 million. The literacy program started in 2006 and has been utilized by over 450 schools and non-profit organizations around the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung hopes for forgiveness of NT$38b debt to central government

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is hoping for debt forgiveness in respect of NT$38.1 billion in labor insurance fees and health insurance premiums that it owes to the central government, a senior city government official said Tuesday.

Lei Chung-da, director of the Finance Bureau of the Kaohsiung city government, said that since 1993, the central government has seized 39 tracts of land owned by the city government because the city government could not afford to pay its share of the labor insurance fees and the health insurance premiums.

According to the Labor Insurance Act and the National Health Insurance Act, the city government, as a special municipality under the control of the Cabinet, has an obligation to shoulder 5 percent of the labor insurance fees and health insurance premiums for certain employees, including employees of publicly and privately owned enterprises or institutions.
Lei said the seizure of the 39 tracts of land -- worth billions of New Taiwan Dollars -- by the central government has hampered many of the city's development projects.
He urged the central government to amend the existing relevant laws to forgive the city's debts and alleviate the local government's financial difficulties.
Lei welcomed a decision made by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan a few days ago that the Cabinet will delink Kaohsiung's debts to the central government from seizure of Kaohsiung's land.

He said Kaohsiung's debt to the central government is growing by NT$5.6 billion annually, and that although the city government has set aside NT$3.6 billion every year to pay back the central government, it will never be able to settle the debt.

DOC.HEADLINE: City government begins site selection for damaged gondola tower

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government has begun the process of selecting a site for the possible relocation of a damaged support tower on the Maokong Gondola system, Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Tuesday.

"We have started a feasibility study and evaluation of possible sites for relocation of damaged support tower T-16 in accordance with recommendations by local civil engineering experts, " Hau told a news conference held after a city government policy review meeting.

The cable car system, a popular tourist attraction in a mountainous area of Taipei's suburban Wenshan district, was closed indefinitely Oct. 1 out of concern that Tower No. 16 could collapse during an earthquake after torrential rain brought by Typhoon Jangmei in September eroded the base of the tower, leaving it bare and exposed.

An initial safety assessment filed by four major civil engineering associations Sunday strongly recommended that the tower be relocated and that the entire slope in the vicinity of the pillar be reinforced to make the Maokong Gondola safe.

According to a preliminary estimate by city officials, relocating the tower will cost at least NT$200 million (US$6 million) and will take two years, while simply reinforcing the existing tower in its original location will take only six months.

As relocation would involve a raft of professional technical details, including comprehensive geological and topographic data, Hau said a final decision on whether the damaged support pillar should be relocated or reinforced will not be made until after the city government has received a final assessment from the four civil engineering groups, which is expected to be submitted by Dec. 12.
Hau said he has directed relevant city staff to begin a relocation feasibility study and evaluation of various possible sites based on the civil engineering groups' recommendations.

As to whether anyone should to be called to account for giving the go-ahead for construction of the gondola system on an area of weak bedrock, Hau said the issue will be addressed after the civil engineering groups provide their final assessment.

"If any civil servants are found to be liable for the original site selection and any subsequent construction flaws, the city government will transfer all relevant information to the watchdog Control Yuan, which will carry out the investigation," Hau added.
Residents in the neighborhood have vowed to launch strong protests if the damaged tower is not moved.

City councilors from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party have criticized Hau's predecessor Ma Ying-jeou, who is now president, for what they describe as mishandling of the gondola construction project.
In response, Hau contended that as a mayor cannot decide the location of the support towers, "former Mayor Ma Ying-jeou bears no political responsibility."
