DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 3, or the sixth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Madrid surrenders to French forces led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
1810: Britain captures the island of Mauritius from France.
1818: Illinois becomes the 21st state of the United States.
1828: John Quincy Adams loses the U.S. presidential election to his arch-rival Andrew Jackson.
1894: Robert Louis Stevenson, Scottish writer of essays, poetry and novels, dies at the age of 44. He authored "Treasure Island," "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "Kidnapped."
1901: American film producer and film animator Walt Disney is born. He created such immortals as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck.
1943: The Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference is issued simultaneously in Chungking, Washington and London.
1944: U.S. forces advance across the Saar River in Germany during World War II.
1948: Republic of China government troops evacuate Hsuchow in eastern China.
1958: Dutch businesses are nationalized in Indonesia.
1960: Chou Tao-chi graduates from National Chengchi University and becomes the first student to earn a national doctorate in the Republic of China.
1966: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone is inaugurated.
1966: Macau imposes a curfew after massive riots allegedly incited by the Communist Chinese.
1967: South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan Barnard successfully performs a human heart transplant, the first of its kind in the world.
1971: Pakistani planes attack northwest India in a dispute over Kashmir. India responds by declaring a state of emergency.
1975: Communists take control of Laos, declare an end to the 600-year-old monarchy and set up the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.
1976: Rear Adm. James H. Morris, commander of the amphibious forces of the U.S. 7th Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) wins a landslide victory in supplementary parliamentary elections. The KMT captures 62 of 71 seats up for grabs in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition wins six seats and independents take three.
1989: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev end a summit meeting on Malta in the Mediterranean Sea, signaling the end of the Cold War and entry into a new era of peace and cooperation.
1992: Millions of gallons of crude oil spill into the sea off the coast of La Coruna, Spain, threatening ecological disaster.
1993: Ukraine and the United States fail to resolve a dispute over Ukraine's stockpile of some 1,000 long-range nuclear warheads.
1994: The first popular elections for the governor of Taiwan Province and the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities are held. James C.Y. Soong is elected governor of Taiwan. Chen Shui-bian and Wu Den-yih win the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
1995: Chun Doo Hwan, former president of South Korea, is arrested on charges of military rebellion stemming from a 1979 coup and a later massacre of civilians by the army.
1997: South Korea signs a letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a loan of US$57 billion, the largest of its kind ever provided by the IMF, to help South Korea get through its financial crisis.
1999: Visiting Malawian President Bakili Muluzi and his ROC counterpart Lee Teng-hui sign a communique reconfirming the friendship between their two countries.
2000: Francis Ng wins the "Best Leading Actor Award," Maggie Cheung wins the "Best Leading Actress Award," and To Kei-Fung wins the "Best Director Award" at the 2000 Golden Horse Awards.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says his party's dramatic win in legislative elections will not change his commitment to improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that he is willing to share political power and resources with other political parties on the basis of mutual respect, to promote political stability, national identity and democratic reform.
Motse's lesson of the day: "We are certain that heaven desires to have men love and benefit one another and abominates to have them hate and harm one another."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
No information from China on WHA bid talks: presidential spokesman

TEXT.P: The government has not received any information about talks with China on Taiwan's bid to take part in the annual World Health Assembly (WHA) meeting, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said late Tuesday.

Wang was responding to reports that Beijing is open to dealing with issues regarding Taiwan's participation in the WHA -- the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO) -- in line with a joint communique issued after a meeting in Beijing in 2005 between then-Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and Chinese President Hu Jintao.

The reports quoted an unidentified KMT official as saying that when Hu met with Lien on the sidelines of the annual Asia Pacific Economic Forum (APEC) leaders' summit in Peru, he expressed the hope that President Ma Ying-jeou would send delegates to Beijing to discuss the WHA issue.
Lien, now the KMT's honorary chairman, served as Ma's envoy at the Nov. 22-23 APEC summit held in the Peruvian capital of Lima.
Wang said the government has been working toward its goal of securing participation in the 2009 WHA to be held next May in Geneva.
"We have been striving hard for this target and will never stop our efforts until realizing the goal, " he said.
As to how Taiwan will participate in the annual WHA activities, Wang said the government has not yet received any further information.

Because of Beijing's sovereignty claim, Taiwan has been barred from taking part in international organizations or activities that require statehood, including the United Nations and the U.N.-affiliated WHO and its governing body, the WHA.

In the 2005 Lien-Hu joint communique, the two men pledged to galvanize the two sides to address the aspiration of Taiwan's people to be represented in major international activities, particularly Taiwan's participation in WHO activities.
At the time, the KMT was in opposition and Hu signed the communique in his capacity as general secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC).
The two parties promised to work together to create favorable conditions for an ultimate solution to the thorny issue regarding Taiwan's participation in world organizations.
Lien's office would not comment on the latest reports about Hu's hope of President Ma sending delegates to China for talks on WHA issues.

Although the KMT returned to power in May this year, senior party officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there is little chance that Taiwan's WHA participation issue will be addressed through the KMT-CPC dialogue platform.
In their view, they added, the issue should instead be handled by the Cabinet- level Mainland Affairs Council and Taiwan's quasi-official intermediary body -- the Straits Exchange Foundation.

Meanwhile, KMT Deputy Secretary-General Chang Jung-kung, who concurrently heads the KMT's Mainland Affairs Department, said he had not heard Lien mention China's hope that Ma send envoys to China for talks on the WHA issue.
As to a regular KMT-CPC forum scheduled to take place later this month, Chang said the meeting's agenda will focus on economic and trade topics and will not address the WHA bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: Murderer in love rivalry case released on parole

TEXT.P: A former graduate student of National Tsinghua University who murdered her love rival and mutilated her body in 1998 was released on parole Wednesday after serving over two-thirds, or nearly 11 years, of her sentence for the crime.
Hung Hsiao-huei was given her freedom from the Kaohsiung Women's Prison in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, after the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) granted her parole Nov. 11.

The MOJ cited a number of factors in its decision, including that Hung had served over two-thirds of her sentence of 16 years and three months without misbehaving and had been awarded merits on nine occasions for good behavior as an inmate.
It also said the prison promised that Hung would have full family support and have no problem looking for work upon her release.

Meeting the press at the gate of the prison, Hung once again apologized to the parents of her victim, graduate school classmate Hsu Chia-chen, and expressed her willingness to do whatever she could to compensate them for their loss.
Hung apologized for the shock and disturbance she had caused the country and offered her appreciation to Taiwan's society for "giving her an opportunity to restart her life as a new person."

Accompanied by volunteers from the nonprofit social service group Taiwan After- care Association, Hung then reported to the Kaohsiung District Prosecutors Office, where she met probation officers on matters regarding her release and how she should behave after being freed.
Hung will be on parole for the remaining five years of her sentence, during which she will be required by law to report to probation officers once a month.
The Kaohsiung Women's Prison had previously applied for parole on Hung's behalf four times, but was rejected three times by a Kaohsiung prison parole review board and once by the MOJ.
MOJ officials said those rejections came after taking into consideration such factors as social justice, the perceptions of the general public and the feelings of the family of the victim.
Hung was found guilty of killing and mutilating Hsu in an auditorium at National Tsinghua University in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan, in March 1998.
At the time, Hung and Hsu were second-year graduate students at the prestigious university's radiobiology institute vying for the affection of the same man.

During an argument, Hung knocked Hsu unconscious and poured aqua regia -- a potent corrosive chemical -- over Hsu's nose and mouth, killing her classmate. Hung then dragged the body to the rear of the auditorium in the hope that it would remain undetected.

Hung was eventually sentenced to 18 years in a jail, which was reduced last year to 16 years and three months, and ordered by the court to pay Hsu's parents NT$24 million (US$718,563) in compensation.

Hung served part of her sentence at the Taipei Prison and the Taoyuan Prison from January 1999 through March 2001. She was transferred to Kaohsiung Women's Prison on March 21, 2001, and has been held there ever since.

Known as the prison's best-educated inmate, Hung taught other inmates English and various other subjects, prison sources said, adding that she looked forward to continuing her graduate studies after her release.
They also said Hung hopes society will forgive her and will allow her to get back on her feet and save enough money to meet her obligations to Hsu's parents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expects sound ties with U.S. under Obama administration
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/03/08 14:25:36 (By Jennifer Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and the United States should remain sound under the new administration of U.S. President-elect Barack Obama as Taipei continues to try to rebuild mutual trust between the two sides, a high-ranking Taiwan official said in London Tuesday.

Expressing optimism over the future development of Taiwan-U.S. relations, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Andrew Li-yan Hsia said he believes "it will not be too difficult" to restore the frienship that was broken by the former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration, citing improving relations between Taipei and Washington since President Ma Ying-jeou was inaugurated six months ago.
In his keynote speech at the Royal United Services Institue for Defence and Securities in London, Hsia contrasted the approaches of Ma's administration and the previous DPP government.

During the eight-year DPP administration, he argued, Taiwan followed a diplomatic policy that emphasized the country's sovereignty and highlighted its presence in the international community using extreme methods, without regard for the economic and military prowess of China.

Such an approach was unsuccessful in achieving Taiwan's goal for membership in the United Nations and World Health Organization, and instead cost the country the support of international friends, Hsia contended.
The number of Taiwan's diplomatic allies fell from 29 to 23 during those eight years, and the country was labeled a "troublemaker," he said.
Since his May 20 inauguration, President Ma has been working to improve Taiwan's ties with China and engage in foreign relations using a pragmatic approach, Hsia said.

With Taiwan-China dialogue resuming in June and a second round of talks following in November, the two sides have signed several agreements to pave the way for direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport and postal links and improved food safety, he said.
Hsia told his audience that Ma's foreign policy is aimed at turning Taiwan into a "peacemaker" and preventing Taiwan and China from wasting resources on unnecessary diplomatic competition.
Under such a policy, Ma advocates expanding Taiwan's international participation while maintaining the status quo in which Taiwan has 23 diplomatic allies and China has 171, he said.

Stressing that it is very important for Taiwan to enjoy a reasonable presence in the international community, Hsia warned that if Beijing continues to suppress Taiwan's bids to participate in international organizations, it will fuel anti- China sentiment among Taiwan's people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Wednesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for December falling 42 points to end at 4,188, with 94,456 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for January lost 30 points to finish at 4,160, with 838 contracts traded, while March futures declined 27 points to end at 4,128, with 24 contracts traded.
June futures advanced one point to close at 4,119, with 11 contract transactions, while September futures remained unchanged at 3,950, with seven contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 4,230 for December, 4,190 for January, 4,155 for March, 4,118 for June and 3,950 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 49.72 points to finish at 4,307.26, on turnover of NT$59.42 billion (US$1.77 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
December TE futures fell 5.5 points to close at 151.2, with 6,689 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 5.4 points to finish at 149, with 44 contracts traded.

March TE futures dropped 5.55 points to finish at 145.85 points, with three contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 2.4 points to close at 143.35, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.
December TF futures were down 2.6 points to close at 524, with 4,288 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures increased 0.6 points to finish at 520.2, with 49 contracts traded.

March TF futures advanced 14.6 points to end at 526.6, with one contract traded, while June TF futures increased 4.6 points to close at 507, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 49.72 points, or 1.14 percent, to close at 4,307.26.

Finishing lower for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,346.05 and fluctuated between 4,379.25 and 4,289.13 during trading. A total of 4 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$59.42 billion (US$1.77 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 1.09 percent. Paper and pulp issues increased 1.04 percent, cement stocks were up 0.44 percent, textile stocks advanced 0.12 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares gained 0.1 percent.

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 2.16 percent. Construction issues declined 0.22 percent and banking and financial shares were down 0.08 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 757 to 536, with 332 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$6.88 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Demand for key posts remains high: job bank

TEXT.P: Although most local companies have stopped hiring additional workers or are planning job cuts, demand for key posts remains high at a few businesses that intend to expand their workforces, an online employment service provider said Wednesday.

According to the results of a survey conducted by the 104 Job Bank, only about 10 percent of the companies surveyed are projecting to recruit new workers, with 41.6 percent of them offering jobs only for key posts such as business representatives, researchers or management personnel.

Among those companies questioned that have plans to employ new workers, 21.9 percent said they need middle- and high-ranking directors, the survey shows. The information industry has the greatest demand in this regard, with prominent companies like Acer Computer, Asustek Computer, Quanta Computer and Toshiba Electronics Taiwan Corp. all planning to conduct hiring.
Amid the ongoing economic recession, about 60 percent of the companies polled said they plan to begin recruiting new workers only when business conditions show signs of improvement.

Most of the companies are resorting to layoffs, cutting salaries, forcing workers to take unpaid leave or leaving vacant posts unfilled in a bid to tackle the financial squeeze, a job bank executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. to support Taiwan's pursuit of international space: think tank

TEXT.P: Brookings Institution President Strobe Talbott said Wednesday that the next United States administration will support the concept of giving Taiwan more international space and insisted that there would be continuity in Washington's Taiwan Strait policy.

Speaking at a seminar held to discuss the impact of a new U.S. administration on relations between Taiwan and China, Talbott argued that Taiwan should be allowed to participate in the international community because the world of today is much more complicated than in the past and countries are more interdependent.

"Taiwan is part of the international community and has contributed to the international community, " said Talbott, citing Taiwan's presence in the World Trade Organization and its contributions in medicine and public health."

The next U.S. admininstration will therefore support "the concept of giving more international space to Taiwan, " said Talbott, who served as deputy secretary of state from 1994 to 2001 during the Clinton administration and has been mentioned as a possible appointee in the new government.

Richard Bush, director of the Brookings Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies (CNAPS) and former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, questioned, however, whether the United States might not pay less attention to Taiwan in view of its severe economic challenges.

He said people in Taiwan are concerned about how the new administration and policies of U.S. President-elect Barack Obama would affect other countries, "including the cross-strait development between Taiwan and mainland China."
Talbott responded that relations would remain unchanged, as they had since the U.S. formally broke ties with Taiwan to recognize China in 1979.

"Since 1979, we have had five United States presidents, three Republicans and two Democrats. Sometimes the conservative ones replaced the liberal president, or vice versa. But the U.S.-Taiwan relationship remains fundamentally the same," Talbott said.
Talbott said Washington's Taiwan Strait policy would continue to be based on the "one-China" policy, the three communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act.

"The United States' commitment to peace, stability, and a non-confrontation approach in cross-strait matters has no changes whatsoever, " Talbott said. "I would say that President-elect Obama will continue the previous U.S. policy in the Asia region. You can count on it."

The new president-elect, however, will change the overall American approach to foreign policy based on the ideas of a "common humanity" and "common security" articulated in his campaign, Talbott said.

"Obama is assuming himself as the diplomatic chief. He thinks of the U.S. president as a community organizer, helping the international community to organize things to meet global problems and to come up with global solutions," Talbott said.
That will mean a return to the principles of pragmatism and multilateralism following the failure of unilaterism, Talbott said.

"The U.S. needs to refurbish its image. And to do that we need help from our allies. We also need their help to address the daunting challenge of the economic crisis that is emerging, " argued Talbott, who said this new focus should be good news to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City continuing push for cable car project

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City government is continuing its push for construction of a cable car system in the southern port city, as the Maokong Gondola in Taipei's suburban Muzha area has been plagued by mounting safety concerns, a city government official said Wednesday.

Installing a cross-Kaohsiung harbor cable car system is part of a Kaohsiung City government project to develop its Cijin island into a popular tourist destination similar to Sentosa Island in Singapore, according to Wu Yi-lung, chief of the city's Urban Development Planning Bureau.
He said the Sentosa-style resort plan was submitted to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications' Tourism Bureau for review but has not yet been approved.
The plan involves opening 100 hectares of land between the Cijin Windmill Park and the Chihou Fortress for private investment in hotels, cable cars and amusement park facilities, Wu added.

Noting that the cost of the development plan is estimated at NT$46 billion (US$1.37 billion) , Wu said that after the plan is approved by the Tourism Bureau, the city government will develop the land into aspecial tourism zone to attract investment from tourism and gambling operators.

Wu said the city government plans to build two cross-harbor cable car routes -- one connecting Kaohsiung MRT Sizihwan Station and Chihou and the other from Chihou to the Chungchou Windmill Park in Cijin. The two routes will be built over a total distance of 3.5 kilometers at a cost of around NT$1.7 billion, he added.

He also said that the municipal government is not worried about encountering the same safety problems as on the Maokong Gondola system because the planned Kaohsiung cable car system will be built on a non-sensitive geological area. He added that once the support pillars on the proposed system are stable enough, there should be no safety problems.
The Maokong Gondola service has been suspended since October 1 over safety concerns after mudslides created by Typhoon Jangmei left a2.5m gap beneath one of its support pillars.

Although Cijin was selected as the third most popular scenic spot around the country, it has not attracted enough tourists to generate higher consumption in the area, according to Wu. He said the government therefore decided to designate a special tourism zone to help boost the local economy.
Many enterprises from home and abroad have shown interest in investing in the construction of hotels and leisure facilities in Cijin once all public infrastructure is completed, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Less job-hopping amid recession

TEXT.P: Fewer salaried people are daring to switch jobs amid the economic sluggishness, while those who have recently changed jobs have found they are being paid less than they earned in their previous jobs, an online job bank said Wednesday.

Chiu Wen-jen, a supervisor at the 104 Job Bank, said the number of office workers who plan to change jobs this year has declined 14 percent compared to last year, quoting the results of a survey carried out by the company recently.

About 30 percent of those who succeeded in changing jobs in the most recent three months found that their starting salaries in their new companies have been lower by an average of 14.3 percent compared with their previous salaries, Chiu said.

He said the bleak business climate has reduced people's willingness to change jobs, with 30.4 percent of the survey respondents choosing to stick with their current jobs in order to "save their rice bowls," representing double the figure recorded last year.

A high of 76 percent of the respondents said they had become much more timid in making changes in the face of the domestic economic downturn caused by the global financial meltdown, according to Chiu.

Of those who want to change jobs, a great majority mentioned failure of their current salaries to meet their expectations or reaching their promotion ceiling as reasons for a change, according to Chiu.

The poll found that employees in the tourism, mass communications and manufacturing sectors are keenest to change jobs, as these businesses have been hardest-hit by the economic downturn and heavy layoffs are most likely to occur before the end of the year, Chiu noted.

The poll also found that employees in the financial services and high tech sectors -- two fields that are traditionally highly coveted -- have become increasingly restless and more inclined to change jobs, Chiu went on.

Over 60 percent of the employees surveyed in these two sectors said they want to change careers, Chiu said, adding that of these, some 30 percent of the financial services professionals wanted to move to other service industries, while less then 20 percent wanted to remain in their current employment.

Taiwan's jobless rate in October hit a five-year monthly high of 4.37 percent, one of a number of indicators reflecting the country's weakening labor market as a result of the global economic straits, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.039 to close at NT$33.528.
A total of US$705 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.489 and fluctuated between NT$33.435 and NT$33.554.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to shorten conscription term to one year

TEXT.P: A draft amendment to Taiwan's Conscription Act was passed preliminarily by a legislative committee Wednesday, shortening the term of conscription from one year and two months to one year.

The Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee passed preliminarily the draft amendment to Article 16 of the Conscription Act, calling for the shortening of the conscription period to one year, beginning January 2009.

Lu Shiow-yen, a legislator from the ruling Kuomintang, which controls nearly three-fourths of the legislative seats, said the amendment is adopted in response to the government's policy of continuously shortening the draft period.
Since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949, Taiwan's government has required young men over the age of 18 to undergo military training, due to the threat of possible attacks from its rival China.
The Ministry of National Defense began to shorten the term of conscription in 2004, when the period of mandatory military service was reduced from one year and 10 months to one year and eight months.
By January 2007, the term was shortened to one year and four months and as of July 2007, it was further shortened to one year and two months.
The shortening of the conscription period is part of the government's efforts to downsize Taiwan's armed forces, with a target of cutting the number of troops to fewer than 300,000 by 2009.
Relations between Taiwan and China have improved this year, following the election of President Ma Ying-jeou, who has made reducing tensions and improving ties with China one of his key policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Carotenoid-rich micro-algae protect, repair liver function: study

TEXT.P: A recent study indicates that a micro-alga, dunaliella salina, is capable of protecting and repairing human livers, as the species contains large amounts of carotenoids that can neutralize oxidants and free radicals, according to Chung Shan Medical University (CSMU).

Researchers at the university in the central city of Taichung said Wednesday that although carotenoids can be found in many vegetables, the yield of carotenoid is relatively low. For example, 100 grams of carrot can yield only 12 milligrams of beta-carotene, they said.

However, 6,000 milligrams of beta-carotene can be obtained from 100 grams of dunaliella salina -- 500 times higher than the yield from carrots, making it a far better source of carotenoids, the researchers explained.

More than 600 kinds of carotenoid have been discovered to date, including alpha- carotene, beta-carotene, lycopene, lutein, and zeaxanthin. Carotenoid, an organic pigment in essence, can help the human body synthesize vitamins and prevent oxidation damage.

Lu Fung-Jou, a professor at CSMU's Institute of Medicine, noted that with their anti-oxidizing effect, carotenoids can be good anti- aging agents. They can also help to prevent chronic diseases and age- related macular degeneration (AMD), an eye disease, he said.
"Five of them -- alpha-carotene, beta-carotene, lycopene, lutein, and zeaxanthin -- are the most effective of all," Lu added.

Lu said the research team found in its lab experiments that dunaliella salina not only contains all five of the most effective carotenoids, but also that it is effective in protecting the health of organs such as the liver.

In experiments on rodents, the team found that mice whose livers had been damaged showed signs of improved liver functions after being fed with the algae, as their levels of glutamate oxaloacetate transaminase (GOT) , glutamate pyruvate transaminase (GPT) , triglycerides (TG), and cholesterol all dropped noticeably.
Researchers said further analysis and testing may discover the full potential of dunaliella salina and facilitate wider application of the algae.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese bishops to report to the Pope on the state of dioceses

TEXT.P: The Archbishop of the Taipei Archdiocese in Taiwan said Wednesday that he will lead a delegation to the Vatican to present a report for the first time to Pope Benedict XVI on the state of Taiwan's dioceses, and to invite the Pope to attend next year's celebrations of the 150th anniversary of the establishment of the Catholic Church in Taiwan.
"We will present an invitation to the Pope, in the hope that he can visit Taiwan next year," Archbishop John Hung Shan-chuan told the Central News Agency.
As bishops are supposed to meet the Pope every five years, the visit will be the first time for Taiwanese bishops to report to Benedict XVI, who was elected Pope in 2005.
Taiwanese bishops met the late Pope John Paul II in 2002.
If the Pope cannot come to Taiwan, a special envoy or a representative is expected to attend the celebrations next year, Hung said.
The eight-member Taiwanese delegation, including bishops and auxiliary bishops, are slated to leave for the Vatican on Dec. 6. Their trip will last until Dec. 15.
The delegation will also report on Taiwan's dioceses' exchanges with Chinese churches, such as donations of books.

The Catholic Church was established in Taiwan in 1859 when three Spanish Dominican priests from the Philippines and five Chinese missionaries arrived in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, and built the island's first Catholic church.

Catholicism actually first arrived on the island in the 17th Century when Taiwan was occupied by Spanish people. But the brief missions were interrupted when Chinese people defeated foreigners and claimed the island.
According to policies of the Roman Catholic Church, residential diocesan bishops are supposed to visit the pope and report on the state of their dioceses every five years.
To celebrate the 150th anniversary, Taiwan's bishops and parish priests plan to lead 15,000 people to receive the baptism within a year.

According to Peter Liu Cheng-chung, bishop of the Kaohsiung diocese, the number of Taiwan's Catholic followers has reached about 300,000 people, and there are at present 724 Catholic churches, 682 priests and 1,052 nuns in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Miaoli County to launch free after-school program

TEXT.P: The Miaoli county government has decided to earmark a budget of NT$70 million (US$2.09 million) to allow elementary school students in the northern county to attend free after-school classes from next February, county officials said Wednesday.

The educational program has been designed for first-to-fourth graders so that parents can leave their children at school until they finish work and are able to collect them and take them home, the officials

On average, wage earners in Taiwan get off work at 5 p.m., first- and second- graders finish school at noon, while third- and fourth-graders usually finish at noon on Wednesday and Friday and at 4 p.m. during the rest of the week.

Rather than being left to wander the streets until their parents get home, the students will be given the opportunity to sharpen their reading and writing skills and will also be able to play sports under the supervision of teachers, the officials said.

Cheng Lai-chang, director of the Ministry of Education's (MOE's) Department of Elementary Education, said the ministry is pleased that the local government has decided to set up the program to benefit all of the county's first-to-fourth graders and their parents as well.

Since 2003, Cheng said, the MOE has offered free after-school education program for schoolchildren of the socially disadvantaged, including low-income, aboriginal and physically and mentally challenged parents, and earmarks NT$200 million every year to finance it.
To date, 150,000 underprivileged children have benefited from the program, he added.

However, asked if the MOE will extend this program to benefit all elementary- grade children around the country, Cheng said the enormous cost of such a nationwide program would be exorbitant, making the likelihood of central government funding unlikely.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should tighten system to prevent corruption: former HK official

TEXT.P: Taiwan should establish a sound system that can prevent any government officials, whoever they may be, from engaging in corruption, a former official of Hong Kong's Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) said in Taipei Wednesday.

Stephen Char, a former senior corruption prevention officer with the ICAC, made the suggestion while giving a lecture at the Control Yuan -- Taiwan's watchdog body -- on the operations of the ICAC. He will give two more lectures on the same subject during his stay in Taiwan.

Offering his view on the ongoing investigation into allegations of embezzlement, bribe-taking and money laundering by former President Chen Shui-bian, Char said the people of Taiwan should ask: "Why did he have the opportunities to do that?"
Taiwan should set up a system that can prevent anyone who sits in that position from having the opportunity to engage in corruption, he suggested.

"It is the 21st century now. We cannot pray to God to give us an uncorrupt head of state, but we can establish the right system so that anyone who takes that position will not be able to engage in corruption, and if he does, people will know immediately," Char said.

He said that if Taiwan wants to set up an anti-corruption organization in the government similar to Hong Kong's ICAC, the lawmakers preparing the legislation need to consider which government department should have the portfolio.
In Char's opinion, if the anti-corruption body is placed under the Ministry of Justice, it will be at too low a level.

The ICAC answers directly to the chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, he said. However, even so, the chief executive does not have the right to interfere in cases being handled by the ICAC, he added.

According to Char, Taiwan is in a good position to push for corruption-free government because its people are well-educated, and its free news media can play the role of a watchdog against government corruption.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pledges to uphold Constitution in promoting ties with China

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou pledged Wednesday to abide by the Constitution and the "1992 consensus" on the "one China, separate interpretation" issue in promoting relations with China and other countries.

Ma said that while his administration believes improved Taiwan-China relations will help remove many of the barriers the country faces in trying to expand its international participation, the government will not harbor any unrealistic thoughts and will deal with the situation very carefully.

During an interview with Radio Taiwan International, Ma pointed to ruling Kuomintang Honorary Chairman Lien Chan's recent attendance as the president's envoy at the 2008 informal leaders summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum as a successful experience.

Lien, who is also a former Republic of China vice president, was the most prominent figure to be appointed Taiwan's presidential envoy to APEC and was able to take part in the event on an equal footing with other APEC leaders, Ma said.
The president said he was deeply moved by Lien's inclusion because Taiwan has long aspired to have a voice in the international arena, and for the first time, Taiwan "has made it at APEC."
"If we deal with cross-strait relations properly, our space in this aspect will probably increase as well," Ma said.

Ma said he believes Taiwan and China should not only reconcile across the Taiwan Strait but also in the international community, as international participation is an area in which Taiwan's people can find dignity.

According to Ma, besides the progress at APEC, Taiwan's stable relations with its diplomatic allies over the past six months have also been due to the government's efforts to improve cross-strait relations.

Looking ahead, the government hopes to achieve greater progress in promoting Taiwan's bid to participate in the World Health Assembly and will discuss the issue with China during future cross-strait talks, he said.

On the next round of cross-strait talks -- likely to take place in the first half of next year, the president said the government will prioritize long- delayed economic issues such as the signing of a memorandum of understanding on cooperation in financial supervision and regulations, cooperation on fighting crime and the signing of an investment protection pact.

Responding to allegations by opposition Democratic Progressive Party politicians that his administration has been promoting relations with China at the expense of Taiwan's sovereignty, Ma challenged the accusers to specify in what way the six cross-strait agreements signed over the past several months have undermined Taiwan's sovereignty or dignity.
The ROC's status as a sovereign state has not been changed, nor has his status as ROC president, Ma noted.

The "1992 consensus" that allows Taipei and Beijing to agree to disagree on the meaning of "one China" -- based on which cross-strait dialogue was resumed -- does not involve a sacrifice of the country's sovereignty, either, because the ROC Constitution was established under a "one China (Republic of China)" framework, he argued.
According to Ma, Taiwan's efforts to improve ties with China have won the support of the international community and have helped Taiwan shed its image as a "troublemaker."
On Taiwan's relations with the United States, Ma said his administration will continue to work to rebuild mutual trust between the two sides.

He added that the recovery of Taiwan-U.S. trust over the past six months has allowed the two sides to deal with each other in a more friendly manner than before, which is evident in the progress on U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Demolition work at Losheng sanatorium begins despite protest

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) began work Wednesday to dismantle and relocate the historic Losheng Sanatorium despite a protest by 200 activists demanding that the 1930-era building built to house lepers should be preserved.

Although the sanatorium has not been designated as a historic site, it will be reopened to the public in the form of a modern medical treatment park for leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, said Huang Kun-chang, chief executive officer of the DOH Hospital Administration Commission.

The park, which will accommodate some of the old sanatorium buildings, will serve as a significant educational site to show people of the lack of human rights afforded to lepers, who were in the past mostly segregated from the rest of society, Huang noted.

According to Losheng Sanatorium President Lee Nai-shu, 44 of the 55 old buildings that comprise the sanatorium will be repaired, one will be relocated, eight in poorer condition will be dismantled and restored in their original locations, and the six most dilapidated will be torn down for good.
Under the construction plan, 90 percent of the sanatorium complex will be preserved. Lee said.

The work will make way for the long-stalled construction of a depot for the Sinjhuang Line of the Mass Rapid Transport system, which will resolve serious traffic congestion in the Sinjhuang and Shulin areas of Taipei County.

The decision to tear down some of the buildings is not without controversy, however, and before workers began erecting fences surrounding the sanatorium in preparation for the demolition, 200 activists, as well as several elderly inmates who have lived in the shelter almost all their lives, staged a protest sit-in.

More than 200 police officers were mobilized to evict the protesters, which they did by bundling several dozen of them into vehicles and driving them to a remote mountainous area in nearby Linkuo, where they planned to dump them to prevent them from returning to the site.

In Linkuo, however, the activists -- including members of the Losheng Youth Alliance and Yu Chao-ching, a professor at the architecture department of Chung Yuan Christian University -- protested to the police for taking them against their will to a place where they could not easily find their way back to the city.
After negotiations, the police agreed to drive them to Danshuei, more than an hour's drive from Sinjhuang but situated on an MRT line.

The fight to preserve the sanatorium -- one of just three remaining historic leper facilities in the world -- can be traced back to 2001, when the county government decided to transform Losheng into a community hospital, bringing to an end its time as a place exclusively for the hospitalization and care of leprosy patients.

Since then, scholars of urban planning, student activists and dozens of Hansen's disease patients who have lived at Losheng nearly all their lives have been striving to make the government designate the sanatorium as a historical site.

DOC.HEADLINE: More cross-strait mutual trust needed: former AIT head

TEXT.P: Former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush said Wednesday that more mutual trust between Taiwan and China needs to be built to create a stable environment in which both sides can co-exist and prosper.

Speaking at a seminar in Taipei to discuss the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations since President Ma Ying-jeou took office, Bush, now director of the Brookings Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies (CNAPS), said Ma's assumption of the presidency offered the possibility of reducing cross-strait tension and hostility.

Bush said, however, that while Ma, who argued that Taiwans prosperity and security are best ensured by reassuring and engaging China, has launched a series of initiatives to improve cross-strait relations since he took the helm and achieved some results, it remains to be seen whether mutual trust between the two sides will be developed.

He noted that China still imposes diplomatic quarantine to obstruct Taiwans participation in international matters and would not give up resorting to military means if the island were to declare independence.
The process of economic cooperation is not enough to reduce Taiwan peoples fear,Bush said.

The two sides reached agreements to expand direct flights and to launch direct shipping and postal links during a round of talks last month. They plan to discuss financial cooperation in the next round of negotiations. Both sides are avoiding political issues for now.

Bush said he hopes Beijing wouldshow more flexibilitytoward Taiwans bid to participate in U.N. activities, such as its hopes of gaining observer status in the World Health Organization, and find a way to reduce the Taiwan peoples sense of insecurity.

He stressed that mutual trust is vital to reach the ultimate goal of stabilization across the Taiwan Strait, an environment in which he said the two sides can coexist, cooperate without mutual fear, as well as maximize opportunities for cooperation.

The road to creating the environment is not an easy one," Bush said, adding that if the two sides can successfully achieve the goal with joint efforts, it will not only serve the best interests for the two governments and their people, the United States willno doubt welcome itas well.

He said he was encouraged to see the current incremental negotiation processes taken by the two sides to deal with cross-strait relations, becauseit is risky to try to do it all at once between two adversaries who seek to back away from the situation of mutual fear and mistrust."
If the current process is to succeed, it will be the result of a gradual step- by-step process where the two sides can build mutual trust,he contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: President suggests China watch Taiwan film to learn about Taiwan

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Wednesday suggested people in China should watch a Taiwanese-produced box office hit to learn more about the island and its culture, despite a story line which mainland Chinese might find offensive.

Ma made the remarks in an interview with Radio Taiwan International after reports said that China hesitated in airing the locally produced "Cape No. 7", which depicts the love stories between two Taiwanese-Japanese couples.

According to the local United Daily News Monday, China has suspended a plan to show "Cape No.7" prior to Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 26 next year, citing the Beijing-based newspaper Legal Mirror.

The reports suggested that officials in Beijing were worried that the airing of the film might whip up nationalistic sentiments in China, as the film touches on Japan's colonization of Taiwan from 1895 to 1945.
One of the love stories is about a Taiwanese woman and a Japanese man's unrequited love during that period of the island's history.

Ma said viewing the film from a human nature perspective will help Chinese audiences rest their adverse sentiments on certain scenes and stories and focus on ordinary people's relationships that are "faithfully captured" in the film.
Japan's colonization of Taiwan lasted for half a century and it is impossible to deny that people can develop relationships in such a long time, he said.

He added that similar stories can certainly be found in China as its northeastern area was under control by Japan from 1932-1945, and can even be found between the two sides across the Taiwan Strait, which until recently had suffered from strained relations.

Taiwan and China split in 1949 after a civil war. China adopts a much more unforgiving view of Japan's World War II occupation of China, partly because of widespread wartime atrocities carried out by Japanese troops there, including the Nanjing Massacre and the use of Chinese people for chemical experiments.
Ma, nonetheless, highly recommended the film, saying it will be a good start for Chinese people to learn more about the society in Taiwan, which has been separated from theirs for 60 years.
The interview of Ma was also aired by Phoenix Television, a Hong Kong-based mandarin Chinese television broadcaster, on the same day.

As of the end of November, the film had earned NT$459.15 million (US$13.91 million) at the box office in Taiwan, becoming the second top grossing film in the island's cinematic history, behind the "Titanic".

DOC.HEADLINE: 200,000 workers to benefit from special loans: labor chief

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Wang Ju-hsuan agreed Wednesday to double the size of a special loan package for workers in economic straits and offer the loans at a reduced interest rate of about 2.95 percent, which may benefit some 200,000 workers.

Wang made the announcement during a committee meeting at the Legislative Yuan in response to a proposal by lawmakers that the CLA increase the size of the loan package from NT$10 billion to NT$20 billion (US$600 million) -- the biggest in history -- and lower the interest rate to a record 2.95 percent from the original 3.225 percent.
The lawmakers argued that the CLA should provide greater assistance to the working class, particularly at this time of economic crisis which has resulted in many people losing their jobs.

Taiwan's jobless rate climbed to 4.37 percent in October, bringing the number of unemployed workers to some 476,000, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Ho Tsai-feng said during a question-and-answer session. In December 2007, the country's unemployment rate stood at 3.83 percent, which represented an unemployed population of 414,000, she noted.

Under the terms of the plan, as many as 200,000 Taiwanese workers could each receive a loan of up to NT$100,000, as long as they have been in the labor insurance program for at least 15 years and have never defaulted on their premium payments.

In two weeks' time, the CLA will publish relevant information on how to apply for the loans. Successful applicants are expected to receive the funds before the Lunar New Year which falls on Jan. 26, 2009.
Since its inception six years ago, the CLA has been offering special loans for workers every year ahead of the Chinese new year festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan mulling free trade agreement with China

TEXT.P: The head of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Wednesday that it matters little what the proposed free trade agreement between Taiwan and China is called, once it is beneficial to Taiwan's economy.
Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the SEF, made the remarks at the legislature while answering questions from legislators of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

He said it is not really important whether the agreement is called a comprehensive economic partnership agreement (CEPA), a free trade agreement (FTA) , or a comprehensive economic cooperation agreement (CECA) -- preferred by President Ma Ying-jeou -- because the content will be practically the same.

However, Lai Hsing-yuan, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , which has the authority to supervise SEF operations, told the lawmakers that she has always insisted that Taiwan should not follow the Hong Kong model and sign a closer economic partnership agreement -- also known as a CEPA -- with China, because that would downgrade Taiwan to the level of a local government.

She said that she would also oppose any other agreement -- even named differently -- if it signifies a relationship similar to that between China and Hong Kong -- a special administrative region under China's "one country, two systems."

Chiang later told reporters that he would attach greater importance to the content rather than to the name of the proposed agreement, which would allow zero tariffs on up to 90 percent of Taiwan's exports to China.
Chiang acknowledged that the closer economic partnership between Hong Kong and China is different in structure from free trade agreements between nations.

He gave the assurance that if the SEF is authorized by the MAC to sign an economic cooperation agreement with its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, he will make sure that Taiwan is not downgraded in the agreement to a local government of China.
The SEF and the ARATS are quasi-official organizations representing each side of the Taiwan Strait in talks on issues related to cross-strait exchanges, in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Activists threaten lawsuit over Beitou cable car project

TEXT.P: With Taipei's Maokong Gondola cable car system shut down over safety concerns, environmentalists on Wednesday threatened to file a lawsuit against Taiwan's former Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) minister Hau Lung-bin, Taipei's current mayor, for not having done an environmental impact assessment on another project -- the Beitou cable car system.

The environmentalists asserted that the geological conditions at the site reserved for the 4.8-km Beitou cable car system in Taipei are unfavorable, saying that rock strength there is very low and that the site has landslide risks.

"If the Beitou cable car system project continues, a worse result than that of the Maokong Gondola system can be expected, " Lynn Lin, secretary-general of the Wild at Heart Legal Defense Association, Taiwan, told a press conference.

In addition, activists said that as the Beitou cable car system is designed to be located inside the Yangmingshan National Park, the Taipei city government should review the contractor's soil and water conservation plan before beginning construction.

Hau, when he was EPA minister, decided an environmental impact assessment report was not necessary because the project area was relatively small and the regulations did not require such environmental impact assessments be conducted on cable car systems.

Construction of the project has not officially begun, but contractors in 2006 cut down vegetation and dug holes on the site in preparation for the project, violating the Soil and Water Conservation Act, Lin said.

The project to build the Beitou cable car system, mapped out by the Taipei City Government, was sent to the Yangmingshan National Park Administration in early October for review, according to the city government's Public Works Department.
The project is awaiting approval from the park administration and Taiwan's Ministry of the Interior.
The environmentalists said that construction should not proceed before concerns over safety and environmental impact are addressed.

Urging the Taipei city government to make the cable car project submit to an environmental impact assessment and take citizens' safety into consideration, the environmentalists said they did not rule out the possibility of filing a lawsuit against Taipei Mayor Hau.
Meanwhile, it remains unclear when the 4-km Maokong Gondola cable car system will resume operation.

Located in the south of the capital, it began operations in July 2007 and was a popular tourist attraction. But the system has been closed since October 1 over concerns that its Tower No. 16 could collapse after torrential rains brought by Typhoon Jangmei in September eroded the base of the tower.

DOC.HEADLINE: Time not ripe for Kinmen to admit Chinese workers: official

TEXT.P: The time is not yet ripe for the outlying Kinmen County to lure investment or admit workers from China, Kao Chang, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, said in Kinmen Wednesday.

"For the time being, it is more suitable for Kinmen to develop its tourism," Kao said during a meeting with Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng to exchange opinions on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait ties.
Kao was invited to Kinmen by the Kinmen Defense Command to give a military strategy lecture to troops stationed on the island.

Kao's comments were made in response to a suggestion by Lee for Kinmen to admit Chinese workers and allow China investment in order to help bolster the local economy and allow the offshore island to serve as an experimental case for Taiwan proper in this regard.

Kao said it is not a good time for Kinmen to take that approach, considering that Kinmen has no manufacturing or labor intensive job opportunities. Kinmen cannot compete with Xiamen, a port city on the opposite side of the strait in China's Fujian Province, to offer Chinese workers such jobs, he added.

However, Kinmen is ideally positioned to boost its tourism, thanks to its historic role as a military bastion against Chinese communist invasion in the past and a recent decision by Beijing to allow more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan proper and several of its offshore islands, including Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu, he proposed.
Taiwan and China inked two landmark accords in June in Beijing, to allow Chinese tourists from 13 provinces and cities to visit Taiwan, and to establish non-stop charter flights on weekends.

The two sides expanded the scope of the two pacts during their talks in Taipei in November, allowing Chinese residents from more cities and provinces to make pleasure trips to Taiwan and expanding the weekend charter flights to a daily service that is slated to begin Dec. 15.

The direct air travel network between Taiwan proper and China will not exclude Kinmen from the cross-strait exchanges, but rather would help Kinmen to lure more "genuine" Chinese tourists, instead of just Chinese travelers who transit through the island to and from Taiwan, Kao said.
He suggested that Kinmen authorities use the opportunity to improve the quality of the island's tourism facilities and services to woo more Chinese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH hopes to discuss Chinese medicine issues in cross-strait talks

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to include the regulation of Chinese medicine and animal feed safety in the next round of cross-Taiwan Strait consultations on food safety, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Chin-chuan said Wednesday.
Yeh made the remarks while reporting to a legislative committee on a cross- strait agreement on food safety signed last month in Taipei.

In its inspection of food products from China, the DOH in recent years has found levels of bleachers, artificial sweeteners, preservatives, residual pesticides and animal drugs in excess of allowable standards in Taiwan, Yeh said.
"The government will communicate with China on these issues within the framework of the cross-strait food safety agreement," he added.
Around 90 percent of all Chinese medicines imported by Taiwan are from China, 80 percent of which are usually consumed by the public, he said.
The DOH will select some of these medicines for priority consultations, he added.
He also said that animal feed could also end up in the systems of people via the food chain and could pose a public heath hazard if it is tainted.
As for the issue of adulterated milk imported from China recently, 19 Taiwan importers have asked for the DOH's assistance to seek compensation from China, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President says China raised issue of peace accord a year ago

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that China's President Hu Jintao raised the issue of signing a peace accord with Taiwan about one year ago, which Ma said was an indication that China wants peace as much as Taiwan.
Hu's aim was to end cross-Taiwan Strait hostilities, not to ensnare Taiwan, the president said.
Ma made the statement at a tea party hosted by the Taiwan Foreign Correspondents' Club at Sherwood Hotel in Taipei.
"Both sides of the Taiwan Strait want a peace accord, " said Ma. "However, it is not a pressing issue."
Ma noted that since he took office in May, the ambience of the cross-strait relationship has improved greatly.

"Hostilities have decreased to the lowest point in cross-strait history," said Ma. "We will deal with the easy issues first, and then we will move on to the more difficult ones. This is why we are talking about economics first and then will go on to political issues."
Ma said that the issue of Chinese missiles aimed at Taiwan remains a major cause for concern.

The prerequisite for a cross-strait peace accord is that the two sides show goodwill toward each other, " the president said. "But right now, the people of Taiwan are still very much afraid because of the more than 1,000 (Chinese) missiles aimed at Taiwan."
Ma said his government will insist that the missiles be removed before signing any peace pact with China.
More than a year ago, Hu raised the issue of a peace accord between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, " said Ma. "He did so not to set a trap for us, but to end cross-strait hostilities."
However, Ma stressed that mutual trust must first be established, especially between the military of both sides.
"This is so that the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will feel safe," Ma said.
He added that the content of the proposed peace pact has not been decided, but the government of Taiwan will ensure that it benefits the Taiwan people.
"Both sides need to devote more time and energy to cross-strait negotiations before such an accord can be realized," he added.

When asked by reporters if he would like to meet Hu or China Premier Wen Jiabao, Ma replied,I do not have any such plans at the moment, but I do not object to the idea, I do not rule out the possibility."
Noting that he has devoted great effort to improving cross-strait ties, Ma reiterated that his cross-strait policy is "no re-unification, no independence and no use of force."
He said he will maintain these policies, as they have the support of the people.

"As for the cross-strait battle to gain allies, both sides have called a truce, " said Ma, adding that Beijing showed goodwill by allowing former Vice President Lien Chan to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Peru recently.
"Beijing is being very flexible," he said.
While this is a sign that the cross-strait atmosphere is improving, Ma said, his government is not naive enough to interpret it as a "green light."
"We will continue to seek mutual interest and consensus to further develop cross-strait ties," the president vowed..
As for the Taiwan's efforts to participate in the World Health Assembly next year, Ma said that Beijing has not yet raised that issue.
"But we will keep investing our efforts in that direction, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan people remain wary of engaging China: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Wednesday Taiwan people remain wary of engaging China mainly because Taiwan's eased policy toward China has not yet yielded obvious interests and Beijing has not responded favorably to Taiwan's appeals for an end to military threat and diplomatic isolation.
Siew made the remarks in a speech delivered at a lunch meeting in Taipei organized by the Brookings Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies (CNAPS), a noted U.S. think tank.

Although tensions in relations across the Taiwan Strait have thawed since the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration in May, Siew said a spate of large-scale street protests seen during top Chinese negotiator Chen Yunlin's historic visit to Taiwan early last month indicate that more efforts must be done to alleviate local people's wariness toward cross-strait engagements.

Siew attributed Taiwan people's wariness to two major reasons -- the launch of direct cross-strait charter flights and Taiwan's opening up to Chinese tourists has yet to bring about substantial interests and local people find that Beijing has not shown explicit goodwill response to calls for dismantling more than 1,000 ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan and for stopping its boycott of Taiwan's presence in world arenas.

At the moment, Siew said, China still deploys 1,400 missiles against Taiwan and has not shown any intention to compromise on Taiwan's participation in the annual World Health Assembly (WHA) meetings and East Asian economic integration.
"Only when these critical issues are resolved can people of Taiwan reach a higher degree of consensus on the development of cross-strait relations, " Siew said.

Meanwhile, Siew said Taiwan needs the support of major countries around the world, including the United States, in its pursuit of representation in the WHA and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
In light of Taiwan's contribution to the world economy, Siew said he sees no reasons for ASEAN to exclude Taiwan from regional economic integration.

On relations with the United States, Siew said he looks forward to seeing progress in major bilateral cooperation projects, including negotiations for signing a Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement (FTA) , following the inauguration of President-elect Barack Obama next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: President rules out possibility of visit by Dalai Lama at this time

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying Jeou said Wednesday that all religious leaders in the world are welcome to visit Taiwan, but that the timing for a visit by the Dalai Lama is not right.

In response to questions by foreign press members at a tea party press hosted by the Taiwan Foreign Correspondence Club in Taipei, Ma noted that the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader has visited Taiwan twice in the past.

We generally welcome all religious leaders in the world to come to Taiwan, but I think, at the moment, the timing isn't appropriate for this," he said. Ma was responding to question on whether he and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs would approve a visit to the country by Dalai Lama, who has said that he is considering the idea.
The Dalai Lama is seeking autonomy for Tibet, rather than independence, from China.

Turning to the issue of a possible presidential pardon for former President Chen Shui-bian, Ma said in response to a reporter's question that "a presidential pardon is possible in our country, but we have to wait for an indictment before we could consider pardoning Chen. Right now, he is only a suspect."
Chen has been detained and is being investigated on suspicion of embezzlement, bribe-taking and money laundering during his two terms in office from 2000 to 2008.
Meanwhile, Ma said that in the face of the global economic crisis, his government is ready to rescue any Taiwan industry that falls into trouble.
"The DRAM industry has its own survival plans, but we are on standby, ready to help if it asks for our help," he said.

In addition, I will not give up my policy of targeting 6 percent economic growth, per capita income of US$30,000 and an unemployment rate of below 3 percent," the president said when asked if the global credit crisis will dampen Taiwan's economic outlook.
Ma pointed out that his government is borrowing money and using special budgets to fund expanded public projects.
"We have to implement the expansion of public projects to stimulate the economy, " Ma said. "When the economy gets better, the government could pay off its debts."

When asked if a Cabinet reshuffle is imminent following the recent resignation and replacement of the Financial Supervisory Commission chairman, Ma replied, " There will be no more changes until the end of this year. But my evaluations of the Cabinet are ongoing. I hope that the Cabinet will be able to satisfy the needs of the people."
The reporters also questioned Ma on Taiwan's defense policy, asking if his government would still like to purchase submarines and F-16 warplanes.

"I do not think the Obama administration will change its position on selling defensive weapons to Taiwan, " replied Ma. "We continue to request permission to purchase F-16C/D fighter planes for defense."
Ma explained that his government's purchase of arms does not mean it is seeking hostilities in the Taiwan Strait.
However, "we still need to deter China. I do not want to see the use of force, but we must take the necessary precautions against the other side of the Taiwan Strait."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan business delegation seeking partners, trade deals in India
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/04/08 00:18:40 (Bu Paul Kuo and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation that is currently in India to seek business partners and trade deals there has attracted great attention from Indian industries, according to the leader of the group Lee Tung-sen, Wednesday.

Lee, a staff member at Taiwan External Trade Development Council, told the CNA that the delegation consists of representatives of 18 Taiwan companies that for two days have been displaying a variety of products at booths set up at the PHD Chamber of Commerce and Industry in New Delhi.
The exhibits include machinery, hardware, energy-saving lighting devices, lathes, packers, textiles, rubber, and chemical equipment, Lee said.
Representatives of more than 150 Indian enterprises have visited the delegation's booths, with many showing interest in the Taiwan companies, he said.
For example, he said, one Indian company proposed cooperating with Taiwan's Asia Automatic Pum Co. to make pump products in India.
Another Indian company expressed interest in supplying Taiwan Dyeing and Fabric Co. with raw materials, Lee said.
He said the delegation will move on to Mumbai, India's financial center, Thursday, and will head to the Sri Lankan capital of Colombo Dec. 7.
Wong Wen-chi, Taiwan's representative to India, said cooperation between the business sectors of both countries will create a win-win situation for future development.

Lee Chuan-lian, the economy section chief at Taiwan's representative office in India, noted that India is Taiwan's largest trading partner in South Asia. The bilateral trade volume between the two countries was US$4.88 billion for 2007, which represented growth of 80 percent from the 2006 figure.
The bilateral trade volume from January to June this year exceeded US$3 billion, representing annualized growth rate of 53 percent, Lee said.

India's economy was forecast to remain stable in spite of the global economic downturn, with its economic growth rate for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2009 expected to maintain around 7.5 percent, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bedding industry facing difficulties: IDB

TEXT.P: Following on the heels of Taiwan's footwear industry, the bedding industry is now on the verge of failing, the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Wednesday.
The bedding industry's problems are reportedly largely due low-price competition from manufacturers in China and Vietnam.
Meanwhile, 18 manufacturers, including towel, knitted sock and stocking makers, have been put on a watch list because of the visible problems they are encountering.

IDB officials said that if an industry shows abnormal import and export figures for the past two years, the quoted price of domestic products plunge, or there is a dramatic increase in similar imports, the IDB will assess the impact on the industry and place it on a watch list or categorize it as being on the verge of failing.
The IDB or the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration will then take steps to provide counselling and assistance, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan County named one of world's 21 intelligent cities
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan County, Taiwan, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/04/08 00:34:19 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The head of Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan shared an international honor with information industry leaders at a reception Wednesday after the New York-based Intelligent Community Forum (ICF) named the county one of 21 smart communities in the world.

Taoyuan County Magistrate Li-lun Chu was joined by executives of Chunghwa Telecom Co., Quanta Computer Inc., Hewlett Packard Co. and Microsoft Taiwan Corp. at the celebration of the county's emergence from among 400 candidate cities around the world to win the rare honor.

Chu signed a letter of intent for future cooperation with the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Chunghwa Telecom and Global Mobile Corp. on the provision of wireless broadband service in Taoyuan County.
Taoyuan County, with a population of 1,950,000, was the only Asian community on the list of the Smart21 Communities of 2009 announced by the ICF on Oct. 29.

The ICF is a think tank that studies the economic and social development of the 21st century community. It will name the Top Seven Intelligent Communities of 2009, selected from among the Smart21, on Jan. 21 next year during the Pacific Telecommunications Council annual conference in Honolulu, Hawaii.

The Smart21 of 2009 includes communities from 12 nations on four continents with populations ranging from 17,000 to 2.5 million. Ten of the 2009 Smart21 are North American communities, seven are in Europe, two in the Asia-Pacific, one in South America, and one in Africa.
The list includes Albany in New York; Edmonton, Canada; Gold Coast City, Australia; Manchester, England; and California, the United States;
"Each of these communities has demonstrated a commitment to improving their communities through innovative broadband applications," said ICF Co-founder Louis Zacharilla in a news release.

"The ingenuity of these communities is exemplified in their investments in the future of the young, the growth and progress of job-creating businesses, and economic security," he said. An overarching theme of the 2009 honorees has been the dedication to putting people first and building a "talent inventory" that will thrive with technology and innovation, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Losheng Sanatorium controversy in last throes

TEXT.P: The long-lasting dispute over plans to dismantle the 1930-era Losheng Sanatorium -- Taiwan's first hospital for lepers -- came to an end Wednesday when police cleared elderly inmates from a shabby building that they had called home for most of their lives and dispersed demonstrators who were protesting the dismantling of the buildings.
Despite constant protests by human rights activists and preservationists, work to build a depot for the Sinjhuang Line of the Mass Rapid Transport system in Taipei, northern Taiwan, was restarted.

According to the Taipei metro department, the inauguration date of the Sinjhuang line had to be postponed from Dec. 31, 2009 to Aug. 15, 2112 because of the disputes over the dismantling of the sanatorium and the ensuing disruptions to the work on the project.

The controversy over the project, which is being constructed to alleviate the serious traffic congestion in the Sinjhuang and Shulin areas of the densely populated Taipei County, has highlighted a period in history when Hansen's disease patients were deprived of their human rights.

Hansen's disease, also known as leprosy, is a chronic bacterial disease that primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves and upper airway. Because the disease was feared as highly contagious, Hansen's patients were isolated and often shunned by the societies in which they lived.
The disease is now known to be treatable and not highly transmissible.

Losheng Sanatorium was constructed in 1929 by the Japanese colonial government on a vast tract of land covering Hueilong and Shulin townships in Taipei County and Gueishan in Taoyuan County to quarantine patients with the disease.

After the World War II, the Kuomintang (KMT) regime, inheriting the isolation policy, expanded the housing facilities to more than 60 units. At its peak, the sanatorium sheltered nearly 1,000 patients.

In 1961, the forced quarantine policy was revoked and the patients were allowed to leave the sanatorium. However, many of them, facing the prospect of chronic isolation and discrimination, had little choice but to stay, and they grew used to the setting.
As urban development accelerated, the metro department selected the 30-hectare sanatorium complex as the site of a train depot and began 12 years ago to develop a construction plan.

In 2003, part of the sanatorium was demolished, forcing some of the more than 200 long-term patients -- aged 75 years on average -- to move away. One year later, the Youth Federation for Losheng was formed by activists fighting for the rights of the patients.

After years of controversy over the issue, the Legislative Yuan on July 18 this year passed a set of regulations to protect the rights of Hansen's disease patients. Under the bill, the patients were offered compensation for the discrimination they suffered due to the segregation policy.

According to the Department of Health (DOH), the regulations also require the government to issue a public apology to the patients, hold a public memorial ceremony for those who have passed away, and educate the society about the disease.
Under the regulations, the government will pay a total of NT$720 million (US$ million) to nearly 1,000 Losheng Sanatorium patients as compensation.

The bill stipulates that 90 percent of the sanatorium compound will be preserved and part of it will be converted into a park dedicated to educating the society about Hansen's disease. Forty of the 55 buildings on the sanatorium complex will be preserved and will continue to serve as home to many of its patients.
