DOC.HEADLINE: DOH hopes to discuss Chinese medicine issues in cross-strait talks

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to include the regulation of Chinese medicine and animal feed safety in the next round of cross-Taiwan Strait consultations on food safety, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Chin-chuan said Wednesday.
Yeh made the remarks while reporting to a legislative committee on a cross- strait agreement on food safety signed last month in Taipei.

In its inspection of food products from China, the DOH in recent years has found levels of bleachers, artificial sweeteners, preservatives, residual pesticides and animal drugs in excess of allowable standards in Taiwan, Yeh said.
"The government will communicate with China on these issues within the framework of the cross-strait food safety agreement," he added.
Around 90 percent of all Chinese medicines imported by Taiwan are from China, 80 percent of which are usually consumed by the public, he said.
The DOH will select some of these medicines for priority consultations, he added.
He also said that animal feed could also end up in the systems of people via the food chain and could pose a public heath hazard if it is tainted.
As for the issue of adulterated milk imported from China recently, 19 Taiwan importers have asked for the DOH's assistance to seek compensation from China, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President says China raised issue of peace accord a year ago

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that China's President Hu Jintao raised the issue of signing a peace accord with Taiwan about one year ago, which Ma said was an indication that China wants peace as much as Taiwan.
Hu's aim was to end cross-Taiwan Strait hostilities, not to ensnare Taiwan, the president said.
Ma made the statement at a tea party hosted by the Taiwan Foreign Correspondents' Club at Sherwood Hotel in Taipei.
"Both sides of the Taiwan Strait want a peace accord, " said Ma. "However, it is not a pressing issue."
Ma noted that since he took office in May, the ambience of the cross-strait relationship has improved greatly.

"Hostilities have decreased to the lowest point in cross-strait history," said Ma. "We will deal with the easy issues first, and then we will move on to the more difficult ones. This is why we are talking about economics first and then will go on to political issues."
Ma said that the issue of Chinese missiles aimed at Taiwan remains a major cause for concern.

The prerequisite for a cross-strait peace accord is that the two sides show goodwill toward each other, " the president said. "But right now, the people of Taiwan are still very much afraid because of the more than 1,000 (Chinese) missiles aimed at Taiwan."
Ma said his government will insist that the missiles be removed before signing any peace pact with China.
More than a year ago, Hu raised the issue of a peace accord between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, " said Ma. "He did so not to set a trap for us, but to end cross-strait hostilities."
However, Ma stressed that mutual trust must first be established, especially between the military of both sides.
"This is so that the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will feel safe," Ma said.
He added that the content of the proposed peace pact has not been decided, but the government of Taiwan will ensure that it benefits the Taiwan people.
"Both sides need to devote more time and energy to cross-strait negotiations before such an accord can be realized," he added.

When asked by reporters if he would like to meet Hu or China Premier Wen Jiabao, Ma replied,I do not have any such plans at the moment, but I do not object to the idea, I do not rule out the possibility."
Noting that he has devoted great effort to improving cross-strait ties, Ma reiterated that his cross-strait policy is "no re-unification, no independence and no use of force."
He said he will maintain these policies, as they have the support of the people.

"As for the cross-strait battle to gain allies, both sides have called a truce, " said Ma, adding that Beijing showed goodwill by allowing former Vice President Lien Chan to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Peru recently.
"Beijing is being very flexible," he said.
While this is a sign that the cross-strait atmosphere is improving, Ma said, his government is not naive enough to interpret it as a "green light."
"We will continue to seek mutual interest and consensus to further develop cross-strait ties," the president vowed..
As for the Taiwan's efforts to participate in the World Health Assembly next year, Ma said that Beijing has not yet raised that issue.
"But we will keep investing our efforts in that direction, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan people remain wary of engaging China: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Wednesday Taiwan people remain wary of engaging China mainly because Taiwan's eased policy toward China has not yet yielded obvious interests and Beijing has not responded favorably to Taiwan's appeals for an end to military threat and diplomatic isolation.
Siew made the remarks in a speech delivered at a lunch meeting in Taipei organized by the Brookings Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies (CNAPS), a noted U.S. think tank.

Although tensions in relations across the Taiwan Strait have thawed since the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration in May, Siew said a spate of large-scale street protests seen during top Chinese negotiator Chen Yunlin's historic visit to Taiwan early last month indicate that more efforts must be done to alleviate local people's wariness toward cross-strait engagements.

Siew attributed Taiwan people's wariness to two major reasons -- the launch of direct cross-strait charter flights and Taiwan's opening up to Chinese tourists has yet to bring about substantial interests and local people find that Beijing has not shown explicit goodwill response to calls for dismantling more than 1,000 ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan and for stopping its boycott of Taiwan's presence in world arenas.

At the moment, Siew said, China still deploys 1,400 missiles against Taiwan and has not shown any intention to compromise on Taiwan's participation in the annual World Health Assembly (WHA) meetings and East Asian economic integration.
"Only when these critical issues are resolved can people of Taiwan reach a higher degree of consensus on the development of cross-strait relations, " Siew said.

Meanwhile, Siew said Taiwan needs the support of major countries around the world, including the United States, in its pursuit of representation in the WHA and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
In light of Taiwan's contribution to the world economy, Siew said he sees no reasons for ASEAN to exclude Taiwan from regional economic integration.

On relations with the United States, Siew said he looks forward to seeing progress in major bilateral cooperation projects, including negotiations for signing a Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement (FTA) , following the inauguration of President-elect Barack Obama next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: President rules out possibility of visit by Dalai Lama at this time

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying Jeou said Wednesday that all religious leaders in the world are welcome to visit Taiwan, but that the timing for a visit by the Dalai Lama is not right.

In response to questions by foreign press members at a tea party press hosted by the Taiwan Foreign Correspondence Club in Taipei, Ma noted that the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader has visited Taiwan twice in the past.

We generally welcome all religious leaders in the world to come to Taiwan, but I think, at the moment, the timing isn't appropriate for this," he said. Ma was responding to question on whether he and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs would approve a visit to the country by Dalai Lama, who has said that he is considering the idea.
The Dalai Lama is seeking autonomy for Tibet, rather than independence, from China.

Turning to the issue of a possible presidential pardon for former President Chen Shui-bian, Ma said in response to a reporter's question that "a presidential pardon is possible in our country, but we have to wait for an indictment before we could consider pardoning Chen. Right now, he is only a suspect."
Chen has been detained and is being investigated on suspicion of embezzlement, bribe-taking and money laundering during his two terms in office from 2000 to 2008.
Meanwhile, Ma said that in the face of the global economic crisis, his government is ready to rescue any Taiwan industry that falls into trouble.
"The DRAM industry has its own survival plans, but we are on standby, ready to help if it asks for our help," he said.

In addition, I will not give up my policy of targeting 6 percent economic growth, per capita income of US$30,000 and an unemployment rate of below 3 percent," the president said when asked if the global credit crisis will dampen Taiwan's economic outlook.
Ma pointed out that his government is borrowing money and using special budgets to fund expanded public projects.
"We have to implement the expansion of public projects to stimulate the economy, " Ma said. "When the economy gets better, the government could pay off its debts."

When asked if a Cabinet reshuffle is imminent following the recent resignation and replacement of the Financial Supervisory Commission chairman, Ma replied, " There will be no more changes until the end of this year. But my evaluations of the Cabinet are ongoing. I hope that the Cabinet will be able to satisfy the needs of the people."
The reporters also questioned Ma on Taiwan's defense policy, asking if his government would still like to purchase submarines and F-16 warplanes.

"I do not think the Obama administration will change its position on selling defensive weapons to Taiwan, " replied Ma. "We continue to request permission to purchase F-16C/D fighter planes for defense."
Ma explained that his government's purchase of arms does not mean it is seeking hostilities in the Taiwan Strait.
However, "we still need to deter China. I do not want to see the use of force, but we must take the necessary precautions against the other side of the Taiwan Strait."

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 4, or the seventh day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1154: Nicholas Breakspeare becomes the first Englishman to become the pope.
1795: Thomas Carlyle, Scottish historian and essayist, is born. His works include "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution."
1892: Gen. Francisco Franco, Spanish dictator from 1939 until his death in 1975, is born.
1893: Britain and France reach an agreement on Siam (Thailand).
1912: Turkey reaches an armistice with all the Balkan allies except Greece.
1947: Tennessee Williams' play "A Streetcar Named Desire" premiers on Broadway, with Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy in the leading roles.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China leaves Loyang for Xian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular languages instead of Latin in performing the sacraments.
1963: The Kuomintang Central Standing Committee approves the resignation of ROC Premier Chen Cheng, who is concurrently serving as the vice president, and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7," which would orbit the earth for a record 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guard arrests communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han and Wan Li.
1973: Jordanian Minister of Tourism and Antiquities Ghaleb Z. Barakat arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: The Third Conference of East Asia Economists opens in Taipei with 30 Japanese and 50 Chinese delegates attending.
1975: Defense Minister Kao Kuei-yuan announces that the fighting capability of the ROC armed forces has nearly quintupled over the last quarter of a century.
1975: Willem Pretorius, the new South African consul-general to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes the Central African Kingdom, and President Jean Bedel Bokassa is crowned king.
1976: A seminar on agricultural engineering and development is held at National Taiwan University to mark the 60th anniversary of the establishment of the Chinese Agriculture Society.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing everyone onboard.
1989: Members of East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign, and Head of State Egon Krenz is forced to step down only six weeks after replacing a beleaguered Erich Hoenecker.
1994: U.S. Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first U.S. secretary to carry out the new U.S. policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.
1998: A trial is held in Shanghai for a Chinese entrepreneur accused of providing e-mail addresses to an online democracy magazine.
1999: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian leaves for a five-day European visit.
2000: The fourth Global Semiconductor Industry Seminar opens in the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, with more than 200 of the leading lights of the global semiconductor sector participating.
2000: David Yen, one of Taiwan's most prominent anti-smoking activists, is granted a Thai royal decoration in Taipei for his contributions toward successfully controlling tobacco consumption in Thailand.
2001: Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen Ta-jen goes to Xiamen City opposite to the Taiwan-held frontline island aboard a passenger vessel for a four-day visit, the first of its kind for a Republic of China official in more than 50 years.
2001: The remains of 14 crew members of a surveillance aircraft affiliated with the former Republic of China Air Force's 34th Squadron, nicknamed the Black Bats Squadron, that was shot down by mainland Chinese fighters in Jiangxi province nearly four decades ago are airlifted back to Taiwan.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The interest of the wise ruler lies in carrying out what makes for order among the people and avoiding what makes for confusion. When the administration of the ruler answers the desires of the people, there will be order, otherwise there will be confusion."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Think tank adjusts Taiwan's economic growth downward to 1.68%

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth will be 1.68
percent for this year and 1.24 percent for next year, a think tank forecast Thursday.
The Chung-Hwa Institution for Economic Research (CIER) made the forecast at a seminar on the 2009 global economic outlook, which was hosted by CIER President Daigee Shaw.

Wang Lee-rong, director of CIER's Center for Economic Forecasting, said that with the global economic downturn, the center has decided to adjust its forecast for domestic economic growth sharply downwards.
The jobless rate for next year has been forecast at 4.35 percent, Wang said.
The CIER predicted in October that economic growth could reach 3.82 percent this year, and 3.34 percent next year.

Wang said that if the world financial crisis continues to worsen, and economic growth for the United States, Japan and China also deteriorate, then "Taiwan's economic growth could be negative 0.92 percent next year."

Among all the domestic think tanks, the CIER has made the most pessimistic economic forecast, while the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research has been the most optimistic, predicting an economic growth this year of 4.08 precent, and 4.11 percent for next year.

The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics also adjusted its forecast for 2008 and 2009 economic growth sharply downward to 1.87 percent and 2.12 percent, respectively.

CIER officials said the world financial crisis has had the biggest impact on the banking and insurance sectors, but that the plastics and chemical, steel, cement and shipping sectors have also been affected.
With the economic slowdown in Europe and the United States, the market for large-size panels, computer memory and personal computers will shrink, the officials said.
In addition, due to rising unemployment and decreased consumption, the wholesale and retail, eatery and real estate sectors will also be affected, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Investigation Bureau head gets 10-year prison sentence

TEXT.P: Former Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) Director-General Yeh Sheng-mao was sentenced Thursday to 10 years in prison over his handling of intelligence concerning a case of suspected money laundering involving former President Chen Shui-bian and a separate case of alleged influence peddling implicating a legislator.
A panel of judges at the Taipei District Court ruled that Yeh should also be deprived of his civil rights for five years.
The court found Yeh guilty of corruption, of concealing a government file and of leaking confidential information, for which he was given a prison sentence of eight and a half years.
In the second case, Yeh was also convicted of leaking confidential information, for which he was sentenced to two and a half years in prison.
The two sentences will combined into a jail term of 10 years, the verdict stated. The ruling can be appealed.
Also Thursday, the court rejected a bail petition by Yeh -- who has been detained since Oct. 6 -- in view of the severity of the offenses with which he was charged.

At the center of the money-laundering case was a report delivered to the MJIB in January through the international anti-money laundering organization Egmont Group, in which the Cayman Islands' financial intelligence unit raised the suspicion that the former first family was laundering money through an account created under the name of Chen's daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching at the Merrill Lynch Bank in Geneva, Switzerland.

Based on the report, the bureau's Anti-Money Laundering Center on Jan. 29 compiled a file intended for delivery to the Supreme Prosecutors Office. Yeh later requested that the file be handed over to him, saying that he would pass it to State Public Prosecutor General Chen Tsung-ming in person.
However, instead of giving the file to Chen Tsung-ming, Yeh leaked its contents to Chen Shui-bian during a visit to the former president's official residence between Jan. 31 and Feb. 1.
The district court said in its verdict that Yeh's actions had undermined the independence of Taiwan's justice institutions and caused "immeasurable damage" to the country's image.
However, Yeh has not been repentant, had changed his statement many times during the trial and refused to admit to his offenses, the verdict stated.

In the other case, Yeh was found to have leaked a plan by prosecutors and investigators to raid the offices of Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Ker Chien-ming in April in an investigation into Ker's alleged involvement in influence peddling in an illegal mining operation in the eastern county of Hualien.

TAIEX Index futures for January lost 56 points to finish at 4,106, with 999 contracts traded, while March futures declined 51 points to end at 4,077, with 31 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,189 for December, 4,162 for January, 4,128 for March, 4,095 for June and 3,912 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 52.3 points to finish at 4,254.96, on turnover of NT$53.67 billion (US$1.59 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
December TE futures gained 0.85 points to close at 151.75, with 7,171 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 1.05 points to finish at 150.05, with 88 contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei forms sister city ties with capital of Burkina Faso

TEXT.P: Taipei City has established sister city links with Ouagadougou, the capital of Burkina Faso, and will donate ambulances to help improve medical conditions there, Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Thursday.

Hau said at the signing ceremony that the two cities first established ties in 2002 during a visit to Taipei by the mayor of Ouagadougou, and that the new alliance will further enhance mutual trust and facilitate partnerships between the two diplomatic allies.

The two cities are expected to launch various initiatives and collaborate in areas such as public affairs management, information technology, transportation, the environment and health, according to Hau.

As a first step, Hau pledged that his city will donate four ambulances to Ouagadougou and will assist with the construction of a youth center in the African city, known for its craftsmanship, to provide a space for its culture to thrive.
In response, Ouagadougou Mayor Simon Compaore said that the donation of ambulances will help alleviate the lack of adequate medical facilities in the Burkina Faso capital.
Compaore mentioned that Taiwan helped to build the biggest hospital in Burkina Faso and has sent medical missions to the country, which he said has greatly benefited his people.

He said that the people of Burkina Faso know about Taiwan and are familiar with the cooperation schemes Taiwan launched in the country. The signing of the sisterhood pact between Taipei and Ouagadougou will take the bilateral relations to the next level, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 major infrastructure projects to be carried out 'seriously'

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan passed a resolution Thursday, ruling that the 10 major infrastructure projects that it has selected for immediate implementation will be carried out "seriously" and under direct supervision by the nation's four ministers without portfolio.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said after hearing a briefing on the plan that the 10 selected infrastructure projects, including a mass rapid transit system connecting the capital city of Taipei and the nearby Taoyuan International Airport in Taoyuan County, should be carried out as scheduled and of the quality required.
"It is also anticipated that the development of these infrastructure projects will help rev up the slumping domestic economy and boost employment," Liu said.

The MRT system connecting the Taipei Railway Station and the Taoyuan airport is envisioned to reduce travel time between the two places to some 35 minutes, from the current hour or so. It can also provide convenient transit services to some 200,000 travelers to and from the airport and commuters who commute to work at the airport per day, according to the plan.

Another project -- an expansion of the Kaohsiung Harbor, the largest seaport in Taiwan -- is expected to create some 27,000 jobs and generate businesses worth NT$39.4 billion (US$1.2 billion) when it is completed. The project will be a joint venture between the government and the private sector, according to Chu Yun-peng, one of the four ministers without portfolio to be in charge of the projects.
The other three ministers without portfolio will be Tsai Hsung-hsiung, Chang Jin-fu and Ovid J.L. Tzeng.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 52.3 points to close at 4,254.96.

Finishing lower for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened at the day's high of 4,347.66 and reached a low of 4,209.91 during trading. A total of 3.74 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$53.67 billion (US$1.59 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 5.77 percent, followed by textile stocks at 4.89 percent, banking and financial shares at 3.53 percent, construction issues at 3.1 percent, paper and pulp issues at 2.12 percent, cement stocks at 1.8 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.73 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.21 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,002 to 336, with 300 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$6.42 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Universities to allow study extensions for parenting purposes

TEXT.P: Local undergraduate and graduate students would be allowed to apply for extension of their expected period of study for reasons related to parenting, according to a draft amendment to the University Act adopted by the Cabinet Thursday.
The reasons would include pregnancy, childbirth and the care of children under three years old, stated the draft, which is pending final approval by the Legislative Yuan.

Ho Cho-fei, head of the Department of Higher Education under the Ministry of Education (MOE) , explained that the bill is intended to protect the rights of students, who very often are forced to give up their studies because of the demands of parenting.

Although the MOE in 2005 directed domestic universities to allow maternity leave for pregnant students and to deduct the period of absence from their expected duration of study, some universities have not done so.

Under these circumstances, pregnant students would have to ask for sick leave or private affairs leave instead, in which case they could face a dismissal if they are absent from more than one third of their classes in a semester.

If the students choose to withdraw temporarily from university, the maximum duration of such withdrawal, as stipulated in the University Act, is four years. In reality, however, most universities only allow a withdrawal of two years at the maximum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to join U.S. Visa Waiver Program if it meets requirements:AIT

TEXT.P: The director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), Stephen M. Young, said Thursday that the incoming Obama administration will give careful consideration to including Taiwan in the U.S. Visa Waiver Program if it meets the requirements.

During a speech at a luncheon organized by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, Young said that he would not rule out the possibility that Taiwanese citizens can get visa-free treatment when they travel to the United States.

However, Young noted that there are a number of issues that need to be resolved before Taiwan can be considered for the Visa Waiver Program, which has already been granted in November to citizens of seven countries, including South Korea.
Under the Visa Waiver Program, citizens of member countries may travel to the U.S. visa free for up to 90 days for business or pleasure.

Young said that the U.S remains a favored destination for study, business, and leisure for Taiwanese people, but too often the U.S. has found instances where people who were not Taiwanese citizens have been able to obtain genuine Taiwanese passports.
"We applaud Taiwan's efforts to introduce a new passport", said Young, referring to the "ePassports" which Taiwan plans to unveil at the end of this month.
The electronic passports are embedded with a chip that contains the biographical data and the facial image of the passport bearer. They are difficult to forge.

Young added that the U.S. hopes that the new passports and other measures including the strengthening of passport application procedures will ensure that passports are not inadvertently issued to people who are not Taiwanese citizens.

Young reiterated that the U.S. recognizes that Taiwanese travelers to the U.S. have a strong reputation of abiding by the country's immigration laws and also most importantly for spending generously while in America, which is why he thinks that the Obama administration will look favorably upon Taiwan as an applicant to the visa waiver program.

"People-to-people exchange is a critical component of our relationship", said Young, adding that many of the Taiwanese government leaders he works with, including President Ma Ying-jeou, obtained their degrees in the U.S.

According to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, there are now 36,000 students from Taiwan in the U.S., making Taiwan second only to South Korea worldwide in the terms of the portion of its overall population studying in the U.S.
Young said that the he is glad to see that the number of Taiwanese students in the U.S. remains strong.
On the other hand, he said there has been a drop in applications by Taiwanese citizens for visitor visas to the United States, a trend he blames on the current weak economic climate.
Young assumed duties as director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan on March 18, 2006.

The AIT serves as the representative office of the United States in Taiwan. Washington's establishment of diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1979 required termination of its diplomatic relations with the Republic of China. However, the AIT serves to assist and protect U.S. interests in Taiwan in a non-official manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's first foreigner assistance center to be opened in Hsinchu

TEXT.P: The first Cabinet-sponsored foreigner assistance center is expected to open soon in the northern city of Hsinchu to provide services to foreigners visiting or staying in Taiwan.

The Hsinchu Foreigner Assistance Center, to be located at No. 107 Zhong Yang Road in Hsinchu City, will be a consultancy office dedicated to helping foreigners solve problems they encounter in Taiwan, Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer said Thursday.

The center has already begun offering assistance to foreigners since a soft opening several days ago, Lin said, adding that consultants in the center include professional consultants and young men serving alternative military service who speak fluent English or Japanese.

After learning that similar foreigner assistance centers have been established in major Asian countries, such as Japan, Singapore and South Korea, Lin said, the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission recently decided to establish one in Taiwan. Hsinchu City was chosen to host the first center of this kind in the country.

Hsinchu is home to Taiwan's "Silicon Valley, " -- the Hsinchu Science Park -- which is the country's first and largest science-based industrial park. As a result, the city attracts a lot of foreign visitors.
In the future, said Lin, students of Hsinchu's prestigious National Tsinghua University will be selected to work as volunteers at the center.

Consultancy services the Hsinchu Foreigner Assistance Center will be offering include help in getting settled in Taiwan, planning travel itineraries, doing business and investing, finding housing and obtaining medicare and medical information, as well as transportation information, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dalai Lama visit could be arranged at proper time: spokesman

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's decision to nix the idea of a visit to Taiwan at this time by the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama was based on concern for Taiwan's overall interests, but "such a visit could be arranged at a proper time in the future," Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Thursday.

"The president is concerned about the situation in Tibet, but his rejection of a possible visit by the Dalai Lama at present was based on consideration of the nation's overall interests, " Wang said while taking questions from the press at the Presidential Office.
However, Wang sidestepped a question on whether the term "national interests" refers to cross-Taiwan Strait relations, saying that "this is a complex issue."
He also stressed that Beijing has not contacted the Taiwan government on the Dalai Lama issue.
Although the Dalai Lama has publicly expressed interest in visiting Taiwan for a third time, sources said, the Tibetan spiritual leader has not applied to the Taiwan government to do so.

President Ma said during a news conference with members of the Taiwan Foreign Correspondents' Club Wednesday that Taiwan welcomes visits by all the world's religious leaders, but added, "I think at the current moment, the timing is not appropriate" for a visit by the Dalai Lama.

Fielding questions from reporters on the matter Thursday at the Legislative Yuan, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng suggested President Ma reconsider his position, as a visit by the Dalai Lama, widely viewed as the world's most admirable religious leader, would be religious in nature.

"It is not necessary to look a visit by the Dalai Lama from a political viewpoint," Wang said. "Taiwan could permit him to visit in a way that would make the world take positive notice of Taiwan, without upsetting the improving cross-strait ties."
Later Thursday, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang expressed regret over the president's negative position on a possible visit by the Dalai Lama at this time.

Cheng said the president should provide the public with a clear explanation of his stance on the issue, arguing that Taiwan should never give way to pressure from Beijing as this would tarnish Taiwan's international image.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, members of the DPP legislative caucus urged the president to review his stance, adding that they would propose a motion in the legislature to welcome a visit by the Dalai Lama to Taiwan.
Ma's position on the Dalai Lama issue has not only hurt the Taiwan people's feelings, but will also create a misconception of Taiwan internationally, DPP lawmakers said.
DPP Legislator Huang Wei-cher questioned why the Ma administration had so eagerly welcomed a visit by Chen Yunlin, but was turning a cold shoulder to the Tibetan spiritual leader.
Chen, who serves as Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan, held talks with his Taiwanese counterpart in November in Taipei amid warming ties between Taiwan and China since Ma came to power in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will admit Chinese students in gradual manner: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday that the opening of Taiwan's universities to Chinese students will be carried out in a gradual manner and with caution.

Liu made the remarks after the Cabinet approved a package of draft amendments to the University Act, the Junior College Act, and the Statute Governing Relations Between the Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area to facilitate its plan to allow Chinese students to attend universities in Taiwan and to recognize education credentials from Chinese universities.
Liu directed the Ministry of Education (MOE) to observe the principle of "gradual opening with complimentary measures" in its implementation of the policy.
The draft amendments will now be sent to the Legislative Yuan for review.

Under the amended laws, Taiwan will only recognize diplomas issued by reputable Chinese universities, will set a quota for the number of Chinese students coming to Taiwan, and in the initial stage will not recognize medical school credentials, even from reputable Chinese universities.

There will be specific admission quota for Chinese students applying to Taiwan schools, which will be set apart from the quota for local students, so that the rights of Taiwanese students pursuing higher education will not be affected, according to the plan.

Chinese students will not be awarded scholarships by Taiwanese universities, will not be allowed to work in Taiwan, must leave Taiwan after completion or termination of their studies, and will not be allowed to take Taiwan's civil service exams for government jobs, the regulations stipulate.

Ho Cho-fei, director of the MOE's Department of Higher Learning, said that the number of Chinese students to be admitted will range between 0.5 percent and 1 percent of the total number of new students enrolled in domestic colleges and universities, or between 1,000 and 2,000.
"The MOE will temporarily let each college and university decide individually on the tuition fees for Chinese students," Ho added.

An estimated 7,000 Taiwanese students are studying in China, and some 240,000 Chinese nationals have married into Taiwanese families. When these Taiwanese students and Chinese spouses look for employment in Taiwan, they face the problem of employers not recognizing their education credentials, thus depriving them of equal opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.022 to close at NT$33.550.
A total of US$694 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.528 and rose as high as NT$33.590.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to push for reform of detention system: chairwoman

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) passed a resolution Wednesday supporting its legislators to push for reform of Taiwan's detention system in light of the fact that a number of suspects, including current or former DPP members, have been detained without trial.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made the announcement at a news conference after a DPP weekly Central Standing Committee meeting.
Tsai said that DPP lawmakers will propose amendments to relevant laws at the Legislative Yuan aimed at improving protection of detainees' human rights.

Describing the Ministry of Justice as a "human rights killer, " for its role in several recent cases involving the ill-treatment of detainees, Tsai said all public officials involved should resign to take responsibility for violating human rights during investigations.
Among the most notorious of such practices are those pertaining to forcing detainees to have a short crew-cut and handcuffing them before trial, Tsai cited as examples.

In the most high-profile example, ex-president and former DPP chairman Chen Shui-bian was led away in handcuffs on Nov. 12 and remains in detention without being formally charged, pending an investigation into alleged corruption and money laundering by the former first family.
Tsai on Thursday also lambasted Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng for interfering in legal cases and publicly discussing the content of legal cases on TV talk shows.
Meanwhile, she accused the ministry of taking steps against Cheng Wen-long, the lawyer for former president Chen, under the pretext that he allegedly leaked information about the case to the press.
The ministry recently sent a request to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office and the Taiwan Lawyers Association asking them to investigate Cheng and see whether he should have his license revoked.
Tsai said that the ministry's move has already generated a profound chilling effect among local attorneys and is a giant step backwards for human rights.
She added that the ministry's actions reminded her of the Formosa Incident in 1979 when defense lawyers were subjected to intimidation by the authorities.

The DPP chairwoman said that President Ma Ying-jeou has stated publicly several times that he had never intervened in any legal case when he was minister of justice, but he seemed to forget that he, as head of state, should take full responsibility for the inadequacy of the country's legal system and human rights violations.
"Up until now, the president or the ministry have not come up with any idea or proposal for relevant law amendments," Tsai added.

She suggested that the president should first review the criminal procedure system and modify regulations on the treatment of detainees, such as banning the use of precautionary appliances, such as handcuffs, in order to avoid human rights infringements.

Tsai also called on Ma to conduct a public investigation into clashes between police and protesters during the visit of Chinese negotiator Chen Yunlin to Taipei early last month, to determine whether law enforcement authorities infringed on protesters' freedom of expression and personal safety.
She said Ma should not dodge his responsibility over the issue, rather he should consider a proposal by the U.S. Freedom House to create an independent commission to thoroughly look into the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should adopt international food safety standards: AIT

TEXT.P: The United States is urging Taiwan to adopt internationally consistent standards as quickly as possible in its development of food regulatory systems, American Institute in Taiwan Director Stephen M. Young said Thursday.

Young made the remarks during a speech titled "U.S. Taiwan Relations: Looking To The Future, Building On Past Achievements," at a luncheon hosted by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taiwan at the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei.

Noting that the overall value of U.S. agricultural exports to Taiwan has continued to grow for the sixth consecutive year, Young said, however, "the agricultural market access problems remain at the heart of our trade agenda."
He said that there are still major challenges ahead for the further opening of Taiwan's market to key U.S. agricultural products.

Nearly three years ago, Taiwan led Asia in re-opening its market to imports of U.S. boneless beef, and since then Taiwanese consumers have welcomed U.S. beef, buying US$107 million worth in 2007 alone, said Young.
However, he added, despite ample scientific evidence that the imports of U.S. "bone-in" beef pose no safety risk, they continue to be banned in Taiwan.
"Taiwanese consumers are confident that U.S. beef is safe", Young stated.

Calling for Taiwan to fully open its market to U.S. beef, Young reminded Taiwan that the transparent application of scientific principles consistent with established international norms is the best way to ensure food safety while facilitating trade.
"As Taiwan seeks to expand its role in the global community, it should also live up to its responsibilities as a member of that community," he advised.

He said that the U.S. understands that the Department of Health of Taiwan (DOH) will soon publish the findings of its risk assessments on the safety of U.S. beef products, adding that he hopes the results will bring the U.S. closer to the early, science-based opening of the market to the full range of U.S. beef products.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of "bovine spongiform encephalopathy"(BSE), better known as mad cow disease, was diagnosed in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle under 30 months old, but the Taiwan government re-imposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the United States. The DOH didn't lift the ban until Jan.25, 2006.

Taiwan currently only allows the import of U.S. boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months, produced from certificated slaughterhouses and without high risk parts such as brains and spinal cord marrow.

DOC.HEADLINE: New batch of men prepare to carry out alternative service abroad

TEXT.P: A group of young Taiwanese men will be dispatched in mid-December to countries that have diplomatic relations with Taiwan to provide technical and medical assistance, as an alternative to mandatory military service, the government- funded International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) said Thursday.

Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Javier C. S. Hou said that while this valuable experience will "allow young Taiwanese to broaden their horizons," it is also a way to "contribute to the more balanced development of the world."

Hou encouraged the young men to give their best in assisting Taiwan's allies, because "although you are called military men, you are regarded as experts by the developing countries with which Taiwan has ties."

According to the ICDF, 94 servicemen, after completing eight weeks of extended training in areas such as professional skills, language courses and adjustment to foreign cultures, will depart for Taiwan's 22 diplomatic allies in the Asia- Pacific, Africa, the Caribbean, and Central and South America.

The conscripts, who are in their mid-20's, will join Taiwan's overseas medical missions or technical teams currently operating in counties with diplomatic ties to Taiwan, providing assistance in areas that include agriculture, aquatic product cultivation, public health and information technology, according to the ICDF.

The ICDF, mandated by Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to facilitate aid to Taiwan's allies and other nations, began recruiting servicemen for overseas work in 2001. Over the past seven years, the number of participants in the program has grown to 425. After completing their overseas assignments, many servicemen usually chose to join the ICDF's teams abroad as a career.

The youth overseas service initiative provides an alternative option for young Taiwanese males, who are required to serve for 14 months in the military, to meet their obligations while making use of their professional skills and helping to improve the living standards in Taiwan's allies. The period of alternative service is two months longer than the regular conscription.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese giant pandas expected to come to Taiwan before Christmas

TEXT.P: A pair of giant pandas which China has promised to give to Taiwan is expected to be delivered to Taipei prior to Christmas Day, a ranking official of the intermediary body Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Thursday.

Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the quasi-official SEF, expressed hopes at the Legislative Yuan that the two pandas could be delivered days before Christmas to facilitate the rare animals' public display at the Taipei Zoo during the Lunar New Year holidays, which begin on Jan. 25.
"Taipei Zoo would be in a rush should the pandas arrive by Christmas or later, " Kao said.
He explained that it would take one month for the animals to undergo quarantine observation after arriving in Taiwan before they could be presented to zoo visitors.

Meanwhile, Kao said, the 17 seedlings of the Chinese endemic dove tree that China has also promised to give to Taiwan as a token of peace across the Taiwan Strait are expected to be delivered along with the pandas.

He noted that the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has already referred import-export documents to relevant Chinese authorities for the animals and the seedlings, and that delivery could proceed as long as Chinese authorities return the documents.
The dove tree usually lives for 50-150 years and is known as a "living fossil" because it is believed to have survived the Ice Age.

The species is called dove tree by the Chinese because its flowers look like white doves. It was named Davidia Involucrata in the West in honor of Pierre Armand David, a French missionary and explorer who found wild dove trees in Muping of Sichuan, China in 1903.

The dove tree, which has been declared by Beijing as one of China's eight rare and endangered fauna species, is also called the "pearls of the forests" in China. Most of the wild dove tree forests are found in China's Sichuan, Hubei, Guizhou, Gansu and Yunnan provinces.

China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , and his Taiwanese counterpart, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, agreed in Taipei during Chen's visit to Taipei last month that the two sides present each other with rare indigenous species of fauna and flora as tokens of friendship and amity.
Under that agreement, Taiwan will reciprocate with a pair of Formosan serow - a type of goat - and a pair of Formosan sika deer.
Chen and Chiang also signed pacts on food safety, the expansion of cross-strait charter flight services and the establishment of direct shipping and postal links.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF chief heads for Japan

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung left for Japan Thursday to explain the recent developments in Taiwan-China ties to Japanese figures and arrange a visit by ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung to that country.

Speaking to reporters at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport prior to his departure, Chiang said he will meet representatives from Japan's political and media circles and from local expatriate communities to provide them with comprehensive information concerning recent changes in cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
In addition, he said, he will help arrange the itinerary for Wu, who is slated to visit Japan next week.
Japan has been a long time and close ally of Taiwan in the region.

Taiwan-China ties have significantly improved after President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office in May, and a visit to Taipei last month by Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, also gave a further boost to bilateral ties, the SEF chief said.
Taiwanese officials have said that the island's closer relations with China will not jeopardize its relations with other countries, but rather benefit the region by promoting peace and stability.
In a follow-up to their historic encounter in June in Beijing, Chiang and Chen inked four agreements during their meeting in Taipei last month.

The agreements, which are slated to take effect from Dec. 15, will expand direct flights between the two former rivals and launch direct shipping and postal links. An agreement to cooperate closely in dealing with food safety control was also inked.

Chiang on Thursday expressed his confidence that the four pacts will benefit both sides of the Taiwan Strait, which separates the island and China, particularly the accords that allow the establishment of direct shipping and air travel links.

DOC.HEADLINE: European countries urged to give Taiwan nationals visa-free entry

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed the hope Thursday that European countries will waive visa requirements for Taiwanese tourists.

Ma noted that Taiwan has given more than 30 countries, including 20 European Union nations, visa-free treatment. If the European countries could also reciprocate, then the number of Taiwan tourists to Europe will definitely increase dramatically, he added.

The president made the remarks when he received foreign participants to the 25th Taiwan-European Conference, an annual academic meeting sponsored by National Chengchi University's Institute of International Relations.

Ma said the conference has played a major role in increasing academic exchanges between Taiwan and European countries over the past 25 years. He added that it has also contributed to the progress made in relations between Taiwan and many European countries.
Ma noted that the European Union is now Taiwan's fourth largest trading partner.

The EU has been supportive of Taiwan in many ways, including its support of the second round of talks between Taiwan and China in Taipei last month and of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization and its governing body, the World Health Assembly, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH urges dentists to exercise self-discipline over implant quality

TEXT.P: Self-discipline on the part of dentists who supply dental implants might be the only defense against substandard implant quality, as the government has no effective quality control mechanism in this area, Department of Health (DOH) official Chou Tao-chun said Thursday.
Chou, a section chief of the DOH's Bureau of Medical Affairs, said that while dentists are allowed to perform the procedure, there is no system to guarantee their competence.
He urged patients to check whether their dentists have received certifications from professional groups before getting dental implants.
Wang Kang-yu, a Taipei Citizen, told CNA that same day that he contracted periodontal disease that he said stemmed from substandard dental implants that he received a decade ago.

Wang's current dentist, Chen Liang-chou, who treated Wang's dental problems, said substandard tooth implants can indeed cause dental problems that without treatment could lead to the loss of the implants.

Tsai Yi-min, an executive of Taiwan's Academy of Oral Implantology (AOI) , said Taiwanese customers buy around 100,000 dental implants every year, but added that most local dentistry schools do not provide enough training in the procedure.
Those who want to perfect their technique have to seek training on their own, for which many travel abroad, but even overseas training can be hasty and is no guarantee of quality, Tsai said.

In addition to the uneven standards among dentists, the market is also chaotic in terms of price levels for both materials and procedures, with the price of a complete dental implant ranging from NT$30,000 (US$895)-NT$100,000, Tsai said.

Another health official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Taiwan has about 15,000 practicing dentists, only about 1,000 of whom are members of either the AOI or the only other professional organization in the field, the International Congress of Oral Implantology in Taiwan.

An AOI executive pointed out that only about 140 of the academy's members have been granted dental implant certification by the academy, a process in which members apply to receive evaluation from the academy. The evaluation process, which takes about two years, is considered proof that a member has outstanding dental implant skills.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ready to open to qualified Chinese institutional investors

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved Thursday a set of regulatory measures to pave the way for the opening of Taiwan's securities and commodities markets to qualified domestic institutional investors (QDII) from China.

The measures will take effect on the date of their proclamation by the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said during a Cabinet meeting, adding that the opening is expected to attract more overseas investment to Taiwan and help expand the size of the country's capital market.

The move will also speed up Taiwan's internationalization and enhance its competitiveness, elements that are essential to the government's bid to transform the country into a regional financial hub, Liu said.
According to the regulations, Chinese QDII funds will be permitted to invest up to 3 percent of their capital in Taiwan.

With such funds having experienced significant shrinkage owing to the global financial crisis, FSC Vice Chairwoman Lee Jih-chu estimated that the 3 percent ratio will mean an amount of just US$200 million, down sharply from the US$1.1 billion estimated in August.
The regulations stipulate that QDII investors will be forbidden from investing in Taiwan's over-the-counter market and from engaging in margin trading.

They also impose restrictions that will prevent investors from taking control of the Taiwanese businesses in which they invest, so that they will not be allowed to become board directors or supervisors of Taiwanese businesses or to influence the personnel decisions of such businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China seen likely to sign MOU on banking supervision

TEXT.P: There is a strong likelihood that Taiwan and China will sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) during the first quarter of next year to facilitate cooperation in the area of banking supervision, according to a local banker.

Susan S. Chang, chairwoman of the Bank of Taiwan (BOT), made the comments at a news conference Wednesday after her return from Beijing where she attended an academic symposium on cross-Taiwan Strait financial cooperation.

Chang said that during the symposium she discussed with Chinese banking officials the possibility of Taiwan and China signing an MOU, which they believe would impact positively on bilateral banking cooperation.
The MOU would also make it possible to upgrade the seven liaison offices established by Taiwanese banks in China to bank branches, she added.

According to Chang, four Chinese banks have been permitted by China's Banking Regulatory Commission to set up footholds in Taiwan. However, as Taiwan has not yet revised its law to permit such opening, none of the banks have been able to establish operations here, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC citizens banned from taking political posts in China

TEXT.P: Taiwanese citizens are prohibited by the Republic of China government from taking up any public post in China that is political in nature, the Cabinet- level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.

MAC spokesman and Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said Taiwanese citizens are not allowed to be Chinese Peoples Political Consultative COnference (CPPCC) members, regardless of whether the position is at the city-based CPPCC committee or national level, according to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

Liu made the remarks in response to a news report from China's Fujian Province that day that Xiamen City has passed an amendment recently allowing Taiwanese residents to be elected members of the city committee of the CPPCC as part of the city government's efforts to "protect Taiwan residents' investments in Xiamen."

Liu said that although admission to the CPPCC as a delegate would be conducive to solving the problems facing Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, he urged China-based Taiwanese businessmen not to challenge Taiwan's laws.

According to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, Taiwanese citizens or organizations are prohibited from joining or taking posts in political, military or administrative groups or organizations in China.

In May this year, representatives of several associations of Taiwanese businessmen in China called for President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to earmark money to establish a "taishang fund" in China to financially assist Taiwanese businessmen, who face constant difficulties operating in the "factory of the world."

One of the representatives also urged the administration to seek to revise the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area so that China-based Taiwanese businessmen can be elected as members of CPPCC committees.

Since most Taiwanese businessmen living in China run businesses there, admission to the CPPCC as delegates would allow their voices to be better heard and would give them a platform for communication with the local and central Chinese governments, the representative said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. president-elect to maintain consistent Taiwan policy: AIT

TEXT.P: The United States will maintain a consistent policy regarding its relations with Taiwan under the incoming administration of U.S. President-elect Barack Obama, American Institute in Taiwan Director Stephen M. Young said Thursday.

Young, head of the de facto U.S. embassy in Taipei in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two countries, made the remarks in a speech titled "U.S. Taiwan Relations: Looking To The Future, Building On Past Achievements, " at a luncheon hosted by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei.
Young said he is confident the "consistency" that has served both countries so well in the past will continue as the U.S. prepares for the transition to a new administration.

He also revealed that influential cross-Taiwan Strait affairs experts such as James Steinburg, Richard Bush and Jeff Bader might be appointed to senior positions in the Obama Administration, a possibility that he described as "favorable to Taiwan's interests."

"The global environment has seen dramatic changes in the past three decades, " said Young, adding that despite those changes, the United States has maintained a remarkably consistent policy regarding its relations with Taiwan.

Explaining how U.S. policy has contributed to Taiwan's development, Young said that "it is precisely this consistency that has helped form the basis for the extraordinary political and economic progress now enjoyed by everyone in Taiwan, a progress that can serve as an example to all who seek to build a society that combines prosperity and freedom."

Asked about the four agreements signed between Taiwan and China in the past six months to enhance cross-strait economic links, Young described them as the "low hanging fruits" of the development of cross-strait economic relations.

He said that although the immediate economic benefits of the recent cross-strait opening might not always be apparent, each incremental step in an ongoing process will help build a climate that favors investment and growth.

"The United States welcomes increased economic and trade ties between China and Taiwan, " Young reiterated, adding that enhanced cross-strait economic links "are just plain good for business, especially at a time of global economic uncertainty."

DOC.HEADLINE: Matsu tourism operators fear impact of cross-strait air links

TEXT.P: Tourism and shipping operators on outlying Matsu Island voiced concern Thursday over the opening of direct air links between Taiwan proper and Fuzhou in China's Fujian Province, which they said could seriously impact their livelihoods.

The operators took the issue to the island's Lienchiang County Government Transport Bureau after Chinese media reported recently that a one-way charter flight between Taipei and Fuzhou, to be operated by China's Xiamen Airlines, will cost 680 yuan (US$99).

The fare will be lower than a one-way ferry trip between the two destinations -- currently priced at 700 yuan -- according to the Chinese media report. The price will also be cheaper than the NT$3,800 for travel between Taiwan and Fuzhou via Matsu -- commonly known as the "mini links, " according to the Chinese media report.

In that case, the existing Matsu-Fuzhou ferry business will be seriously impacted because a direct Taipei-Fuzhou flight can also save at least three hours in travel time compared to sailing via the "mini links," tourism operators said.

County officials refused to comment on the concerns, however, saying that the Legislative Yuan has yet to approve accords inked last month between Taiwan and China on expanding the two-way air travel network and opening shipping services.
The "mini links" also include ferry services between Taiwan-held Kinmen Island and the Fujian ports of Xiamen and Quanzhou since January 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT chairman calls for better Taiwan-Japan ties

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said Thursday that it requires mutual endeavors by both sides if Taiwan and Japan want to further cement bilateral relations.

"Taiwan and Japan have a special partnership, " Wu said, adding that Japan is Taiwan's second- largest trading partner and that some 2.5 million tourists travel between the two countries annually, while two-way trade tops US$70 billion per year.
"Taiwan and Japan can also cooperate to crack the vast China market," he went on.

Wu said that although Taiwan cannot relinquish its sovereignty claim over the disputed Tiaoyutais, a group of islets in the East China Sea claimed by both sides along with China, both Taiwan and Japan "can put aside the dispute and move toward fishery cooperation, " a move espoused by President Ma Ying-jeou.
He denied claims by critics that Ma is anti-Japan, but said the president is in fact well- informed about Japan and wants to strengthen Taiwan-Japan relations.

Wu is scheduled to lead a KMT delegation on a visit to Japan Dec. 7, marking the first time a KMT chairman will have visited Japan to promote party-to-party exchanges since the KMT came to power in May. The delegation is scheduled to meet with officials from Japan's ruling and opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Maokong Gondola being completely examined: Taipei mayor

TEXT.P: The Maokong Gondola is being given a complete safety examination and the Taipei city government will allow it to resume operation only after its safety has been absolutely assured, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Thursday.

Hau made the announcement after Taipei City Councilor Chuang Jui-hsiung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said earlier in the day that a gap had been found between the ground and the base of the cable car system's support tower T-20.

In response to Sheng Chi-tseng, vice general manager of the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. that operates the system, who said the gap was caused when heavy rain washed away the topsoil around the tower, the city's New Construction Office Director-General Wu Chun-hsien said the interstice can simply be filled with more topsoil and will not affect the tower's safety.
Sheng also said the cable car system's 25 support towers have all been fitted with tilt panels to monitor any changes in their positions and that so far, the monitoring results appear normal.

The gondola, a popular tourist attraction in the mountains of Taipei's Muzha area, was closed indefinitely Oct. 1 out of concern that tower T-16 could collapse during an earthquake after torrential rain brought by Typhoon Jangmei in September eroded the base of the tower, leaving it bare and exposed.
Hau said the complete overall examination includes installing the tilting panels and checking whether all construction steps were carried out according to the design brief.
Each support tower will be assessed by experts to ensure its safety, Hau continued, adding that the city government has no timetable or cost estimate for the examination.
The mayor announced earlier in the week that the city government had begun the process of selecting a site for the possible relocation of tower T-16.

An initial safety assessment filed by four major civil engineering associations last Sunday strongly recommended that the tower be relocated and that the entire slope in the vicinity of the pillar be reinforced to make the system safe.

Hau said Poma Co., the system's French manufacturer and installer, will send technicians to Taiwan if necessary and that city government staff are in discussions about the types of machines and cranes that will be needed for a relocation effort.

DOC.HEADLINE: HKTDC chief to preside over opening of Taiwan branch office

TEXT.P: The head of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council (HKTDC) is slated to arrive in Taipei Friday to officiate at an opening reception for a branch office in Taiwan.
HKTDC Chairman Jack So will be accompanied by other senior executives of the trade promotion organization, the council's Taipei representative, Perry Fung, said Thursday.
Fung, who has been in Taipei since October preparing for the opening of the council's first foothold here, said the HKTDC Taiwan office will begin formal operations early next year.

The HKTDC, a Hong Kong government-funded but unofficial organization, began considering opening a branch in Taiwan five years ago, but did not file an application until after the Kuomintang -- seen as more friendly toward China than the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration -- regained power in Taiwan in May this year.

After Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs approved the HKTDC application in October, the Hong Kong group sent Fung -- formerly the HKTDC Beijing office's top executive in charge of the northern China market -- to Taipei to prepare for the opening of the new office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Airfares for cross-strait charter flights to be cut by 10%:CAA

TEXT.P: Airfares for northbound flights on direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter planes will be cut by an average of 10 percent after such services are expanded to a daily basis, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Thursday.

CAA Director-General Lee Lung-wen made the remarks in response to recent appeals by the Consumers Foundation which said ticket prices for direct cross-strait charter flights should be lowered to reflect the shortened flight time once such services are expanded to a daily basis from the current weekend basis.
Noting that the foundation's appeal is plausible, Lee said the CAA has persuaded five locally owned air carriers to adjust downward their cross-strait ticket prices.

"All of the five carriers have given a positive response to our push, " Lee said, adding that China Airlines, Mandarin Airlines, EVA Airways and UNI Airways have promised to lower airfares on northbound cross-strait flights by an average of 10 percent, while Trans Asia Airways will cut prices for one-way tickets by NT$500 to NT$600.

DOC.HEADLINE: Matsu tourism operators fear impact of cross-strait air links

TEXT.P: Tourism and shipping operators on outlying Matsu Island voiced concern Thursday over the opening of direct air links between Taiwan proper and Fuzhou in China's Fujian Province, which they said could seriously impact their livelihoods.

The operators took the issue to the island's Lienchiang County Government Transport Bureau after Chinese media reported recently that a one-way charter flight between Taipei and Fuzhou, to be operated by China's Xiamen Airlines, will cost 680 yuan (US$99).

The fare will be lower than a one-way ferry trip between the two destinations -- currently priced at 700 yuan -- according to the Chinese media report. The price will also be cheaper than the NT$3,800 for travel between Taiwan and Fuzhou via Matsu -- commonly known as the "mini links, " according to the Chinese media report.

In that case, the existing Matsu-Fuzhou ferry business will be seriously impacted because a direct Taipei-Fuzhou flight can also save at least three hours in travel time compared to sailing via the "mini links," tourism operators said.

County officials refused to comment on the concerns, however, saying that the Legislative Yuan has yet to approve accords inked last month between Taiwan and China on expanding the two-way air travel network and opening shipping services.
The "mini links" also include ferry services between Taiwan-held Kinmen Island and the Fujian ports of Xiamen and Quanzhou since January 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT chairman calls for better Taiwan-Japan ties

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said Thursday that it requires mutual endeavors by both sides if Taiwan and Japan want to further cement bilateral relations.

"Taiwan and Japan have a special partnership, " Wu said, adding that Japan is Taiwan's second- largest trading partner and that some 2.5 million tourists travel between the two countries annually, while two-way trade tops US$70 billion per year.
"Taiwan and Japan can also cooperate to crack the vast China market," he went on.

Wu said that although Taiwan cannot relinquish its sovereignty claim over the disputed Tiaoyutais, a group of islets in the East China Sea claimed by both sides along with China, both Taiwan and Japan "can put aside the dispute and move toward fishery cooperation, " a move espoused by President Ma Ying-jeou.
He denied claims by critics that Ma is anti-Japan, but said the president is in fact well- informed about Japan and wants to strengthen Taiwan-Japan relations.

Wu is scheduled to lead a KMT delegation on a visit to Japan Dec. 7, marking the first time a KMT chairman will have visited Japan to promote party-to-party exchanges since the KMT came to power in May. The delegation is scheduled to meet with officials from Japan's ruling and opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Maokong Gondola being completely examined: Taipei mayor

TEXT.P: The Maokong Gondola is being given a complete safety examination and the Taipei city government will allow it to resume operation only after its safety has been absolutely assured, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Thursday.

Hau made the announcement after Taipei City Councilor Chuang Jui-hsiung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said earlier in the day that a gap had been found between the ground and the base of the cable car system's support tower T-20.

In response to Sheng Chi-tseng, vice general manager of the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. that operates the system, who said the gap was caused when heavy rain washed away the topsoil around the tower, the city's New Construction Office Director-General Wu Chun-hsien said the interstice can simply be filled with more topsoil and will not affect the tower's safety.
Sheng also said the cable car system's 25 support towers have all been fitted with tilt panels to monitor any changes in their positions and that so far, the monitoring results appear normal.

The gondola, a popular tourist attraction in the mountains of Taipei's Muzha area, was closed indefinitely Oct. 1 out of concern that tower T-16 could collapse during an earthquake after torrential rain brought by Typhoon Jangmei in September eroded the base of the tower, leaving it bare and exposed.
Hau said the complete overall examination includes installing the tilting panels and checking whether all construction steps were carried out according to the design brief.
Each support tower will be assessed by experts to ensure its safety, Hau continued, adding that the city government has no timetable or cost estimate for the examination.
The mayor announced earlier in the week that the city government had begun the process of selecting a site for the possible relocation of tower T-16.

An initial safety assessment filed by four major civil engineering associations last Sunday strongly recommended that the tower be relocated and that the entire slope in the vicinity of the pillar be reinforced to make the system safe.

Hau said Poma Co., the system's French manufacturer and installer, will send technicians to Taiwan if necessary and that city government staff are in discussions about the types of machines and cranes that will be needed for a relocation effort.

DOC.HEADLINE: HKTDC chief to preside over opening of Taiwan branch office

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 5, or the eighth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1782: Martin Van Buren, the eighth president of the United States, is born.
1791: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer considered among the greatest and most prolific composers in history, dies in Vienna of kidney failure at the age of 35. He had written more than 600 works.
1792: George Washington is reelected president of the United States.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out, with Japanese troops occupying Height 203, the ideal position for capturing Lushun, west of the port city of Talien.
1906: Russian Adm. Niebogatov goes on trial on charges of surrendering ships to the Japanese.
1915: Chen Chi-mei, a follower of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, leads a revolt against Yuan Shih-kai by trying to seize the warship Chaoho. His attempt fails the following day.
1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States celebrates the end of 14 long years of prohibition when the government nullifies the 18th Amendment, which outlawed the production, transportation or sale of alcohol.
1945: Six U.S. Navy aircraft carrying 27 airmen go missing without a trace in the Atlantic Ocean near Bermuda.
1946: A strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1949: Li Tsung-jen, acting president of the Republic of China, leaves Hong Kong for the United States.
1950: North Korean and Communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang as United Nations forces are forced to withdraw southward.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.
1957: The Indonesian government orders the expulsion of all Dutch nationals.
1968: The Taiwan Provincial Government launches a one-person-one-dollar movement to raise money for national sports development.
1972: The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York opens a branch office in Taipei.
1975: Campaign activities for the Dec. 20 legislative elections open with 61 candidates contesting 37 Taiwan area seats.
1976: Professional golfers Kuo Chi-hsiung and Hsu Sheng-san leave for Palm Springs, Calif., to take part in the 24th World Cup professional golf tournament.
1978: The Soviet Union signs a 20-year treaty of friendship with Afghanistan.
1984: Ninety-three miners are killed in an accident at the Haishanyikeng mining pit in Shanhsia township, Taipei County.
1984: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang unanimously supports a bill to amend the Firearms Control Act, imposing heavy punishments on the unauthorized manufacture of deadly weapons, with a maximum sentence of death.
1985: The United States decides to pull out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
1985: Four businessmen are sentenced to prison terms ranging from two-and-a-half years to 12 years by a military court under the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters for conducting direct trade with the Communist Chinese.
1995: Javier Solana, the Spanish foreign minister, is appointed the secretary- general of NATO.
1999: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang leaves for Miami to attend the annual Miami Conference on the Caribbean and Latin America.
2000: A total of 105 young Indonesians begin to receive two years of professional training in Taiwan as part of the ROC's efforts to help its major Southeast Asian trading partner develop small- and medium-sized enterprises.
2001: Beijing authorities sternly rejects Taiwan's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait commence dialogue on the "three direct links" issue under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The "three direct links" refers to direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler answers to the desire of the subjects, it manifests an understanding of approvals and disapprovals of the people. When there is such an understanding, the good will be discovered and rewarded and the bad will be discovered and punished, and the country will surely attain order."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC military to be fully volunteer force by 2014

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has started planning to push a fully professional voluntary military service system in a bid to build the country's military into "lean and mean" fighting force, Vice Defense Minister Chang Liang- jen said Friday.

The fully volunteer military program will be promoted in a gradual manner, with the number of uniformed men and women recruited through a voluntary enlistment system increasing 10 percent year-on-year from 2010 and eventually reaching a fully volunteer force by 2014, Chang said during a forum held in Taipei.

Speaking at the forum on a volunteer military and the transformation of the armed forces that was sponsored by the Institute of International Relations of National Chengchi University, Chang said the government will take advantage of the eased atmosphere across the Taiwan Strait to restructure the military to make it a modern defense force that can help maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait on a long-term basis.

Defense Minister Chen Chao-min said in August that in order to comply with the objectives set forth in President Ma Ying-jeou's election campaign platform, the MND has been working to launch a voluntary enlistment system in 2010 with the goal of making the military into a fully volunteer force gradually.

Ma, who took office May 20, has promoted the introduction of a fully professional and volunteer military and the continued streamlining of the armed forces, with the ultimate goal of reducing the number of military personnel to 200,000.
After the voluntary enlistment system is in place, the president said in June, "the military will be further streamlined and a smaller but stronger military will be established."
