According to an MND budget plan, the number of military personnel will have been reduced to a total of 275,000 by the end of this year, including 250,000 on the regular MND payroll.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait ties reach `mutual non-denial' stage: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's relations with China have progressed to a stage in which the two sides no longer deny each other, thanks to the government's efforts to improve ties over the past six months, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Friday.

According to MAC Vice Chairman Chao Chien-min, this "mutual non-denial" stage marks a milestone in the transition from "mutual denial" to "mutual recognition" between the two sides. Chao made the remarks while addressing an award- presentation ceremony for short films addressing the theme of cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges.

The change, he said, is demonstrated in the fact that Chinese officials are now willing to recognize the official capacity of Taiwanese government officials and to visit Taiwan's president, Chao said.

This shows great differences from the past, when Chinese officials and academics visiting Taiwan always avoided visits to government offices and refused any meetings with Taiwanese government officials at their offices, he noted.

In what was widely viewed as a major breakthrough, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, called on MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan at her office and met with President Ma Ying-jeou during his historic visit to Taiwan last month.

During his stay in Taiwan, Chen -- who serves as Beijing's top negotiator with Taipei -- signed four agreements with Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung on cross-strait air, shipping and postal services, and food safety communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: President welcomes Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan at opportune time

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that Taiwan would extend a warm welcome to the Dalai Lama to visit Taiwan for religious activities at an opportune time, although he added that the timing for such a visit at the present time would not be right.
Ma said that the Dalai Lama, who has expressed an interest in making another visit to the country at some point next year, would be welcome to visit Taiwan because he has so many followers here.

He made the remarks to visiting Italian Senator Salvo Fleres, who during a brief meeting with Ma at the Presidential Office, asked about the prospects for a visit to Taiwan by Tibet's exiled spiritual leader.

Fleres, visiting at the head of a six-member delegation from Italy, told Ma he has gained a better understanding over the past three days of Taiwan's political and economic development and has discovered that the Taiwanese people not only enjoy the fruits of democratization but also freedom of religion.

Ma responded by saying that "it's true that the Republic of China is a country where the people enjoy absolute freedom of religion and that's the reason why all religious leaders and figures in the world are welcome to visit Taiwan."

Meanwhile, Ma also called for the Italy-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group established in 1994 to continue its efforts to cement bilateral ties between Taiwan and Italy and help boost private exchanges between the people of the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC delegation for U.S. presidential inauguration undecided: MOFA

TEXT.P: The government has yet to make a final decision on the members to be included in Taiwan's delegation to the Jan. 20 inauguration of U.S. President-elect Barack Obama, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Friday.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen also denied a media report that the MOFA has rejected a plan by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to name former Vice President Annette Lu as the party's representative on the delegation.

The MOFA requested Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who will lead the delegation, to help organize the delegation a few weeks ago, but he has not submitted a list of potential members to the ministry, the officials said.
The MOFA fully respects Wang's opinion and has not expressed any views on who he should choose, the officials went on.
Chen said it would not be a problem if Lu were to join the delegation, because her possible participation is not expected to meet any opposition from the U.S. side.

According to the report, the delegation is likely to include ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lin Yu-fang, co-chair of the Foreign and National Defense Committee; DPP Legislator Chai Trong-rong; Non-Partisan Solidarity Union Legislator Lin Pin-kuan; Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin; Taoyuan Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu; Taichung Mayor Jason Hu; and Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair. The KMT has nominated Legislator John Chiang as the party's representative.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former VP should attend U.S. presidential inauguration: KMT

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) caucus Deputy Secretary- General Lo Shu-lei said Friday at a press conference that the caucus would be happy to see former Vice President Annette Lu of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) attend the inauguration of U.S. President-elect Barack Obama if she is invited.

"Annette Lu is a very good diplomat, " said Lo. "We would be very happy to see her going to the Obama inauguration if she is invited to do so. However, it is entirely up to the United States to decide if they want to invite her or not. It is their call, " she pointed out.
KMT Legislator Wu Ching-chih noted that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has yet to decide who will be appointed to join the Taiwanese delegation that will attend the Jan. 20 inauguration.

"The MOFA should encourage Lu to attend the inauguration, " said Wu. "Even if China objects, we should still allow her to be part of the delegation to show that we, Taiwanese, are non-partisan, " he added. KMT Legislator Shuai Hua-ming echoed Wu, saying that "the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) does not have too many talented diplomats. Lu is the only DPP figure with the prominence to attend international events. I have no objections to her attending Obama's inauguration."

The KMT caucus remarks were prompted by reports that the DPP is planning to recommend Lu as part of the Taiwanese delegation that will attend the inauguration, in an effort to seek the limelight following the success of KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan's trip to attend the APEC Forum in Lima, Peru as President Ma Ying-jeou's envoy.

DPP Legislator Ker Chien-ming had said earlier that same day that "it seems that MOFA is trying to obstruct Lu from being part of the delegation. It is the DPP's right to send who ever we see fit to attend Obama's inauguration. Lu is a very appropriate candidate."
MOFA spokesman Henry Chen responded immediately, saying that the delegation is still in the planning stages and denying that any objections had been raised to any DPP recommendations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung city cuts electricity bill with energy-saving measures

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government has cut its electricity use by 500,000 kilowatt- hours (kWh) thanks to measures implemented by an "energy conservation, carbon reduction" task force established in July, City Government Secretary-General Hau Chien-sheng said Friday.

Hau, who convened the task force, said in an interview that such cost cutting measures launched by the task force as reducing the number of elevators in use at government buildings and encouraging staff to turn off computers, printers and other electrical equipment when not in use has helped reduce electricity consumption by about 4.5 percent over the last five months, translating into savings of some NT$1.5 million (US$45,000).

To realize the goals of the energy conservation plan, the task force regularly dispatches personnel to various government offices to conduct spot checks to verify whether the recommended electricity saving measures are being followed, Hau said.
The city council has also been working in line with the energy conservation plan, according to Hsu Mau-sen, head of the city council's general affairs department.

Hsu said measures like turning off one of the two large air conditioners in the city council's main hall and adjusting the temperature to 23 degrees Celsius, as well as requiring employees to cultivate energy saving habits such as turning off lights when not in use, has helped cut the electricity bill by hundreds of thousands of dollars over the past year.
For the month of October alone, the city council reduced electricity consumption by 17,600 kWh, which translated into savings of about NT$40,000 on its electricity bill, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
University launches fundraising drive for education for poor children

TEXT.P: National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) has launched a fundraising drive in which it has invited the public to make donations to help poor children receive education amid the global financial downward, NTNU President Kuo Yi-hsiung said Friday.
The donations will be used to subsidize tuition, school lunches and health insurance, according to Kuo.
He urged the country's 206,963 elementary, junior and high school teachers to support the drive.

He said each teacher is encouraged to donate NT$3,600 (US$107) , which is the equivalent value of the consumption vouchers that will be issued by the government next January in an effort to boost consumption.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan announced in November that the government will issue consumption vouchers to the country's citizens, with each eligible individual receiving vouchers worth NT$3,600.
Kuo said that if every teacher makes the donation, NT$745 million will be raised -- enough to subsidize 140, 000 children from impoverished families.
Speaking at the drive's launch ceremony Thursday, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin- pyng showed his support by donating not only NT$3,600 but also a further NT$1 million to fund the drive.
Wang also said he will invite legislators of different political parties to donate.
In addition, the NTNU announced a variety of other activities designed to draw society's attention to the impact of the global financial downward on education among the disadvantaged.
The activities will include a Dec. 18 "lighting up" ceremony involving the country's 4,000 schools at elementary and secondary levels and 300 private sector companies.

From that day onward, members of the public will be able to get free miniature light bulbs made with recycled materials from the participating schools, which they will be able to wear to show their concern about education for the nation's poor children, Kuo said.

In addition, the NTNU will send outstanding students to remote areas to help children with their studies during vacations, and will launch a free online learning system and CD-ROMs to provide easier access to resources for students who need extra assistance, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for December advancing 37 points to end at 4,179, with 91,680 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for January gained 24 points to finish at 4,134, with 807 contracts traded, while March futures increased 23 points to close at 4,100 with 35 contracts changing hands.
June futures rose nine points to end at 4,049, with eight contract transactions, while September futures rose nine points to finish at 3,872, with 14 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,142 for December, 4,110 for January, 4,077 for March, 4,040 for June and 3,863 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 29.89 points to finish at 4,225.07, on turnover of NT$40.04 billion (US$1.19 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures rose 2.1 points to close at 154.2, with 5,254 contracts traded, while January TE futures increased 1.15 points to finish at 151.2, with 66 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.
December TF futures gained 12.2 points to finish at 519, with 4,312 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures increased 12.4 points to finish at 515, with 63 contracts traded.
March TF futures rose 12.8 points to end at 505.8, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Meeting on investigation into Chaoliao gas leak to be held Dec. 9

TEXT.P: A meeting will be held in Chaoliao village in the southern county of Kaohsiung Dec. 9 to explain to residents the results of official investigations into a gas leak that occurred at the beginning of the month, village chief Wu Chih-hui said Friday.

On Dec. 1, more than 80 students and teachers at Chaoliao Junior High School, which is located just south of the Ta Fa Industrial District, were sent to hospital for treatment for nausea and dizziness after the gas leak during morning classes.
The victims, which were put on intravenous drips and placed under observation, did not suffer any serious effects, according to the hospital.

Kaohsiung County's Environmental Protection Bureau and other related agencies sent personnel to the site of the suspected gas leak to trace its source immediately after being notified of the matter Dec. 1.

Village residents had planned to visit the Ta Fa Industrial District's service center that day to demand an explanation for the gas leak but decided to postpone the move after being promised that the Dec. 9 meeting will explain the results of the investigations by the Executive Yuan's Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Development Bureau, Wu said.
At the meeting, the authorities will also outline the steps they will take to increase monitoring to avoid any such incidents in the future, according to Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.001 to close at NT$33.549.
A total of US$482 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.550 and fluctuated between NT$33.472 and NT$33.612.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Ducks' may not be ready for 2009 World Games: official

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City government might not be able to introduce amphibious tourist "duck boats" before the World Games next year, a city official said Friday.
"The plan to introduce two 'duck boats' before the July 16-26 World Games next year may run into difficulty, " said city Transportation Bureau Director Wang Kuo-tsai.

Wang noted that his bureau has appropriated nearly NT$60 million (US$1.8 million) to introduce the boats to diversify the leisure activities for residents of Kaohsiung, a city which features a river, sea and harbor.
The bureau had originally hoped that the boats could be introduced in June to boost tourism during the World Games period.
But he said that the plan to build two "duck boats" are not going well, meaning it will be "very difficult to introduce them before the World Games opens July 16."

Tours in the "ducks, " modeled after a World War II amphibious landing vehicle, have been popular in Singapore and cities around the United States, including Boston and Baltimore, which is why the city believes they will boost tourism there.
The bureau first opened a tender for the "ducks" Nov. 26, but nobody came forward, and the bureau was forced to open a second tender Dec. 4 that will close on Dec. 8.
Transportation officials said that if the tender goes smoothly this time, the boats will take seven months to build and additional time will be needed for inspection.
The officials said that the captain of the boat should have both bus and vessel operating licenses, and that the "duck" should also pass the inspections required for both ships and vehicles.
The bureau intends to buy two "duck boats, " with each accommodating 30 passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 29.89 points to close at 4,225.07.

Finishing lower for the fourth consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,213.07 and fluctuated between 4,261.32 and 4,190.02 during trading. A total of 2.78 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$40.04 billion (US$1.2 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 2.55 percent. Cement stocks declined 2.43 percent, construction issues dropped 0.97 percent, machinery and electronics shares were down 0.85 percent, paper and pulp issues decreased 0.79 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares and textile stocks both declined 0.43 percent.
Banking and financial shares gained ground, advancing 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 911 to 410, with 288 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$2.19 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mother who lost son counsels other victims' parents to forgive

TEXT.P: A single mother whose only son was killed at the age of 17 and once was obsessed with getting revenge is now more forgiving and advises others facing similar predicaments to "forgive others so you can spare yourself."

Mrs. You from the northeastern city of Yilan, whose husband died of an illness 10 years ago and whose son was killed at a barbecue nine years ago, was directing her message at the parents of the victim of a campus murder in 1998.

With the convicted assailant, former National Tsinghua University graduate student Hung Hsiao-huei, released Thursday after spending nearly 11 years in jail for murdering classmate and love rival Hsu Chia-chen, You has advised Hsu's parents to "forgive Hung to allow yourselves to live."
You said she spent three years in living hell after her son was stabbed to death by a 15-year-old youth surnamed Yang in a free-for-all.
During those years, she recalled, she was so distracted that she once dumped rice into the toilet as she was preparing to cook it.

She said she would also open the door late at night upon "hearing something outside, " but never saw her son there. When she repeated the behavior for weeks, relatives from her mother's side of the family took her to her mother's home to live to prevent accidents from occurring.
You also admitted that she hid knives and pesticide in her purse when appearing in court as a witness during Yang's trial, hoping to kill him first and then herself.
In another of her obsessive acts, You bought four child-sized figures made of resin home and changed the clothes of the four boy models every day, pretending they were her son.

None of those actions helped reduce You's thirst for revenge until one day three years ago when a voice from within asked her, "if your son was the killer, would you hope for forgiveness from the victim's family?"

Those words awakened You like a thunderbolt. The next morning, she visited Chiu Sung-shan, a volunteer with a victims protection association in Yilan and directly asked Chiu, "has the boy fared well in jail?"
You began writing regularly to Yang, her son's killer. She even traveled from Yilan to the southern port city of Kaohsiung to pay him a visit in prison.
When Yang asked her to hug him, You said, she broke down and wept and acceded to Yang's request. At that moment, she said, she felt as though her son was back.
Gradually, she gave the figure models away as well as all the clothes left by her son. She also put away all photos of her deceased son while continuing to write Yang letters.

Last year, when Yang was released on parole, the young man called her, telling her that he would look for a job to earn some money to support his family. You, nevertheless, encouraged him to return to school.
Recalling four years ago when he received a letter from You, Yang said he was shocked to learn that the mother of his victim was visiting him.
He said he was absolutely unprepared as You visited on the same day he received the letter and was numb and speechless when he first saw her.
Presently a college student, Yang said he now has two mothers to take care of, vowing that he will take good care of You throughout his life to compensate her for her loss.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's forex reserves hit US$280 billion

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$280.69 billion as of the end of November, the Taipei-based Central Bank of the Republic of China reported Friday.

The figure represents an increase of US$2.53 billion over the previous month's level and leaves Taiwan with the fourth highest foreign reserves of any country in the world, behind China, Japan and Russia, central bank officials said.

The officials attributed the increase to interest earned on foreign exchange reserve investments and the appreciation of some of its reserve currencies, such as the euro and the Japanese yen, relative to the U.S. dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Website of pandas from mainland China launched in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A website of Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, the pair of giant pandas that is expected to arrive in Taipei this month as a sign of warming ties between Taiwan and China, was launched by the Taipei City Zoo on Friday.

Taipei City Education Department Director Wu Ching-shan said at the website's launching ceremony that the Taipei City Zoo has made all the necessary preparations to receive the pair of endangered animals, including setting up a website for them.

"We have video links on the website for people to watch the precious documentaries about the everyday life of giant pandas in general," said Wu. "We hope to enhance people's understanding about these lovely creatures."
The website address is: http://www.zoo.gov.tw/panda/english/index.htm

Photographs of the two animals can be seen on the website, which also includes an introduction on the concepts and methods of animal protection. Activities arranged by the Taipei City Zoo can also be found on the website.
Taipei City Zoo Director Jason Yeh joined Wu in the website launch, with both men each holding a panda doll in their hands.
Yeh added that the giant pandas, like other wildlife, are being endangered by humans.
"Their habitats are being destroyed or threatened with destruction, " said Yeh. "We hope to help people understand wildlife and so be able to take appropriate actions to protect them."

The Straits Exchange Foundation's (SEF) vice chairman and secretary-general, Kao Koong-lian, said Thursday that the pair of giant pandas which China has promised to give to Taiwan is expected to be delivered to Taipei prior to Christmas Day.
It would take one month for the animals to undergo quarantine observation after arriving in Taiwan before they can be presented to zoo visitors, according to Kao.

Taiwan formally agreed to accept the pandas last month during a historic visit to Taipei by China's top negotiator on Taiwan affairs, Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

Chen and his Taiwanese counterpart, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, agreed during the visit that the two sides present each other with rare indigenous species of animals and plants as tokens of friendship and amity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to help salvage local DRAM industry

TEXT.P: Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. Chairman Frank Huang has called on the government to help the ailing DRAM (dynamic random access memory) industry survive, arguing that it is a strategic industry in Taiwan and its survival would influence the development of other technology sectors.
Oversupply and shrinking demand due to the global economic downturn have caused a drastic slump in DRAM prices and sent most players deep into the red.

If Taiwan's DRAM industry dies, South Korea will become the world's monopoly in the sector, a development that could have great impact on the future of high- technology industries and a consequence the government cannot afford to neglect, Huang, the chief of the nation's largest computer memory chipmaker warned Thursday on the sidelines of a technology forum in Taipei.
"As a result, prices of all the PC and consumer electronic products in the world would be determined by South Korea because DRAM components are the core of all the products," Huang explained.
Taiwan and South Korea are the only two DRAM manufacturing countries in the world, Huang said.
Taiwan currently has four major DRAM chipmakers which have been in the red for more than one and half years, owing NT$400 billion (US$11.6 billion) in debt at the end of September this year.

The government is mulling measures bailing out the sector for fear that leaving it alone would trigger nationwide financial turmoil, including the possibility of putting some 20,000 workers in the industry out of jobs.

Since Taiwan's electronics industry has been one of the most competitive industrial sectors in the country, the government should take measures to save the DRAM industry so that the competitiveness of the island's electronics and PC industries can be maintained, he said.

The survival of Taiwan's DRAM industry will also benefit downstream companies, Huang noted. For example, laptop maker ASUSTeK Computer Inc. has said that with cooperative ties with local DRAM manufacturers, the company is able to cut transport costs and enjoy the convenience of speedy product delivery and other benefits, Huang noted.
He did not specify what the government should do, but insisted something should be done efficiently and with the lowest cost.

Huang expressed hope that the government would help consolidate the strategic partnership among Taiwan's Powerchip, Rexchip Electronics Corp and Japan's Elpida Memory Inc, and assist with the merger among Taiwan's Inotera Memories Inc, Nanya Technology Corp and the U.S. Micron Technology Inc. to enable local DRAM companies to become more competitive through integration and globalization.

Meanwhile, Huang said that given the sharp depreciation of the South Korean won, Taiwan particularly needs to take measures to salvage the DRAM industry when it is in a disadvantaged position in a competition with South Korea, in terms of DRAM exports.
Besides DRAM production, Taiwan and South Korea are competing fiercely in TFT- LCD panel production, according to an economic official Friday in response to Huang's remarks.

Acknowledging the importance of the DRAM industry in Taiwan, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has formed a task force aimed at providing guidance and assistance for the industry, said the official who spoke on condition of anonynimity.

The official said that the ministry will focus its efforts on helping DRAM companies conduct industrial upgrade through enhancing research and development capabilities in order to raise their competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's railway welcomes first 'green' station

TEXT.P: Taiwan's railway system has inaugurated its first "green" station, which will provide transportation services with state-of-the-art, eco-friendly design and technologies, senior administrators said Friday.

At a ceremony to celebrate the inauguration of the renovated Dalin Station in the southern county of Chiayi, Taiwan Railways Administration Director-General Frank Fan praised the station as a "pastiche of history and modernity."

The station's old building, which was preserved in the renovation project, was built in 1903 under Japanese colonial rule, while the new "green" service complex is equipped with all kinds of eco-friendly technology.

Lauding it as "the most novel, most beautiful, most user-friendly" station among the 200 or so train stations in Taiwan, Fan said the complex is a 100-percent "green building" that not only fully relies on natural ventilation and natural light, but also recycles rainwater and converts sunlight into electricity.

Meanwhile, Fan continued, to reduce the pollution caused by the station itself and railway operations, the station is also equipped with noise reducing units and air purifiers that can reduce the exhaust of diesel locomotives,

In addition, the new complex also adopted the "overpass station" design that places the service areas over the rails, both to reduce the area occupied and allow free access from both sides of the rails.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Legislature approves bill to issue consumption vouchers

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a bill Friday that authorizes the government to issue NT$3,600 (US$108) in consumption vouchers to Taiwan's citizens in an attempt to stimulate the country's slumping retail sector and boost the overall economy.

The plan, which will cost approximately NT$83.5 billion and boost 2009 gross domestic product growth by 0.64 percent if all the vouchers are used, was passed without much resistance given the ruling Kuomintang's two-thirds majority in the lawmaking body.

To finalize the voucher plan and ensure the vouchers can be distributed by the government's target date of Jan. 18, the Cabinet must still submit a consumption voucher budget bill -- needed to secure funding for the program -- to the legislature by Dec. 8 at noon.
The bill must then be approved by related legislative committees by Dec. 22 and the full legislature by Dec. 26 for the program to go forward and meet the distribution deadline.
Should the budget bill be passed, as is expected, the vouchers would first be issued on Jan. 18, a week before the Lunar New Year holiday, and then after the holiday until March 31.
The vouchers will be valid for use until Sept. 30, 2009, and retailers must claim reimbursement for the vouchers by Oct. 31, 2009.

Prior to Friday's vote on the bill's contents, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party pushed its own alternative measure, which called for the distribution of NT$3,800 in cash, instead of vouchers, to Taiwan's citizens.
Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng called a meeting between KMT and DPP lawmakers to try and bridge the gap between the two measures, without success.

All Taiwanese citizens, with the exception of those living abroad without an identity card, local registration or residency rights, as well as their foreign spouses will be eligible to receive NT$3,600 in vouchers.

Those born by the end of March 2009 who have household registrations as citizens of the Republic of China will be eligible for the program, according to one of a set of resolutions attached to the bill.
Critics of the bill have argued that the voucher program will have potentially high administrative costs, including the cost of printing a voucher that is hard to counterfeit.
To contain these expenses, another resolution attached to the bill stipulated that administrative costs could not exceed 3 percent of the special budget earmarked for the program.

The Executive Yuan proposed the last month as a way to pump money into Taiwan's flagging retail sector. The vouchers must be used to purchase goods locally and cannot be deposited as savings in banks or exchanged for cash.
Those who donate their coupons to charity, however, will be entitled to a tax deduction.
The consumption vouchers are just one of a number of measures the government has proposed to boost the local economy, which contracted in the third quarter by 1.02 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fugitive gunman escorted back to Taiwan from the Philippines

TEXT.P: An infamous gunman and drug trafficker who fled Taiwan 14 years ago was escorted back home from the Philippines Friday, police said.
Chen Kuan-yuan, 52, was arrested by Taiwan police in 1993 for smuggling heroin into the country from Thailand and possessing firearms, according to the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB).
Chen fled to Southeast Asia using a fake passport in 1994, before the Kaohsiung District Court sentenced him in absentia to eight years and two months in prison, CIB officials said.
In November 1998, Chen was arrested in the Philippines for threatening others with a gun, and has since been held by Filipino authorities, the officials said.

Efforts by Taiwanese police to have Chen sent back to the country was unsuccessful until recently, after a model for cooperation between the two sides' law enforcement agencies was established, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Silk Road exhibition opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: More than 150 works of art and relics unearthed in Xinjiang province, China, including the "Loulan Beauty" mummy, will be displayed in Taipei to showcase the cultural diversity of the Silk Road, the exhibition curators said Friday.

Titled "Legends of the Silk Road--Treasures from Xinjiang, " the exhibition will give Taiwan people an idea of the cultures that converged on the ancient trade route, said Huang Yung-chuan, director of the National Museum of History where the exhibition will be staged.

The works of art, well preserved thanks to the dry climate in western China, have great value in terms of academic study on the trade, transportation and Chinese-Western exchanges on the Silk Road, Hang said at a press conference. They will also allow a glimpse into diverse ethnic civilizations and traditions, such as ancient funeral customs, he added.
The most eye-catching exhibit is the "Loulan Beauty" mummy that dates back 3,800 years, he said.

The mummy is a female between 40 and 45 years of age and of Indo-European descent. She was unearthed lying on her side as though in sleep, a tuft of hair falling across her head and ragged moccasins on her feet, and is considered once of the best preserved mummies ever found.
The mummy was discovered in the 1980s in the ancient Loulan region along China's Silk Road in Xinjiang province.

Since then, she has only been on display once outside China -- in Japan, according to Aierken Mijiti, standing deputy-director of the Cultural Heritage Bureau of Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region which is providing the exhibits.

"Through the current exhibition, we hope the distance between Xinjiang and Taiwan would be narrowed, and that the Taiwanese people would have a better understanding of Xinjiang province and the cultures of the Silk Road," he said.
The exhibition will also include pre-Qin metal vessels, textiles dating back to the Han Dynasty and later, funeral objects found in the Xiaohe cemetery, and paintings on silk from the Tang Dynasty.
The Silk Road was a trade route opened up during the Western Han Dynasty (206 BC-24 AD) and it extended for over 7,000 kilometers to connect Asia and the Mediterranean region.
The Silk Road proved to be of great historical and cultural importance because of its geographical location and bustling business, and the interactions of different cultures and religions.

The museum divided the 150 items unearthed into five categories: The beauty of the Silk Road, The Traces of the Silk Road, The Wonders of the Silk Road, The Ancient Kingdoms of the Silk Road and The Gods of the Silk Road.
The exhibition will be held from December 6 to March 15 next year at the National Museum of History.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bisphenol A may be listed potentially toxic substance in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) is planning to officially list bisphenol A (BPA) as a potentially toxic substance in light of increased public concern that it may pose a health risk to humans, especially infants, an official said Friday.

After BPA is listed as a potentially toxic substance, manufacturers that use the chemical in their products will be required to file a declaration with the EPA, according to Wu Wen-chuan, deputy chief of the EPA's Department of Environmental Sanitation and Toxic Substance Management.
BPA has been placed on an EPA watch list since 2007.

The chemical is commonly found in certain hard plastic products, including polycarbonate (PC) baby bottles. It is thought to be an endocrine disruptor and has been proven harmful to animals in laboratory experiments, raising concerns that it could cause negative health effects in humans.

With health concerns over BPA increasing worldwide in recent years, Canada announced in April this year its intention to ban the import and sale of PC bottles containing BPA, making it the first country in the world to take action on the chemical, Wu pointed out.

While Japan has placed BPA on its list of possible endocrine disruptors, the United States has required the manufacturers, importers and processors of BPA- made products to submit related information to authorities, Wu said.
The European Union, meanwhile, has set a limit of 30 ppb for BPA emissions, Wu said.
According to Wu, as the metabolic systems of infants and young children are not as developed as adults, BPA consumption is likely to affect their reproductive system.
There have not been any reports of such incidents in Taiwan.

As BPA has not been banned in containers for baby use, Wu urged the public to avoid putting high-temperature liquids in these containers and discard containers that have cracked to reduce the risk that the chemical has been released into the food or beverage being consumed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Natural gas prices should be cut further: Consumers' Foundation

TEXT.P: Natural gas prices in Taiwan should be cut further even after a 2.99 percent drop announced earlier this week by the the state-run petroleum refiner, CPC Corp. Taiwan, the Consumers' Foundation suggested Friday.
Hsieh Tien-jen, chairman of the non-profit civil organization, said natural gas prices should have room for another 40 percent cut to reflect the international market price.
Hsieh also suggested that Taiwan follow in the U.S.' footsteps and print the current international natural gas price on receipts to keep consumers informed.

CPC on Tuesday announced its first adjustment of domestic natural gas prices since May 28, dropping the price by 2.99 percent on average. This translated into a price reduction of between NT$0.24 per cubic meter and NT$1.63 per cubic meter, depending on the category of natural gas user.
On May 28, CPC's natural gas price was raised by NT$3.85 per cubic meter from the average NT$13.46 per cubic meter due to skyrocketing international crude oil prices.

The price cut Tuesday, made retroactive to Dec. 1, was the biggest drop in natural gas prices announced by CPC since it was authorized to adjust prices. The announcement came as a surprise, as the company had initially said it would not lower natural gas prices until next month.
On Friday, CPC officials rebutted media reports that it was about to further slash natural gas prices by 7 percent, saying they were purely speculative.
CPC is allowed to adjust the price of natural gas within a range of 3 percent each month without government permission.

The company is currently discussing with the relevant authorities whether to lower the prices further considering that its natural gas department has recorded an accumulated loss of NT$35 billion (US$1.04 billion) this year due to import costs outstripping domestic prices, CPC Chairman Wenent Pan said.

Citing data showing that natural gas futures in New York plunged by 47 percent, from US$12.977 per MMbtu on July 7 to US$6.92 per MMbtu on Oct. 20, Hsieh said domestic natural gas prices should be reduced to the pre-May 28 level.
He also suggested that CPC review its operational performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fullest moon in 15 years expected on Dec. 12

TEXT.P: Taiwanese residents will have a chance to see a super full moon on Dec. 12, which will be visible in Taiwan at its fullest in 15 years, the Taipei Astronomical Museum said in a press release Friday.
The full moon is expected to rise from the east at 4: 31 p.m. Dec. 12 and fall on the west at 6:58 a.m. Dec. 13, the museum said.
The moon will move on its oval orbit around the earth to the spot closest to the earth -- 356,566 kilometers in distance -- at 6 a.m. Dec. 13.
For people who miss a chance to see the moon this year, they will have to wait until Nov. 14, 2016 to see a full moon bigger and brighter than this one, the museum said.
Meanwhile, local sky watchers may also expect the approach of the Geminid meteor shower next week, which will fly pass the earth at 7 a.m. on Dec. 14.
The maximum meteor volume will reach 120 units per hour, and the shower will fly pass at a speed of 35 kilometers per second, according to the city-run museum.
The meteor shower can be observed between Dec. 7-17, and if the sky is clear, observers may have the chance to see the passing of brighter meteors, the museum said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local areas' public works projects will be launched in time

TEXT.P: With a NT$58.3 billion (US$1.75 billion) infrastructure expansion project in an economic stimulus package put in place by the central government, local governments are confident that construction of public works projects in their area will be launched by the end of this year, Public Construction Commission Minister Frank Fan said Friday.

Fan made the remarks at a news conference held following a meeting earlier Friday with Premier Liu Chao-shiuan. Also present at the meeting were government officials from 11 local areas, where the launch of public works projects have lagged behind that of Taiwan's 14 other cities and counties.
According to Fan, Liu encouraged the local governments to closely cooperate with the Executive Yuan in completing construction of their projects so as to help stimulate Taiwan's economy.
At present, an average 72.09 percent of all the public construction projects nationwide -- 6,733 cases out of a total of 9,340 -- are under construction, Fan said.
As of early December, only the offshore Kinmen and Lienchiang counties have fully launched construction of their 11 and five projects, respectively, Fan noted.

However, the 11 local cities and counties -- including Yilan, Hsinchu, Taitung, Nantou, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Changhua, Taipei, Yunlin, Pingtung counties and Chiayi City -- have each failed to reach a 75 percent construction rate, Fan said.

Fan pointed out that Pingtung County in southern Taiwan has registered the lowest rate of 2.45 percent, but deputy magistrate Chung Chia-pin asserted during the meeting that all the county's public construction projects will be kicked off by late this month as slated.
The minister said that budgets earmarked for the local governments to carry out the task will be returned to the national coffers in due process if they fail to meet the year-end deadline.
Later Friday, Chung clarified that the Pintung County's construction rate has hit 22.34 percent -- or 168 cases under construction out of a total of 752 projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA develops new varieties of rice, cabbage

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) presented Friday new varieties of rice and cabbage that it said are more environmentally friendly and more adaptable to warm temperatures.

According to Chen Jung-wu, director of the Taichung District Agricultural Research and Extension Station (TDARES) under the COA, unhusked rice grains usually have fine spikes called awns attached to them.

He said that the awns often cause air pollution and cause rice workers to develop problems such as skin irritations during the milling of the rice. As a result, during the harvesting period, people living near rice mills have to close their doors and windows tightly, he added.
However, after years of effort, the TDARES in central Taiwan has succeeded in creating Taiwan's first rice variety without awns, he said.
"Thanks to the new variety, named "Taichung 193, " not only the quality of the product, but also people's living environment has improved," Chen said.

Although the crops of the new rice variety in some regions were poor and it is not very resistant to blight, the research team is working on improvements and is trying to develop new awn-free varieties, he said.
Moreover, the TDARES has also developed a new variety of cabbage, a common vegetable in Taiwan, that is more resistant to warm temperatures, Chen said.

He added that the most popular cabbage variety in Taiwan, which has a market share of 70 percent, does not thrive well in high temperatures. To meet the market demand in summer, farmers have been forced to grow cabbages at high altitudes.

To solve problems of high prime cost and warmer temperatures, the TDARES in December 2007 developed the "Taichung 1" cabbage variety that has proved to be more resistant to high temperatures and is expected to help stabilize cabbage harvests at low altitudes in late summer, fall and winter, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12th defendant named in former first family's money laundering case

TEXT.P: The Special Investigation Division of the Supreme Prosecutors Office on Friday listed a college classmate of former first lady Wu Shu-jen as a defendant for allegedly helping Wu with money laundering, increasing the number of defendants in the case to 12.

Prosecutor Chen Yun-nan, director of the division, confirmed that his division had summoned Wu's former classmate Tsai Mei-li for questioning as a defendant in the case, but said Tsai begged out of the session because she was ill.

Tsai's two brothers -- Tsai Ming-che and Tsai Ming-chieh -- have already been listed as defendants in the case for allegedly serving as proxies in helping the former first family launder money abroad.

In addition to Wu, three other members of the former first family -- former President Chen Shui-bian, son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui- ching -- have all been listed as chief defendants in the money laundering case.

Others listed as defendants include the former first lady's elder brother Wu Ching-mao, his wife Chen Chun-ying, former Mega Financial Holding Co. Chairman Cheng Shen-chih, Yuanta Securities board member Tu Li-ping, and former Presidential Office cashier Chen Chen-hui.
None of those listed as defendants in the case have been indicted on charges related to money laundering, as at this stage in the investigation they are still only viewed as suspects.
Wu Ching-mao was released Nov. 28 on NT$2 million (US$59,580) bail after he had been held in custody for 53 days to prevent possible collusion among the defendants and witnesses.

Prosecutors who examined the information provided by judicial authorities of Singapore about an account owned by Wu Ching-mao believe they have enough evidence to suspect that Tsai Mei-li and her brothers helped the former first lady transfer millions of U. S. dollars illegally to her brother's account with South Africa's Standard Bank in Singapore through their bank accounts in Hong Kong.
Prosecutors found that they money was later wired to a Swiss bank account held by the son and daughter-in-law of the former president and his wife.

Before listing Tsai Mei-li as a defendant, the prosecutors questioned her four times. On Sept. 25, they searched her residence and office for possible evidence. Her brother Tsai Ming-che has been held in custody since Oct. 2.

In addition to their alleged violations of laws against money laundering, Chen Shui-bian and his wife also face investigation on charges of embezzling state affairs funds of the Presidential Office and accepting bribes during the former president's two terms between 2000 and 2008.
With the permission of the Taipei District Court, the Special Investigation Division has detained the former president since Nov. 12, after interrogating him for six hours a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nanjing culture show kicks off in Taipei County

TEXT.P: An art and culture show featuring China's Nanjing City kicked off in Taipei County Friday, as part of a cross-strait cultural exchange effort.
The Taipei county government said the event includes six performances being staged Friday to Monday by a children's art group, a drama group and a Shaoxing opera group from Nanjing City.

In addition, a photo gallery will allow the public to get a sense of Nanjing City's historical cultures, while a textile show will display the city's famous Yun Jin (Cloud embroidery) designs and techniques until Dec. 18.
A weaving machine the height of a two-story building, which was used to make clothing with the Cloud embroidery design, is on exhibition at County Hall.
The other events are being staged at the county's cultural center, a county government official said.

The show was organized by Taipei County's Cultural Affairs Bureau under a memorandum of understanding signed by Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei and Nanjing City Mayor Jiang Hongkun in July to pave the way for exchanges in art, trade, and agriculture.
Nanjing City Deputy Mayor Chen Gang said the city has rich cultural resources, as it has a 2,470-year history and served as the capital of China during six different dynasties.
Liu Jien, head of a visiting cultural delegation of about 140 members from Nanjing City, said the cultural exchanges will help close the gap between the people on both sides.
In mid-November, several groups from Taipei County performed in Nanjing City, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$47 billion to be set aside for facelift of old school buildings

TEXT.P: The government will spend NT$47 billion (US$1.4 billion) over the next four years to repair or reinforce run-down school buildings throughout the country, Minister of Education Cheng Jei-cheng said Friday.

According to Cheng, the old school building renovation program will form a critical part of a major infrastructure construction project designed by the Executive Yuan to help spur domestic demand amid the current global economic recession.
Under the program, 5,250 dilapidated elementary and junior high school classrooms and 980 senior and vocational high school classrooms will be renovated.
Meanwhile, 2,045 other classrooms will be reinforced to enhance their ability to resist earthquakes.

Given the government's limited budget, Cheng said, the ministry will appropriate NT$2.5 billion to repair elementary and junior high school classrooms and another NT$700 million to revamp senior and vocational high school classrooms in 2009, the first year of the project.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer prices stabilizing in Taiwan: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Consumer prices in Taiwan have stabilized and may even be on the decline, as the consumer price index (CPI) fell month-on-month by 1.08 percent in November and wholesale prices fell at an even faster clip, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Friday.

According to the report, the CPI stood at 106.74 in November, 1.08 percent lower than in October and 1.88 percent higher than in the same month last year. The year-on-year rise was the lowest since September 2007, it said.
The report attributed the latest weakness in prices to declines in crude oil and grain prices in the international market.
Reductions in domestic fuel and liquefied natural gas prices, overseas tour package costs and food products made from wheat and soybean, also steadied prices last month.
The wholesale price index (WPI) stood at 104.94 in November, sliding 5.31 percent from the previous month's level and 4.95-percent year-on-year, the first fall after rising for 36 consecutive months.
Because of higher inflation earlier in the year, the average WPI in the first 11 months of the year grew by 6.63 percent compared with the same period in 2007, the DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Patients with heart disease urged to undergo artery checkup

TEXT.P: Patients with heart disease in Taiwan should have a checkup as early as possible to find out whether they have coronary artery disease, a doctor with Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Keelung said Friday.
Wu Kuan-chun, a diagnostic radiologist, pointed out that heart disease is one of the top 10 causes of death in Taiwan, ranking fourth after cancer, accidents and chronic liver disease.

Wu cited statistics as showing that 80 percent of those who died of heart disease in Taiwan died because of coronary artery stenosis -- the abnormal constriction of a coronary artery, and that 30 percent of them died after suffering their first heart attacks.

As a precautionary measure, patients with heart disease should get a three- dimensional CT (computed tomography) scan as soon as possible, he said, adding that the 64-slice computed tomography can have an accuracy rate of 99 percent.

Coronary artery disease usually begins when hard cholesterol substances, known as plaques, are deposited within a coronary artery. The plaques in the coronary arteries can cause a tiny clot to form, which can obstruct the flow of blood to the heart muscle producing chest pain or trigger a heart attack or sudden death.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pandas to get speedy customs clearance: Taipei Zoo

TEXT.P: A pair of giant pandas will get speedy customs clearance upon arrival in Taiwan from China, the Taipei Zoo said Friday.

Zoo Director Jason Yeh said as soon as the plane carrying the two pandas -- Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan -- lands at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, customs officials will examine the quarantine papers before giving the green light for their entry.
Yeh said a motorcade will escort the two pandas to the zoo, which is expected to take one hour, to cut the discomfort of their long trip to the minimum.
An official of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) announced a day earlier that the two pandas will arrive before Christmas.
Yeh said that if the pandas could come before Christmas, then they might make their debut in front of the public before the Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan. 26.
"The SEF and the ARATS have chosen two dates for the delivery prior to Dec. 24, but have yet to make a final decision," Yeh said.
He also said the zoo has formed a team, including two senior animal feeding staff and 18 veterinarians and assistants, to take care of the pandas.
"After the zoo learns of the exact date of delivery, it will send two animal feeding staff two weeks in advance to Sichuan to have close contact with the two pandas," he added.
This is because the pandas have a sharp sense of smell and the staff would like to nurture a relationship with the animals to facilitate their care in the zoo.
The zoo estimates that the two pandas will consume between 40 kilograms and 80 kgs. of bamboo shoots a day, and the zoo is planting more bamboo.
The zoo will allocate NT$1.02 million annually for the bamboo expenses, he added.
China first promised to send the two pandas as a gift to Taiwan during a meeting between the-then Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and Chinese leader Hu Jintao in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing urged to approve Amway China employees' Taiwan tour plan

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) wrote to its Chinese counterpart Friday seeking its assistance in pushing the Chinese government to approve a planned visit to Taiwan next year by Amway China Co.'s management and sales staff.

Some 13,000 employees from the U.S.-based direct selling company's China operations are set to take a cruise to Taiwan next March, which is expected to give a badly needed shot in the arm to the island's tourism industry.

However, Amway's Taiwan subsidiary sought the SEF's help Thursday as the Chinese government reportedly is unwilling to approve the Amway China staff's travel plans because the Chinese employees will come from all parts of the country, not just the designated 13 provinces whose residents are now allowed to make pleasure trips to Taiwan.

In its message to the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), the SEF said the Amway China staff will mainly attend an advanced personnel training camp during their stay in Taiwan.
Moreover, the SEF said Taiwan is only a stop in the Amway staff's planned overseas package tour which will also take them to Japan and other destinations.
Against this backdrop, the SEF said the Amway staff's Taiwan travel plan should not be subject to the restrictions of a cross-strait agreement on Chinese citizens' sightseeing trips to Taiwan.

According to an accord signed by the heads of the two quasi-official intermediary bodies -- SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yulin -- in June in Beijing, Taiwan will admit up to 3,000 Chinese tourists per day and China will allow residents in 13 specified municipalities and provinces to make pleasure trips to Taiwan.

Stressing that the Amway group's Taiwan travel plan will contribute significantly to cross-strait civilian exchanges, the SEF wrote in its letter that Taiwan has approved the Amway's plan on a case-by-case basis.
"We look forward to your assistance in coordinating an approval by relevant mainland agencies as soon as possible to facilitate the smooth proceeding of the travel plan," the SEF wrote.
According to the original plan, Amway China employees will visit in several groups on cruise liners from Shanghai to Keelung Harbor and Taichung Harbor.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF head assures Japan there is no Taiwan-China economic threat
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/08 22:56:37 (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China are independent economic entities within the World Trade Organization (WTO) and will not become one economy that could pose a threat to Japan, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) chairman, Chiang Pin-kung, said in Tokyo Friday.

Although one of President Ma Ying-jeou's policies is to build closer economic ties and ultimately ink a comprehensive economic cooperation agreement (CECA) with China, Chiang said, Taiwan and China will not integrate into one economic entity because they are independent WTO members that each hold negotiations on an equal footing under the WTO framework.

"It is a totally different case from that of Hong Kong and China, which signed a closer economic partnership agreement (CEPA) with each other in line with Beijing's 'one-country, two systems' formula," Chiang said.
While Taiwan hopes to boost economic development through cooperation with China, there is no need for Japan to worry about the possibility of a Taiwan- China economic threat, he stressed.

Chiang made the remarks during a meeting held at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan to explain to Japanese political figures and media the recent developments in cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

The SEF and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- the two intermediary bodies in charge of cross-strait negotiations -- have agreed to deal with practical economic issues before complex political matters, Chiang said.
"It would be a long time before Taiwan and China could start political talks, " he said, adding that "clinching a CECA with China is currently one of Taiwan's long-term goals."
Mainland China and Hong Kong absorb about 40 percent of Taiwan's exports, while the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and Japan take some 15 percent and 7 percent, respectively, he said.

Meanwhile, the question of whether Taiwan is allowed to take part in the 2009 annual conference of the World Health Assembly in May as an observer will serve as a test of Taiwan-China relations, which have showed improvements over the past six months, he said.
"If Taiwan continues to be excluded from the WHA annual meeting due to Beijing's interference, the Taiwan people will be very hurt," he said.
Stating that Taiwan is eager to sign a free trade agreement or an economic partnership agreement with Japan, he called on the Japanese government to respond soon to Taiwan's overtures.

Chiang left for Japan Thursday on a three-day visit with the aim of explaining the recent developments in Taiwan-China relations to Japanese figures and Taiwanese expatriates there and to make arrangements for a visit by ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung to Japan next week.
Japan has long been a close ally of Taiwan in the region.

Before his departure from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Thursday, the SEF chief noted that Taiwan-China ties have improved significantly since Ma assumed office in May and that a visit to Taipei last month by ARATS President Chen Yunlin had further boosted bilateral ties.

Taiwanese officials have said that the island's closer relations with China will not jeopardize Taiwan's relations with other countries, but rather would benefit the region by fostering peace and stability.
In a follow-up to their historic encounter in June in Beijing, Chiang and Chen inked four cooperation pacts during their second meeting in Taipei last month.

The agreements, slated to take effect from Dec. 15, will allow for the expansion of direct weekend charter flights between the two sides into a daily service, and the launch of direct shipping and postal links. An agreement to cooperate on food safety control was also inked.
Chiang expressed confidence Thursday that the four pacts will benefit both sides of the Taiwan Strait, particularly the accords on the establishment of direct shipping and air travel links.

DOC.HEADLINE: HKTDC opens branch in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong Trade Development Council (HKTDC) will promote cooperation among small- and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) in Taiwan, Hong Kong and China to tap into the vast Chinese market, the head of the council's Taipei office said Friday.
Perry Fung made the pledge at a cocktail reception marking the opening of the HKTDC Taiwan office, which will formally become operational early next year.

Noting that China already has a middle-class population of 230 million, Fung said the Chinese consumer market is worth developing and that there is ample room for SMEs in the three Chinese-speaking societies to cooperate in exploring such an immense opportunity.

Senior HKTDC executives also traveled to Taipei to attend the opening reception, which saw the attendance of many Taiwanese trade promoters and business managers, including Wang Chih-kang, chairman of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
Addressing the occasion, HKTDC Chairman Jack So said capital, commodity and manpower exchanges among Taiwan, China and Hong Kong will get ever closer in the future.
Against this backdrop, So said the HKTDC decided to open a branch in Taipei to facilitate further cooperation.

The HKTDC, a Hong Kong government-funded but unofficial organization, began considering opening a branch in Taiwan five years ago, but did not file an application until after the Kuomintang -- seen as more friendly toward China than the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration -- regained power in Taiwan in May this year.

After Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs approved the HKTDC application in October, the Hong Kong group sent Fung -- formerly the HKTDC Beijing office's top executive in charge of the northern China market -- to Taipei to prepare for the opening of the new office.
Taiwan's government has warmly welcomed the HKTDC's decision to establish a foothold in Taipei as it will facilitate bilateral trade and civic exchanges.
Hong Kong is Taiwan's fourth- largest trading partner after China, Japan and the United States.

According to customs statistics, Taiwan-Hong Kong trade totaled US$39.8 billion in 2007, accounting for 8.54 percent of Taiwan's overall foreign trade for the year. Of that amount, Taiwan's exports accounted for US$37.98 billion, or 15.4 percent of the country's total exports for the year, making Hong Kong Taiwan's second-largest export outlet after China.
At the same time, Hong Kong invested more than US$200 million in Taiwan, up 76 percent from 2006, while Taiwan's investment in Hong Kong for that year totaled about US$190 million.
In the first six months of this year, Hong Kong investment had already topped US$236 million, far exceeding its investment for the whole of 2007, according to official Taiwan government tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Red Cross signs post-quake reconstruction pact in Sichuan

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China signed a post-reconstruction agreement with its Chinese counterpart in Sichuan province Friday, according to a press release issued by the society in Taipei.

C.V. Chen, president of Taiwan's Red Cross Society, signed the agreement with Jiang Yiman, executive vice president of the Red Cross Society of China, in Yinxiu township, Wenchuan, one of the hardest hit areas in the May 12 quake.
Chen earlier visited a mass grave in Yinxiu, which was located at the epicenter of the magnitude-8.0 earthquake, to pay tribute to tens of thousands of victims of the devastating temblor.
Chen said the Red Cross Society arrived in the quake-stricken area with donations and relief supplies.

The society intends to spend NT$1.595 billion (US$47.89 million) in remote parts of Sichuan, Gansu and Shaanxi provinces to rebuild 44 schools, 43 health care facilities and one rehabilitation center for the disabled in the Aba Tibetan- Qiang Autonomous Region, Chen said.

He added that the Red Cross Society will also sponsor schooling for impoverished children in the affected areas, and work with nonprofit organizations in Taiwan and China to promote social service programs so as to help the underpriviledged people in the affected areas return to normal life.
It is estimated that 32,648 students and more than 1.5 million affected residents in Sichuan, Gansu and Shaanxi will benefit from the assistance, the press release said.

Official figures as of July 21, 2008, put the number of confirmed dead from the earthquake at 69,227, including 68,636 in Sichuan province. Another 374,176 were listed as injured, with 18,222 listed as missing.
The earthquake left about 4.8 million people homeless, according to official statistics, but that number could be as high as 11 million. Approximately 15 million people lived in the affected area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mother who lost son counsels other victims' parents to forgive

TEXT.P: A single mother whose only son was killed at the age of 17 and once was obsessed with getting revenge is now more forgiving and advises others facing similar predicaments to "forgive others so you can spare yourself."

Mrs. You from the northeastern city of Yilan, whose husband died of an illness 10 years ago and whose son was killed at a barbecue nine years ago, was directing her message at the parents of the victim of a campus murder in 1998.

With the convicted assailant, former National Tsinghua University graduate student Hung Hsiao-huei, released Thursday after spending nearly 11 years in jail for murdering classmate and love rival Hsu Chia-chen, You has advised Hsu's parents to "forgive Hung to allow yourselves to live."
You said she spent three years in living hell after her son was stabbed to death by a 15-year-old youth surnamed Yang in a free-for-all.
During those years, she recalled, she was so distracted that she once dumped rice into the toilet as she was preparing to cook it.

She said she would also open the door late at night upon "hearing something outside, " but never saw her son there. When she repeated the behavior for weeks, relatives from her mother's side of the family took her to her mother's home to live to prevent accidents from occurring.
You also admitted that she hid knives and pesticide in her purse when appearing in court as a witness during Yang's trial, hoping to kill him first and then herself.
In another of her obsessive acts, You bought four child-sized figures made of resin home and changed the clothes of the four boy models every day, pretending they were her son.

None of those actions helped reduce You's thirst for revenge until one day three years ago when a voice from within asked her, "if your son was the killer, would you hope for forgiveness from the victim's family?"

Those words awakened You like a thunderbolt. The next morning, she visited Chiu Sung-shan, a volunteer with a victims protection association in Yilan and directly asked Chiu, "has the boy fared well in jail?"
You began writing regularly to Yang, her son's killer. She even traveled from Yilan to the southern port city of Kaohsiung to pay him a visit in prison.
When Yang asked her to hug him, You said, she broke down and wept and acceded to Yang's request. At that moment, she said, she felt as though her son was back.
Gradually, she gave the figure models away as well as all the clothes left by her son. She also put away all photos of her deceased son while continuing to write Yang letters.

Last year, when Yang was released on parole, the young man called her, telling her that he would look for a job to earn some money to support his family. You, nevertheless, encouraged him to return to school.
Recalling four years ago when he received a letter from You, Yang said he was shocked to learn that the mother of his victim was visiting him.
He said he was absolutely unprepared as You visited on the same day he received the letter and was numb and speechless when he first saw her.
Presently a college student, Yang said he now has two mothers to take care of, vowing that he will take good care of You throughout his life to compensate her for her loss.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's forex reserves hit US$280 billion

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$280.69 billion as of the end of November, the Taipei-based Central Bank of the Republic of China reported Friday.

The figure represents an increase of US$2.53 billion over the previous month's level and leaves Taiwan with the fourth highest foreign reserves of any country in the world, behind China, Japan and Russia, central bank officials said.

The officials attributed the increase to interest earned on foreign exchange reserve investments and the appreciation of some of its reserve currencies, such as the euro and the Japanese yen, relative to the U.S. dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Website of pandas from mainland China launched in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A website of Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, the pair of giant pandas that is expected to arrive in Taipei this month as a sign of warming ties between Taiwan and China, was launched by the Taipei City Zoo on Friday.

Taipei City Education Department Director Wu Ching-shan said at the website's launching ceremony that the Taipei City Zoo has made all the necessary preparations to receive the pair of endangered animals, including setting up a website for them.

"We have video links on the website for people to watch the precious documentaries about the everyday life of giant pandas in general," said Wu. "We hope to enhance people's understanding about these lovely creatures."
The website address is: http://www.zoo.gov.tw/panda/english/index.htm

Photographs of the two animals can be seen on the website, which also includes an introduction on the concepts and methods of animal protection. Activities arranged by the Taipei City Zoo can also be found on the website.
Taipei City Zoo Director Jason Yeh joined Wu in the website launch, with both men each holding a panda doll in their hands.
Yeh added that the giant pandas, like other wildlife, are being endangered by humans.
"Their habitats are being destroyed or threatened with destruction, " said Yeh. "We hope to help people understand wildlife and so be able to take appropriate actions to protect them."

The Straits Exchange Foundation's (SEF) vice chairman and secretary-general, Kao Koong-lian, said Thursday that the pair of giant pandas which China has promised to give to Taiwan is expected to be delivered to Taipei prior to Christmas Day.
It would take one month for the animals to undergo quarantine observation after arriving in Taiwan before they can be presented to zoo visitors, according to Kao.

Taiwan formally agreed to accept the pandas last month during a historic visit to Taipei by China's top negotiator on Taiwan affairs, Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

Chen and his Taiwanese counterpart, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, agreed during the visit that the two sides present each other with rare indigenous species of animals and plants as tokens of friendship and amity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to help salvage local DRAM industry

TEXT.P: Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. Chairman Frank Huang has called on the government to help the ailing DRAM (dynamic random access memory) industry survive, arguing that it is a strategic industry in Taiwan and its survival would influence the development of other technology sectors.
Oversupply and shrinking demand due to the global economic downturn have caused a drastic slump in DRAM prices and sent most players deep into the red.

If Taiwan's DRAM industry dies, South Korea will become the world's monopoly in the sector, a development that could have great impact on the future of high- technology industries and a consequence the government cannot afford to neglect, Huang, the chief of the nation's largest computer memory chipmaker warned Thursday on the sidelines of a technology forum in Taipei.
"As a result, prices of all the PC and consumer electronic products in the world would be determined by South Korea because DRAM components are the core of all the products," Huang explained.
Taiwan and South Korea are the only two DRAM manufacturing countries in the world, Huang said.
Taiwan currently has four major DRAM chipmakers which have been in the red for more than one and half years, owing NT$400 billion (US$11.6 billion) in debt at the end of September this year.

The government is mulling measures bailing out the sector for fear that leaving it alone would trigger nationwide financial turmoil, including the possibility of putting some 20,000 workers in the industry out of jobs.

Since Taiwan's electronics industry has been one of the most competitive industrial sectors in the country, the government should take measures to save the DRAM industry so that the competitiveness of the island's electronics and PC industries can be maintained, he said.

The survival of Taiwan's DRAM industry will also benefit downstream companies, Huang noted. For example, laptop maker ASUSTeK Computer Inc. has said that with cooperative ties with local DRAM manufacturers, the company is able to cut transport costs and enjoy the convenience of speedy product delivery and other benefits, Huang noted.
He did not specify what the government should do, but insisted something should be done efficiently and with the lowest cost.

Huang expressed hope that the government would help consolidate the strategic partnership among Taiwan's Powerchip, Rexchip Electronics Corp and Japan's Elpida Memory Inc, and assist with the merger among Taiwan's Inotera Memories Inc, Nanya Technology Corp and the U.S. Micron Technology Inc. to enable local DRAM companies to become more competitive through integration and globalization.

Meanwhile, Huang said that given the sharp depreciation of the South Korean won, Taiwan particularly needs to take measures to salvage the DRAM industry when it is in a disadvantaged position in a competition with South Korea, in terms of DRAM exports.
Besides DRAM production, Taiwan and South Korea are competing fiercely in TFT- LCD panel production, according to an economic official Friday in response to Huang's remarks.

Acknowledging the importance of the DRAM industry in Taiwan, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has formed a task force aimed at providing guidance and assistance for the industry, said the official who spoke on condition of anonynimity.

The official said that the ministry will focus its efforts on helping DRAM companies conduct industrial upgrade through enhancing research and development capabilities in order to raise their competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's railway welcomes first 'green' station

TEXT.P: Taiwan's railway system has inaugurated its first "green" station, which will provide transportation services with state-of-the-art, eco-friendly design and technologies, senior administrators said Friday.

At a ceremony to celebrate the inauguration of the renovated Dalin Station in the southern county of Chiayi, Taiwan Railways Administration Director-General Frank Fan praised the station as a "pastiche of history and modernity."

The station's old building, which was preserved in the renovation project, was built in 1903 under Japanese colonial rule, while the new "green" service complex is equipped with all kinds of eco-friendly technology.

Lauding it as "the most novel, most beautiful, most user-friendly" station among the 200 or so train stations in Taiwan, Fan said the complex is a 100-percent "green building" that not only fully relies on natural ventilation and natural light, but also recycles rainwater and converts sunlight into electricity.

Meanwhile, Fan continued, to reduce the pollution caused by the station itself and railway operations, the station is also equipped with noise reducing units and air purifiers that can reduce the exhaust of diesel locomotives,

In addition, the new complex also adopted the "overpass station" design that places the service areas over the rails, both to reduce the area occupied and allow free access from both sides of the rails.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Legislature approves bill to issue consumption vouchers

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a bill Friday that authorizes the government to issue NT$3,600 (US$108) in consumption vouchers to Taiwan's citizens in an attempt to stimulate the country's slumping retail sector and boost the overall economy.

The plan, which will cost approximately NT$83.5 billion and boost 2009 gross domestic product growth by 0.64 percent if all the vouchers are used, was passed without much resistance given the ruling Kuomintang's two-thirds majority in the lawmaking body.

To finalize the voucher plan and ensure the vouchers can be distributed by the government's target date of Jan. 18, the Cabinet must still submit a consumption voucher budget bill -- needed to secure funding for the program -- to the legislature by Dec. 8 at noon.
The bill must then be approved by related legislative committees by Dec. 22 and the full legislature by Dec. 26 for the program to go forward and meet the distribution deadline.
Should the budget bill be passed, as is expected, the vouchers would first be issued on Jan. 18, a week before the Lunar New Year holiday, and then after the holiday until March 31.
The vouchers will be valid for use until Sept. 30, 2009, and retailers must claim reimbursement for the vouchers by Oct. 31, 2009.

Prior to Friday's vote on the bill's contents, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party pushed its own alternative measure, which called for the distribution of NT$3,800 in cash, instead of vouchers, to Taiwan's citizens.
Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng called a meeting between KMT and DPP lawmakers to try and bridge the gap between the two measures, without success.

All Taiwanese citizens, with the exception of those living abroad without an identity card, local registration or residency rights, as well as their foreign spouses will be eligible to receive NT$3,600 in vouchers.

Those born by the end of March 2009 who have household registrations as citizens of the Republic of China will be eligible for the program, according to one of a set of resolutions attached to the bill.
Critics of the bill have argued that the voucher program will have potentially high administrative costs, including the cost of printing a voucher that is hard to counterfeit.
To contain these expenses, another resolution attached to the bill stipulated that administrative costs could not exceed 3 percent of the special budget earmarked for the program.
