According to the WHO, the TDI is meant to help national authorities set safe limits in food for withdrawal purposes should melamine be detected as a result of intentional adulteration.
"We expect this could better guide the authorities in protecting the health of their public, " said WHO Director for Food Safety, Jorgen Schlundt, at the close of the WHO Expert Meeting.

The WHO Expert Meeting to review toxicological aspects of melamine and cyanuric acid, held in Ottawa, Canada, was attended by 21 international experts, including Kang Jaw-jou, professor of the Graduate Institute of Toxicology of the National Taiwan University.

Milk products imported from China have caused serious panic in Taiwan since September, as many foods, such as pre-mixed beverages, biscuits and creamers, were found to be contaminated with melamine due to Chinese food ingredients.
The DOH has announced overall bans on import of Chinese milk powder, vegetable- based proteins, ammonium bicarbonateVa leavening agent -- and protein powder.
At present, at least 19 local food ingredient importers and companies have expressed an intent to demand compensation from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA pleased to see partial settlement of boat collision dispute

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is gratified to see a settlement between the skipper of a Taiwanese recreational fishing boat and the Japan Coast Guard (JCG) over a collision dispute near the Tiaoyutai Islands in June this year, an official said Saturday.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen was responding to Japanese media reports that the JCG has agreed to pay NT$10.5 million (US$312,500) in damages to Ho Hung-yi, skipper of the Lienho recreational fishing boat that sank some six nautical miles southwest of the Tiaoyutais June 10 after being hit by a Japanese coast guard patrol vessel.

"We are glad to see the positive development in seeking a final solution to the incident, " Chen said, adding that the MOFA looks forward to continued Japanese efforts to resolve compensation claims from the passengers and crewmen of the ill-fated ship.

According to Chen, three lawyers retained by Ho came to terms with two lawyers representing the JCJ Friday after several months of intense negotiations over compensation for the skipper of the sunken vessel.
Ho said that although he was not fully satisfied with the amount, but he could not but accept it.

The Lienho sank after it collided with a JCG patrol vessel that was trying to chase it away from the disputed Tiaoyutai waters. Ho and his two crew members were detained by Japanese authorities for questioning after they and 13 Taiwanese recreational fishermen onboard were rescued by the JCG officers.
The 13 anglers returned to Taiwan June 11 and two crewmen returned June 12, while Ho, the last to be released, returned June 13.
The incident caused tensions between Taiwan and Japan, which thawed only after the JCG offered a formal apology to Ho June 20.
Negotiations for compensation terms got underway in August and culminated in an agreement Friday.
But the two sides need to negotiate further on compensation to the two other crewmen and 13 fishermen aboard the Lienho.
The uninhabited Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea are claimed by Taiwan, Japan and China.
The conflicting claims over the sovereignty of Tiaoyutais have complicated fishing disputes between Taiwan and Japan in waters near the islands.

Both sides held the 15th round of fishery talks in July 2005 to try to resolve persistent disputes, and both sides agreed to hold the next round of talks in March 2006, but the talks never took place.
Taiwanese fishing boats are often chased away by Japanese patrol vessels in the disputed waters, but collisions there are rare.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign medical degree holders threaten locals in job market

TEXT.P: Graduates of local medical schools have complained recently about the challenges they face from Taiwanese graduates of foreign medical schools, but Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Saturday the problem can only be resolved by revising the law.

Users of the Chinese-language Ptt Web site launched a debate earlier this year over a local hospital's hiring of Taiwanese graduates from medical schools in Poland and the Philippines as resident doctors in its emergency ward and surgical department.

The posters argued that some Polish medical schools have low admission thresholds for applicants, and have attracted an increasing number of Taiwanese students who could not gain admission to local medical schools because they failed tough entrance examinations.

With the Polish medical degree, the graduates are allowed to participate in Taiwan's national examinations to acquire a general physician's certification, with which they can apply for a job in local medical institutions.

Ptt users complained that the foreign degree holders were paid at a low wage of NT$50,000 (US$1,487) a month to serve in the surgical department, and this "cheap labor force" has posed a threat to physicians with local degrees in the employment market, they criticized.
Meanwhile, an anonymous physician serving at a hospital in central Taiwan recently sent a letter to the DOH minister's online mailbox criticizing the system.

The letter said that under Taiwan's existing regulations governing licensed physicians, foreign medical degree holders are entitled to participate in the national examination without having to pass a much more challenging screening of their academic performance by the Ministry of Education.
Having those physicians serve on medical front lines could jeopardize the country's medical treatment quality or even risk the precious life of patients, the physician argued.

In response to the complaint, DOH officials responsible for medical affairs admitted that the current law recognizes academic degrees offered by "developed countries and areas, " including the United States, Japan, Europe, Canada, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore and Hong Kong.
After Poland joined the European Union in 2004, many Taiwanese students pursuing a medical degree in the Philippines transferred to schools there, the officials said.

Although the DOH does not want to recognize the degrees and hopes to insist that the degree holders get practical training at local clinics and hospitals, and pass an academic screening before they can take the national physician certification examination, the decision can't be carried out without having the law amended, Yeh said.
The academic services-oriented Web site touts itself as an open and free place for students to exchange views and ideas in their professional fields through a bulletin board system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Snow falls on southern Taiwan mountain areas

TEXT.P: Snow fell Saturday on the South Cross-Island Highway that bridges the western and eastern parts of southern Taiwan -- a region that normally features a marine tropical climate.

The snowfall lasted for three hours, beginning at 10 a.m., on the highway section between Siangyang and Daguanshan, said a vendor surnamed Pan who sells tempura in Daguanshan at 2,700 meters above sea level.
Pan said she observed flurries at around 5 a.m. before the snowfall turned heavy five hours later and continued for three hours. She expected it would snow again later in the day.
Many residents in nearby areas flocked to the Daguanshan as early as Friday night in anticipation of seeing snow after cold rain fell in Taitung the previous day.

Taiwan is currently under the influence of a cold air mass from China. The Central Weather Bureau issued a low-temperature report Saturday, which predicted that temperatures along the northeastern coast and areas north of Chiayi County will drop to as low as 10 degrees Celsius Saturday night and early Sunday.

Snow also fell on Mt. Jade (known locally as Yushan) -- the highest peak in Northeast Asia -- earlier in the day. At 6 p.m. the snowfall was measured at 2 centimeters. It was the second time snow had fallen on the mountain this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young people should learn to share by volunteering: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou encouraged the country's young generation Saturday to develop a philosophy focused on "sharing" through volunteering, which he said would not only influence themselves and those in need, but also help forge global friendships for Taiwan.

Speaking at the inaugural meeting of the Regional Peace Volunteer Group as the group's honorary leader, Ma said that by serving as volunteers, people can help the underprivileged while learning to adapt to challenges.

Ma suggested that young people volunteer to share their time, wealth, health or life, such as making donations of money, blood or even organs, all of which he said will have an impact on their own lives and those of the beneficiaries.
In his speech, Ma made particular mention of Taiwan's remote towns and villages and encouraged young people to contribute to the deprived areas.
He suggested offering computer training to children there, which he said would not only narrow the digital gap between cities and towns but also change the lives of the children.

Meanwhile, Ma said Taiwan ranked among the top public welfare countries in the world. Over 10 percent of the population has donated blood, and the number of the country's volunteers in 2006 ranked fourth in the world and surpassed 100,000 in 2007 alone, the president said.

He also mentioned initiatives launched by World Vision Taiwan to adopt poor children in the world, as well as global disaster relief efforts by the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, saying that all these acts of good will "naturally" spread Taiwan's image, reputation and power, and helped bridge friendships between Taiwan and the rest of the world.

Therefore, he said, he will urge the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to launch more programs with a focus on humanitarian relief instead of " checkbook diplomacy, " in which Taiwan has tried to lure China's diplomatic allies to switch diplomatic recognition by providing large sums of money and aid.

The Regional Peace Volunteer Group was formed by the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission as well as civic groups such as the Red Cross Society of Republic of China and World Vision Taiwan, along with 750 youth volunteer representatives attending the convention earlier in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP-TSU civic meeting on national affairs slated for early 2009

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) announced Saturday their plan to jointly hold a civic conference on national affairs in early 2009 to discuss the economic, social and political issues faced by the country.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said the conference will be comprised of two sessions, to take place before and after the Chinese New Year holidays in late January.

While the session slated before the holidays will focus on the financial and economic situation and assistance for disadvantaged citizens, the one to be held after the holidays will address social reforms and possible changes to the government system, Tsai said.
An organizing committee formed by prestigious social elites will be set up by mid-December, she said.

On whether former President Lee Teng-hui -- the TSU's spiritual leader -- will attend the conference, TSU Chairman Huang Kun-huei said the matter will be decided by the organizing committee, which will be responsible for producing a list of potential participants.
According to Huang, the main purpose of the conference will be to address Taiwan's current economic problem to help the country through the crisis.

Accusing President Ma Ying-jeou of failing to set a clear direction in which he is leading the country after being in office for half a year, Huang said "strong sunlight" is now needed to bring Taiwan out of the "dark clouds looming over the country."

Agreeing with Huang, Tsai said with public resentment toward the Kuomintang administration mounting, the opposition should play the role of agenda setter and serve as a platform for the integration of public opinion.
The mechanism will ensure the people's voices are heard by the government and help complement the checks and balances in the government, Tsai said.
Asked if she has any plans to accept President Ma's offer for a meeting with her, Tsai said she has no intention of doing so because she has no idea what to discuss with the president.

However, Tsai said if the upcoming conference comes up with a substantive conclusion or a direction for national development, she will be "very happy to hold talks with President Ma" bringing along the conclusion.
Commenting on Tsai's remarks, an anonymous source in the KMT said Tsai's reaction to Ma's proposal shows that she is evading dialogue with him.

Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi, meanwhile, said Ma has raised the proposal because he believes direct dialogue with Tsai can help sort out differences between the ruling and opposition parties over major issues.
Wang said the civic conference being planned by the DPP and TSU is unnecessary because the Legislative Yuan already serves as a supervisory mechanism of the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Cape No.7' star wins Golden Horse best supporting actor honor

TEXT.P: Ma Ju-long, a veteran Taiwanese actor, was named Best Supporting Actor at the 45th Golden Horse Awards, considered the Oscars of Chinese-language films.
Ma was honored for his outstanding portrayal of a local politician in "Cape No. 7," a Taiwanese romantic comedy that has been a smash at the local box office.
Another Taiwanese movie star, Mei Fang, won the best supporting actress award, for her moving performance in the grown-up film "Orzboyz."
Suming Chiang, an Amis aboriginal musician, clinched the coveted Best New Performer award, for his brilliant performance in the film "Hopscotch."

Chiang said the award came as a big surprise to him. "I'm very lucky to be able to win in this 'lovely race' with a beautiful Japanese lady and a 'national treasure,'" an emotional Chiang said at the presentation ceremony.

The lead singer of a pop band beat two performers in the top grossing "Cape No.7" -- the film's leading actress Chie Tanaka of Japan and Johnny C.J. Lin, known as "national treasure" Mao Po in the film.

Meanwhile, "Cape No.7" captured two music awards -- the Best Original Film Score and the Best Original Song -- with its pleasing music and lyrical theme song "South of the Border." Composers Fred Lu and Lo Chi-yi said they appreciate ideas and concepts offered by the film's director, Wei Te-sheng, in the course of their music making.
The annual Golden Horse Awards are styled on the U.S. Academy Awards but are decided by a jury along with the lines of the Cannes film festival.

Hong Kong film "The Warlords, " with martial arts star Jet Li, leads this year's nominations at the awards that are being presented Saturday evening in a star- studded ceremony held in the central city of Taichung. "Cape No.7" followed with 10 nominations. The presentation ceremony is still ongoing as of the press time.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Cape No.7' name the Outstanding Taiwan Film of the Year

TEXT.P: The "Cape No.7," a Taiwanese romantic comedy that has been a smash at the local box office, was named the Outstanding Taiwan Film of the Year at the 45th Golden Horse Awards Saturday.
And the film's director, Wei Te-sheng, was honored as the Outstanding Taiwan Film Worker of the Year at the star-studded Golden Horse presentation ceremony held in the central city of Taichung.

The "Cape No.7," the second highest grossing film in Taiwan after Titanic, won 10 nominations in this year's Golden Horse Awards, second only to 11 nominations garnered by Hong Kong film "The Warlords."
The Golden Horse Awards are widely regarded as the Oscars of Chinese-language films.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK film 'The Warlords' named Golden Horse Best Feature Film

TEXT.P: Hong Kong film "The Warlords" that tells the story of a 19th century general set to become governor during the turbulent years of waning Qing dynasty was named the Best Feature Film at 45th Golden Horse Awards, regarded as the Oscars of Chinese-language films.
The film's director, Peter Chan Ho-Sun, captured the coveted best director award.

After receiving the trophy at a glitzy presentation ceremony held at the central city of Taichung, Chan said emotionally that the award is a hard-earned honor and that he appreciates all moviegoers whose generous support has bolstered the development of the film industry.

Taiwanese box office smash "Cape No.7" won a total of five awards -- beating all other entries in terms of number -- for best supporting actor, best original film score, best original song, the Outstanding Taiwanese Film of the Year and the Outstanding Taiwanese Filmmaker of the Year.

Suming Chiang, an Amis aboriginal singer, emerged as the real dark horse by defeating two strong competitors from the "Cape No.7" cast to clinch the Best New Performer Award. He was awarded for his role in "Hopscotch" which was also named the Best Short Film at the award ceremony.

A full list of the award winners: -- Best Feature Film -- The Warlords -- Best Director -- Peter Ho-Sun Chan, The Warlords --Best Leading Actor -- Zhang Han- yu, Assembly --Best Leading Actress -- Prudence Liew, True Women For Sale --Best Supporting Actor -- Ma Ju-Lung, Cape No.7 --Best Supporting Actress -- Mei Fang, Orzboyz --Best New Performer -- Suming Chiang, Hopscotch --Best Original Screenplay -- Tsai Tsung-Han and Tom Shu-Yu Lin, Winds of September -- Best Screenplay Adaption -- Liu Heng, Assembly -- Best Cinematography -- Cheng Siu- Keung, Sparrow -- Best Visual Effects -- Ng Yuen Fai, The Warlords --Best Art Direction -- Chao Shih-Hao, Parking --Best Makeup & Costume Design -- Luke Huang and Sai Com, Candy Rain --Best Action Choreography -- Li Chung-Chi, Connected --Best Original Film Score -- Fred Lu and Lo Chi-Yi, Cape No.7 --Best Original Film Song -- Cape No.7 --Best Film Editing -- Yau Chi-Wai, Connected --Best Sound Effect -- Steve Burgess, Missing --Best Short Film -- Hopscotch --Best Documentary -- Up The Yangtze --The Outstanding Taiwanese Film of the Year -- Cape No.7 --The Outstanding Taiwanese Filmmaker of the Year -- Wei Te- sheng

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 7, or the 10th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti- corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso- kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
2001: The opening ceremony of the 2001 Austronesian Cultural Festival is held at Peinan Park in Taitung City, with famed singer Chang Hui-mei giving a performance.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Cape No.7' star wins Golden Horse best supporting actor honor

TEXT.P: Ma Ju-long, a veteran Taiwanese actor, was named Best Supporting Actor at the 45th Golden Horse Awards, considered the Oscars of Chinese-language films.
Ma was honored for his outstanding portrayal of a local politician in "Cape No. 7," a Taiwanese romantic comedy that has been a smash at the local box office.
Another Taiwanese movie star, Mei Fang, won the best supporting actress award, for her moving performance in the grown-up film "Orzboyz."
Suming Chiang, an Amis aboriginal musician, clinched the coveted Best New Performer award, for his brilliant performance in the film "Hopscotch."

Chiang said the award came as a big surprise to him. "I'm very lucky to be able to win in this 'lovely race' with a beautiful Japanese lady and a 'national treasure,'" an emotional Chiang said at the presentation ceremony.

The lead singer of a pop band beat two performers in the top grossing "Cape No.7" -- the film's leading actress Chie Tanaka of Japan and Johnny C.J. Lin, known as "national treasure" Mao Po in the film.

Meanwhile, "Cape No.7" captured two music awards -- the Best Original Film Score and the Best Original Song -- with its pleasing music and lyrical theme song "South of the Border." Composers Fred Lu and Lo Chi-yi said they appreciate ideas and concepts offered by the film's director, Wei Te-sheng, in the course of their music making.
The annual Golden Horse Awards are styled on the U.S. Academy Awards but are decided by a jury along with the lines of the Cannes film festival.

Hong Kong film "The Warlords, " with martial arts star Jet Li, leads this year's nominations at the awards that are being presented Saturday evening in a star- studded ceremony held in the central city of Taichung. "Cape No.7" followed with 10 nominations. The presentation ceremony is still ongoing as of the press time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local synchronized swimmers fight to popularize sport in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Lali Shavelashvili worked her way through the old Soviet Union sports system to become an award-winning synchronized swimmer at the junior level, so when she arrived in Taiwan about 10 years ago, she was eager to pass on her knowledge and experience.

What she did not know but quickly discovered is that building a sports program in Taiwan is often a Herculean challenge, even for mainstream sports, which are plagued by a lack of funding, coaching and facilities.

In such an environment, a less recognized sport like synchronized swimming has even less of a chance to thrive, as Shavelashvili found out when she looked into booking an indoor pool suitable for the sport in northern Taiwan.
To her surprise, she could not find any because none existed -- at least none with the minimum 3-meter regulation depth.

Eventually she and a group of parents, who wanted their children to take up the sport to improve their health, made an arrangement with National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) in downtown Taipei to use its 2-meter deep indoor pool -- adequate to train teenagers but still not up to international standards.

Shavelashvili is convinced synchronized swimming is a good fit for Asians because success does not depend on having a specific body type, but her difficulty in finding a training facility only highlights the problems the sport has had in gaining recognition and traction locally.
Government indifference, the lack of a sports culture in Taiwan and insufficient funding along with limited facilities have all hindered the sport's growth.

Shavelashvili, who has taught synchronized swimming in northern Taiwan since marrying a Taiwanese man in 1999, is particularly vexed by a culture that forces young trainees to abandon the sport in favor of pursuing academic goals.
The reason for this, she explained to the Central News Agency, is that Taiwan's education system has failed to open channels for talented synchronized swimmers to develop a future in the field.
"It is heartbreaking but there's nothing I can do," she sighs.
A recent casualty of the system is Yang Yi-ju, one of Shavelashvili's students.

Yang is one of four teenage members of a local synchronized swimming team known as the "Silver Tsunami, " which has earned widespread applause around Taiwan for its dazzling performances since the foursome came together in 2004.

The group trains with Shavelashvili every Saturday at NTNU, but Yang, a senior at Keelung Girls High School, recently pulled out for six months to prepare for the university entrance exams that will decide her future.

While Yang may one day resume her training, her mother, reflecting the pragmatism of many Taiwanese parents in directing their children toward higher education and away from sports, nixed the idea of her daughter aspiring to represent her country in international competitions.
"That would be impossible. My daughter is fond of swimming, and the sport is a good habit to maintain, but it is too difficult to build a career around it," said Yang's mother Wang Shuei-li.
"She would have to practice almost 24 hours a day and if she eventually won some big competitions, what could she become in the future? Could she find a good job with her skills? " Wang wondered.

With fewer than 100 students participating in the sport in Taiwan at present, Wang's concerns are not unfounded, as Chen Chuan-min, an official in charge of grassroots training at the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council acknowledged.

Chen said the reality is that the government must invest its limited budget in sports in which Taiwan is competitive enough to win medals in significant competitions such as the Asian Games and the Olympics, meaning money, and potential coaching roles for athletes like Yang, will be hard to come by in synchronized swimming.

However, parents and youngsters involved in the sport unanimously laud it as a recreational pastime because it combines swimming, dance, and gymnastics, and builds advanced water skills, strength, endurance, flexibility and balance.

Like Shavelashvili, Vincent Shih from Taichung is committed to popularizing the sport in Taiwan, founding the Synchronized Swimming Association of Taiwan (SSAT) in 2001, and he believes the sport's benefits should make it attractive to local girls.

"In Taiwan there are no sports fit for girls to play, except for synchronized swimming, " because it demands flexibility and basic dancing skills. Injuries are rare because participants are always supported by water, Shih said.

Parents are now discovering the sport's virtues, enrolling their children in synchronized swimming courses because they believe the sport will improve their children's lung capacity while helping them overcome the fear of being in deep water, Shih said.

The association every Sunday runs organized synchronized swimming courses in Taipei -- at the NTNU pool of course -- and in Taichung. Russian Julia Startchenko serves as the chief coach and senior adviser to Taiwan's only organization dedicated to promoting the sport here.
Aside from the obvious fitness benefits, swimmers also develop a "different lifestyle, " said the 32-year-old Startchenko, who like Shavelashvili, began living in Taiwan after marrying a local.

She believes synchronized swimmers develop self-determination, self-esteem and self-expression. "They are confident in their lives and have the determination to achieve a goal, " she said while directing her students from poolside.

Driven by his enthusiasm, Shih has taken various initiatives to build a wider following for the sport in Taiwan, including trying to pave the way for young swimmers to continue the sport without concerns over the academic futures.

"While we have opened doors for those who are talented in the sport to enter a high school without the need to take the basic qualification examinations, we are working to prevail on a higher educational institute to take the talented athletes and allow them to continue their training," he added.

The government may lack any ambition to promote the sport, but Shih is confident Taiwan can break into the top three in synchronized swimming in Asia, behind China and Japan, if funding can be secured.

"We need at least NT$2 million a year to hire professional coaches, organize national competitions and send students to compete overseas to gain international experience. Right now, all we have is an annual subsidy of NT$240,000," Shih said.

Wang Tzi-wen, in charge of civil sports organization affairs at the Sports Bureau under the Ministry of Education said the ministry could finance plans to send students to competitions abroad, if the activity's organizer submits a "complete proposal."
Any subsidy, however, would only range between NT$50,000 and NT$100,000 per project. "It might not help a lot," Wang acknowledges.

Parents have expressed their frustrations in appealing to the government for funding, but Shavelashvili believes that government help is still necessary to establish proper facilities and offer relevant training courses in school if the sport is to thrive.
While many barriers continue to exist that argue against a bright future for synchronized swimming in Taiwan, the sport's faithful are not about to give up.

Wei Shih-ting, a 14-year-old junior high school student who is learning advanced synchronized swimming skills from Startchenko and her sister Helen, has her sites set on the biggest prize, regardless of what sports authorities may think.
"I want to be the country's first athlete to compete in the Olympics in the synchronized swimming event, " she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
KMT chairman departs for Japan to cement bilateral ties

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and his KMT delegation departed for Japan Sunday for a week-long visit aimed at cementing bilateral relations with Tokyo.
It marked the first time the KMT chairman has headed to Japan to promote party- to-party exchanges since the KMT came to power in May.
During the visit, Wu and his team are expected to meet with leaders of major political parties in Japan and several senior politicians who have assumed important government positions.
Noting that President Ma Ying-jeou is attaching great importance to the trip, Wu told the media prior to his departure that the president asked him to pass on some messages to the Japanese side.
One of them, Wu said, was that in view of the "special partnership" Taiwan and Japan have maintained, the two sides should spare no effort to further bolster bilateral ties.

Taiwan and Japan are very close to each other geographically, share many common interests and have deep historical links, with bilateral trade amounting to US$60 billion and more than 2.5 million visitors traveling between the countries per year, Wu quoted Ma as saying the day before.

Wu said that although Taiwan cannot relinquish its sovereignty claim over the disputed Tiaoyutais, a group of islets in the East China Sea claimed by both sides along with China, the president believes that Taiwan and Japan "can put aside the dispute and move toward pursuing their common interests, like fishery cooperation."

Wu said Japan may suffer some losses as a transportation hub after direct air and shipping links between Taiwan and China are developed, but that overall Japan will continue to benefit from closer Taiwan-China exchanges.

For example, he said, a great number of Taiwanese enterprises have purchased machinery and production equipment from Japan and then exported their products to China, allowing both Taiwan and Japan to prosper from the triangular relationship.
"Taiwan and Japan can work together to crack China's vast market," he said.

One of the key members of Wu's delegation is former Taiwan representative in Japan Hsu Shui-teh. Wu said Hsu will contribute a lot to the visit because he has maintained close connections with Japanese politicians and has clout in bilateral Taiwan-Japan relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Grown-up orphans return to celebrate founder's 100th birthday

TEXT.P: Nearly 800 former orphans have returned to their common home, the Liouguei Christian Orphanage, over the past two days to celebrate the 100th birthday of orphanage founder, Reverend Yang Hsu, known in Taiwan as "the father of indigenous orphans."

Among the well-wishers were public functionaries, including local-level government officials, teachers and policemen and policewomen, all of whom were raised at the church-orphanage founded by Yang in the mountains of Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan.

At a concert held in Kaohsiung County Saturday night, physically challenged foot and mouth painter Yang En-dian, who was raised by Yang and his Atayal wife from infancy after she was brought to the orphanage in a basket in March 1974, said "my heart has always been at the orphanage, which is my home forever."

Yang En-dian was born without arms and later abandoned by her parents. Believing that the baby was "sent by the Lord, " Reverend Yang named the infant "Yang En- dian, " meaning "grace and benevolence from God."
Little did he knew that the child would develop a legendary friendship with then-President Chiang Ching-kuo, who reportedly visited the orphanage six times despite its remote location.

Chiang developed a special attachment to the child and arranged for her to receive surgery in Taipei to help straighten her spine and allow her to stand unaided. He even arranged for her to learn Chinese brush painting and calligraphy.

The child became a celebrity after a picture of her and President Chiang was used on a postage stamp. Yang En-dian did not let the late president down and grew up to earn her own living by selling her paintings. A courageous artist, she now leads a happy and ordinary life as a mother and a wife.

Chiang saw to it that the church-orphanage be helped financially after learning that Yang and her wife, along with 20-odd "little soldiers, " developed the land in the backwater mountainous area in Liouguei in 1964 in order to accommodate an ever-extending family.
When Yang and his wife arrived, there was nothing there. "All I saw were aboriginal people that looked like my wife," Yang recalled.
The couple made their church a home for indigenous Liouguei children who had no food and no money to pay for school.

As Yang and his wife became renowned for their philanthropy, and their names spread to the people of neighboring townships such as Marlin and Taoyuan, they had to enlarge the church to cope with the additional orphans.

No one disputes the claim that Yang has 1,000 children -- given the great number of indigenous orphans and homeless youths that the Shandong, mainland China-born Christian missionary and his wife have raised over the past 50 years.
The reverend's family is so large that his orphanage complex technically forms a small town in the Liouguei mountains, about a two-hour drive from Kaohsiung City.
Counting his achievements over the decades, Yang said receiving copies of records of merit or good deeds that were bestowed on "his children" is one of his most rewarding pleasures.

Among these achievers is Peter Chung, who graduated as the top student from the Marine Academy; Liu Ming-tsung, an army officer decorated by the Presidential Office for his outstanding performance; and Chou Pei-hung, who studied hard and passed the entrance examination for the prestigious National Taiwan University.

Also among the well-wishers was Rachel W.Y. Liang, a star from a popular CTC singing contest known as a Taiwan version of the British Pop Idol. Liang, in her early 20s, was sent to the church-orphanage with her younger sister after their Rukai father and Atayal mother died one after another about 10 years ago.

Both talented singers, Liang and her brother had been members of the orphanage's choir. She received special vocal training given by a Christian father from the United States and received financial aid from a U.S. church to help her complete college education.
At the age of 100, Father Yang said that with God's blessing, his duties are sweet and will never end.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global credit crisis tops list of crises concerning local people

TEXT.P: The collapse of investment bank Lehman Brothers, which triggered a global credit crunch, has been named by people in Taiwan as the most serious crisis of the past two years, a recent survey conducted by the John Tung Foundation (JTF) , a public welfare group, has found.

The survey, which attempted to determine how recent disasters were perceived by local residents and affected their lives, found that 46.8 percent of respondents identified "economic crisis" when asked what came to their mind when they heard the word "disaster."
Earthquakes, at 23.8 percent, and traffic accidents, at 11.2 percent, were the other types of calamities most identified as disasters.

As for the disasters over the past two years that made the biggest impression on local individuals, the credit crunch triggered by the collapse of Lehman Brothers was chosen by a majority (53.5 percent) of respondents.

Lehman Brothers declared bankruptcy on Sept. 15, 2008, creating further instability in financial markets and eventually sending already depressed stock markets plunging further. Taiwan's benchmark index has fallen 30 percent since mid-September.

The results of the survey, which was conducted by the foundation from Oct. 15 to Nov. 14 and obtained 8,738 valid responses, were presented at the 6th Union Congress of Psychotherapy and Mental Health in Taiwan being held Sunday.

Trailing behind the global credit crunch as crises that made a major impression on people were the discovery of melamine-tainted milk powder and non-dairy creamers in Taiwan, chosen by 20.8 percent of respondents, and the magnitude-8.0 earthquake that struck China's Sichuan province in May, the choice of 16.3 percent of those surveyed.
Yeh Ya-hsing, the head of the foundation's mental health section, said the survey's results indicated that the fear of crisis stems primarily from concerns over the loss of life and property damage.

"People said they are concerned with the negative effects of crises on their everyday lives, " Yeh said. "Some said that if they were directly affected by a crisis, the psychological trauma would hurt them more than physical injuries."

The poll also asked the participants if they thought that the government's response to crises had been adequate, with 68.3 percent answering that they were not satisfied with the government's crisis management abilities.
"But 21.6 percent of the people surveyed said they still had high expectations that the government would respond well when a crisis did occur," Yeh said.
"This means that people still have hope in the government, and therefore, if it can actually handle crises, it will win back the confidence of the people," she said.

Yeh also pointed out that the foundation, whose main objective is the promotion of "health for all" in Taiwan, will compile the detailed results of the survey and make recommendations to the government on how to fine-tune its response to the global credit crisis and how to develop confidence building measures. enditem/ls

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to recover from financial crisis : President

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that he is confident that Taiwan will soon recover from the global financial "tsunami," not because of his administrative leadership, but because of his confidence in Taiwan's people.

"The people's resilience and persistence can help us tide over the difficulties, " Ma said in his address delivered Sunday at a ceremony held at Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School to mark the prestigious school's 110th founding anniversary.

Ma said his administration will create some 300,000 jobs in the following four years, with the first 100,000 being created within the next six months to help spark the slumping domestic economy, which has been inevitably affected by the global financial meltdown.

"We don't expect Taiwan to emerge unscathed from this current global financial crisis but hope at least that Taiwan will tide over the difficulties without sustaining major harm like it did the last Asian economic crisis," Ma said.

He added that after fully guaranteeing deposits at all banks around the country in a bid to stabilize the domestic financial market, the administration has put forth a four-year, NT$500 billion (US$15.15 billion) economic stimulus plan to pull Taiwan out of its economic rut.

The plan features extra funding for new and old infrastructure development projects and the distribution of shopping vouchers worth some NT$80 billion, aimed at spurring consumption and reviving Taiwan's suffering retail sector.

In related news, Ma said at a discussion with members of the business and industrial community in the southern county of Pingtung earlier in the day that his campaign "check" of allowing the Kaohsiung MRT system to be expanded southward to Pingtung county has not "bounced."
"The development plan will be implemented once a more detailed assessment is completed," Ma promised.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poinsettia display brings Christmas flavor to Taipei Youth Park

TEXT.P: The Parks and Street Lights Office of the Taipei City government is holding an exhibition of poinsettia at the Taipei Youth Park, drawing crowds eager to see the traditional Christmas flower.

As Christmas nears, we will have a chance to view the many different species and designs of poinsettias here in Taipei, said local resident Judith Yeh, who brought her two sons and husband to see the exhibition.
The exhibition will run through Dec. 30 and is open from 8: 20 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. and from 1:30 p.m. to 4: 30 p.m.
According to the Taipei Youth Park, in order to highlight the different colors of the poinsettia leaves and their respective beauty, the exhibition displays them in three separate sections.

One section is devoted to displaying and describing the many different species of poinsettia. Another focuses on garden landscapes featuring poinsettias and the third section is comprised of Christmas accessories, such as decorations made from the flower.
Poinsettias are very popular at this time of the year, said Lee Jien-hsuen, a father of three.I'm here to select a few to decorate my home.

According to legend, poinsettias became associated with Christmas when a poor Mexican girl presented weeds as a gift to the Christ child as Christmas Eve services. As she lay the bouquet near the nativity scene, the weeds suddenly burst into red blooms, leading those there to believe they had witnessed a Christmas miracle.
Now, the perennial flowering shrubs that are native to Mexico, they are widely used as Christmas decorations.
Those interested in attending the exhibition can make their way to the Taipei Youth Park, located in the city's Wanhua district, on the number 12, 630, 212, 223, 670, 204, 249, and 205 city buses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers favor establishment of national vaccine fund

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have reached consensus that a national vaccine fund should be established to ensure a sufficient supply of vaccines in Taiwan, a KMT legislator said Sunday.

Chung Shao-ho, a KMT legislator from Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan, told reporters that the legislature's Health, Environment and Labor Committee is expected to complete the screening of amendments to the Communicable Diseases Control Act on Dec. 10.

The amendments, when adopted on the floor, will pave the way for the Cabinet- level Department of Health (DOH) to establish a national vaccine fund to stabilize the supply of various vaccines in Taiwan, Chung said.

Huang Sue-ying, a DPP legislator-at-large who introduced an amendment to provide for the establishment of the fund, also proposed another amendment, which would ask all members of the DOH's Advisory Committee on Communicable Disease Control to disclose their relationships with pharmaceutical companies to prevent possible irregularities in the procurement of vaccines for the fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan to finalize NT$85.7 billion voucher budget

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will meet Monday to finalize the NT$85.7 billion budget for its program to issue shopping vouchers to Taiwan's citizens.

A Cabinet official said the budget will then be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval, now that a bill to give the Executive Yuan a legal basis to formulate a budget for the program passed the legislature Friday.

Of the NT$85.7 billion earmarked for the program, NT$83 billion will go to finance the consumption vouchers and the remainder will cover expenses for the vouchers' printing, distribution and envelopes containing the vouchers, according to the official.
In order to answer the public's questions about the program, a hot line will be set up and operated around the clock, the official said.
Under the Executive Yuan's plan, NT$3,600 in vouchers will be handed out on Jan. 18, one week before the Chinese New Year, which is the traditional shopping season in Taiwan.
The government hopes that the vouchers, which can be used at all retail outlets around the country, will stimulate spending and boost Taiwan's slumping retail sector.

The official said the Cabinet is working on an arrangement with local shopping malls under which voucher users can get a discount if they pay for their purchases using a combination of vouchers and cash or credit card.
The approach would create a multiplier effect that would extend the economic impact of the program, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students end month-long sit-in with march

TEXT.P: A group of students paraded through the boulevard in front the Presidential Office in Taipei Sunday, carrying a coffin draped in national flag to underline their claims that human rights died in Taiwan.
The march caused traffic chaos but was otherwise peacefully.
Police followed the protesters and asked them--- three times as required by law--- to disperse because their protest has not been permitted but didn't bother to interrupt the parade.

The parade began from Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall where these students has staged a sit-in since early November and meandered through the Legislative Yuan, Executive Yuan, the Presidential Office before back to the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
A leader of the protesters said they will end their month-long sit-in protest Sunday night.
The sit-in was held to protest what they claimed the police's brutality toward protesters when Chinese top negotiator with Taiwan Chen Yunlin visited the island.
In a statement issued on Sunday, the students, who called themselves wild strawberries, asked the government to change the law to give people the full freedom to demonstrate.
They also asked the government to probe "the excessive use of force" by police against protesters during Chen's visit.
"Although we will end our protest tonight, we only leave temporarily, and will be back whenever it is necessary." the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lovers in Hualien rush to get married before Year of Rat is out

TEXT.P: The eastern Taiwan County of Hualien recorded a considerable increase in the number of couples getting married in November, compared with the same month of 2007, according to statistics released Sunday by the Civil Affairs Department of the county government.
Officials at the department said they recorded 178 couples getting married in Hualien County during November, a rise of 20 percent over November 2007, which saw 149 couples joining in wedlock.

According to the officials, the increase was probably due to the fact that many of the couples rushed to get married before the Year of the Rat -- based on the Chinese lunar calendar -- runs out in late January 2009.

They said that many of the couples who preferred to get married in 2008 probably felt uneasy about the superstition that the next lunar year happens to have two first spring days -- one on the 10th day of the first lunar month and the other on the 21st day of the 12th month -- and therefore is not a good year for weddings.
It is believed by some people that women who get married in a lunar year with two first spring days would become widowed soon.

Meanwhile, the bridal shops and wedding dress stores in Hualien have reported brisk business despite the ongoing economic recession. Some store owners said they expect another wave of weddings taking place in the county before the Year of the Rat runs out on Jan. 26, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF chairman to brief overseas Taiwanese bizmen in Manila

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung is scheduled to leave for the Philippines Monday to brief Taiwanese businessmen from Asia at a meeting in Manila on the new development in the relationship between Taiwan and China.

According to a news release issued by the SEF, Chiang has been invited by the Asia Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce to give a keynote speech on cross-Taiwan Strait relations at its board meeting being held in Manila.

Chiang will explain the Kuomintang government's policy toward mainland China, the historic significance of his recent talks with his Chinese counterpart -- Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- and the results of their talks in Taipei.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations responsible for handling cross-strait engagements in the absence of official relations.
While in Manila, Chiang will also meet with leaders of the local Taiwanese community and pay a courtesy call on the Manila mayor, according to the SEF.

At the second round of their talks held in Taipei Nov. 3-7, Chiang and Chen signed four agreements to allow direct flights, shipping links, postal services and the establishment of a food safety mechanism between the two sides.
Chen was the highest-ranking Chinese official to have set foot on Taiwan since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949.
The four agreements are expected to become effective automatically this month although it appears there is hardly enough time for the legislature to go through the screening process.

According to the Act Governing Relations between the Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, an agreement signed between the SEF and the ARATS will become effective automatically if the legislature has not acted to sanction it within one month after it was sent to its Procedure Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 8, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: The opening of a Cabinet extraordinary meeting. Date and Time: 9 a.m., Monday, Dec. 8, 2008. Place: No. 1, ZhongXiao East Road, Section 1, Taipei city, the Executive Yuan. Host and/or main speakers: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan. Organizers: The Executive Yuan. Press Contact: 3356-6500.

With fewer than 100 students participating in the sport in Taiwan at present, Wang's concerns are not unfounded, as Chen Chuan-min, an official in charge of grassroots training at the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council acknowledged.

Chen said the reality is that the government must invest its limited budget in sports in which Taiwan is competitive enough to win medals in significant competitions such as the Asian Games and the Olympics, meaning money, and potential coaching roles for athletes like Yang, will be hard to come by in synchronized swimming.

However, parents and youngsters involved in the sport unanimously laud it as a recreational pastime because it combines swimming, dance, and gymnastics, and builds advanced water skills, strength, endurance, flexibility and balance.

Like Shavelashvili, Vincent Shih from Taichung is committed to popularizing the sport in Taiwan, founding the Synchronized Swimming Association of Taiwan (SSAT) in 2001, and he believes the sport's benefits should make it attractive to local girls.

"In Taiwan there are no sports fit for girls to play, except for synchronized swimming, " because it demands flexibility and basic dancing skills. Injuries are rare because participants are always supported by water, Shih said.

Parents are now discovering the sport's virtues, enrolling their children in synchronized swimming courses because they believe the sport will improve their children's lung capacity while helping them overcome the fear of being in deep water, Shih said.

The association every Sunday runs organized synchronized swimming courses in Taipei -- at the NTNU pool of course -- and in Taichung. Russian Julia Startchenko serves as the chief coach and senior adviser to Taiwan's only organization dedicated to promoting the sport here.
Aside from the obvious fitness benefits, swimmers also develop a "different lifestyle, " said the 32-year-old Startchenko, who like Shavelashvili, began living in Taiwan after marrying a local.

She believes synchronized swimmers develop self-determination, self-esteem and self-expression. "They are confident in their lives and have the determination to achieve a goal, " she said while directing her students from poolside.

Driven by his enthusiasm, Shih has taken various initiatives to build a wider following for the sport in Taiwan, including trying to pave the way for young swimmers to continue the sport without concerns over the academic futures.

"While we have opened doors for those who are talented in the sport to enter a high school without the need to take the basic qualification examinations, we are working to prevail on a higher educational institute to take the talented athletes and allow them to continue their training," he added.

The government may lack any ambition to promote the sport, but Shih is confident Taiwan can break into the top three in synchronized swimming in Asia, behind China and Japan, if funding can be secured.

"We need at least NT$2 million a year to hire professional coaches, organize national competitions and send students to compete overseas to gain international experience. Right now, all we have is an annual subsidy of NT$240,000," Shih said.

Wang Tzi-wen, in charge of civil sports organization affairs at the Sports Bureau under the Ministry of Education said the ministry could finance plans to send students to competitions abroad, if the activity's organizer submits a "complete proposal."
Any subsidy, however, would only range between NT$50,000 and NT$100,000 per project. "It might not help a lot," Wang acknowledges.

Parents have expressed their frustrations in appealing to the government for funding, but Shavelashvili believes that government help is still necessary to establish proper facilities and offer relevant training courses in school if the sport is to thrive.
While many barriers continue to exist that argue against a bright future for synchronized swimming in Taiwan, the sport's faithful are not about to give up.

Wei Shih-ting, a 14-year-old junior high school student who is learning advanced synchronized swimming skills from Startchenko and her sister Helen, has her sites set on the biggest prize, regardless of what sports authorities may think.
"I want to be the country's first athlete to compete in the Olympics in the synchronized swimming event, " she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
KMT chairman departs for Japan to cement bilateral ties

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and his KMT delegation departed for Japan Sunday for a week-long visit aimed at cementing bilateral relations with Tokyo.
It marked the first time the KMT chairman has headed to Japan to promote party- to-party exchanges since the KMT came to power in May.
During the visit, Wu and his team are expected to meet with leaders of major political parties in Japan and several senior politicians who have assumed important government positions.
Noting that President Ma Ying-jeou is attaching great importance to the trip, Wu told the media prior to his departure that the president asked him to pass on some messages to the Japanese side.
One of them, Wu said, was that in view of the "special partnership" Taiwan and Japan have maintained, the two sides should spare no effort to further bolster bilateral ties.

Taiwan and Japan are very close to each other geographically, share many common interests and have deep historical links, with bilateral trade amounting to US$60 billion and more than 2.5 million visitors traveling between the countries per year, Wu quoted Ma as saying the day before.

Wu said that although Taiwan cannot relinquish its sovereignty claim over the disputed Tiaoyutais, a group of islets in the East China Sea claimed by both sides along with China, the president believes that Taiwan and Japan "can put aside the dispute and move toward pursuing their common interests, like fishery cooperation."

Wu said Japan may suffer some losses as a transportation hub after direct air and shipping links between Taiwan and China are developed, but that overall Japan will continue to benefit from closer Taiwan-China exchanges.

For example, he said, a great number of Taiwanese enterprises have purchased machinery and production equipment from Japan and then exported their products to China, allowing both Taiwan and Japan to prosper from the triangular relationship.
"Taiwan and Japan can work together to crack China's vast market," he said.

One of the key members of Wu's delegation is former Taiwan representative in Japan Hsu Shui-teh. Wu said Hsu will contribute a lot to the visit because he has maintained close connections with Japanese politicians and has clout in bilateral Taiwan-Japan relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Grown-up orphans return to celebrate founder's 100th birthday

TEXT.P: Nearly 800 former orphans have returned to their common home, the Liouguei Christian Orphanage, over the past two days to celebrate the 100th birthday of orphanage founder, Reverend Yang Hsu, known in Taiwan as "the father of indigenous orphans."

Among the well-wishers were public functionaries, including local-level government officials, teachers and policemen and policewomen, all of whom were raised at the church-orphanage founded by Yang in the mountains of Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan.

At a concert held in Kaohsiung County Saturday night, physically challenged foot and mouth painter Yang En-dian, who was raised by Yang and his Atayal wife from infancy after she was brought to the orphanage in a basket in March 1974, said "my heart has always been at the orphanage, which is my home forever."

Yang En-dian was born without arms and later abandoned by her parents. Believing that the baby was "sent by the Lord, " Reverend Yang named the infant "Yang En- dian, " meaning "grace and benevolence from God."
Little did he knew that the child would develop a legendary friendship with then-President Chiang Ching-kuo, who reportedly visited the orphanage six times despite its remote location.

Chiang developed a special attachment to the child and arranged for her to receive surgery in Taipei to help straighten her spine and allow her to stand unaided. He even arranged for her to learn Chinese brush painting and calligraphy.

The child became a celebrity after a picture of her and President Chiang was used on a postage stamp. Yang En-dian did not let the late president down and grew up to earn her own living by selling her paintings. A courageous artist, she now leads a happy and ordinary life as a mother and a wife.

Chiang saw to it that the church-orphanage be helped financially after learning that Yang and her wife, along with 20-odd "little soldiers, " developed the land in the backwater mountainous area in Liouguei in 1964 in order to accommodate an ever-extending family.
When Yang and his wife arrived, there was nothing there. "All I saw were aboriginal people that looked like my wife," Yang recalled.
The couple made their church a home for indigenous Liouguei children who had no food and no money to pay for school.

As Yang and his wife became renowned for their philanthropy, and their names spread to the people of neighboring townships such as Marlin and Taoyuan, they had to enlarge the church to cope with the additional orphans.

No one disputes the claim that Yang has 1,000 children -- given the great number of indigenous orphans and homeless youths that the Shandong, mainland China-born Christian missionary and his wife have raised over the past 50 years.
The reverend's family is so large that his orphanage complex technically forms a small town in the Liouguei mountains, about a two-hour drive from Kaohsiung City.
Counting his achievements over the decades, Yang said receiving copies of records of merit or good deeds that were bestowed on "his children" is one of his most rewarding pleasures.

Among these achievers is Peter Chung, who graduated as the top student from the Marine Academy; Liu Ming-tsung, an army officer decorated by the Presidential Office for his outstanding performance; and Chou Pei-hung, who studied hard and passed the entrance examination for the prestigious National Taiwan University.

Also among the well-wishers was Rachel W.Y. Liang, a star from a popular CTC singing contest known as a Taiwan version of the British Pop Idol. Liang, in her early 20s, was sent to the church-orphanage with her younger sister after their Rukai father and Atayal mother died one after another about 10 years ago.

Both talented singers, Liang and her brother had been members of the orphanage's choir. She received special vocal training given by a Christian father from the United States and received financial aid from a U.S. church to help her complete college education.
At the age of 100, Father Yang said that with God's blessing, his duties are sweet and will never end.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global credit crisis tops list of crises concerning local people

TEXT.P: The collapse of investment bank Lehman Brothers, which triggered a global credit crunch, has been named by people in Taiwan as the most serious crisis of the past two years, a recent survey conducted by the John Tung Foundation (JTF) , a public welfare group, has found.

The survey, which attempted to determine how recent disasters were perceived by local residents and affected their lives, found that 46.8 percent of respondents identified "economic crisis" when asked what came to their mind when they heard the word "disaster."
Earthquakes, at 23.8 percent, and traffic accidents, at 11.2 percent, were the other types of calamities most identified as disasters.

As for the disasters over the past two years that made the biggest impression on local individuals, the credit crunch triggered by the collapse of Lehman Brothers was chosen by a majority (53.5 percent) of respondents.

Lehman Brothers declared bankruptcy on Sept. 15, 2008, creating further instability in financial markets and eventually sending already depressed stock markets plunging further. Taiwan's benchmark index has fallen 30 percent since mid-September.

The results of the survey, which was conducted by the foundation from Oct. 15 to Nov. 14 and obtained 8,738 valid responses, were presented at the 6th Union Congress of Psychotherapy and Mental Health in Taiwan being held Sunday.

Trailing behind the global credit crunch as crises that made a major impression on people were the discovery of melamine-tainted milk powder and non-dairy creamers in Taiwan, chosen by 20.8 percent of respondents, and the magnitude-8.0 earthquake that struck China's Sichuan province in May, the choice of 16.3 percent of those surveyed.
Yeh Ya-hsing, the head of the foundation's mental health section, said the survey's results indicated that the fear of crisis stems primarily from concerns over the loss of life and property damage.

"People said they are concerned with the negative effects of crises on their everyday lives, " Yeh said. "Some said that if they were directly affected by a crisis, the psychological trauma would hurt them more than physical injuries."

The poll also asked the participants if they thought that the government's response to crises had been adequate, with 68.3 percent answering that they were not satisfied with the government's crisis management abilities.
"But 21.6 percent of the people surveyed said they still had high expectations that the government would respond well when a crisis did occur," Yeh said.
"This means that people still have hope in the government, and therefore, if it can actually handle crises, it will win back the confidence of the people," she said.

Yeh also pointed out that the foundation, whose main objective is the promotion of "health for all" in Taiwan, will compile the detailed results of the survey and make recommendations to the government on how to fine-tune its response to the global credit crisis and how to develop confidence building measures. enditem/ls

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to recover from financial crisis : President

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that he is confident that Taiwan will soon recover from the global financial "tsunami," not because of his administrative leadership, but because of his confidence in Taiwan's people.

"The people's resilience and persistence can help us tide over the difficulties, " Ma said in his address delivered Sunday at a ceremony held at Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School to mark the prestigious school's 110th founding anniversary.

Ma said his administration will create some 300,000 jobs in the following four years, with the first 100,000 being created within the next six months to help spark the slumping domestic economy, which has been inevitably affected by the global financial meltdown.

"We don't expect Taiwan to emerge unscathed from this current global financial crisis but hope at least that Taiwan will tide over the difficulties without sustaining major harm like it did the last Asian economic crisis," Ma said.

He added that after fully guaranteeing deposits at all banks around the country in a bid to stabilize the domestic financial market, the administration has put forth a four-year, NT$500 billion (US$15.15 billion) economic stimulus plan to pull Taiwan out of its economic rut.

The plan features extra funding for new and old infrastructure development projects and the distribution of shopping vouchers worth some NT$80 billion, aimed at spurring consumption and reviving Taiwan's suffering retail sector.

In related news, Ma said at a discussion with members of the business and industrial community in the southern county of Pingtung earlier in the day that his campaign "check" of allowing the Kaohsiung MRT system to be expanded southward to Pingtung county has not "bounced."
"The development plan will be implemented once a more detailed assessment is completed," Ma promised.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poinsettia display brings Christmas flavor to Taipei Youth Park

TEXT.P: The Parks and Street Lights Office of the Taipei City government is holding an exhibition of poinsettia at the Taipei Youth Park, drawing crowds eager to see the traditional Christmas flower.

As Christmas nears, we will have a chance to view the many different species and designs of poinsettias here in Taipei, said local resident Judith Yeh, who brought her two sons and husband to see the exhibition.
The exhibition will run through Dec. 30 and is open from 8: 20 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. and from 1:30 p.m. to 4: 30 p.m.
According to the Taipei Youth Park, in order to highlight the different colors of the poinsettia leaves and their respective beauty, the exhibition displays them in three separate sections.

One section is devoted to displaying and describing the many different species of poinsettia. Another focuses on garden landscapes featuring poinsettias and the third section is comprised of Christmas accessories, such as decorations made from the flower.
Poinsettias are very popular at this time of the year, said Lee Jien-hsuen, a father of three.I'm here to select a few to decorate my home.

According to legend, poinsettias became associated with Christmas when a poor Mexican girl presented weeds as a gift to the Christ child as Christmas Eve services. As she lay the bouquet near the nativity scene, the weeds suddenly burst into red blooms, leading those there to believe they had witnessed a Christmas miracle.
Now, the perennial flowering shrubs that are native to Mexico, they are widely used as Christmas decorations.
Those interested in attending the exhibition can make their way to the Taipei Youth Park, located in the city's Wanhua district, on the number 12, 630, 212, 223, 670, 204, 249, and 205 city buses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers favor establishment of national vaccine fund

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have reached consensus that a national vaccine fund should be established to ensure a sufficient supply of vaccines in Taiwan, a KMT legislator said Sunday.

Chung Shao-ho, a KMT legislator from Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan, told reporters that the legislature's Health, Environment and Labor Committee is expected to complete the screening of amendments to the Communicable Diseases Control Act on Dec. 10.

The amendments, when adopted on the floor, will pave the way for the Cabinet- level Department of Health (DOH) to establish a national vaccine fund to stabilize the supply of various vaccines in Taiwan, Chung said.

Huang Sue-ying, a DPP legislator-at-large who introduced an amendment to provide for the establishment of the fund, also proposed another amendment, which would ask all members of the DOH's Advisory Committee on Communicable Disease Control to disclose their relationships with pharmaceutical companies to prevent possible irregularities in the procurement of vaccines for the fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan to finalize NT$85.7 billion voucher budget

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will meet Monday to finalize the NT$85.7 billion budget for its program to issue shopping vouchers to Taiwan's citizens.

A Cabinet official said the budget will then be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval, now that a bill to give the Executive Yuan a legal basis to formulate a budget for the program passed the legislature Friday.

Of the NT$85.7 billion earmarked for the program, NT$83 billion will go to finance the consumption vouchers and the remainder will cover expenses for the vouchers' printing, distribution and envelopes containing the vouchers, according to the official.
In order to answer the public's questions about the program, a hot line will be set up and operated around the clock, the official said.
Under the Executive Yuan's plan, NT$3,600 in vouchers will be handed out on Jan. 18, one week before the Chinese New Year, which is the traditional shopping season in Taiwan.
The government hopes that the vouchers, which can be used at all retail outlets around the country, will stimulate spending and boost Taiwan's slumping retail sector.

The official said the Cabinet is working on an arrangement with local shopping malls under which voucher users can get a discount if they pay for their purchases using a combination of vouchers and cash or credit card.
The approach would create a multiplier effect that would extend the economic impact of the program, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students end month-long sit-in with march

TEXT.P: A group of students paraded through the boulevard in front the Presidential Office in Taipei Sunday, carrying a coffin draped in national flag to underline their claims that human rights died in Taiwan.
The march caused traffic chaos but was otherwise peacefully.
Police followed the protesters and asked them--- three times as required by law--- to disperse because their protest has not been permitted but didn't bother to interrupt the parade.

The parade began from Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall where these students has staged a sit-in since early November and meandered through the Legislative Yuan, Executive Yuan, the Presidential Office before back to the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
A leader of the protesters said they will end their month-long sit-in protest Sunday night.
The sit-in was held to protest what they claimed the police's brutality toward protesters when Chinese top negotiator with Taiwan Chen Yunlin visited the island.
In a statement issued on Sunday, the students, who called themselves wild strawberries, asked the government to change the law to give people the full freedom to demonstrate.
They also asked the government to probe "the excessive use of force" by police against protesters during Chen's visit.
"Although we will end our protest tonight, we only leave temporarily, and will be back whenever it is necessary." the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lovers in Hualien rush to get married before Year of Rat is out

TEXT.P: The eastern Taiwan County of Hualien recorded a considerable increase in the number of couples getting married in November, compared with the same month of 2007, according to statistics released Sunday by the Civil Affairs Department of the county government.
Officials at the department said they recorded 178 couples getting married in Hualien County during November, a rise of 20 percent over November 2007, which saw 149 couples joining in wedlock.

According to the officials, the increase was probably due to the fact that many of the couples rushed to get married before the Year of the Rat -- based on the Chinese lunar calendar -- runs out in late January 2009.

They said that many of the couples who preferred to get married in 2008 probably felt uneasy about the superstition that the next lunar year happens to have two first spring days -- one on the 10th day of the first lunar month and the other on the 21st day of the 12th month -- and therefore is not a good year for weddings.
It is believed by some people that women who get married in a lunar year with two first spring days would become widowed soon.

Meanwhile, the bridal shops and wedding dress stores in Hualien have reported brisk business despite the ongoing economic recession. Some store owners said they expect another wave of weddings taking place in the county before the Year of the Rat runs out on Jan. 26, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF chairman to brief overseas Taiwanese bizmen in Manila

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung is scheduled to leave for the Philippines Monday to brief Taiwanese businessmen from Asia at a meeting in Manila on the new development in the relationship between Taiwan and China.

According to a news release issued by the SEF, Chiang has been invited by the Asia Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce to give a keynote speech on cross-Taiwan Strait relations at its board meeting being held in Manila.

Chiang will explain the Kuomintang government's policy toward mainland China, the historic significance of his recent talks with his Chinese counterpart -- Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- and the results of their talks in Taipei.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations responsible for handling cross-strait engagements in the absence of official relations.
While in Manila, Chiang will also meet with leaders of the local Taiwanese community and pay a courtesy call on the Manila mayor, according to the SEF.

At the second round of their talks held in Taipei Nov. 3-7, Chiang and Chen signed four agreements to allow direct flights, shipping links, postal services and the establishment of a food safety mechanism between the two sides.
Chen was the highest-ranking Chinese official to have set foot on Taiwan since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949.
The four agreements are expected to become effective automatically this month although it appears there is hardly enough time for the legislature to go through the screening process.

According to the Act Governing Relations between the Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, an agreement signed between the SEF and the ARATS will become effective automatically if the legislature has not acted to sanction it within one month after it was sent to its Procedure Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

The weighted price index lost 29.89 points, or 0.7 percent to close at 4,225.07 Friday.

The greenback was trading at NT$33.513 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.036 from Friday.
