DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 8, or the 11th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy- three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taipower ready to build nuke waste dump in Taipei county

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) said Monday that it will soon submit a water and soil conservation plan to the Taipei County Government for the construction of a new, dry nuclear waste dump for its First Nuclear Power Plant.

Once the Taipei County Government approves the water and soil conservation plan, Taipower will be able to start building the interim repository near the First Nuclear Power Plant for dry storage of its spent nuclear fuel rods, said Tu Yueh-yuan, chief engineer and Taipower spokesman.
The First Nuclear Power Plant, located in the county's coastal Shihmen township, has been operational since 1978 and is expected to be decommissioned in 2018, according to Tu.

He added that if the construction of the nuclear waste dump is postponed, Taiwan's electricity supply might be affected in the near future, as the existing dump for wet storage of spent fuel rods will be full by March 2010.
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) gave conditional approval in late August to Taipower to build the new dry-storage interim repository for spent fuel rods.

An EPA environmental impact assessment panel gave the green light on condition that Taipower promises not to make the repository a final disposal site and that the company "try to purchase" residential properties near the proposed dump site.

In addition, the panel suggested that a supervisory commission organized by residents be set up to monitor construction of the dump. The panel also stipulated that spent nuclear fuel rods could be stored in the planned repository for maximum of 40 years, after which Taipower would have to relocate the waste to a permanent disposal site.

As the current waste dump, located within the plant itself, can only store spent fuel from nuclear reactors for up to 30 years, Taipower must present a construction plan to the EPA for the new, 0.45-hectare spent fuel rod repository.
Taiwan has three nuclear power plants in operation, with a fourth under construction.

According to Huang Ching-tsun, director of the Radioactive Waste Management Bureau under the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council, the planned First Nuclear Power Plant waste repository will be equipped with 30 casks, each of which will have a storage capacity of 54 spent fuel rods.
Huang noted that by March 2010, when the First Nuclear Power Plant will be closed for an 18-month routine overhaul, 120 spent fuel rods will be removed from the plant's No. 1 reactor.

A total of 97,672 barrels of low-radiation waste, including spent fuel rods, produced by the three nuclear power plants before 1996 were stored in 23 trenches on Orchid Island, also known as Lanyu, off the southern coast of Taiwan.
The island stopped accepting additional nuclear waste in 1996 due to protests by local residents, and all waste generated since then has been stored at the power plants themselves.
Until a permanent repository is built at a location yet to be determined, all the spent fuel rods will remain in storage at the three plants, said Huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Social welfare budget 2nd-largest government expenditure: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that the government's social welfare budget will be its second-largest expenditure next year, behind only those for educational, scientific and cultural development.

Addressing the opening of an international forum on the welfare of people with disabilities, Ma said there are at present a total of 1.027 million people in Taiwan who are physically or mentally challenged, constituting 4.45 percent of the country's population.

With the number continuing to rise, Ma continued, the administration has decided to allocate a budget of NT$19.2 billion (US$581.82 million) next year to provide care for this group of disadvantaged people.
However, he went on, "the figure is still not enough to cover all the costs in this area and we will try our best to improve it."

Ma noted that a United Nations convention on the rights of people with disabilities is expected to be launched in two years, showing that protection of the welfare and rights of the physically and mentally challenged is now a global issue.
He added that although Taiwan is not a U.N. member, the Republic of China Constitution stipulates that the country's citizens should observe U.N. charters.
The international forum, titled "Proud to Be Myself -- Citizen Rights of Persons with Disabilities" is being sponsored by the non-profit Eden Social Welfare Foundation.
A total of 11 speakers, including eight from Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, Singapore, Sweden, South Korea and Thailand, are expected to deliver speeches at the two-day forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet plans to boost effectiveness of shopping vouchers: GIO

TEXT.P: Government Information Office Minister Vanessa Yea-ping Shih said Monday that the Executive Yuan wants to boost the effectiveness of the government-issued consumption vouchers by running a creativity contest on how best to issue the vouchers and by setting up a Web site that will provide consumers with information on discounts and sales.
Shih made the remarks shortly after the Cabinet finalized a proposal on the special budget needed to finance the consumption voucher program.

"We want to create more value for the consumption vouchers," said Shih, adding as an example that "some have suggested that discounts could be given to consumers who spend just one of their nine consumption vouchers at a time so that they will be encouraged to make nine separate purchases, thereby boosting consumption."

The current plan is to issue the NT$3,600 (US$108) to which each citizen is entitled in nine vouchers, and the government is hopeful that consumers will make additional cash or credit card purchases whenever they use the consumption vouchers.

Shih said the Government Information Office (GIO) wants to gather good ideas from the public on boosting the effectiveness of the program to help shop owners increase their sales volume, adding that a panel of judges will evaluate the ideas and select the best of them.

The GIO will announce further details about the contest later in the week, Shih went on, adding that prizes will be awarded to the winners. The GIO also hopes to obtain the rights from all entrants to publish their ideas, whether they are prize winners or not, so that individual shop owners can consider them. GIO staff said the prizes might be as much as NT$100,000.

Meanwhile, Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi pointed out that the current plan for the consumption vouchers is to issue each recipient with nine vouchers -- three with a face value of NT$200 and six with a face value of NT$500.

"If anyone has any better ideas, they should suggest them to the Ministry of the Interior, which will provide awards in return for the best ones, " Liao said after an Executive Yuan press conference on the finalization of the special budget proposal for financing the consumption vouchers.
"I want to encourage good ideas, " said Liao, adding, however, that the government does not want to offer any more than 10 vouchers per person in order to keep production costs down.

He also said that any combination of the face value for the vouchers must include one for NT$200 and one for NT$500 in order to boost the likelihood of shoppers spending additional cash along with the vouchers and thereby increasing their total spending.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei creates online `safety map' to expose dangerous spots

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government has recently created an online "safety map network" for citizens to report places in their communities that they believe are not safe areas in which to stay or walk through, the chairman of the non-profit organization that helped develop the map said Monday.

The map, available at http: //subweb.health.gov.tw/TaipeiSafety and devised with the help of the Hualien City-based Memory Space Institution (MSI), allows members of the public to monitor the safety of the communities in which they live, said MSI Chairman Lee Ming-hsien.

Each year, more than 700 students from elementary schools through universities lose their lives in accidents, including campus accidents, Lee said, citing statistics compiled by the Ministry of Education.
Lee reminded the public to stay alert to dangers such as traffic on campuses and elsewhere in their communities and to note areas that are unsafe.

He encouraged the public to photograph any such unsafe areas and upload the images to the Safety Map Web site to allow other users to see them. The information could also serve as reference for the city government during urban construction improvements, he added.

Seven city schools have already registered with the Web site, Lee went on, expressing hope that other residents all over the capital city will participate in the work to develop a safe living environment.
The non-profit MSI was founded in 2004 in Hualien City, eastern Taiwan, to promote the concept and the establishment of healthy cities, communities and schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: Computex Taipei 2009 to generate over US$25 billion in sales: TAITRA

TEXT.P: Next year's Computex Taipei 2009, which will be one of the world's leading information and communication technology (ICT) procurement platforms, with more than 40,000 overseas buyers, is expected to generate more than US$25 billion in sales, organizers said Monday at a press conference to announce the trade show.

"Computex Taipei never stops outperforming itself, " said Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) Vice President Walter Yeh, adding that with the success of the show in 2008, Computex Taipei 2009 will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) Halls 1, 2 and 3, the newly built Nangang Exhibition Hall and the Taipei International Convention Center, to show the world the latest technologies and products.

Yeh noted that the show, which will take place next June 2-6, will bring together possibly the greatest IT selection on earth, covering such categories as components and parts, data storage devices, software, computer systems, motherboards and add-on cards, communication products, peripherals, displays and digital entertainment products.

Organized by TAITRA and the Taipei Computer Association (TCA) , Computex Taipei is the second-largest computer trade show in the world after Germany's CeBIT, said Yeh, who added that "it is the procurement platform for hundreds of thousands of professional ICT buyers because it is where visions are realized and technologies are truly applied."
He pointed out that Computex Taipei does not show just product prototypes, but the actual products themselves.

In addition to the computer equipment, a further 1,800 vendors occupying around 4,800 booths -- compared to last year's 1,700 vendors and 4,481 booths -- will display products such as car electronic devices, IC applications, embedded products, medical electronics, auto ID, IP telecom, robots, digital signage and security.
"The great variety of products and technologies that will be on display underscores Computex Taipei's status as the world's most significant ICT procurement platform", Yeh said.

Computex Taipei 2009 will not only exhibit the best and the latest in ICT products, but will also stage a series of events ranging from forums to factory visits, from conferences to a buyer's night, hoping to help visitors better understand how the show has come such a long way and its critical role in the development of the ICT industry.

The new technology of WiMAX -- Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access -- will also be on display, said Yeh, adding that the technology has grown 314 percent over the past year and, with government backing, will connect more than 80 million users by 2013.

WiMax is still in the early development period, said TCA Deputy Secretary- General Chang Li, "so it has high growth potential, as deploying fiber for next- generation networks is an inevitable trend."

Chang said it is estimated that the overall communication equipment market will still enjoy moderate growth in 2009, despite the gloomy economic outlook, with an annual growth rate of 3 percent and a market scale of US$428.7 billion.
Asked if China will participate in next year's show, Yeh said close to 200 booths will be opened at the China Pavilion, featuring 120 exhibitors from China and Hong Kong.
Describing Computex Taipei as the pilot of the ICT industry, Yeh said he is confident the 2009 show will give an insight into worldwide market trends and demands.

DOC.HEADLINE: Some details of giant panda imports still to be negotiated: SEF

TEXT.P: There are still some procedural details that need to be negotiated before Taiwan can import a pair of giant pandas offered by China as gift, the head of the intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Monday.
Although the two pandas are expected to be delivered to Taiwan before Christmas, some procedural details still need to be smoothed out, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin- kung said.

Chiang said the relevant details are being handled by Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the quasi-official SEF, who has met with officials from China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) several times to settle some procedural matters surrounding the panda delivery.

Meanwhile, Chiang said, the technical details -- including the exact time of the pandas' arrival and which airline will transport them -- are being handled by Taipei Zoo, where the two pandas will be housed.

Chiang made the remarks at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport before departure for the Philippines and Singapore for a five-day visit to brief Taiwanese business leaders there on the new cross-Taiwan Strait developments since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May.
Kao said last week that the necessary papers for the pandas' entry are being prepared by the SEF and ARATS.
China first promised to send the two pandas as a gift to Taiwan during a meeting between then Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and China's President Hu Jintao in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to release results of probe on lawmakers' foreign citizenship

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Monday that the ministry will soon inform the Legislative Yuan of the results of a probe into whether Taiwan's lawmakers possess American citizenship.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, MOFA's Political Deputy Minister Andrew L. Y. Hsia said that the ministry last Friday received the results of the investigation conducted with the assistance of the American Institute in Taiwan's Washington office, and will release the results to the legislature as soon as it can.

Hsia stressed, however, that as some appendixes to the report have not arrived and that the Legislative Yuan had made a classified request, the ministry "will have to deal with the issue with caution."

The issue of foreign citizenship was heatedly debated in the runup to the presidential election in March this year. The Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) candidate Frank Hsieh had accused the Kuomintang's (KMT) candidate Ma Ying-jeou of holding a U.S. green card.
Ma, who won the election, had said his U.S. permanent residency rights, acquired when he was studying in the United States many years ago, had long expired.
The issue later spread to whether lawmakers held foreign residency rights or foreign citizenship.
It is against Taiwan's laws for lawmakers to hold dual nationalities.
One legislator on Monday expressed worries that some lawmakers might have wittingly abandoned their foreign citizenship prior to the investigation being launched.

Opposition DPP Legislator Tsai Huang-liang urged MOFA not only to look into whether lawmakers currently possess dual nationalities, but also when those who used to hold foreign citizenship gave it up.

He said that if the foreign ministry only bases its investigation on the findings since it launched the probe in June, it will not know for certain whether incumbent lawmakers held dual nationalities before the probe began.
In response, Hsia said he would not deny such a possibility, but stressed that if his ministry is to conduct such a probe, the Legislative Yuan should submit an official request.
Earlier this year, KMT Legislator Lee Ching-an gave rise to public attention on the citizenship issue after a local magazine revealed that she allegedly possesses a U.S. passport.
According to relevant stipulations, any lawmaker, if found to possess another foreign nationality, will be stripped of his or her duties at the Legislative Yuan.

Following the incident, the Legislative Yuan approved two motions in May called by the opposition DPP requiring an in-depth investigation into the country's legislators' and government officials' citizenship status. The legislature later suggested that MOFA begin by checking to see who has American citizenship.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 193.26 points, to close at 4,418.33.

Lifted by a big bounce on Wall Street the previous trading day, the local bourse opened at the day's low of 4,278.61 and rose as high as 4,424.09 during the session. A total of 3.77 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$64.22 billion (US$1.91 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 6.68 percent. Construction issues advanced 5.37 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 5.26 percent, textile stocks gained 4.34 percent, paper and pulp issues were up 3.41 percent, plastic and chemicals shares rose 2.18 percent, foodstuff issues moved up 2.16 percent and cement stocks gained 0.26 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,342 to 137, with 174 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$3.94 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet finalizes budget for shopping voucher plan

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Monday during a Cabinet meeting that the Executive Yuan has finalized the proposal for the special budget to issue shopping vouchers to all citizens of the country.

Liu chaired the Cabinet meeting that focused on finalizing the NT$85.7 billion budget plan for the shopping voucher program, which is aimed at stimulating the country's slumping retail sector and boosting the overall economy.
"As the Legislative Yuan approved the bill for the voucher program last week, we now have to send our finalized budget proposal to them for approval," Liu said.

He added that the Ministry of Finance and the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) will be pushing to have the NT$85.7 billion (US$2.6 billion) budget bill reviewed and passed by the legislature as soon as possible.
The legislature last Friday passed a bill that would authorize the government to issue NT$3,600 (US$108) in consumption vouchers to each Taiwan citizen.

"We want to make sure that the effects of the shopping voucher initiative are fully realized, " said Liu. "Therefore, I am asking all Cabinet agencies, especially the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of the Interior, to coordinate well to make sure this policy works at its best."

In explaining the breakdown of the voucher program budget, DGBAS Minister Shih Su-mei said that printing costs will amount to NT$287 million, media advertising will cost NT$28 million, distribution of the vouchers NT$801 million, cashing operations NT$837 million and consultancy services NT$13 million.

The bill specifies that the overhead costs of the program should not exceed 3 percent of the total budget, Shih said, noting that the currently the overheads amount to NT$1.966 billion, or 2.29 percent of the total.

To ensure that the vouchers can be distributed by the government's target date of Jan. 18, the Cabinet must submit the budget proposal to the Legislative Yuan by noon Dec. 8 and obtain approval by Dec. 26.

If the budget is passed as expected, the vouchers would be issued on Jan. 18, the week before the Lunar New Year holiday, and after the holiday until March 31. They will be valid for use until Sept. 30, 2009, and retailers must redeem them by Oct. 31, 2009.
The government estimates that the program will boost the country's 2009 gross domestic product by 0.64 percent, if all the vouchers are used.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index rising by the maximum allowable 7 percent for December, January, March, June and September.
TAIEX Index futures for December surged 292 points to end at 4,471, with 92,030 contract transactions, while January futures gained 289 points to finish at 4,421, with 2,687 contracts traded.
March futures increased 287 points to close at 4,387 with 83 contracts changing hands, while June futures rose 283 points to end at 4,332, with 14 contract transactions.
September futures rose 271 points to finish at 4,143, with 24 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 4,179 for December, 4,132 for January, 4,100 for March, 4,049 for June and 3,872 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 193.26 points to finish at 4,418.33, on turnover of NT$64.2 billion (US$1.92 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures rose 10.75 points to close at 164.85, with 4,505 contracts traded, while January TE futures increased 10.55 points to finish at 161.75, with 61 contract transactions. September TF futures gained 4.6 points to close at 143, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.
December TF futures gained 36.2 points to finish at 553.6, with 1,739 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures increased 36 points to finish at 550.4, with 93 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, falling NT$0.032 to close at NT$33.517.
A total of US$636 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.549 and fluctuated between NT$33.490 and NT$33.599.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City anti-betel-nut drive helps addicts quit

TEXT.P: An anti-betel-nut program launched by Taipei City in late May has helped 91 out of 153 betel nut addicts to kick the habit, marking a 60 percent success rate, a local health official said Monday.

The program included holding the first ever betel nut withdrawal classes in the city's 12 districts in May. Each the 153 addicts who participated spent eight hours taking the classes that lasted for about three months, the official told reporters.
A participant identified by his last name Lin, who ended his addiction to betel nuts, said he chewed about 30-50 betel nuts a day before quitting.

One of Lin's colleagues in Taipei City's cleaning squad in which Lin worked temporarily early this year, "forced" him to take the classes, worrying that Lin's betel-nut affected mouth will hinder his social life, according to Lin.

Lin ran a betel nut kiosk for more than 10 years before his temporary job in the squad. After kicking the habit, Lin said he started selling Taiwanese cold noodles, gaining quite good income of about NT$7,000 (US$209)-NT$8,000 each day.

Those who have successfully given up chewing betel nuts will be able to save about NT$10,000 - money they would have used to buy the Taiwan-grown products, according to Lee Ming-hsien, a professor at National Dong Hwa University, who was commissioned by the Taipei city government to hold the classes.
Betel nut chewing damages the mouth and causes oral cancer, which is the fourth top killer for men in Taiwan, said Chen Li-kai, director-general of Taipei City Hospital's Dentistry Department.
Chen pointed out that most betel nut addicts are men between the ages of 30 and 50, with many being their family's main breadwinner.
The Taipei City health official said those who smoke, drink and chew betel nuts have 123 times the likelihood of developing oral cancer than those who do not have these habits.
To help prevent oral cancer, the government is providing free oral cancer screenings to people age 18 or older at several branches of Taipei City Hospital this month, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elderly woman who dazzled audiences as ballroom dancer dies at 83

TEXT.P: A Taiwan legendary elderly lady who tangoed, waltzed and quick stepped on professional dance floors up until her death, died of an accidental fall on Monday. She was 83.

According to her family, Sung Yu-heng -- who was invited to show off her ballroom dancing skills as a special guest at the 2008 Professional Dance Championships Asian Tour Taipei Open in February -- fell unconscious after she tripped on the stairs at her home in Taipei County's Yonghe City while trying to take her garbage out to a passing garbage truck.
The garbage truck, like those in neighborhoods all over Taipei, picks up garbage at designated times. Residents generally take their garbage out to the truck when they hear the truck's melody.
Sung, who was in excellent health, never awoke from the fall, which occurred last week, her daughter Chen Shao-chia told the CNA.
Although doctors declared her brain dead shortly after she was rushed to a nearby hospital, Sung's other organs had remained healthy, and she had a normal heart beat and strong lungs.
Sung's dance coach Shih Ta-chien played DVDs of her performances on the dance floor in Sung's hospital room, in hopes that it would revive her, but Sung was pronounced dead on Monday.

Prior to her death, Sung, who had the figure of a teenage girl, danced like a pro, even though she only came in contact with dancing at age 76 when she was trying to find some physical exercises which were also fun.
According to Shih, Sung had a good physique with muscles and bones that were much younger than her age. More importantly, dancing was so natural to her.

Sung and Shih, who was also her dance partner, had appeared and danced in many of the major television variety shows in Taiwan and had been invited to appear on other educational TV programs. She was cited by local TV hosts as a role model for retirees seeking to stay healthy and spend their later years happily. Sung told CNA in an interview in September that she had become healthier and happier than she was seven years ago before she took up dancing.
"You expect more and more of yourself; it's something like an addictive feeling, " she said.

She and Shih had been invited to show off their dance moves in Southeast Asia and Sung even danced in early September in Shanghai with Zhou JitianVone of the top dance sport athletes in China. Zhou and his partner won the championship in the tango competition in the 2005 East Asian Games and the title for New Stars in the tango category in the World International Standard Dance Championship held in Germany in 2006.

Before her death, Sung's greatest dream was to take part in international standard dance competitions abroad -- including, if possible, in Blackpool, England, the mecca of professional ballroom dancers from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Season for Pacific saury coming

TEXT.P: The season for Pacific saury is coming as fishing boats have been seen sailing into Taiwan's largest Kaoshiung Harbor over the past few days, unloading tons of blade-shaped silver fish, named "Qiu Dao Yu" in Chinese or "sanma" in Japanese.
Kaohsiung City Marine Bureau Director Sun Chih-peng said Monday the fish is one of three ocean treasures the port city generates, along with tuna fish and squid.
"Now is the best time to have delicious cuisine with the fish, " he said.

Every autumn and winter, Kaohsiung, one of Taiwan's ocean fishery centers, is packed with pelagic fishing boats that have just returned from the North Pacific fishing grounds, carrying with them loads of fresh Pacific saury.

Sun pointed out that Kaohsiung's saury output has been one of the largest in the world. Over the past five years, the annual output reached 50,000-110,000 tons, creating an annual production value at between NT$1.2 billion and NT$2.5 billion (US$74.48 million).
Saury has not only offered Taiwanese residents a cheap and delicious source of fish cuisine, but also brought substantial income to the port city, the official said.

The migratory fish are found in the North Pacific in schools, from Japan eastward to the Gulf of Alaska and southward to subtropical Mexico. They are known to glide above the surface of the water when moving away from predators (a behavior that links them to the flying fish, a cousin of the saury family).
The ocean fishing boats from Kaohsiung usually sail to the North Pacific fishing areas for the saury from the Southwest Atlantic Ocean, after completing their hunting for squid.
A local grill shop owner, surnamed Lin, said the best way to cook the saury is grilling them in whole, coated with salt and then serving them with lemon and turnip paste.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese shipping delegation eyes Kaohsiung Harbor

TEXT.P: A Chinese shipping delegation praised Taiwan's four international harbors Monday, with one of its members expressing particular interest in investing in Kaohsiung Harbor in the south of the country.

The 18-member delegation, headed by Hu Hanxiang, director of China's Cross- Strait Transport Exchange Association, arrived in Taiwan last Tuesday for an eight-day trip and has visited Kaohsiung, Taichung, Keelung and Hualien harbors, as well as meeting with representatives of Taiwanese shipping companies during its stay.

"Each of the four international harbors has its own distinctive features, " Hu noted, adding that although the ranking of Kaohsiung Harbor in terms of the number of containers handled has slipped in recent years, it is nevertheless a good natural harbor with a tidal range of just 0.75 meters.
He said the harbor has "great potential" and that one member of his delegation has expressed keen interest in investing in it.

The harbor, which enjoys a superb geographical location and operating advantage, used to rank third in the world in terms of container-handling prior to 2000. Its rank started to slip in 2001, dropping to eighth place by 2007.

Hu also praised Taichung Harbor, saying that although it is an artificial harbor, it has a vast hinterland covering a land area 1.9 times that of Kaohsiung Harbor and seven times that of Keelung harbor, which he said is favorable to its development as a container harbor.
As for Keelung Harbor and its much smaller hinterland, Hu said it still has the potential to be developed into a harbor suitable for bulk cargo vessels and cruise liners.
He also likened the nearby Suao and Taipei harbors as "the two wings" of Keelung Harbor.
Turning to eastern Taiwan's Hualian Harbor, Hu said it could specialize in cross-strait bulk cargo such as gravel for the country's construction sector. By Lilian Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor denies he will run for Taipei County magistrate

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu denied Monday that he will move to Taipei County in northern Taiwan to run for magistrate of that county after his second mayoral term in Taichung expires in December 2009.

Clarifying a newspaper report that he may accept an arrangement by the Kuomintang government to run for Taipei County magistrate, Hu told Taichung City Council Speaker Chang Hung-nien that the report "is absolutely untrue."

Taipei County is scheduled to be upgraded to the status of a special municipality under the direct control of the Cabinet in December 2010, when Taichung City and Taichung County will be merged into one administrative area and given the same status.

As a result, according to the Ministry of the Interior, the original December 2009 elections in Taichung and Taipei County will be postponed to December 2010 to coincide with the mayoral elections in the other two special municipalities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung.
Later at a question-and-answer session with members of the Taichung City Council, Hu reaffirmed that he will not run for magistrate of Taipei County.
"I assure you I will stay in Taichung to finish my remaining term of office," he said.
"If I ever run for public office again, it's going to be in Taichung," Hu added.
Ho Ming-chen, a city councilor of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said it would be an "insult" to ask Hu to run for Taipei County magistrate, because he is "premier material."
"We hope the next post for Mr. Hu will be beneficial to Taichung, as well. If he becomes Taipei County magistrate, what's in it for us?" Ho asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City seeking to increase MRT ridership

TEXT.P: According to Wang, the city government is seeking ways to push up passenger loads on the system to a ridership of 300,000 passengers per day -- up from the current daily level of a combined 210,000 passengers (120,000 on the MRT and 90,000 on accompanying shuttle buses.)
The Kaohsiung MRT began its operations in March this year with the Red Line and phased in the Organe Line in August.

However, a Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) executive said the company is set to post an annual deficit of NT$1 billion (US$29.9 million) next year even if it reaches a daily ridership target of 300,000 -- a level that will leave the company unable to pay for the interest on its loans or to pay for the phasing out of carriages once they age.
The system needs to attract at least 400,000 passengers per day to break even, he explained.

Since the launch of its construction until the end of September this year, the MRT has incurred a combined deficit of NT$2.4 billion, said Kaohsiung City Rapid Transit Department Director Lee Cheng-pin.

In a bid to attract more passengers to use the system and its shuttle bus connection service, the city government has earmarked NT$140 million in its 2009 budget to enhance the bus network and upgrade its services, Lee said.

As long as the KRTC is willing to allocate an additional NT$42 million, the bus service can be upgraded to a frequency of every 10 minutes, an improvement from the present 20 minute frequency, Lee went on, adding that such a move would definitely boost passenger numbers.

In addition, he continued, the city government is also planning to build a light rail rapid transit system to create further improvement, with the central government having already approved a budget for the project.

Despite these incentives, however, the municipal authorities are concerned about declining ridership, which dwindled in November by nearly 700,000 passenger trips compared to the previous month's level amid falling gasoline and fuel prices, Lee noted.
Later that same day, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu urged President Ma Ying-jeou and the central government to pay equal heed to the development needs of Taiwan's southern regions.

Chen said that the Executive Yuan should not just sit idly by in view of the Kaohsiung MRT's operating difficulties but should extend the system to neighboring Pingtung County, which was the projection prior to the launch of construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to seek to join APEC agreement: Cabinet official

TEXT.P: Taiwan is to seek opportunities to be a part of an expansion plan of the Trans- Pacific Strategic Economic Partnership (P4) Agreement launched by four Asia- Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum member economies, a Cabinet official said Monday.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Deng Chen-chung made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan, adding that with this year's APEC forum that took place in late November, the greatest significance for Taiwan "lies in the P4's expected expansion, " bringing three more APEC countries into the agreement.

P4 refers to a free trade agreement that took effect in 2006 among APEC members of Singapore, Brunei, New Zealand and Chile with the aims of reducing customs tariffs and eventually clearing trade barriers, which they believe will help enhance regional economic integration under the APEC spirit.
Deng said Taiwan has shown interest in joining the pact over the past few years, but noted that the country's efforts have been restricted due to political obstruction by China.

He pointed out that P4 was originally an agreement among the four founding members alone, but now with more countries welcome to be included, Taiwan will strive once again for their consent to admit the country as a signatory.

The United States, Australia and Peru -- this year' APEC host country -- have recently expressed their willingness to join the agreement, with the U.S. slated to begin the first round of negotiations with the four initiating countries next year.

Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Cheng Li-wun emphasized the importance of Taiwan's participation in the agreement, saying it would provide a "great opportunity" to offset the marginalization the country will suffer in the process of regional economic integration and cooperation among members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which Taiwan is also prevented from joining due to China's obstruction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Natural gas prices to fall by another 12.99%

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) decided Monday to further reduce natural gas prices by an average of 12.99 percent, after adjusting prices downward last week for the first time since rates were raised in May.

The latest adjustment was made retroactive to Dec. 1 and will be followed by Great Taipei Gas Corp. and Hsin Kao Gas Co., the leading natural gas suppliers to households in northern and southern Taiwan respectively.
Thanks to the cut, household users can save up to NT$100 a month based on a monthly consumption of 40 cubic meters, according to the MOEA.
State-run petroleum refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan, which wholesales the natural gas, said the price reductions will hurt its bottom line, with losses expected to reach NT$35.32 billion this year.
Monday's decision was made during the meeting of the MOEA power and natural gas price consultant committee.

MOEA Vice Minister Shih Yen-Shiang said the committee decided to lower the price of natural gas for household users by 13.27 percent, translating to an NT$2.25 reduction per cubic meter in the north and NT$2.5 reduction per cubic meter in the south.
Households will now pay NT$16.34 and NT$14.69 per cubic meter of natural gas in the south and north respectively.
Industrial users of natural gas will get a 16.88 percent price cut, representing a drop of between NT$3.07 and NT$3.41 per cubic meter, depending on different calorific values, he added.
Other customers, such as power plants running on natural gas, received slightly lower price reductions, bringing the overall average rate decrease to 12.99 percent.

Natural gas prices were first lowered by 2.99 percent last week, the first price adjustment in the fuel since May 28, when CPC raised its average natural gas price of NT$13.46 per cubic meter by NT$3.85 due to soaring international crude oil and natural gas prices at the time.
Last week's 2.99 percent price cuts were incorporated in Monday's overall reductions.

International energy prices have plummeted in recent months, but while local gasoline prices have been lowered to reflect international markets, local natural gas prices have held steady, triggering public pressure to bring them down.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT head relays president's call for better ties with Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/08 21:48:53 (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Visiting Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung paid a visit to Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara Monday at the Tokyo City Hall and relayed President Ma Ying- jeou's call for better ties between the two countries.

Wu told reporters after his meeting with Ishihara that Ma cherishes Taiwan-Japan ties and looks forward to stepping up bilateral exchanges and mutual understanding by putting aside controversial issues.
The main aim of Wu's visit is to help the ruling KMT strengthen Taiwan-Japan ties and explain the recent state of relations with China to Japanese politicians and Taiwanese expatriates.
Wu said, however, that he stressed to Ishihara that improving the cross-Taiwan Strait relationship will also be in Japan's interests and that Taiwan pays equal importance to its relations with Japan.

In response to Ishihara's suggestion that Taiwan and Japan closely cooperate in combating the current financial crisis, Wu agreed that the two sides are closely linked to each other and that Taiwan maintains very special ties with Japan, as the number of two-way tourist arrivals exceeds 2.5 million visits per year, and the volume of annual bilateral trade has totaled around US$70 billion.

The KMT chairman also relayed the president's appreciation to Ishihara for his long-term concern over Taiwan and thanked him for Japan's support for Taiwan's attendance at the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer.
"Taiwan stands a good chance of taking part in the 2009 World Health Assembly annual conference in May," he said.
"Taiwan needs greater international space, in particular its participation at the WHA, because it plays an indispensable role in the world's fight against epidemics," he asserted.
According to the KMT chief, he also expressed his support to Ishihara for Tokyo's bid to host the 2016 Summer Olympics.

Wu was accompanied by a 14-member delegation, composed of Taiwan's representative to Japan John C. T. Feng, former representative to Japan Hsu Shui-teh, KMT lawmakers and officials and Taipei City councilors during the 30-minute meeting.
It was Wu's first visit to Japan in his capacity as head of Taiwan's ruling party.

On Monday evening, the KMT chief was hosted by the Tokyo-based Interchange Association Chairman Atshshi Hatakenaka at a tea party before taking part in a dinner held by Feng in his honor in which several Japanese parliamentarians were among the guests.
Wu will proceed to Yokohama Thursday and visit the city's mayor, Hiroshi Nakada, and meet Taiwanese community representatives there before heading for Kobe and Osaka for the same purpose.
He is slated to fly back to Taiwan Saturday.

Japan, a long-term close ally of Taiwan in the region despite the lack of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, has been wary of the warming relations between Taiwan and China since Ma came to power in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: E-mail spam irksome: survey

TEXT.P: The flood of E-mail spam, or junk e-mails, that bombards Internet users daily has become a nagging problem, according to a survey released by the Taiwan Internet Association Monday.
The survey found that Internet users receive on average of 29 junk e-mails per day, with most of them related to pornography, violence, fraud, online shopping and computer viruses.
As they are resented by the majority of people, up to 70 percent of recipients simply delete them without bothering to open them up, the survey found.

Based on estimates that it costs NT$0.02 to send one e-mail, the deleted spam alone translates into an annual waste of NT$2 billion per year, based on figures provided by Taiwan's top 20 IAPs (Internet Access Providers) that the volume of spam reached 117.2 billion messages in the past year.

On the effect of junk e-mail, the public is most worried about their propensity to spread computer viruses, with 80.5 percent saying that they are irksome, 78.1 percent considering them a waste of time, and 51.6 percent saying they are a waste of computer and Internet resources.
Around 50 percent worried that the spam could inadvertently cause them to delete other important information, and 41.3 percent said they are worried about being defrauded.
The survey also showed that 74 percent of the public hope the government can formulate legislation or take administrative measures to regulate the spam.
The survey, conducted between Nov. 14 and Dec. 5, received 12,497 effective samples with a margin of error of 0.88 percentage points.
The association estimated that 10.14 million people, or 44 percent of the total population, in Taiwan will have frequent access to the Internet as of the end of this year,
The survey also found that 24.1 percent of those polled spend between one and two hours on the Internet daily if working hours are excluded, while 65.9 percent spend more than two hours.
The survey also found that 64.5 percent send less than five e-mails daily, while only around 20 percent send more than 10 e-mails a day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Irish pork not sold in Taiwan: DOH

TEXT.P: Taiwan has not imported pork or related products from Ireland, the Department of Health (DOH) reported Monday, following Ireland'swarnings not to consume its pork because it contained contaminants.

European supermarkets have been ordered to clear their shelves of Irish bacon, ham and sausages after authorities announced Sunday that Irish pork products had been tainted with dioxin, a potentially cancer-causing chemical..
According to DOH spokesman Wang Je-chau, the DOH's Bureau of Food Safety has checked customs clearance documents which showed that no Irish pork products have been imported into Taiwan.
Foreign wire service reprots said European health officials have warned their consumers not to eat Irish pork after the discovery that dioxins had been in some of the pigs' feed for months.

Irish government officials described the recall, which affects all pig products produced since Sept. 1, as a precautionary move, but farmers called it a nightmare for Ireland's 450 million euro (US$570 million) pig farming industry.
The reports said dioxin-contaminated Irish pork products might have been sold to 25 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Steel to refrain from new investment in high speed rail

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp. (CSC), Taiwan's largest steelmaker, has decided not to make any further investment in Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC), a company executive said Monday.

Chung Lo-min, spokesman and an executive vice president of the steelmaker, said the high speed rail corporation has been operating at a loss and therefore is unable to issue dividends to its shareholders, including China Steel.
"It would be unfair to China Steel's shareholders if we continue to invest in Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp.," Chung said.

He also indicated that China Steel's Board of Directors had already decided to report the company's NT$4.74 billion (US$141.17 million) investment in THSRC as a one-time impairment loss in the third quarter of 2008.

Chung said that although China Steel had asked the high speed rail company to redeem the preferred shares held by China Steel, THSRC replied that its current financial condition would not permit it to do.
"As a result, we could only decide not to invest any more funds in Taiwan's high speed rail," he said.
China Steel, which is 23 percent owned by the state, posted profits totaling NT$12.58 billion for the third quarter of 2008, down from its NT$15.19 billion earnings in the second quarter.

According to the latest financial information released by the company, its revenues in November dropped to a 28-month low of NT$15.38 billion, down 37.5 percent from October and 15.67 percent year-on-year.
China Steel's steel production in November also dropped 17.55 percent from October to 648,880 metric tons, a decrease of 24.94 percent compared to the same month a year earlier.

China Steel has mapped out a plan to reduce its steel production in response to decreasing world demand by either shutting down two of its four blast furnaces, or by "damping" them down to keep production at a minimum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academicians awarded Italian science prize

TEXT.P: Two academicians of Taiwan's top research institute Academia Sinica won an Italian science award for their scientific advancement for peaceful purposes, according to a press statement released by Academia Sinica Monday.

Wu Maw-kuen and Chu Ching-wu won the award together for their discovery of the Y Ba2 Cu3 superconductor, which is the first superconductor system with a transition temperature exceeding 77 degrees Kelvin, in addition to their continuous contributions in physics education, the statement said.
Wu, who was made an academician in 1998, directs Academia Sinica's Institute of Physics and is a foreign associate of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences.
Chu, an academician since 1988, is also the president of Hong Kong University of Science and Technology.
Wu said he is very happy to be granted the award, as many winners of the award were Nobel laureates.

He said research in superconductors will be beneficial for energy saving, as superconductors can be used to store energy and avoid energy waste. It is also an important material in nuclear fusion reactions for generating energy, Wu added.
The prize was established by the Sicilian Parliament in 1990 to recognize scientists whose research helped improve the development of peace for human beings.
The award is named after Italian physicist Ettore Majorana, known for his achievements in neutrino masses. He was born in 1906 and disappeared mysteriously in 1938.
Recipients of the award are elected every year by members of the World Federation of Scientists, which, founded in Switzerland in 1973, has over 10,000 scientist members from over 110 countries.
The federation is known for establishing the "Erice Statement" in 1982, which opposes the use of science for militaristic means and promotes its use for peaceful purposes.
The two winners have received letters of congratulations from the Pontifical Academy of Science Chancellor Marcello Sanchez Sorondo and World Federation of Scientists President Antonino Zichichi.
The award ceremony will be held by the Pontifical Academy of Science in the Vatican in Rome Dec. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: Transportation head wants Chunghwa Telecom to improve spam problem

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Monday that he will ask Chunghwa Telecom to address the e-mail spam problem.

Mao, who formerly served as chairman of Chunghwa Telecom, said he himself was troubled by spam, or e-mail junk mails, when using the company's Hinet e-mail box and, as a result, switched to Web mail services provided by other portals.
"There is no reason why Chunghwa cannot improve the spam problem," Mao said.
He said that Chunghwa can no longer use privacy rights as a pretext for not dealing with the problem.
The MOTC, as the telecom's largest shareholder, will ask Chunghwa to shoulder the responsibility for improving the problem, he said.
Mao believed that Chunghwa should give its e-mail recipients the option to choose whether they want to receive junk e-mails.

Mao's remarks came as a survey showed that the daily bombardment of spam has become a nagging problem for Internet users in Taiwan, especially because they generally feature content of a pornographic or violent nature.

Media reports said that a Hinet mail box user surnamed Chen, in order not to let his young daughter be exposed to the porno-related spam, has since mid-November taken up a David vs. Goliath battle by returning all the porno-related spam messages.
His fight drew the attention of the MOTC, media watchdog the National Communications Commission and Chunghwa Telecom.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. homeland security official arrives for four-day visit

TEXT.P: Paul Rosenzweig, a deputy assistant secretary for policy development of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, arrived in Taipei Monday for a four-day visit.

The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , which serves as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taipei in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, said in a statement that Rosenzweig will deliver a speech on critical infrastructure protection at an international conference on homeland security and technology.
Rosenzweig will also discuss Taiwan-U.S. cooperation on travel and transportation security with Taiwan authorities, the AIT statement added.

Meanwhile, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official told CNA that during his stay, Rosenzweig will get first-hand information on the progress in Taiwan's preparation for the issuance of e-passports.

Noting that pushing for Taiwan's inclusion into the U.S. Visa Waiver Program (VWP) is one of the MOFA's priority diplomatic goals in its work with the United States in recent years, the official said the U.S. government has expressed hope that Taiwan can first issue forgery-proof chip-embedded passports to reduce the entry rejection rate for Taiwanese passport holders.

The United States has offered visa-free entry for citizens from 34 countries, including South Korea. The official said the MOFA and the Executive Yuan's homeland security office have discussed the issue with the U.S. Department of State and the Department of Homeland Security over the past few years.

In addition to the issuance of e-passports, the U.S. government also wants to reinforce bilateral anti-terrorist security cooperation before its inclusion of Taiwan into its Visa Waiver Program, the official said.
Washington is also requesting that Taiwan expand its airborne police force and develop a comprehensive information link-up system to facilitate exchanges of terrorism-related information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's steel exports down in November

TEXT.P: Taiwan's steel exports fell considerably in November, with its largest steel maker China Steel Corp. failing to meet the company's expected target by at least 30 percent, informed sources in the steel industry said Monday.
The sources, who declined to be named, cited figures showing that China Steel sold 566,000 metric tons of steel in November, a decrease of 29.67 percent from October.

China Steel's quoted prices in the fourth quarter of this year were higher than in the third quarter, bucking the international market where steel prices have plunged in the final three months of the year.
Despite the steelmaker's subsequent efforts to grant discounts to its customers, its exports in November still dropped 30 percent from its target volume, according to the sources.
Some of the mid- and downstream steel factories in Taiwan were not doing well either, they said.

Yieh Phui Enterprise Co. -- a galvanized steel plant -- and Sheng Yu Steel Co. both reduced output by 50 percent in November, compared with their peak outputs in the first half of this year, after many orders from the United States and Europe dried up.

Among the smaller steel factories relatively less affected by the world market downturn were Wei Chih Steel Industrial Co., Feng Hsin Iron & Steel Co., Tung Ho Steel Enterprise Corp., and Kao Hsing Chang Iron & Steel Corp., according to the sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global economic slump takes toll on Taiwan's export trade

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports declined in November for a third consecutive month, indicating that the lingering global financial crisis and economic recession have taken a toll on the country's export trade, trade officials said Monday.

According to the latest customs statistics, Taiwan's outbound shipments fell 23.3 percent in November from the same month last year to US$16.78 billion, the largest year-on-year drop for any single month since October 2001.
Worse still, November exports to China and Hong Kong combined fell by a record 38.5 percent year-on-year.

Shipments to Taiwan's other major export destinations also plunged in November, according to customs figures. Exports to the United States shrank 14.2 percent and sales to the six major countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations fell 19.4 percent year-on-year.

In the first eight months of the year, Taiwan's exports grew 16.8 percent compared to the same period of last year, but the trend reversed itself in September when outbound shipments contracted by 1.6 percent, the biggest fall in exports since April 2004.
Exports fell another 8.3 percent in October to US$20.81 billion before plummeting further last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 9, 2008
