DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan people's mental health barely passes: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan's people just barely passed a latest mental wellness evaluation conducted by the Mental Health Foundation, with 43 percent of those surveyed not feeling optimistic about the future.
The results of the biennial evaluation released Tuesday showed that for 2008, the levels of mental health of Taiwanese people averaged 80.11, just over the passing score of 80.
The score compares with 82.63 in 2006 and 80.60 in 2004 -- the first year the evaluation was carried out.
This year's study was conducted between September and October among 1,114 people around the country.
On average, the respondents measured 79.2 in terms of psychological and physical health, 76.3 in personal values, 79.7 in terms of feeling in control of life, and 85.6 in family wellness.

Yang Tsung-tsai, head of the psychiatric and psychological center at Cardinal Tien Hospital, attributed the decline in Taiwanese people's mental health levels to the impact of several incidents occurring during the period of the evaluation, including the melamine contamination of milk products and food ingredients imported from China, and the worsening of the global financial crisis.
Among the four areas assessed, all got a failing score except for family wellness, which indicates that family provides important support for the public's mental health, Yang said.

Aspects that remained at especially low levels were effectiveness of one own's abilities and personal trait, which averaged 65.0; satisfaction with one own's achievements, which averaged 68.8; and one's belief that the future will be better, which averaged 67.2, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP Siew presents Microsoft's first WinHEC Awards

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew, presented on Tuesday the top panel award as well as five separate categories of awards to the winners of the Windows Hardware Engineering Conference 2008 Awards (WinHEC 2008 Awards).

During the award ceremony, which took place at the Taipei International Convention Center, Siew praised Microsoft for working successfully with many outstanding hardware companies in Taiwan over the past 15 years.

"It has not only helped Taiwan develop into the worldwide leader of personal computer manufacturing, but it has also shaped the future of the global information technology (IT) industry with its partners in Taiwan," Siew said.
More than 1,000 hardware engineers and experts from Taiwan are attending the two-day WinHEC, at which Microsoft announced the inaugural awards 16 years after WinHEC was launched.
"I truly appreciate Microsoft Taiwan's creation of the WinHEC Award this year," said Siew.

The vice president emphasized that such an initiative would allow Taiwan's already powerful hardware industry to take further advantage of Microsoft's global resources and international marketing experience to develop better products and stronger competitiveness.

"The Taiwanese government will continue to provide incentives to further encourage innovation and design in our IT industry, " Siew said, adding that the i-Taiwan projects include mechanisms to provide financial assistance to those companies that are interested in participating in the government's Branding Taiwan plan.

Promising to continue making available its global marketing resources to help the winners launch their successful ideas in the global IT market, Davis Tsai, general manager of Microsoft Taiwan, said that Microsoft has always highly valued Taiwan's hardware industry, which plays an indispensable, strategic global role.

Tsai said that according to the 2008 Branding Taiwan survey conducted by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, which was commissioned by the Bureau of Foreign Trade, the total value of Taiwan's top-20 brands amounted to US$9.141 billion, breaking the US$9 billion mark for the first time.

"This is evidence of the success of the government's Branding Taiwan initiative that helps businesses strengthen their competitiveness in international brand marketing," noted Tsai, adding that these top brands are now able to maintain consumer preference in the face of a global recession and stiff competition.

According to Tsai, the globally unprecedented WinHEC Awards identified 10 oustanding works in five prize categories and a top panel award with the help of Jan Hung-tse, chairman of PC Home International Co. Ltd, and 10 professional panelists over the past month.
Showing his gratitude for Siew's presence at the award presentation ceremony, Tsai said that the vice president's attendance represented the highest recognition for the award winners.
Jan, the chief panelist for the WinHEC Award and a renowned trend guru, noted that "this year's Microsoft WinHEC Award has really given encouragement to the Taiwan IT industry."
Jan said the industry's production quality, design innovation, and cost control were first class, and that the participants were also considerate of every need and want of consumers.
This year's WinHEC Award offered prizes in five categories: Environmental soundness, digital media and home entertainment, Internet applications, technology innovation, and industrial design.

The winners were Via Technologies, for its green platform, and Asus, for its Asus N20A notebook computer in the environemntal soundness category; Aiptek, for its pocketsize multimedia projector, Acer, for its 8920G Blu-ray notebook computer, and Ipevo, for its Kaleido R 7 Wireless Digital Frame in the digital media and home entertainment category; Acer, for its Aspire One notebook and Inventec, for its Kohjinsha S32 7-inch ultra-portable tablet computer, in the Internet application category; Quanta, for its optical touch-control display in the technology innovation category; and Acer, for its Aspire Predator G700, and Quanta, for its Digital Operator Phone System in the industrial design category.
The winner of the top panel award was Aiptek's pocketsize multimedia projector.

Prior to the awards ceremony Jon DeVaan, senior vice president, Windows Core Operating System Divison, Microsoft, delivered a keynote speech on the status of the development of the Windows 7 operating system with his company's IT partners in Taiwan and demonstrating Windows 7's performance in log-on/off speed, memory and power management, as well as multitouch interface innovation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exports suffer steepest drop in 7 years

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports in November fell US$5.09 billion, or 23.3 percent, to US$16.78 billion from a year earlier, the biggest drop since October 2001, the Ministry of Finance said Monday.

Meanwhile, imports in November slid 13.2 percent, or US$2.32 billion, to US$15.26 billion, the sharpest decline since March 2002, leaving a trade surplus of US$1.52 billion, Lin Li-jen, chief of the ministry's statistics department said at a press conference.
The figures represent a sharp decline of 64.6 precent in the trade surplus in November compared with the previous month, she added.

The value of exports for November was the lowest since September 2005, mainly due to a 25.3 percent decline in the electronics sector, its worst drop since December 2001. Optical products and electric machinery manufacturers also recorded a 47.6 percent and a 51.8 percent decline in exports, respectively, the ministry report showed.

It also revealed that shipments to China and Hong Kong, which accounted for more than one-third of Taiwan's exports, fell sharply by a record 38.5 percent, or US$3.53 billion, to US$5.63 billion from last year.
Exports to the U.S., Taiwan's second-largest export market, fell 14.2 percent, while exports to Japan increased 19.2 percent, the report said.

Amid the global economic downturn, the November figures marked the third straight month of negative growth in exports, following a 1.6 percent decline in September and an 8.3 percent drop in October, according to Lin.
She expressed reservations about Taiwan's export outlook for December and the first half of next year, saying "it would not turn brighter."

Other figures also provide further evidence that Taiwan is increasingly reeling from the effects of the global economic slump. Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc and Siliconware Precision Industries Co, Taiwan's two main semiconductor packaging and testing service providers, posted record lows of NT$6.14 billion and NT$4.23 billion, respectively, in business turnover for November, which represented a 35.8 percent and a 24 percent year-on-year drop, respectively.
Meanwhile, a number of DRAM makers, TFT-LCD manufacturers and IC design companies also recorded more than 30 percent decline in turnover for November.
Among them, DRAM maker Nanya Technology and TFT-LCD manufacturer AU Optronics Corp suffered a whopping 55 percent and 66.8 percent revenue drop in November compared with October.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT chairman to attend KMT-CPC forum in Shanghai

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , Wu Poh-hsiung, will attend the fourth forum between the KMT and its Chinese counterpart, the Communist Party of China (CPC), that will be held from Dec. 20-21 in Shanghai, China, a KMT spokesman announced Tuesday.

KMT Deputy Secretary-General Chang Jung-kung released a statement to make public the plan. It will be the first time Taiwan's ruling party chairman will attend the cross-Taiwan Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum, also known as the KMT-CPC Forum.
Chang pointed out that the upcoming event is aimed at promoting further cross- strait economic, trade and cultural exchanges and cooperation, and the stable development of cross-strait relations.
Participants will discuss major issues, including cross-strait cooperation in the finance and services sectors, mutual investment, and ways to systemize mutual investment and economic exchanges.
There will also be an in-depth cultural workshop, Chang said.
Chang noted that Wu will deliver a speech at the opening of the two-day forum. KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan has also been invited to address the participants, he added.
Around 150 Taiwanese delegates will join the forum, including KMT executive members, thinktank representatives, and representatives in the industrial and academic sectors and other political parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mongolian official visits Taichung charity

TEXT.P: A Mongolian official visited the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) in the central city of Taichung Monday to express her gratitude to the charity for its assistance to poor Mongolian children over the past four years, according to a TFCF official.

TFCF Chairman Po-Rung Lin received Togtokhnyam Mijiddorj, the head of National Authority for Children in Mongolia, at the TFCF headquarters. Lin briefed Mijiddorj on the TFCF's history and services, the official added.

Mijiddorj expressed her gratitude to the TFCF for its assistance to a total of 4,059 poor Mongolian children, which was made possible though donations from Taiwanese since a TFCF branch office was opened in Mongolia in 2004.

The TFCF office also established a village in the country's capital of Ulan Bator where yurts, water supply stations and child-care centers have been set up for homeless people and children, Mijiddorj said.

Mijiddorj is in Taiwan to attend a two-day international aid forum which opened Tuesday at National Taiwan University in Taipei City. The event is being sponsored by the TFCF for individuals and groups devoted to international social work and international humanitarian aid.
The main purpose of the forum is to help Mongolia to draw on Taiwan's experience in implementing child protection policies, so that Mongolia can address its serious problem of homeless children.

Founded in 1985, the TFCF is the first non-profit organization in Taiwan that provides needy children with financial assistance and an opportunity to continue their education through sponsorship programs, scholarships and emergency relief funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most single Taiwanese women don't see themselves as losers: poll

TEXT.P: Some 68.7 percent of Taiwan's unmarried female office workers do not see themselves as losers, but instead believe that having a job will help them achieve greater self-worth, the results of an online survey published Tuesday found.

Most of the island's unmarried women choose to stay single because they have not found a suitable mate to get married with; because they love freedom; or because their current economic situation do not allow them to do so, the cyber poll carried out by the 1111 human resources bank showed.

According to the job bank's investigation, about 33 percent of the female workers responding to the survey admitted to eating or shopping alone, envying husbands and wives who walk hand-in-hand, and despising machismo.
The sectors with the highest percentage of unmarried women are the information technology and financial services sectors, as well as the media and publishing industries.
These women's long and irregular work hours were seen as the main reason for their lack of a social life.
The survey asked the women if they identified with the term "loser dog" -- which was coined by Japanese author Junko Sakai, referring to women in marriageable age who remain unmarried and childless.

The survey's findings mirrored government statistics which showed a trend of Taiwanese women marrying much later than in previous decades, or not marrying at all, which is part of the reason for the declining birth rate on the island of 23 million people.

Statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics showed that the ratio of Taiwan's unmarried women in the 25-39 age group rose to 39.4 percent in 2007, up from 22.5 percent in 1997.

The women also tend to be well-educated and financially independent, and are unwilling to marry beneath them. Many also do not want to live with or cater to parents-in-law, which is still expected of them in traditional Taiwanese society, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pandas to attract six million visitors to Taipei zoo: mayor

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin said on Tuesday that the two giant pandas soon to arrive from China are expected to attract six million visitors to the Taipei City Zoo each year.

"We had five million visitors each year to the zoo to see the koalas in the past. With the two giant pandas, we estimate at least six million tourists will visit the zoo every year," said Hau at a press conference with foreign media at the Eslite Book Store.
He was referring to domestic visitors as well as overseas tourists.
The whole of Taiwan saw about 3.7 million overseas visitors last year, although the Tourism Bureau is trying to raise that figure to 4 million this year.
Hau believes the pandas will help boost tourism not only for the zoo but for Taipei.
"I hope many tourists will come and see the pandas," said Hau.
He said that the coming of the mainland Chinese pandas is a major sign of improved cross-strait relations.
Hau said that he is expecting the giant pandas to arrive very soon and that the city is just waiting for the permits to come through and the paperwork to be processed.
"The Taipei City Zoo is now fully prepared, " said Hau.
In addition to pandas, Hau said weekday direct cross-strait flights, which begin this month, will also make Taipei's business environment better.

"Our science park in Neihu will be able to attract more international enterprises to relocate their office to Taipei, " said Hau. "Even with the global economic downturn, the science park in Neihu District of Taipei is still booming."
More than 3,000 companies have relocated their offices to the science park in Neihu and the total capital invested has reached nearly NT$ 2.3 trillion (US$0.069 trillion), Hau noted.

On another front, Hau was questioned by foreign reporters on the issue of the Maokong Gondola, which is shut down indefinitely due to soil erosion caused by a typhoon this fall. The city government has been criticized for its handling of the cable car system's problems.

"The Taipei City government has done a lot for the gondola," said Hau. "We acted according to engineer's professional recommendations. We made all the necessary emergency arrangements. Our major concern is the safety of the residents and citizens of Taipei."
"The trouble was due to excessive rain from the typhoon. It was not due to human error," said Hau, adding that the city hopes to have the gondola safe, up and running again by June 2009.
Hau pointed out that the cable car route, built at a cost of NT$1.3 billion (US$0.039 billion), had already attracted five million tourists.

"Polls showed that 80 percent of the people in Taipei are happy with it. Therefore it is a very important Taipei City tourism asset," Hau said, but he did not specify whether he was referring to polls taken before or after it was found that the cable car's foundations were unable to withstand Taiwan's frequent typhoons.
In the press conference, Hau also touted the honor of Taipei City to hold the Deaflympics in 2009.

"In the past, it was held only in the United States and European countries, " said Hau. "It is first time that the Deaflympics is held in an Asian City. Taipei is honored to be the first Asian City to hold the Deaflympics."
Hau added that the Deaflympics will host participants from 81 countries, with 4,000 athletes, which is close to double the number of what it was when Deaflympics was held in Melbourne in 2005.

"We hope that the holding of the Deaflympics in Taipei will give a good impression of the city to foreigners, added Hau. "We have made preparations for this event and we are sure it will make Taipei shine."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.029 to close at NT$33.546.
A total of US$675 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.517 and fluctuated between NT$33.460 and NT$33.560.

DOC.HEADLINE: Many school children ride motorcycles without helmets: survey

TEXT.P: Many children in Taiwan are transported to school by motorcycle everyday without wearing helmets, which puts them at higher risk of becoming victims in of road traffic accidents, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by the Jing Chuan Child Safety Foundation.
The survey was conducted between mid and late November among 1,409 students from 22 elementary schools around Taiwan.
The results revealed that of the 42.3 percent of children who are transported on a motorcycle every day, approximately 50 percent seldom or never wear a helmet.
Seventeen percent of the respondents have had motorcycle accidents, 31.4 percent of whom were not wearing a helmet at the time.
The survey found that the low rate of helmet wearing among school children is closely linked to parents' attitude on the issue.
Nearly 40 percent of the respondents said their parents do not require them to wear a helmet, and 21.2 percent said their parents seldom wear a helmet.
However, 50.5 percent of the children indicated a preference for wearing a helmet because they feel safer with one, are afraid of being fined, or think a helmet can shield them from the wind and sun.
Another 20 percent of the respondents said they hate wearing a helmet because it makes them feel uncomfortable, makes them sweat, or is too troublesome.
Nearly 10 percent of the children said they wear a helmet only to avoid being fined.

Lin Yueh-chin, assistant executive director of the foundation, called the public's attention to the safety issues concerning motorcycle riding, as an increasingly larger number of people are choosing to ride a motorcycles instead of driving cars at a time when the economy is doing poorly.

As shown in statistics from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the number of motorcycles in Taiwan rose by an average 34,000 per month during the first 10 months of this year to a total of 14.32 million, Lin said.
Among the fatal road traffic accidents in Taiwan, those involving a motorcycle rider or passenger accounted for 58.9 percent, she said.

Meanwhile, statistics from the National Police Agency indicate that in motorcycle accidents, the death rate among those wearing a a helmet stood at 0.73 percent, which was much lower than the 5.31 percent among those without a helmet, she noted.

In an effort to improve the safety of school children, the foundation has successfully solicited the donation of 240 child helmets by the Rotary Club of Taipei Tunghua for distribution in seven elementary schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: Easy-to-carry 'electric pills' developed

TEXT.P: A novel "electric pill" that can generate three watts of electricity to power portable digital devices has the potential to become a more eco-friendly alternative to existing batteries, the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) reported Tuesday.

The only residue of the power generation process is sodium metaborate (NaBO2), a low-toxic chemical that is much less hazardous to the environment than the conventional electricity cell, according to the Hsinchu-based institute.

Tsao Fang-hei, a division chief at ITRI's Energy and Environment Research Laboratories, explained that when added to a micro fuel cell, the white pills of concentrated hydrogen can easily produce electricity by interacting with the catalysts inside the cell.

"A pill of two to three centimeters in diameter can provide three watts electricity for at least one hour," said Tsao. The electricity is sufficient to power a mobile phone or even a laptop computer, he added.
The ITRI said it is trying to transfer the related technologies to private manufacturers, and the easy-to-use, easy-to-carry pills may one day become a better alternative to batteries on the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung County hopes for highway extension to mountainous area

TEXT.P: Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng has said that the county government will ask for subsidies from the central government to have a county highway extended to a mountainous area to provide more convenient travel for local residents.
Huang made the remarks in response to Taichung County Councilor Tsai Cheng- kuei's request at a council session on Nov. 27.
Tsai urged the local government to ask for the central government's support on extending Highway No. 4 to the county's eastern township of Tungshih to ease travel for local residents.
The highway, which started operation in 2000, begins from Cingshuei township in the county's west to Fengyuan City, where the county hall is located.

The part from Fengyuan City to Wufeng township, the county's southernmost area, is currently under construction, but the road does not cover the county's eastern area, which includes Tungshih township and Hoping township.

Huang said he has introduced the county government's plan for road extension to Transportation and Communications Minister Mao Chi-kuo, and the process of designing the extension are likely to start next year.
But he added that he will continue to plea for funding from the central government to ensure its support on the extension.
Tsai also asked Huang about the plan to resume operation of the Central Cross- Island Highway in the county.

The east-west bound road, which covers mountainous regions from Taichung County, Nantou County, and Hualien County, was seriously damaged in the 921 earthquake in 1999, especially the part in Hoping township in eastern Taichung County.
Restoration efforts were made continuously, but were never completed as rains and earthquakes and their aftermath have caused parts of the road to collapse.
Huang said the section from Tungshih township to Guguan Scenic Area in Hoping township will soon be resumed, and follow-up restorations will continue section by section.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president's close aide freed on bail

TEXT.P: Former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng was freed on bail of NT$500,000 Tuesday, after being held in custody since November on suspicion of involvement in graft.

The Taipei District Court granted permission to the anti-corruption Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office to free Ma, who is known as the right-hand man of former President Chen Shui-bian.
The court however retained its ban on Ma leaving the country or changing his place of residence.
Ma was detained on Nov. 4 during a probe into a "special state affairs fund" misappropriation case involving the former president .

At the time, the district court ruled in favor of detaining Ma on grounds that he could tamper with evidence in the case and that he was suspected of committing a crime that carries a sentence of more than five years in prison.

Ma was indicted, along with former first lady Wu Shu-jen, in another case on Nov. 3, 2006 for allegedly helping Wu embezzle NT$14.8 million in public funds set aside for the official discretionary use of then President Chen Shui-bian.
Chen, who was spared indictment at the time because he had presidential immunity, was taken into custody Nov. 12 in a probe into his role in that case and others during his eight-year presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA cautions Taiwanese against Nigeria-originated scams

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials urged Taiwanese nationals Tuesday to be on the alert against scams involving perpetrators from Nigeria by means of emails.

Chang Yun-ping, director-general of the ministrys Department of African Affairs, issued the warning at a regular press briefing, saying that the ministry received two scam cases in December alone, in which Taiwanese victims were asked to send valuable products or remittances to Nigeria.

He added, however, that the ministry had cooperated with the Nigerian police as well as Taiwanese businessmen operating there, and have successfully prevented the products and money from falling into the hands of the fraudsters.
Fraud cases are most rampant in the Nigerian city of Lagos, the countrys major commercial hub located in its south, Chang said, adding that fraudsters, however, commit crimes overseas as well.

The scam artists usually break into the victims email account and send to the victims family messages that he or she has been robbed of money and passport and need immediate monetary assistance in the form of remittances, according to Chang.
He suggested families who receive such emails should verify with the original account user, while contacting MOFAs local representative office in the Nigerian capital of Abuja.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen, who had served part of his diplomatic duties in Nigeria, also warned Taiwanese businesses against the risks of doing trade with the African country, as he saidthey can fake all kinds of official documents, including letters of authority.

He advised Taiwanese businesses to carefully verify the authenticity of documents before shipping out their products as there have been reports of Taiwanese enterprises suffering losses due to the counterfeit documents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan makes progress in 2008 Bribe Payers Index report

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made improvements in its perceived corruption levels, according to the 2008 Bribe Payers Index (BPI) report issued by Transparency International (TI) Tuesday, despite wide publicity concerning prosecutors' investigations into the former first family's alleged bribe-taking, embezzlement and money laundering scandals.
TI-Taiwan released the report at a news conference in Taipei on behalf of TI -- a global coalition against corruption based in Berlin -- to coincide with International Anti-Corruption Day.

The TI survey assesses the supply side of corruption in 22 of the world's leading exporting countries, based on interviews with 2,742 senior business executives in 26 countries. The combined global exports of the 22 countries represent 75 percent of the world's total.

The BPI, expressed on a scale of zero to 10, is a measure of how willing a nation appears to be to comply with demands for corrupt business practices. The higher the score, the lower the likelihood of companies from the country in question engaging in bribery when doing business abroad.

Taiwan received a score of 7.5, sharing the No. 14 spot with South Africa and South Korea but lagging behind Singapore, which placed ninth along with France and the United States with a score of 8.1, and Hong Kong, which ranked 13th with a score of 7.6.
China ranked 21st with a score of 6.5 among the 22 countries -- only slightly better than Russia, which placed last with a score of 5.9.

Topping the list were Belgium and Canada, each with a score of 8.8, followed by the Netherlands and Switzerland, which shared third place with scores of 8.7, while Germany, Japan and the United Kingdom placed fifth with scores of 8.6. Australia ranked eighth with a score of 8.5.
In TI's 2006 BPI report, Taiwan placed 26th with a score of 5.41 -- one notch above China's 21st place with a score of 4.94. That survey evaluated 30 leading exporting countries.

TI said in a news release that there is evidence that "a number of companies from major exporting countries still use bribery to win business abroad, despite awareness of its damaging impact on corporate reputations and ordinary communities."

The organization urged the governments of major exporting countries to redouble their efforts to enforce existing laws and regulations on foreign bribery. It also urged companies to adopt effective anti-bribery programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese oranges to be shipped to China Dec. 15: COA

TEXT.P: China on Tuesday ordered 1,200 metric tons of Taiwanese oranges which will be shipped Dec. 15 via the direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links to be inaugurated that same day, according to the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).
COA Secretary-General Hsu Han-ching, who is in Fuzhou in China's Fujian Province, made the announcement during a telephone interview with the CNA.

According to Hsu, China ordered the oranges at a price of NT$13 (US$0.39) per kilogram and the produce will be shipped to destinations in the coastal regions of China next Monday. On that same day, the accords on the opening of two-way direct daily charter flights and shipping services, inked by Taiwan and China in early November, will take effect.

Of the 1,200 metric tons of oranges ordered, 1,000 metric tons will be delivered from Yunlin County and 200 metric tons from Kaohsiung County, both in southern Taiwan, in an arrangement that resulted from coordinated efforts by agricultural product distribution companies on both sides of the strait, Hsu said.

Asked whether China will buy more Taiwanese fruit in the future, Hsu said this is a goal that the COA will pursue. China has also shown interest in purchasing Taiwan's wax apples, pineapples and custard apples, he added.
According to officials of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, the council hopes that these export efforts will help to boost record low orange prices on the domestic market.

Orange prices in Taiwan have dipped to a record low of NT$10 per kilogram for fine quality oranges, and NT$5 per kilogram on average for those of lower quality produced in the southern regions of the island in a period from November to April.

Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, clinched the direct cross- strait transportation link agreements with his Taiwan counterpart Chiang Pin- kung in Taipei during an unprecedented visit by Chen to Taiwan last month.
He promised to purchase locally grown oranges, after he learned of a glut of the fruit in central and southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung to use prizes to attract shopping voucher spenders

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu disclosed Tuesday that consumers who spend their shopping vouchers -- to be issued by the central government in January -- in his central city will have a chance to win one of three new cars or even a large house as an incentive.

Hu said the Taichung city government will work with local construction companies to provide a house no smaller than 50 pings (one ping equals 36 square feet) with a market value of between NT$5 million and NT$10 million for a lucky draw to be held by the end of February.
"The lucky winner will have several houses in various styles from which to choose," Hu said, adding that "the winner can even pick the house facing in his or her preferred direction."
The mayor's plan to attract people to spend their consumption vouchers in Taichung has won the support of many members of the city council.
Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi said the city government is prepared to give away gifts worth a total of NT$20 million, including three cars each worth between NT$500,000 and NT$1 million.
Hsiao added that the full details of the draw will be announced between Jan. 7 and Jan. 10.

"All a person needs to do is spend a required amount in consumption vouchers in Taichung and collect three stamp marks from Taichung tourist attractions in order to get a ticket to participate in the draw," he said.
The government's NT$85.7 billion (US$2.6 billion) budget plan to fund the shopping voucher program is aimed at stimulating Taiwan's slumping retail sector and boosting the overall economy.

The legislature adopted a bill last week authorizing the government to issue NT$3,600 (US$108) in consumption vouchers to each Taiwanese citizen, foreign spouses of Taiwanese citizens and infants born before the end of March 2009.

The vouchers are expected to be distributed from Jan. 18, a week before the Lunar New Year holiday. They will be valid until Sept. 30, 2009 and retailers must claim reimbursement for the vouchers by Oct. 31 of that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien County launches non-toxic meat products

TEXT.P: Hualien County in eastern Taiwan has launched a series of instant packages of cooked meat made with the county's non-toxic farming produce, Hualien County Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan said Monday.
The instant packages, with choices of pork, lamb, or beef, were launched by the Kuangfeng Farmers' Association Nov. 26, Hsieh said.

The association spent two years establishing the country's first non-toxic meat process plant and has obtained certifications of HACCP--Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points and ISO22000 on food safety, Hsieh said.
Lin Ching-shui, secretary-general of the farmers' association, said the newly launched products are low-fat foods and contain no MSG or chemical additives.

The recipes for the instant packages were designed by Tsai Meng-chen, a researcher at the country's Food Industry Research and Development Institute, and Lien Ai-ching, a writer of many famous cookbooks, Hsieh said.
Chen Teh-hui, chief of the county's Bureau of Agriculture, expressed the hope that the launch of the products will attract more support for the county's non- toxic farming.

The county's non-toxic farming project, which started five years ago, banned the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers in farm produce and antibiotics in aquaculture products, according to another agriculture official in the county.
Contract farmlands have to pass tests conducted on soil and water resources for heavy metal contamination, and products are tested for pesticide residues before being labeled and put on the market.

The non-toxic farming project operates under a food safety framework similar to organic agriculture, except that the project covers a wider range of products, including fishery products, the official said.
In addition, non-toxic farming does not require that farmlands lie fallow for three years before the first planting, although it still requires strict land quality tests, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum offering discounts on gift items

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum (NPM), in coordination with the government's economic stimulus plans, is offering steep discounts on a range of items in its gift shops and on all food in its restaurants during the month of December, its director Chou Kung-shin said Monday.

"We want to do what we can to help the economy," Chou said at a press conference, adding that the museum will also be accepting the shopping vouchers to be issued to Taiwan citizens by the government next month.

"With the decline of the economy, the wallets of consumers have also shrunk quite a bit," said Chou. "In response to the government's call to increase consumer spending and stimulate the economy, the NPM has come up with a rebate plan to offer the best discounts on our merchandise."
Heather Chun-huan Ho, managing director of the NPM shop and restaurant, said at the press conference that the museum is focusing on the gift giving customs of local Taiwanese.

The discounted items include Huai-su calligraphy derived products, ties and silk scarves, tea mugs, stationery, low-relief bronze pieces, and tea gift sets, she said, adding that free gift-wrapping service will also be provided.
"We have selected 150 gift items that are being offered at 10 percent discount, " Ho said. "Discounts of 40 percent on other items are aimed at students and other low income groups."
In addition, Ho said the NPM has designated a 40 percent sales area that will be maintained until the products are sold out.

"For art lovers, this unprecedented sale is the perfect opportunity to purchase some valuable artworks, " said Ho. "In addition, there is a series of 27 Huai-su products, such as stationery items, silk scarves, ties, and shawls. These are favorites among foreign visitors."
The Huai-su products, with their beautiful calligraphy, have been highly praised by many corporations, and they make ideal gifts for friends abroad, she added.

Also on sale will be a variety of other items such as red envelopes, fashionable products for daily use, various reproductions of calligraphies and paintings, DVDs on museum artifacts and postcards, Ho said.
Furthermore, all NPM cafes and restaurants are now offering a 20 percent discount, she added, urging consumers to consider shopping at the NPM for Christmas and New Year gifts.
The National Palace Museum, located in Tienmu, Taipei City, has a one of the world's largest permanent collections of over 650,000 pieces of ancient Chinese artifacts and artworks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city government to spend NT$20 million to host movie shoot

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government plans to spend NT$20 million (US$596,747) to finance a feature film that will allow the world to see the unique characteristics of the northern Taiwanese city, a senior city government official said Tuesday.

Yang Hsiao-Tung, spokesman for the city government and director of the Department of Information and Tourism, disclosed at a discussion with Taiwanese directors that shooting of the film will hopefully begin in March or April next year.
He added that the city government will invite award-winning director Hou Hsiao- hsien to produce the film and Hsiao Ya-chuan to direct it.

Yang noted that many cities have left indelible imprints on people's minds because they served as backdrops in highly successful movies, such as Rome in the 1953 movie Roman Holiday, New York City in the 2008 film Sex and the City, London in the 2001 film Bridget Jones's Diary, and Chiufen -- a mountain village in Taipei County put back on the map because of Hou's 1989 award-winning film, A City of Sadness.
More recently, the small town of Hengchun in the southernmost county of Pingtung became a favorite spot for local holidaymakers because of the box office smash Cape No. 7, he added.
Yang said the film should reflect Taipei's beauty, vitality, color and other outstanding aspects in order to help the city attract foreign tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 10, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Opening of the Techno Culture Expo 2008. Date and Time: 9 a.m., Wednesday, Dec. 10, 2008. Place: No.1, Bade Road, section 1. Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: Vice President Vincent Siew. Organizers: The Association of Digital Culture Taiwan Press Contact: 23278749

DOC.HEADLINE: Many school children ride motorcycles without helmets: survey

TEXT.P: Many children in Taiwan are transported to school by motorcycle everyday without wearing helmets, which puts them at higher risk of becoming victims in of road traffic accidents, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by the Jing Chuan Child Safety Foundation.
The survey was conducted between mid and late November among 1,409 students from 22 elementary schools around Taiwan.
The results revealed that of the 42.3 percent of children who are transported on a motorcycle every day, approximately 50 percent seldom or never wear a helmet.
Seventeen percent of the respondents have had motorcycle accidents, 31.4 percent of whom were not wearing a helmet at the time.
The survey found that the low rate of helmet wearing among school children is closely linked to parents' attitude on the issue.
Nearly 40 percent of the respondents said their parents do not require them to wear a helmet, and 21.2 percent said their parents seldom wear a helmet.
However, 50.5 percent of the children indicated a preference for wearing a helmet because they feel safer with one, are afraid of being fined, or think a helmet can shield them from the wind and sun.
Another 20 percent of the respondents said they hate wearing a helmet because it makes them feel uncomfortable, makes them sweat, or is too troublesome.
Nearly 10 percent of the children said they wear a helmet only to avoid being fined.

Lin Yueh-chin, assistant executive director of the foundation, called the public's attention to the safety issues concerning motorcycle riding, as an increasingly larger number of people are choosing to ride a motorcycles instead of driving cars at a time when the economy is doing poorly.

As shown in statistics from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the number of motorcycles in Taiwan rose by an average 34,000 per month during the first 10 months of this year to a total of 14.32 million, Lin said.
Among the fatal road traffic accidents in Taiwan, those involving a motorcycle rider or passenger accounted for 58.9 percent, she said.

Meanwhile, statistics from the National Police Agency indicate that in motorcycle accidents, the death rate among those wearing a a helmet stood at 0.73 percent, which was much lower than the 5.31 percent among those without a helmet, she noted.

In an effort to improve the safety of school children, the foundation has successfully solicited the donation of 240 child helmets by the Rotary Club of Taipei Tunghua for distribution in seven elementary schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: Easy-to-carry 'electric pills' developed

TEXT.P: A novel "electric pill" that can generate three watts of electricity to power portable digital devices has the potential to become a more eco-friendly alternative to existing batteries, the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) reported Tuesday.

The only residue of the power generation process is sodium metaborate (NaBO2), a low-toxic chemical that is much less hazardous to the environment than the conventional electricity cell, according to the Hsinchu-based institute.

Tsao Fang-hei, a division chief at ITRI's Energy and Environment Research Laboratories, explained that when added to a micro fuel cell, the white pills of concentrated hydrogen can easily produce electricity by interacting with the catalysts inside the cell.

"A pill of two to three centimeters in diameter can provide three watts electricity for at least one hour," said Tsao. The electricity is sufficient to power a mobile phone or even a laptop computer, he added.
The ITRI said it is trying to transfer the related technologies to private manufacturers, and the easy-to-use, easy-to-carry pills may one day become a better alternative to batteries on the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung County hopes for highway extension to mountainous area

TEXT.P: Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng has said that the county government will ask for subsidies from the central government to have a county highway extended to a mountainous area to provide more convenient travel for local residents.
Huang made the remarks in response to Taichung County Councilor Tsai Cheng- kuei's request at a council session on Nov. 27.
Tsai urged the local government to ask for the central government's support on extending Highway No. 4 to the county's eastern township of Tungshih to ease travel for local residents.
The highway, which started operation in 2000, begins from Cingshuei township in the county's west to Fengyuan City, where the county hall is located.

The part from Fengyuan City to Wufeng township, the county's southernmost area, is currently under construction, but the road does not cover the county's eastern area, which includes Tungshih township and Hoping township.

Huang said he has introduced the county government's plan for road extension to Transportation and Communications Minister Mao Chi-kuo, and the process of designing the extension are likely to start next year.
But he added that he will continue to plea for funding from the central government to ensure its support on the extension.
Tsai also asked Huang about the plan to resume operation of the Central Cross- Island Highway in the county.

The east-west bound road, which covers mountainous regions from Taichung County, Nantou County, and Hualien County, was seriously damaged in the 921 earthquake in 1999, especially the part in Hoping township in eastern Taichung County.
Restoration efforts were made continuously, but were never completed as rains and earthquakes and their aftermath have caused parts of the road to collapse.
Huang said the section from Tungshih township to Guguan Scenic Area in Hoping township will soon be resumed, and follow-up restorations will continue section by section.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president's close aide freed on bail

TEXT.P: Former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng was freed on bail of NT$500,000 Tuesday, after being held in custody since November on suspicion of involvement in graft.

The Taipei District Court granted permission to the anti-corruption Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office to free Ma, who is known as the right-hand man of former President Chen Shui-bian.
The court however retained its ban on Ma leaving the country or changing his place of residence.
Ma was detained on Nov. 4 during a probe into a "special state affairs fund" misappropriation case involving the former president .

At the time, the district court ruled in favor of detaining Ma on grounds that he could tamper with evidence in the case and that he was suspected of committing a crime that carries a sentence of more than five years in prison.

Ma was indicted, along with former first lady Wu Shu-jen, in another case on Nov. 3, 2006 for allegedly helping Wu embezzle NT$14.8 million in public funds set aside for the official discretionary use of then President Chen Shui-bian.
Chen, who was spared indictment at the time because he had presidential immunity, was taken into custody Nov. 12 in a probe into his role in that case and others during his eight-year presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA cautions Taiwanese against Nigeria-originated scams

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials urged Taiwanese nationals Tuesday to be on the alert against scams involving perpetrators from Nigeria by means of emails.

Chang Yun-ping, director-general of the ministrys Department of African Affairs, issued the warning at a regular press briefing, saying that the ministry received two scam cases in December alone, in which Taiwanese victims were asked to send valuable products or remittances to Nigeria.

He added, however, that the ministry had cooperated with the Nigerian police as well as Taiwanese businessmen operating there, and have successfully prevented the products and money from falling into the hands of the fraudsters.
Fraud cases are most rampant in the Nigerian city of Lagos, the countrys major commercial hub located in its south, Chang said, adding that fraudsters, however, commit crimes overseas as well.

The scam artists usually break into the victims email account and send to the victims family messages that he or she has been robbed of money and passport and need immediate monetary assistance in the form of remittances, according to Chang.
He suggested families who receive such emails should verify with the original account user, while contacting MOFAs local representative office in the Nigerian capital of Abuja.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen, who had served part of his diplomatic duties in Nigeria, also warned Taiwanese businesses against the risks of doing trade with the African country, as he saidthey can fake all kinds of official documents, including letters of authority.

He advised Taiwanese businesses to carefully verify the authenticity of documents before shipping out their products as there have been reports of Taiwanese enterprises suffering losses due to the counterfeit documents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan makes progress in 2008 Bribe Payers Index report

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made improvements in its perceived corruption levels, according to the 2008 Bribe Payers Index (BPI) report issued by Transparency International (TI) Tuesday, despite wide publicity concerning prosecutors' investigations into the former first family's alleged bribe-taking, embezzlement and money laundering scandals.
TI-Taiwan released the report at a news conference in Taipei on behalf of TI -- a global coalition against corruption based in Berlin -- to coincide with International Anti-Corruption Day.

The TI survey assesses the supply side of corruption in 22 of the world's leading exporting countries, based on interviews with 2,742 senior business executives in 26 countries. The combined global exports of the 22 countries represent 75 percent of the world's total.

The BPI, expressed on a scale of zero to 10, is a measure of how willing a nation appears to be to comply with demands for corrupt business practices. The higher the score, the lower the likelihood of companies from the country in question engaging in bribery when doing business abroad.

Taiwan received a score of 7.5, sharing the No. 14 spot with South Africa and South Korea but lagging behind Singapore, which placed ninth along with France and the United States with a score of 8.1, and Hong Kong, which ranked 13th with a score of 7.6.
China ranked 21st with a score of 6.5 among the 22 countries -- only slightly better than Russia, which placed last with a score of 5.9.

Topping the list were Belgium and Canada, each with a score of 8.8, followed by the Netherlands and Switzerland, which shared third place with scores of 8.7, while Germany, Japan and the United Kingdom placed fifth with scores of 8.6. Australia ranked eighth with a score of 8.5.
In TI's 2006 BPI report, Taiwan placed 26th with a score of 5.41 -- one notch above China's 21st place with a score of 4.94. That survey evaluated 30 leading exporting countries.

TI said in a news release that there is evidence that "a number of companies from major exporting countries still use bribery to win business abroad, despite awareness of its damaging impact on corporate reputations and ordinary communities."

The organization urged the governments of major exporting countries to redouble their efforts to enforce existing laws and regulations on foreign bribery. It also urged companies to adopt effective anti-bribery programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese oranges to be shipped to China Dec. 15: COA

TEXT.P: China on Tuesday ordered 1,200 metric tons of Taiwanese oranges which will be shipped Dec. 15 via the direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links to be inaugurated that same day, according to the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).
COA Secretary-General Hsu Han-ching, who is in Fuzhou in China's Fujian Province, made the announcement during a telephone interview with the CNA.

According to Hsu, China ordered the oranges at a price of NT$13 (US$0.39) per kilogram and the produce will be shipped to destinations in the coastal regions of China next Monday. On that same day, the accords on the opening of two-way direct daily charter flights and shipping services, inked by Taiwan and China in early November, will take effect.

Of the 1,200 metric tons of oranges ordered, 1,000 metric tons will be delivered from Yunlin County and 200 metric tons from Kaohsiung County, both in southern Taiwan, in an arrangement that resulted from coordinated efforts by agricultural product distribution companies on both sides of the strait, Hsu said.

Asked whether China will buy more Taiwanese fruit in the future, Hsu said this is a goal that the COA will pursue. China has also shown interest in purchasing Taiwan's wax apples, pineapples and custard apples, he added.
According to officials of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, the council hopes that these export efforts will help to boost record low orange prices on the domestic market.

Orange prices in Taiwan have dipped to a record low of NT$10 per kilogram for fine quality oranges, and NT$5 per kilogram on average for those of lower quality produced in the southern regions of the island in a period from November to April.

Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, clinched the direct cross- strait transportation link agreements with his Taiwan counterpart Chiang Pin- kung in Taipei during an unprecedented visit by Chen to Taiwan last month.
He promised to purchase locally grown oranges, after he learned of a glut of the fruit in central and southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung to use prizes to attract shopping voucher spenders

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu disclosed Tuesday that consumers who spend their shopping vouchers -- to be issued by the central government in January -- in his central city will have a chance to win one of three new cars or even a large house as an incentive.

Hu said the Taichung city government will work with local construction companies to provide a house no smaller than 50 pings (one ping equals 36 square feet) with a market value of between NT$5 million and NT$10 million for a lucky draw to be held by the end of February.
"The lucky winner will have several houses in various styles from which to choose," Hu said, adding that "the winner can even pick the house facing in his or her preferred direction."
The mayor's plan to attract people to spend their consumption vouchers in Taichung has won the support of many members of the city council.
Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi said the city government is prepared to give away gifts worth a total of NT$20 million, including three cars each worth between NT$500,000 and NT$1 million.
Hsiao added that the full details of the draw will be announced between Jan. 7 and Jan. 10.

"All a person needs to do is spend a required amount in consumption vouchers in Taichung and collect three stamp marks from Taichung tourist attractions in order to get a ticket to participate in the draw," he said.
The government's NT$85.7 billion (US$2.6 billion) budget plan to fund the shopping voucher program is aimed at stimulating Taiwan's slumping retail sector and boosting the overall economy.

The legislature adopted a bill last week authorizing the government to issue NT$3,600 (US$108) in consumption vouchers to each Taiwanese citizen, foreign spouses of Taiwanese citizens and infants born before the end of March 2009.

The vouchers are expected to be distributed from Jan. 18, a week before the Lunar New Year holiday. They will be valid until Sept. 30, 2009 and retailers must claim reimbursement for the vouchers by Oct. 31 of that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien County launches non-toxic meat products

TEXT.P: Hualien County in eastern Taiwan has launched a series of instant packages of cooked meat made with the county's non-toxic farming produce, Hualien County Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan said Monday.
The instant packages, with choices of pork, lamb, or beef, were launched by the Kuangfeng Farmers' Association Nov. 26, Hsieh said.

The association spent two years establishing the country's first non-toxic meat process plant and has obtained certifications of HACCP--Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points and ISO22000 on food safety, Hsieh said.
Lin Ching-shui, secretary-general of the farmers' association, said the newly launched products are low-fat foods and contain no MSG or chemical additives.

The recipes for the instant packages were designed by Tsai Meng-chen, a researcher at the country's Food Industry Research and Development Institute, and Lien Ai-ching, a writer of many famous cookbooks, Hsieh said.
Chen Teh-hui, chief of the county's Bureau of Agriculture, expressed the hope that the launch of the products will attract more support for the county's non- toxic farming.

The county's non-toxic farming project, which started five years ago, banned the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers in farm produce and antibiotics in aquaculture products, according to another agriculture official in the county.
Contract farmlands have to pass tests conducted on soil and water resources for heavy metal contamination, and products are tested for pesticide residues before being labeled and put on the market.

The non-toxic farming project operates under a food safety framework similar to organic agriculture, except that the project covers a wider range of products, including fishery products, the official said.
In addition, non-toxic farming does not require that farmlands lie fallow for three years before the first planting, although it still requires strict land quality tests, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum offering discounts on gift items

TEXT.P: The National Palace Museum (NPM), in coordination with the government's economic stimulus plans, is offering steep discounts on a range of items in its gift shops and on all food in its restaurants during the month of December, its director Chou Kung-shin said Monday.

"We want to do what we can to help the economy," Chou said at a press conference, adding that the museum will also be accepting the shopping vouchers to be issued to Taiwan citizens by the government next month.

"With the decline of the economy, the wallets of consumers have also shrunk quite a bit," said Chou. "In response to the government's call to increase consumer spending and stimulate the economy, the NPM has come up with a rebate plan to offer the best discounts on our merchandise."
Heather Chun-huan Ho, managing director of the NPM shop and restaurant, said at the press conference that the museum is focusing on the gift giving customs of local Taiwanese.

The discounted items include Huai-su calligraphy derived products, ties and silk scarves, tea mugs, stationery, low-relief bronze pieces, and tea gift sets, she said, adding that free gift-wrapping service will also be provided.
"We have selected 150 gift items that are being offered at 10 percent discount, " Ho said. "Discounts of 40 percent on other items are aimed at students and other low income groups."
In addition, Ho said the NPM has designated a 40 percent sales area that will be maintained until the products are sold out.

"For art lovers, this unprecedented sale is the perfect opportunity to purchase some valuable artworks, " said Ho. "In addition, there is a series of 27 Huai-su products, such as stationery items, silk scarves, ties, and shawls. These are favorites among foreign visitors."
The Huai-su products, with their beautiful calligraphy, have been highly praised by many corporations, and they make ideal gifts for friends abroad, she added.

Also on sale will be a variety of other items such as red envelopes, fashionable products for daily use, various reproductions of calligraphies and paintings, DVDs on museum artifacts and postcards, Ho said.
Furthermore, all NPM cafes and restaurants are now offering a 20 percent discount, she added, urging consumers to consider shopping at the NPM for Christmas and New Year gifts.
The National Palace Museum, located in Tienmu, Taipei City, has a one of the world's largest permanent collections of over 650,000 pieces of ancient Chinese artifacts and artworks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city government to spend NT$20 million to host movie shoot

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government plans to spend NT$20 million (US$596,747) to finance a feature film that will allow the world to see the unique characteristics of the northern Taiwanese city, a senior city government official said Tuesday.

Yang Hsiao-Tung, spokesman for the city government and director of the Department of Information and Tourism, disclosed at a discussion with Taiwanese directors that shooting of the film will hopefully begin in March or April next year.
He added that the city government will invite award-winning director Hou Hsiao- hsien to produce the film and Hsiao Ya-chuan to direct it.

Yang noted that many cities have left indelible imprints on people's minds because they served as backdrops in highly successful movies, such as Rome in the 1953 movie Roman Holiday, New York City in the 2008 film Sex and the City, London in the 2001 film Bridget Jones's Diary, and Chiufen -- a mountain village in Taipei County put back on the map because of Hou's 1989 award-winning film, A City of Sadness.
More recently, the small town of Hengchun in the southernmost county of Pingtung became a favorite spot for local holidaymakers because of the box office smash Cape No. 7, he added.
Yang said the film should reflect Taipei's beauty, vitality, color and other outstanding aspects in order to help the city attract foreign tourists.
