DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 10, or the 13th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1898: Spain signs treaty with the United States, ending the Spanish-American War and ceding Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States in exchange for US$20 million dollars.
1901: The first Nobel Prize presentation ceremonies are held separately in Stockholm, Sweden, and Oslo, Norway.
1902: Construction of the Aswan Dam is completed in the upper section of the Nile River in southwest Egypt.
1911: French scientist Marie Curie wins a second Nobel Prize, becoming the first person to do so.
1929: Chen Tu-siu, one of the Chinese Communist Party's co-founders, issues a statement to party comrades calling Joseph Stalin an opportunist who caused a massive split within the Communist Party.
1936: Britain's King Edward VIII abdicates, becoming the Duke of Windsor. He is succeeded by his brother, George VI.
1941: Japanese warplanes sink the British battleships "Repulse" and "Prince of Wales," killing nearly 800 in the South China Sea.
1948: The Third United Nations General Assembly adopts the Convention on Genocide and Human Rights.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek flies from Chengtu, Szechwan Province, to Taipei.
1952: The ROC government drafts its first four-year economic development plan.
1955: Cambodian Prime Minister Norodom Sihanouk arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1959: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Ku Cheng-kang as the acting secretary-general of the National Assembly.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Gabon.
1973: A five-day Seminar on Agricultural Development with special reference to Taiwan is opened at the JCRR (Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction) Building in Taipei.
1974: Toshio Urabe, newly appointed chief of the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1975: China Petroleum Corporation President Jerome Hu confirms the discovery of undersea oil deposits some 15 kilometers west of central Taiwan.
1975: A 12.5-kilometer section of the North-South Freeway between Chungli and Yangmei is completed. A 42-kilometer section of the roadway is now open to traffic.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her ceaseless work in helping the destitute.
1979: The Formosa Incident, during which Formosa magazine demonstrators clash with police, occurs in Kaohsiung.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh is awarded as the co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry at the Stockholm Concert Hall in Sweden.
1988: Mainland Chinese troops shoot into crowds of Tibetans demonstrating for human rights in Lhasa.
1988: The Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDF), manufactured by ROC aviation experts, are formally named "Ching-kuo" class fighters by President Lee Teng- hui.
1993: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela says he and South African President F.W. de Klerk are bound by the Nobel Peace Prize they accepted to spend the rest of their lives building a democratic South Africa free of racial discrimination.
1996: The Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs is established. The Taiwan Independence Party, which is a Democratic Progressive Party splinter group, is also established.
1999: The first human rights monument in Asia is officially inaugurated, on Green Island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan.
1999: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), formally names Annette Lu as his running mate for the 2000 presidential election.
2000: Under an amnesty decree issued by President Chen Shui-bian, 21 prisoners are released on International Human Rights Day.
2001: Fabrice de Murat, general manager of L'Oreal Taiwan, is re-elected chairman of the European Council for Commerce and Trade (ECCT).
2001: A delegation of high-ranking Taiwan police officers arrive in Beijing for a 12-day visit to the mainland. The delegation is the first of its kind to visit the mainland since the two sides separated following the end of China's civil war in 1949.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A young man, when at home, should be a good son; when out in the world, a good citizen. He should be circumspect and truthful. He should be in sympathy with all men, but intimate with men of moral character. If he has time and opportunity to spare, after the performance of those duties, he should then employ them in literary pursuits."

DOC.HEADLINE: President supports proposal to revise Detention Act

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed support Tuesday for a proposal to amend the Detention Act in a way that would differentiate the treatment of detained criminal suspects from that for convicts.
Ma made the remarks when asked during a TV interview to comment on the current situation in which detained suspects in Taiwan are treated as if they are convicts.

The issue has been widely debated since former President Chen Shui-bian was held by prosecutors last month to facilitate an investigation into alleged corruption involving Chen and alleged money laundering by the former first family.
Ma agreed that there is room for improvement in the situation, noting that the Detention Act has not undergone any major change since its enactment more than 60 years ago.
Ma, who has served as a minister of justice, admitted that detained suspects could be better treated because they have not been found guilty of any crimes.
Owing to an insufficient number of prisons in Taiwan, however, detention centers very often also function as prisons, which leads to similar management of the two different kinds of facilities.

While some have argued that the pre-trial detention of criminal suspects is a violation of human rights, Ma pointed out that a similar system has been in practice in the United States since 1984 to prevent criminal suspects from committing other crimes before trial, running away or colluding with other co- conspirators.

In Taiwan, prosecutors are required to obtain permission from a court before taking any criminal suspects into custody, and in Chen's case, the court only made a decision after a nine-hour session, which showed how carefully considered the decision was, Ma said.

Asked about the possibility of granting Chen a special pardon if he is convicted, Ma said it was premature to discuss the matter because Chen has not even been charged. Even if he were formally indicted and put on trial, he should still be considered innocent before a conviction, Ma added.
As to whether it is appropriate to take a former president into custody, Ma said he is also thinking about the issue.
On the other hand, Ma said, he is also wondering if it is proper to allow a former president to enjoy privileges that normal people do not have.
According to Ma, Chen has not received any discriminatory treatment in the detention center, provided with a room and food that are similar to those given to other inmates.
Instead of giving special treatment to specific persons, it would be a better solution to seek to improve the general treatment for detained suspects, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU welcomes Taiwan's accession to WTO gov't procurement accord
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/10/08 12:39:41 (By P.C. Tang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The European Commission, the top decision-making body of the European Union, on Tuesday gave a "hearty welcome" to Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization's (WTO's) Government Procurement Agreement (GPA).

The WTO Committee on Government Procurement formally approved on Tuesday the accession of Taiwan -- under the name the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu -- to the GPA, giving Taiwan's companies open access to public contracts in the 40 other GPA economies and vice versa.
It was the second time in nine days that the European Commission had welcomed Taiwan's joining the GPA.
"This GPA accession offers the EU and Taiwan's suppliers access to each other's public procurement markets, " said Catherine Ashton, the European commissioner for trade.

Charlie McCreevy, another commissioner in charge of internal markets, said that it has always been one of the European Commission's goals to have the number of GPA economies increased, because an enlarged GPA grouping means European suppliers would have broader access to Taiwan's regular government procurement projects.

According to the European Commission, Taiwan's government procurement market totaled in excess of 120 billion euros (NT$5.2 trillion) over the past 10 years, with European companies taking a 3 percent market share worth about 3.7 billion euros.

The WTO plurilateral GPA was first negotiated during the Tokyo Round and entered into force on Jan. 1, 1981. Its purpose is to open up as many public contracts as possible to international competition.

The agreement is designed to make laws, regulations, procedures and practices regarding government procurement more transparent and to ensure they do not protect domestic products or suppliers, or discriminate against foreign products or suppliers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
3.8-month bonus plan rejected

TEXT.P: Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Wednesday that a plan submitted by the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) to give bureau employees a year-end bonus equal to 3.8 months of salary has been rejected.
Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Yeh said he has already asked the bureau to come up with a new plan within two weeks.

At the meeting, Yeh was grilled over whether the BNHI would maintain its tradition of paying higher-than-normal year-end bonuses to its staff in the face of an economic recession and the bureau's snowballing operational deficit.

According to a statement made by Yeh in early November, the BNHI's deficit for this year may top NT$26 billion (US$776.12 million), and the bureau has estimated that next year's deficit will be more than NT$20 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Protecting infrastructure key to national security: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Wednesday that because Taiwan is heavily dependent on key infrastructure for its future development, he has asked government agencies to give priority to strengthening the protection of the country's infrastructure to ensure homeland security.

Since the 9/11 terror attacks, all nations in the world are placing emphasis on homeland security, said Liu during his address to the 2008 International Conference on Homeland Security and Technology in Taipei.The government has the responsibility to protect the property and lives of its people.
Liu suggested that Taiwan faces a much lower risk of a terrorist attack than some other countries but that it is still heavily reliant on its gas and electrical facilities for its economic activity.
"The daily lives of our people also rely on these important facilities,the premier said.
In addition to gas and electrical facilities, the government also considers the financial system and Internet network as key components of the country's infrastructure.
If we encounter natural or man-made disasters, it will cause great harm to the nation, including to our stock market and trading activities,Liu contended.
He said he has already requested all relevant government agencies to develop in- depth risk assessments of the nation's key public facilities.
I am asking all government agencies to strengthen security measures and the protection of these key components of our infrastructure,Liu said.

The premier has also asked the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of Defense, to increase cooperation on security issues with other countries and create commercial opportunities in the area of security and infrastructure protection.

The 2008 International Conference on Homeland Security and Technology is being held so that Taiwan can exchange its experiences, views and policies on national infrastructure protection and security with other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: GPA accession will have little impact on Taiwanese businesses: agency

TEXT.P: Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization's (WTO's) Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) will have little impact on domestic businesses in the initial stages, the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission (PCC) said Wednesday.
The commission reasoned that Taiwan was already an open market for foreign bidders and suppliers before the country was admitted as a full member of the GPA a day earlier.

Between 2005 and 2007, PCC officials said, foreign bidders won 26.87 percent of all contracts on public procurement projects in Taiwan, reflecting the fact that the country's public procurement markets are already "very open."

The officials quoted international tallies as indicating that foreign suppliers won 13.8 percent of the public procurement contracts in Japan in 2002, while the figure relating to the United States for 1999 stood at a mere 5.3 percent.

Meanwhile, they noted, the WTO Committee on Government Procurement's formal approval on Tuesday's accession of Taiwan to the GPA -- under the name of Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu -- also gave Taiwanese companies open access to public contracts in the 40 other GPA economies.
In Taiwan's favor, they went on, GPA accession offers local suppliers access to the U.S. government procurement market, worth in excess of US$300 billion annually.

The WTO multilateral GPA was first hammered out during the WTO Tokyo Round of negotiations and entered into force Jan. 1, 1981. Its purpose is to open up as many public contracts as possible to international competition.

The agreement is designed to make laws, regulations, procedures and practices regarding government procurement more transparent and to ensure they do not protect domestic products or suppliers, or discriminate against foreign products or suppliers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for December advancing 230 points to end at 4,691, with 113,641 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for January gained 224 points to finish at 4,651, with 3,050 contracts traded, while March futures increased 226 points to close at 4,615, with 73 contracts changing hands.
June futures advanced 223 points to close at 4,585, with 38 contract transactions, while September futures rose 226 points to finish at 4,400, with 39 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 4,461 for December, 4,427 for January, 4,389 for March, 4,362 for June and 4,174 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 186.21 points to finish at 4,658.87, on turnover of NT$92.37 billion (US$2.76 billion).

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher, with TE futures for December, January, March and September all surging by the maximum allowable 7 percent.
December TE futures rose 11.6 points to close at 177.35, with 7,264 contracts traded, while January TE futures increased 11.4 points to finish at 174.7, with 164 contract transactions.

March TE futures gained 11.15 points to finish at 171.1, with six contract transactions, while September TE futures rose 10.4 points to end at 159.35, with five contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.
December TF futures gained 36 points to finish at 606, with 6,446 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures increased 33.6 points to finish at 600, with 126 contracts traded.

March TF futures lost 11.8 points to end at 563, with two contracts traded, while June TF futures advanced 37.4 points to close at 583, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Combination of technology and culture may boost the economy: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew suggested Wednesday that Taiwan strengthen its efforts to combine the country's cultural and technology industries, which he said mayhelp boost the economyin the face of the global financial crisis.

Speaking at the opening ceremony of the TechnoCulture Exposition, which is being held in Taipei from Dec. 10-12, Siew said that with Taiwan's global edge in technology and its cultural diversity, the country should encourage more partnerships between the two industries.

Culture is the core of our future competitiveness, Siew said, adding that with the combination of digital technology, it may serve asa new roadon which Taiwan's economy can rely for growth and prosperity in the coming years.
Siew cited severalsmall countries,such as Singapore, Ireland and the Netherlands, as examples of countries that have found their niches in the global cultural market.
Each of them, Siew said, have fewer than 20 million people yet rank among the world's top 10 cultural product exporters.

The vice president said that once the two industries have been integrated, Taiwan should seek to optimize their potential economic value in line with the government's aim to build aculture-centered" position on the global stage.
The exposition is focused on exploring the possibilities of combining culture and creativity with technology, according to the organizer, the Association of Digital Culture Taiwan.

Huang Pi-twan, the minister of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs, said that the exposition not only showcases traditional cultural preservation and applications, but will also improve Taiwans visibility and competitiveness in the global arena.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's security focus should be natural disasters: U.S. expert

TEXT.P: Taiwan's critical infrastructure protection policies should focus on the threat natural disasters pose to the country's key facilities, asserted Paul Rosenzweig, the U.S. deputy assistant secretary of homeland security, at a conference in Taipei Wednesday.
Rosenzweig said that threats to a nation's critical infrastructure arise not only from man-made causes, such as terrorism, but also from natural disasters.

The United States has just been through the hurricane season. Taiwan has also just passed through the typhoon season. These are all threats to a nation's security,Rosenzweig explained at the International Conference on Homeland Security and Technology.

Rosenzweig stressed that the essence of critical infrastructure protection (CIP) is to identify which facilities are vulnerable to natural disasters, or even terrorist attacks, and then work out a strategy to protect them.
For Taiwan, natural disasters top all other threats to its infrastructure. This is what Taiwan should take into account for its CIP policy," he said.

American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Director Stephen Young said, however, that maintaining the continued security of the global trading system was also important to Taiwan and the U.S., and he noted that Washington and Taipei have cooperated closely in this area.
"The challenge is to maintain the openness and vibrancy of our economic and commercial ties while ensuring that this openness cannot be used against us," Young said.

One joint program put in place in 2005, Young said, is the Container Security Initiative (CSI) , which ensures the safety of goods flowing from and through the U.S. and Taiwan, and expedites the flow of Taiwan's own shipments to the U.S.

The CSI primarily targets terrorist activity but also can detect other forms of illicit activity. For instance, Young said, U.S. and Taiwan Customs officers have stopped shipments of contraband, including precursor drugs, counterfeit currency, and products that violate intellectual property rights, through the initiative.
Another program mentioned by Young was the Megaports Initiative, established in 2003, to prevent terrorists from smuggling nuclear or other radioactive materials through commercial shipping channels.
Taiwan began working with the U.S. to implement the program in 2006.

"This high-tech scanning has minimal impact on port operations but facilitates trade by increasing the security of seaports. This cooperation is a potent symbol of our commitment to international maritime security," Young said.

Taiwan also cooperates with the U.S. on export controls, especially in the area of enforcement, technology transfers and transshipment under the U.S. Export Control and Related Border Security program, Young said.

Taiwan's recent development of electronic passports is also welcomed by Washington, Young said, noting that the more secure a nation's travel documents, the more able it is to protect itself from international terrorist and criminal activity.

He warned, however, that Taiwan's efforts to introduce the new passport needed to be "matched by a corresponding strengthening of application procedures so passports are not inadvertently issued to people who are not Taiwan citizens."

Though trade and the free movement of goods are critical to Taiwan's economy, the greatest blows to its infrastructure have come at home, and Rosenzweig suggested that Taiwan needed a risk-based approach that was flexible.
The U.S. had learned in New Orleans how serious a natural disaster could be if local infrastructure could not withstand the forces of nature.

The bottom line is that there is no quick approach in addressing the issue of protection for a nations infrastructure, Rosenzweig said.A risk-based approach is needed. We have to put money where it is needed the most.
If a protection strategy is not cost effective, he said, "then the government has to say you can't build such and such here.

The U.S. Department of Homeland Security has created 18 sector-specific CIP plans, each with its own governing council, ranging from information technology and energy facilities, to dams and most recently to automakers, heavy equipment manufacturers and steel producers.
We recognize that there can't be a one-size fit-all program on how to protect our infrastructure, Rosenzweig said.What you need to protect a dam is different from what you need to protect IT systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 186.21 points, to close at 4,658.87.

Finishing higher for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened at the day's low of 4,470.73 and reached a high of 4,658.87 during the session. A total of 5.11 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$92.37 billion (US$2.76 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 5.39 percent. Construction issues advanced 5.33 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 5.05 percent, textile stocks increased 3.89 percent, cement stocks gained 3.34 percent, paper and pulp issues were up 3.24 percent, plastics and chemicals shares advanced 1.82 percent, and foodstuff issues rose 1.13 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,351 to 161, with 203 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$8.97 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady plays storyteller to aboriginal children

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching visited Taitung Wednesday mainly to tell stories to aboriginal school children in that eastern county.

Dressed in a black pantsuit, the self-effacing Chow visited the National Museum of Prehistory in Taitung City, where she met students from the Chia Na Elementary School, which has a majority student body from the indigenous tribe of Bunun. She also met with pupils from the Chang Ping Elementary School, which is attended mainly by students from the indigenous Amis tribe.
Most of the museum staff did not know of the first lady's visit until they saw her entering the building.
To the Bunun school children, Chow told a story about clouded leopards and black bears -- animals that legendarily existed in Taiwan and are said to be on the brink of extinction.

To the Amis children, Chow, who retired as a legal expert from a state-run bank a couple of months ago, told a story about a youth from the aboriginal tribe of Siraya tribe in southern Taiwan and his friends.

Sixth-grader Huang Pei-hsin told the CNA that she was so excited Tuesday night she could hardly sleep after she learned that the "Aunt Chou" who was going to tell stories the next day would actually be the wife of President Ma Ying-jeou.
"I saw her on TV," said fourth-grader Lee Sheng-teh.
Chow's trip to Taitung was arranged by World Vision Taiwan in the run-up to Christmas.
Later in the day, Chow attended a Christmas celebration sponsored by World Vision Taiwan, where she met with scores of children from indigent families who are regular recipients of charity.
Over the past several months since Ma took office on May 20, Chow has traveled to southern Taiwan many times to meet with children from indigenous communities to bring them cheer.

In July, she bought high-speed rail tickets for tribal youths for them to travel from southern Taiwan to the capital city of Taipei in the north and she accompanied them to see paintings by French realist artist Jean-Francois Millet at the National Museum of History.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.097 to close at NT$33.449.
A total of US$797 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.546 and fluctuated between NT$33.430 and NT$33.547.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local department store takes legal action against Chinese partner

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based department store chain Shin Kong Mitsukoshi has applied for arbitration in Hong Kong to settle a dispute over management rights in a Beijing joint venture in which it is involved, the company announced in a statement issued Wednesday.

Shin Kong Mitsukoshi and the Beijing Haulian Group set up their joint venture department store -- Shin Kong Place -- in China's capital in April 2007, with total investment of 750 million yuan (US$109.3 million) and each party holding 50 percent of the shares.

Anonymous department store industry sources said the fact that the Taiwanese company did not take a majority stake in the joint venture meant that from the very beginning, business disputes were inevitable.

The dispute erupted when Beijing Hualian Group, suspecting problems involving construction payments, raided the department store with 200 security guards, fired most of the Taiwanese executives for allegedly taking bribes and took over management of the department store last August.

Wu Shin-da, general manager of Shin Kong Mitsukoshi's Beijing operation, was detained by Chinese security officials just as he was about to board a plane for Taiwan, a move that caused a stir among Taiwanese businessmen in China, as well as the Japanese department store sector.

Following the incident, Beijing Haulian Group refused to negotiate with Wu, prompting Shin Kong Mitsukoshi Chairman Wu Tung-hsing to embark on a marathon negotiating session lasting more than 10 hours in Beijing in September 2007 with his Chinese counterpart, Ji Xiaoan, in a vain attempt to work out a way for further cooperation.

In recent years, Shin Kong Mitsukoshi -- a merger between the Taiwanese group and Japanese retail giant Mitsukoshi Ltd. -- is said to have been trying unsuccessfully to attract foreign investment in the Beijing department store.

Owing to differences in opinion on operation and management between the two companies, Shin Kong Mitsukoshi has made great efforts to communicate with its Chinese counterpart in an attempt to continue with the partnership, but the Beijing company has constantly broken contracts and has illegally infringed on Shin Kong's management rights, the Taiwanese company said, hence the need to resort to legal action.

DOC.HEADLINE: Recycling operators battered by recession

TEXT.P: Like a viral infection, the recession has spread to all facets of Taiwan's business sector, even the humble recycling business, in which several thousand individuals who collect recyclable waste are threatened by a plunge in the prices of recyclable resources.

Recyclable resource prices have fallen from a peak at the beginning of this year and bottomed out in October. At present, scrap iron -- which previously sold for NT$20 (US$0.03) per kilogram -- now only fetches NT$2 or NT$3 per kilo.
Waste paper has not fared much better, with the price plummeting from NT$4-NT$5 per kilogram to just NT$0.5-NT$1, sighed one recycler Wednesday in Tainan County, southern Taiwan.

Things are even bleaker in central Taiwan, where the price of scrap iron has slid to even less than NT$2 per kilogram, while the price for used PET bottles -- one of the most valuable recyclable waste items -- has also dropped from NT$20 per kilogram to just NT$6.

Lin Yu-hsin, the owner of the Da Gang resource recycling company in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, told CNA that his company's recycling volume has plummeted by two thirds over the past four months, as has turnover.
"It is too painful to talk about, " Lin said, noting that some of his competitors have been forced to close.
Meanwhile, life for the some 9,000 individual recyclable waste collectors around Taiwan -- who are mostly old, poor and lack job skills -- has become even harder.

"They might not be able to earn even NT$20 for a mountain of waste paper they have sweated to collect in the alleys and streets, " said Lin Chien-huei of the Recycling Fund Management Board (RFMB) under the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
According to RFMB data, prices for recyclable waste started to climb in late 2004 and reached a peak in June this year.

Taking copper -- one of the most valuable resources in the manufacturing industry -- as an example, Lin pointed out that the price of scrap copper stood at more than US$3,000 per ton in 2004, and had climbed to over US$8,000 per ton as of June 2008.
Now, copper only fetches US$4,000 per ton, Lin said.
In the case of plastic, he went on, the price was NT$37 per kilogram in 2004, and reached NT$57 per kilogram in June before dropping to NT$46 in October.

According to EPA forecasts, recycling prices will improve in about six months to one year, and until the recession ends, Lin said the government has prepared relief programs to help tide businesses and individual waste collectors over the lean times.
In one such program, the EPA has decided to enroll 700 individual waste collectors, deploying them at local government-run recycling departments to serve as "recycling assistants."
They will be offered NT$9,900 per month in return for working four hours per day, 22 days per month, according to the EPA.
Although the money is not much, it might actually help those in urgent need, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wine guru promoting Australian wine to Taiwanese consumers

TEXT.P: A leading wine critic and vigneron in Australia is visiting Taipei on a four-day trip as part of an initiative of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei (ACIO) to promote premium Australian wine to local consumers.
James Halliday has written or co-authored over 60 books on wine since 1979, including "Oxford Companion to Wine" and "Larousse Encyclopedia of Wine," two of Australia's favorite wine titles.

"Taiwan is a very important wine market for us," said ACIO Senior Trade Commissioner Yvonne Chan, noting that Halliday's experience and capacity to teach consumers and wine writers about the subtleties and strengths of a wider range of Australian wine varieties could further boost Australian wine exports to Taiwan.

Chan also said that Australia is Taiwan's second-largest source of wine imports, adding that A$9.5 million (about US$6.28 million) -worth of its wine was imported to Taiwan between 2007 and 2008, accounting for 11 percent of Taiwan's total wine market.

The strengths of Taiwan as an export destination for Australian wine exporters are often misunderstood, Chan continued, pointing out that Taiwan is Australia's eighth-largest trading partner and adding that per capita and companies-to- market comparisons indicate that Taiwan can offer an easier first option in the region.

Halliday, who arrived in Taipei Tuesday, said he has long believed that the future of Australian wine lies in Asia, emphasizing that with the history and romance of wine linked to perceptions that Europe is the favorite source of the best quality wines, there is still a lot of work to be done to help consumers in Taiwan -- as well as other Asian countries -- understand that premium Australian wines can compete with the world's best.
"Taiwan has an affluent consumer demographic well-acquainted with quality wine, " Halliday said, adding that with only one day in Taipei, the city has already made a big impact on him.
"The sophistication of the Taiwanese lifestyle and society is far greater than I expected," he went on.

Halliday said he is also keen to help consumers understand that Australian wines, which often use screw caps, are less likely to be tainted by the cork mold that spoils around 10 percent of all wines and affects the taste of an even greater percentage of cork-bottled wine.
"Australia has taken the international lead on screw-top caps, which are incorrectly perceived by many consumers in Asia as a sign of poor quality," he said.

"In fact, screw-tops should be seen as being of particular value to buyers of premium and aged wines because they protect producers, distributors, retailers and consumers alike from cork taint and oxidation," Halliday said.

Two events will be held during Halliday's stay in Taiwan -- a tasting night for Taiwanese industry stakeholders and a dinner for local wine lovers in which Australian wines will be matched to a selection of fine cuisine.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma calls for legislative endorsement of human rights covenants

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called on the Legislative Yuan Wednesday to give its long-delayed endorsement to two international human rights documents to help implement human rights protection in Taiwan.

Referring to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights that were introduced by the United Nations in 1966 and came into force in 1976, Ma said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will again present the covenants to the Cabinet during a weekly Cabinet meeting Thursday, to highlight the importance Taiwan attaches to human rights.
After that, the documents will be forwarded to the Legislative Yuan for review, Ma said.

He made the remarks while addressing the presentation of the 2008 Asian Democracy and Human Rights Award, an annual event organized by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy to mark Dec.10 International Human Rights Day.

The winner of this year's award is Sima Samar, chairwoman of the Afghan Independent Human Rights Commission and founder of the Shuhada Organization, a non-government group dedicated to the welfare and progress of Afghan people residing inside and outside of Afghanistan, with a primary focus on the empowerment of women and girls.
Ma noted that although the Republic of China signed the treaties before losing its U.N. membership in 1971, they have never been endorsed by the country's legislature over the ensuing 40 years.

During the eight-year Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration that ended earlier this year, the covenants were submitted by the Cabinet to the legislative for endorsement four times, none of which were successful, Ma went on.

The president said the legislature's endorsement is essential before Taiwan can move on to the next steps -- seeking to deposit its ratifications of the two covenants with the United Nations and implementing them in Taiwan.

Realizing the difficulties involved in seeking to deposit the ratifications with the United Nations without membership in the organization, Taiwan did not try soliciting legislative endorsement of the covenants until the pro-independence DPP came to power in 2000.

The move, however, gave rise to fears that the covenants -- which promise the right of self-determination for all peoples -- could boost a bid by pro- independent activists to promote a plebiscite on the issue of independence vs. unification with China and escalate tension across the Taiwan Strait.

The covenants therefore failed to win the support of the then-opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party, which together held a majority in the legislature during the eight years in which the DPP was in power.
With Ma's strong support for the ratification of the covenants, it remains to be seen if his ruling KMT, which now controls two-thirds of the legislative seats, will change its attitude on the issue.

Commenting on the matter, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said his ministry will step up its communication with the legislators to facilitate early ratification of the covenants and further Taiwan's achievements in human rights protection.

Also during Wednesday's ceremony, Ma said Taiwan's improvements in its human rights record over the past 15 years have greatly impressed world human rights groups, with Taiwan's status having been changed from that of a "partly free" country to a "free" country.

He added that thanks to the government's continued efforts to uphold human rights, Taiwan has now become "the world's freest country" in terms of the people's right to assembly, which he said was very well demonstrated by several protests at the ceremony in support of a variety of causes.

The protesters included several supporters of Tibetan independence who were there to express their opposition to Ma's recent rejection of a proposed visit to Taiwan by the Dalai Lama, and an activist against the government's recent relocation of a sanatorium for leprosy patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: Butterfly populations on Orchid Island changing: biologist

TEXT.P: Population structures of butterfly species on Orchid Island off the east coast of Taiwan have been changing, possibly as a result of climate change, a biologist said Wednesday.

Jason Yeh, director of the Taipei Zoo, told reporters that a butterfly research team of zoo workers and students from National Taiwan University and National Taiwan Normal University has monitored butterfly communities on Orchid Island for two years and has found an apparent change in the population structure of various species.

Yeh said the population of Catopyrops ancyra almora -- a lycaenid butterfly originating in the Philippines -- has established a stable foothold on Orchid Island after the species was first discovered there in 1998.

He also noted that on Nov. 23, the research team, working with two biologists from Japan, caught a tagged blue-mottled butterfly, or Parantica sita niphonica, that had been released from the island of Kamigoto in Nagasaki Prefecture, southwestern Japan.
It was the second time a tagged butterfly of this species released in Kamigoto was found to have made a long-distance migration to Orchid Island, with the first sighting reported in 2007.
Parantica sita niphonica, also known as the chestnut tiger butterfly, is a medium-sized species with a wingspan that can reach 10 centimeters. It has semi- transparent blue spots on its wings.
Large numbers of this species can be found between May and July on Yangming Mountain and Datun Mountain in northern Taiwan's Yangmingshan National Park.

Since 2000, Taiwanese and Japanese lepidopterists have worked together to investigate how the little, fragile creatures can travel more than 2,000 kilometers across the ocean between Taiwan and Japan.
In recent years, at least four tagged butterflies released in Taiwan have been retrieved in Japan, while six tagged in Japan have been discovered in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait detente serves Japan's interests: KMT chief
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/08 20:11:20 (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Improving Taiwan-China relations will help to reduce tensions and create peace in the region, serving the interests of Japan and Asia as a whole, Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) chairman said in Tokyo Wednesday.

"Based on the opinion of the majority in Taiwan, President Ma Ying-jeou has a clear policy to maintain the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, but conditions are not yet ripe for the two sides to talk about unification," said Wu Poh-hsiung.

The KMT chairman made the remarks while explaining the KMT's policies and the purpose of his current visit to Japan to international reporters at a news conference sponsored by the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan. Taiwan's top representative to Japan John C. T. Feng was also present.
Wu said that the Ma administration will not support independence for Taiwan because that would lead to war with China.
Both the United States and Japan are in favor of cross-strait detente, and Taiwan is committed to making peace in the region, rather than creating trouble, he said.
However, to maintain its self-defense and safeguard cross-strait peace, Taiwan will continue to purchase weapons from the United States, he stated.

President Ma attaches great importance to Taiwan's special partnership with Japan, Wu said, adding that his own visit to Japan in his capacity as KMT chairman is aimed at helping to step up two-way interactions with various sectors in Japan.

Commenting on the controversy over the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, an uninhabited island group in the East China Sea which is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan, Wu stressed that Taiwan and Japan should set aside sovereignty disputes and handle the issue peacefully through mutually beneficial joint development, particularly in the area of fishing rights.

Meanwhile, on the upcoming fourth forum to be held by the KMT and the Communist Party of China in Shanghai Dec. 20-21, Wu said the two sides are expected to discuss economic cooperation to deal with the current economic recession.
Taiwan will also be willing to collaborate with Japan to tackle the financial turmoil, he added.
Turning to the Tibet issue, Wu said that in accordance with the Republic of China Constitution, Taiwan authorities will not support the Tibet independence movement.

Wu will proceed to Yokohama Thursday where he will call on the city's mayor, Hiroshi Nakada, and meet with representatives of the Taiwanese community there before heading to Kobe and Osaka where he will have a similar agenda.
Wu paid a call on Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara Monday at the Tokyo City Hall and relayed President Ma's desire for better ties between the two countries.
Wu arrived in Japan Sunday at the head of a 15-member delegation on his first visit to the country in his capacity as leader of Taiwan's ruling party.
He is slated to return to Taiwan Saturday.

Japan, a long-term close ally of Taiwan in the region despite the lack of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, has been wary of the warming relations between Taiwan and China since Ma came to power in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan airport MRT line expected to be completed by 2014

TEXT.P: The mass rapid transit (MRT) line that is being built to connect Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and metropolitan Taipei is scheduled to be completed by 2014, transportation officials said Wednesday.

The new facility will offer travelers faster and more convenient transportation services, cutting the distance between Taipei City and the country's main airport to 35-minutes, from the current average 45 minutes by bus, the officials said.

Once the MRT line goes into operation, the officials noted, there will be a 25 percent drop in the number of privately owned automobiles entering the airport and a 20 percent decline in the number of regular buses operating on the airport route.
The metro system, currently under construction, will alleviate traffic congestion between Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Taipei, aviation police said.

Aviation Police Office statistics show that the traffic flow toward the airport averages 30,000 vehicles a day. Road traffic around the terminals is usually jammed during the peak flight periods at the airport, the police said.
According to the Bureau of High Speed Rail which is in charge of the MRT project, work on the section of metro line between the airport and Sanchong in Taipei County has been on schedule.
However, completion of the underground section between Sanchong and Taipei will be delayed until October 2014 due to the challenging underground work, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin County promotes Taiwan's oranges amid slump in prices

TEXT.P: Southwest Taiwan's agricultural-based Yunlin county organized an "Orange Day" activity Wednesday in an all-out effort to promote the homegrown produce amid a glut and severe drop in prices.

On Wednesday, county Magistrate Su Chih-fen and the county's agricultural bureau chief Lu Cheng-chang visited Gukeng township in eastern Yunlin, which is a major orange production area in Taiwan, and urged the public to consume more oranges during the current high season.
They also promised to help sell the produce to overseas markets, including China, through direct channels.
From Dec. 15 - Jan. 25, Taiwanese consumers can buy fine-quality oranges from Yunlin at 120 specially designated venues across the country, Lu said.
According to Su, some 3,500 hectares of farmland in Yunlin are reserved for cultivating oranges -- which could yield more than 80,000 metric tons of the fruit per year.
The amount of oranges produced is apparently more than the domestic market can consume, as more growers have dedicated to cultivating the fruit in recent years.
Lu said the Yunlin county government will explore more feasible ways to sell local oranges to the whole world, including Southeast Asia, Europe and the United States.

On Tuesday, China ordered 1,200 metric tons of Taiwanese oranges at above market prices, in keeping with a promise made by visiting Chinese negotiator Chen Yunlin during his historic visit to Taiwan last month.
Chen made the promise as a goodwill gesture and to alleviate the pressure on orange growers after he learned of a glut of the fruit in central and southern Taiwan.
Of the 1,200 metric tons of oranges China ordered, 1,000 metric tons will be delivered from Yunlin County and 200 metric tons from Kaohsiung County, also in southern Taiwan.

China ordered the oranges at a price of NT$13 (US$0.39) per kilogram. Orange prices in Taiwan have dipped to a record low of NT$10 per kilogram for fine quality oranges, and NT$5 per kilogram on average for those of lower quality produced in the southern regions of the island from November to April.
Some of the local growers prefer to let their oranges become ripe and fall to the ground, instead of harvesting them due to a lack of profit.

DOC.HEADLINE: New rules for U.K. student visas to take effect next March: BTCO

TEXT.P: New rules for foreign students, including Taiwanese, applying to study in the United Kingdom will take effect beginning next March in time for the 2009 summer season, the Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) said Wednesday.

Under the new measures, students will be required by a sponsor school licensed by the U.K. Border Agency to apply for a visa, Nick Jagger, head of BTCOs British Assistance & Services Section, explained in a press conference.

Along with the requirement, Jagger said that all British public as well as private schools of all levels that intend to recruit overseas students from non- European Economic Area will also be evaluated on whether they meet the governments criteria to be issued a license.
BTCO Deputy Director Charles Garrett said that the initiative will ensure the quality of education received by overseas students, while helping the British government stamp out bogus schools.
The list of schools qualified to receive the license will be released in the near future, he added.

Under the points-based system (PBS) introduced by the U.K. in June, there are five tiers, or categories, for visa applications: Tier 1Vhighly skilled individuals; Tier 2Vskilled individuals with job offer; Tier 3Vlow skilled individuals; Tier 4 Vstudents; and Tier 5Vyouth mobility and temporary workers.

Jagger said that students who attend a licensed sponsor school will be granted up to four months of extended stay permission, during which they can apply to switch to a Tier 1 visa if they wish to remain in the U.K. to find work after their studies.

He noted, however, that if students decide to travel back to their home country, but later decide to go back to the U.K., they will also be eligible to apply for a Tier 1 visa within 12 months of graduation, which, if enoughpointsare collected on the U.K.'s points-based system assessment, will allow them to stay two years in the European country.

Jagger expressed his hopes that the plan for the student-tier of the system will attract more students to consider studying in the U.K., and enhance their willingness to remain in the country after graduating so they can contribute to the British society by working there.
According to the BTCO, the PBS was introduced to control immigration to the country and streamline the visa application process.
In the past, applicants would have to first apply to the Home Office in the U.K. and then go to the BTCO to apply for a visa if they pass the Home Office review process.

Also, with the PBS, applicants are able to do an online self-assessment before applying to enable them to calculate whether or not they are likely to meet the number of points required to be issued a visa.
Points will be awarded according to an objective criteria such as qualifications, previous earnings, competence in the English language and ability to support themselves and their dependents.
Tier 1 under the PBS was first implemented by the end of June, which Tier 2 and Tier 5 took effect last month. No date has yet been set yet for Tier 3 to be activated, according to BTCO.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Vaccine Fund passes first review in legislature

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's Health, Environment and Labor committee completed its first review of a draft amendment to the Law on the Control of Communicable Diseases, which aims to establish a national vaccine fund, improve health care in Taiwan, and boost the country's competitiveness in the fields of public health and medicine, the Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday.
The amendments allow for the establishment of a national vaccine fund for the purchase of vaccines and the implementation of national inoculation policies.
The bill has to be sent to the full legislature for further discussion and examination.
If the bill is passed by the legislature, a budget to purchase vaccines will be available from the year following the establishment of the vaccine fund.

Revenue for the fund will be drawn from government budgets, the health and welfare tax on tobacco, earnings from the public welfare lottery, and donations. Donors, however, will not be allowed to specify which vaccines should be purchased from the fund.
Once the bill is passed, the Cabinet-level DOH will have a stable fund from which to pay for its procurement of vaccines and ancillary items and will thus be able to ensure a stable supply.
The items that could be purchased under the fund will be discussed with a view to avoiding conflicts of interests.

DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said in a Legislative Yuan committee meeting that currently, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has a budget of only NT$400 million to buy vaccines that are offered to the public by the government.
"With the establishment of a national vaccine fund, the CDC will have more financial resources to widen the range of vaccines provided by the government," he said.
However, with a national vaccine fund in place, the DOH said, it will have to evaluate the priority of vaccines suggested by a committee and prepare budgets to make the purchases.

According to Twu Shiing-jer, a legislator of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, 86.7 percent of parents pay for their children to receive five-in-one or six-in-one vaccines instead of opting for the traditional three- in-one vaccines provided by the government, while 34.6 percent of parents pay for pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccines for their children.
Twu said this is an indication that Taiwan's inoculation policy is outdated and results in a waste of vaccines.

As to the cervical cancer vaccine, an official of the Bureau of Health Promotion said that due to controversy over its safety and opposition by local women rights organizations, it will not be included in the fund for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mandarin Airlines opens Taichung-Hangzhou air route on Dec. 21

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Mandarin Airlines will begin on Dec. 21 direct chartered flight services between the Chingchuankang Airport in Taichung, central Taiwan and Hangzhou city of the southeastern Chinese province of Zhejiang, the carrier announced Wednesday.
From that day there will one flight on the new route every Sunday, a spokesman for the company said, noting that travelers can book the flight at travel agencies.

The fare for the 100-minute flight will be NT$8,000 (US$239) round-trip -- excluding tax -- per person for group travelers and NT$12,000-NT$13,000 (excluding tax) for business travelers, according to Mandarin, which is an affiliate of the Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) -- Taiwan's largest airline.
The spokesman also revealed that the company has invited Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng to take the maiden flight, and they have agreed.
CAL Chairman Philip Wei and Mandarin Airlines Chairman Harris Wang will also be onboard the flight, he added.

The new air route was settled in one of the four significant agreements sealed by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait Nov. 4 to further expand cross-strait air services, as well as direct shipping and postal services.
The weekend cross-strait nonstop charter flight services, therefore, were expanded to every day of the week.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agriculture officials probing deaths of ducks from eating cabbage

TEXT.P: The government is investigating the cause of death of 19 ducks after they were fed cabbage leaves suspected to have been contaminated with a toxic substance, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday in a statement.
The ducks died earlier Wednesday in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, according to the COA.
Officials from the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency have contacted Taoyuan County authorities to determine the origin of the cabbages, the COA said.
Samples of the ducks and cabbages have also been taken to a laboratory for testing.
The case, though isolated, should be resolved as soon as possible in order not to affect consumers' confidence, the agency said.

In an effort to help protect consumers' health, the agency often conducts random tests on the chemical residue levels in vegetables growing in the fields and sold in wholesale markets. From the beginning of the year to the end of November, it had conducted 3,761 tests, with 97.28 percent of them passing.
The agency will ask farmers whose vegetables failed the test to delay their harvest and provide them with safe pesticides, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Demining project on Kinmen halted after protests by residents

TEXT.P: A project to clear landmines on the Taiwan-controlled outlying island of Kinmen off China's Fujian province was temporarily halted Wednesday after local residents complained that the project had obliterated nearly 1,000 graves of their ancestors.

The Kinmen defense Command ordered that all demining operations in a 20-hectare area in Kuningtou village be suspended, pending consultations with the island's residents. Kuningtou was the site of a 1949 battle in which Republic of China forces defeated two invading regiments of China's People's Liberation Army.

Li Chao-chin, head of the village of Kuningtou, said most of the graves in the area marked for demining did not have headstones, and that it would be extremely difficult now for the residents to locate their ancestors' graves.
Lee Wen-chun, head of the Chinning Township, where the village of Kuningtou is located, said the residents are demanding that their ancestors' graves be restored to their original conditions.
Noting that many of graves could no longer be distinguished, Lee said the military may need to build a shrine for collective ancestor worship by local residents.
Some of the residents have threatened to take legal action to settle the dispute and seek compensation from the defense command.
The shores of Kinmen -- Taiwan's farthest outpost in the military standoff with China -- were carpeted with landmines during the peak hostilities between the two sides in the 1950s.
In the 1950s and 1960s, many civilians were killed or maimed when they accidentally stepped on the explosive devices.
As cross-strait tensions eased, the government lifted the wartime regulations in 1992 and ended Kinmen's status as a combat zone.
The move allowed the island to open up to tourism, prompting the need to clear the landmines from areas of Kinmen no longer under military control.

DOC.HEADLINE: High court rejects KMT lawmaker's appeal against election annulment

TEXT.P: The Taichung High Court rejected Wednesday the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislator Lu E-jin's appeal against a Miaoli District Court ruling which annulled his election on vote-buying charges.

Lu, a first-time lawmaker, was the first member of the current legislature to lose a seat. The loss of Lu's seat is not expected to make a big impact on the legislature, which is dominated by the KMT. The party and its allies control nearly three-fourths of the seats.

Lu, a former secretary-general of the Miaoli County Farmers' Association, was elected in the Jan. 12 legislative election. He won the election with 64,817 votes against two-term legislator Tu Wen-ching of the Democratic Progressive Party, who received 46,905 ballots.
Soon after his election, Lu and two of his campaign staff members were indicted on vote-buying charges.
And Tu filed a civil suit seeking the invalidation of Lu's election.

The court verdict said Lu made 16 visits to temples in Yuanli and Chunan -- two of the eight townships in one of Miaoli's County's two constituencies -- between June and October last year. During that time he made donations and solicited support, via his campaign aides, for his election bid.

The court said Lu had not been known previously to make donations to the temples and had only done so during the election campaign. The court then ruled that his donations would influence voters' voting behavior.
The high court has the final say on the case.
The current Public Officials Election and Recall Law requires that an incumbent legislator be stripped of his or her seat on the day the high court annuls his or her election.

As Lu's remaining term in office exceeds one year, the Central Election Commission must hold a by-election in the northern county of Miaoli within three months from the day it receives the relevant court verdict.
In a May 29 ruling, the Miaoli District Court annulled Lu's election on vote- buying charges. Lu appealed the case to the Taichung High Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southern Taiwan township presents massive flower field landscape

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture on Wednesday picked Chiaotou township in the southern county of Kaohsiung as one of Taiwan's 10 major flower field landscapes.

The township administration worked with local farmers to turn 50 hectares of fallow farmland into stunning, colorful flower fields by growing three kinds of flowers -- Cosmos bipinnatus, sunflower, and Ruellia brittoniana.
The sea of flowers has attracted many visitors from Kaohsiung and other counties, including couples who have their wedding photos taken among the blooms.

Hsu Chung-ming, head of Chiaotou township, said visitors to his township will find that in addition to the beautiful flowers, there are other attractions, such as a 100-year-old sugar factory that makes delicious ice popsicles.
Visitors may also join various carnival-type fun activities and savor local delicacies during their stay in Chiaotou, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local governments gear up to lure consumption coupon purchases

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan has yet to pass the budget for the much-anticipated consumption coupons for all citizens, but local governments have been rushing to unveil lucrative incentives to lure consumers from around the country to spend the free vouchers in their districts.

The legislature last Friday passed a bill that authorizes the govenrment to issue NT$3,600 (US$108) in consumption vouchers to each local citizen as part of an all-out effort to spur private consumption and bolster the slumping economy. The Cabinet has accordingly come up with a NT$85.7 billion budget plan for the project, which is pending legislative approval.
If all goes well, the shopping vouchers will be distributed from Jan. 18 for use until Sept.30, 2009.

The Taichung city government is among the first to come up with a comprehensive package geared toward getting the biggest possible slice of the "consumption voucher" pie by offering a luxury house valued at NT$10 million as the top prize in a lucky draw for those who make purchases in the central city with the soon- to-be-issued shopping vouchers.

Speaking at a Taichung City Council meeting Wednesday, Mayor Jason Hu told councilors that the city government has worked out a number of creative tactics to attract consumers from around Taiwan to spend their shopping vouchers in the city.

Under the initial plan, the top prize winner will also be treated to a candlelit dinner with Hu, which will feature dishes cooked by Taichung City Council Speaker Chang Hung-nien and city councilors waiting tables.

Deputy Mayor Hsiao Jia-chi said the city government will unveil further details about its lucky draw promotion package in early January, with an aim of attracting NT$10 billion worth of business to Taichung through the central government-financed shopping voucher program.

According to the initial plan, those who spend a specified amount in shopping vouchers and visit the city's designated tourist spots will be eligible to join the lucky draw in which many prizes, including a luxury house and three expensive cars, will be at stake.

Other city and county governments, including Miaoli County, Yulin County, Taipei County, Kaohsiung City and Pingtung County, have also announced various promotion projects to lure consumers to spend their shopping vouchers in those districts.

The Miaoli county government in northern Taiwan said it will earmark NT$10 million to finance a lucky draw for the participation of those who spend up to NT$5,000 in the county and the prizes up for grabs will include 10 luxury cars and 100 high-end TV sets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shopping vouchers call center to be activated early next month

TEXT.P: A call center will be activated after the New Year holiday to offer counseling services to local consumers and retailers on the use and reimbursement of the shopping vouchers to be issued by the government to buttress the sluggish economy, an official said Wednesday.

Hu Chung-ying, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said the government has budgeted NT$12 million to finance the call center operations which will remain open until the end of September when the shopping vouchers will expire.
According to Hu, an open tender will be held to pick a qualified bidder to operate the call center.

In the initial stage, 20 telephone lines will be installed at the call center to provide counseling on the distribution, use and reimbursement of shopping vouchers, Hu said, adding that the CEPD will unveil detailed regulations for shopping voucher distribution, use and reimbursement next week after further discussion with the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Finance and other agencies.

The legislature last Friday passed a bill that authorizes the govenrment to issue NT$3,600 (US$108) in consumption vouchers to each local citizen as part of an all-out effort to spur private consumption and bolster the slumping economy. The Cabinet has accordingly come up with a NT$85.7 billion budget plan for the project, which is pending legislative approval.
If all goes well, the shopping vouchers will be distributed from Jan. 18 for use until Sept.30, 2009. endirem

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma calls for legislative endorsement of human rights covenants

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called on the Legislative Yuan Wednesday to give its long-delayed endorsement to two international human rights documents to help implement human rights protection in Taiwan.

Referring to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights that were introduced by the United Nations in 1966 and came into force in 1976, Ma said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will again present the covenants to the Cabinet during a weekly Cabinet meeting Thursday, to highlight the importance Taiwan attaches to human rights.
After that, the documents will be forwarded to the Legislative Yuan for review, Ma said.

He made the remarks while addressing the presentation of the 2008 Asian Democracy and Human Rights Award, an annual event organized by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy to mark Dec.10 International Human Rights Day.

The winner of this year's award is Sima Samar, chairwoman of the Afghan Independent Human Rights Commission and founder of the Shuhada Organization, a non-government group dedicated to the welfare and progress of Afghan people residing inside and outside of Afghanistan, with a primary focus on the empowerment of women and girls.
Ma noted that although the Republic of China signed the treaties before losing its U.N. membership in 1971, they have never been endorsed by the country's legislature over the ensuing 40 years.

During the eight-year Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration that ended earlier this year, the covenants were submitted by the Cabinet to the legislative for endorsement four times, none of which were successful, Ma went on.

The president said the legislature's endorsement is essential before Taiwan can move on to the next steps -- seeking to deposit its ratifications of the two covenants with the United Nations and implementing them in Taiwan.

Realizing the difficulties involved in seeking to deposit the ratifications with the United Nations without membership in the organization, Taiwan did not try soliciting legislative endorsement of the covenants until the pro-independence DPP came to power in 2000.

The move, however, gave rise to fears that the covenants -- which promise the right of self-determination for all peoples -- could boost a bid by pro- independent activists to promote a plebiscite on the issue of independence vs. unification with China and escalate tension across the Taiwan Strait.

The covenants therefore failed to win the support of the then-opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party, which together held a majority in the legislature during the eight years in which the DPP was in power.
With Ma's strong support for the ratification of the covenants, it remains to be seen if his ruling KMT, which now controls two-thirds of the legislative seats, will change its attitude on the issue.

Commenting on the matter, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said his ministry will step up its communication with the legislators to facilitate early ratification of the covenants and further Taiwan's achievements in human rights protection.

Also during Wednesday's ceremony, Ma said Taiwan's improvements in its human rights record over the past 15 years have greatly impressed world human rights groups, with Taiwan's status having been changed from that of a "partly free" country to a "free" country.

He added that thanks to the government's continued efforts to uphold human rights, Taiwan has now become "the world's freest country" in terms of the people's right to assembly, which he said was very well demonstrated by several protests at the ceremony in support of a variety of causes.

The protesters included several supporters of Tibetan independence who were there to express their opposition to Ma's recent rejection of a proposed visit to Taiwan by the Dalai Lama, and an activist against the government's recent relocation of a sanatorium for leprosy patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: Butterfly populations on Orchid Island changing: biologist

TEXT.P: Population structures of butterfly species on Orchid Island off the east coast of Taiwan have been changing, possibly as a result of climate change, a biologist said Wednesday.

Jason Yeh, director of the Taipei Zoo, told reporters that a butterfly research team of zoo workers and students from National Taiwan University and National Taiwan Normal University has monitored butterfly communities on Orchid Island for two years and has found an apparent change in the population structure of various species.

Yeh said the population of Catopyrops ancyra almora -- a lycaenid butterfly originating in the Philippines -- has established a stable foothold on Orchid Island after the species was first discovered there in 1998.

He also noted that on Nov. 23, the research team, working with two biologists from Japan, caught a tagged blue-mottled butterfly, or Parantica sita niphonica, that had been released from the island of Kamigoto in Nagasaki Prefecture, southwestern Japan.
It was the second time a tagged butterfly of this species released in Kamigoto was found to have made a long-distance migration to Orchid Island, with the first sighting reported in 2007.
Parantica sita niphonica, also known as the chestnut tiger butterfly, is a medium-sized species with a wingspan that can reach 10 centimeters. It has semi- transparent blue spots on its wings.
Large numbers of this species can be found between May and July on Yangming Mountain and Datun Mountain in northern Taiwan's Yangmingshan National Park.

Since 2000, Taiwanese and Japanese lepidopterists have worked together to investigate how the little, fragile creatures can travel more than 2,000 kilometers across the ocean between Taiwan and Japan.
In recent years, at least four tagged butterflies released in Taiwan have been retrieved in Japan, while six tagged in Japan have been discovered in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait detente serves Japan's interests: KMT chief
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/08 20:11:20 (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Improving Taiwan-China relations will help to reduce tensions and create peace in the region, serving the interests of Japan and Asia as a whole, Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) chairman said in Tokyo Wednesday.

"Based on the opinion of the majority in Taiwan, President Ma Ying-jeou has a clear policy to maintain the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, but conditions are not yet ripe for the two sides to talk about unification," said Wu Poh-hsiung.

The KMT chairman made the remarks while explaining the KMT's policies and the purpose of his current visit to Japan to international reporters at a news conference sponsored by the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan. Taiwan's top representative to Japan John C. T. Feng was also present.
Wu said that the Ma administration will not support independence for Taiwan because that would lead to war with China.
Both the United States and Japan are in favor of cross-strait detente, and Taiwan is committed to making peace in the region, rather than creating trouble, he said.
However, to maintain its self-defense and safeguard cross-strait peace, Taiwan will continue to purchase weapons from the United States, he stated.

President Ma attaches great importance to Taiwan's special partnership with Japan, Wu said, adding that his own visit to Japan in his capacity as KMT chairman is aimed at helping to step up two-way interactions with various sectors in Japan.

Commenting on the controversy over the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, an uninhabited island group in the East China Sea which is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan, Wu stressed that Taiwan and Japan should set aside sovereignty disputes and handle the issue peacefully through mutually beneficial joint development, particularly in the area of fishing rights.

Meanwhile, on the upcoming fourth forum to be held by the KMT and the Communist Party of China in Shanghai Dec. 20-21, Wu said the two sides are expected to discuss economic cooperation to deal with the current economic recession.
Taiwan will also be willing to collaborate with Japan to tackle the financial turmoil, he added.
Turning to the Tibet issue, Wu said that in accordance with the Republic of China Constitution, Taiwan authorities will not support the Tibet independence movement.

Wu will proceed to Yokohama Thursday where he will call on the city's mayor, Hiroshi Nakada, and meet with representatives of the Taiwanese community there before heading to Kobe and Osaka where he will have a similar agenda.
Wu paid a call on Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara Monday at the Tokyo City Hall and relayed President Ma's desire for better ties between the two countries.
Wu arrived in Japan Sunday at the head of a 15-member delegation on his first visit to the country in his capacity as leader of Taiwan's ruling party.
He is slated to return to Taiwan Saturday.

Japan, a long-term close ally of Taiwan in the region despite the lack of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, has been wary of the warming relations between Taiwan and China since Ma came to power in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan airport MRT line expected to be completed by 2014

TEXT.P: The mass rapid transit (MRT) line that is being built to connect Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and metropolitan Taipei is scheduled to be completed by 2014, transportation officials said Wednesday.

The new facility will offer travelers faster and more convenient transportation services, cutting the distance between Taipei City and the country's main airport to 35-minutes, from the current average 45 minutes by bus, the officials said.

Once the MRT line goes into operation, the officials noted, there will be a 25 percent drop in the number of privately owned automobiles entering the airport and a 20 percent decline in the number of regular buses operating on the airport route.
The metro system, currently under construction, will alleviate traffic congestion between Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Taipei, aviation police said.

Aviation Police Office statistics show that the traffic flow toward the airport averages 30,000 vehicles a day. Road traffic around the terminals is usually jammed during the peak flight periods at the airport, the police said.
According to the Bureau of High Speed Rail which is in charge of the MRT project, work on the section of metro line between the airport and Sanchong in Taipei County has been on schedule.
However, completion of the underground section between Sanchong and Taipei will be delayed until October 2014 due to the challenging underground work, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin County promotes Taiwan's oranges amid slump in prices

TEXT.P: Southwest Taiwan's agricultural-based Yunlin county organized an "Orange Day" activity Wednesday in an all-out effort to promote the homegrown produce amid a glut and severe drop in prices.

On Wednesday, county Magistrate Su Chih-fen and the county's agricultural bureau chief Lu Cheng-chang visited Gukeng township in eastern Yunlin, which is a major orange production area in Taiwan, and urged the public to consume more oranges during the current high season.
They also promised to help sell the produce to overseas markets, including China, through direct channels.
From Dec. 15 - Jan. 25, Taiwanese consumers can buy fine-quality oranges from Yunlin at 120 specially designated venues across the country, Lu said.
According to Su, some 3,500 hectares of farmland in Yunlin are reserved for cultivating oranges -- which could yield more than 80,000 metric tons of the fruit per year.
The amount of oranges produced is apparently more than the domestic market can consume, as more growers have dedicated to cultivating the fruit in recent years.
Lu said the Yunlin county government will explore more feasible ways to sell local oranges to the whole world, including Southeast Asia, Europe and the United States.

On Tuesday, China ordered 1,200 metric tons of Taiwanese oranges at above market prices, in keeping with a promise made by visiting Chinese negotiator Chen Yunlin during his historic visit to Taiwan last month.
Chen made the promise as a goodwill gesture and to alleviate the pressure on orange growers after he learned of a glut of the fruit in central and southern Taiwan.
Of the 1,200 metric tons of oranges China ordered, 1,000 metric tons will be delivered from Yunlin County and 200 metric tons from Kaohsiung County, also in southern Taiwan.

China ordered the oranges at a price of NT$13 (US$0.39) per kilogram. Orange prices in Taiwan have dipped to a record low of NT$10 per kilogram for fine quality oranges, and NT$5 per kilogram on average for those of lower quality produced in the southern regions of the island from November to April.
Some of the local growers prefer to let their oranges become ripe and fall to the ground, instead of harvesting them due to a lack of profit.

DOC.HEADLINE: New rules for U.K. student visas to take effect next March: BTCO

TEXT.P: New rules for foreign students, including Taiwanese, applying to study in the United Kingdom will take effect beginning next March in time for the 2009 summer season, the Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) said Wednesday.

Under the new measures, students will be required by a sponsor school licensed by the U.K. Border Agency to apply for a visa, Nick Jagger, head of BTCOs British Assistance & Services Section, explained in a press conference.

Along with the requirement, Jagger said that all British public as well as private schools of all levels that intend to recruit overseas students from non- European Economic Area will also be evaluated on whether they meet the governments criteria to be issued a license.

Jagger expressed his hopes that the plan for the student-tier of the system will attract more students to consider studying in the U.K., and enhance their willingness to remain in the country after graduating so they can contribute to the British society by working there.
According to the BTCO, the PBS was introduced to control immigration to the country and streamline the visa application process.
