According to Twu Shiing-jer, a legislator of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, 86.7 percent of parents pay for their children to receive five-in-one or six-in-one vaccines instead of opting for the traditional three- in-one vaccines provided by the government, while 34.6 percent of parents pay for pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccines for their children.
Twu said this is an indication that Taiwan's inoculation policy is outdated and results in a waste of vaccines.

As to the cervical cancer vaccine, an official of the Bureau of Health Promotion said that due to controversy over its safety and opposition by local women rights organizations, it will not be included in the fund for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mandarin Airlines opens Taichung-Hangzhou air route on Dec. 21

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Mandarin Airlines will begin on Dec. 21 direct chartered flight services between the Chingchuankang Airport in Taichung, central Taiwan and Hangzhou city of the southeastern Chinese province of Zhejiang, the carrier announced Wednesday.
From that day there will one flight on the new route every Sunday, a spokesman for the company said, noting that travelers can book the flight at travel agencies.

The fare for the 100-minute flight will be NT$8,000 (US$239) round-trip -- excluding tax -- per person for group travelers and NT$12,000-NT$13,000 (excluding tax) for business travelers, according to Mandarin, which is an affiliate of the Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) -- Taiwan's largest airline.
The spokesman also revealed that the company has invited Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng to take the maiden flight, and they have agreed.
CAL Chairman Philip Wei and Mandarin Airlines Chairman Harris Wang will also be onboard the flight, he added.

The new air route was settled in one of the four significant agreements sealed by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait Nov. 4 to further expand cross-strait air services, as well as direct shipping and postal services.
The weekend cross-strait nonstop charter flight services, therefore, were expanded to every day of the week.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agriculture officials probing deaths of ducks from eating cabbage

TEXT.P: The government is investigating the cause of death of 19 ducks after they were fed cabbage leaves suspected to have been contaminated with a toxic substance, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday in a statement.
The ducks died earlier Wednesday in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, according to the COA.
Officials from the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency have contacted Taoyuan County authorities to determine the origin of the cabbages, the COA said.
Samples of the ducks and cabbages have also been taken to a laboratory for testing.
The case, though isolated, should be resolved as soon as possible in order not to affect consumers' confidence, the agency said.

In an effort to help protect consumers' health, the agency often conducts random tests on the chemical residue levels in vegetables growing in the fields and sold in wholesale markets. From the beginning of the year to the end of November, it had conducted 3,761 tests, with 97.28 percent of them passing.
The agency will ask farmers whose vegetables failed the test to delay their harvest and provide them with safe pesticides, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Demining project on Kinmen halted after protests by residents

TEXT.P: A project to clear landmines on the Taiwan-controlled outlying island of Kinmen off China's Fujian province was temporarily halted Wednesday after local residents complained that the project had obliterated nearly 1,000 graves of their ancestors.

The Kinmen defense Command ordered that all demining operations in a 20-hectare area in Kuningtou village be suspended, pending consultations with the island's residents. Kuningtou was the site of a 1949 battle in which Republic of China forces defeated two invading regiments of China's People's Liberation Army.

Li Chao-chin, head of the village of Kuningtou, said most of the graves in the area marked for demining did not have headstones, and that it would be extremely difficult now for the residents to locate their ancestors' graves.
Lee Wen-chun, head of the Chinning Township, where the village of Kuningtou is located, said the residents are demanding that their ancestors' graves be restored to their original conditions.
Noting that many of graves could no longer be distinguished, Lee said the military may need to build a shrine for collective ancestor worship by local residents.
Some of the residents have threatened to take legal action to settle the dispute and seek compensation from the defense command.
The shores of Kinmen -- Taiwan's farthest outpost in the military standoff with China -- were carpeted with landmines during the peak hostilities between the two sides in the 1950s.
In the 1950s and 1960s, many civilians were killed or maimed when they accidentally stepped on the explosive devices.
As cross-strait tensions eased, the government lifted the wartime regulations in 1992 and ended Kinmen's status as a combat zone.
The move allowed the island to open up to tourism, prompting the need to clear the landmines from areas of Kinmen no longer under military control.

DOC.HEADLINE: High court rejects KMT lawmaker's appeal against election annulment

TEXT.P: The Taichung High Court rejected Wednesday the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislator Lu E-jin's appeal against a Miaoli District Court ruling which annulled his election on vote-buying charges.

Lu, a first-time lawmaker, was the first member of the current legislature to lose a seat. The loss of Lu's seat is not expected to make a big impact on the legislature, which is dominated by the KMT. The party and its allies control nearly three-fourths of the seats.

Lu, a former secretary-general of the Miaoli County Farmers' Association, was elected in the Jan. 12 legislative election. He won the election with 64,817 votes against two-term legislator Tu Wen-ching of the Democratic Progressive Party, who received 46,905 ballots.
Soon after his election, Lu and two of his campaign staff members were indicted on vote-buying charges.
And Tu filed a civil suit seeking the invalidation of Lu's election.

The court verdict said Lu made 16 visits to temples in Yuanli and Chunan -- two of the eight townships in one of Miaoli's County's two constituencies -- between June and October last year. During that time he made donations and solicited support, via his campaign aides, for his election bid.

The court said Lu had not been known previously to make donations to the temples and had only done so during the election campaign. The court then ruled that his donations would influence voters' voting behavior.
The high court has the final say on the case.
The current Public Officials Election and Recall Law requires that an incumbent legislator be stripped of his or her seat on the day the high court annuls his or her election.

As Lu's remaining term in office exceeds one year, the Central Election Commission must hold a by-election in the northern county of Miaoli within three months from the day it receives the relevant court verdict.
In a May 29 ruling, the Miaoli District Court annulled Lu's election on vote- buying charges. Lu appealed the case to the Taichung High Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southern Taiwan township presents massive flower field landscape

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture on Wednesday picked Chiaotou township in the southern county of Kaohsiung as one of Taiwan's 10 major flower field landscapes.

The township administration worked with local farmers to turn 50 hectares of fallow farmland into stunning, colorful flower fields by growing three kinds of flowers -- Cosmos bipinnatus, sunflower, and Ruellia brittoniana.
The sea of flowers has attracted many visitors from Kaohsiung and other counties, including couples who have their wedding photos taken among the blooms.

Hsu Chung-ming, head of Chiaotou township, said visitors to his township will find that in addition to the beautiful flowers, there are other attractions, such as a 100-year-old sugar factory that makes delicious ice popsicles.
Visitors may also join various carnival-type fun activities and savor local delicacies during their stay in Chiaotou, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local governments gear up to lure consumption coupon purchases

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan has yet to pass the budget for the much-anticipated consumption coupons for all citizens, but local governments have been rushing to unveil lucrative incentives to lure consumers from around the country to spend the free vouchers in their districts.

The legislature last Friday passed a bill that authorizes the govenrment to issue NT$3,600 (US$108) in consumption vouchers to each local citizen as part of an all-out effort to spur private consumption and bolster the slumping economy. The Cabinet has accordingly come up with a NT$85.7 billion budget plan for the project, which is pending legislative approval.
If all goes well, the shopping vouchers will be distributed from Jan. 18 for use until Sept.30, 2009.

The Taichung city government is among the first to come up with a comprehensive package geared toward getting the biggest possible slice of the "consumption voucher" pie by offering a luxury house valued at NT$10 million as the top prize in a lucky draw for those who make purchases in the central city with the soon- to-be-issued shopping vouchers.

Speaking at a Taichung City Council meeting Wednesday, Mayor Jason Hu told councilors that the city government has worked out a number of creative tactics to attract consumers from around Taiwan to spend their shopping vouchers in the city.

Under the initial plan, the top prize winner will also be treated to a candlelit dinner with Hu, which will feature dishes cooked by Taichung City Council Speaker Chang Hung-nien and city councilors waiting tables.

Deputy Mayor Hsiao Jia-chi said the city government will unveil further details about its lucky draw promotion package in early January, with an aim of attracting NT$10 billion worth of business to Taichung through the central government-financed shopping voucher program.

According to the initial plan, those who spend a specified amount in shopping vouchers and visit the city's designated tourist spots will be eligible to join the lucky draw in which many prizes, including a luxury house and three expensive cars, will be at stake.

Other city and county governments, including Miaoli County, Yulin County, Taipei County, Kaohsiung City and Pingtung County, have also announced various promotion projects to lure consumers to spend their shopping vouchers in those districts.

The Miaoli county government in northern Taiwan said it will earmark NT$10 million to finance a lucky draw for the participation of those who spend up to NT$5,000 in the county and the prizes up for grabs will include 10 luxury cars and 100 high-end TV sets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shopping vouchers call center to be activated early next month

TEXT.P: A call center will be activated after the New Year holiday to offer counseling services to local consumers and retailers on the use and reimbursement of the shopping vouchers to be issued by the government to buttress the sluggish economy, an official said Wednesday.

Hu Chung-ying, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said the government has budgeted NT$12 million to finance the call center operations which will remain open until the end of September when the shopping vouchers will expire.
According to Hu, an open tender will be held to pick a qualified bidder to operate the call center.

In the initial stage, 20 telephone lines will be installed at the call center to provide counseling on the distribution, use and reimbursement of shopping vouchers, Hu said, adding that the CEPD will unveil detailed regulations for shopping voucher distribution, use and reimbursement next week after further discussion with the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Finance and other agencies.

The legislature last Friday passed a bill that authorizes the govenrment to issue NT$3,600 (US$108) in consumption vouchers to each local citizen as part of an all-out effort to spur private consumption and bolster the slumping economy. The Cabinet has accordingly come up with a NT$85.7 billion budget plan for the project, which is pending legislative approval.
If all goes well, the shopping vouchers will be distributed from Jan. 18 for use until Sept.30, 2009. endirem

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open marginally higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened marginally higher Thursday, moving up 6.17 points at 4,665.04 on a turnover of NT$3.73 billion (US$111.51 million).
The weighted price index gained 186.21 points, or 4.16 percent, to close at 4,658.87 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Thursday.
The greenback was trading at NT$33.390 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.059 from Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 11, or the 14th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: The British restore Java, Indonesia, to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton) which results in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan being appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy during World War Two.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin being elected as speaker.
1961: Two companies of U.S. military helicopters arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier, representing the first direct U.S. military support for the South Vietnam regime's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and for misfeasance.
1972: The U.S. Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1973: Maj. Gen. Slade Nash, newly appointed chief of the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: The Executive Yuan of the ROC approves the Sino-Ivory Coast Agricultural Development Technical Cooperation Pact.
1974: Ten "outstanding entrepreneurs" of the year are awarded plaques and citations in Taipei.
1976: The opening ceremony of the National Conference on Atmospheric Science is held at the Central Weather Bureau in Taipei with some 100 experts participating.
1976: Eric G. Sandstrong Jr., deputy commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-cheng becomes head of the National Police Administration and concurrently the director of the Taiwan Provincial Police Department, succeeding Lt. Gen. Chou Chu-tsun.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer residing in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow the formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish a loose federation with a common foreign policy and a single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, sweeps to victory in the election for Hong Kong's leader-in-waiting to take over when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
1998: A Thai Airways Airbus crashes into a flooded rubber plantation, killing 101 people in southern Thailand.
1999: Chinese Taipei wins an across-the-board victory at the Czech Table Tennis Open with both the men and women's teams gaining group singles and group doubles victories.
2000: David Hu, director-general of the South and Central American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is confirmed by MOFA to be the new ROC ambassador to Panama.
2001: Newly elected county magistrates and legislators from Kinmen and Matsu meet in Beijing with Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, to discuss exchanges between the mainland and the two Taiwan-controlled islands.
2001: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, impeaches Ting Yuan- chin, former director-general of the National Police Administration, for filing a fraudulent report on payments for a luxury house.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who is not serious will not inspire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Majority of air traffic controllers have communication problems: poll

TEXT.P: Nearly two thirds of air traffic controllers in Taiwan have difficulty communicating with foreign pilots, mainly due to the pilots' English accents, a survey released by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) showed Thursday.

The MOTC conducted the survey between April and July on 2,003 pilots of six Taiwan air carriers -- China Airlines, EVA Airways, Mandarin Airlines, Trans Asia Airways, UNI Airways Corp. and Daily Air Corp. -- and 261 air traffic controllers of the Civil Aeronautics Administration. Responses were obtained from 38.2 percent of the pilots and 93.5 percent of the air traffic controllers.
According to the survey, 74.6 percent of the air traffic controllers said they have difficulty communicating with foreign pilots.
The main reasons for the problems were found to be the level of English proficiency of the air traffic controllers and the English accents of foreign pilots from non-English speaking countries.

Also, 23.4 percent of the air traffic controllers said they do not understand how an aircraft functions, which led the MOTC to suggest that more training is needed to enhance flight safety and air control efficiency.

Contrary to the perception that pilots and air traffic controllers earn high pay, 60 percent of the pilots polled said they were "not satisfied" with their salaries, while 82.5 percent of the air traffic controllers said their pay was unsatisfying.

Also, 77.2 percent of the air traffic controllers were of the view that their shifts are understaffed and that overtime work endangers flight safety. They suggested that the Civil Aeronautics Administration pay attention to the problem of inadequate air traffic controller staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet pushes for excise tax discount to boost car purchases

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved Thursday a draft amendment to the Commodity Tax Act that would provide an NT$30,000 (US$898) excise tax discount for car owners who replace their unserviceable vehicles, in a bid to stimulate the sluggish automobile market.
The proposed amendment, which is pending passage by the Legislative Yuan, would apply to car owners who declare their old vehicles unserviceable and register ownership of new ones by Dec. 31, 2009.
According to Minister of Finance Li Sush-der, the bill, if passed, would help boost demand in the automobile market, which has experienced declining sales for three consecutive years.
Li said that although the measure would reduce government revenue by NT$9 billion, it would provide support for the automobile industry and the country's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to communicate with legislature on human rights covenants

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan instructed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Thursday to actively seek negotiations with legislators to win their long-delayed endorsement of two international human rights covenants.

Liu issued the directive at a weekly Cabinet meeting, during which the Ministry of Foreign Affairs delivered a report on the progress in promoting ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights.
Liu's directive came one day after President Ma Ying-jeou openly called for an early ratification of the covenants to highlight the importance Taiwan attaches to human rights protection.

The covenants were introduced by the United Nations in 1966 and came into force in 1976. The Republic of China became a signatory to the covenants in 1967, when it was still a member of the United Nations.

At a news conference held after the Cabinet meeting, Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou noted that the government did not proceed immediately with the ratification of the covenants in the 1960s because at that time, the human rights situation in Taiwan was not in compliance with the requirements set forth in the documents.
The procedure was suspended after the country lost its U.N. membership in 1971, Ou said.

During the former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration, the Cabinet submitted the covenants to the legislature for endorsement, first in 2001 and again in 2002 and 2005, but because of differences among legislators, there was no decision on the issue, he said.
The treaties were last presented to the Legislative Yuan in February 2008, but were again excluded from the legislative agenda, Ou said.

A major bone of contention was a clause in the covenants promising self- determination of all peoples, which some feared could fuel a bid by pro- independence activists to promote a plebiscite on the issue of independence versus unification with China and thereby escalate tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

The covenants therefore failed to win the support of the then-opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party, which together held a majority in the legislature during the eight years the pro-independence DPP was in power.

With Ma's strong support for the ratification of the covenants, it remains to be seen whether his ruling KMT, which now controls two-thirds of the legislative seats, will change its stance on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sun Moon Lake being spoiled by incongruous buildings: visitors

TEXT.P: Sun Moon Lake, one of Taiwan's most popular scenic spots, is often described as a wonderland veiled in mountain mist. But some tourists have been complaining about series of big hotels on the edge of the lake which detract from the aesthetics of the setting.
Sun Moon Lake, located in central Taiwan in Nantou County's Yuchih Township and the island's largest lake, is surrounded by mountains that rise 760 meters above sea level.
The eastern part of the lake is round like the sun and the western part is shaped like a crescent moon, hence its name Sun Moon Lake.

According to Hung Wei-hsin, deputy director of the Sun Moon Lake Scenic Area Administration, in 2007, a total of 3 million foreign and domestic tourists visited the area and this year the number is very likely to increase.
But some of these visitors have expressed regret that the natural scenery is being spoilt by unsightly artificial structures on the edge of the lake.

Rui Ming-tai, a tourist from Taichung City in central Taiwan, told the Central News Agency that public facilities and the quality of service at the Sun Moon Lake Scenic Area have improved, but that the views seem to be less stimulating than when he visited the area two years ago.

"The quality of the roads is better, and hotels are more and more comfortable, but we are seeing many giant hotels, including some under construction, and their facades are far from being in harmony with nature," he said.
He suggested that the administration do something about coordinating the height and outward appearance of the hotel buildings.
Rui said he would have liked to be able to see the lake from his hotel room, but another hotel under construction on the edge of the lake was blocking the view.

Another tourist, who declined to give her name, said that the design of some buildings being constructed near the lake is "odd." She pointed to the example of a station for a cable car service that will connect Sun Moon Lake with the Formosan Aboriginal Culture Village, also a tourist spot in Nantou County.

Having traveled in many countries, she said, she does not understand why the Taiwan government cannot harmonize the buildings' design and require hotel developers to use natural construction materials such as wood so that the buildings would blend with the surroundings.

According to the Urban Planning section of the Nantou County Government, construction plans for hotels are subject to regulations on size and height, which specify that the building should be no taller than six or seven floors.
However, some some of the hotels in the area do not adhere to these specifications and there are no regulations regarding the facades of hotels and the materials used to construct them.
"The county government and the scenic area administration can only make suggestions (on hotels' appearance and building materials) to the owners," said Hung.
Moreover, hotel operators have their own business considerations and usually want to have as many rooms as possible to maximize their profits, he added.
With the construction of several new hotels in progress, it is not known if and when the aesthetics of the area will improve.
According to a tour guide with a yacht company at the lake, the number of rooms and hotels at the Sun Moon Lake area remain inadequate, especially during the peak seasons.
Even on an ordinary day, there would be enough passengers for her yacht to make several round tours of the lake before 7: 30 a.m., she said.

She expressed the view that although the number of Chinese tourists to the area has been lower than anticipated since Taiwan increased the allowable daily number to the country, business from that source will pick up.
Currently, there are three big hotels under construction in the Sun Moon Lake scenic area.

When the three hotels become operational next year, the number of rooms in the lake area will rise from the current 2,500 to around 3,000, which should be sufficient to meet the demand by that time, Hung said.
"That number should be sufficient, " he said. "After all, the Sun Moon Lake hinterland is very limited (in terms of space for construction)," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Volunteer sees age as no impediment to her work

TEXT.P: After having served as a volunteer swimming coach for 23 years, 70-year-old Chao Yueh-nu has now expanded her work to other social service areas, saying that "one is never too old, nor it ever too late to be a volunteer."
Chao, an expert swimmer who excels at the butterfly stroke, came under the spotlight Thursday at a press conference sponsored by the Taipei county government to mark 2008 International Volunteer Day.
Chao has frequently accompanied amateur swimmers taking part in the Swim Across the Sun Moon Lake activity, an annual ritual that is quite physically demanding.

Speaking at the news conference, Chao said that of all the people she has coached, her most rewarding experience was teaching an 11-year-old visually- impaired girl who at first screamed whenever she was in the water but later came to enjoy diving.
During the summer, Chao said, she spent much time at the Zhitan Dam in Xindian on the outskirts of Taipei City serving as a lifeguard.
"I have saved numerous lives," she said.
According to Hsu Ming-yu, chief of the Voluntary Service Center of the Taipei county government, Chao has expanded her volunteer work to other social service areas in recent years.

Chao has visited a nursing home in Taipei County's Bali township to feed ailing seniors and has also worked as a telephone counselor to talk to senior citizens who live alone and to find out about their needs and problems, Hsu said.
At the news conference, the Taipei county government displayed some of the results of the Voluntary Service Center's work over the past year in the educational, cultural, social and medical areas.

With the number of volunteers continuing to increase, the Voluntary Service Center expects to tap 100,000 recruits in the next year to further expand volunteer services in Taiwan's most populous county, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for December declining 23 points to end at 4,666, with 95,881 contracts traded.
TAIEX Index futures for January futures declined nine points to end at 4,645, with 2,472 contracts traded, while March futures fell nine points to close at 4,606, with 23 contract transactions.
June futures lost nine points to finish at 4,576, with 17 contract transactions, while September futures were down eight points to close at 4,393, with eight contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,689 for December, 4,654 for January, 4,615 for March, 4,585 for June and 4,401 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 3.3 points to finish at 4,655.57, on turnover of NT$95.9 billion (US$2.88 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also mixed.
December TE futures advanced 0.75 points to close at 178.1, with 7,185 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 2.05 points to finish at 176.75, with 305 contracts traded.
March TE futures were up 0.8 points to end at 171.9, with five contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June and September.
December TF futures were down 11.2 points to close at 594, with 4,605 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved down 8.2 points to close at 591.8, with 135 contracts traded.
March TF futures lost 15.4 points to end at 570, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices marginally lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices finished slightly lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 3.3 points to close at 4,655.57.

Ending a three-day gaining streak, the local bourse opened at 4,665.04 and fluctuated between 4,694.4 and 4,617.17. A total of 5.44 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$95.9 billion (US$2.88 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.77 percent. Textile stocks advanced 0.95 percent and machinery and electronics shares were up 0.86 percent.

The other five major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 4.55 percent. Cement stocks declined 1.58 percent, banking and financial shares dropped 1.57 percent, plastics and chemicals shares lost 1.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues shed 0.61 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 785 to 699, with 255 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$7.99 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.140 to close at NT$33.309.
A total of US$972 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.449 and fluctuated between NT$33.294 and NT$33.460.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung to launch self-service bike rental system

TEXT.P: The southern harbor city of Kaohsiung will launch a self-service bicycle rental system at 20 transit points around the city by the end of December, in an initiative to further reduce greenhouse gas emissions, a senior city government official said Thursday.

Hsiao Yu-cheng, director of the city's Environmental Protection Bureau, said that the service will have at least 1,500 bikes before the end of January, and the scale will be expanded to 50 rental sites and 4, 500 bikes in six months time.
All the rental spots, he added, will be located near metro stations or scenic areas to allow easy access and to optimize efficiency.

According to the city government, the service will be accessible to members as well as non-members. Members will be required to pay a lump-sum fee in advance and use their membership cards to rent bikes from the self-service rack, while non-members will be able to use their credit cards to pay on the spot.

The bureau said that the eco-friendly NT$90 million (US$2.7 million) bike rental service will help reduce the city's total greenhouse gas emissions and induce tourists to travel throughout the city by a "greener" means.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign donations made to Taiwanese runner

TEXT.P: A German runner recently forwarded to Taiwan the donations collected in a charity event in Germany, in the hope of providing assistance to a Taiwanese female runner whose legs had to be amputated due to a severe bacterial infection she contracted after a race in France, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Thursday.

The charity run, voluntarily organized by German runner Siegfried Bullig in the city of Dusseldorf in late October, drew over 40 participants from various European countries who donated more than 6,200 euros (approximately NT$268,476), according to Bullig's Web site for the event.

The MOFA said it received the donation Tuesday and passed it on to Chiu Shu- jung, an ultra-marathon runner who broke the Asian record and placed second in the Spartathlon race held in Greece in March. Chiu lost both her legs after she completed the 18-day Trans Gaule run along a 1,150-kilometer route in France.

Bullig said on his Web site that although he knew the donation would "not be sufficient to render noticeable financial help" to Chiu and her family, he hoped the event would serve as an example and stimulate people to think of what they can do for others.
He also expressed the hope that Chiu, a friend of his, would be encouraged to see how many people around the world showed compassion toward her.
Chiu returned to Taiwan in late September after the double amputation surgery in France, and is now in the process of recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority of Taiwan consumers think saving is important: poll

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked 6th among 14 Asia Pacific markets in terms of the importance its consumers attach to saving, with 88.6 percent of the population highly valuing this practice, according to the results of a survey released by MasterCard Worldwide Wednesday.
The MasterCard Worldwide Index of Consumer Purchasing Priorities showed that 54.8 percent of Taiwan people think that it is "important" to save, while 33.8 percent think it is "very important."
According to the survey, most consumers in the Asia Pacific markets plan to increase their savings in the coming year, and 87 percent see saving money as a very important aspect of their lives.

About 91 percent of those whose annual income is lower than US$10,000 and 85 percent of those whose annual income is higher than US$30,000 supported the idea that saving is important, the report showed.

In both Indonesia and the Philippines, 97 percent of consumers said they think saving is important or very important, while 93 percent in Malaysia and 92 percent in India shared this view, the survey found.
China ranked at bottom of all 14 markets, with 77 percent of its consumers giving importance to saving. In South Korea the figure was 81 percent and in Singapore 79 percent.
The survey is conducted annually on markets in Asia Pacific, South Asia, Middle East and Africa.
In each of Asia Pacific's 14 markets, 400 or more interviews were conducted from Sept. 1-29 among males and females aged 18 and over from middle and upper income groups.
The survey had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points and a confidence level of 90 percent, the report stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese container ships ready to depart for China Dec. 15

TEXT.P: A container ship owned and operated by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp. is ready to depart for China's northern port city of Tianjin Dec. 15 when direct cross- Taiwan Strait shipping links will be launched, a corporate source said Thursday.

When Evergreen's full-container vessel Uni-Adroit departs from Kaohsiung Harbor at 10 a.m. Dec. 15, it will be the first Taiwanese commercial ship to sail directly from Kaohsiung to a port in mainland China after a hiatus of more than five decades.

Uni-Adroit, with a capacity of 1,168 TEUs, is scheduled to sail directly from Kaohsiung to Tianjin's New Port before heading to the northern Chinese ports Dalian and Qingdao on its way home, according to an Evergreen spokesman.

Meanwhile, four container ships owned and operated by Taiwan's Wan Hai Lines, Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., Taiwan Navigation Co. and China's Huarong Marine Co., respectively, are also scheduled to depart Dec. 15, from the northern port of Keelung.

Among the four vessels, the YM Heights, which has a capacity of 1,500 TEUs, is scheduled to depart from Keelung for Kaohsiung Harbor before heading to Shanghai. From Shanghai, it will visit other Chinese ports -- Dalian, Taicang, Qingdao and Lianyungang -- before returning to Keelung, according to an official from Yang Ming Marine.

Also on Dec. 15, a 20,000-ton bulk carrier owned and operated by Da Sheng Marine Co. is scheduled to depart from Taichung Harbor on central Taiwan's western coast for China's southeastern port of Fuzhou, from where it will transport gravel back to Taiwan.

The launch of direct cross-strait shipping links is one of four agreements sealed by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on Nov. 4 to further expand transportation exchanges, postal services and address food safety issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: International report warns against Taiwan's coral reef deterioration

TEXT.P: A report released this week on the status of coral reefs around the world warned that Taiwan's coral reefs, especially those located in its south and south-east seas, were under severe stress or had been heavily damaged, and that a trend of declining coral cover deserves attention.
The report "Status of Coral Reefs of the World: 2008" found that coral cover at 24 of the 49 sites surveyed in Taiwan was lower than 30 percent.
The lowest coral cover sites were even less than 10 percent, the report said.
"Overall, monitoring is showing a general trend of declining coral cover on Taiwanese coral reefs, " indicated the report released by the Global Coral Reef Monitoring Network on Wednesday.

While damage to coral reef elsewhere in the world were largely caused by the 1998 widespread coral bleaching phenomenon, which occurred due to the strong El Nino effect that caused a rise in sea temperature, the main reasons for coral reef deterioration in Taiwan are inappropriate fishing methods and excessive development, experts said.
"For coral reefs in Taiwan, the most serious impact would be excessive fishing and silt sediment, " said Dai Chang-feng, professor of the Institute of Oceanography of the National Taiwan University.
He said that some fishing methods, such as using explosives, cause considerable damage to coral reefs.

According to the report, coastal areas of Taiwan have also been under extensive infrastructure development with the growing populations including aquaculture, agriculture and resort building. As a consequence, serious soil erosion have led to frequent landslides in rain and typhoon seasons and massive sediment flows into reef areas.
Rising sea surface temperature represents only part of the problem for coral reefs in Taiwan, Dai said.

The report also indicated that macro-algal cover has increased in about half of the surveyed sites in Taiwan, accompanied by higher sedimentation loads and increased water turbidity, suggesting continuous reef degradation and a possible phase shift from coral- dominated to algal-dominated reef communities.

Dai said that the increase of macro-algal cover is a consequence of sewage from coastal towns and villages discharged over reefs without proper treatment, resulting in algal proliferation and coral loss.
The macro-algal cover problem is more serious in the northern part of Taiwan than in the south, Dai said.

To improve the current situation of coral reefs, the report suggested increasing the focus on socioeconomic monitoring as well as ecological monitoring to provide reliable data and information for better coastal management.
The report also suggested developing mechanisms for extending the network of monitoring scientists to start a dialogue with decision makers to recommend appropriate coral conservation.

Meanwhile, the report noted that flourishing coral reef communities were observed at several sites of Lutao, Lanyu and Dongsha Atoll in Taiwan 's southern seas. The Dongsha Atoll shows the most scenic underwater images, with coral cover ranging from 78 percent to 85 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-made robots to perform "The Phantom of the Opera"

TEXT.P: A Taiwan university announced Thursday the creation of what could be the world's first robot theater, which will make its debut on Dec. 27 by performing the musical "The Phantom of the Opera".
The theater is comprised of four intelligent robots developed by the Center for Intelligent Robots at National Taiwan University of Science and Technology.

They include a male robot named Thomas and a female robot named Janet, who can walk and are equipped with silicon facial muscles that enable them to mimic the facial expressions and lip motions of a human being.
The other two members of the theater are Pica the painter and Ringo the jazz drummer, who move on two wheels.
Chen Shi-shuenn, president of the university, said the Dec. 27 performance will feature Thomas and Janet as the two leading characters in "The Phantom of the Opera".
There will also be singing and a Chinese comic dialogue show, Chen said.

Lin Chyi-yeu, a professor of mechanical engineering who heads the Center for Intelligent Robots, said the center has started with the development of entertainment robots and will further apply the eye-hand coordination technology on the development of other service robots.
Also, the incomes generated from the theater performance will be used on related research and development, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan eases restrictions against spouses from mainland China

TEXT.P: The Cabinet on Thursday took steps to lift restrictions against mainland Chinese spouses married to Taiwanese residents, allowing them to work soon after arriving and shortening the time it takes them to qualify for ID card -- basically treating them more like other foreign spouses.

Under a draft amendment to a law passed by the Executive Yuan, the spouses - mostly wives - can work as long as they enter Taiwan legally, instead of having to meet a host of requirements as they do now, including having lived here for at least two years, having kids or having low income.

The draft amendment will still have to be approved by the Legislative Yuan. If approved, it will also shorten the amount of time that it takes for the Chinese immigrants to qualify for a Taiwanese ID card, from eight years to six years.
That is still two years more than it usually takes a spouse from any other country, such as Vietnam, to obtain an ID card.
The move comes as Taiwan and China have begun building warmer ties since President Ma Ying-jeou came into office in May.

Previous administrations have argued that the rules were imposed to prevent fake marriages and marriages based on weak foundations, often arranged by marriage agencies. They also admitted there were concerns about an influx of mainlanders to Taiwan, despite the fact that single Taiwanese men tend to marry them more than women from other countries.

But the Chinese spouses and non-governmental groups representing them have long called such policies discriminatory. Fake marriages also exist among spouses from other countries and the divorce rate of mainland spouses are about the same as that of local Taiwanese couples.
There are an estimated 290,000 mainland Chinese spouses here - making them the largest group of non-native spouses in Taiwan.

A current restriction limiting the amount of money the mainland spouses can inherit from their Taiwanese spouse to NT$2 million will also be lifted, according to the draft amendment to the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of Taiwan Area and the People of Mainland Area.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said the dramatic changes are meant to "protect the legal Chinese spouses and crack down on the illegal ones in a bid to provide better protection to the working, ID card and property rights of legal Chinese spouses."
Liu noted that the Chinese spouses are a part of Taiwan's society, and that the government has to address their rights so that they feel accepted here.

However, mindful that some parts of the population remain wary of mainlanders, fearing they will take local people's jobs or believing they are gold diggers, Liu said: "The government will not allow Chinese people who come to Taiwan in convenience marriages to work here."

He demanded the Ministry of the Interior and other related agencies strengthen the interview mechanism which assesses whether the marriages are real upon the Chinese spouses' arrival and the visiting mechanism at their homes after they begin living in Taiwan.

Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said the amendment signifies a major reform regarding the rights of Chinese spouses in Taiwan and a realization of the protection of human rights.

With the amended law shortening the years required for Chinese spouses to get IDs to six years, Lai said around 31,000 Chinese spouses who have now stayed in Taiwan for more than six years will get IDs immediately.
The government also plans to scrap a regulation that has made it impossible for the spouses to sponsor their children from a previous marriage to join them in Taiwan.

Under the regulation, Chinese spouses have to be in Taiwan for at least eight years before they can register their household here and another five years after that before they can apply to have their biological children under 12 years of age to come to Taiwan.
But Lai noted that after waiting eight years and then another five years, the children would be 13 and would no longer qualify to come here under the rule.
She criticized the regulation as being "unreasonable and not in line with human rights," adding that the Ministry of the Interior will scrap it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Casual promise turns into oath sworn by river of Styx

TEXT.P: How long should a promise remain binding?
For Liao Ming-yi, a resident of Jhonghe City, Taipei County, it will be as long as his coffee trees stay alive.

Keeping a casual promise made by his great grandfather to a foreign tea trader, Liao continues to take care of about 100 coffee trees that were previously in the care of his late father, grandfather and great grandfather.
The trees, planted on a hillside at the end of Sinnan Road, Jhonghe City by a British tea trader more than a hundred years ago, are still thriving.
Coffee trees in general are rare in Taiwan, not to mention ones that are more than 100 years old.

According to records kept by local agricultural authorities, a British tea trader brought about 100 Arabica coffee trees to Taiwan from Southeast Asia in 1884. The trees were planted in what is now the Haishan area, Taipei County.
The following year, British traders sowed coffee seeds in Wenshan and Xizhi in Taipei County, according to the records.

However, these British traders' dream of establishing coffee plantations in Taiwan never panned out and the few coffee trees they planted on an experimental basis were left unattended after they withdrew from Taiwan.

Liao's great grandfather was a tea farmer who lived in Jhonghe at the time. Liao quoted his late great grandmother, born 108 years ago, as saying that when a foreign tea trader was about to leave Taiwan, he asked her husband to take care of the coffee trees.

From that time on, Liao's family has cared for the trees, starting with his great grandfather and on down the line to his grandfather, father, and now Liao himself, although there is no record of the foreign tea trader ever returning to Taiwan.
The old coffee trees are still thriving and bearing fruit, and from their seeds, one of Liao's uncles started a small coffee garden on a patch of his own hillside land.
"By taking care of these trees, we are not only keeping an ancestor's promise but also keeping alive our memories of our ancestors and their sense of solidarity." Liao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vietnam thanks local foundation's help for disadvantaged children

TEXT.P: Vietnamese officials in Taipei visited a local foundation Thursday to express their appreciation for its long-term financial and medical assistance to disadvantaged Vietnamese children.

During a visit to the Taipei-based Compassion International Taiwan (CITW) , Ngu Yen Cong Manh, deputy director of the Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei, voiced his gratitude for the foundation's efforts over the past 13 years to help nearly 3,000 poor or sick children in central Vietnam.

With CITW's support, he said during a speech on cross-cultural cooperation, children who used to wander the streets can now go to school and receive a formal education. In addition, a medical scheme that the CITW has been promoting has benefited children who suffer deformities as a result of residue from chemicals used during the Vietnam War, the official added.

CITW CEO Jay Hung noted that as the high inflation rate in Vietnam has deterred some poor families in the Southeast Asian country from sending their children to school, his organization will increase its school funding to alleviate the burden on these families.

The foundation will also conduct a survey to ascertain which families are in need, Hung went on, adding that it will also launch a plan to cooperate with 10 local elementary schools to promote the fun of reading.
Hung said the foundation welcomes donations to help such deprived children, and noted that further information can be found at http://www.friendshipcit.org

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to renew, enhance industrial parks

TEXT.P: The government has earmarked NT$16 billion (US$480 million) to renew the infrastructure of Taiwan's aged industrial parks in the coming four years, in an effort to upgrade their overall quality, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Thursday.

MOEA officials said dozens of industrial parks on the island urgently need renovations, as 51 of them have been used for more than 20 years, while 25 of them have been used for more than three decades.
They said the project will first aim at improving the parks' lighting, out-bound highways, sewerage treatment facilities, and environmental protection.

Meanwhile, the ministry said, an industry-academia cooperation platform will be launched to better help the manufacturers in the export processing parks upgrade their technology levels and enhance their competitiveness.

The ministry has already signed agreements with 36 universities, incubation centers, and vocational training institutions, which will assist the manufacturers to strengthen business operations, provide better job training and upgrade research capability.

MOEA officials said that with the project, they will not only try to help the manufacturers survive the current economic downturn, but also aim to better prepare the industry players for the next surge in market demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Possible naming of Nobel physicist as U.S. energy secretary welcomed

TEXT.P: The head of Taiwan's top research institution on Thursday welcomed the possibility that U.S. President-elect Barack Obama will name Nobel physicist Steven Chu as his secretary of energy.

Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong said Chu, a co-winner of the 1997 Nobel Prize in Physics, has maintained close and cordial relations with the Academia Sinica - Taiwan's top research institute.
"If Chu is named by Obama as the new U.S. energy secretary, it will be conducive to closer cooperation in the field of sciences between Taiwan and the United States," Wong said.
U.S. media this week reported that Chu is one of the candidates being considered by Obama for the post.

If Chu is named the U.S. energy secretary, he will be the second Cabinet-level minister of Chinese descent in U.S. history, after Secretary of Labor Elaine L. Chao. The 55-year-old Taiwan-born Chao is currently the highest-ranking American official of Chinese descent in the United States.
Chu was born in the United States. His parents were both from mainland China.

Chu, known for his research in laser cooling and the trapping of atoms, which won him the Nobel Prize in Physics, has just returned to the United States from Taiwan, where he attended an Academia Sinica-sponsored forum of heads of prominent science institutes from around the world from Dec. 6-7.
During that forum, Chu delivered a keynote speech, titled: "The World's Energy Problem and What We Can Do About It".
Chu is currently a professor of physics and molecular and cellular biology at the University of California, Berkeley and the director of the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.

As warnings about global warming grow more dire, Chu is currently pushing his scientists at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and industry players to develop technologies to reduce the impact of climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County to turn salt field into ecological wetland

TEXT.P: The Tainan county government plans to turn a disused salt field into a wetland area that will benefit the county's ecology conservation, a local official said Thursday.

The county government will spend five years transforming the 16-hectare disused salt field in Chiku township into a wetland ecology park, according to Yang Ya- chu, an official of the county's Department of Agriculture.

Yang, who is a member of the department's forest biodiversity and conservation section, pointed out that growing trees is a lot more difficult on salt land than on ordinary farmland, and he admitted that Taiwan has had no success in turning salt fields into productive land.

In order to achieve a better chance of success, the local government has commissioned scholars and experts from National Chiayi University, National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, and the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute to evaluate and design the tree-planting project, and signed a contract Wednesday with the company that will carry out the project.
The company will first clear up a one-meter layer of clay under the salt field before connecting drainage pipes to ditches leading to the sea to help remove the salt from the land.
A flood pool will then be dug at the center to collect rainwater, and littoral plants such as mangroves will be planted around the pool to function as a windbreak, Yang said.

Yang said the county government hopes to see the project pay off within five years, although he said a subsidy of NT$40 million (US$1.2 million) from the central government is barely enough even for the project's initial phase, which will last until the end of next rear.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chang Gung University reveals new augmented-reality technologies

TEXT.P: Chang Gung University has developed a new set of augmented reality technologies for brain surgery that can shorten the time needed for surgery and reduce the risks involved, neurologists reported Thursday.

The technologies, invented by researchers at the Chang Gung University and Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Taoyuan, combine holographic display, augmented- reality surgery, an automated skull- opening drill, and customized tools for skull repair implants.

Unlike virtual reality (VR) , which uses computer-generated graphics to recreate items on a screen, augmented reality (AR) creates images by modifying real-time images of objects with additional computer-generated graphics.

Explaining the function of the technology, Lee Shih- tseng, director of the Medical Augmented Reality Research and Development Center operated by the university and hospital, said holographic displays can analyze medical data to produce a "remodeled" skull on screen, which allows 360-degree inspection and free removal of all bone and tissue.
Lee said that with the holographic display, brain surgeons can get a better idea of their patients' conditions and can determine the best path and means of surgery.

The complimentary technology of AR surgery, said Lee, allows the surgeon to operate on the model skull using a scalpel-like device that provides feedback and emulates the characteristics of blood vessel, tumor or bone.
"With the AR surgery, surgeons can practice the process in advance to reduce risk and avoid mistakes in the real operation, " Lee said.

In real surgery, Lee continued, the automated skull-opening drill will help control collateral damage by precisely measuring the depth of the drill, while the implant customization tool can precisely measure one or more bone plates that have to be replaced, and assist in producing implants that will fit perfectly with other surrounding bone.
According to Lee, the tool has been used on nearly 50 patients with good results.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-made snake antivenin exported to U.S.

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Thursday that it has recently received orders from the U.S. State of Florida for four kinds of antivenin to combat snakebite.

The CDC under the Cabinet-level Department of Health said the orders, from the Miami Fire Department, are for antivenin for envenomation by various well-known venomous snakes, including the Russell's viper and the banded krait.

As the orders were for four kinds of antivenin, each totaling 20 doses, the CDC has invited private companies to undertake the production of the total 80 doses of antivenin, with the CDC supplying the development know-how, CDC officials said.

According to the CDC, the agency has received more than 20 orders since 2003 from the United States, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and Israel for antivenin, with sales totaling nearly NT$3 million (US$90,909).

The CDC quoted World Health Organization statistics as indicating that about 125,000 people die from snake envenomation worldwide each year, while only 22 pharmaceutical companies from 17 countries are capable of producing antivenin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua county firefighting performance tops country

TEXT.P: Changhua County in central Taiwan has topped the country in terms of its firefighting performance in a national evaluation, the county's Fire Bureau Director-General Hsiao Chia-cheng said Thursday.

The fire bureau's performance was designated as "excellent" this year, receiving top ratings in five major categories -- fire prevention, disaster rescue and relief, local residents' involvement in firefighting efforts, fire disaster investigations and emergency medical treatment.

Hsiao said the National Fire Agency under the Ministry of the Interior conducts the annual evaluation in seven major categories, with more than 200 rating items on each city and county's firefighting performance.
The county won fifth place in 2005, third in 2006 and first in 2007, winning top ratings in four major categories, Hsiao noted.

The bureau has set up an efficient information management system on disaster reporting and vehicle and personnel dispatch. It also promotes training in cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, among local residents.

About 20,000 local residents have received CPR training over the past two years, Hsiao went on adding that the bureau will keep promoting CPR with the aim of having at least one in 10 people trained in the life-saving skill.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central bank announces further interest rate cuts

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank announced Thursday that it will further lower its benchmark interest rates by 0.75 percentage points from Friday as inflationary pressure has eased while the risks of a further downturn to the domestic economy are rising amid the global financial turmoil.

It will be the second-largest interest rate cut in the country's history and the fifth time the central bank has adjusted downward its key lending rates since September, when the global economy went into a recession because of fallout from the U.S. subprime crisis.

After the latest adjustments, the central bank's key lending rates will return to the levels recorded in July 2005, with the discount rate -- the interest rate the central bank charges depository institutions that borrow reserves from it -- falling to 2 percent, the rate on accommodations with collateral to 2.375 percent and the rate on accommodations without collateral to 4.25 percent.

Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) , told a news conference held after a meeting of the bank's board of directors and supervisors that the interest rate cut is expected to help spur domestic demand and buttress economic growth.

Quoting a forecast by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Perng said the consumer price index will grow a mere 0.37 percent next year, which will help ease inflationary pressure and stabilize domestic commodity prices.

Nevertheless, he went on, the job market might face even gloomier prospects and the unemployment rate will probably climb further as the country's exports -- the growth engine of the local economy -- have continued to shrink for three consecutive months.
Perng urged local banks not to withhold lending to normally operating business corporations at this trying time in order to keep the local economy afloat.

He also told local companies to make good use of the current low interest rates to launch long-term investments to facilitate corporate restructuring or transformation and upgrade their competitive edges.
For its part, Perng said, the central bank will maintain its measured monetary policy that will feature timely adjustments in a gradual manner.
