A current restriction limiting the amount of money the mainland spouses can inherit from their Taiwanese spouse to NT$2 million will also be lifted, according to the draft amendment to the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of Taiwan Area and the People of Mainland Area.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said the dramatic changes are meant to "protect the legal Chinese spouses and crack down on the illegal ones in a bid to provide better protection to the working, ID card and property rights of legal Chinese spouses."
Liu noted that the Chinese spouses are a part of Taiwan's society, and that the government has to address their rights so that they feel accepted here.

However, mindful that some parts of the population remain wary of mainlanders, fearing they will take local people's jobs or believing they are gold diggers, Liu said: "The government will not allow Chinese people who come to Taiwan in convenience marriages to work here."

He demanded the Ministry of the Interior and other related agencies strengthen the interview mechanism which assesses whether the marriages are real upon the Chinese spouses' arrival and the visiting mechanism at their homes after they begin living in Taiwan.

Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said the amendment signifies a major reform regarding the rights of Chinese spouses in Taiwan and a realization of the protection of human rights.

With the amended law shortening the years required for Chinese spouses to get IDs to six years, Lai said around 31,000 Chinese spouses who have now stayed in Taiwan for more than six years will get IDs immediately.
The government also plans to scrap a regulation that has made it impossible for the spouses to sponsor their children from a previous marriage to join them in Taiwan.

Under the regulation, Chinese spouses have to be in Taiwan for at least eight years before they can register their household here and another five years after that before they can apply to have their biological children under 12 years of age to come to Taiwan.
But Lai noted that after waiting eight years and then another five years, the children would be 13 and would no longer qualify to come here under the rule.
She criticized the regulation as being "unreasonable and not in line with human rights," adding that the Ministry of the Interior will scrap it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Casual promise turns into oath sworn by river of Styx

TEXT.P: How long should a promise remain binding?
For Liao Ming-yi, a resident of Jhonghe City, Taipei County, it will be as long as his coffee trees stay alive.

Keeping a casual promise made by his great grandfather to a foreign tea trader, Liao continues to take care of about 100 coffee trees that were previously in the care of his late father, grandfather and great grandfather.
The trees, planted on a hillside at the end of Sinnan Road, Jhonghe City by a British tea trader more than a hundred years ago, are still thriving.
Coffee trees in general are rare in Taiwan, not to mention ones that are more than 100 years old.

According to records kept by local agricultural authorities, a British tea trader brought about 100 Arabica coffee trees to Taiwan from Southeast Asia in 1884. The trees were planted in what is now the Haishan area, Taipei County.
The following year, British traders sowed coffee seeds in Wenshan and Xizhi in Taipei County, according to the records.

However, these British traders' dream of establishing coffee plantations in Taiwan never panned out and the few coffee trees they planted on an experimental basis were left unattended after they withdrew from Taiwan.

Liao's great grandfather was a tea farmer who lived in Jhonghe at the time. Liao quoted his late great grandmother, born 108 years ago, as saying that when a foreign tea trader was about to leave Taiwan, he asked her husband to take care of the coffee trees.

From that time on, Liao's family has cared for the trees, starting with his great grandfather and on down the line to his grandfather, father, and now Liao himself, although there is no record of the foreign tea trader ever returning to Taiwan.
The old coffee trees are still thriving and bearing fruit, and from their seeds, one of Liao's uncles started a small coffee garden on a patch of his own hillside land.
"By taking care of these trees, we are not only keeping an ancestor's promise but also keeping alive our memories of our ancestors and their sense of solidarity." Liao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vietnam thanks local foundation's help for disadvantaged children

TEXT.P: Vietnamese officials in Taipei visited a local foundation Thursday to express their appreciation for its long-term financial and medical assistance to disadvantaged Vietnamese children.

During a visit to the Taipei-based Compassion International Taiwan (CITW) , Ngu Yen Cong Manh, deputy director of the Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei, voiced his gratitude for the foundation's efforts over the past 13 years to help nearly 3,000 poor or sick children in central Vietnam.

With CITW's support, he said during a speech on cross-cultural cooperation, children who used to wander the streets can now go to school and receive a formal education. In addition, a medical scheme that the CITW has been promoting has benefited children who suffer deformities as a result of residue from chemicals used during the Vietnam War, the official added.

CITW CEO Jay Hung noted that as the high inflation rate in Vietnam has deterred some poor families in the Southeast Asian country from sending their children to school, his organization will increase its school funding to alleviate the burden on these families.

The foundation will also conduct a survey to ascertain which families are in need, Hung went on, adding that it will also launch a plan to cooperate with 10 local elementary schools to promote the fun of reading.
Hung said the foundation welcomes donations to help such deprived children, and noted that further information can be found at http://www.friendshipcit.org

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to renew, enhance industrial parks

TEXT.P: The government has earmarked NT$16 billion (US$480 million) to renew the infrastructure of Taiwan's aged industrial parks in the coming four years, in an effort to upgrade their overall quality, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Thursday.

MOEA officials said dozens of industrial parks on the island urgently need renovations, as 51 of them have been used for more than 20 years, while 25 of them have been used for more than three decades.
They said the project will first aim at improving the parks' lighting, out-bound highways, sewerage treatment facilities, and environmental protection.

Meanwhile, the ministry said, an industry-academia cooperation platform will be launched to better help the manufacturers in the export processing parks upgrade their technology levels and enhance their competitiveness.

The ministry has already signed agreements with 36 universities, incubation centers, and vocational training institutions, which will assist the manufacturers to strengthen business operations, provide better job training and upgrade research capability.

MOEA officials said that with the project, they will not only try to help the manufacturers survive the current economic downturn, but also aim to better prepare the industry players for the next surge in market demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Possible naming of Nobel physicist as U.S. energy secretary welcomed

TEXT.P: The head of Taiwan's top research institution on Thursday welcomed the possibility that U.S. President-elect Barack Obama will name Nobel physicist Steven Chu as his secretary of energy.

Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong said Chu, a co-winner of the 1997 Nobel Prize in Physics, has maintained close and cordial relations with the Academia Sinica - Taiwan's top research institute.
"If Chu is named by Obama as the new U.S. energy secretary, it will be conducive to closer cooperation in the field of sciences between Taiwan and the United States," Wong said.
U.S. media this week reported that Chu is one of the candidates being considered by Obama for the post.

If Chu is named the U.S. energy secretary, he will be the second Cabinet-level minister of Chinese descent in U.S. history, after Secretary of Labor Elaine L. Chao. The 55-year-old Taiwan-born Chao is currently the highest-ranking American official of Chinese descent in the United States.
Chu was born in the United States. His parents were both from mainland China.

Chu, known for his research in laser cooling and the trapping of atoms, which won him the Nobel Prize in Physics, has just returned to the United States from Taiwan, where he attended an Academia Sinica-sponsored forum of heads of prominent science institutes from around the world from Dec. 6-7.
During that forum, Chu delivered a keynote speech, titled: "The World's Energy Problem and What We Can Do About It".
Chu is currently a professor of physics and molecular and cellular biology at the University of California, Berkeley and the director of the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.

As warnings about global warming grow more dire, Chu is currently pushing his scientists at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and industry players to develop technologies to reduce the impact of climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County to turn salt field into ecological wetland

TEXT.P: The Tainan county government plans to turn a disused salt field into a wetland area that will benefit the county's ecology conservation, a local official said Thursday.

The county government will spend five years transforming the 16-hectare disused salt field in Chiku township into a wetland ecology park, according to Yang Ya- chu, an official of the county's Department of Agriculture.

Yang, who is a member of the department's forest biodiversity and conservation section, pointed out that growing trees is a lot more difficult on salt land than on ordinary farmland, and he admitted that Taiwan has had no success in turning salt fields into productive land.

In order to achieve a better chance of success, the local government has commissioned scholars and experts from National Chiayi University, National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, and the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute to evaluate and design the tree-planting project, and signed a contract Wednesday with the company that will carry out the project.
The company will first clear up a one-meter layer of clay under the salt field before connecting drainage pipes to ditches leading to the sea to help remove the salt from the land.
A flood pool will then be dug at the center to collect rainwater, and littoral plants such as mangroves will be planted around the pool to function as a windbreak, Yang said.

Yang said the county government hopes to see the project pay off within five years, although he said a subsidy of NT$40 million (US$1.2 million) from the central government is barely enough even for the project's initial phase, which will last until the end of next rear.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chang Gung University reveals new augmented-reality technologies

TEXT.P: Chang Gung University has developed a new set of augmented reality technologies for brain surgery that can shorten the time needed for surgery and reduce the risks involved, neurologists reported Thursday.

The technologies, invented by researchers at the Chang Gung University and Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Taoyuan, combine holographic display, augmented- reality surgery, an automated skull- opening drill, and customized tools for skull repair implants.

Unlike virtual reality (VR) , which uses computer-generated graphics to recreate items on a screen, augmented reality (AR) creates images by modifying real-time images of objects with additional computer-generated graphics.

Explaining the function of the technology, Lee Shih- tseng, director of the Medical Augmented Reality Research and Development Center operated by the university and hospital, said holographic displays can analyze medical data to produce a "remodeled" skull on screen, which allows 360-degree inspection and free removal of all bone and tissue.
Lee said that with the holographic display, brain surgeons can get a better idea of their patients' conditions and can determine the best path and means of surgery.

The complimentary technology of AR surgery, said Lee, allows the surgeon to operate on the model skull using a scalpel-like device that provides feedback and emulates the characteristics of blood vessel, tumor or bone.
"With the AR surgery, surgeons can practice the process in advance to reduce risk and avoid mistakes in the real operation, " Lee said.

In real surgery, Lee continued, the automated skull-opening drill will help control collateral damage by precisely measuring the depth of the drill, while the implant customization tool can precisely measure one or more bone plates that have to be replaced, and assist in producing implants that will fit perfectly with other surrounding bone.
According to Lee, the tool has been used on nearly 50 patients with good results.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-made snake antivenin exported to U.S.

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Thursday that it has recently received orders from the U.S. State of Florida for four kinds of antivenin to combat snakebite.

The CDC under the Cabinet-level Department of Health said the orders, from the Miami Fire Department, are for antivenin for envenomation by various well-known venomous snakes, including the Russell's viper and the banded krait.

As the orders were for four kinds of antivenin, each totaling 20 doses, the CDC has invited private companies to undertake the production of the total 80 doses of antivenin, with the CDC supplying the development know-how, CDC officials said.

According to the CDC, the agency has received more than 20 orders since 2003 from the United States, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and Israel for antivenin, with sales totaling nearly NT$3 million (US$90,909).

The CDC quoted World Health Organization statistics as indicating that about 125,000 people die from snake envenomation worldwide each year, while only 22 pharmaceutical companies from 17 countries are capable of producing antivenin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua county firefighting performance tops country

TEXT.P: Changhua County in central Taiwan has topped the country in terms of its firefighting performance in a national evaluation, the county's Fire Bureau Director-General Hsiao Chia-cheng said Thursday.

The fire bureau's performance was designated as "excellent" this year, receiving top ratings in five major categories -- fire prevention, disaster rescue and relief, local residents' involvement in firefighting efforts, fire disaster investigations and emergency medical treatment.

Hsiao said the National Fire Agency under the Ministry of the Interior conducts the annual evaluation in seven major categories, with more than 200 rating items on each city and county's firefighting performance.
The county won fifth place in 2005, third in 2006 and first in 2007, winning top ratings in four major categories, Hsiao noted.

The bureau has set up an efficient information management system on disaster reporting and vehicle and personnel dispatch. It also promotes training in cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, among local residents.

About 20,000 local residents have received CPR training over the past two years, Hsiao went on adding that the bureau will keep promoting CPR with the aim of having at least one in 10 people trained in the life-saving skill.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central bank announces further interest rate cuts

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank announced Thursday that it will further lower its benchmark interest rates by 0.75 percentage points from Friday as inflationary pressure has eased while the risks of a further downturn to the domestic economy are rising amid the global financial turmoil.

It will be the second-largest interest rate cut in the country's history and the fifth time the central bank has adjusted downward its key lending rates since September, when the global economy went into a recession because of fallout from the U.S. subprime crisis.

After the latest adjustments, the central bank's key lending rates will return to the levels recorded in July 2005, with the discount rate -- the interest rate the central bank charges depository institutions that borrow reserves from it -- falling to 2 percent, the rate on accommodations with collateral to 2.375 percent and the rate on accommodations without collateral to 4.25 percent.

Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) , told a news conference held after a meeting of the bank's board of directors and supervisors that the interest rate cut is expected to help spur domestic demand and buttress economic growth.

Quoting a forecast by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Perng said the consumer price index will grow a mere 0.37 percent next year, which will help ease inflationary pressure and stabilize domestic commodity prices.

Nevertheless, he went on, the job market might face even gloomier prospects and the unemployment rate will probably climb further as the country's exports -- the growth engine of the local economy -- have continued to shrink for three consecutive months.
Perng urged local banks not to withhold lending to normally operating business corporations at this trying time in order to keep the local economy afloat.

He also told local companies to make good use of the current low interest rates to launch long-term investments to facilitate corporate restructuring or transformation and upgrade their competitive edges.
For its part, Perng said, the central bank will maintain its measured monetary policy that will feature timely adjustments in a gradual manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: Proposal to revise election law draws heated debate

TEXT.P: A proposal to revise the election law was debated heatedly Thursday, one day after a lawmaker of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) had his election annulled by the Taichung High Court.
The court rejected Lu E-jin's appeal against a Miaoli District Court ruling in May that annulled his Jan. 12 election on vote-buying charges.

Lu, a first-term lawmaker, was the first of six legislators involved in election-related lawsuits to lose his seat. However, the loss was not expected to have a major impact on the legislature, which is dominated by the KMT, controlling along with its allies nearly 75 percent of the seats. The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) controls only 27 seats.
Lu, a former secretary-general of the Miaoli County Farmers' Association, was elected with 64,817 votes, beating two-term Legislator Tu Wen-ching of the DPP, who received 46,905 ballots.
Soon after his election, however, Lu and two of his campaign staff were indicted on vote-buying charges.

The district court ruled that 16 visits Lu made to temples to donate money through campaign aides in Yuanli and Ghunan -- two of the eight townships in one of Miaoli's County's two constituencies -- between June and October last year were undertaken to solicit support for his election bid.
The court said Lu had not been known previously to have made donations to the temples and had only done so during the election campaign.

Lu said Thursday that "it is only normal to make donations to temples" and denied that his donations were vote-buying. He added that members of his family will take part in the by-election for the legislative vacancy left by his annulment, adding that if the KMT nominates his wife, she will "run to the end."

KMT Legislator Lin Tsang-min proposed a revision to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, which stipulates that an incumbent legislator be stripped of his or her seat on the day the High Court annuls his or her election.

Lin proposed that an election should only be annulled upon conviction after the third or final ruling by the Supreme Court, and that the six-month time limit on each level of the court's litigation process should be scrapped.
The proposal was put on the agenda for Friday, but the KMT legislative caucus, possibly aware of the controversy over the proposal, decided that it would be discussed at a later date.
Chang Sho-wen, a KMT legislative caucus whip, said the proposal will still be fully discussed by lawmakers, as the DPP has expressed stiff opposition.

Judicial Yuan officials said Thursday that such a revision of the law governing election lawsuits could lengthen the litigation process to continue until even after the related party has served the full term.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Justice said it is not opposed to a revision of the law, but will respect the views of the agency in charge -- the Ministry of the Interior.

The prosecutors said that election lawsuits are a major tool in the battle to achieve clean elections and that if the litigation cannot be expedited but is in fact lengthened, then even the most rigorous crackdowns on vote-buying will lose their significance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Probes into ex-president's alleged corruption may end Friday

TEXT.P: Prosecutors may conclude investigations Friday into several high-profile money- related crimes allegedly implicating former President Chen Shui-bian and may recommend severe penalties for Chen, judicial sources said Thursday.

According to the sources, nearly 30 suspects, including Chen, will be indicted for their roles in four major cases -- embezzlement of a special presidential fund, money laundering and taking bribes in a science park land deal and a trade exhibition hall construction project.

The sources said prosecutors at the Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office are very busy these days as they are scheduled to finalize probes into the four complicated cases Friday.

Chen Yun-nan, director of the SID office, would not confirm whether investigations into those cases will be concluded anytime soon. He just said that members of the investigative team are very busy in recent days.

After a heated debate, judicial sources said, prosecutors have come to terms on seeking harsh penalties for the former president in light of the severity of the crimes he committed and his attitude in the course of hearings.
The sources said prosecutors may recommend a prison term longer than 25 years for Chen Shui-bian because the four crimes he allegedly committed were all very serious.

According to SID investigations, those who could be indicted in the "special state affairs" fund embezzlement case will include former President Chen, former first lady Wu Shu-jen, former presidential office cashier Chen Chen-hui and Chen Shui-bian's close aides Lin Teh-hsun and Ma Yung-cheng.

Nine suspects, including Chen Shui-bian, Wu Shu-jen, Chen Shui-bian's son and daughter-in-law Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching as well as Wu Shu-jen's older brother Wu Ching-mao, will be indicted in the money-laundering case, the sources said.

Chen Shui-bian and Wu Shu-jen will also be indicted for taking bribes in the Lungtan land development project, the sources said, adding that investigations into bribery in the Nangang Exhibition Hall construction project are jointly handled by the SID and the Taipei District Prosecutors Office.

The SID will be responsible for indictment of Wu Shu-jen and Tsai Ming-jhe for their roles in the Nangang project, while the Taipei District Prosecutors Office will handle indictment of other suspects in the case, including former Interior Minister Yu Cheng-hsien and 15 scholars responsible for evaluation of the project.
Meanwhile, sources said investigations into other cases impicating the former president and his family members, such as taking bribes from local financial groups, are still ongoing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Friday, moving down 54.60 points at 4,600.97 on a turnover of NT$2.62 billion (US$78.66 million).
The weighted price index lost 3.3 points to close at 4,655.57 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$33.293 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.016 from Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 12, or the 15th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Abel Yasman, a Dutch navigator, discovers New Zealand.
1787: Pennsylvania becomes the second state of the United States.
1804: Spain declares war on Britain.
1894: Japanese troops invade Korea.
1901: Italian physicist Marchese Guglielmo Marconi completes his first trans- Atlantic wireless radio transmission.
1906: The German company Telefunken successfully tests a wireless telephone.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, the provisional president of the Republic of China who promised to establish a republican government, proclaims himself emperor.
1932: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
1936: Chang Hsueh-liang's troops mutiny in Xian and hold Chiang Kai-shek and other ranking ROC government officials hostage.
1937: Japanese planes bomb and sink a U.S. warship in the Yangtze River in China, straining relations between Japan and the United States.
1941: The "Taiwan Revolutionary Alliance" is set up in Chungking and issues a statement urging all compatriots to unite against Japanese aggression.
1946: The ROC Ministry of the Interior rebuilds a national boundary monument at its southernmost boundary in the Nansha (Spratly) Islands.
1959: The "Hai Ming" freighter of China Merchants Steam Navigation Co. begins plying a route between Taiwan and the east coast of the United States, becoming the first Chinese ship to sail the route.
1971: Yiu Mi-chien, who was known as "the father of Taiwan's tourism industry," dies in Taipei at the age of 74.
1972: The Taipei City Council adopts a resolution on the establishment of sisterhood relations with Guam.
1972: The Sino-Guatemalan agricultural technical cooperation agreement is put into effect.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo declares that the ROC will become a nation of heavy industry after the completion of the "Ten Basic Construction Projects."
1979: Maj. Gen. Chun Doo-hwan and his colleagues stage an army coup and seize power in South Korea.
1982: The ROC wins a high proportion of medals, including 4 golds and 16 others as well as a special prize, at the 31st World Fair for Inventions held Dec. 4-12 in Brussels.
1984: An extradition treaty between the ROC and the Republic of Costa Rica is signed, the first such treaty signed by the ROC.
1991: Boris Yeltsin wins landslide approval in the Russian Parliament for his new Commonwealth of Independent States.
1992: Major earthquakes kill 2,500 people on Flores Island in eastern Indonesia.
1994: The Lien Chan Cabinet is re-organized, and new Cabinet members are sworn in three days later.
1995: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations passes a resolution to implement a treaty to set up a non-nuclear zone.
1999:A four-member delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng departs for Panama to attend a forum of presidents of legislative assemblies of the ROC and Central American countries.
2000: Legislator Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, takes the helm of an association of lawmakers to promote relations between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: Internet and media firm tom.com Ltd. and Taiwan's Business Weekly Publishing Inc. reach an agreement that tom.com purchases the magazine group's equity interest for NT$1.65 billion.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Bandeira Melo de Menezes, accompanied by his counterpart, ROC President Chen Shui-bian, visits the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) at Mailiao in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in business and careful in speech. He should seek the company of men of virtue and learning in order to profit by their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
U.S. varsity offers tuition privileges to Taiwanese students
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/12/08 12:53:57 (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The University of South Carolina, which maintains academic exchanges with several universities in Taiwan, is offering tuition privileges to students from Taiwan pursuing advanced studies at the university, beginning 2009, a faculty source said Thursday.

Taiwanese students who are admitted to the university to study from 2009 will be charged preferential tuition rates previously reserved only for students from the state of South Carolina, the source said.

The university, which maintains academic exchanges with the Taipei-based National Taiwan University and Ming Chuan University, as well as the Taichung- based China Medical University, has also decided to hire several teachers from Taiwan to teach mandarin Chinese starting in 2009.
The university has increased its exchanges with the Taiwanese universities since its president and deputy presidents began making visits to Taiwan several years ago.
It has also organized two teams of faculty and student representatives that travel to Taiwan each summer to learn mandarin Chinese and attend cultural exchanges forums.
Two professors from the university visited Taiwan earlier this year under the auspices of the Republic of China Ministry of Education for three weeks of research.

Meanwhile, Patricia Willer, an assistant president of the university in charge of international affairs, also traveled to Taiwan this year to lecture on international seminar sponsorship and practical experiences, at the invitation of the Foundation for International Cooperation on Higher Education, Taiwan, the source said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Around-Taiwan cycle relay kicks off in Taipei

TEXT.P: Four cycling teams are attempting to complete a 1,000 km around-Taiwan relay ride in 24 hours, with the first team setting off from Taipei early Friday, according to the organizers.

Speaking at a press conference to announce the start of the tour, Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Deputy Minister Tzeng Sheng-bao cited a statement by the International Cycling Union (ICU) saying that the event will demonstrate the energy and vitality of Taiwan, a global giant in the field of bicycle manufacture.

According to the Chinese Taipei Cycling Association, the relay tour is aimed at both promoting the International Tour de Taiwan that will take place next March and lending further impetus to the cycling fad in the country.

The first team of professional riders departed from the SAC headquarters, riding south down the island's west coast until it meets up with the next group in Miaoli, central Taiwan. Two other teams will be standing by in Kaohsiung and Taitung, respectively, to finish the remaining legs of the route.
The organizers said that adverse conditions along the way will challenge the cyclists, such as riding against the winter monsoon as well as the steep gradients on the mountainous eastern coast.
The teams will make stops in several counties that will play host to part of the Tour de Taiwan next year, with the final team slated to return to Taipei Saturday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung public construction contracts to be awarded before year-end

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission said Friday that the government will award contracts by the end of the year to bidders for public construction projects to be carried out with funds allocated to the southern port city by the Executive Yuan to stimulate domestic demand.
Commission chief Hsu Li-ming said that all 189 of the public construction projects, financed with a NT$3.78 billion central government budget, will be completed by the end of October next year.

Hsu said that as the public construction projects are meant to stimulate domestic demand in the short term, the city government has created deadlines for the awarding of the contracts and completion of the projects.

Many of the projects will be completed before the start of the 2009 Kaohsiung World Games that are set to kick off next July 16, Hsu said, adding that they include construction of several World Games venues such as an international standard swimming pool, ice skating rink and baseball field.
The largest public construction project under the plan is a series of water remediation projects, which will cost a total of about NT$550 million, according to the commission.
Some of the funds allocated by the Executive Yuan will also be used for social welfare, maintenance and upgrading of cultural sites, and other projects, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA launches plans to promote vocational training for workers

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Friday a series of plans to help workers and jobless people enhance their vocational skills with a budget of NT$2.7 billion (US$81 million) , in the hope of easing the unemployment upsurge.
"The plans will help workers accumulate vocational skills and boost the competitiveness of enterprises in terms of future development," CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan said at a press conference.

Chen Yi-min, director-general of the Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training, said vocational training is an investment for the future and a way to help enterprises ensure sustainable operations.
The vocational training plans are expected to provide assistance to 200,000 people, both workers and jobless people.

According to the CLA's plans, enterprises will be encouraged to apply for subsidies of 50 percent to 100 percent of training expenses from the Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training. Small- and medium-sized enterprises can receive a maximum subsidy of NT$950,000, while larger enterprises can get a maximum subsidy of NT$1.9 million.

The CLA will accept enterprises' applications for their workers aged between 15 and 65, including Taiwanese workers and Chinese spouses permitted to work, as well as foreign spouses with residence permits. Companies can file applications until September next year.

In addition, to help jobless people enhance their professional skills and return to the employment market, the CLA will provide subsidies to encourage them to take vocational training courses in more than 180 occupation categories. They will also receive a living allowance during the training period.
Of these, 137,000 lost their jobs as a result of closures or business reduction, which the CLA said is the main reason for the soaring unemployment rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president indicted

TEXT.P: Ex-president Chen Shui-bian was indicted Friday on money-laundering and corruption charges, becoming the first former president in Taiwan's history to be put on trial for criminal offenses.
Also indicted were 13 others.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president indicted (update-1)

TEXT.P: Ex-president Chen Shui-bian was indicted Friday on money-laundering and corruption charges, becoming the first former president in Taiwan's history to be put on trial for criminal offenses.
Instead of seeking a specifically defined sentence, the prosecutors are seeking the "harshest penalty" for the former president.
They also recommended "harsh penalties" for some of the other notables indicted, including Chen's wife Wu Shu-jen, his son Chen Chih-chung, his daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.

Prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office also formally charged 10 other individuals for their involvement in the former first family's alleged corruption and money-laundering schemes.

The charges are related to Chen's handling of his discretionary "state affairs fund" during his two terms as president from 2000-2008 and the movement of funds through proxies to overseas accounts held by Chen's wife, son and daughter-in- law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TransAsia pilot, co-pilot grounded for tire mishap

TEXT.P: The pilot and co-pilot of a TransAsia Airways ATR 72 aircraft whose four main tires burst upon landing in Penghu County Thursday were grounded Friday for negligence, with the pilot also likely to be fined.

The aircraft's four main tires burst when the TransAsia flight from southern Taiwan landed at Makung airport on Penghu Island at 10:36 a.m., but none of the 72 passengers and crew on the flight were injured.
Investigators from the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) originally suspected the accident was caused by mechanical failure or improper braking by the pilot.

They later found, however, that, in contravention of aviation regulations, the pilot activated the emergency brake during the flight to demonstrate emergency procedures to the co-pilot only to forget to release it before landing.
As a result, the tires locked upon landing and burst under pressure from the friction between the tires and the runway, the first time such an accident had occurred in Taiwan's aviation history.

CAA Deputy Director-General Lin Hsin-teh said the pilot and the co-pilot may be grounded for three months to one year, while the pilot may face fines ranging from NT$60,000 to NT$300,000 (US$9,090.90) for his negligence.

Lin said the CAA will complete the investigation into the case in one month and come up with a report for a CAA committee on aviation safety assessment and evaluation, which will make a decision on further disciplinary action.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature approves higher deductions for income taxpayers

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed amendments to the Income Tax Act Friday to raise several categories of deductions for individual income taxpayers.
The increased deductions will be applicable in May 2009 when 2008 tax returns should be filed.

One of those changes involves the standard deduction, which has been increased from NT$38,000 (US$114) to NT$73,000 for single taxpayers and from NT$76,000 to NT$146,000 for married couples filing a joint return.
A salary or wage earner's special deduction has been raised from NT$75,000 to NT$100,000, while the special deduction for the disabled has been hiked from NT$63,000 to NT$100,000.
Another of the changes concerns the deduction for higher education expenses, which has been adjusted from NT$25,000 per household to NT$25,000 per student.
Meanwhile, premiums for the national pension system have been listed as a deductible itemized expense.

The amendments mark the first time in recent years in which the deductions stipulated in the law have been changed, although the actual deductions have been raised several times over the past few years to reflect inflation.

For the tax year 2007, for example, the standard deduction was NT$46,000 for single taxpayers and NT$92,000 for married couples filing a joint return, while a salary or wage earner's special deduction was NT$78,000, and the special deduction for the disabled was NT$77,000.
The Ministry of Finance has estimated that the changes will benefit 3.6 million households, accounting for 69 percent of the total of 5.18 million families that file tax returns each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Energy conservation measures bear fruit: MOEA

TEXT.P: Energy-conservation incentives put in place in July helped reduce power consumption by 2.35 billion kilowatt hours between July to October from the same period a year earlier, representing a savings of NT$3.56 billion (US$106.94 million) on electricity bills around the country, the government said Friday.

The electricity rate discount program launched by The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on July 1 also contributed to a 1.5-million-ton reduction in carbon dioxide emissions during the four-month period, according to state-run Taiwan Power Company statistics.

Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming praised the success of the incentive measure, which was designed to promote energy conservation and greenhouse gas emission reduction at a time when oil, natural gas and coal prices were skyrocketing.
Earlier in day, Yiin visited the home of Taipei resident Hung Juo-pu, to present her with an award -- a folding bicycle -- for being the "master of conserving energy" in the city.
Hung won the title for saving 779 kwh, or 39.9 percent, in electricity consumption between July and September compared to the same period in 2007.
As a result, she saved a total of NT$713 on her electricity bills for the three- month period, according to the utility.

Hung's main energy-conservation strategies included using energy-saving bulbs, cleaning lamp covers regularly, and only using her washing machine two times a week and at off-peak hours at night, she said.

Under the government program, electricity rates were increased as of July 1 to reflect rising input costs. But those household and elementary and junior high school users who consumed less power than for the same period a year earlier were entitled to a rate discount of between 5 percent and 20 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia Sinica predicts near-zero economic growth for 2009

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth is likely to be near zero -- standing at just 0.56 percent -- for 2009 owing to the deep impact of the global financial crisis, the Academia Sinica forecast Friday.
The forecast compares with the 2.12 percent growth projected by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

In its latest outlook, the Academic Sinica's Institute of Economics predicted that Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) will record a negative growth of -2.3 percent in the fourth quarter of 2008, with the growth rate for the whole year registering 1.72 percent.

The institute said the industrial sector is expected to suffer further from a credit crunch in 2009 as international financial market adjustments continue, weighing inevitably on the country's unemployment rate and economic momentum.

Taiwan's export sector is likely to post a rare negative growth owing to a global economic downturn, while the worsening unemployment situation and weakening capital market will leave very limited room for an expansion in domestic demand, it said.
Boosted by the consumption voucher program and increased deductions for income taxpayers, private consumption is expected to increase by 1.42 percent in 2009.
But private sector investment will remain weak, with a negative growth of -3.85 percent expected for next year, according to the institution.

It predicted that the global economic freeze that began in the second half of 2008 will continue well into the first half of 2009, and Taiwan's exports of goods and services are unlikely to recover from negative growth until the third quarter of 2009, the institution said.
Meanwhile, the institution projected a decline of 4.25 percent in Taiwan's wholesale price index for 2009 because of plummeting global oil and commodity prices.
The situation will greatly relieve inflationary pressure in the country, with the consumer price index for 2009 likely to rise by a mere 0.17 percent, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NGOs demand equal rights for Chinese spouses

TEXT.P: Nongovernmental organizations on Friday criticized a Cabinet-approved amendment that will ease restrictions on Chinese spouses married to Taiwanese residents, saying it still did not give these new immigrants the same rights as other foreign spouses living in Taiwan.
"There is a gap between our expectations and the result, " admitted Chung Jin- ming, president of an alliance that promotes marriages between Taiwanese and Chinese nationals.
He urged President Ma Ying-jeou to fulfill his campaign promise to treat Chinese the same way as other foreign spouses.
"That's our bottom line," he said.

The Cabinet approved Thursday a draft amendment to the Act Governing Relations Between People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, shortening the time it takes them to qualify for a Taiwan identity card.
The draft amendment will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for review. If approved, it will take Chinese immigrants six years, instead of the current eight, to qualify for a Taiwanese identity card.
But for other foreign spouses, mostly originating from Southeast Asian countries, such as Vietnam and Indonesia, it takes only four years to get an identity card.

Wang Chuan-ping, president of the New Immigrants Labor Rights Association, expressed herregretsthat the Cabinet decided to mandate a waiting period of six years before Chinese spouses can apply for a Taiwan identity card.
She said that her association will begin lobbying legislators next week in a bid to convince them to change the length of the ID card waiting period to the same as for other foreign spouses.

Among other adjustments included in the Cabinet-approved amendment was eliminating the cap on the amount Chinese immigrants could inherit from their Taiwanese spouses, which currently stands at NT$2 million.

They can also obtain work permits as long as they enter Taiwan legally, instead of having to meet specific existing requirements, such as having lived in Taiwan for at least two years, having children or being in a low-income household.
In terms of the changes, Chung described the Cabinet's decision as "postponed justice."
There are an estimated 290,000 Chinese spouses in Taiwan, representing the largest group of foreign spouses in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Medical U. chairman cited for outstanding achievements

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taipei Medical University (TMU) was recently cited by the Hong Kong-based Asian Knowledge Management Association (AKMA) for outstanding achievement in facilitating medical reforms in Taiwan.

Lee Tsu-teh, a TMU alumnus who majored in dentistry and has been chairman of the Taiwanese Business Association in Tangshan in northern China since 1996, was conferred with an Asian Knowledge Management Association Award for corporations by the AKMA at a ceremony held at the University of Hong Kong Dec. 9.
Lee was the only citizen from Taiwan to be honored with the prestigious award this year.
After being elected a board member of TMU in 1995 in his capacity as a TMU alumnus, Lee soon helped unite the university that had long been splintered by internal strife and financial deficits.
Lee then was elected chairman of the university's board of directors because of his shrewd moves to help the privately-run medical university emerge from its personnel and financial quagmire.
Over the past decade, Lee also pushed TMU to incorporate Taipei City Hospital's Wan Fang Branch, enabling the branch to become profitable within a few years.

Lee was also instrumental in facilitating TMU's takeover of the management of Shuang Ho Hospital located in Jhonghe City, Taipei County, beating out a number of powerful competitors, including the Taichung-based China Medical University, Fu Jen Catholic University and Chang Gung Memorial Hospital.
TMU's incorporation of Wan Fang Hospital and Shuang Ho Hospital transformed the university and its affiliated hospitals into the largest medical service system in the Greater Taipei area.

AKMA is the first professional body in the world to have developed a series of certification standards specific to knowledge management, intellectual property protection and intellectual capital realization.
AKMA is dedicated to the ongoing development, promotion and application of knowledge management principles, models and techniques in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower sharply Friday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for December falling 244 points to close at 4,425, with 119,805 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for January lost 256 points to finish at 4,388, with 8,950 contracts traded, while March futures declined 230 points to end at 4,376, with 68 contracts traded.
June futures fell 238 points to close at 4,338, with 19 contract transactions, while September futures lost 240 points to finish at 4,153, with 48 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,669 for December, 4,644 for January, 4,606 for March, 4,576 for June and 4,393 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 174.3 points to finish at 4,481.27, on turnover of NT$90.22 billion (US$2.71 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
December TE futures fell 12.15 points to close at 165.85, with 6,785 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 12.35 points to finish at 164.4, with 405 contracts traded.

March TE futures dropped 11.75 points to finish at 160.15 points, with three contracts traded, while September TF futures lost 11.1 points to end at 148.9, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June.
December TF futures were down 39.8 points to close at 554, with 5,663 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures decreased 40.8 points to finish at 551, with 296 contracts traded.

March TF futures lost 39.8 points to end at 540, with four contracts traded, while September TF futures lost 37.4 points to end at 524.2, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.006 to close at NT$33.315.
A total of US$995 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.309 and fluctuated between NT$33.209 and NT$33.355.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares plunge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Friday, with sentiment dampened by the U.S. Senate's failure to approve a US$14 billion bailout of the U.S. auto industry overnight.

The Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, fell 174.3 points, or 3.74 percent, to close at 4,481.27, after opening at 4,600.97 and fluctuating between a high of 4,654.75 and a low of 4,401.05.
A total of 5.33 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$90.22 billion (US$2.71 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares falling the most at 5.66 percent, machinery and electronics stocks shedding 4.51 percent, paper and pulp issues moving down 3.94 percent, cement stocks falling 2.52 percent, foodstuff issues dropping 1.97 percent, textile stocks decreasing 1.75 percent, plastics and chemicals shares losing 1.74 percent, and construction stocks falling 1.35 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,291 to 247, with 190 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$4.56 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers must spend more to help economic recovery: vice president

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Friday that increased consumer spending is vital to helping the domestic economy gradually recover.

Speaking at the opening of an IT Month event in the central city of Taichung, Siew said that although the government has a responsibility to implement response measures to deal with the flagging economy, it is more important that consumers understand the situation and have confidence in the economy by "standing firm and moving forward" with more spending.

He noted that the government has moved to stem a further decline in the economy through its consumer voucher program and public construction projects, which he said will hopefully help the country move away from negative economic growth by next year.
After attending the ribbon-cutting ceremony to open the event, Siew spent some time viewing the various digital products on display.
More than 300 hundred businesses have set up over 1,200 booths at the IT Month being held at the former Shuinan Airport to showcase their latest computer and consumer electronics products.
Taichung is the second stop of the IT Month event -- now in its 26th year -- following a nine-day run at the Taipei World Trade Center earlier this month.

After wrapping up in Taichung, the show will move to Tainan and Kaohsiung. It will also be held in Yilan County in March and in Yunlin County in April -- the first time it will have been held in those areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's benefits to continue despite indictment

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian will continue to receive his retirement benefits despite being indicted Friday on money-laundering and corruption charges, according to a Presidential Office source.

Chen will continue to receive the benefits former presidents are entitled to, including a monthly pension of NT$250,000 (US$7,485) and reimbursement of expenses for an office staff and chauffeur, unless he is convicted and has exhausted all avenues for appeal, the source said.
According to the law governing the benefits of retired presidents and vice presidents, ex-presidents receive NT$8 million in overall retirement benefits in their first year after leaving office.
The amount declines annually and falls to NT$5 million by the fourth year of their retirement and stays at that level for the rest of their lives.

In addition, Chen, as a former president, is entitled to have eight to 12 bodyguards provided by the National Security Bureau and the number of bodyguards can be added if necessary, according to the law.
The Presidential Office calculated recently that the year-end bonus that Chen will be receiving soon totals NT$507,688.
In related news, the Presidential Office would not comment on Chen's indictment Friday, saying only that the government respects all decisions made by the judiciary.

The Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office asked in its 209-page indictment that judges of the Taipei District Court give the former president "the harshest penalty" and requested that Chen continue to be detained pending probes into other criminal cases in which he may be implicated.
The prosecutors also recommended "harsh penalties" for some of the other notables indicted, including Chen's wife Wu Shu-jen, his son Chen Chih-chung, his daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
They also formally charged 10 other individuals for their involvement in the former first family's alleged corruption and money-laundering schemes.

The charges are related to Chen's handling of his discretionary "state affairs fund" during his two terms as president from 2000-2008 and the movement of funds through proxies to overseas accounts held by Chen's wife, son and daughter-in- law.

DOC.HEADLINE: 24-hour charity ultra-marathon to kick off in Taipei

TEXT.P: A 24-hour charity ultra-marathon will kick off in Taipei Saturday, with the participation of internationally recognized runners, in the hope of providing assistance to a Taiwanese runner who lost both legs after she contracted a severe bacterial infection earlier this year, the organizer said Friday.

Speaking at a press conference to announce the start of the Soochow International Ultra-Marathon 24-hr Race, Soochow University President Hwang Jenn-tai said that in addition to helping the runners to develop will and perseverance, the race this year will be dedicated to Chiu Shu-jung.

Chiu, a female ultra-marathon runner who broke the Asian record and placed second in the Spartathlon race held in Greece in March, had to have a double amputation due to a bacterial infection she contracted after completing the 18-day Trans Gaule run along a 1,150-kilometer route in France.

Twenty-eight participants from around the world will run around the school athletics track for 24 straight hours starting Saturday morning, the organizer said. While the race is in progress, local students will stage a series of performances at different intervals.

Among the international participants, Edit Berces from Hungary, who currently holds two world records, and Ryoichi Sekiya from Japan, who has won three world championships titles, will be running for Chiu's cause.
Sponsoring businesses will adopt the accumulated laps run the by athletes, donating NT$100 (US$3) for each lap. The organizer is eying a target of NT$1 million.
Chiu returned to Taiwan in late September after her double amputation surgery in France, and is now in the process of recovery.

The Taipei race, certified by the International Association of Ultra Runners (IAU), is currently the only ultra-marathon held on a regular basis in Taiwan and has produced the world's best records in five of its seven years of history.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gondola's damaged support pillar should be relocated: engineers

TEXT.P: Four associations of professional engineers in Taipei city finalized their assessment of the damage to a support structure on the Maokong Gondola system Friday and recommended that relocating the eroded pillar would be the best choice to deal with the problem.

Shih Yi-fang, the spokesman for the groups of civil engineers, experts in structure engineering, soil and water conservation technicians and geotechnical engineers, made the recommendation as the groups released their final report on the damage to Tower No.16 on the cable car system.
Shih said they have concluded that the most suitable spot for T-16 would be 20-30 meters away from its current location, closer to Tower No. 17.
It is better for the new T-16 to be erected between T-17 and the damaged pillar and in a straight line with them, he said.

The 120-page report attributed the problem to a cave-in on the hillside where the damaged pillar is located, and concluded that the cave-in occurred because of the area's "unsuitable geology" for the support structure and an unusually high volume of rainfall.
The report described T-16 as a "casualty of the cave-in."

The geology problem could have been detected by drilling at the spot before the tower was constructed, the report stated, adding however that the recent data collected for T-16 was obtained by drilling at a spot some 70 meters away from its current location.

According to a preliminary estimate by city officials, relocating the tower would cost at least NT$200 million (US$6 million) and would take two years, while reinforcing the existing tower at its current location would take only six months.

The gondola, one of the most popular tourist attractions in the capital city, connects Taipei City Zoo and the Maokong tea production area in the Muzha district. The service was closed indefinitely on Oct. 1 on fears that T-16 could collapse during an earthquake.
Torrential rain brought by Typhoon Jangmei in September eroded the tower's base, leaving its foundation exposed.

Taipei city government spokesman Yang Hsiao-tung said that the findings in the engineers' report proved that the cave-in, which poses a threat to a nearby community, was not caused by the construction of the gondola system.

The city government will begin work to stabilize the eroded slope and reinforce the foundation of the problematic pillar, and at the same time, will select the best site for the relocation of T-16, he said.
Yang said the city government will do its utmost to resume operation of the cable car system, which he described as the public's favorite leisure facility.
However, there is now no fixed schedule for the resumption of the service, he added.
According to the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. which operates the Maokong Gondola, over 6.1 million passengers had ridden the system as of Oct. 1 since its official inauguration on July 4, 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president indicted (update-2)

TEXT.P: Ex-president Chen Shui-bian was indicted Friday on money laundering, corruption and forgery charges involving nearly half a billion Taiwan dollars, becoming the first former president in Taiwan's history to be put on trial for criminal offenses.
Instead of seeking a specifically defined sentence, the prosecutors are seeking the "harshest penalty" for Taiwan's former leader.

Prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office also formally charged Chen's wife Wu Shu-jen, his son Chen Chih-chung and his daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, and recommended they receive "harsh penalties."
In addition, prosecutors indicted 10 other individuals for their involvement in the former first family's alleged corruption and money-laundering schemes.

In a news conference called to announce the indictment, Chen Yun-nan, chief of the division, said Chen Shui-bian's purported offenses were staggering and allowed him to obtain ill-gotten gains on a scale "never seen before."

His offenses were all the more objectionable because he had sworn to abide by the lay in carrying out his duties as president, and therefore should be punished to the full extent of the law, the leading prosecutor said.
As to the ex-first lady, Chen Yun-nan said she deserves a harsh penalty for using her status to interfere with her husband's administration's decisions in exchange for personal profits.

The ex-president's son and daughter-in-law, who are the holders of many of their family's overseas bank accounts, should also be punished harshly for refusing to reveal until now their overseas wealth.
The prosecutors in charge of the investigation of the case suspect those bank accounts were used to conceal some of their parents' ill-gotten assets.
The indictment charged Chen Shui-bian and his wife of illegally receiving or embezzling NT$490 million, including NT$204.15 million and US$8.73 million, some of which was sent overseas.
Of that total, the indictment reads, NT$104.15 million was embezzled from the state affairs fund set aside for the president's discretionary use during his eight years in office from 2000 to 2008.

Prosecutors charge that more than NT$27 million of that was obtained by using inappropriate receipts to claim reimbursement from the fund, nearly double the NT$14.8 million Wu was originally indicted for embezzling from the fund in 2006.

The balance, or more than NT$76 million, was claimed by Presidential Office cashier Chen Chen-hui as "secret funds" from the state affairs fund and handed over to Wu Shu-jen to pay for the family's daily living expenses and other uses, the indictment alleges.

The ex-first family allegedly received Another NT$100 million and US$6 million in kickbacks from a total payoff of US$11.98 million by a development company called "Dayu" to pave the way for the Hsinchu Science Park to buy a plot of land held by Dayu in Taoyuan County at a price prosecutors believe was unreasonably high.

The balance of the bribe money was pocketed by James Lee, then-chief of the Hsinchu Science Park, and Tsai Ming-jhe, who transferred the kickback to accounts held by ex-first family members, prosecutors charged.

The indictment accuses the former first family of collecting another US$2.73 million in bribes from contractor Kuo Chuan-ching to help him win a tender to build the Nangang Exhibition Hall between 2002 and 2003.

Prosecutors believe Kuo won the contract by bribing members of a panel organized by the Ministry of Interior to assess the bidding after then-Interior Minister Yu Cheng-hsien revealed the list of panel members to Kuo at the request of Wu Shu-jen.
Yu Cheng-hsien was separately indicted by the Taipei District Prosecutors Office Friday for leaking secrets.
As for the other 10 defendants, the prosecutor asked the court to hand down lenient punishments or spare them because they have shown remorse and thoroughly testified to their roles in the case.
They included Wu Shu-jen's brother Wu Ching-mao, her sister-in-law Chen Chun-ying, her university classmate Tsai Mei-li, and Tsai's brothers Tsai Ming- jhe and Tsai Ming-jie.
They were all charged with helping the ex-first family collect bribes and wire them abroad.
Also included were Chen Shui-bian's former aides, cashier Chen Chen-hui, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng, and the head of the president's office Lin Teh-hsun.
They were accused of helping the ex-first family illegally claim reimbursements from the state affairs fund.
Former Hsinchu Science Park chief Lee and businessman Kuo were also indicted for helping the ex-first family solicit bribes and line their own pockets with a portion of the revenues.
Of the 14 defendants, only the former president is still being held in custody.

The ex-first family's possible engagement in money laundering come to light after the anti-money laundering group, The Egmont Group, alerted Taipei in late 2006 and early 2008 of millions of U.S. dollars stashed in overseas bank accounts held by their family members.

In one instance of the alleged intricate money laundering scheme, prosecutors tracked Kuo's kickback to a bank account held by Tsai Ming-jhe in Hong Kong, then to a Standard Bank account held by Wu Ching-mao in Singapore.

The funds were then transferred to Huang Jui-ching's Merrill Lynch Bank account in Switzerland and an account in RBS Coutts Bank in Switzerland held by Chen Chih-chung under the name Galahad Management S.A.

The former president admitted on August 14 that his wife had remitted more than US$20 million overseas, but said the funds were surplus contributions to his campaigns for Taipei City mayor in 1994 and 1998 and the presidency in 2000 and 2004.

Friday's indictment may not be the last legal challenge the former first family faces. Chen Shui-bian and his wife are still being probed for helping several financial conglomerates acquire financial holding companies in return for their "political contributions."
Wu Shu-jen has already been indicted in 2006 for embezzling NT$14.8 million from the state affairs fund and the trial is ongoing.
Chen Shui-bian was not charged at the time because he held presidential immunity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Coral survey suggests huge quakes may hit South Asia in next decades

TEXT.P: An international survey of the coral reefs off Indonesia indicates that a series of huge earthquakes are likely to hit South Asia in the coming decades, packing destructive power similar to the magnitude 9.3 quake that triggered a devastating tsunami in Southeast Asia in Dec. 2004.

According to an article published in the latest issue of the weekly journal Science, a research team composed of scientists from Indonesia, Taiwan, and the United States studied seismic patterns over the past 700 years and hypothesized the existence of an "earthquake supercycle" every 200 years.

During the supercycle, a magnitude-8 quake would mark the beginning of a new cycle, one or more magnitude-8 quakes would follow, and a super quake of about magnitude 9 would end the cycle by consuming much of the tectonic energy accumulated over the past two centuries.
The magnitude-8.4 temblor of September 2007, they reported, is the "opening salvo" in the 30-year period of each supercycle of quakes in the region when seismic activity peaks.
The researchers suggested that a quake with a magnitude of between 7 to 8 will occur every six to 13 years, and a super quake of magnitude 9 will hit South Asia in about 30 years.

The study -- conducted by scientists from Indonesia, Taiwan, and the United States -- derived their conclusions from an analysis of dead corals off Sumatra's Mentawai Islands to get a better idea of how corals are affected by earthquakes, especially those of magnitude 7 or above.
The scientists explained that huge earthquakes in the past would lift the reefs by one meter or more above the sea's surface and cause the massive die-off of coral reefs.
These dead corals left behind, much to the team's surprise, mineral structures that explicitly recorded the time and scale of almost every large earthquake in the area over the past 700 years.

"Each incident triggered widespread coral deaths, but the long- lasting mineral structures built by the colonies enable scientists to estimate the dates of the massive quakes that caused those upheavals," said Aron J. Meltzner, a participant from the California Institute of Technology.
The earthquakes "recorded" in coral structures occurred in 1374, 1596, 1675, 1797, 1833 and 2007.

In the "coral records of earthquakes," the scientists discerned a pattern for the earthquakes in the region, namely the supercycle theory. They used the theory and the temblor of September 2007 to reach the conclusion that a new supercycle has already begun.

The Dec. 2004 earthquake was not considered in the study because its epicenter was located 150 kilometers northwest of the northern tip of Sumatra Island and had probably consumed much of the tectonic energy in its area.
The study's area of investigation was much farther south off the Sumatra coast and part of a different tectonic system, according to Shen Chuan-chou, a project member from National Taiwan University.

A separate study reported in the Dec. 4 Nature also suggested that the region's 2007 quake released only one-quarter of the energy that had accumulated since 1833, so the quakes in the region in the coming decades may be even larger than expected.

"If the supercycle theory proves true, the South Asian countries should stay alert for possible huge earthquakes and step up their efforts to establish the earthquake/tsunami early warning network, " Shen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's lawyers describe indictment as purge

TEXT.P: The indictment against former President Chen Shui-bian on corruption and money laundering charges is inaccurate and basically a "purge of officials of the previous administration, " Chen's lawyers said Friday.

The lawyers, including Cheng Sheng-chu, Cheng Wen-lung, Lee Sheng-hsiung and Lee Sheng-chen, made the remarks after Chen was indicted earlier in the day in connection with a series of corruption-related scandals involving himself and family members.
The charges were the first filed against Chen since his Nov.12 arrest and detention. No other former Taiwan president has ever faced criminal prosecution.
Prosecutors have recommended that the former president be given the harshest sentence for his alleged illegalities involving nearly half a billion Taiwan dollars.
Indicted together with Chen were his wife, Wu Shu-jen, his son Chen Chih-chung, his daughter-in-law, Huang Jui-ching, three of his former aides in the Presidential Office, and seven other associates.
Prosecutors said the former president and his wife together embezzled NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special presidential fund during Chen's presidency from 2000-2008.

They also took bribes worth NT$100 million and US$6 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another US$2.73 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, prosecutors charged.

Cheng Sheng-chu said he was not surprised by the indictment of the former first couple, but he insisted that all the charges against Chen Shui-bian and Wu Shu- jen as well as the 12 other defendants are not factual.
For one thing, Cheng said, prosecutors overlooked the fact that local politicians tend to accept political contributions.
"Prosecutors cast the Chen family's huge cash assets in a negative light and then tried to seek evidence to back their conjecture.

"In the process, they had to detain many potential suspects and enticed the detainees to become witnesses for the state, " Cheng contended, adding that the conjecture and evidence presented in the indictment are full of contradictions and not solid.

He also questioned the propriety of the presidential fund embezzlement charges against Chen, arguing that the use of the fund belonged to the president's administrative power, which should be free of interference by judicial authorities.
Another of Chen's lawyers, Cheng Wen-lung, said he felt a bit disappointed when he read the indictment, which he described as "not well argued."
Accusing prosecutors of squeezing testimony from detainees has infringed upon the human rights of suspects.
"The prosecution has failed to uphold the due process of law and justice," he asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former first lady's brother apologizes for role in money laundering

TEXT.P: The brother-in-law of ex-President Chen Shui-bian apologized to the public Friday for the social costs caused by his role in helping with the alleged money laundering of the former first family.

Wu made the apology in an interview with television reporters after the Special Investigation Division (SID) of the Supreme Prosecutors Office indicted 14 people upon conclusion of its investigation into the money laundering and corruption cases that prosecutors charged netted the former first family NT$490 million (US$14.71 million) in illegal gains.

Although Wu was one of the 14 defendants being prosecuted, the SID's indictment recommended to the court that his sentence be reduced to the minimum in consideration of the fact that he was fully cooperative during the investigation.
"I appreciate the Special Investigation Division's understanding, " Wu said. "I was willing to cooperate fully with the prosecutors in their investigation, and I regretted what I had done."

Asked how he felt about the prosecution describing the conduct of his sister -- the former first lady Wu Shu-jen -- as a "serious violation of the law," he said it will be up to the court to judge whether that is the case.

In its indictment, the SID asked the court to mete out the "harshest" sentence to the former president and "heavy" penalties for his wife, son and daughter-in- law, while seeking commuted sentences for the other 10 defendants, including Wu Ching-mao, because they were cooperative during the investigation.

Wu was released on Nov. 28 on bail of NT$2 million after being detained for 53 days as prosecutors investigated allegations that he used his accounts in Singapore to help his sister transfer US$20 million to two bank accounts in Switzerland held by her daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
The investigation began after Swiss authorities suspected money laundering and sought information about the account holder from Taiwan's judicial authorities.

The SID later also obtained information from Singapore's judicial authorities, tracing the money to an account at South Africa's Standard Bank in Singapore owned by Wu Ching-mao, who received the money in several transactions from bank accounts in Hong Kong held by the former first lady's college classmate Tsai Mei-li and Tsai's two brothers.

Taiwan's investigative authorities received a report from the international anti-money laundering organization The Egmont Group in January this year regarding the Cayman Islands' financial intelligence unit's suspicions that the former first family was laundering money through an account created under the name of Chen's daughter-in-law at the Merrill Lynch Bank in Geneva, Switzerland.

However, instead of ordering an investigation into the suspected money laundering, the then Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau Director-General Yeh Sheng-mao showed the report to the then president -- the chief suspect who should have been the target of the investigation.
In early December, the Taipei District Court sentenced Yeh to 10 years in prison after finding him guilty of corruption, of concealing a government file and of leaking confidential information.

DOC.HEADLINE: President formally opens historic figure's residence to visitors

TEXT.P: The residence of Chang Hsueh-liang (1901-2001), who was a key figure in the modern history of China, was formally opened to the public Friday, in the hope that the historic site in the Wufeng township of Hsinchu County will attract tourists, particularly those from China.

President Ma Ying-jeou cut the ribbons at the ceremony to unveil two bronze statues of Chang and Chang's wife Chao I-ti. Also at the ceremony were members of Chang's family, and Guo Junsheng, curator of a museum in Shenyiang, northeastern China, dedicated to the Chang's son.

Chang was placed under house arrest in Wufeng in northern Taiwan and held until 1990 for his role as the instigator of the Xian Incident that occurred in Xian in the central China province of Shaanxi on Dec. 12, 1936.

On that date, Chang kidnapped the leader of the Kuomintang (KMT) government Chiang Kai-shek and held him hostage until Chiang agreed to form a united front with the Communists of China against the Japanese.

Chiang at the time held a non-aggressive position regarding Japan and considered the Communists to be a greater danger to the government of the Republic of China than the Japanese. His overall strategy, therefore, was to annihilate the Communists before focusing his efforts on the Japanese. However, growing nationalist anger against Japan made this position very unpopular, leading to Chang's action against Chiang.

The operation cost Chang his freedom, as he was placed under house arrest shortly after the incident and was not freed even after the KMT government relocated to Taiwan in 1949 when the Communists took control of the Chinese mainland.
In his address, Ma described Chang as a "quiet and silent" historic figure, who even after he was freed in 1990 never publicly complained of being mistreated.

The raw emotions of the feud have faded since the deaths of both Chang and Chiang, Ma said, adding that his own efforts to foster reconciliation between Taiwan and China also include seeking forgiveness.
"I hope this historic site will attract tourists," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung County police relieve stress by smashing dinnerware

TEXT.P: The Taitung County Police Bureau has borrowed an idea from abroad to help overworked police officers relieve stress by encouraging them to smash dinnerware at a training camp.
Some of the officers who took part in the stress-relief program said Friday that they felt great when they heard the ceramic plates breaking against a wall.
"I felt like the pressure on me was gone," said one of the officers as he recounted his experience.
The police bureau collected 400 unwanted plates from restaurants in the county for the program. Each officer was allowed to smash three plates.
Pent-up officers could write down their complaints or the names of the bosses they hated most on the plates before hurling the dinnerware as hard as they could against a stone wall.
According to another police officer who spoke on condition of anonymity, the stress comes mainly from the constant demand for good work performance.
He added that unscheduled stints, irregular work shifts and pressure from elected county councilors also contribute to the stress on police officers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former interior minister indicted

TEXT.P: The Taipei Prosecutors Office on Friday indicted former Interior Minister Yu Cheng-hsien, construction contractor Kuo Chuan-ching and seven scholars for their involvement in irregularities related to the construction of the Taipei World Trade Center's Nankang Exhibition Hall.
The indictment asked that the court be lenient toward Yu and Kuo, but demanded that the seven scholars be severely punished.
