Chang was placed under house arrest in Wufeng in northern Taiwan and held until 1990 for his role as the instigator of the Xian Incident that occurred in Xian in the central China province of Shaanxi on Dec. 12, 1936.

On that date, Chang kidnapped the leader of the Kuomintang (KMT) government Chiang Kai-shek and held him hostage until Chiang agreed to form a united front with the Communists of China against the Japanese.

Chiang at the time held a non-aggressive position regarding Japan and considered the Communists to be a greater danger to the government of the Republic of China than the Japanese. His overall strategy, therefore, was to annihilate the Communists before focusing his efforts on the Japanese. However, growing nationalist anger against Japan made this position very unpopular, leading to Chang's action against Chiang.

The operation cost Chang his freedom, as he was placed under house arrest shortly after the incident and was not freed even after the KMT government relocated to Taiwan in 1949 when the Communists took control of the Chinese mainland.
In his address, Ma described Chang as a "quiet and silent" historic figure, who even after he was freed in 1990 never publicly complained of being mistreated.

The raw emotions of the feud have faded since the deaths of both Chang and Chiang, Ma said, adding that his own efforts to foster reconciliation between Taiwan and China also include seeking forgiveness.
"I hope this historic site will attract tourists," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung County police relieve stress by smashing dinnerware

TEXT.P: The Taitung County Police Bureau has borrowed an idea from abroad to help overworked police officers relieve stress by encouraging them to smash dinnerware at a training camp.
Some of the officers who took part in the stress-relief program said Friday that they felt great when they heard the ceramic plates breaking against a wall.
"I felt like the pressure on me was gone," said one of the officers as he recounted his experience.
The police bureau collected 400 unwanted plates from restaurants in the county for the program. Each officer was allowed to smash three plates.
Pent-up officers could write down their complaints or the names of the bosses they hated most on the plates before hurling the dinnerware as hard as they could against a stone wall.
According to another police officer who spoke on condition of anonymity, the stress comes mainly from the constant demand for good work performance.
He added that unscheduled stints, irregular work shifts and pressure from elected county councilors also contribute to the stress on police officers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
'I have fought the good fight' against corruption: former DPP chair

TEXT.P: The leader of the unsuccessful 2006 campaign to depose then President Chen Shui- bian declined on Friday to comment on the indictment of Chen and three members of the former first family, whose integrity came into question publicly at the time amid a series of corruption scandals.

Shih Ming-teh, who served as chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party between 1994 and 1996 before quitting the party in 2000, said in a brief statement, "I have fought the good fight against corruption, and there is no need for me to clean the battlefield."

Shih was highly critical of Chen in mid-November after the former president staged a hunger strike while being held in a detention center to prevent him from collusion with other defendants and witnesses in the corruption cases involving the former first family.
Shih said that Chen "trampled on the dignity of the Taiwanese people and betrayed their expectations."

Shih issued the statement after the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office indicted Chen, seeking the "harshest" penalty for him on charges of money laundering, corruption and forgery involving nearly half a billion Taiwan dollars, and making him the first former president in Taiwan's history to face trial for criminal offenses.

The prosecutors also formally charged Chen's wife Wu Shu-jen, his son Chen Chih- chung and his daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, and sought "heavy penalties" for them, while recommending commuted sentences for 10 other individuals for their involvement in the former first family's alleged corruption and money- laundering schemes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former interior minister indicted

TEXT.P: The Taipei Prosecutors Office on Friday indicted former Interior Minister Yu Cheng-hsien, construction contractor Kuo Chuan-ching and seven scholars for their involvement in irregularities related to the construction of the Taipei World Trade Center's Nankang Exhibition Hall.
The indictment asked that the court be lenient toward Yu and Kuo, but demanded that the seven scholars be severely punished.

The indictment charged that the seven -- Cheng Tsung-jung, Wang Lung-chang, Chiang Cher-ming, Chou Chia-peng, Chen Po-ya, Kuo Yung-chieh and Wang Cheng-ying -- who all teach at local universities, have "pursued their own interests in lining their own pockets during the screening of the nation's major procurement projects and had shown no remorse."
According to the indictment, Kuo promised former first lady Wu Shu-jen he would pay 2.5 percent of the total contract value as a kickback if he won the tender.

Yu told prosecutors that Wu then asked him to release the names of the seven scholars on the project's screening panel to Kuo, the chairman of Leader Construction Co., so that Kuo could influence the panel and help his chances of winning the tender.
The Ministry of the Interior is required by law not to reveal the names of those on the screening panel.

With the list in hand, Kuo paid between NT$500,000 and NT$1 million to each of the panel members to secure their support and ultimately was named as the priority bidder on the project in January 2004 before winning the contract at a price tag of NT$3.59 billion, the indictment charged.
Prosecutors asked for leniency toward the former interior minister after determining that Kuo's kickbacks were paid to the former first lady and not to Yu.

They also asked for leniency for Kuo, who the indictment said confessed to his acts of wrongdoing during the investigation and took the initiative to provide related evidence to shed more light on the case.

The Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office earlier Friday indicted former President Chen Shui-bian and his wife Wu Shu-jen for illegal gains of NT$490 million from embezzling state funds and taking bribes in two other scandals, including taking payoffs from Kuo related to the Nankang Exhibition Hall project.
Wu, during questioning by prosecutors Nov. 15, said the money she received from Kuo was a political donation.

The indictment said, however, that the US$2.73 million Kuo paid Wu was not an ordinary political donation, noting Kuo's promise to pay 2.5 percent of the total contract value as a kickback, and Kuo's offering of NT$6 million in standard political donations on Nov. 19, 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to assume political responsibility for Chen's legacies: chief

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is willing to assume full political responsibility for what former President Chen Shui-bian did during his years in office between 2000 and May 2008, the opposition party's chief said Friday.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made the remarks after Chen was indicted earlier in the day on corruption and money laundering charges involving himself and family members. No other former Taiwan president has ever faced criminal prosecution.
Prosecutors have recommended that the former president be given the harshest sentence for his alleged illegalities involving nearly half a billion Taiwan dollars.
Noting that Chen is an integral part of the DPP's history, Tsai said the party will definitely assume political responsibility for his legacies.
Terming Chen's indictment marks one of the most difficult moments in the party's history, Tsai called on all DPP members to stand united in order not to let down its supporters.

Chen, who has been detained since Nov.12, twice served as DPP chairman, but quit the party in August after publicly confessing to doing "what the law does not permit" by wiring a sum of money abroad. He still retains a core of enthusiastic pro-independence supporters.
Some political analysts predicted that Chen will still affect the inner workings of the DPP and may even split party members during the course of the trial.
Tsai reminded party members that the DPP has a historic mission for Taiwan and should therefore unite to help the party move beyond its predicament.

Stressing that all DPP members are kind-hearted and have integrity, Tsai said she expects Chen to face up to his judicial challenge and mount a vigorous defense against the corruption charges leveled against him.

In the meantime, Tsai said, the DPP will work to defend Chen's judicial rights and human rights. She demanded an immediate end to Chen's detention to pave the way for the beginning of a fair trial of his cases.
She dismissed as speculation media reports that the DPP will turn its back on Chen or regards him as a liability to the pro-independence cause both Chen and the DPP espouse.
Indicted together with Chen were his wife, Wu Shu-jen, his son Chen Chih-chung, his daughter-in-law, Huang Jui-ching, three of his former aides in the Presidential Office, and seven other associates.
Prosecutors said the former president and his wife together embezzled NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special presidential fund during Chen's presidency from 2000-2008.

They also took bribes worth NT$100 million and US$6 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another US$2.73 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, prosecutors charged.
Both Chen Shui-bian and Wu Shu-jen have denied any wrongdoing. Chen's lawyers described the indictment as a "purge of officials of the previous administration."

Wu's lawyers also issued a statement on her behalf, saying that the indictment was unacceptable as prosecution charges are aimed at demonizing the former first lady, who has been confined to a wheelchair since she was hit by a truck in 1985.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. expresses confidence in Taiwan's legal system
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/13/08 13:46:18 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States is confident that Taiwan's legal system will be "transparent, fair and impartial, " a U.S. State Department official said Friday in response to a reporter's question on U.S. opinion regarding the indictment earlier that day of former Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian.

Asked during a daily press briefing to comment on Chen's indictment on charges of money laundering, corruption and forgery, State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said that "this is a matter for Taiwan's legal system to resolve."
"We are confident in Taiwan's democracy and its legal system. And we have every expectation that the process will be transparent, fair and impartial," McCormack said.
He declined to comment on allegations by Chen and his supporters that the prosecutors' investigation into his cases were marred by political interference.

Earlier in the day, the prosecutors formally charged Chen and his wife, Wu Shu- jen, with illegally receiving or embezzling NT$490 million (US$14.79 million) , some of which was wired into overseas bank accounts.

Of that total, the indictment reads, NT$104.15 million was embezzled from the "special state affairs fund" set aside for the president's discretionary use during his eight years in office from 2000 to 2008.

The former first family allegedly received another NT$$299.85 million in kickbacks from a total payoff of NT$399 million by a development company to pave the way for the Hsinchu Science Park to buy a plot of land in Taoyuan County at a price prosecutors believe was unreasonably high.

The indictment also accuses the former first family of collecting another NT$90.9 million in bribes from contractor Kuo Chuan-ching to help him win a tender to build the Nangang Exhibition Hall between 2002 and 2003.
Chen and his wife are also still being probed for helping several financial conglomerates acquire financial holding companies in return for political contributions.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. military school delegation visits Taiwan

TEXT.P: A delegation of U.S. military school students from the state of Delaware is visiting Taiwan's Chung Cheng Armed Forces Preparatory School for educational exchanges, Chung Cheng Commandant Hsia Yu-jen said Saturday.
Hsia said seven student representatives of the Delaware Military Academy led by Commandant Charles Baldwin and an instructor arrived at his school Dec. 4 and will stay until Dec. 17.
The visit is a result of a request Baldwin made to Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense last year for the two schools to engage in education interactions, Hsia said.

In addition to learning about the school's training system, the Delaware delegation is also taking classes in mandarin Chinese and calligraphy, as well as lessons in playing the ocarina, a wind instrument that first became popular in ancient Chinese civilization.

The Delaware Military Academy, a publicly funded charter high school, cultivates personnel for the U.S. naval forces. It was founded in 2003 and currently has over 500 students in grades nine to twelve -- the equivalent of senior high school in Taiwan.
The Chung Cheng school prepares students for professions in the naval, air, and military forces and has about 700 students at present.
Hsia added he will sign an agreement with the U.S. school Tuesday to pave the way for an exchange visit to Delaware next April.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Japanese prime minister likely to visit Taiwan in 2009

TEXT.P: Former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is likely to visit Taiwan in the first half of 2009, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Saturday.
If the visit takes place, it will make Abe the fourth former Japanese prime minister to have visited Taiwan after Nobusuke Kishi, Takeo Fukuda and Yoshiro Mori.
The visit would also attest to the deepening of Taiwan-Japan relations, the MOFA official said.

According to the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, Taiwan has been inviting Abe to visit the country since he stepped down as prime minister in September 2007, and the invitation has recently been accepted.

Abe, who is now a member of parliament, originally planned to come during a parliamentary recess in late 2008, but he was forced to postpone his plan following an extension of the parliamentary session to deal with legislation in reaction to the global financial crisis, the official said.
The MOFA is now expecting his arrival in the first half of next year after the next budget session of the Japanese parliament ends in April, he said.

The plan, however, is not final, because if the House of Representatives is re- elected in the first half of next year, Abe will need to campaign for his Liberal Democratic Party, which would make him too busy to visit Taiwan, the official noted.
Abe was the 90th prime minister of Japan and held office from Sept. 26, 2006 to Sept. 12, 2007.
During his term, the Japanese government granted Taiwanese citizens visa-free entry and the two sides mutually recognized each other's driver's licenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water conservation measures implemented for Matsu reservoir

TEXT.P: The Lienchiang County Water Supply Plant on the outlying island of Matsu announced Saturday that it will implement second-phase water conservation measures from Tuesday for its Nankang area reservoir.
According to the second-phase water conservation measures, water supplies will be halted every fourth day, according to plant officials.

The Nankang area received plentiful rainfall during the first half of this year, but because water use increased significantly during the drier summer months, water levels at the reservoir began to decline, the officials said.
It was therefore decided to implement first-phase water conservation measures at the reservoir in August, under which water supplies were halted during the nighttime hours.
According to plant statistics, the Nankang area reservoir contained less than 130,000 metric tons of water as of Friday.

With water use averaging about 2,000 tons per day in the distribution area, the reservoir therefore has only about 58 days of water supply left, the officials noted, adding that residents served by the reservoir should do all they can to limit their water use.
Water levels at other reservoirs on the outlying island are currently normal, and there are no concerns about water shortages in those areas in the short term, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Schengen visas available at Swiss trade office: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan passport holders can apply for the Schengen visa at the Trade Office of Swiss Industries (TOSI) in Taipei from Dec. 15, the Swiss representative office said in a statement Friday.
The statement said Switzerland began application for inclusion into the Schengen Area in 1997 and has achieved this goal after a decade of efforts.

Travelers wishing to visit Switzerland while in Europe will no longer need to apply for a separate visa to enter the country, the statement noted, adding that further details of the application procedure and requirements are available at http://www.swiss.org.tw.
The visa processing time is usually three days for short-term visas of up to 90 days, while visas of more than 90 days require six to eight weeks for processing.

The Schengen Area comprises most of the European Union member states, although Switzerland is not a member of the EU. The area now includes Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxemburg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland.
The Schengen agreement is aimed at facilitating travel for individuals by eliminating systematic checks at common borders of signatory states.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait ties enter new era with 4 pacts taking effect: MAC

TEXT.P: Relations across the Taiwan Strait turned a new page Saturday with four agreements signed Nov. 4 by the two sides of the strait on the establishment of direct transport and postal links and closer cooperation in food safety control taking effect that day.

The four agreements signed by the heads of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) cover the expansion of existing weekend cross-strait direct chartered flights to weekdays, as well as the establishment of direct shipping links, postal exchanges and a cross-strait food safety mechanism.
The accords were signed by SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS President Chen Yunlin during Chen's historic visit to Taipei Nov. 3-7.
The two sides agreed at the time that the four agreements would automatically go into effect 40 days after their signing -- Dec. 13.

The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said in a statement issued late Friday that the Ministry of Transport and Communications has already made the necessary arrangements for the weekday charter flights, direct shipping links and postal exchanges in accordance with the existing domestic regulations.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations responsible for handling cross-strait engagements in the absence of official relations, while the MAC oversees the SEF operations.

The MAC statement also noted that the agreements took effect in full compliance with the relevant provisions set forth in the Statute Governing Relations Between the People of Taiwan and the Mainland China.

An earlier meeting between Chiang and Chen six months ago in Beijing following the May 20 inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang -- seen as having a more conciliatory approach toward China -- marked the beginning of a thaw in cross-strait relations.
Chen's visit to Taiwan made him the highest-ranking Chinese official to set foot on Taiwan in nearly 60 years since the Chinese civil war of 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yang named world's top junior in year-end rankings

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Yang Tsung-hua became the country's first young tennis player to finish the year as the world's top-ranked junior, but now faces the even bigger challenge of converting that promise into a thriving pro career that has eluded many other highly-ranked juniors.

Yang clinched the spot after struggling past Matthew Kandath of the United States 7-6 (5), 4-6, 6-2 in the first round of the Dunlop Orange Bowl in Key Biscayne, Florida, Monday, making it impossible for Yang's closest pursuer entered in the tournament, Indian Yuki Bhambri, to catch him.

The 17-year-old, known for his powerful, though at times erratic first serve, secured the top spot thanks to the International Tennis Federation's rankings system for juniors that weighs both singles and doubles performances.

Yang, who captured this year's French Open junior singles title, trailed Bulgaria's Grigor Dimitrov and Australia's Bernard Tomic in the singles rankings, but made up the gap with outstanding doubles results in partnership with Taiwan's Hsieh Cheng-peng, including trophy-winning runs in the Australian Open and Wimbledon junior doubles.
When Dimitrov and Tomic decided not to play in the Orange Bowl tournament, Yang's hold on the top-ranking was virtually assured.
The Taiwanese teenager was unable to overtake Dimitrov in the singles ranking, however, after being ousted in the Orange Bowl's round of 16 Thursday by American Alexander Domijan, 3-6, 6-4, 7-5.
Yang actually had a match point in the third set but could not stop Domijan from winning his 14th straight match on the ITF junior tennis circuit.
The match was just another reminder to Yang that one's ranking in today's fiercely competitive tennis world provides no guarantees for success.
It's a lesson Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun, who was ranked eighth in junior singles at the end of 2000, and Wang Yeu-tzuoo, who finished 2001 ranked fifth, have learned the hard way.
Both have faced considerable obstacles in sustaining a professional career at the highest level, including litanies of injuries and funding shortages.

Also, for every Roger Federer (1998) , Andy Roddick (2000) and Richard Gasquet (2002), who turned their top junior singles rankings at year's end into outstanding pro careers, there have also been Arnaud di Pasquale (1997) , Kristian Pless (1999) , Gilles Muller (2001) and Donald Young (2005) who have never fulfilled the promise of their top ranking.

Yang, who plans to turn pro next year and is already ranked 550th on the ATP Tour after playing in some lower level Futures events this year, will soon find out if he can make the successful leap to the pros that has eluded so many juniors.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT chairman's Japan visit helps dispel concerns: party spokesman

TEXT.P: A visit to Japan by ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wo Poh-hsiung has helped dispel Japanese concerns over what the country's media have described as the KMT's "China-tilted policies and anti-Japan sentiment, " KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung said Saturday.

Lee noted that Wu, who returned Saturday from a six-day visit, had meetings with Japanese politicians, media heads and Taiwanese expatriate groups in Japan in which he pointed out that President Ma Ying-jeou is well-versed in Japanese affairs and that Ma considers Taiwan-Japan ties to be of great importance.

Wu's meetings were successful in soothing Japan's misgivings about the KMT's China policies since the new administration took office in May, and allowed Japan to realize the importance of mutual goodwill between the two countries, Lee went on.
Meanwhile, Republic of China Representative to Japan John Feng also said Wu's visit has helped boost cooperative efforts with Japan.

In addition, KMT Legislator Lee Hung-chun, who visited Japan as part of Wu's delegation, said the party chairman also expressed the country's hopes of resuming bilateral negotiations on fishing rights around the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, over which Taiwan, Japan and China all claim sovereignty.

He said various Japanese parliamentarians gave Wu their word that they will try to facilitate such negotiations, and added that Wu's suggestion of pushing for direct flights between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Tokyo was also well- received by Japanese officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three more Chinese airlines to set up offices in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Three more Chinese airlines will set up offices in Taiwan to prepare for expanding cross-Taiwan Strait aviation services in the future, joining another Chinese carrier that has already done so, an official said Saturday.

The Civil Aeronautics Administration has approved applications by Shanghai Airlines, Air China and China Southern, the official said, adding that the latter company has taken office space near the Taipei Songshan Airport.

The other Chinese carrier, China Eastern, opened an office near the airport soon after the weekend direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services began in July, while various Taiwanese carriers have also opened offices in China, the official said.
These offices cannot sell tickets but they can be upgraded into full branch offices in the future to cope with an expected wider range of aviation services, the official went on.
The existing weekend direct charter flights will be expanded to a daily service Dec. 15 as the result of an agreement signed between Taiwan and China Nov. 4.
The expansion will increase the 36 direct flights currently operated between Taiwan and China Friday to Monday to 108 per week, available every day.

The number of destinations in China will also be increased from the current five to 21, and both passenger and cargo charter flights will be available, the official went on, adding that even further expansion in services is possible in the coming year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA advises farmers not to rush to plant more vegetables

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday that prices for domestically grown vegetables are currently reasonable and advised farmers not to rush to plant more.

The COA said that as Taiwan's winter climate is relatively cool and suitable for growing a variety of vegetables, supplies in local markets are expected to be sufficient over the coming months without additional planting, and it warned farmers that if they rush to plant even more, their actions could lead to a glut that would adversely affect their incomes.

In addition to taking steps to control vegetable supplies, the CLA said it will also continue to carry out random pesticide testing on vegetables sold at wholesale markets to ensure the safety of consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90% avian flu vaccine trial subjects produce antibodies: research

TEXT.P: Results of a clinical trial on avian influenza vaccine in Taiwan show that antibodies formed in over 90 percent of the trial subjects and that even if the virus mutated, 45 percent of the vaccinated subjects would still be able to resist the virus.

The results were released at an academic conference held by the Taiwan Society of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine Saturday. The trial -- part of an Asia- Pacific clinical trial on vaccine against the H5N1 strain of avian flu -- was hosted by National Taiwan University College of Medicine Dean Yang Pan-chyr. A total of 400 healthy people aged between 18 and 60 took part in the clinical trial that began at the beginning of 2007 at two local hospitals -- National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) and the Taipei Veterans General Hospital.
Each trial subject was given two shots of H5N1 vaccine containing AS03 adjuvant, with the second shot given three weeks after the first.

NTUH Vice President Chang Shan-chwen said that while it is still not possible to precisely predict how the H5N1 virus will mutate or whether it will develop into a powerful viral strain that can spread from human to human, it is important to know that the flu vaccine is effective in producing extensive and constant immunity against different strains of H5N1.
No cases of the virulent H5N1 virus have ever been reported in Taiwan, in either animals or humans.

The world's first recorded case of a human infected by H5N1 was in 2003. As of Dec. 12 this year, 390 human cases have been recorded that have claimed the lives of 246 people in 15 countries in Asia, Africa and Europe -- mainly poultry workers who caught the disease from working in close proximity to livestock -- according to statistics compiled by the World Health Organization (WHO) . The figures mark a mortality rate of over 60 percent.

The WHO has recommended all countries should take precautions against a possible worldwide avian flu outbreak, and has suggested using vaccine and anti-viral medicine as two key strategies to reduce mortality during a major outbreak.

DOC.HEADLINE: University head calls for more exchanges in communications studies

TEXT.P: National Chengchi University (NCCU) President Wu Se-hwa said Saturday that the world today is much more closely intertwined than ever before and that he hopes to use international academic exchanges to generate the future direction of research in mass communications studies.
Wu made the remarks at the opening ceremony of a two-day international conference titled "De-Westernizing Communication Research: What is the Next Step?" organized by NCCU and CNA.

The conference invited international scholars in the area of mass communications such as Professor David Morley of Goldsmiths University of London, Graham Murdoch, reader in the Sociology of Culture at the Department of Social Sciences at Loughborough University, Professor Molefi Kete Asante of Temple University in Philadelphia, Professor Kim Min-sun of the University of Hawaii, Shelton Gunaratne, professor of mass communications emeritus from the Minnesota State University, and Su Herng, professor and department chair of the Department of Journalism of National Chengchi University.

"This is the first time NCCU has invited international scholars in the area of mass communication from various different cultural backgrounds to attend an international conference, " said Wu, adding that "we hope to use international academic exchanges to understand the issue of Eurocentrism in mass communications studies so as to generate the role of Asiacentricity in the future of mass communications studies."

Eurocentrism is the practice of viewing the world from a European perspective, with an implied belief, either consciously or subconsciously, in the pre- eminence of European, and more generally, of Western culture. The term Eurocentrism implies criticism of the concerns and values at the expense of non- Europeans.

CNA Board Chairman Huang Chao-sung pointed out that global media organizations are facing a crisis of management and said possible solutions to the crisis is to discover and nurture more professional media talent.

"The study of mass communications not only affects media management, " said Huang. "It affects society, culture, politics and psychological aspects as a whole. Therefore, we hope to initiate multi-element exchanges and research on mass communications study."
Other speakers at the conference touched on the issue of the dominance of Western culture in mass communication studies, while a local speaker, Professor Su of NCCU, spoke about the Taiwanese media.

Su noted that a central criticism of many Taiwanese communication studies is that they subscribe indiscriminately and significantly to theoretical models mostly imported from the United States and Europe. "Researchers of communication problems in Taiwan have not behaved independently and have so far failed to build concepts rooted in the particular experience of life from their own perspective," Su said.
Established in 1927, NCCU is noted for its humanities and social sciences disciplines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ready for direct cross-strait shipping, cargo charters

TEXT.P: A new raft of shipping and air services pacts established between Taiwan and China officially went into effect Saturday, setting the stage for the historic Dec. 15 launch of direct shipping, air cargo charter and daily passenger charter services across the Taiwan Strait.

Among the ships scheduled to take part in the inaugural direct sailing Monday will be two vessels belonging to Evergreen Marine Corp. and Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., respectively, both named "Taiwan." One will embark from Taiwan's Kaohsiung Port bound for China's port of Tianjin, while the other will set said from Keelung, bound for Shanghai.
The day will also see two Chinese vessels, each named "China, " put out from Chinese ports to make the direct crossing across the Taiwan Strait to ports in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, the first direct cross-strait cargo charter flight will be provided by China Southern Airlines and is scheduled to take off at 3 p.m. from Guangzhou for the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, according to Civil Aeronautics Administration officials.

The earliest daily passenger flights available that day will be provided by Taiwan's TransAsia Airways and China's China Eastern Airlines and will take off 8 a.m. from Taipei for Shanghai and from Shanghai for Taoyuan, respectively.

The shipping and air agreements were signed Nov. 4 in Taipei by Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin -- who as the heads of the semi-official intermediary bodies serve as the top negotiators representing either side -- upon the conclusion of their second round of talks in five months since cross-strait dialogue was resumed in June.

The shipping services agreement allows Taiwanese-owned and Chinese-owned vessels to sail directly across the Taiwan Strait, without having to make a detour through Ishigaki Island in Japan's Okinawa Prefecture.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) has estimated that the direct shipping will shorten the sailing time between Keelung and Shanghai to 17 hours, which is as much as nine hours faster than it is now.
The voyage between Keelung and China's Fuzhou, meanwhile, will take only six hours, representing a saving of up to 12 hours in sailing time.
The services will also help reduce shipping costs by 15 percent-30 percent, according to the MOTC.

At the same time, the air services pact addresses the inauguration of direct cargo charter services, with a total of 60 flights allowed to be operated per month between Taoyuan and Kaohsiung on the Taiwan side and Shanghai and Guangzhou in China.

According to the CAA, the carriers that will operate the cargo charter services are Taiwan's China Airlines and EVA Airways and China's China Cargo Airlines and China Southern Airlines, which will between them provide 24 flights during the first week.

The air services agreement also concerns an expansion of the weekend charter passenger services -- which have been operating between Friday and Monday since July -- to every day of the week, with the number of flights provided rising from 36 to 108 per week.

The number of destinations in China will be expanded to 21, to include Chengdu, Chongqing, Hangzhou, Dalian, Guilin, Shenzhen, Wuhan, Fuzhou, Qingdao, Changsha, Haikou, Kunming, Xi'an, Shenyang, Tianjin and Zhengzhou. At present, the services are available only in five Chinese cities -- Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Xiamen and Nanjing.
Taiwanese and Chinese carriers will be allowed to fly to destinations in northern China more directly and will no longer be required to make a detour through Hong Kong air space.
During the first week of the daily passenger services, the five Taiwanese carriers and seven Chinese carriers operating the services will together provide a total 101 flights, CAA officials said.

The routes to be flown during this period will cover only 13 Chinese destinations -- Beijing, Shanghai, Nanjing, Guangzhou, Xiamen, Hangzhou, Shenzhen, Tianjin, Chongqing, Chengdu, Fuzhou, Haikou and Dalian, the officials went on, adding that the four Taiwanese destinations covered will be Taoyuan, Taipei, Kaohsiung and Taichung, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic groups protest against proposed tax reforms

TEXT.P: The Fair Tax Reform Alliance, with support from 17 other civic groups, staged a protest against the government's proposed tax reforms in Taipei Saturday, drawing about 4,000 demonstrators.
According to spokesman Chien Hsi-chieh, the alliance is against the proposed reforms as it believes they will only benefit big business and the wealthy.
Wang Jung-chang, the alliance's founder, said the reforms, if implemented, will favor the rich but generate debts for future generations.

The protest lasted about two hours, with protesters moving from the Liberty Square at the Chiang Kai-Shek Memorial Hall complex and marching past the Legislative Yuan building before ending their protest at Kategelan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.
The 17 civic groups that took part included the National Federation of Bank Employees Unions, the Union of Bank SinoPac and the National Teachers' Association, Chien said.
He added that the protest was just a start and that the alliance will invite the public to refuse to pay their taxes next April and May if the government does not improve its tax policies.
One specific appeal of the alliance is to oppose a government's plan to cut inheritance and gift tax from 50 percent to 10 percent.
According to the alliance, the cut will only profit the rich while shaving NT$20 billion (US$600 million) from the government coffers.
It also took issue with the Ministry of Finance insistence that the proposed tax cut would help attract investment to Taiwan and expressed doubt as to the effectiveness of such a move.

Chien also criticized the Tax Reform Committee, which was established in late June to give objective and professional advice on the government's tax policy making and reform proposals, as being a tool of President Ma Ying-jeou.
Chien was a consultant for the committee but dropped out last month after deciding that the committee only serves the interests of big companies and the rich.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipower may lose NT$100 billion this year: economics minister

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Yiin Chii-ming said Saturday that the state-owned Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) could lose NT$100 billion (US$3.01 billion) this year and might continue to lose money next year due to rising prices of fuel coal and natural gas.

Yiin made the remarks while accompanying President Ma Ying-jeou on a visit to the Dawulun Industrial Park in northern Taiwan's Keelung City where they met with operators of small- and medium-sized enterprises, during which the operators expressed their wish that electricity rates could be cut to help stimulate the economy.

Yiin pointed out, however, that Taiwan generates electricity mainly from natural gas and coal, adding that although the world oil price has slumped, the prices of coal and natural gas have continued to surge.

He noted that the ministry had wanted to make a sharp upward adjustment to electricity rates in July to reflect the rising costs, but ended up increasing prices by only 25 percent of the required level and announcing a second 25-percent rise in October.
He said that as Taipower has continued to absorb the rising costs of coal and natural gas, it could lose NT$100 billion this year.
"If the situation does not improve, then the losses next year could be between NT$100 billion and NT$150 billion, " he told the businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Christmas coming, but poinsettia sales decline due to economic slump

TEXT.P: With just two weeks until Christmas, many growers of poinsettias -- the festive red and green pot plant that is an indispensable and ubiquitous Christmas decoration -- said Saturday that they are feeling the impact of the global economic slump and are having to try hard this year to maintain the turnover they enjoyed last year.
Poinsettia, or Christmas flower, whose formal name is Euphorbia pulcherrima, is often used as an ornamental plant during the Christmas season due to the brilliance of its vermilion leaves.
A subtropical plant that originated in Mexico, poinsettia is cultivated mostly in the north of Taiwan and looks its best from October to February.
Even though poinsettias are indispensable for the Christmas period, flower farmers said they still under heavy economic pressure, adding that both production and demand are declining.

Chuang Ying-cheng, owner of the Sanmin Garden located in the countryside of Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan, told CNA that poinsettias are also in short supply due to adverse weather conditions earlier this year.
He noted that frequent typhoons and high temperatures this summer caused a delay in the plants' development of florescence in their leaves, making some of them not red enough for sale.

In addition, he said, plant diseases earlier in the year have also reduced harvests and reduced quality. He estimated that disease has led to a reduction of about 100,000 pots of poinsettias around the country, bringing the total harvest this year down to about 1.1 million pots.
These factors, he went on, have meant that quantities can barely meet market demand, even though the market demand seems to have declined slightly compared to the past few years.
Instead of raising prices to take advantage of the short supply, however, Chuang said he has reduced the price of his poinsettias by NT$5 to NT$10 per pot due to the economic slump.
A poinsettia pot costs from NT$30 (US$0.9) to several hundred dollars in Taiwan, depending on size and variety.
"In general this year, we have recorded an approximate 10 percent reduction in turnover compared to last year," Chuang said.

Meanwhile, a seller at Chunghsing Garden, also located in Taoyuan County, said the number of their orders recorded a decline of almost 30 percent this year. Although retail sales quantities do not appear to have changed, wholesale traders' orders have fallen, she said.
To adapt to the economic slump, some farmers have been trying to maintain their business with other activities to boost their incomes.

The Hualu Flower Farm in Miaoli County, established in 1988, is a recreational farm open to tourists throughout the year. Owner Chen Ji-neng said his business has remained as stable as last year and that visitors are still willing to buy his flowers, although he also offers other items such as carnivorous plants, as well as activities such as camping and fruit-picking.
He has created new varieties of dwarf poinsettias, as well as a three-color poinsettia that bears red, pink and white leaves on the same stem.
But according to Chen, it is the traditional red poinsettias with their big vibrant leaves that give a joyful Christmassy atmosphere that are still the favorite variety among local buyers.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIA welcomes visits by Japanese students

TEXT.P: The Japan Interchange Association (JIA) said Saturday that it welcomes a group of 20 Japanese senior high school students set to arrive in Taiwan for a weeklong visit the following day.
The JIA is Japan's de facto embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties.

JIA officials said the group, invited by the East Asia Relations Commission -- JIA's Taiwanese counterpart -- will visit schools and scenic spots, meet with Taiwanese students and get a taste of how they live during its stay.

The officials noted that the visit will be a reciprocal one following the association's invitation of 60 Taiwanese students to visit Japan last February, and they expressed hope that such visits will help promote exchanges between the young people of the two countries.
They also said the association will invite around 130 Taiwanese students and young reporters to visit Japan next February with the aim of enhancing the understanding of Japan among Taiwan's youth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reform aimed at boosting tax fairness: MOF

TEXT.P: The government's tax reform plan is mainly aimed at boosting tax fairness, formulating sound fiscal policies and improving public financial management, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said in a statement Saturday.

The ministry issued the statement after tax reform activists staged a march through downtown Taipei earlier in the day to protest an MOF-proposed tax reform package which they said would only benefit big business groups and the super rich while generating debts for future generations.

Defending its reform package, which is now under legislative screening, the ministry said local people's tax burden, at a rate of 14 percent of the government's overall income, is lower than a majority of advanced countries around the world.

However, many people often complain about the heavy tax burden and unfairness in taxation. Against this backdrop, the ministry said it has formed a Tax Reform Committee in June to conduct an overall review of the existing tax system and come up with reform proposals.
Insisting that the reform package has taken into account tax fairness and efficiency, the ministry said the newly proposed business income tax rate will be applied to all industries.
The tax rate adjustment will be implemented in connection with the expiration of tax breaks for selected high-tech industries at the end of next year.

By so doing, the ministry said, all industrial sectors, including various traditional industries, will benefit from lowered business income taxes and will better afford to invest in restructuring and technological upgrading to enhance their competitiveness.
In the meantime, the ministry went on, the reform package also proposes increases of four categories of income tax deductions to benefit all taxpayers.

On the estate tax reform, the ministry said the reform package includes measures to levy special sales tax on luxury goods and to overhaul existing land and housing taxes with an aim to expand tax base and maintain tax fairness.
As to the proposal to largely cut the inheritance and gift taxes, a bone of contention, the ministry said reduction in inheritance and gift taxes is a global trend.

After Hong Kong and Singapore cancel such taxes, South Korea has also announced a reform plan recently that would lead to a substantial cut into its inheritance and gift taxes, the ministry said, adding that its plan to lower the inheritance tax from the current 50 percent to 10 percent is in compliance with the general world trend.

DOC.HEADLINE: Human trafficking ring busted in Penghu

TEXT.P: Police announced Saturday the busting in offshore Penghu County of a cross- Taiwan Strait human trafficking ring, saying that nine people have been arrested for suspected involvement in the operations.

Among the detained were four Chinese women who police said were smuggled to Penghu off the southwestern Taiwan coast from Quanzhou in the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian Friday via a fishing boat.
Also arrested were a Chinese man, who was allegedly the mastermind of the human trafficking operations, and four of his Taiwanese accomplices.

Police said the number of cross-strait human trafficking cases has increased recently because the interview system for marriages between local and Chinese citizens has become ever more stringent, which has helped deter cases of Chinese women entering Taiwan for sex trade through marriage of convenience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial squeeze exacerbates Taiwan's stray dog problem

TEXT.P: Factories have shut down, workers are being laid off and many people with jobs are not expecting to get a bonus or raise, but people are not the only ones affected by the ongoing financial tumult sweeping across Taiwan; the economic downturn has also dealt a blow to the island's pets.

A growing number of dogs are being abandoned in national parks, small lanes, highways and even downtown Taipei in recent months -- worsening a problem that was already a headache in this densely populated capital, according to animal shelters and government agencies.

"It has become more common to find stray dogs on the streets in recent days," said Huang Ching-jung, secretary-general of the Animal Protection Association of the Republic of China, who also runs a veterinary hospital in Taipei.
Big dog breeds, such as Huskies, Golden Retrievers and Labradors, are the main victims in this recent wave of dog abandonment, shelter and government officials said.

Tallies compiled by Taipei City's Environmental Protection Department, which is responsible for handling stray dogs, show that the highest number of abandoned canines were captured in the Shihlin and Beitou districts, adjacent to Yangmingshan National Park, a recreation area in northern Taiwan.
The park has become a popular dumping ground because dog owners believe its vast wooded environment is suitable for dogs to find food, take shelter and survive on their own.
Huang estimated that there are more than 300 or 400 stray dogs roaming within the park at any given time.
They survive on food and snacks left by visitors as well as small wild animals, such as snakes and mice, Huang said.
Those abandoned in the cities scavenge for kitchen scraps at dumpsters outside the city's many restaurants.
As the financial crisis lingers, fewer people are adopting dogs, further exacerbating the stray dog problem.

A dog adoption program run by the ROC Animal Protection Association since 2003 has seen the number of dogs adopted from its shelter in Bali, Taipei County fall from 45 in 2006, to 35 in 2007 and only 20 so far this year.

Stressing that the ultimate goal of the association is to provide a good environment and care for strays, Huang appealed to pet owners to treat their animals like their family members and urged the public to adopt dogs and cats.

"Rather than strays, they should be our good friends, " he said, because "we want them to return to human society and become a popular companion for human beings, " Huang said. "This is our greatest hopes for them."
According to an association worker surnamed Wu who does not want her name to be mentioned, most of the dogs sent to a shelter run by the association in Bali were of cross breeds in the past.
But since last year, almost all the breeds of dogs, including pricey dogs, began showing up, she noted.
This is an indication that even relatively well-to-do dog owners were finding it too expensive to own dogs.
According to pet shops, it costs at least NT$10,000 or more per month to raise a dog of big breeds.
Wu, a veteran animal rights advocate, believed that the selfish mindset of some pet owners is a major root cause of the acute stray animal problem in Taipei.
Many people fancying to have a dog like those depicted in movies might blindly buy a pet dog, but throw them away rashly when they realize they do not enjoy taking care of their pets, she said.
The government recommends that pet owners implant a microchip in their pets and have them spayed or neutered, but owners are not required to do so and many dog owners do not follow the practice.
"Only doing so will effectively reduce the number of stray or wild dogs and cats," Wu said.
The problem of dogs born to stray parents has also been a big headache for the city's environmental protection authorities as it causes the population of strays to multiply.

Stray dogs sometimes chase and bite people, while others can cause traffic accidents by not knowing how to cross the street. A continuously rising number of abandoned dogs has also damaged Taipei city's image, with dog poo frequently seen on the streets.
The dogs abandoned in parks have also harmed the parks' ecological system and threatened visitors' safety.
Once caught, abandoned dogs will be sent to animal shelters and some of them will be eventually put to sleep if there is no way to trace their owners.
Owners found to have intentionally abandoned their dogs could be fined up to NT$75,000 (US$2,240), officials said.
The problem is not limited to Taipei alone, as other areas are also reporting dogs being deserted.

A pet shop owner in Tsaotun township in Nantou County, central Taiwan said six pet dogs have been dumped at his shop in just the last month. He said he is afraid that a large wave of such abandoning will emerge during the upcoming Chinese New Year in late January because money will be tight for many families then.

Besides pet shops, veterinary hospitals are also a common target for dog owners who want to discard their dogs. According to pet shops and veterinary hospitals, the number of pet owners who dump their pets at the shops has also been on a sharp rise.
Veterinary hospitals in central Taiwan have begun demanding animal owners pay a NT$5,000 deposit in advance if they send their pets there for treatment.
As the problem of strays grows, animal rights advocates urge the government to allot more funding for shelters.
Shelters -- the only refuge for stray dogs -- operate on thin budgets, often surviving only by individuals' donations and fundraising activities.

Due to limited resources, some public shelters are entitled to put animals to sleep within seven days if a dog or a cat has not been adopted upon their arrivals, officials said. Others such as Huang's take care of the animals until they die naturally, but space at those facilities are limited.
Last year, 8,000 of the over 9,000 stray dogs housed at the Hsinwu animal shelter in Taoyuan County were put to sleep, volunteer works said.
Animal rights advocates said more also needs to be done by the government and society to educate people about being responsible pet owners and to punish people for abandoning their dogs.

They said the process can start in pet shops, urging pet shop owners to not simply be tempted by money, and to assess buyers and warn them about the responsibilities of raising a dog, especially when the dogs grow to mature size.
"But setting up more shelters to house the stray dogs or cats is by no means the perfect solution to this problem," Wu stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 14, or the 17th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti- corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso- kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
2001: A rehearsal for the formal commission of Taiwan's first F-16 fighter wing is held at Chiayi air force base in southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
KMT official heads to China to witness launch of shipping links

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan departed for China's northern port city of Tianjin Sunday to witness the launch of direct shipping links across the Taiwan Strait from the Chinese side.

Lien and a 10-member KMT delegation were scheduled to travel via Hong Kong to Tianjin Sunday, where the group will attend a ceremony the following day to mark the opening on the Chinese side of direct cross-strait shipping links.

Commercial vessels from both sides of the strait will begin historic direct cross-strait voyages Monday, with Taiwan's ports of Kaohsiung, Keelung and Taichung and 11 Chinese seaports, including Tianjin, Dalian, Qingdao and Shanghai, being the key players in the initial stages.

Among the ships scheduled to take part in the inaugural direct sailings Monday will be two vessels belonging to Evergreen Marine Corp. and Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., respectively. One will embark from Kaohsiung bound for Tianjin, while the other will set sail from Keelung bound for Shanghai.
The day will also see two Chinese vessels put out from Tianjin and Shanghai, respectively, to make the direct crossing to ports in Taiwan.

The launch of the direct cross-strait shipping links is one of four agreements sealed by the two sides Nov. 4 on expanding transport exchanges, postal services and establishing a food safety mechanism.

After attending the ceremony in Tianjin, Lien and his delegation, including KMT Vice Chairman Lin Feng-cheng, will proceed to Shanghai to attend the fourth forum between the KMT and its Chinese counterpart, the Communist Party of China (CPC), that will take place Dec. 20-21 in Shanghai.

KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung is also expected to attend the forum, marking the first time a Taiwanese ruling party chairman will attend the cross-Taiwan Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum, also known as the KMT-CPC Forum.

According to KMT Deputy Secretary-General Chang Jung-kung, the forum is aimed at promoting cross-strait economic, trade and cultural exchanges and cooperation, as well as the stable development of cross-strait relations.

Participants will discuss major issues, including cross-strait cooperation in the finance and services sectors, mutual investment, and ways to systemize mutual investment and economic exchanges, according to Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist arrivals expected to double with daily charters

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan is likely to double to 600 per day following Monday's opening of direct daily charter flight services between the two sides, according to the results of research by the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC).
As more direct routes will be adopted for the daily cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights from Dec. 15, passengers will be able to save on both cost and travel time from that day, the MOTC said.

The daily charter services will connect Taiwan to 21 Chinese destinations scattered across China, including Chengdu, Chongqing, Hangzhou, Dalian, Shenzhen, Tianjin, Kunming, Qingdao, Haikou and Shenyang.
According to tour operators, the reduced travel time will be the greatest advantage in the new measures.

From Monday, a trip on the new Taipei-Shanghai route will take only 90 minutes -- one hour less than the present route that has to go through the Hong Kong flight information zone, tour operators said. This will also help reduce the time of a flight between Taipei and Beijing to two hours and 50 minutes from the present three hours and 35 minutes.

At the same time, the number of the two-way charter flights per week will rise from 36 to 108, bureau officials said. Currently, some 90 percent of the passengers are Taiwanese businessmen, so seats will need to be added to meet tourism demand between the two sides, they noted.
The increased flights and destinations will also help attract a larger number of Chinese tourists, they contended.
The MOTC's Tourism Bureau forecast that an average of 600 Chinese tourists will come to Taiwan for sightseeing per day aboard the direct flights, double the current daily number of 300.

Since the direct cross-strait charter flights on weekends have been implemented from mid-July, a total of 32,973 tourists from China had visited Taiwan as of early November, an average of some 300 per day, according to bureau statistics.
Some 55 percent of the total, or 18,184 people, flew into Taiwan aboard weekend charter flights from five Chinese cities -- Beijing, Shanghai, Nanjing, Guangzhou and Xiamen -- the tallies indicate.
Taiwan and China inked two landmark accords in June in Beijing to allow Chinese tourists from 13 provinces and cities to visit Taiwan and to establish the direct weekend charter flights.

The two sides expanded the scope of the two pacts during talks in Taipei in November, allowing Chinese residents from more cities and provinces to make pleasure trips to Taiwan and expanding the weekend charter flights to a daily service.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mountain climbers seek to restore flagship hiking route

TEXT.P: Four mountain climbing groups, including one composed of soldiers from an army airborne division, gathered in central Taiwan Sunday to mark the restoration of a flagship hiking trail between Hsitou and Alishan that has been blocked since the devastating 921 Earthquake.

About 100 people in four groups gathered at the Shanlinhsi Recreational Park in Nantou County to mark their efforts to renovate the hiking trail between Hsitou and Alishan -- known as the Hsi-Ah Trail -- which was damaged by the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake that rattled Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999.

Since the earthquake, which left more than 2,300 people dead, 8,800 injured and some 10,000 others homeless, the renowned Hsi-Ah Trail was closed to hikers as many sections of the trail were destroyed by the temblor.

The 17-member special military squad departed from Alishan early Friday and hiked along the route that roughly followed the old Hsi-Ah Trail, reaching Shanlinhsi early Sunday. They trekked a total of 31 km, mostly along the ridgelines of the mountains between Alishan and Hsitou.

The captain of the squad, surnamed Chen, said the trek was a "synergy" operation, as the soldiers completed long-haul march training and fact-finding for the building of military communications relay stops, as well as enjoying a trail famous among mountain climbers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Singapore minister mentor applauds cross-strait development: SEF

TEXT.P: The Singapore government has praised the cross-Taiwan Strait policies of President Ma Ying-jeou, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said in a press release Saturday following a visit to Singapore by SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.

Chiang, who made a three-day visit to Singapore that ended Dec. 12, met Singapore Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong and Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew and exchanged views on cross-strait relations, cross-strait development, the ruling Kuomintang's cross-strait policies, the results of a November meeting between Chiang and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, and Asia's regional security issues.

According to the SEF statement, the Singapore government and various scholars said the continued building of mutual trust across the Taiwan Strait and the promoting of cross-strait economic and cultural exchanges will help Taiwan gain international space.

Cross-strait ties began warming up with an earlier meeting between Chiang and Chen six months ago in Beijing following Ma's May 20 inauguration -- seen as having a more conciliatory approach toward China.

A second round of SEF-ARATS talks was held in Taipei Nov. 3-7, in which Chiang and Chen signed four agreements to allow expanded direct flights, as well as shipping links and postal services, in addition to the establishment of a food safety mechanism between the two sides.
Chen was the highest-ranking Chinese official to have set foot on Taiwan since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949.
Lee, a former prime minister, is seen as one of the most influential political figures in Southeast Asia, while Goh, also a former prime minister, is chairman of the central bank of Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan mountain railway to celebrate 97th anniversary

TEXT.P: One of Taiwan's most famous national treasures, the Alishan Forest Railway, will celebrate its 97th anniversary Dec. 25 when the railway's operator, Hungtu Alishan Development Co., reopens the line between Fenchihu and Alishan stations after spending months repairing the damage caused by landslides during the typhoon season.

According to Hungtu Alishan executives, the repair work on the damaged sections of the narrow-gauge railway was completed Nov. 25, and test runs over the past two weeks have confirmed that the railway is safe to resume passenger services.
A ceremony will be held at the Fenchihu train depot Dec. 25 to reopen the line and to celebrate the 97th anniversary of the railway.

The railway is said to be one of just three alpine railways remaining in existence anywhere in the world. The other two are located in northern India, connecting Himalayan mountains, and in the Andean mountain range of South America.

Unlike the national rail system administered by the Taiwan Railway Administration, the Alishan Forest Railway was originally managed by the Forestry Bureau under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture

Opened in 1912 while Taiwan was under Japanese rule, the main line of the railway was built to haul timber down the mountain but is now mainly used to transport the more-than 200,000 tourists who visit Alishan's 2,274 meter peak every year.
The scenic railway is 86 km in length. The main line, which is 72 km, runs from the city of Chiayi in southern Taiwan at an elevation of 30 meters to the final station of Alishan at 2,216 meters.
The train stops at 17 stations and the whole journey takes about three hours and 20 minutes.

The vegetation along the way changes from subtropical to temperate before giving way finally to alpine. The line features many switchbacks as it winds its way up the mountain, crossing 72 bridges and passing through about 47 tunnels.
In 2007, the railway underwent four months of repair work to remove massive amounts of fallen rocks from successive landslides during the typhoon season.

At the time, the government had been operating the train at an annual loss of about NT$110 million (US$3.35 million) because it wanted to preserve the line not only for its historic value but as a means to boost local tourism.
In June this year, Hungtu Alishan, a subsidiary of Hungtu Construction Co., won a NT$1.7 billion (US$56 million) build-operate-transfer (BOT) project to operate the railway for the next 30 years.

Hungtu Alishan also won a contract to build a five-star hotel on 2.2 hectares of state-owned land near Jhaoping Station, the last stop on the main line. The development company also obtained the right to develop 0.9 hectares of land surrounding Peimen Station in Chiayi City, for the construction of another hotel.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei officials to depart for China on panda mission

TEXT.P: A Taipei city government delegation of officials and animal keepers will depart Monday for Chengdu in the southwestern Chinese province of Sichuan to arrange for the delivery of two giant pandas offered by China as a gift to the Taiwanese people.

The delegation, to be headed by Yang Hsiao-tung, director of the city's Department of Information and Tourism, will visit the giant panda habitat in the Wolong Nature Reserve to discuss the transportation of the two endangered animals.

"The arrival day and how the pandas will be transported will not be finalized until we reach a consensus with our Chinese counterparts on what's best for the pandas, " Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin told reporters Dec. 11
Two Taipei Zoo technicians left for the Wolong wildlife sanctuary Dec. 12 to familiarize themselves with the rare animals.

China offered Taiwan the two pandas in 2005 when then-opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan made an ice-breaking visit to Beijing. The Chinese authorities also chose the names Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan for the pandas -- which together mean "reunion" or "unification" in Chinese -- through an online vote.

The offer, however, was turned down by the then-ruling Democratic Progressive Party administration, suspicious that China would claim the shipment of the pandas as a "domestic transfer" between zoos, which would mean Taiwan would have admitted it was part of China had it accepted them.

As giant pandas are a Grade-One endangered wildlife species subject to the protection of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) , cross-border transfer of the animal must follow strict CITES provisions.
