According to an agreement signed Nov. 6 by Chen and his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, Taiwan will give Beijing a pair of Formosan sika deer and a pair of Formosan serow in return for the pandas.

Introducing the pandas at the pact-signing ceremony, Chen did not mention the names Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, which local analysts said might mark an effort by Beijing to avoid offending local pro-independence activists.
Asked whether the two pandas will be given new names after their arrival, Hau said last week that the city government has no plans to do so.

"At four years of age, the two animals have already reached full maturity. We should respect their rights and refrain from changing the names by which they have been called since shortly after their birth," Hau argued.

Beijing has already issued an export permit for the transfer of the two pandas, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun said over the weekend, adding that the animals are listed on the documents as being shipped from "Chengdu, Sichuan" to "Taipei, Taiwan."

According to Liu, filling in the export documents in this way is a common practice when Taiwan imports protected wild herbal species from China. "The precedent is being followed in the panda case, " he added.

Although CITES requires identification of the "country of import" and "the country of origin" on any export permit covering trade or cross-border movement of Grade-One endangered species, both Taiwan and China refrain from demanding having their national titles printed on the documents to avoid sovereignty disputes.

While Taiwan did not demand strict adherence to the CITES provisions to highlight cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a "state-to-state" relationship, an anonymous analyst said, China also did not use the term "Taipei, China" to belittle Taiwan or underscore its sovereignty claim.
"By so doing, the two sides have set yet another good example of shelving disputes in favor of peaceful development of bilateral ties," the analyst added.

The Taipei Zoo has created a Web site for Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan at http: //www.zoo.gov.tw/panda/english/index.htm. Photographs of the two animals can be seen on the site, which also includes an introduction on the concepts and methods of animal protection.

Zoo Director Jason Yeh said recently that the zoo has made enhancements to the interior of the panda hall and that the keepers have conducted a dry run to make sure there will be no hitches while they are caring for the two pandas.

He further said that ensuring the welfare of the animals will be the top priority when the animals are transported from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to the zoo after they arrive in Taiwan later this month.

He added that the zoo will seek police assistance to try to shorten the transport time from the airport to the zoo to approximately 40 minutes. Police might be deployed to ensure smooth traffic flow to avoid having the pandas stuck in traffic and to make the journey as least traumatic for them as possible, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to attend opening of direct shipping links in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will preside over a ceremony at Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan Monday to mark the historic inauguration of direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links.

A vessel belonging to Evergreen Marine Corp. -- Taiwan's largest shipping company and one of the world's biggest -- will sail from the Taiwan's largest port to the port of Tianjin in northern China's Hebei Province -- the first-ever between the two sides in 60 years.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan will also attend a similar ceremony at Keelung Port in northern Taiwan, from where four Taiwanese commercial ships will depart for Xiamen in Fujian Province, Shanghai and Taichang in Jiangsu Province and for Dalian in Liaoning Province, respectively.
Meanwhile, a vessel will put out from Taichung Port -- the third port selected by the authorities to handle such crossings -- bound for Huangpu in Guangdong Province.
At the same time, China is opening 63 ports for cross-strait links from Dec. 15, based on one of four agreements inked last month in Taipei by the two sides.
Establishing direct cross-strait air and shipping links has been one of Ma's major policies since he assumed office in May.

Executives of Yangming Marine Transport Corp., another of the local shipping companies involved in the new venture, said the measure will help shippers save as much as US$60 million per year on costs, as well as greatly reducing journey times.

Keelung Harbor Bureau Director-General Hsiao Ding-hsun said Saturday that the northern Taiwanese port and shipping companies will benefit from the long- awaited opening of direct cross-strait shipping links.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors may appeal against former president's release

TEXT.P: The Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office will hold a meeting Monday to decide whether to appeal former President Chen Shui- bian's release following his indictment on charges of corruption and money laundering, State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming said Sunday.

According to Chen Tsung-ming, the prosecutors felt that in principle they should file an appeal against the Taipei District Court's decision a day earlier to release the former president without bail.

He said that with Chen Shui-bian out of detention, some of the witnesses to be questioned in the second stage of the investigation into his alleged taking of bribes from the financial sector might be reluctant to testify.
The prosecutors will make an announcement after reaching a decision at Monday's meeting, he added.
The former president had been detained for 32 days since Nov. 12 as prosecutors prepared their case against him.

After four months of intensive investigations, prosecutors indicted him Dec. 12 on charges of embezzlement, bribe-taking and money laundering. He was released the following day on his own recognizance after the court rejected a request by the prosecutors to keep him in custody.

According to the indictment, the former president and his wife together embezzled NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from the president's special discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000-2008.

They also took bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, prosecutors charged.
The prosecutors recommended that the former president be given the harshest possible sentence for his alleged illegalities involving nearly half a billion new Taiwan dollars.

They also demanded severe penalties for his wife, son and daughter-in-law for their "unrepentant attitude" in the course of investigations, while recommending commuted sentences for 10 other defendants because they had been cooperative and helpful in the process of the investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Family with eight voluntary workers honored

TEXT.P: Eight people in a three-generation family who have worked as volunteers in the northern county of Taoyuan were cited by Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi Sunday for their unselfish services to others.

The eight people, including 73-year-old Hsiao Ah-chi, his 71-year-old wife You Chu, their daughter, their son-in-law, and four of their grandchildren, were cited by Liao at a ceremony held in the central city of Taichung.
Addressing the ceremony, Liao described the volunteer workers around the country as unsung heroes in their efforts to help the government serve the people and make Taiwan a better place to live.
He noted that it was tremendously hard for the volunteers to be elected a "model volunteer family, " as very few families in Taiwan meet the criteria to be cited at the annual event.

Under the criteria, he went on, each member of the family should have been a volunteer worker for over three years, at least two of the family members must currently be volunteers, each of the volunteers should have worked over 1,000 voluntary hours and the total number of voluntary work time of the family must exceed 3,000 hours.

Both Hsiao and You have been working as volunteers at agencies under the Taoyuan county government. Hsiao has been a volunteer worker for six years and six months, with his voluntary work time totaling 3,114 hours, according to sponsors of the citation event.
You has been working even harder than her husband, with her voluntary work time totaling an astonishing 10,852 hours, mostly at the Taoyuan County Library, where she works as a cultural volunteer.
Four of the Taoyuan couple's grandchildren -- the youngest of whom is just eight years old -- have also been volunteer workers.
"Volunteer work offers us an opportunity to pursue the pleasure of getting along with people," said You.

DOC.HEADLINE: Creative ideas for consumption vouchers pouring in: interior minister

TEXT.P: A call by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) for the public to contribute ideas on the best way to maximize the effects in stimulating the ailing econonmy of the government's consumption vouchers has resulted in many ideas being submitted, Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said Sunday.
Liao made the remarks while attending a ceremony to award volunteer workers in Taichung City.

The Executive Yuan has now finalized the issue of the consumption coupons to be a combination of six coupons with a face value of NT$500 (US$15) and three coupons with a face-value of NT$200, for a total of nine coupons with a combined value of NT$3,600.

In addition to various value combinations, the ideas put forward by members of the public included stamp- sized coupons and coupons that look like vouchers issued by department stores, while others suggested having the vouchers on a single sheet that would be stamped each time it was used.
Liao did not disclose if anyone had actually won any of the various prizes offered by the MOI for winning ideas, but he thanked the submitters for their creativity.

Meanwhile that day, the Government Information Office (GIO) announced that the GIO will start a creativity contest Dec. 15 on how to maximize the economy- stimulating effect of the coupons, with a grand prize of NT$100,000 for the winner, whose name will be announced at the end of January. It also said there will be runner-up prizes of NT$30,000 and NT$10,000.

All the ideas, whether or not they are winners, will be placed into a database that will be made available for business operators and shop owners, while the GIO will also set up a Web site for business operators to advertise their discounts, sales and promotional events.
Premier Liu Chao-shuan will brief the legislature Dec. 16 in an effort to convince the lawmakers to approve the NT$85.7 special budget for the vouchers proposed Dec. 8 by the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: University students to read newspapers for school children

TEXT.P: Students from a local university's journalism department will begin a program in which they will read newspapers to children at a local elementary school to foster their love for reading and their interest in news stories.

According to a press release it issued Sunday, students from the College of Journalism and Communication of Chinese Culture University in Yangmingshan, suburban Taipei, will read newspapers to students from grades three to six at Yangmingshan Elementary School from Dec. 11-30.
College Dean Shen Huei-sheng said the purpose of the program is to help the children understand the significance of every story and how news stories are produced.

The stories will cover issues in the field of environmental protection, law enforcement and life education, and the organizers hope they will instill the listeners with love for reading, literature and life.

Chen Hsien-yin, principal of the Yangmingshan Elementary School, said the children are looking forward to knowing the stories behind the news, especially how the news is processed and presented by mass media outlets.

Tsai Yi-lin, a journalism student enrolled in the program as a reader, said the most challenging part for a reader is not reading the newspapers but inspiring the children to think about the meaning behind the stories.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-designed folding chair wins Red Dot Design Award

TEXT.P: A folding chair without screws designed by a teacher at Shu-Te University in Kaohsiung County and his student has won a Red Dot Design Concept Award in the competition for Germany's 2008 Red Dot Design Awards, considered "the Oscars of the design world."

Lecturer Chen Chun-tung and his student Fang Po-hsiung had spent three months perfecting their design of the "Good-bye Screw" folding chair, which emerged one of the winners in the furniture category from among 1,900 entries.

Chen, who has designed 10 different kinds of chairs for an industrial company, said Monday that it takes only one minute to assemble the folding chair, because it has only a few components and no screws.
He added that the company working with him has obtained the right to manufacture the new product and will consider mass production at an appropriate time.

According to Chen, the chair is made of polypropylene mixed with textile fibers, and treated with the gas injection technique. This technique can increase the strength of the main body while reducing the plastic consumption, and results in a cost reduction for the production.
The new design has been put on display for one year at the Red Dot's second museum in Singapore.

The Red Dot Design Concept Award is regarded as the barometer for future design directions and trends. It also offers many business opportunities for the award- winning design ideas by attracting industrialists as potential partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gravel ship sinks, four crew members unaccounted for

TEXT.P: A ship loaded with construction sand and gravel sank off the coast of Keelung Sunday evening, with six of its 10 crew members rescued and the others unaccounted for.

A coast guard officer in Keelung said his office received the distress message from the 1177 ton weighted ship, named Lienmeng, when it capsized and sank 5.2 nautical miles off the coast of Keelung. A coast guard cutter and a helicopter rushed to the scene and fished out six crew members from the sea. A search for the remaining four crew members was going on as of the press time.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 15, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Ceremony marks the launch of direct cross-strait shipping links at Keelung Harbor Date and Time: 10 a.m., Monday, Dec. 15, 2008. Place: West No. 16 Wharf, Keelung Harbor Host and/or main speakers: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan Organizers: Keelung Harbor Bureau Press Contact:(02)24206100@ Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT official heads to China to witness launch of shipping links

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Lien Chan departed for China's northern port city of Tianjin Sunday to witness the launch of direct shipping links across the Taiwan Strait from the Chinese side.

Lien and a 10-member KMT delegation were scheduled to travel via Hong Kong to Tianjin Sunday, where the group will attend a ceremony the following day to mark the opening on the Chinese side of direct cross-strait shipping links.

Commercial vessels from both sides of the strait will begin historic direct cross-strait voyages Monday, with Taiwan's ports of Kaohsiung, Keelung and Taichung and 11 Chinese seaports, including Tianjin, Dalian, Qingdao and Shanghai, being the key players in the initial stages.

Among the ships scheduled to take part in the inaugural direct sailings Monday will be two vessels belonging to Evergreen Marine Corp. and Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., respectively. One will embark from Kaohsiung bound for Tianjin, while the other will set sail from Keelung bound for Shanghai.
The day will also see two Chinese vessels put out from Tianjin and Shanghai, respectively, to make the direct crossing to ports in Taiwan.

The launch of the direct cross-strait shipping links is one of four agreements sealed by the two sides Nov. 4 on expanding transport exchanges, postal services and establishing a food safety mechanism.

After attending the ceremony in Tianjin, Lien and his delegation, including KMT Vice Chairman Lin Feng-cheng, will proceed to Shanghai to attend the fourth forum between the KMT and its Chinese counterpart, the Communist Party of China (CPC), that will take place Dec. 20-21 in Shanghai.

KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung is also expected to attend the forum, marking the first time a Taiwanese ruling party chairman will attend the cross-Taiwan Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum, also known as the KMT-CPC Forum.

According to KMT Deputy Secretary-General Chang Jung-kung, the forum is aimed at promoting cross-strait economic, trade and cultural exchanges and cooperation, as well as the stable development of cross-strait relations.

Participants will discuss major issues, including cross-strait cooperation in the finance and services sectors, mutual investment, and ways to systemize mutual investment and economic exchanges, according to Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist arrivals expected to double with daily charters

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan is likely to double to 600 per day following Monday's opening of direct daily charter flight services between the two sides, according to the results of research by the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC).
As more direct routes will be adopted for the daily cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights from Dec. 15, passengers will be able to save on both cost and travel time from that day, the MOTC said.

The daily charter services will connect Taiwan to 21 Chinese destinations scattered across China, including Chengdu, Chongqing, Hangzhou, Dalian, Shenzhen, Tianjin, Kunming, Qingdao, Haikou and Shenyang.
According to tour operators, the reduced travel time will be the greatest advantage in the new measures.

From Monday, a trip on the new Taipei-Shanghai route will take only 90 minutes -- one hour less than the present route that has to go through the Hong Kong flight information zone, tour operators said. This will also help reduce the time of a flight between Taipei and Beijing to two hours and 50 minutes from the present three hours and 35 minutes.

At the same time, the number of the two-way charter flights per week will rise from 36 to 108, bureau officials said. Currently, some 90 percent of the passengers are Taiwanese businessmen, so seats will need to be added to meet tourism demand between the two sides, they noted.
The increased flights and destinations will also help attract a larger number of Chinese tourists, they contended.
The MOTC's Tourism Bureau forecast that an average of 600 Chinese tourists will come to Taiwan for sightseeing per day aboard the direct flights, double the current daily number of 300.

Since the direct cross-strait charter flights on weekends have been implemented from mid-July, a total of 32,973 tourists from China had visited Taiwan as of early November, an average of some 300 per day, according to bureau statistics.
Some 55 percent of the total, or 18,184 people, flew into Taiwan aboard weekend charter flights from five Chinese cities -- Beijing, Shanghai, Nanjing, Guangzhou and Xiamen -- the tallies indicate.
Taiwan and China inked two landmark accords in June in Beijing to allow Chinese tourists from 13 provinces and cities to visit Taiwan and to establish the direct weekend charter flights.

The two sides expanded the scope of the two pacts during talks in Taipei in November, allowing Chinese residents from more cities and provinces to make pleasure trips to Taiwan and expanding the weekend charter flights to a daily service.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mountain climbers seek to restore flagship hiking route

TEXT.P: Four mountain climbing groups, including one composed of soldiers from an army airborne division, gathered in central Taiwan Sunday to mark the restoration of a flagship hiking trail between Hsitou and Alishan that has been blocked since the devastating 921 Earthquake.

About 100 people in four groups gathered at the Shanlinhsi Recreational Park in Nantou County to mark their efforts to renovate the hiking trail between Hsitou and Alishan -- known as the Hsi-Ah Trail -- which was damaged by the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake that rattled Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999.

Since the earthquake, which left more than 2,300 people dead, 8,800 injured and some 10,000 others homeless, the renowned Hsi-Ah Trail was closed to hikers as many sections of the trail were destroyed by the temblor.

The 17-member special military squad departed from Alishan early Friday and hiked along the route that roughly followed the old Hsi-Ah Trail, reaching Shanlinhsi early Sunday. They trekked a total of 31 km, mostly along the ridgelines of the mountains between Alishan and Hsitou.

The captain of the squad, surnamed Chen, said the trek was a "synergy" operation, as the soldiers completed long-haul march training and fact-finding for the building of military communications relay stops, as well as enjoying a trail famous among mountain climbers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Singapore minister mentor applauds cross-strait development: SEF

TEXT.P: The Singapore government has praised the cross-Taiwan Strait policies of President Ma Ying-jeou, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said in a press release Saturday following a visit to Singapore by SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.

Chiang, who made a three-day visit to Singapore that ended Dec. 12, met Singapore Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong and Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew and exchanged views on cross-strait relations, cross-strait development, the ruling Kuomintang's cross-strait policies, the results of a November meeting between Chiang and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, and Asia's regional security issues.

According to the SEF statement, the Singapore government and various scholars said the continued building of mutual trust across the Taiwan Strait and the promoting of cross-strait economic and cultural exchanges will help Taiwan gain international space.

Cross-strait ties began warming up with an earlier meeting between Chiang and Chen six months ago in Beijing following Ma's May 20 inauguration -- seen as having a more conciliatory approach toward China.

A second round of SEF-ARATS talks was held in Taipei Nov. 3-7, in which Chiang and Chen signed four agreements to allow expanded direct flights, as well as shipping links and postal services, in addition to the establishment of a food safety mechanism between the two sides.
Chen was the highest-ranking Chinese official to have set foot on Taiwan since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949.
Lee, a former prime minister, is seen as one of the most influential political figures in Southeast Asia, while Goh, also a former prime minister, is chairman of the central bank of Singapore.

He further said that ensuring the welfare of the animals will be the top priority when the animals are transported from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to the zoo after they arrive in Taiwan later this month.

He added that the zoo will seek police assistance to try to shorten the transport time from the airport to the zoo to approximately 40 minutes. Police might be deployed to ensure smooth traffic flow to avoid having the pandas stuck in traffic and to make the journey as least traumatic for them as possible, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to attend opening of direct shipping links in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will preside over a ceremony at Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan Monday to mark the historic inauguration of direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links.

A vessel belonging to Evergreen Marine Corp. -- Taiwan's largest shipping company and one of the world's biggest -- will sail from the Taiwan's largest port to the port of Tianjin in northern China's Hebei Province -- the first-ever between the two sides in 60 years.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan will also attend a similar ceremony at Keelung Port in northern Taiwan, from where four Taiwanese commercial ships will depart for Xiamen in Fujian Province, Shanghai and Taichang in Jiangsu Province and for Dalian in Liaoning Province, respectively.
Meanwhile, a vessel will put out from Taichung Port -- the third port selected by the authorities to handle such crossings -- bound for Huangpu in Guangdong Province.
At the same time, China is opening 63 ports for cross-strait links from Dec. 15, based on one of four agreements inked last month in Taipei by the two sides.
Establishing direct cross-strait air and shipping links has been one of Ma's major policies since he assumed office in May.

Executives of Yangming Marine Transport Corp., another of the local shipping companies involved in the new venture, said the measure will help shippers save as much as US$60 million per year on costs, as well as greatly reducing journey times.

Keelung Harbor Bureau Director-General Hsiao Ding-hsun said Saturday that the northern Taiwanese port and shipping companies will benefit from the long- awaited opening of direct cross-strait shipping links.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors may appeal against former president's release

TEXT.P: The Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office will hold a meeting Monday to decide whether to appeal former President Chen Shui- bian's release following his indictment on charges of corruption and money laundering, State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming said Sunday.

According to Chen Tsung-ming, the prosecutors felt that in principle they should file an appeal against the Taipei District Court's decision a day earlier to release the former president without bail.

He said that with Chen Shui-bian out of detention, some of the witnesses to be questioned in the second stage of the investigation into his alleged taking of bribes from the financial sector might be reluctant to testify.
The prosecutors will make an announcement after reaching a decision at Monday's meeting, he added.
The former president had been detained for 32 days since Nov. 12 as prosecutors prepared their case against him.

After four months of intensive investigations, prosecutors indicted him Dec. 12 on charges of embezzlement, bribe-taking and money laundering. He was released the following day on his own recognizance after the court rejected a request by the prosecutors to keep him in custody.

According to the indictment, the former president and his wife together embezzled NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from the president's special discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000-2008.

They also took bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, prosecutors charged.
The prosecutors recommended that the former president be given the harshest possible sentence for his alleged illegalities involving nearly half a billion new Taiwan dollars.

They also demanded severe penalties for his wife, son and daughter-in-law for their "unrepentant attitude" in the course of investigations, while recommending commuted sentences for 10 other defendants because they had been cooperative and helpful in the process of the investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Family with eight voluntary workers honored

TEXT.P: Eight people in a three-generation family who have worked as volunteers in the northern county of Taoyuan were cited by Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi Sunday for their unselfish services to others.

The eight people, including 73-year-old Hsiao Ah-chi, his 71-year-old wife You Chu, their daughter, their son-in-law, and four of their grandchildren, were cited by Liao at a ceremony held in the central city of Taichung.
Addressing the ceremony, Liao described the volunteer workers around the country as unsung heroes in their efforts to help the government serve the people and make Taiwan a better place to live.
He noted that it was tremendously hard for the volunteers to be elected a "model volunteer family, " as very few families in Taiwan meet the criteria to be cited at the annual event.

Under the criteria, he went on, each member of the family should have been a volunteer worker for over three years, at least two of the family members must currently be volunteers, each of the volunteers should have worked over 1,000 voluntary hours and the total number of voluntary work time of the family must exceed 3,000 hours.

Both Hsiao and You have been working as volunteers at agencies under the Taoyuan county government. Hsiao has been a volunteer worker for six years and six months, with his voluntary work time totaling 3,114 hours, according to sponsors of the citation event.
You has been working even harder than her husband, with her voluntary work time totaling an astonishing 10,852 hours, mostly at the Taoyuan County Library, where she works as a cultural volunteer.
Four of the Taoyuan couple's grandchildren -- the youngest of whom is just eight years old -- have also been volunteer workers.
"Volunteer work offers us an opportunity to pursue the pleasure of getting along with people," said You.

DOC.HEADLINE: Creative ideas for consumption vouchers pouring in: interior minister

TEXT.P: A call by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) for the public to contribute ideas on the best way to maximize the effects in stimulating the ailing econonmy of the government's consumption vouchers has resulted in many ideas being submitted, Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said Sunday.
Liao made the remarks while attending a ceremony to award volunteer workers in Taichung City.

The Executive Yuan has now finalized the issue of the consumption coupons to be a combination of six coupons with a face value of NT$500 (US$15) and three coupons with a face-value of NT$200, for a total of nine coupons with a combined value of NT$3,600.

In addition to various value combinations, the ideas put forward by members of the public included stamp- sized coupons and coupons that look like vouchers issued by department stores, while others suggested having the vouchers on a single sheet that would be stamped each time it was used.
Liao did not disclose if anyone had actually won any of the various prizes offered by the MOI for winning ideas, but he thanked the submitters for their creativity.

Meanwhile that day, the Government Information Office (GIO) announced that the GIO will start a creativity contest Dec. 15 on how to maximize the economy- stimulating effect of the coupons, with a grand prize of NT$100,000 for the winner, whose name will be announced at the end of January. It also said there will be runner-up prizes of NT$30,000 and NT$10,000.

All the ideas, whether or not they are winners, will be placed into a database that will be made available for business operators and shop owners, while the GIO will also set up a Web site for business operators to advertise their discounts, sales and promotional events.
Premier Liu Chao-shuan will brief the legislature Dec. 16 in an effort to convince the lawmakers to approve the NT$85.7 special budget for the vouchers proposed Dec. 8 by the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: University students to read newspapers for school children

TEXT.P: Students from a local university's journalism department will begin a program in which they will read newspapers to children at a local elementary school to foster their love for reading and their interest in news stories.

According to a press release it issued Sunday, students from the College of Journalism and Communication of Chinese Culture University in Yangmingshan, suburban Taipei, will read newspapers to students from grades three to six at Yangmingshan Elementary School from Dec. 11-30.
College Dean Shen Huei-sheng said the purpose of the program is to help the children understand the significance of every story and how news stories are produced.

The stories will cover issues in the field of environmental protection, law enforcement and life education, and the organizers hope they will instill the listeners with love for reading, literature and life.

Chen Hsien-yin, principal of the Yangmingshan Elementary School, said the children are looking forward to knowing the stories behind the news, especially how the news is processed and presented by mass media outlets.

Tsai Yi-lin, a journalism student enrolled in the program as a reader, said the most challenging part for a reader is not reading the newspapers but inspiring the children to think about the meaning behind the stories.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-designed folding chair wins Red Dot Design Award

TEXT.P: A folding chair without screws designed by a teacher at Shu-Te University in Kaohsiung County and his student has won a Red Dot Design Concept Award in the competition for Germany's 2008 Red Dot Design Awards, considered "the Oscars of the design world."

Lecturer Chen Chun-tung and his student Fang Po-hsiung had spent three months perfecting their design of the "Good-bye Screw" folding chair, which emerged one of the winners in the furniture category from among 1,900 entries.

Chen, who has designed 10 different kinds of chairs for an industrial company, said Monday that it takes only one minute to assemble the folding chair, because it has only a few components and no screws.
He added that the company working with him has obtained the right to manufacture the new product and will consider mass production at an appropriate time.

According to Chen, the chair is made of polypropylene mixed with textile fibers, and treated with the gas injection technique. This technique can increase the strength of the main body while reducing the plastic consumption, and results in a cost reduction for the production.
The new design has been put on display for one year at the Red Dot's second museum in Singapore.

The Red Dot Design Concept Award is regarded as the barometer for future design directions and trends. It also offers many business opportunities for the award- winning design ideas by attracting industrialists as potential partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gravel ship sinks, four crew members unaccounted for

TEXT.P: A ship loaded with construction sand and gravel sank off the coast of Keelung Sunday evening, with six of its 10 crew members rescued and the others unaccounted for.

A coast guard officer in Keelung said his office received the distress message from the 1177 ton weighted ship, named Lienmeng, when it capsized and sank 5.2 nautical miles off the coast of Keelung. A coast guard cutter and a helicopter rushed to the scene and fished out six crew members from the sea. A search for the remaining four crew members was going on as of the press time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 15, or the 18th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1891: The Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution, goes into effect.
1915: Noted Taiwan folklore writer Chung Li-ho is born.
1920: China and Austria are admitted into the League of Nations.
1927: The Republic of China government orders the closure of the Soviet consulate in Shanghai and begins rounding up communists following an attempted communist coup in Canton the day before.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman and premier of the Nationalist government, retires, citing the interests of party unity as the reason for his move.
1938: The United States agrees to lend US$25 million to China under a Sino- American oil loan agreement.
1944: Chinese expeditionary forces capture Bhamo in northern Burma.
1946: The U.N. General Assembly decides to set up its permanent headquarters in New York City.
1948: France completes the construction of its first nuclear reactor.
1949: The ROC Executive Yuan names Wu Kuo-chen as governor of Taiwan.
1952: Beijing rejects India's plan for a Korean armistice.
1961: The U.N. General Assembly votes against a Soviet proposal to admit Communist China as a member.
1965: The U.S. Mariner spacecraft flies past Venus and relays data about the planet to scientists on Earth.
1966: Walter Elias Disney -- the U.S. animator, showman and film producer known as "Walt" -- dies at the age of 65.
1970: The first Sino-American Conference on Mainland China is opened in Taipei.
1971: The state-run Bank of China becomes a private bank and changes its name to the International Commercial Bank of China.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1972: The Japanese embassies in Taipei and Kaohsiung are closed.
1973: Tachien Dam, which had been under construction in central Taiwan for four years, becomes operational.
1977: A newly built integrated steel plant of the state-run China Steel Corp. starts operating in Kaohsiung.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter announces that he will establish diplomatic relations with Communist China from Jan. 1, 1979, and break off relations with the Republic of China at the same time.
1978: The "Chang Sheng," the first Taiwan-built 20,000-ton container vessel, is launched in Keelung.
1980: The ROC's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is inaugurated.
1988: The U.N. General Assembly overwhelmingly calls for the convening of an international Middle East peace conference.
1993: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves a revision of the University Law, giving more autonomy to colleges and allowing students to participate in meetings related to school affairs.
1995: Beijing sentences Wei Jingsheng, a noted dissident, to 14 years in jail for "conspiring to subvert the government," a move that arouses international condemnation.
1999: The U.S. State Department clarifies its stance on the ROC's bid to join the World Health Organization, saying the U.S. supports Taiwan's "meaningful participation," not its membership, in the body.
2000: Chiang Peng-chien, a member of the Control Yuan and founding chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), dies of pancreatic cancer at the age of 61.
2001: The Second International Bio Science and Technology Exposition opens at the Taipei World Trade Center, with over 300 firms from home and abroad participating.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leaves for Japan for a week-long visit, making him the first KMT chairman to visit Japan since the party moved its headquarters to Taiwan in 1950.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Think how anxious your parents are when you are sick, and you will know your duty toward them. The duty of a good son nowadays means only to be able to support his parents. But you also keep your dogs and horses alive. If there is no feeling of love and respect, where is the difference?"

DOC.HEADLINE: President presides over opening of direct cross-strait shipping links

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou traveled to the southern port city of Kaohsiung Monday to officiate at a ceremony that marked the historic inauguration of direct cross- Taiwan Strait shipping links.

Addressing the ceremony, Ma said he has mixed feelings about the establishment of the links as he had published a white paper on direct cross-strait air and shipping links 16 years ago when he was vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and when the two sides were technically at war.

The president said he is pleased that direct air and shipping transport links across the Taiwan Strait have been launched only six months and 15 days since his inauguration, as a result of efforts by the administrations on both sides.

"The opening of direct air and shipping links means the two sides are no longer hostile toward each other and are willing to replace confrontation with dialogue and conflict with reconciliation, " he said.

The direct cross-strait shipping links officially got underway at 10 a.m. at the Kaohsiung Harbor, with the Uni-Adroit, a full-container ship owned and operated by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp, setting sail for China's northern port city of Tianjin.

The Uni-Adroit, with a capacity of 1,168 TEUs, was scheduled to sail directly from Kaohsiung to Tianjin's New Port before heading to the northern Chinese ports Dalian and Qingdao on its way home, according to an Evergreen spokesman.

Meanwhile, four container ships owned and operated by Taiwan's Wan Hai Lines, Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., Taiwan Navigation Co. and China's Huarong Marine Co., respectively, were also scheduled to depart Monday from Taiwan's northern port of Keelung for various Chinese seaports, including Shanghai and Dalien.

Also on Monday, 15 Chinese vessels were scheduled to set sail from six Chinese seaports, including Tianjin and Shanghai, to make the direct crossing to Taiwan's Kaohsiung, Keelung and Taichung harbors.

The launch of direct cross-strait shipping links is one of four agreements sealed by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on Nov. 4 to further expand transportation exchanges, postal services and address food safety issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
MAC denies expanded cross-strait links represent 'tribute to China'

TEXT.P: Dismissing the disapproval expressed by some critics of the latest cross-Taiwan Strait opening, Taiwan's top China policy coordinator said Monday that the launch of direct shipping and expanded air transport links across the Taiwan Strait does not mean that Taiwan is now tilting toward China.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said the inauguration of direct cross-strait shipping links and the launch of expanded cross-strait air links Monday are by no means symbolic of Taiwan "paying tribute to the Chinese leaders" as some have alleged.
Instead, she said, the opening of the links was one of the administration's policies to create an environment that would be conducive to the Taiwan people making commercial profits.

With the opening of direct cross-strait shipping links, she said, Taiwan-based shipping companies and related businesses would see huge cuts in costs and transport time, which in turn would help to bolster Taiwan's international competitiveness.

Meanwhile, she noted that negotiators from both sides have agreed that the Taiwanese and Chinese vessels plying the routes would fly their respective national flags while they are in their own country, but the flags would be removed when they enter the territory of the other side.
The launch of direct cross-strait shipping links is one of four agreements sealed by the two sides Nov. 4 on expanding transport exchanges, postal services and establishing a food safety mechanism.
The private sector estimates that the establishment of two-way direct transport links would save Taiwan up to US$90 million per year in direct flights and shipping costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: New era in cross-strait shipping links begins: premier

TEXT.P: Direct shipping links between Taiwan and mainland China were officially launched Monday morning with formal ceremonies at Keelung harbor in northern Taiwan and Kaohsiung harbor in southern Taiwan, at which Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and President Ma Ying-jeou officiated, respectively.
I am very happy to see that a new page has been turned in shipping links between Taiwan and mainland China, " said Liu at the launch ceremony at Keelung Harbor.

"This is an important step in cross-strait transportation. We have worked for several years to make this happen, " he said. "I am happy to see this progress, but I am sad that it took us so long to complete this step."

With the establishment of direct shipping links, cargo transport between mainland China and Taiwan will increase, as such links will allow for lower shipping costs and quicker delivery of goods between the two sides, he said.
A 20,000-ton cargo ship will save around NT$200,000 per trip from Keelung to any port in Fujian province he said.
For passengers, if you board a vessel at 8 p.m. then go to sleep, when you wake up, you will be in mainland China," said Liu.
"The service, in a sense, will be better than express delivery, he added.

He expressed the view that Taiwan products, especially fruit, will be very popular in mainland China, noting that it will now cost less to transport farm produce to China because of the shipping links.
He urged that everyone strive to boost the local economy, noting that the opening of direct cross-strait shipping links was one President Ma Ying-jeou's major election promises.
"Today, fully-loaded cargo vessels are sailing to mainland Chinese ports, which makes Keelung Harbor a shining star in northern Taiwan, "he said.

With the launch of the direct shipping links, commercial vessels will ply sea routes between the two sides, with Kaohsiung, Keelung and Taichung in Taiwan and 11 seaports in China, including Tianjin, Dalian, Qingdao and Shanghai, being the key ports in the initial stages.

The "Ming Chun" cargo ship of the Wanhai Lines, "YM Heights" belonging to Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., the container vessel "Tao Yuan" belonging to the Taiwan Navigation Company and the cargo ship "Kang Ping" which belongs to the Huarong Marine Shipping Co. were all set to sail from Keelung Harbor Monday.
The "YM Heights" was bound for Shanghai, while the other three were headed for other ports in mainland China.
The crews of the four vessels stood on deck after they finished loading the cargo waiting for the historic formal launching of the links.
Meanwhile, two mainland Chinese vessels were scheduled to embark for Taiwan from Tianjin and Shanghai, respectively, to make the direct crossing of the Taiwan Strait to ports in Taiwan.

The launch of the direct cross-strait shipping links was effected under one of four agreements sealed by the two sides Nov. 4 on expanding transport exchanges and postal services and establishing a food safety mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2,400 employees laid off from Hsinchu Science Park in 1st 11 months

TEXT.P: A total of 2,400 employees were laid off by companies in the Hsinchu Science Park in the first 11 months of this year, a park administration official said Monday.

The figure represents a year-on-year increase of 70 percent when compared to the one posted for the same period of 2007, but is about the same level as the 2006 figure for the first 11 months -- before the effects of the global financial meltdown became apparent -- said Tu Chi-hsiang, deputy director-general of the Hsinchu Science Park Administration.
Tu called for the management of firms in the park to keep in mind that an excellent workforce is the bedrock of any business seeking long-term sustainable development.

The Hsinchu Science Park, located in northern Taiwan, is known as the country's "Silicon Valley, " as it was the first science-based industrial park to be established and is still the largest of its kind in terms of revenues, the number of companies in operation and the number of people employed there.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO support sought from Asia-Pacific countries: legislative speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng expressed hope Monday that Asia-Pacific countries will voice support for Taiwan's bid for observer status at the World Health Assembly -- the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO) -- to be held next May.

In his opening remarks at the International Conference on East Asia Regional Development held in Taipei, Wang said Taiwan's influence on and contributions to the world make the country's bids for participation in international organizations such as the WHO deserving of support from nations in the Asia- Pacific region.

In addition, he went on, through the overseas visits he has made in the past, he has come to realize that strengthening the country's foreign relations is key to achieving political and economic stability at home.
Therefore, the country should make every effort to involve itself in Asia- Pacific affairs, especially at present, when the region is faced with challenges and changes, Wang said.

Apart from the development of friendly relations with regional neighbors, he pointed out that whether cross-Taiwan Strait links will improve effectively also plays a pivotal role in Taiwan's continued prosperity.

In the past, Taiwan's efforts to obtain WHO membership have always been stymied by China, and while there has so far been no clear indication regarding what its attitude is likely to be next May, the Beijing authorities have not ruled out the possibility of negotiations on Taiwan's participation in the world body.

Wang said that during a landmark visit to Taiwan in early November by Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, he proposed to Chen that China could withdraw its more-than 1,000 missiles targeting the country and cease to obstruct Taiwan's participation in international bodies.
Peaceful cross-strait development, he continued, will in turn ensure stability in East Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei bourse
