DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese spouses welcome direct flights, but want lower airfare

TEXT.P: Chinese spouses married to Taiwanese people on Monday overwhelmingly welcomed the launching of daily direct flights between Taiwan and China, expressing hopes it will make it easier for them to travel back and forth between the two sides.
I believe it will save time and be more convenient, " said Zeng Yen-mei, who originated from east China's Jiangxi province, and has been in Taiwan for more than 10 years.
In the past, it took her about 10 hours to travel from Taipei to Jiangxi to see relatives, due to a mandatory stopover in Hong Kong, or Macau. With direct flights, the travel time has been reduced.
In addition to Taiwanese investors, the estimated 290,000 Chinese spouses, mostly wives, in Taiwan are believed to be one of the main beneficiaries of the new ease of transportation.

Until recently, many of the spouses could not easily work here until after living in Taiwan for several years, due to government restrictions. That and the costly detoured flights made it difficult for them to visit parents and other family members back in China. Many visit only once a year during Chinese New Year, or not every year.
Spouses on Monday, however, said they will not jump at the chance of taking the direct flights, as airfares are still expensive.
"I hope that the ticket price would come down to NT$15,000,said Wu Feng-hua, who came from Sichuan province, adding that the current price is around NT$20,000 for a roundtrip ticket.

Wu said the resumption of direct daily flights after a nearly 60 year hiatus following a Chinese civil war makes her more willing to go back to China to visit her family there. She currently visits no more than once a year.

In addition to allowing flights to fly directly, the number of destinations in China have also been significantly expanded, including Chengdu in Wu's home province of Sichuan and nearby Chongqing in southwest China.
As a result, Wu's journeys home will be significantly shortened.

As part of landmark agreements signed in early November by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, which went into effect Monday, new direct and regular air services are opened among eight Taiwan cities and 21 of Chinas.

As the planes no longer need to fly south through Hong Kong's air space, the flight time between Taipei and Shanghai is cut by an hour, becoming 80 minutes. It will take only 150 minutes from Taipei to Beijing, making it possible for businessman and others to travel back and forth between the two sides in one day.

It is believed that the reopening of cross-strait air links will help boost Taiwans tourism, with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications expecting the number of Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan to rise to about 600 a day, up from the current 300.

Lower airfares and more departure points from China could enable more of the mainland spouses' relatives to visit Taiwan. Other than parents and siblings, some of the spouses have children from previous marriages whom they long to see.

The direct flights, as well as direct shipping and mail deliveries launched Monday between Taiwan and China are the first to happen since the end of a civil war in 1949 when the Communist Party seized power on the Chinese mainland and the Nationalist Party or Kuomintang fled to Taiwan.
Mainland spouses represent the largest group of foreign spouses in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: New evidence proves brown dwarfs form like stars

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-U.S. astronomical research project has discovered the first ever direct evidence that brown dwarfs form in the same way as stars, a finding that may settle the argument on whether brown dwarfs form like stars or like planets.
According to Academia Sinica, a brown dwarf is an astronomical object with a mass larger than a planet but smaller than a star -- generally 15 to 75 times larger than Jupiter.

The paper, which will be published in the Dec. 20 issue of the Astrophysical Journal Letters, stated that a brown dwarf dubbed "ISO- Oph 102" was observed developing an accretion disk and two outflow jets in opposite directions -- the unique phenomena of star formation.

However, it is not clear whether brown dwarfs -- sometimes called "failed stars" -- form like stars, from the gravitational collapse of gas clouds, or form like planets, agglomerating rocky material until they grow massive enough to draw in nearby gas.

Another surprising aspect of the scientists' findings is that the observation was made with an older generation telescope, the Submillimeter Array -- a collaborative project of the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory in the United States and Academia Sinica in Taiwan.

"As brown dwarfs tend to have smaller mass and weaker outflows, we thought only a next-generation telescope like ALMA could make the observation," said Phan Bao-ngoc, a visiting scholar at the Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics of Academia Sinica.
Compared to the outflow from a typical star, the ISO-Oph 102's outflow contains 1,000 times less mass and the outflow rate is also one-hundredth that of star, the scientists reported.
"In all respects, the molecular outflow of ISO-Oph 102 is a scaled-down version of the outflow process seen in young stars," they concluded.

ALMA, or the Atacama Large Millimeter Array, is a collaborative project conducted by Europe, Japan, the United States, and Taiwan. The ALMA employs 66 antennas of various sizes to form the largest ground-based radio telescope so far at the 5,000-meter-high foothills of the Andes in Chile.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man booked for snatching lawmaker's wig

TEXT.P: A staunch supporter of former President Chen Shui-bian was booked by police Monday for snatching the wig off the head of ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chiu Yi, an outspoken critic of Chen.

The incident took place when Chiu was emerging from the Control Yuan after urging the government's supreme watchdog to initiate a probe into the judge who released Chen Shui-bian on his own recognizance last Saturday.
The man, who was loitering outside the Control Yuan with a group of men who claimed to be Chen's "bodyguards, " charged at Chiu and grabbed at his wig before police could stop him.
He was overpowered immediately by police, while the lawmaker was driven away by his aide in a car, minus his hairpiece.

The man, identified only by his family name of Huang, was booked by police, who later quoted him as saying that he "accidentally ran into" the lawmaker and that Chiu lost his wig while fleeing the scene.

Police said Huang, who hails from Tainan City in southern Taiwan, is a firm supporter of Chen and that he also had a brush with the law in Tainan in 2006 for heckling protesters who were calling for Chen's ouster.
According to police, Huang waited for Chiu outside the Control Yuan after learning from the TV news that the legislator intended to file a complaint against Judge Chou Chan-chun.

Chiu said the previous day that Chou's decision to reject a request from prosecutors to keep the former president in custody was flawed and he urged the Control Yuan to step in and reverse the ruling, arguing that ex-leaders are more likely to elude justice than ordinary people and citing the examples of disgraced Philippines ex-President Ferdinand Marcos and Peru's former President Alberto Fujimori.
The judge released Chen after he was formally indicted by prosecutors on charges of corruption, forgery and money laundering.

DOC.HEADLINE: Maritime pilots welcome opening of cross-strait shipping links

TEXT.P: Maritime pilots from both Kaohsiung and Keelung harbors -- Taiwan's two major seaports -- on Monday welcomed the launch of direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links.

They believe the opening of direct shipping routes for Taiwanese and Chinese ships traveling to each other's ports will significantly increase the number of ships docking at the ports, and benefit harbors in Taiwan, which have seen a decline in ships in recent years.

A pilot working at the southern port city of Kaohsiung said business at Taiwan's largest harbor will definitely soar with the historic inauguration of the direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links Monday.

Taiwanese and Chinese ships will exchange an even greater number of visits to seaports from each other's side in days to come with the opening of cross-strait shipping links that was made possible after Taiwan and China sealed four agreements Nov. 4 to further expand transportation exchanges, launch postal services and address food safety issues.

The pilot, who preferred to speak on condition of anonymity, said the number of vessels visiting Kaohsiung has suddenly soared with the launch of the cross- strait shipping links -- a phenomenon that was seldom seen over the past decade as Kaohsiung Harbor's container handling volume has been on a steady decline, with the number of container ships from around the world visiting it continuing to decrease.
He said he has keenly expected the launch of direct cross-strait shipping links, believing it will rev up Kaohsiung Harbor's business once and for all and boost his own incomes.

A pilot working at the northern port of Keelung said the opening was a shot in the arm for both the harbor and for Taiwan's pilots, whose incomes have decreased over the past several years noticeably due to declining shipping transport business in Taiwan.

The pilot, who was also reluctant to have his name known, said in recent months, his monthly salary -- mainly depending on the number of vessels he piloted -- has declined by about one-fourth to a tune between NT$300,000 and NT$400,000 (US$12,048), compared to an average of NT$500,000 per month during the 60s and 70s.

The shipping links officially got underway at 10 a.m. Monday at the Kaohsiung Harbor, with the Uni-Adroit, a full-container ship owned and operated by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp, setting sail for China's northern port city of Tianjin.

The Uni-Adroit, with a capacity of 1,168 TEUs, was scheduled to sail directly from Kaohsiung to Tianjin's New Port before heading to the northern Chinese ports Dalian and Qingdao on its way home, according to an Evergreen spokesman.

Meanwhile, four container ships owned and operated by Taiwan's Wan Hai Lines, Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., Taiwan Navigation Co. and China's Huarong Marine Co., respectively, also departed Monday from Taiwan's northern port of Keelung for various Chinese seaports, including Shanghai and Dalian.
Also on Monday, 15 Chinese vessels were scheduled to set sail from six Chinese seaports, including Tianjin and Shanghai, for Taiwan's Kaohsiung, Keelung and Taichung harbors.

A maritime pilot is a mariner who guides ships through dangerous or congested waters, such as harbors or river mouths. Legally the master remains in command of the ship. The pilot is a senior adviser only. It is one of the oldest, least known professions and yet one of the most important in terms of maritime safety. The economic and environmental risk from today's large cargo ships makes the role of the pilot essential.

Normally the pilot joins an incoming ship at sea via pilot boat and climbs a swaying Jacob's ladder sometimes up 40 feet to the deck of the largest container and tanker ships. With outgoing vessels, a pilot boat returns the pilot to land after the ship has successfully negotiated coastal waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County to build science museum in industrial park

TEXT.P: The Tainan county government in southern Taiwan has decided to build a science museum in an industrial park there to create recreational and educational functions that will be open to the public, a local official said Monday.

The museum, tentatively named the Life Science Story House, will be located in a two-story building in the Tree Valley Park, an industrial area designed to also function as an ecological park, the official said.

It will host collections and exhibitions on animal science, human life and history, and will introduce the relationship between the development of science and human civilization, the official went on.

The building's roof will be used for birdwatching and stargazing and its surrounding green land will serve as a concert venue, the official continued, adding that construction is expected to be completed by the end of next year.
The Tree Valley Park, which is so named to reflect its ecological image, will be open to both company personnel who work there and to the general public, the official said.
A total of 13 enterprises have invested in the 247-hectare park within the last year, including Chi Mei Corp., a leading plastics producer, the official noted.

Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih said investment in the park has been particularly efficient thanks to the county's plan that allows the private sector to take charge of land development projects without wasting time waiting for the government's time-consuming land development procedures.
Su thanked Chi Mei Corp. for providing 20,000 jobs for local people, as well as planting 100,000 trees in the park, noting that the move has transformed the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to strengthen climate policies

TEXT.P: The government was urged by the Taiwan Green Party Monday to strengthen its climate policies and impose carbon taxes in the wake of a consensus reached at a summit Friday by European Union leaders on a so-called 20-20-20 package that aims to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 20 percent by 2020 compared to the 1990 level, make 20 percent energy savings and bring renewable energy sources up to 20 percent of total energy use.

Green Party Secretary-General Pan Han-shen criticized the various targets set by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou as "too loose, " referring to Ma's vow on World Environment Day June 5 to maintain Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions as 2008 levels, reduce the emissions to 2000 levels by 2025 and halve the emissions from 2000 levels by 2050.

Pan was also scathing about the Executive Yuan's passage -- also on World Environment Day -- of the Sustainable Energy Policy Guidelines, according to which the government should raise energy efficiency by 2 percent every year during the coming eight years, and reduce energy intensity by at least 20 percent by 2015 compared to the 2005 level.
The guidelines also aim to increase the low-carbon energy proportion of the country's total energy supply to more than 55 percent by 2025.

Citing Claude Turmes, a Luxembourg Green Party member of the European parliament, Pan urged the government to take advantage of the current economic slump to adjust domestic industrial structure, warning that otherwise, energy consumption in Taiwan might become even greater when the economy is revitalized.
Turmes said recently that governments of EU countries are "using the economic downturn as an excuse to water down their climate policies."
Pan also suggested that the government impose carbon taxes that would make the heavier polluters pay more.

An official of the Environmental Protection Administration said that Europe, with its advanced technology and funds, as well as the higher public perceptions about the environment, is certainly the most capable and active in terms of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

But asked if Taiwan's greenhouse gas emission reduction targets are looser than those of Europe, he said that every country has its own unique background and should therefore set up their own individual emission reduction targets.
"After all, (reducing greenhouse gas emissions) is a `common but differentiated responsibility, '" he said, adding that in Taiwan's case "at present, we are still building our capacity."

DOC.HEADLINE: Air fares for flights to China could be cut by New Year: airline

TEXT.P: Fares for daily passenger charter flights across the Taiwan Strait could be adjusted downwards before the New Year because of supply exceeding demand for seats at current prices, a local airline official said Monday.

The TransAsia Airways official noted that it used an Airbus A-321 aircraft with a capacity of 182 passengers to fly the Taipei-Shanghai route Monday -- the first flight to leave for China under a new daily cross-Taiwan Strait passenger charter agreement -- but only 144 passengers were on board.
The passenger load factor of only about 80 percent on the inaugural flight led the official to forecast that supply would exceed demand for future flights.
"Considering the market, a price cut is inevitable and the cuts could come before the New Year," he said.

The official anticipated that from now until Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 26, will be a low season for tourism. He said the airline will stand pat for the time being before deciding on price cuts or seeking strategic cooperation with other air carriers based on market needs and the economic situation.

The official noted that when weekend charter flights between Taiwan and China were inaugurated in July, most observers believed that the flights would not be able to meet demand, but the reverse has turned out to be true.
The daily passenger charters were expected to draw more interest than the weekend flights because they operated daily and offered shorter flight times to destinations in central and northern China.

But despite the shorter flight times and distances, reports said air fares on the Taipei-Shanghai route had fallen by only NT$1,000, from NT$17,000 and NT$18,000 to NT$16,000 and NT$17,000, prices some consumers still consider too high.

Weekend charter passenger services were inaugurated in July. Monday marked the beginning of expanded air links, with the number of flights provided rising from 36 to 108 per week, that were finalized in an agreement signed between Taiwan and China in early November.

Unlike the weekend flights, which were required to pass through the flight information region of Hong Kong or Macau, the daily flights to central and northern China are being allowed to pass through the flight information region of Japan, resulting in shorter flying times.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southern counties eyeing tourism opportunities from direct links

TEXT.P: A tourism promotion task force of Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County and Pingtung County in southern Taiwan is preparing to make concerted efforts to lure more Chinese tourists following the opening Monday of direct transport links between Taiwan and China.

The task force, led by Kaohsiung city government adviser Lin Fu-nan and composed of tourism officials and tourism association representatives from the three administrative regions, is slated to meet Thursday to devise a strategy to lure more visitors from China.
Direct daily charter flights, shipping and postal links between Taiwan and China kicked off Monday -- the first since the People's Republic of China was established in 1949.
Under the new links, Taiwan has opened 11 ports to vessels linking up with up to 63 ports in China.
Earlier Monday, a vessel belonging to Evergreen Marine Corp. set out from the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung, the country's biggest, to the port of Tianjin in northern China's Hebei province.
President Ma Ying-jeou presided over the ceremony held in Kaohsiung marking the historical launch of the direct shipping links.

Kaohsiung Port, once the world's third-largest container port, is hoping that the direct links well help improve its competitiveness and reverse its declining container traffic rankings that left it in eighth place in the world in 2007.

Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau Director-General Hsieh Ming-huei estimated that the direct shipping links with China will boost the number of TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units) the port handles by one million a year.

At present, Kaohsiung Port handles about 10 million TEUs annually, leaving it just behind Rotterdam and Dubai in the world rankings and just ahead of the fast-growing Chinese ports of Qingdao, Ningbo and Guangzhou.
The real estate market, particularly commercial property owners, in Kaohsiung City is also looking for a new lease on life with the establishment of direct cross-strait shipping links.
The local land development and construction sector is eagerly hoping that the links can help bring to Kaohsiung more resources, including talent, technology, raw materials and investment.

Kaohsiung City hopes to replace Hong Kong or Singapore as a business operations hub and a research and development center in the Asia-Pacific region, said Cheng Wu-tsong, chairman of the city's construction association.
Huang Fu-chiao, chairman of the Kaohsiung County Travel Association, said the direct Taiwan-China transportation links will help Taiwan's tourism and ease tensions across the strait.
According to Huang, Kaohsiung County hopes to capitalize on its rich cultural heritage and ecological diversity in attracting tourists.

For instance, he said, Chinese visitors should be interested in the important cultural and religious sites of the Hakka-style Meinong township and Foguangshan Temple, as well as the hot spring resort area of Baolai in Liouguei village and the many fruit orchards scattered across the county.
Hoteliers in Baolai are keen to embrace Chinese tourists in the hope of strengthening their businesses, Huang said.
Dates, guavas, wax apples and lichis cultivated in Kaohsiung County enjoy renown for their fine quality among Taiwanese consumers and could also prove to be good draws.

Despite disappointing arrival numbers to date following an agreement opening tourism to Taiwan in June, Huang believed that more Chinese tourists will come to Taiwan following the Lunar New Year holiday in late January 2009.

In neighboring Pingtung County, many wax apple growers have begun to weigh the possibility of shipping the fragile fruit to China -- something which was beyond their imagination in the past -- thanks to the direct shipping links.

Although the Pingtung County government has been selling locally produced pineapples, papayas, dates, bananas and lemons to China in recent years, many local wax apple farmers are hesitant to follow suit out of concerns over greater difficulties to preserve them.

Yao Chih-wang, a section chief of the county's agriculture bureau, contended that the reduced shipping time will definitely help Pingtung export its high- quality fruit to China, but suggested it would take time for local farmers to feel the impact of the direct links.

DOC.HEADLINE: Direct flights, shipping, postal links opened between Taiwan, China

TEXT.P: After nearly six decades, Taiwan and China on Monday resumed daily direct passenger flights, direct cargo flights and direct shipping links, seen by many as a step toward ending decades of hostilities and cutting the cost of travel and trade between the two countries.
Daily nonstop charter flights, which will fly more direct routes across the Taiwan Strait, were inaugurated Monday.

According to Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) , a flight from Shenzhen, China, to Taipei landed shortly before 9 a.m. while the first flight from Taipei to Shanghai, China, departed at 8 a.m.

In the first week, 16 daily flights to or from Taiwan and 101 cross-strait flights are scheduled. Eventually, up to 108 flights will be available each week between the two sides, with flight times on the most popular route -- Taipei- Shanghai -- shortened by as much as one hour.
In addition to daily direct air service, direct shipping was also launched for the first time since the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949.
Ceremonies were held at seaports in China as well as in Taiwan's Keelung, Taichung and Kaohsiung harbors, to send off commercial vessels on direct routes across the Taiwan Strait.
In all, ships will be able to sail between 11 ports in Taiwan and 63 ports in China, including Tianjin, Dalian, Qingdao and Shanghai, without being required to transit through a third region.
Among the ships taking part in the inaugural direct sailings on were vessels belonging to Evergreen Marine Corp. and Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp.

Evergreen's vessel embarked from Kaohsiung bound for Tianjin, while Yang Ming's set sail from Keelung bound for Shanghai. At the same time, two Chinese vessels left from Tianjin and Shanghai on nonstop voyages to ports in Taiwan.
President Ma Ying-jeou traveled to Kaohsiung Monday for the ceremony marking the historic inauguration of direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links.

"The opening of direct air and shipping links means the two sides are no longer hostile toward each other and are willing to replace confrontation with dialogue and conflict with reconciliation, " Ma said.

The launch of the direct cross-strait shipping links is one of four agreements sealed by the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) on Nov. 4.
The others expanded air links from weekend to daily nonstop charter flights, and established direct postal services and a food safety mechanism.

The opening up of Taiwan and China's airspace and water to each other will not only cut travel and shipping times, but also the costs of doing business between the two key trading partners, which are suffering from the global economic downturn.
According to Premier Liu Chao-shuan, ships with 20,000 tons of cargo will save NT$200,000 per shipment because of the direct links.
"I am very happy to see that a new page has been turned in shipping links between Taiwan and mainland China," Liu said at the launch ceremony at Keelung Harbor.
"We have worked for several years to make this happen. I am happy to see this progress, but I am sad that it took us so long to complete this step," Liu said.
Such direct links were not possible in the past because China refused to negotiate with former President Chen Shui-bian, whose administration staunchly supported Taiwan's independence.

Since being elected as president in March, Ma has invested enormous efforts in cultivating improving relations with Beijing, openly stating that he opposes reunification with or independence from China and favors pursuing a policy focused in economic ties.

Out of humanitarian concern, the former KMT government started to allow Taiwanese people to visit their families and relatives in China on Nov. 2, 1987, opening a limited door for exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

In recent years, as the cross-strait exchanges have steadily increased, the demand for the opening of the "three links" -- direct transportation, communications and trade links between Taiwan and China -- has been growing, partly due to increased trade and travel between the two sides.
Responding to the people's call, the government established the "small three links" between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu and China's Fujian Province on Apr. 5, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taxi fleet drivers to serve as anti-smoking ambassadors

TEXT.P: Fifty drivers of the Taiwan Taxi Co. who each smoked 20 to 30 years before kicking the habit will serve as ambassadors to promote non-smoking in the coming two months, the taxi company announced Monday.
These taxi drivers joined a program to quit smoking offered by Taiwan Adventist Hospital in Taipei in August 2007 and successfully got rid of their addiction to nicotine.
Liao Chia-ching, who smoked at least 20 cigarettes a day for 37 years, recounted that he was not sure whether he could succeed when he first joined the program on Aug. 8 last year.
"I am proud that, with the interim use of nicotine patches, I made it," Liao said.

According to Wu Hsien-lin, a physician in the hospital's Department of Thoracic Medicine, the taxi drivers in last year's program had an 80 percent success rate in quitting smoking, the highest ever achieved by the hospital.
Wu said the taxi drivers will share their experience with passengers, providing free brochures and compact discs about the hazards of smoking, and invite smokers to join anti-smoking programs.
The taxi drivers' "say goodbye to nicotine" campaign is also intended to call public attention to Taiwan's newly amended Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act, which will take effect on Jan. 11, 2009.
Under the act, smoking is banned in indoor public areas, including KTV lounges, bowling alleys, cybercafes, and passenger waiting rooms, as well as in indoor working areas with over three people.
Smoking is also prohibited in outdoor public areas, including train station platforms, gymnasiums, swimming pools, college campuses, and entertainment areas.
Those who violate the law can be fined between NT$2,000 and NT$10,000 (US$605).

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County inaugurates 'English village' in elementary school

TEXT.P: Changhua County has inaugurated its first "English village, " aiming to help students improve their ability to communicate in English in a vivid learning environment, Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan said Monday.

The language learning village at the central county's Minsheng Elementary School simulates a high speed rail station, with a panel showing arriving and departing train schedules, ticket booths, and even mock trains deployed in three classrooms.
Cho was present at the opening of the village held earlier in the day and led a group of county government officials in practicing English with students who were acting as station staffers.
Students at the village can learn how to deal with tasks related to this scenario such as buying tickets and also learn how to describe local cultures in English, Cho said.
Every student who steps into the village environment is required to communicate with others in English.

The county plans to create three other English villages, with each simulating a different scenario, including a hypermarket at Hsinkang Elementary School, a fast food restaurant at Hsinmin Elementary School, and an international airport at Erlin Elementary School, Cho said.
The four villages will be utilized by all junior high and elementary school students in the county, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: History made as new cross-strait flight route inaugurated

TEXT.P: Flight controllers in Taipei and Shanghai simultaneously announced the inauguration of a new air route between the two cities at 8: 06 a.m. Monday, ushering in a new era in air traffic across the Taiwan Strait.

Both Taipei Area Control Center Director Chi Liang and his Shanghai counterpart, Qian Haisheng, expressed their resolve at the inaugural ceremony to make every possible effort to ensure cross-strait flight safety.

Almost at the same time, a China Eastern Airlines aircraft took off from Shanghai en route to Taoyuan in northern Taiwan and a few minutes later, a TransAsia Airways plane set off on a flight from Taipei to Shanghai.

Both planes used the flight numbers of the new direct flight route. Radar data at the Taipei Area Control Center showed that both aircraft reached the new waypoint "SULEM" at 8:47 a.m., where flight controllers from the two sides handed off air traffic control responsibilities to their counterparts.

Despite a 3,000-foot difference in altitude between the two flights, it marked the first time in six decades that flight controllers from Taiwan and China had engaged in direct dialogue above the center line of the Taiwan Strait.
Flight controllers exchanged greetings and looked forward to cooperating with each other.

When direct weekend cross-strait charter flight services opened in July, aircraft had to pass through the Hong Kong and Jeju Island flight information regions, and air traffic controllers on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait did not come in direct contact with each other.
With the charter flights expanded to daily service, the flight route on all northbound flights to various Chinese destinations, such as Shanghai, Hengzhou, Beijing and Dalian, was straightened.
Carriers will now fly a route that requires the transfer of air traffic control at waypoint "SULEM."

The waypoint "SULEM, " located at the intersection of Taiwan and China's flight information regions (FIRs) , acquired its name last month in an agreement between Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration and its Chinese counterpart, the Civil Aviation Administration of China.

From now on, a China-bound plane, after taking off from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, will first fly northward along the B576 international flight route and turn in a northwest direction after reaching the "BERBA" waypoint sitting on the intersection of Taiwan and Japan's FIRs.

After reaching the waypoint "OLIVE" in Taiwan's FIR, the flights will turn westward and Taiwan's flight controllers will hand off air traffic control responsibilities to their Chinese counterparts when the flight reaches "SULEM."
On the other hand, Taiwan-bound flights from China will also see transfer of air traffic control responsibilities at the waypoint "SULEM, "a CAA official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: National fund will leave stock market after Dec. 17: official

TEXT.P: A national fund will not intervene in the stock market after its authorization expires Dec. 17, an official of the fund's steering committee said Monday.
William Tseng, secretary-general of the National Stabilization Fund Steering Committee, made the remarks after a committee meeting.
Tseng said committee members believed the stock market has begun to stabilize with increased volume and buying by foreign institutional investors, prompting them to quit the market.
The members indicated, however, that they will continue to monitor the situation and would meet again should any emergencies take place.
The fund was activated Sept. 18 to help prop up the stock market for one month, and its authority to intervene has since been extended twice. The latest extension expires Dec. 17.
Taiwan's main index has shed about a quarter of its value since mid-September, reflecting a global sell-off after the collapse of investment bank Lehman Brothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum puts up Christmas decor, offers discounts

TEXT.P: Christmas decorations have been put up at the renowned National Palace Museum (NPM) in suburban Taipei this year for the first time in its history, along with performances, offers of discounts and even free entry, museum officials said Monday.

Heather C.H. Ho, managing director of the NPM Museum Shop and Restaurant, said at a press conference that the museum hopes to promote the Christmas spirit of "sharing" its rich collection with visitors, as well as to attract more local and international visitors to one of Taiwan's premier tourist attractions.

Among the attractions are Saturday performances, launched in November, that feature drummers, bands, dancers and jazz musicians, and Ho said that those who visit the museum on those days between 5 p.m. and 8: 30 p.m. will also enjoy free entry to the museum.
According to the official, the Saturday programs will continue for the next two years.

Prices for refreshments are also being reduced by 20 percent for an indefinite period, while discounts of 40 percent will be offered on selected souvenirs while supplies last. In addition, a 10 percent discount on other items will be offered until the end of December, Ho said.
American visitor Charles Shasky said he finds the idea "wonderful," adding that "it will help attract foreign visitors."
Meanwhile, Ho said, the museum has also crafted a variety of different itineraries to suit the particular needs of young people, couples and families.

For example, she said, young people should visit on Saturday evening to enjoy a dessert and performance all for less than NT$100 (US$3) , while couples should walk the valentine trail and enjoy a five-star Christmas dinner near the museum complex.
Families can book a guided tour specifically catering to children and a picnic by a nearby lake.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to set up special panel to review impact of direct links

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will form a special task force to review possible adverse impacts on Taiwan of the launch of direct transport and postal links across the Taiwan Strait, a DPP legislator said Monday.
In a further thaw of once stalled relations, Taiwan and China launched daily direct passenger and cargo flights and direct shipping and postal links Monday.

Arguing that the new links underscore how quickly ties between Taipei and Beijing have warmed under "pro-China" President Ma Ying-jeou, DPP legislative whip Ker Chien-ming accused the Kuomintang administration of failing to consider the possibly negative impact the new opening will have on Taiwan's sovereignty, national security and economic well-being.
According to Ker, the new DPP panel will hold a daily news conference to brief the public on the impact of the new direct cross-strait links, also known as "big three links."
Meanwhile, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said the party headquarters and the DPP legislative caucus will work together to evaluate the links' potentially adverse effects on Taiwan.
Claiming that the KMT administration has only publicized the positive side of the new links, Cheng said the DPP will inform the public of the links' social costs.

Cheng quoted DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen as having said at a party meeting held earlier in the day that Taiwan could soon become China's economic vassal because the KMT administration has failed to come up with well-devised complementary measures before launching the new direct transport links.

For instance, Cheng said the KMT administration has never evaluated how the "big three links" may affect Taiwan socially and culturally, such as whether direct air links will accelerate an exodus of Taiwanese talent to China or help attract Taiwanese talent to return home.
Cheng said the DPP will give priority to defending Taiwan's homegrown industries, job opportunities and competitive edges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese charters more crowded than Chinese counterparts

TEXT.P: Taiwanese carriers had an average passenger load factor of over 76 percent on the first day of daily nonstop charter flights between Taiwan and China, higher than the 67 percent recorded by Chinese airlines, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) reported Monday.

According to statistics compiled by the CAA, flights operated by three Taiwanese carriers filled 3,753 of the 4,899 seats available from Taiwan to four Chinese destinations, while six Chinese carriers flew 1,829 passengers, or 67 percent of the combined 2,722-seat capacity, from China to Taiwan.

The three Taiwanese carriers -- China Airlines, EVA Airways and TransAsia Airways -- operated 16 two-way charter flights from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Taipei Songshan Airport to Shanghai, Hangzhou, Shenzhen and Guangzhou in China.
Six Chinese carriers flew a total of 16 charter flights from Shanghai, Tianjin, Hangzhou, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen to Taoyuan and Taipei in northern Taiwan.

Monday's charters were the first nonstop daily flights between Taiwan and China since 1949, when the People's Republic of China was founded and the Kuomintang set up a separate government on the island.
The charters were made possible by a set of accords signed by Taipei and Beijing in early November, which also paved the way for the launching of direct postal and shipping links on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Keelung expects renewed prosperity from direct shipping with China

TEXT.P: The northern Taiwan port city of Keelung is banking on the newly opened direct shipping links with 60 ports in China for renewed prosperity, experts in the container shipping business said Monday.

Yang Chi-li, president of the Keelung Shipping Agencies Association, said the direct shipping links will be a shot in the arm for the seaport because they not only shorten shipping times but also cut operational costs, creating the prospect for a renewed container shipping boom in the city.
Yang pointed out that container shipping is the lifeline of the port and the city.
Keelung was the world's seventh busiest container port in 1984, but has since fallen, to 32nd in 2002 and to 45th in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taxi fleet drivers to serve as anti-smoking ambassadors

TEXT.P: Fifty drivers of the Taiwan Taxi Co. who each smoked 20 to 30 years before kicking the habit will serve as ambassadors to promote non-smoking in the coming two months, the taxi company announced Monday.
These taxi drivers joined a program to quit smoking offered by Taiwan Adventist Hospital in Taipei in August 2007 and successfully got rid of their addiction to nicotine.
Liao Chia-ching, who smoked at least 20 cigarettes a day for 37 years, recounted that he was not sure whether he could succeed when he first joined the program on Aug. 8 last year.
"I am proud that, with the interim use of nicotine patches, I made it," Liao said.

According to Wu Hsien-lin, a physician in the hospital's Department of Thoracic Medicine, the taxi drivers in last year's program had an 80 percent success rate in quitting smoking, the highest ever achieved by the hospital.
Wu said the taxi drivers will share their experience with passengers, providing free brochures and compact discs about the hazards of smoking, and invite smokers to join anti-smoking programs.
The taxi drivers' "say goodbye to nicotine" campaign is also intended to call public attention to Taiwan's newly amended Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act, which will take effect on Jan. 11, 2009.
Under the act, smoking is banned in indoor public areas, including KTV lounges, bowling alleys, cybercafes, and passenger waiting rooms, as well as in indoor working areas with over three people.
Smoking is also prohibited in outdoor public areas, including train station platforms, gymnasiums, swimming pools, college campuses, and entertainment areas.
Those who violate the law can be fined between NT$2,000 and NT$10,000 (US$605).

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County inaugurates 'English village' in elementary school

TEXT.P: Changhua County has inaugurated its first "English village, " aiming to help students improve their ability to communicate in English in a vivid learning environment, Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan said Monday.

The language learning village at the central county's Minsheng Elementary School simulates a high speed rail station, with a panel showing arriving and departing train schedules, ticket booths, and even mock trains deployed in three classrooms.
Cho was present at the opening of the village held earlier in the day and led a group of county government officials in practicing English with students who were acting as station staffers.
Students at the village can learn how to deal with tasks related to this scenario such as buying tickets and also learn how to describe local cultures in English, Cho said.
Every student who steps into the village environment is required to communicate with others in English.

The county plans to create three other English villages, with each simulating a different scenario, including a hypermarket at Hsinkang Elementary School, a fast food restaurant at Hsinmin Elementary School, and an international airport at Erlin Elementary School, Cho said.
The four villages will be utilized by all junior high and elementary school students in the county, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: History made as new cross-strait flight route inaugurated

TEXT.P: Flight controllers in Taipei and Shanghai simultaneously announced the inauguration of a new air route between the two cities at 8: 06 a.m. Monday, ushering in a new era in air traffic across the Taiwan Strait.

Both Taipei Area Control Center Director Chi Liang and his Shanghai counterpart, Qian Haisheng, expressed their resolve at the inaugural ceremony to make every possible effort to ensure cross-strait flight safety.

Almost at the same time, a China Eastern Airlines aircraft took off from Shanghai en route to Taoyuan in northern Taiwan and a few minutes later, a TransAsia Airways plane set off on a flight from Taipei to Shanghai.

Both planes used the flight numbers of the new direct flight route. Radar data at the Taipei Area Control Center showed that both aircraft reached the new waypoint "SULEM" at 8:47 a.m., where flight controllers from the two sides handed off air traffic control responsibilities to their counterparts.

Despite a 3,000-foot difference in altitude between the two flights, it marked the first time in six decades that flight controllers from Taiwan and China had engaged in direct dialogue above the center line of the Taiwan Strait.
Flight controllers exchanged greetings and looked forward to cooperating with each other.

When direct weekend cross-strait charter flight services opened in July, aircraft had to pass through the Hong Kong and Jeju Island flight information regions, and air traffic controllers on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait did not come in direct contact with each other.
With the charter flights expanded to daily service, the flight route on all northbound flights to various Chinese destinations, such as Shanghai, Hengzhou, Beijing and Dalian, was straightened.
Carriers will now fly a route that requires the transfer of air traffic control at waypoint "SULEM."

The waypoint "SULEM, " located at the intersection of Taiwan and China's flight information regions (FIRs) , acquired its name last month in an agreement between Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration and its Chinese counterpart, the Civil Aviation Administration of China.

From now on, a China-bound plane, after taking off from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, will first fly northward along the B576 international flight route and turn in a northwest direction after reaching the "BERBA" waypoint sitting on the intersection of Taiwan and Japan's FIRs.

After reaching the waypoint "OLIVE" in Taiwan's FIR, the flights will turn westward and Taiwan's flight controllers will hand off air traffic control responsibilities to their Chinese counterparts when the flight reaches "SULEM."
On the other hand, Taiwan-bound flights from China will also see transfer of air traffic control responsibilities at the waypoint "SULEM, "a CAA official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: National fund will leave stock market after Dec. 17: official

TEXT.P: A national fund will not intervene in the stock market after its authorization expires Dec. 17, an official of the fund's steering committee said Monday.
William Tseng, secretary-general of the National Stabilization Fund Steering Committee, made the remarks after a committee meeting.
Tseng said committee members believed the stock market has begun to stabilize with increased volume and buying by foreign institutional investors, prompting them to quit the market.
The members indicated, however, that they will continue to monitor the situation and would meet again should any emergencies take place.
The fund was activated Sept. 18 to help prop up the stock market for one month, and its authority to intervene has since been extended twice. The latest extension expires Dec. 17.
Taiwan's main index has shed about a quarter of its value since mid-September, reflecting a global sell-off after the collapse of investment bank Lehman Brothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum puts up Christmas decor, offers discounts

TEXT.P: Christmas decorations have been put up at the renowned National Palace Museum (NPM) in suburban Taipei this year for the first time in its history, along with performances, offers of discounts and even free entry, museum officials said Monday.

Heather C.H. Ho, managing director of the NPM Museum Shop and Restaurant, said at a press conference that the museum hopes to promote the Christmas spirit of "sharing" its rich collection with visitors, as well as to attract more local and international visitors to one of Taiwan's premier tourist attractions.

Among the attractions are Saturday performances, launched in November, that feature drummers, bands, dancers and jazz musicians, and Ho said that those who visit the museum on those days between 5 p.m. and 8: 30 p.m. will also enjoy free entry to the museum.
According to the official, the Saturday programs will continue for the next two years.

Prices for refreshments are also being reduced by 20 percent for an indefinite period, while discounts of 40 percent will be offered on selected souvenirs while supplies last. In addition, a 10 percent discount on other items will be offered until the end of December, Ho said.
American visitor Charles Shasky said he finds the idea "wonderful," adding that "it will help attract foreign visitors."
Meanwhile, Ho said, the museum has also crafted a variety of different itineraries to suit the particular needs of young people, couples and families.

For example, she said, young people should visit on Saturday evening to enjoy a dessert and performance all for less than NT$100 (US$3) , while couples should walk the valentine trail and enjoy a five-star Christmas dinner near the museum complex.
Families can book a guided tour specifically catering to children and a picnic by a nearby lake.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to set up special panel to review impact of direct links

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will form a special task force to review possible adverse impacts on Taiwan of the launch of direct transport and postal links across the Taiwan Strait, a DPP legislator said Monday.
In a further thaw of once stalled relations, Taiwan and China launched daily direct passenger and cargo flights and direct shipping and postal links Monday.

Arguing that the new links underscore how quickly ties between Taipei and Beijing have warmed under "pro-China" President Ma Ying-jeou, DPP legislative whip Ker Chien-ming accused the Kuomintang administration of failing to consider the possibly negative impact the new opening will have on Taiwan's sovereignty, national security and economic well-being.
According to Ker, the new DPP panel will hold a daily news conference to brief the public on the impact of the new direct cross-strait links, also known as "big three links."
Meanwhile, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said the party headquarters and the DPP legislative caucus will work together to evaluate the links' potentially adverse effects on Taiwan.
Claiming that the KMT administration has only publicized the positive side of the new links, Cheng said the DPP will inform the public of the links' social costs.

Cheng quoted DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen as having said at a party meeting held earlier in the day that Taiwan could soon become China's economic vassal because the KMT administration has failed to come up with well-devised complementary measures before launching the new direct transport links.

For instance, Cheng said the KMT administration has never evaluated how the "big three links" may affect Taiwan socially and culturally, such as whether direct air links will accelerate an exodus of Taiwanese talent to China or help attract Taiwanese talent to return home.
Cheng said the DPP will give priority to defending Taiwan's homegrown industries, job opportunities and competitive edges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese charters more crowded than Chinese counterparts

TEXT.P: Taiwanese carriers had an average passenger load factor of over 76 percent on the first day of daily nonstop charter flights between Taiwan and China, higher than the 67 percent recorded by Chinese airlines, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) reported Monday.

According to statistics compiled by the CAA, flights operated by three Taiwanese carriers filled 3,753 of the 4,899 seats available from Taiwan to four Chinese destinations, while six Chinese carriers flew 1,829 passengers, or 67 percent of the combined 2,722-seat capacity, from China to Taiwan.

The three Taiwanese carriers -- China Airlines, EVA Airways and TransAsia Airways -- operated 16 two-way charter flights from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Taipei Songshan Airport to Shanghai, Hangzhou, Shenzhen and Guangzhou in China.
Six Chinese carriers flew a total of 16 charter flights from Shanghai, Tianjin, Hangzhou, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen to Taoyuan and Taipei in northern Taiwan.

Monday's charters were the first nonstop daily flights between Taiwan and China since 1949, when the People's Republic of China was founded and the Kuomintang set up a separate government on the island.
The charters were made possible by a set of accords signed by Taipei and Beijing in early November, which also paved the way for the launching of direct postal and shipping links on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 16, or the 19th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar canlendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1773: Bostonians creep onto British ships in Boston Harbor and dump cargoes of tea overboard.
1922: Tu Tsung-ming is granted a medical doctorate at the Kyoto University, becoming the first Taiwanese to gain the doctorate during the Japanese colonial period.
1949: Chinese Communist Chairman Mao Zedong visits Soveit Union for the first time.
1962: The United States launches the "Explorer 16" satellite into orbit.
1975: Chinese Communist Central Committee Vice Chairman Kang Sheng dies in Beijing at the age of 77.
1978: The United States and mainland China announce that they will establish diplomatic relations from Jan. 1, 1979.
1988: The United States and the Palestinian Liberation Organization hold a meeting in Tunis, Tunisia, for the first time.
1991: Taiwan Provincial Government Chairman Lien Chan presides over a ceremony to inaugurate the South-Link Line of Taiwan's railway system.
1991: The Association for Ralations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), mainland Chinese quasi-official organization responsible for talks with Taiwan on cross- strait issues, is formed in Beijing.
1996: Former South Korean Presidents Chuan Doo Huan and Roo Tae Woo are sentenced life imprisonment and 17-year jail term, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Inbound travelers rise upon launch of daily cross-strait charters

TEXT.P: The number of inbound travelers to Taiwan increased significantly with the launch of daily passenger charter flights between Taiwan and China, reflecting the greater convenience of the new service, the National Immigration Agency (NIA) said Tuesday.

On the first day of the charter service Monday, a total of 30,372 travelers entered the country through Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, representing a rise of 4,293 from the same day last week when there were 26,079 travelers, NIA statistics showed.
The number of arrivals and departures totaled 60,591, which was similar to the average daily traffic, the NIA said.
There were a total of 18 flights between Taoyuan and China's Shanghai, Beijing, Tianjin, Hangzhou, Guangzhou and Shenzhen on the first day of the service.
The daily charter services are an expansion of the weekend charter passenger services that have been operating between Friday and Monday since July.

During the first week of the daily passenger services, five Taiwanese carriers and seven Chinese carriers operating the services will together provide a total of 101 flights, according to the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

The routes to be flown during this period will serve 13 Chinese destinations -- Beijing, Shanghai, Nanjing, Guangzhou, Xiamen, Hangzhou, Shenzhen, Tianjin, Chongqing, Chengdu, Fuzhou, Haikou and Dalian.
The four Taiwanese destinations served will be Taoyuan, Taipei, Kaohsiung and Taichung.
Prior to the launch of nonstop charters in July, travelers between Taiwan and China were required to transit in a third country or territory, usually Hong Kong.

The new nonstop flights between Taipei and Shanghai launched Monday take less than 90 minutes, a major time savings compared to the nearly six hours the same trip takes when transiting through Hong Kong.
