TEXT.P: Christmas decorations have been put up at the renowned National Palace Museum (NPM) in suburban Taipei this year for the first time in its history, along with performances, offers of discounts and even free entry, museum officials said Monday.

Heather C.H. Ho, managing director of the NPM Museum Shop and Restaurant, said at a press conference that the museum hopes to promote the Christmas spirit of "sharing" its rich collection with visitors, as well as to attract more local and international visitors to one of Taiwan's premier tourist attractions.

Among the attractions are Saturday performances, launched in November, that feature drummers, bands, dancers and jazz musicians, and Ho said that those who visit the museum on those days between 5 p.m. and 8: 30 p.m. will also enjoy free entry to the museum.
According to the official, the Saturday programs will continue for the next two years.

Prices for refreshments are also being reduced by 20 percent for an indefinite period, while discounts of 40 percent will be offered on selected souvenirs while supplies last. In addition, a 10 percent discount on other items will be offered until the end of December, Ho said.
American visitor Charles Shasky said he finds the idea "wonderful," adding that "it will help attract foreign visitors."
Meanwhile, Ho said, the museum has also crafted a variety of different itineraries to suit the particular needs of young people, couples and families.

For example, she said, young people should visit on Saturday evening to enjoy a dessert and performance all for less than NT$100 (US$3) , while couples should walk the valentine trail and enjoy a five-star Christmas dinner near the museum complex.
Families can book a guided tour specifically catering to children and a picnic by a nearby lake.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT welcomes direct links between Taiwan and China

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), the United States' de facto embassy, has welcomed the establishment of direct air, shipping and postal links between Taiwan and China and dismissed concerns such links would draw Taiwan too close to its cross-Taiwan Strait rival.

By facilitating the enhancement of cross strait contact, the direct links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will help regional peace, stability and prosperity, said AIT spokesman Thomas Mark Hodges Tuesday in welcoming the development.

Taiwan and China on Monday launched daily nonstop passenger charter flights, direct cargo flights and direct shipping links, the first time such links have existed since the People's Republic of China was established in 1949.
Asked if the U.S. was concerned the links would draw Taiwan too close to China, Hodges said there was no reason for worry.

"The U.S. government has long called on Taiwan and the People's Republic of China (PRC) to find means to engage in dialogue in order to reduce tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait,Hodges said.
We welcome the positive development. There is no need for the U.S. government to worry about Taiwan and mainland China getting too close.

Some have speculated that the U.S., which sees Taiwan as a strategic partner in limiting China's expansion and influence in the region, is concerned that President Ma Ying-jeou's conciliatory policies toward Beijing are not in its best interests.
The U.S. government has repeatedly denied the speculation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. corrects "error" misrepresenting legislator's nationality

TEXT.P: The United States has corrected an "error" it made in identifying a Kuomintang (KMT) legislator as an American citizen, after looking further into whether two KMT lawmakers have dual nationalities, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.
In an initial report submitted to the ministry on Dec. 5, the U.S. government apparently said KMT Legislator Kung Wen-chi was an American citizen.
It recently discovered, however, that it had confused Kung, a male, with a woman in its database who had the same English name spelling and birth date as the legislator.

The Foreign Ministry received the correction from the American Institute in Taiwan's Washington office Tuesday morning, according to Harry H.J. Tseng, the deputy director of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs.

Meanwhile, Tseng said the investigation into its main target, KMT Legislator Lee Ching-an, is ongoing and that his ministry expects to receive a "clearer answer" to its inquiry over whether she holds U.S. citizenship.

Lee has been hounded by charges that she has dual nationality -- which would be illegal and force her to abandon the seat she has held since being elected in 1998 -- since a local magazine alleged in June that she held a valid U.S. passport.

The ministry received the U.S. government's initial report on the citizenship status of Taiwan's legislators on Dec. 5, but decided to seek further assistance from the U.S. on Dec. 10 to clarify some key points in the report that the ministry found "unclear.
Speculation quickly arose that the initial U.S. report cited two legislators who had dual citizenship, with Kung being one of the names most often mentioned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices flat on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices finished slightly higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 3.17 points to close at 4,616.89.

Finishing higher for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,570.52 and fluctuated between 4,616.89 and 4,532.41. A total of 3.52 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$58.41 billion (US$1.76 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1.41 percent. Foodstuff issues were up 1.05 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 0.37 percent, and cement stocks increased 0.12 percent.

The other four major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 3 percent. Plastics and chemicals shares dropped 1.33 percent, paper and pulp issues decreased 0.96 percent, and construction issues shed 0.18 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 924 to 479, with 301 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$2.2 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County to upgrade declining fishing port

TEXT.P: The Tainan county government in southern Taiwan plans to upgrade a declining fishing port by expanding the yacht manufacturing industry and creating recreational business at the port, a local official said Tuesday.

Chen Hsien-ming, deputy director-general of the county's Department of Urban and Rural Development, said the county government hopes to attract more investment by yacht manufacturers in the county's Jiangjun Fishing Port.

There is already a two-hectare yacht manufacturing plant in operation at the port, and the county government has allocated another 3.6 hectares of land for possible investments by other yacht making companies, Chen said.

The 100-hectare port in the county's Jiangjun township was established in 2002 to dock more than 500 fishing vessels, but because of stiff competition from other fishing ports throughout the county, the number of fishing vessels that berth there and profits from fishing have dropped in past years, Chen said.

The local government hopes that expansion of the yacht manufacturing business at the port will attract yacht lovers and allow for better utilization of the land, which in turn will help to boost the economy, Chen said.

Since 2006, the port has been used as a recreational fish market on holidays, but as business has been below par, the county government now has to try to increase the fishing business and attract more visitors to the port, Chen said.
The expansion plan for the port also involves developing a nearby beach, he added.

The county government plans to build a resort on a 5.4 hectare tract of land near the beach and upgrade the water sports facilities there to draw more tourists, Chen said, adding that the county government is still awaiting central government approval of the resort project.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, falling NT$0.169 to close at NT$33.030.
A total of US$1.49 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.199 and dipped to NT$33.000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier to take responsibility if consumption voucher program fails

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan pledged Tuesday to assume political responsibility if the consumption voucher program does not stimulate at least half of the level of economic growth anticipated by the government.
Liu made the pledge while responding to questions from legislators after delivering a report to the lawmaking body on a special budget plan introduced by the Cabinet for the voucher program.
The Cabinet has estimated that the program will help increase the country's gross domestic product by 0.64 percentage points if all the vouchers are used.

Liu said, however, that the policy will be considered a failure if the program's contribution to overall growth lags below 0.32 percentage points, in which case the Cabinet will assume political responsibility.
Despite the pledge, the premier cautioned that it was "unreasonable" to always demand a certain official to step down for failing to achieve a single policy.

Liu said he believes the program will produce better results in Taiwan than in Japan, given that local businesses have put forth various creative promotional ideas targeting potential voucher holders even before the vouchers have been issued.
He said the vouchers will be designed with various counterfeit-proof features and that those who use fake vouchers knowingly will face legal liability.
The Cabinet is set to distribute the vouchers to the public Jan. 18 to stimulate consumption.
Each Taiwanese citizen with a valid household registration in Taiwan will be entitled to receive NT$3,600 in vouchers that will have to be exchanged for goods by Sept. 30, 2009.
Foreign or Chinese spouses of local citizens who hold legal resident status will also be eligible to receive the vouchers.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF will seek tax relief for Taiwanese businessmen in China

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Deputy Chairman Kao Koong-lian said Tuesday that the foundation will ask China to consider giving Taiwanese businessmen there tax relief, as many of them are facing financial difficulties due to the global economic downturn.
Kao said he hopes that the government in mainland China will consider decreasing the investors' burden by lowering the tax levy on them.
"The economy of the entire world is in recession, " said Kao."There are different impacts on each and every nation. However, mainland China is not as seriously affected as other nations."
Kao said that while he believes Taiwanese businessmen should grasp the opportunity to invest in mainland China, they are also facing difficulties.

"The implementation of the Labor Contract Law in mainland China had greatly increased the operation cost of Taiwan businesses in mainland China," said Kao, referring to the new law which raises the cost of labor by requiring employers give workers contracts and insurance.

The Labor Contract Law came into effect on Jan. 1, 2008, and stipulates that employment contracts must be put in writing within one month of employment, employers must fully inform workers of the nature of the job, their working conditions and compensation. It also limits the ability of employers to use temporary laborers.

Kao also noted that China's land use law in cities and towns is also a heavy burden on Taiwan businessmen and that the SEF hopes that the mainland Chinese government will consider allowing Taiwan businessmen to defer this tax payment.

"The SEF cares about the operation of the Taiwan businessmen in mainland China, " said Kao."We use all possible means to understand the situation of the Taiwan businessmen who are operating businesses in mainland China."
He said he will visit Taiwanese business people in Xiamen on Dec. 20 and will attend an annual celebration of the Taiwanese business association there.
SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung will also pay visits to Taiwan business leaders in Guangdong Province and Jiangsu Province from Jan. 7V11, Kao said.
"Both Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and I will use our opportunities of visits to Taiwan businessmen to find out their needs and to help them in any which way we can," Kao said.
On the issue of the two mainland Chinese giant pandas coming to Taiwan, Kao noted that the most likely date for the pandas to arrive is Dec. 23.

"We have obtained the export permit documents from mainland Chinese authorities," said Kao. "Now, only the technical details need to be worked out. These include the type of aircraft to transport the two giant pandas and the accompanying personnel from mainland China."
Kao pointed out that the Taipei City government had also sent officials to accompany the two giant pandas.
"Everything is ready and waiting, " stressed Kao. "We expect the pandas to be able to meet the public before the Lunar New Year holiday," Kao said.

The pandas were officially offered to Taiwan by China as a token of goodwill during a visit to Taipei last month by China's top negotiator on Taiwan, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait ( ARATS) President Chen Yunlin.

According to an agreement signed during the visit by Chen and his Taiwanese counterpart Chiang, Taiwan will give Beijing a pair of Formosan sika deer and a pair of Formosan serow, a goat-like mammal, in return for the pandas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Direct links with China unrelated to unification: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday the recent opening of direct transport and postal links between Taiwan and China symbolizes the pursuit of peace by the two sides, and has nothing to do with the issue of unification versus independence.
According to Ma, avoiding the use of non-peaceful means to resolve conflicts is a global trend, and the opening of the links Monday was consistent with such a trend.

The greatest significance of the links lies in the narrowing of the distance across the Taiwan Strait, which enables the two sides to put themselves in each other's shoes, instead of sticking to their own positions, Ma said.
This was demonstrated in the recent establishment of air, shipping and postal agreements between the two sides, which involved a great deal of give-and-take by either side, he said.

The president said although the opening of cross-strait links represents the mainstream opinion in Taiwan, the government will respect other non-mainstream opinions and improve any flaws in implementing the measures.
Ma made the remarks during an interview with Hakka Television Service, which focused on the 20th anniversary of a movement by the Hakka community to fight for its right to use its mother tongue.
Ma said the movement was very meaningful because it was an action by the Hakka people to uphold their rights and cultural heritage and led Taiwan toward a multi-cultural society.
On the plan to enact a basic Hakka law, Ma said he believes the law would help enhance ethnic assimilation but he does not think it should set a fixed quota for Hakka politicians in elected bodies.

He said his campaign promise to set up a national Hakka radio station is temporarily unattainable due to problems involving radio channel distribution, but that the Council for Hakka Affairs will continue to work on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fruit growers in southern Taiwan prefer mini links

TEXT.P: Balking at an assumption that the direct air and shipping links between Taiwan and China would be a boon to Taiwan's farmers, some fruit growers in southern Taiwan said they still prefer the mini links over the direct links.

Huang Cheng-ching, chief delegate of Yuching township's farmers association in southern Taiwan's Tainan County, said the mini links still serve their best interest in transporting farm produce to China, despite the long-expected launch of direct daily charter flights and direct shipping and postal deliveries across the Taiwan Strait Monday.

The mini links refer to the shipping links set up between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and the ports of Xiamen and Mawei in China's Fujian Province since January 2001. They were initiated to offset the lack of such connections between Taiwan proper and China.

Currently, most Tainan-grown fruits are transported to Xiamen in Fujian Province through the existing Kinmen-Xiamen mini links, as it is the most economical way in terms of both travel time and shipping cost, Huang said.

According to Huang, Yuching exports some 700 metric tons of fruit to Xiamen every year. Each container costs around NT$60,000 (US$1,820) per each Kaohsiung-Xiamen trip via Kinmen, while the travel time is about a day and a half, he explained.

Huang, however, pointed out that more expensive big containers would conduct the direct cross-strait shipping service launched Monday, but at a lower frequency because big ships would need an average of four days to become fully loaded.
Agricultural officials of southeastern Taiwan's Taitung County also said that local exporters will still use the Kinmen-Xiamen mini links in a bid to deliver their custard apples in time to China.
A trip from Taitung to Xiamen through Kinmen takes around three days and its customs clearance process is relatively simple, they noted.

Taitung agricultural authorities had announced that they would transport some 300 metric tons of custard apples to China on Dec. 18, using the newly established direct cross-strait shipping links. Taitung sold 160 metric tons of the fruit to China last year.

Although a trip via the direct shipping links connecting Kaohsiung to the Chinese side takes only two days, Taitung agricultural officials said, local exporters decided to opt for the Kinmen-Xiamen mini links out of concern over some technical obstacles, such as a more complex customs clearance at the Kaohsiung Port.

Prior to launching the direct shipping links, President Ma Ying-jeou had said that the links could boost Taiwanese fruit exports to China by reducing travel time and costs, enabling fresh fruits and other agricultural products to arrive in China in a timely manner and prolonging their shelf live.

DOC.HEADLINE: TransAsia launches direct Kaohsiung-Hangzhou charter flights

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung on Tuesday celebrated the launch of the maiden daily charter flight destined to Hangzhou in southeastern China, with officials hailing the new route and hoping it will spur more passenger arrivals in the southern city.
The Kaohsiung-Hangzhou flight, operated by Taipei-based TransAsia Airways, took off from Kaohsiung International Airport at 8 a.m., with 150 passengers on board the Airbus A-320 aircraft.

The plane was scheduled to arrive in Hangzhou after a two-hour flight. It was then to return to Kaohsiung at around 1 p.m. the same day, carrying 65 passengers, including 45 Chinese nationals, according to the carrier.

A ceremony was held at Gate 23 to celebrate the new flight, with Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, Kaohsiung Association of Travel Agents Chairman Lin Shang-chih, TransAsia Chairman Chen Che-hsiung, and Kaohsiung International Airport Director Chao Jen-kang in attendance.
The mayor said she was happy to see the launch of daily direct cross-strait charter flights -- an outgrowth of the weekend charter services between Taiwan and China that had been offered since July.

She noted, however, that fewer passengers were arriving in Taiwan from China than traveling to the mainland, an indication that the number of Chinese visitors was not as high as had been expected when Taiwan opened its doors wider to tourists from China in July.

Chen Chu expressed the hope that Chinese authorities will lift all restrictions on visits by Chinese citizens to Taiwan, including easing the ban on individual visits and abolishing the rule that citizens from only 13 of China's 31 provinces can travel to Taiwan.

Chen urged China to allow its people greater freedom to see the island, and voiced the expectation that the daily nonstop charter flights launched from her city will attract more Chinese visitors and trade opportunities.
Besides TransAsia, other two Taiwanese carriers, UNI Airways and China Airlines (CAL) , will also offer daily direct charter flight services from Kaohsiung to destinations in China.
UNI Airways will fly between Kaohsiung and Shenzhen beginning Dec. 19 while CAL will fly to Shanghai from Dec. 20. The flights will all take off from Kaohsiung International Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for December falling 22 points to end at 4,585, with 78,144 contracts traded.
TAIEX Index futures for January futures declined 18 points to end at 4,568, with 17,684 contracts traded, while March futures fell 33 points to close at 4,530, with 83 contract transactions.
June futures lost eight points to finish at 4,522, with 28 contract transactions, while September futures were down 23 points to close at 4,316, with 19 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,607 for December, 4,586 for January, 4,563 for March, 4,530 for June and 4,339 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index on Tuesday gained 3.17 points to finish at 4,616.89, on turnover of NT$58.41 billion (US$1.76 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also mixed.
December TE futures declined 0.5 points to close at 175.3, with 4,523 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 0.35 points to finish at 175.25, with 1,421 contracts traded.

March TE futures were up 0.1 points to end at 171.1, with two contract transactions, while September TE futures declined 11.55 points to end at 156.6, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.
December TF futures were up 13.6 points to close at 588.8, with 3,555 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures moved up 15.2 points to close at 590, with 1,641 contracts traded.

March TF futures gained 17.6 points to end at 580, with two contract transactions, while September TF futures declined 11 points to end at 534.6, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global immigration forum to open in Taipei

TEXT.P: A forum on global immigration trends will be held Thursday at National Taiwan University Hospital in Taipei City in recognition of immigrants in Taiwan, according to an official of the National Immigration Agency (NIA) Monday.
The one-day Trend of Global Immigration Forum, to be sponsored by the NIA under the Ministry of the Interior, is being held to mark International Migrants' Day, the official said.

The United Nations in 2000 designated Dec. 18 as International Migrants' Day in recognition of the significant contribution by migrants to the whole world. In 2000, the number of migrant people throughout the world was registered at nearly 200 million. According to recent government figures, the number in Taiwan is around 900,000.
Following the forum, a one-day International Immigrant Exhibition will be held Saturday at Huashan Cultural Park in Taipei City, NIA Deputy Director-General Hsieh Li-kung said.
The exhibition will feature services for migrants, multicultural festivities, and various talent shows.
Also on Saturday, two-day achievement shows featuring immigrants in Taiwan will open at central Taiwan's Taichung train station and at the Central Park station on the Kaohsiung MRT's Red Line.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to cut bigeye tuna catch by 10 percent next year

TEXT.P: Taiwan's fishing quota for bigeye tuna in the Pacific Ocean will be cut by 10 percent next year after an Pacific Ocean tuna commission called on 25 of its members to slash bigeye tuna catches by 30 percent over the next three years, Taiwan's Fisheries Agency announced Tuesday.

The new quota, proposed by the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission's (WCPFC's) science sub-commission in an effort to maintain the sustainability of the threatened species, was approved at the WCPFC's annual meeting in South Korea's Busan Dec. 8-12, according to the agency.
The sub-commission proposed a similar measure in 2006, at the time calling for a 25 percent reduction in catches, but it was rejected by WCPFC members.
Under the new measure, members of the WCPFC, including Taiwan and Japan, would work to reduce their catches of bigeye tuna by 30 percent between 2009 and 2011.
To comply with the agreement, Taiwan will lower its 2009 fishing quota to 14,269 tons from 15,854 tons this year, said Tsay Tzu-yaw, deputy director-general of the Fisheries Agency.
The fishing quotas for 2010 and 2011 will be decided after the effectiveness of the implementation of the lower quota has been evaluated, he added.
Given that Taiwan currently has 50 deep sea fishing vessels, each fishing vessel will have to cut its catch of bigeye tuna by 20-30 tons in 2009 for Taiwan to meet the goal, Tsay estimated.
At present, almost all bigeye tuna caught by Taiwan's fishing boats are exported to Japan at a price of approximately 700-900 Japanese yen per kilogram, Tsay said.
One of the ways the commission will monitor the agreement is through a new satellite-linked vessel monitoring system (VMS).

Under the measure, all fishing vessels belonging to its members are being asked to install the system by April 2009 so that the WCPFC will be able to monitor vessels, including whether they intrude into the territorial waters of other countries, according to Tsay.

He added that a Regional Observer Program under the auspices of the WCPFC is also in place. By 2012, 5 percent of the fishing vessels will need to be manned by observers to supervise their fishing operations in waters under the jurisdiction of the WCPFC, Tsay said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 Deaflympics to draw 3,965 athletes from 81 countries

TEXT.P: A total of 3,965 athletes from 81 countries will compete in the 21st Summer Deaflympics to be hosted by Taipei City, a Taipei Organizing Committee executive said Tuesday.

According to Lin Kuo-juei, chief executive officer of the committee, the event will take place at different venues in Taipei Sept. 5-15 next year, covering 20 events, with judo, karate and taekwondo included.
Taiwan will enter 164 deaf athletes -- 107 men and 57 women -- to vie for medals in 16 disciplines, Lin said.

In order to provide better reception and translation services for the athletes and officials who will be arriving from around the world, the committee has recruited 2,801 volunteer staffers who are being trained in international sign language at Taipei Municipal University of Education and National Taipei University of Education.

According to Lu Tzu-yi, the committee's international affairs section chief, the volunteers are also being coached in international sports event etiquette, as well as the rules and regulations of the various sports involved.

The committee will recruit another 50 foreign volunteer staffers who speak English and who can communicate in sign language, and will also convene a group of higher-level sign language translators for special translation needs, Lu said.

Another committee executive noted that as Deaflympians cannot be guided by starter's guns, bullhorn commands or whistles, referees or umpires' instructions will be delivered via light signals, gestures and flags.
The Deaflympics was sanctioned by the International Olympic Committee and has been organized by the International Committee of Sports for the Deaf since 1924.

The event is held every four years, and athletes who qualify for the games have to have moderate hearing loss of at least 55 decibels in their better ear. Hearing aids or cochlear implants are not allowed to be used in competition.
The last Deaflympics was held in Melbourne in 2005, and the next one will be held in Athens in 2013.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yacht builders eye Chinese market with expanded bilateral links

TEXT.P: With Taiwan recently opening its doors wider to cross-Taiwan Strait air and marine transport, local yacht builders are optimistic about their business development, expecting a surge in growth if the existing restrictions on yacht traffic between Taiwan and China are relaxed.

The country's yacht industry began prospering in the 1980s, with an annual output of around 2,000 boats. This output, seen as large in those days, cannot compare, however, with the current scale, Taiwan Yacht Industry Association Chief Executive Director Chang Hsueh-chiao said Tuesday.

Over the years, Chang noted, the sector, which has spared no efforts to stay abreast of technological progress, has won many U.S. and European orders thanks to its customer-oriented services. Annual exports have reached NT$20 billion (US$606.89 million), Chang said, attributing the achievement to the low cost and high quality of Taiwan-built yachts.

This year, Taiwan's yacht-building industry has been affected by the global recession, along with many other manufacturing sectors in the country, and orders stopped coming in the fourth quarter of the year, Chang said.
While most local builders are still holding orders for next year, it will be difficult for them to remain in business after 2009 if the recession continues, he predicted.
However, with the opening of direct transport links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, some local yacht builders are eyeing the emerging market in China, Chang said.

Association Chairman Chen Chao-nan said yachts are safer than the fishing boats that local people usually charter for recreational sea trips and that Taiwanese builders are very capable in their construction abilities.
So long as the government further opens its doors to cross-strait yacht services, the demand for Taiwan-built yachts will increase, Chen said.
The long-expected daily cross-strait charter flight services, along with direct marine transport services, began a day earlier, opening a new chapter in the history of cross-strait exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP: Government to help establish a creative cultural industry

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Tuesday that the government will help establish a creative cultural industry in Taiwan.

By creative cultural industry, Siew means an industry which focuses on turning creative ideas such as on arts, fashion, design, into products or services that companies can sell and Taiwan can export to other countries.

"It's good to invest in the creative cultural industry when the economy is bad", said Siew. "We have to combine bright and creative minds with money. ... It was what we did when we built the Hsinchu Science Park 30 years ago."
He was referring to the then government's investment in building Taiwan's high- technology sector, which has contributed to rapid economic growth for the island.
Unlike the technology industry, Siew said, creating a creative cultural industry does not require huge amounts of capital.
Siew made the remarks during the 5th Annual Assembly of the Magazine Business Association of Taipei (MBAT), which took place at Huashan Cultural Park in Taipei.

Establishing a creative cultural industry and a digital contents industry is part of a six-year national development plan called "Challenges 2008", which the Executive Yuan (Cabinet) has been trying to implement.

According to the speaker of the MBAT, Wang Jung-wen, the Taiwanese magazine industry is best suited for the mission, followed by the pop music industry and the on-line games industry, which have a combined output of NT$85 billion and unlimited future potential.

"For this reason, the MBAT has been encouraging its members to actively participate in related programs, hoping to bring about a bright future for the industry by improving the business climate, upgrading the standards, and enhancing the economic strength of the Taiwanese creative cultural industry", noted Wang.
Siew said people with bright minds and ideas do not necessarily have the money that is needed to establish a new industry, and people with money do not necessarily have creative minds.
"It is vital to turn great ideas into policies and policies into action", noted the vice president.

Siew said Taiwan still has a long way to go before it can succeed in establishing a creative cultural industry, but that the government will continue to provide incentives and assistance to those who are willing to participate in the establishment of such an industry.
Founded on Dec. 18, 1996, the MBAT is the only association of its kind in Taiwan. It currently has about 300 members, with a combined strength of more than 400 magazines.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Face the law,' DPP lawmaker tells indicted former first lady

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday that the indicted members of the former first family, especially former first lady Wu Shu-jen, should "face the law, instead of telling more lies and fooling around with the feelings" of DPP members.

Legislator Chiu Yi-ying, a former staunch supporter of ex-President Chen Shui-bian and the first family, made the blunt remarks after media reports said that Chen had criticized former Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien -- a defendant in one of the corruption cases for which Chen was indicted -- for "confessing everything" regarding a corruption case to the prosecutors "after being held in custody for a couple of days."
Chiu said Yu did not deserve the indictment. "Had it not been for Wu Shu-jen's pressure, he would not have risked breaking the law."
She said Yu had complained to her that all the other defendants in the case were dividing bribe money among themselves, while he alone received nothing but a jail term.
"If they did do anything wrong, no one would believe Yu's confession anyway. The confession was important to the prosecutors because they had already obtained other evidence in the case," Chiu said.

Yu was one of 10 defendants indicted by the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office last week along with four members of the former first family -- Chen Shui-bian, his wife, son and daughter-in-law -- who are facing charges of corruption, money laundering and forgery relating to four cases.
The corruption charge against Yu had to do with a scandal involving the construction of the Nankang Exhibition Hall in Taipei in September 2003.
In the written indictment, Yu was quoted as saying that Wu had instructed him to pass the name list of a supervisory panel to contractor Kuo Chuan-ching, president of the Rich Construction Co.

Kuo, who was also indicted, has confessed that he paid Wu NT$90 million (US$2.73 million) through her special assistant Tsai Ming-che, along with NT$10 million commission to Tsai and NT$1 million each to seven members of the supervisory panel, in order to secure the NT$3.59 billion construction contract.

Yu, who was released Nov. 27 on NT$1 million bail after being held in custody for 43 days, claimed that he merely did a job for Wu and accepted no bribes. Kuo was also released on NT$1 million bail that same day.

Tsai was released on NT$3 million bail after he admitted that the bribe money was wired to a bank account owned by his sister in the United States before being transferred to a bank account of a member of the former first family.

In the indictment, the prosecutors sought the "harshest" penalty for the former president, and "heavy" penalties for the other three members of the former first family, while recommending to the court that sentences for Yu, Kuo and Tsai be commuted in consideration of the fact that they were fully cooperative during the investigation.

Also indicted were seven university professors who served on the supervisory panel, all of whom have been released on bail. The prosecutors have asked that they be given the maximum possible penalties.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S scholar urges flexibility on visits by Taiwan's top leaders

TEXT.P: An American expert on Chinese law, who is also known as former mentor of President Ma Ying-jeou, called Tuesday for China to "show more flexibility" on the matter of visits to the United States by Taiwanese presidents.

In an interview with the Central News Agency in Taipei, Professor Jerome A. Cohen, co-director of New York University's U.S.-Asia Law Institute, suggested that China stop objecting to visits to the U.S. by Taiwan's highest-level officials, such as the president, vice president and premier, in reciprocation of Ma's recent efforts to improve cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

Cohen said he invited Ma, during a meeting earlier in the day, to give a speech at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York and that he hoped that Beijing officials would consider not issuing a protest.

Cohen noted that China is gradually responding to Ma's gestures of goodwill by indicating, for example, that Taiwan's participation in the World Health Assembly (WHA) will be negotiable. The next " possible step" for China could be to "expand its appreciation" for Ma's efforts to foster better cross-strait relations, he added.

The president has shown interest in the invitation, Cohen said, adding that both of them, however, acknowledged that a U.S. visit by Ma would be difficult for the time being due to China's obstruction and the U.S.' restrictions.
Cohen is known to have been the mentor of President Ma during the latter's study at Harvard Law School in the U.S. in the early 1980s.

In issuing his invitation for Ma to visit New York, Cohen also called for the U.S. government to amend its current rule against allowing Taiwan leaders to travel to that country for public purposes, arguing that it deprives American audiences of their right to information.

As the cross-strait issue involves U.S. national security, Americans have the right to learn about the Taiwan situation in face-to-face exchanges with Taiwan's leaders as a form of freedom of speech, and this has nothing to do with formal diplomatic protocol, he contended.

Since the U.S. severed diplomatic relations with the Republic of China (R.O.C.) in 1979, R.O.C. presidents have been prohibited from conducting official visits to the U.S. but are allowed to make transit stops there en route to other destinations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of babies in Taiwan born with HIV declining

TEXT.P: The number of babies born in Taiwan with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is declining, with statistics showing that since 2007 there have been no recorded births of HIV-infected infants, the Department of Health reported (DOH) Tuesday.

According to the DOH statistics, Taiwan recorded five cases of babies born with HIV in 2005, and four in 2006. As of Nov. 30 this year, the number of children in Taiwan born with HIV stood at 27, the DOH figures showed.

The DOH in 2005 implemented a number of measures to stem mother-to-infant HIV transmission during pregnancy. The measures focused on three major areas -- disease screening, medical treatment and health care.
As a result, since 2005, 95 babies born to HIV-positive mothers have tested free of the disease, the DOH said.
The department estimates that the risk of mother-to-infant HIV transmission during pregnancy will drop from 45 percent to 2 percent if the mothers adopt preventive medical care.
HIV is transmitted to infants mainly at conception, during labor or by breast feeding. Preventive therapy during these phrases can prevent infection of babies, DOH officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung hoping to attract shopping voucher spenders with discounts

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is working on a plan to entice people to spend their NT$3,600 consumption vouchers -- to be issued by the central government to boost the retail market -- in the southern port city next month.

Liu xin-zheng, director of the city's Economic Affairs Bureau, said the city government is working with nearly 1,000 stores in 18 of the city's favorite shopping areas to issue billions of new Taiwan dollars-worth of discount coupons for consumers who decide to spend their consumption vouchers there.
Liu pointed out that the 1.5 million people in Kaohsiung, the second-largest city in Taiwan, will have NT$5.4 billion-worth of consumption vouchers to spend from Jan. 28.
He said discount coupon booklets will be distributed at department stores, airports, train stations and scenic spots frequented by tourists to encourage people to spend their vouchers in Kaohsiung.

The stores participating in the program will include all kinds of businesses, and shoppers who use their consumption vouchers in conjunction with the coupons will be able to see the value of their vouchers more than double, according to Liu.
The central government's NT$85.7 billion (US$2.6 billion) budget plan to fund the shopping voucher program is aimed at stimulating the slumping retail sector and boosting the overall economy.

The legislature adopted a bill in early December, authorizing the government to issue the NT$3,600 (US$108) in consumption vouchers to each Taiwanese citizen, foreign spouses of Taiwanese citizens and infants born before the end of March 2009.

The vouchers are expected to be distributed from Jan. 18 -- a week before the Lunar New Year holiday. They will remain valid until Sept. 30 and retailers must claim reimbursement for the vouchers by Oct. 31, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese pandas to arrive in Taiwan Dec. 23

TEXT.P: A pair of giant pandas China promised to give Taiwan in 2005 will finally arrive Dec. 23, a spokesman for EVA Airways -- which will bring the animals from China -- said Tuesday.
Nieh Kuo-wei said an EVA plane will leave for Chengdu in western China's Sichuan Province Dec. 22 and return the next day with the pandas, whose arrivals have been long-awaited in Taiwan.
The pandas will be accompanied by its two Chinese keepers, who will bring with them 600 kg of the bamboo on which the animals feed and will stay in Taiwan for two months to help take care of them.
The spokesman also said EVA Airways is offering 100 people the "privilege of traveling with the pandas" for just NT$9,900 for the round trip to Chengdu.
After arriving in Taiwan, the pandas will be put in quarantine until they are put on display at the Taipei Zoo for the first time on Lunar New Year's Eve -- Jan. 25.

Chinese President Hu Jintao presented the pandas to then-Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan in 2005 during an ice-breaking trip Lien made to Beijing, but the delivery was blocked by political bickering between Beijing and Taipei as long as Taiwan was under the rule of the now-opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
However, the political climate between the two sides has thawed since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May this year, thanks to Ma's more conciliatory approach toward China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors file appeal against ex-president's release

TEXT.P: The Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office filed an appeal Tuesday against the Taipei District Court's decision last week to release indicted former President Chen Shui-bian, contending that it is possible that he might abscond through "secret channels."

Chen was released Dec. 13 upon his own recognizance, despite a request by prosecutors to keep him in custody, after being detained for 32 days as prosecutors prepared four cases against him. After four months of investigations, they indicted him Dec. 12 on charges of embezzlement, bribe- taking and money laundering.

In the appeal presented to the Taiwan High Court, the SID prosecutors said they will soon begin to investigate several other corruption cases involving Chen and his wife, and that if he is allowed to remain free, some of the witnesses, including former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng, might not dare tell the truth.

The prosecutors also said they still need to trace NT$570 million (US$17.29 million) in bribe money and that if Chen is not detained, he could obliterate the evidence, as he tried to do before he was detained.
"With NT$570 million stashed abroad, it is hard to say there is absolutely no possibility that he will abscond," they pointed out.

The prosecutors noted that in the initial stage of their investigation, Chen had instructed his former cashier, Chen Chen-hui, former Presidential Office Director Lin Teh-hsun, Ma and other defendants to give false testimony regarding the former first family's embezzlement of the president's state affairs fund and its money laundering activities.
The presiding judge who ordered the release of the former president apparently ignored his proclivity to collude with other defendants and witnesses, they said.

It was also impractical for the judge to claim that Chen's activities would be monitored by the bodyguards assigned to protect him, because he could always instruct them not to follow him around, they added.
The prosecutors cited cases in Ukraine, Peru and Thailand in which corrupt heads of state easily sneaked out of their own countries to go into hiding abroad.
The former president and his wife were indicted for embezzled NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from the president's special discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They also took bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.
The prosecutors recommended that the former president be given the harshest possible sentence for his alleged illegalities involving nearly half a billion new Taiwan dollars.

They also demanded severe penalties for his wife, son and daughter-in-law for their "unrepentant attitude" in the course of investigations, while recommending commuted sentences for 10 other defendants because they had been cooperative and helpful in the process of the investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County sees increased tax revenue from science park

TEXT.P: The Tainan Science Park has plumped up the coffers of Tainan County in southern Taiwan with tax revenue since the park began operations in 1999, a local official said Tuesday.

According to the official of Tainan County's Local Tax Bureau, the house tax revenues from the science park totalled NT$290 million (US$8.79 million) this year compared to less than NT$2 million in 1999.
House tax revenues from throughout the entire county increased from NT$1.78 billion in 1999 to NT$2.39 billion this year, the official said.
Over the same period, the science park generated NT$40 million in land value tax for the county, the official added.

The science park, along with the county's many industrial areas, has also helped to create job opportunities, the official said, adding that most of the science park's 50,000 workers are local residents.
Moreover, the operations of the science park and industrial areas have also helped to boost development of other industries in the county, the official said.
The county's business sales from all its industries increased from NT$812.2 billion in 2002 to NT$1.6 trillion at the end of 2007, the official said.

However, the actual amount is likely to be higher than the recorded figure, as the business sales of 65 of the 167 enterprises in mass production in the park are not registered in the county, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Time not ripe for intermediary bodies to exchange offices: MAC chief

TEXT.P: Although the long-expected direct air, shipping and postal links between Taiwan and China were put in place Monday, hurdles remain to be surmounted before the intermediary bodies of the two sides will be able to exchange offices, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Tuesday.

"The MAC hopes to gradually achieve the goal through increasing two-way interactions, systematic negotiations and building mutual trust, but will never exchange Taiwan's national sovereignty for economic benefits," said Lai.
"In contrast, it will further highlight Taiwan's independent sovereignty from China and set the stage for the two sides to conduct negotiations on an equal footing," she said.
The MAC chairwoman, Taiwan's top China policy planner, made the remarks while explaining the government's cross-Taiwan Strait policy at a public meeting in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County.

Cross-strait relations entered a new era in which Taiwan and China will not deny the other side's existence after a historic meeting between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin in early November in Taipei, Lai said.

In a follow-up to their first-ever encounter in June in Beijing, Chiang and Chen inked four pacts during their second meeting in Taipei, agreeing to establish direct daily charter flights, open shipping and postal services and set up a reporting mechanism on food safety control.

The meeting means that China does not deny Taiwan's existence, which is an improvement from the past, when the two sides did not recognize each other and when cross-strait exchanges were restricted, Lai pointed out.

The SEF and ARATS are semi-official bodies authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait interaction in the absence of official contact between the two sides. The MAC oversees SEF operations.

As Taiwan-China trade totaled over US$130 billion last year, the government needs an effective mechanism to help Taiwan's people resolve their problems arising from two-way dealings and to guarantee fair negotiations between the two sides, she said.
Through the systematic SEF-ARATS negotiations, the government is poised to further strengthen Taiwan's sovereignty in a gradual fashion instead of in a reckless manner, Lai went on.

Chiang and Chen are slated to discuss issues relating to joint crime-fighting efforts, fishery cooperation, cross-strait financial supervision, and the signing of an accord to protect Taiwanese business interests in China during the third round of their talks scheduled for next spring, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. expert praises independence of Taiwan's prosecutors

TEXT.P: An American law expert said Tuesday that he is reassured by the independence of Taiwan's prosecution authorities and expressed the hope that the indictment of former President Chen Shui-bian will serve as an opportunity for the country to strengthen its judicial system and democratic processes.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, visiting professor Jerome A. Cohen, co-director of New York University's U.S.-Asia Law Institute, said that the independence of Taiwan's prosecutors and courts is evidenced by the fact that they received "pressure from all over, " including from the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), in the probes into the Chen family cases.

This level of judicial independence has been one of Taiwan's significant achievements since the early 1990s, he added. Cohen said that in recent years, he has thought that "Taiwan's prosecutors are able and honest people who are not told what to do by the president, or by the Ministry of Justice, or by the Cabinet."

However, Cohen said that the indictment of Chen and his family members on various charges such as corruption and embezzlement is a "personal and political tragedy," and is also "horrible for the DPP."

Cohen suggested that whatever the outcome of the cases, Taiwan should "turn a vice into a virtue" and seize the opportunity to create "something worthwhile, " such as a better judiciary and democracy.
It will also be important for Taiwan in the next ten years to deal with problems regarding criminal justice, he noted.

In addition, Cohen said although Taiwan "is doing a good job" in democratic practices, its people still face challenges such as how to strengthen government institutions and to maintain a responsible two-party political system. "To be a Taiwan citizen now is exciting, but also a pretty heavy responsibility," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 17, or the 20th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1888: The Ching dynasty establishes its Peiyang (northern) navy and appoints Ting Ju-chang as the admiral.
1891: Hu Shih, a noted Chinese scholar who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style, is born in Shanghai.
1902: Classes begin for the first time at National Peking University, China's first university and most prestigious institution of higher education.
1903: American aviation pioneer Orville Wright and his brother Wilbur make the world's first successful sustained flight in a heavier-than-air vehicle, which they invented, flying over sand dunes near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
1919: Pierre Auguste Renoir, French impressionist painter whose warm luminous works include "Child with Watering Can" and "Luncheon of the Boating Party," dies at the age of 78.
1925: The Anping Canal in Tainan, southern Taiwan is inaugurated.
1941: Japanese forces invade North Borneo during World War II.
1948: The Dutch attack Indonesia and arrest President Sukarno and other leaders.
1949: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces the severing of diplomatic relations with Burma.
1957: The United States successfully test-launches its first intercontinental ballistic missile.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt disappears while swimming at Portsea, Victoria.
1968: The Chinese National Committee of the International Press Institute is established in Taipei.
1971: Pakistan and India end a two-week war over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1971: The International Commercial Bank of China (formerly the Bank of China) is inaugurated, becoming a complete private enterprise.
1973: Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez, Costa Rican speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1973: Denzo Okubo, president of the Federation of the Japan-ROC Association, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: Economics Minister Y. S. Sun and Korean Deputy Premier Nam Duck Woo sign a joint communique calling for further economic cooperation.
1975: A boxing tournament opens at the Tainan City Gymnasium, with boxers from the Philippines, South Korea, Japan and the ROC competing.
1978: More than 5,000 people stage an angry protest outside the U.S. embassy in Taipei.
1979: Tsiang Yien-si succeeds Chang Pao-shu as the secretary-general of the Central Committee of the Kuomintang.
1986: The 1986 Nobel Prize winner in chemistry, Lee Yuan-tseh, a member of the Academia Sinica, returns to the ROC. Lee and his wife are received by President Chiang Ching-kuo on Dec. 18.
1986: New Costa Rican Ambassador to the ROC Ruben Acon Leon calls on President Chiang Ching-kuo to present his credentials.
1989: Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, who succeeded Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as commander of the U.S. forces in China during World War II, dies in Washington D.C.
1991: Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev agree to dissolve the Soviet Union and proclaim a new commonwealth on New Year's Day.
1993: Lee Yuan-tseh succeeds Wu Ta-you, becoming the 7th president of the Academia Sinica.
1996: The Ching dynasty's last eunuch Sun Yao-ting dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
1997: A treaty eradicating bribery in international business is signed by the representatives of 34 countries.
1999: Mandarin Airlines, a subsidiary of the Republic of China's former flag carrier China Airlines, opens direct flights between Taipei and Thailand's northern city of Chiang Mai.
2000: Ten king penguins from the United States arrive in Taipei. They are introduced into Taiwan by the Taipei Zoo.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan meets with about 100 party representatives from Japan's Tokyo and Yokohama areas over a dinner in Tokyo.
2001: Five Japanese Lower House members belonging to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit at the invitation of the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Confucius: "A wise man will not make himself into a mere machine fit only to do one kind of work. A wise and good man is one who acts before he speaks, and afterwards speaks according to his actions. A wise man is impartial, not neutral. A fool is neutral but not impartial."

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of babies in Taiwan born with HIV declining

TEXT.P: The number of babies born in Taiwan with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is declining, with statistics showing that since 2007 there have been no recorded births of HIV-infected infants, the Department of Health reported (DOH) Tuesday.

According to the DOH statistics, Taiwan recorded five cases of babies born with HIV in 2005, and four in 2006. As of Nov. 30 this year, the number of children in Taiwan born with HIV stood at 27, the DOH figures showed.

The DOH in 2005 implemented a number of measures to stem mother-to-infant HIV transmission during pregnancy. The measures focused on three major areas -- disease screening, medical treatment and health care.
As a result, since 2005, 95 babies born to HIV-positive mothers have tested free of the disease, the DOH said.
The department estimates that the risk of mother-to-infant HIV transmission during pregnancy will drop from 45 percent to 2 percent if the mothers adopt preventive medical care.
HIV is transmitted to infants mainly at conception, during labor or by breast feeding. Preventive therapy during these phrases can prevent infection of babies, DOH officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese pandas to arrive in Taiwan Dec. 23

TEXT.P: A pair of giant pandas China promised to give Taiwan in 2005 will finally arrive Dec. 23, a spokesman for EVA Airways -- which will bring the animals from China -- said Tuesday.
Nieh Kuo-wei said an EVA plane will leave for Chengdu in western China's Sichuan Province Dec. 22 and return the next day with the pandas, whose arrivals have been long-awaited in Taiwan.
The pandas will be accompanied by its two Chinese keepers, who will bring with them 600 kg of the bamboo on which the animals feed and will stay in Taiwan for two months to help take care of them.
The spokesman also said EVA Airways is offering 100 people the "privilege of traveling with the pandas" for just NT$9,900 for the round trip to Chengdu.
After arriving in Taiwan, the pandas will be put in quarantine until they are put on display at the Taipei Zoo for the first time on Lunar New Year's Eve -- Jan. 25.

Chinese President Hu Jintao presented the pandas to then-Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan in 2005 during an ice-breaking trip Lien made to Beijing, but the delivery was blocked by political bickering between Beijing and Taipei as long as Taiwan was under the rule of the now-opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
However, the political climate between the two sides has thawed since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May this year, thanks to Ma's more conciliatory approach toward China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors file appeal against ex-president's release

TEXT.P: The Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office filed an appeal Tuesday against the Taipei District Court's decision last week to release indicted former President Chen Shui-bian, contending that it is possible that he might abscond through "secret channels."

Chen was released Dec. 13 upon his own recognizance, despite a request by prosecutors to keep him in custody, after being detained for 32 days as prosecutors prepared four cases against him. After four months of investigations, they indicted him Dec. 12 on charges of embezzlement, bribe- taking and money laundering.

In the appeal presented to the Taiwan High Court, the SID prosecutors said they will soon begin to investigate several other corruption cases involving Chen and his wife, and that if he is allowed to remain free, some of the witnesses, including former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng, might not dare tell the truth.

The prosecutors also said they still need to trace NT$570 million (US$17.29 million) in bribe money and that if Chen is not detained, he could obliterate the evidence, as he tried to do before he was detained.
"With NT$570 million stashed abroad, it is hard to say there is absolutely no possibility that he will abscond," they pointed out.

The prosecutors noted that in the initial stage of their investigation, Chen had instructed his former cashier, Chen Chen-hui, former Presidential Office Director Lin Teh-hsun, Ma and other defendants to give false testimony regarding the former first family's embezzlement of the president's state affairs fund and its money laundering activities.
The presiding judge who ordered the release of the former president apparently ignored his proclivity to collude with other defendants and witnesses, they said.

It was also impractical for the judge to claim that Chen's activities would be monitored by the bodyguards assigned to protect him, because he could always instruct them not to follow him around, they added.
The prosecutors cited cases in Ukraine, Peru and Thailand in which corrupt heads of state easily sneaked out of their own countries to go into hiding abroad.
The former president and his wife were indicted for embezzled NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from the president's special discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They also took bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.
The prosecutors recommended that the former president be given the harshest possible sentence for his alleged illegalities involving nearly half a billion new Taiwan dollars.

They also demanded severe penalties for his wife, son and daughter-in-law for their "unrepentant attitude" in the course of investigations, while recommending commuted sentences for 10 other defendants because they had been cooperative and helpful in the process of the investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Time not ripe for intermediary bodies to exchange offices: MAC chief

TEXT.P: Although the long-expected direct air, shipping and postal links between Taiwan and China were put in place Monday, hurdles remain to be surmounted before the intermediary bodies of the two sides will be able to exchange offices, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Tuesday.

"The MAC hopes to gradually achieve the goal through increasing two-way interactions, systematic negotiations and building mutual trust, but will never exchange Taiwan's national sovereignty for economic benefits," said Lai.
"In contrast, it will further highlight Taiwan's independent sovereignty from China and set the stage for the two sides to conduct negotiations on an equal footing," she said.
The MAC chairwoman, Taiwan's top China policy planner, made the remarks while explaining the government's cross-Taiwan Strait policy at a public meeting in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County.

Cross-strait relations entered a new era in which Taiwan and China will not deny the other side's existence after a historic meeting between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin in early November in Taipei, Lai said.

In a follow-up to their first-ever encounter in June in Beijing, Chiang and Chen inked four pacts during their second meeting in Taipei, agreeing to establish direct daily charter flights, open shipping and postal services and set up a reporting mechanism on food safety control.

The meeting means that China does not deny Taiwan's existence, which is an improvement from the past, when the two sides did not recognize each other and when cross-strait exchanges were restricted, Lai pointed out.

The SEF and ARATS are semi-official bodies authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait interaction in the absence of official contact between the two sides. The MAC oversees SEF operations.

As Taiwan-China trade totaled over US$130 billion last year, the government needs an effective mechanism to help Taiwan's people resolve their problems arising from two-way dealings and to guarantee fair negotiations between the two sides, she said.
Through the systematic SEF-ARATS negotiations, the government is poised to further strengthen Taiwan's sovereignty in a gradual fashion instead of in a reckless manner, Lai went on.

Chiang and Chen are slated to discuss issues relating to joint crime-fighting efforts, fishery cooperation, cross-strait financial supervision, and the signing of an accord to protect Taiwanese business interests in China during the third round of their talks scheduled for next spring, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. expert praises independence of Taiwan's prosecutors

TEXT.P: An American law expert said Tuesday that he is reassured by the independence of Taiwan's prosecution authorities and expressed the hope that the indictment of former President Chen Shui-bian will serve as an opportunity for the country to strengthen its judicial system and democratic processes.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, visiting professor Jerome A. Cohen, co-director of New York University's U.S.-Asia Law Institute, said that the independence of Taiwan's prosecutors and courts is evidenced by the fact that they received "pressure from all over, " including from the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), in the probes into the Chen family cases.

This level of judicial independence has been one of Taiwan's significant achievements since the early 1990s, he added. Cohen said that in recent years, he has thought that "Taiwan's prosecutors are able and honest people who are not told what to do by the president, or by the Ministry of Justice, or by the Cabinet."

However, Cohen said that the indictment of Chen and his family members on various charges such as corruption and embezzlement is a "personal and political tragedy," and is also "horrible for the DPP."

Cohen suggested that whatever the outcome of the cases, Taiwan should "turn a vice into a virtue" and seize the opportunity to create "something worthwhile, " such as a better judiciary and democracy.
It will also be important for Taiwan in the next ten years to deal with problems regarding criminal justice, he noted.

In addition, Cohen said although Taiwan "is doing a good job" in democratic practices, its people still face challenges such as how to strengthen government institutions and to maintain a responsible two-party political system. "To be a Taiwan citizen now is exciting, but also a pretty heavy responsibility," he said.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.800 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.230 from Tuesday.
