DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
GIO chief refuses to confirm personnel reshuffle speculation

TEXT.P: Executive Yuan spokeswoman Vanessa Yea-ping Shih refused to confirm reports Wednesday that she will become Taiwan's representative to Singapore, a post that has been vacant for three months.
Approached by the media at the Legislative Yuan, Shih deflected questions on the matter with a smile and the polite refrain "thank you for your concern."

Should the speculation of Shih's move prove accurate, local media has tipped Su Jun-pin as her likely successor. Su, the director of Taoyuan County's Environmental Protection Bureau, served as President Ma Ying-jeou's spokesman during his presidential election campaign.
Su also would not confirm his new appointment, saying it was still too early for him to say anything about personnel changes in the Cabinet.

If Shih were to be reassigned and her appointment received favorably by Singapore's government, she would be the third member of the Ma administration's Cabinet to step down since the new government took power on May 20.

Health Minister Lin Fang-yue resigned in late September to take political responsibility for the Department of Health's questionable handling of a controversy over food ingredient imports from China containing the toxic chemical melamine.

Gordon Chen resigned as chairman of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission in November over what he called his inability, as Taiwan's top financial regulator, to properly respond to the global financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan censures DOH for handling of tainted dragon fruit

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan censured the Department of Health (DOH) Wednesday for its "inattentive management" of tainted dragon fruit imported from Vietnam in October and threatened to impeach health officials if a repeat of the situation occurred.

Control Yuan members Cheng Jen-hung and Wu Feng-shan found that the DOH neglected its duty by not establishing a mechanism to track and inspect local fruit importers who sold tainted dragon fruit before pesticide test results were available.
Such negligence posed risks to consumers' health, the Control Yuan asserted.
If similar incidents happen again in the future, we will not rule out the possibility of impeaching DOH officials,Cheng said.

The case involved more than 18,300 kilograms of dragon fruit arrived from Vietnam in early October. According to normal procedures, the DOH allowed the importer to take possession of the fruit in exchange for a pledge it would not sell the fruit before results of safety tests were available.

Perishable goods are customarily released to local importers before final approval is given so that they can be stored in a proper environment. The government contends it lacks such facilities at the country's seaports and airports.

In the case of the imported dragon fruit, however, when the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection informed the DOH a few days later that the fruit contained excessive pesticide residues, the importer had already illegally sold the shipment in eight counties islandwide.
Cheng accused the DOH of not making sufficient efforts to establish a system that can check, track and control foods they have let into the country prior to their being approved.
This lax control of food safety at its source, Cheng said, has resulted in a 16.7 percent rate of illegal sales from 2006 to November this year.
Cheng also said the DOH has not established clear standards and test methods for laboratories to follow, causing a delay in judging whether foods can be sold or not.
The Control Yuan decision also criticized the DOH for a lack of measures and stiff penalties to prevent illegal sales.

At present, importers who sell foods before receiving approval are fined NT$60,000 (US$1,834) and banned for six months from taking delivery of imported goods before test results are available, penalties that Cheng described aspointless.

The Control Yuan's Wu further described the dragon fruit case as onlythe tip of iceberg,pointing out that Taiwan's budget for food safety, which is only one- fourth that of Japan and one-fourteenth that of the United States, is "seriously deficienct.
Taiwan's main body responsible for monitoring the conduct of public officials and civil servants, the Control Yuan resumed operations in August this year after more than three years of paralysis.
The body had been without its members because the Kuomintang-controlled legislature refused to confirm then-President Chen Shui-bian's nominations of members.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local consumers grow more practical amid recession: survey

TEXT.P: Local consumers are expected to be more practical in making purchasing decisions in 2009 as they seek stability during the economic downturn, according to a consumer trend report released Tuesday.

The report published by Eastern Online, a lifestyle and consumer market research consultant, found that money remains at the top of local consumers' most-wanted list, mentioned by 62.3 percent of the survey's respondents.
Health and a stable life are the second and third top priorities, cited by 48.3 percent and 34.8 percent of respondents, respectively.
The survey results further revealed five trends among Taiwan's consumers, led by a more rational use of money owing to a decline in purchasing power.

The survey found that the ratio of consumers who lack a clear idea of where their money has been spent has dropped from 53.6 percent in 2007 to 32.7 percent in 2008, while the ratio of those who put their money in education or retirement funds has risen from 72.7 percent in 2007 to 79.4 percent in 2008.
Meanwhile, the ratio of consumers investing in high-risk, high-return instruments has decreased from 40.9 percent in 2007 to 30.7 percent in 2008.
The second trend revealed is that the demand for fashion and quality remains high, but not at the expense of practicality.
The results indicated that 63 percent of respondents in the 20-64 age group "would spend more for products with special style, " about the same as in 2007.
However, the group of consumers who "would consider buying fashionable products that are a bit impractical" contracted from 47.7 percent in 2007 to 33.9 percent in 2008.
Another trend identified by the survey is that consumers are less worried about being left behind by new technologies.

While 70 percent of respondents agree that mobile phones, e-mail and MSN are important means of communications and 60.3 percent often use the Internet to search for information, the ratio of those who are often worried about not being up on technological developments has dropped from 59.1 percent in 2004 to 51.9 percent in 2008.
Meanwhile, the report found that Taiwan's consumers are attaching increasing importance to a healthy diet and paying more attention to environmental protection.

More than 84 percent of respondents said they check the list of ingredients and dates of expiry when buying foods, and 91.9 percent said cleanliness is their first consideration in deciding on a place to eat out.
Ninety percent of respondents believe they have a responsibility to protect the earth, and 86.5 percent are concerned that excessive consumption will lead to the depletion of the planet's resources.
The report was based on a survey of 2,000 domestic consumers aged 13-64. It had a margin of error of 2.19 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TTF head leads Taiwan garment, fashion firms to Beijing

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese business group, led by nonprofit Taiwan Textile Federation (TTP) Chairman Roland Tsai, is in Beijing to show off designer garments and fashions made in Taiwan, a federation source said Wednesday.

The delegation -- comprised of makers of 13 renowned brands of upscale apparel, baby and infant wear, underwear and lingerie, and bags and luggage, including Tony Jeans, Les Enfants, Ordifen and Crown -- will stage two fashion shows at the Grand Hyatt Beijing Thursday to promote the Taiwanese goods.
Executives of the companies will also meet with Chinese buyers at business promotion workshops slated for Thursday and Friday in Beijing, according to the TTF official.
The delegation hopes to capitalize on the expanded air and sea links between Taiwan and China launched on Dec. 15 to increase sales to China, according to the TTF official.

The official said that in light of the global economic slowdown, which has resulted in a decline of China's exports, Beijing is planning a 4 trillion-yuan economic stimulus package focused on domestic investment and spending to maintain China's economic growth.
"With one-fourth of the world's population, China's huge domestic market is worth being explored by Taiwanese manufacturers, " the official said.

It is hoped that the fashion shows and business workshops will provide local companies a golden opportunity to make inroads into China and gain niches in department stores in Beijing and major cities around northern China, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City confirms arrival of pandas set tentatively for Dec. 23

TEXT.P: A Taipei City government official confirmed Wednesday that two giant pandas offered as gifts by China will arrive in Taiwan next week, if everything goes according to plan.

If everything goes as planned, the two giant pandas will be put on an EVA Airways flight on Dec. 23 that leaves Sichuan at 11 a.m., " said Yang Hsiao- tung, the city's Department of Information and Tourism, speaking by phone from China where he is preparing for the transfer.
They will arrive at around 2 p.m. at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and are expected to reach their new home at the Taipei City Zoo by nightfall,Yang added.

He cautioned, however, that the planned schedule could be affected by a number of factors, including the pandas' health, traffic conditions in Sichuan, and weather conditions at the international airport in Chengdu, Sichuan's capital.

"We cannot be too optimistic about conditions on the road from the China Panda- protection Research Center in Ya'an to the international airport in Chengdu and the weather at the airport. That's why we can't be too certain about Dec. 23 as the timing for the pandas' arrival in Taiwan,Yang said.

Even if the pandas arrive here next week, they will be kept in quarantine for at least one month before they can be exposed to the public. Zoo officials hope the pandas can make their debut around the Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan. 26.
China offered Taiwan the two pandas in 2005 when then-opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan made an ice-breaking visit to Beijing.
The Chinese authorities named them Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan -- which together mean "reunion" or "unification" in Chinese -- through an online vote.

The offer was turned down, however, by the then-ruling Democratic Progressive Party administration, which objected to China's treatment of the panda transfer as a "domestic transfer" between zoos because it implied that Taiwan was part of China.

As giant pandas are an endangered wildlife species subject to the protection of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) , cross-border transfers of the animal must follow strict CITES guidelines.
According to the guidelines, the two parties must supply export and import permits confirming that all conditions for the transfer have been met, implying that transaction is between two countries.

In contrast with the previous DPP administration, the government of President Ma Ying-jeou has agreed to skirt the issue by identifying the importer as " Taiwan Taipei" and accepting "Chengdu" as the origin of export.
According to an agreement signed Nov. 6 by Taiwan and China, Taiwan will give Beijing a pair of Formosan sika deer and a pair of Formosan serow in return for the pandas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices finished higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 31.13 points to close at 4,648.02.

Posting gains for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,706.23 and fluctuated between 4,725.06 and 4,628.22. A total of 5.39 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$94.53 billion (US$2.89 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 3.22 percent. Cement stocks increased 2.47 percent, textile stocks rose 1.58 percent, paper and pulp issues were up 1.21 percent, machinery and electronics shares advanced 0.87 percent, and banking and financial shares rose 0.36 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares losing 0.4 percent and foodstuff issues declining 0.18 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 791 to 634, with 328 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$9.08 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor groups demand crackdown on unilateral unpaid leave schemes

TEXT.P: Labor associations demanded Wednesday that the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) investigate unpaid leave programs that the groups charge have been imposed by employers without the full consent of their workers.

Taiwan International Family Association representative Li Dan-feng said during a protest in front of the CLA building that several members of her association have been asked to take more than 10 days off without pay per month, costing them more than NT$10,000 (US$306) in monthly wages and seriously impacting their lives.
Moreover, these employees are almost forced into agreeing (to the unpaid leave terms) . They signed the agreement to be able to at least keep their jobs,Li said.
According to the CLA's Department of Labor Standards, employers who suspend their operations or reduce production are required to pay employees in accordance with the original employment contract.
If employers want to institute an unpaid leave program, the terms must be negotiated with their employees before any plan can take effect.

CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan also announced Tuesday that employers must not pay full-time employees a monthly salary less than the minimum wage of NT$17,280, regardless of any unpaid leave scheme, to guarantee their rights.

Despite the existence of these regulations, Lai Hsiang-ling, spokeswoman of the "Raging Citizens Act Now" association, criticized the CLA's weakness in protecting laborers' right to work, a charge supported by 50 protesters who smashed bowls to convey that their livelihoods are at risk.

She urged the CLA to investigate whether there are companies that unilaterally announced unpaid leave programs without negotiating terms with their employees, and whether those workers are being paid below the minimum wage.
In response, CLA Deputy Minister Pan Shih-wei told reporters that the Labor Inspection Office under the CLA will strengthen its regular checks on workers' conditions.
The labor associations also demanded that enterprises violating CLA regulations on unpaid leave be barred from benefiting from the government's financial relief measures.

Due to the global economic downturn, many of Taiwan's leading companies, including chipmakers Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company and United Microelectronics Corporation, have implemented unpaid leave programs to reduce personnel costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.310 to close at NT$32.720.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for December advancing 77 points to end at 4,666, with 55,092 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for January gained 56 points to finish at 4,623, with 60,082 contracts traded, while March futures increased 68 points to close at 4,598, with 66 contracts changing hands.
June futures advanced 40 points to close at 4,562, with 50 contract transactions, while September futures rose 58 points to finish at 4,374, with 14 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 4,589 for December, 4,567 for January, 4,530 for March, 4,522 for June and 4,316 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 31.13 points to finish at 4,648.02, on turnover of NT$94.53 billion (US$2.88 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
December TE futures rose 2.85 points to close at 178.25, with 2,627 contracts traded, while January TE futures increased 1.15 points to finish at 176.5, with 3,948 contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shopping vouchers must be spent in Taiwan: CEPD head

TEXT.P: China-based Taiwanese business people, who are also entitled to get shopping vouchers worth NT$3,600 next month under a government plan to boost spending, must spend the vouchers in Taiwan, the head of the country's top economic planning agency said Wednesday.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Chen Tain-jy, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that if the Taiwanese business people receive the vouchers in China, they would have to use them after they return to Taiwan.

Chen also said the government will try its best to prevent counterfeiting so as to protect retailers' interests. He added that shop owners will be provided with relevant information to verify the authenticity of the shopping vouchers.
The Cabinet has come up with an NT$85.7 billion (US$2.6 billion) budget plan for the shopping voucher project, which is pending legislative approval.

Under the project -- aimed at spurring consumer spending and boosting the slumped economy -- shopping vouchers will be distributed to all of Taiwan's citizens, regardless of age or income levels, before the 2009 Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan. 26.
Under the project, each citizen, including newborns and naturalized foreign spouses, will get NT$3,600 in shopping vouchers from Jan. 18.
The vouchers will remain valid until Sept. 30, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Singapore in consultation over new representative appointment

TEXT.P: The government is currently consulting with Singapore over the appointment of Taiwan's next representative to the city state, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Wednesday.
The name of the candidate will be withheld until the appointment has been accepted by the Singaporean government, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

The official made the remarks in response to media reports that Vanessa Yea-ping Shih, minister of the Government Information Office, has been designated as the country's representative to Singapore, a post that has been vacant for three months.
According to the official, the government officially presented its candidate to Singapore a couple of weeks ago and is still awaiting a reply from the Singaporean side.
He said the media reports should not influence Singapore's position on the matter.

On other diplomatic appointments, Antonio C.S. Chen, current director-general of the MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs, will soon assume the position of Taiwan's representative to Russia, and Chu Wen-hsiang, secretary-general of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, will become Taiwan's representative to Switzerland, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Textile institute introduces new concept in vertical gardens

TEXT.P: A new concept in "vertical gardens" based on newly developed non-woven fabrics made its debut Wednesday, introduced by the Yunlin branch of the non-profit Taiwan Textile Research Institute (TTRI).

Vertical gardens are nothing new in the world of horticulture, but the technology using composite non-woven and cloth fabrics as a base on which plants and flowers can grow is a new twist, said Huang Po-hsiung, deputy director of the Product Development Department of the TTRI's Yunlin branch.
The know-how and application of non-woven vertical gardens can help private houses and public buildings build gardens in an easy, inexpensive and environmentally friendly way, said Huang.
If well cultivated, the gardens could also be used as natural coolers of the environment with their strong heat-repellent properties, Huang added.

The gardens were introduced at a workshop held at the TTRI's Yunlin branch, where other new innovative products developed by TTRI researchers were also introduced, including solar fabrics and cosmetic masks and wound dressings that use biotechnologically developed cellulose.

DOC.HEADLINE: University holds forum for youngsters to share life stories

TEXT.P: Several people who have been dubbed "the glory of Taiwan" by building successful careers without acquiring tertiary education shared their life stories at a forum held Tuesday at National Chung Cheng University in the southern county of Chiayi.

University officials said the forum and an accompanying Web site invited young people who have won prestigious awards and acclaim in the international arena to tell how they turned their interests into a "world number one" skill.
Since 2006, the number of local people in their 20s emerging as world champions in various international competitions has been rising, according to the officials.

Not until those people -- who were originally considered by some local people as not being part of mainstream society -- began to shine in the world, did these same people realize that there are different paths to success, the officials added.

Many people, however, are unaware of how those who had difficulty adapting to the formal education system overcame their financial hardships as well as mental suffering before they were able to attain their ultimate achievements.

For example, balloon artist Chen Yi-wei, who was forced to drop out of university in his second year because of poor grades stemming from his devotion to art, has not only won championships in various balloon art competitions in Japan and the United States, but also operates a booming balloon art design consultancy that opened in 2007.

Chen said that when he decided to devote his life to balloon sculptures a few years ago, he found that the education system did provide sufficient professional information and learning materials for him. Thus, he worked out a solution by searching for information on the Internet, which enabled him to develop his craft.
Several international bartender competition winners who also experienced difficulty with regular class work also shared their stories.

Hsieh Mei-mei, a coach who has trained many world-class bartenders, said given that Taiwan's education system does not provide educational opportunities for students with special talents, many excellent bartenders would not be able to shine on the international stage without the efforts of a group of enthusiastic coaches willing to cultivate talent.

Speaking of her frustration, Hsieh complained that the country has not set up a complete system for training bartenders in international competitions and for handling contestants' visa applications, adding that the lack of government support makes the contestants' road to victory very bumpy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yeast experiments reveal functions of `speciation' genes

TEXT.P: Biologists at Academia Sinica have spotted "speciation" genes in budding yeasts and have observed for the first time the mechanisms related to these genes, according to a paper published in Dec. 12 issue of the peer-reviewed journal Cell.
Biologists have long observed that animals of different species cannot reproduce with each other, and that even if different species do produce offspring, the resulting hybrids are sterile.
These facts have induced evolutionary biologists to hypothesize the existence of speciation genes, a type of evolutionary divider that inhibits inter-species reproduction.
Since then, only a handful of speciation genes have been identified and most of their molecular mechanisms are still unclear, according to Academia Sinica.

However, researchers at Academia Sinica's Institute of Molecular Biology have not only identified a pair of speciation genes in yeast, but have also come to the realization that if the genes are passed down from different species, they will be unable to interact with each other, leading to hybrid sterility.

Leu Jun-yi -- an assistant research fellow at the institute who is leading the project -- said they selected saccharomyces bayanus and saccharomyces cerevisiae, which are closely related to each other in evolutionary terms, as their experiment subjects.

Although the two species do produce offspring, Leu said, the pair of speciation genes -- Aep2 protein in nucleus and OLI1 in mitochondrion -- failed to activate reproduction functions because one came from s. bayanus and the other came from s. cerevisiae.
"Only when both Aep2 and OLI1 come from the same species will the subsequent mechanisms function properly," said Leu.
Explaining why such a divider would exist, Leu suggested that it could be to maintain novel adaptations during the evolutionary process.

Leu elaborated by pointing out that although s. bayanus and s. cerevisiae are closely related in evolutionary terms, one has adopted to aerobic respiration, while the other uses anaerobic respiration. If the two species were allowed to merge through reproduction, one of the respiration methods would disappear, said Leu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Growing number of children from low-income families need help: NGO

TEXT.P: An increasing number of children from low-income families are in need of financial aid to continue their education, according to the findings of a survey released Wednesday.

The survey, conducted in November on 1,234 children from poor families, showed that 63.8 percent of the children said that they do not think they have a chance to go on to higher education, said Wang Ming-jen, executive director of the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF), which conducted the survey.
Survey findings also showed that many of the children were not doing well in school, Wang told a news conference in Taipei.
The TFCF survey found that 2 percent of elementary school children and 14.8 percent of junior high school children from low-income families were falling behind in their academic studies.
The survey findings suggest there is an alarming trend of increase in children from low-income families not performing to their potential in their academic studies, the group said.
This will lead to low self-esteem for the children,Wang told reporters.

The global economic crisis will only make the financial situation of the low- income families worse, according to Wang. Companies in recent days have announced layoffs, unpaid leave and salary freezes.
This means that the children from these families will be even more depleted in education resources,said Wang.
In addition to the TFCF survey, Wang also quoted figures from the Ministry of Interior indicating that Taiwan now has over 90,000 low-income households, a 10-year record high.
According to Wang, many of these low-income families are not spending any money on after-school tutorial education for their children.
This is to the disadvantage of the children,said Wang.
Low-income families are those with a monthly income of less than NT$10,000 (US$303).
TFCF is a non-governmental organization that dedicates itself to helping needy children and their families with welfare and benefits.
Wang said her group is helping about 42,000 children from families of modest means.
I would like to call on the community to reach out and help those children in need by making donations, said Wang, adding that the groups donation hotline is 0800-001-100.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's resource recycling in 2007 bears fruit

TEXT.P: Taiwan's total production value from resource recycling in 2007 reached NT$100 billion (US$3.03 billion) , Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen said Tuesday at the opening of the two-day 2008 International Conference on Resource Recycling.
Shen urged manufacturers to produce more environmentally friendly products and called on the public to purchase recyclable items in an effort to help promote environmentalism.
Hung Jung-hsun, an EPA adviser, said during a keynote speech that the daily amount of junk produced by each Taiwanese person reached 1.14 kg per day in 1996.

With the government's promotion of resource recycling over the past few years, however, the daily amount has been reduced to 0.56 kg per day, with a recycling rate as high as 40 percent, Hung went on.

According to another EPA official, Taiwan is one of the top three countries in terms of recycling rates, adding as an example that Taiwan's recycling rate of dry cell batteries reached as high as 50 percent this year to date.
The production value from recycling discarded scooters, cars and electric appliances accounted for the lion's share of last year's total production values, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seeking an adventurous way to ring in the new year? Try Mt. Ali

TEXT.P: Taiwan's most famous mountain -- Alishan or Mt. Ali -- will be the scene of two music concerts scheduled for Dec. 31 and Jan. 1 to ring in the new year 2009, the national park administration at the mountain said Wednesday.
The Alishan National Scenic Area Administration on Wednesday invited the public to Alishan -- one of the most popular scenic areas in Taiwan -- to celebrate the new year.
On the evening of Dec. 31, the 2008 Best Times Concert will be held at the Alishan Tourist Service Center to bid farewell to 2008, Chung Fu-song, head of the administration, told a news conference.
The concert will feature musicians, singers and the Hamowana Dancing Group of the aboriginal Tsou Tribe. Hamowana, a term from the Tsou dialect, means "celestial God."

The second concert, the 2009 Alishan Sunrise Impression Concert, will take place in the early morning of Jan. 1 at the helicopter landing site of Jhushan -- a favorite spot for tourists to watch the sunrise on Alishan -- as the first gleam of sunlight of 2009 can be seen from there.

The Jan. 1 concert will feature performances by the Ten Drum Art Percussion Ensemble and renowned Canadian environmental musician Mathew Lien, whose music is full of aboriginal spirituality and love for nature.
The two concerts are held jointly by the park administration, the Chiayi County Government and the Chiayi Forest District Office under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture.

Alishan is famous for its five magnificent sights: the sunrise, the sea of clouds, the sunset, the forest, and the alpine railway ascending from the city of Chiayi at 30 meters above sea level to an elevation of more than 2,200 meters on Alishan.

DOC.HEADLINE: County magistrate denies outbreak of bird flu in Tainan

TEXT.P: Tainan Magistrate Su Huang-chih categorically denied Wednesday a local media report that there was an outbreak of avian flu in November in the southern county.

"The report is totally groundless. There has been no bird flu in Tainan County and not a single chicken has been killed as a result of the disease, " Su told a Legislative Yuan news conference in which opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers Chen Ting-fei and Lee Chun-yee also took part.

Su confirmed that some dead chickens in "another county" are being investigated by the health authorities to determine the cause of their deaths, a reference to a number of chicken deaths in neighboring Kaohsiung County.

According to the report carried by the Liberty Times, a large number of chickens raised in a poultry farm in Tainan County were confirmed by a government laboratory to have died from the H5N2 bird flu virus last month, but the Council of Agriculture (COA) tried to conceal the information so as not to mar the launch of direct daily air and regular shipping and postal links on Dec. 15.
Chen voiced grave concern that Taiwan will be exposed to great risk if the COA fails to fulfill its duty now that direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait have been established.

As bird flu has also broken out in Hong Kong and China recently, the COA must quickly detect the origin of the H5N2 virus to help protect public health, Chen said. She also demanded that COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung step down if the council is found to be accountable for any wrongdoing.
Answering questions at the Legislative Yuan Economics Committee later that same day, Chen Wu-hsiung again denied that large numbers of chickens have died in Tainan County in recent months.

He also rejected allegations that the COA has attempted to hide information about a possible bird flu epidemic in southern Taiwan, stressing that the council will publish the results of its investigation once it is complete.

In response to media reports that bird flu had broken out in Tainan and Kaohsiung counties, COA officials said in an urgent news conference Wednesday morning that a joint investigation by the COA and the Tainan county authorities has ruled out any Tainan cases.

However, the officials admitted that in Luchu township in neighboring Kaohsiung County, some 400 chickens at a poultry farm had died in late October and that some others were found in November, although they noted that only around 3 percent of the chickens had died, a fatality rate that is within the normal range for chicken farms and far lower than the average mortality rate caused by the H5N2 virus.

Despite the fact that the chickens did not develop signs of respiratory disease -- a key symptom of an H5N2 epidemic -- animal health officials decided to cull all the remaining 18,000 chickens in an effort to prevent any negative consequences.

The COA officials denied that the COA had tried to keep Kaohsiung's situation secret, saying that a panel of 23 experts had still not completed an investigation into the deaths and that the delay had nothing to do with the opening of direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport links.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the Centers for Disease Control under the Department of Health, also pointed out at a legislative committee meeting that day that there is no evidence the H5N2 virus can make the species jump to humans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Alishan tea to get anti-forgery label to fight fakes

TEXT.P: The Chiayi county government in southern Taiwan announced Wednesday that it has developed an anti-forgery label for its most popular agricultural product, the Alishan mountain oolong tea.

The tea has been popular among tourists, particularly those from China who have been coming to the mountain in larger numbers after non-stop, regular charter flights between Taiwan and China were launched in July, said Lien Chung-yung, the county official responsible of agricultural affairs.
However, the tea's popularity has led to forgeries which are made of substandard tea leaves, and the substandard products are hurting the reputation of the genuine goods, Lien said.

To protect Alishan tea's fame and sales, the county government invented the special label which can be found on the tea package. With a Q-tip and some water, Lien said, consumers can determine whether they are purchasing the real Alishan tea. If the label, which is blue turns pink, that means the product is genuine.
The anti-forgery label can also help consumers trace the producer, the official added.

Alishan mountain tea is produced in the Alishan mountain area at an altitude of at least 1,000 meters above sea level. At that altitude, tea farms are often surrounded by mist and moist clouds in the early morning and in the evening. The cool weather makes the area perfect for growing tea.

The county, through which the Tropic of Cancer runs, has 2,300 hectares of tea farms, which can generate an annual production value of more than NT$2 billion (US$61.3 million), according to the county government.

Since Taiwan opened its doors to more mainland Chinese tourists in July, the Alishan mountain tea has become a must-buy product, which almost every Chinese visitor will purchase for his or her family or friends in China as gifts, Lien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA to review foreign workers policy amid economic downturn

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Wednesday that it will review its foreign worker policies in the short term, in an effort to safeguard job opportunities for Taiwanese workers and to ensure protection of their rights in the current difficult economic environment.

In a statement released Wednesday, the CLA indicated that its current policy on foreign worker recruitment is based on the nation's unemployment rate, the labor shortage rate and the demands of domestic industrial development as a whole.

The CLA said that with the unemployment rate continuing to climb, it is closely observing the national employment situation and will give priority to Taiwanese workers' right to employment and good labor conditions, according to the statement.

With this in mind, the CLA said, it will review in the short term the number of foreign workers recruited to Taiwan and their qualifications, enhance monitoring of the proportion of national to foreign workers in enterprises, and control massive job cuts, in the hope of stabilizing the employment market for national workers.
The CLA reiterated that the current policy of admitting foreign workers must not impact negatively on labor conditions and job opportunities for Taiwan nationals.

The Cabinet-level agency also stated that it will look at the current procedures for the recruitment and management of foreign workers, promote employment services and provide vocational training for Taiwanese workers in order to help nationals tide over the unemployment crisis.

According to the CLA, there were 365,000 foreign workers in Taiwan as of the end of March this year, representing 3.5 percent of Taiwan's working population. Among these foreign workers, 198,000 were industrial workers and the rest were caregivers.
Most of Taiwan's foreign workers come from Southeast Asian countries, such as Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines and Vietnam, to undertake so-called "3D" jobs -- dangerous, dirty and difficult.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait forum on cooperation in herb medicine opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: A cross-Taiwan Strait forum on cooperation in herbal medicine and technical exchanges opened in Taipei Wednesday, with 500 people attending, including a 50-member delegation from China.
The two-day meeting, sponsored by the Hsinchu County-based Industrial Technology Research Institute, is taking place in a conference room of the Grand Hotel.

At the opening ceremony of the forum, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii- Ming, who is serving as the honorary chair of the meeting, presented a glazed porcelain vase along with glass peony flowers as souvenirs to Li Daning, deputy director-general of China's State Administration of Traditional Chinese Medicine.
Li is leading the Chinese delegation in his capacity as the honorary head of the Strait Traditional Medicine Cooperation and Development Center.

Addressing the participants, Yiin expressed the hope that the forum would help to achieve three goals -- an increase in China's supplies of herbal medicine to Taiwan, joint development of new herbal drugs, and mutual cooperation in tapping the world herbal medicine market.
Yiin said the government in Taipei will continue to "build more bridges" and create a better environment for private enterprises to develop.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County attracting increased number of visitors: officials

TEXT.P: Despite the economic slowdown, tourists, mainly Taiwanese travelers, had made over 21 million visits to Tainan County as of the end of October, an increase of nearly 30 percent from the year-earlier level, tourism officials of the southern Taiwan county reported Wednesday.

County tourism officials attributed the noticeable growth in the number of visitors from across the country to a more convenient transportation network, including the high speed rail system, which began operations last year.

Although most city and county governments in Taiwan are keen to lure more Chinese tourists, particularly after direct charter flight services opened between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in July this year, the officials admitted that the number of Chinese visitors to Tainan County remains low.
Most of the Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan would simply skip Tainan County or stay only for a few hours, they said.
"So far, Chinese tourist arrivals have not created brisk business in the southern county," the officials noted.
In 2007, local and foreign tourists made some 16.59 million visits to Tainan County, an increase of 6.1 percent compared to the 2006 figure of 15.63 million, county statistics showed.
Apart from touring Tainan's historical sites, visitors can enjoy the county's hot springs and pursue ecological activities, such as bird watching, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan remains free of H5N1; suspected H5N2 case still being checked

TEXT.P: There have been no infections of the virulent H5N1 avian flu virus in Taiwan to date, a senior official with the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health said Wednesday.

There are also no confirmed cases of an outbreak of low-pathogenic H5N2 avian flu virus among poultry in Taiwan, CDC Deputy Director Lin Ting said, adding that there is no evidence that the H5N2 can jump species to infect humans.

As of Tuesday, the CDC had received reports of eight suspected cases of H5N1 infections in humans, among which two people had visited China, one had visited Vietnam and five had been in close contact with poultry, Lin said.

"Examination results showed that five cases were seasonal influenza virus infections and the remaining three tested negative for any flu viruses, " Lin said, adding that none of suspected cases were H5N1 infections.
Quoting data released by the World Health Organization (WHO), Lin said more than 60 percent of confirmed human H5N1 cases have had close contact with poultry.

He advised local people to avoid contact with wild birds or chickens when they travel to countries or areas where H5N1 outbreaks among humans or animals have been reported, particularly Hong Kong, China's Jiangsu province, Indonesia, Egypt and Cambodia.

Meanwhile, Lin said an outbreak of low-pathogenic H5N2 avian flu is not uncommon among poultry but that the infection usually does not have a grave impact on animals. Even if the virus mutates to a high-pathogenic strain, it would only affect poultry, he said.

To date, Lin said, only a few Japanese officials working in animal quarantine jobs have tested positive for weak H5N2 antibodies after slaughtering chickens infected with the virus. "None of the workers have developed the disease, which indicates that H5N2 is unlikely to infect humans," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cheng Kung University to build 'green' educational center

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University announced Wednesday that it plans to build a 'green' educational center using technologies developed by local businesses.

The university in Tainan, southern Taiwan, said the structure would be the first of its kind in the world, as it would also serve as a green building museum and display green technologies developed in Taiwan.
The construction of the center will start early next year and will be completed in 2010, school officials said.

They said the center will built from local materials and that it will use 40 percent less energy, 30 percent less water and produce 30 percent less carbon dioxide emissions than normal upon completion. The building will last for at least 100 years, they added.
The construction of the building will be financed by a donation of NT$100 million (US$3.03 million) from Delta Electronics Foundation, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Air carrier aborts plan to take passengers on panda flight

TEXT.P: The air carrier that is scheduled to transport a gift of two giant pandas from China to Taiwan abandoned a plan Wednesday to invite passengers to travel aboard the same flight with the animals.

Eva Airways, which will fly to Chengdu, Sichuan province, Dec. 22 and bring them back to Taiwan the next day, announced Tuesday that it was making seats available for 100 people on the flight to Taiwan.
However, the airline abruptly withdrew the offer Wednesday after it drew flak from animal conservationists.

The conservationists argued that pandas are shy animals and that they should be disturbed as little as possible during the transportation process. In response, EVA Air said it "decided to accept the suggestion of the experts."
Eva officials said those travel agents that have accepted reservations will cancel them.

China first offered the pandas as a gift in 2005, but the offer was rejected by the then Democratic Progressive Party government, which feared that China would use the "domestic" transfer of the endangered animals to denigrate Taiwan's sovereign status.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung to import white tigers from China in June

TEXT.P: Even as Taipei City is abuzz with excitement over the imminent arrival of a pair of giant pandas from China, the southern port city of Kaohsiung is preparing to import two white tigers from the mainland.
Tang Cheng-juei, director of the Kaohsiung City Scenic Area Administration, said Wednesday the pair of white tigers are scheduled to be placed in the Shoushan Zoo in June.
The rare animals are a gift of the Guangzhou Xiangjiang Safari Park in southern China to promote friendship between Guangzhou and Kaohsiung, Tang said.
The zoo has appropriated NT$118 million (US$3.6 million) to fund a renovation project aimed at creating a space at the zoo to house the two white tigers, he added.
The tigers are expected to attract an increased number of visitors to the zoo, which draws nearly 500,000 persons a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA double checking cause of chicken deaths

TEXT.P: Dismissing local newspaper reports about an attempt to cover up a possible outbreak of bird flu in southern Taiwan, a government official said Wednesday that there is no H5N2 avian flu outbreak in Taiwan and that the government is still tracking the cause of the deaths among chickens at a local poultry farm.

"There have been no concrete signs of bird flu in Taiwan, except for an incident in late October at a poultry farm in Luchu township in Kaohsiung County, " said Huang Kuo-ching, deputy director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), during an animal disease prevention meeting in Kaohsiung City.

According to Huang, COA officials are still double checking agents obtained from the poultry farm in order to determine the cause of the deaths among the chickens in Luchu and will publish the findings upon completion of the examinations.
The area adjacent to the poultry farm has also been closely monitored, and nothing unusual has been detected, he noted.
Close to 400 chickens were found dead at the Luchu poultry farm in late October, giving rise to speculations that the deaths may have been caused by an outbreak of avian flu.

COA officials initiated an investigation into the cause of the chicken deaths and the preliminary findings showed that the birds had been infected with low- pathogenic H5N2 bird flu virus -- a species that is not known to jump to infect humans, Huang said.

As the fatality rate among chickens at the poultry farm was below 3 percent, which is far lower than the average mortality rate in cases of the low- pathogenic H5N2 virus, the COA is hesitant to categorize it as an epidemic, Huang explained, adding that the council had never tried to cover up any bird flu outbreak.
All the remaining 18,000 chickens at the farm were culled in an effort to keep the situation under control, he added.
Later Wednesday, Japan announced that it will immediately halt poultry meat imports from Taiwan on a temporary basis.
Japan's Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries announced on its official Web site that it made the decision to prevent the H5N2 bird flu virus from entering the country.
The Japanese ministry said that the problem was not one of food safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: District court ordered to reconsider ex-president's release

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court ordered the Taipei District Court Wednesday to reconsider its earlier decision to release former President Chen Shui-bian without bail pending trial on corruption and money laundering charges.
The high court gave the order after the Supreme Prosecutors Office's Special Investigation Division (SID) filed an appeal Tuesday against Chen's release early last Saturday.

In the appeal presented to the Taiwan High Court, the prosecutors said they will soon begin to investigate several other corruption cases allegedly involving Chen and his wife, and that if he is allowed to remain free, some of the witnesses, including three of his former close aides, might not dare to tell the truth.

High court spokesman Wen Yao-yuan echoed the SID prosecutors' concerns, saying that the possibility of Chen colluding with witnesses and co-defendants in the cases to tamper with or destroy evidence before the trial cannot be excluded.
Against this backdrop, Wen said, the district court should reconsider the case and return a new ruling.

In response, Taipei District Court spokesman Huang Chun-ming said that as the SID prosecutors stated in their appeal that they hoped the high court itself would return a new ruling, the district court had sent all relevant files and documents to the high court.
"Therefore, we have to wait until all those documents are sent back to the district court to hand down a new ruling," Huang said.
If all goes well, he added, the district court will open a hearing on the appeal Thursday afternoon at the earliest.

Chen was released Dec.13 upon his own recognizance, despite a request by prosecutors to keep him in custody, after he had been detained for 32 days as prosecutors prepared four cases against him. After four months of investigations, he and 13 other people were indicted Dec. 12 on charges of embezzlement, bribe-taking and money laundering.
Chen and his wife were indicted for embezzling NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They were also charged with accepting bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.
The prosecutors recommended that the former president be given the harshest possible sentence for his alleged crimes involving nearly half a billion new Taiwan dollars.

They also demanded severe penalties for his wife, son and daughter-in-law for their "unrepentant attitude" in the course of the investigations, and recommended commuted sentences for 10 other defendants whom prosecutors said had been cooperative and helpful in the process of the investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP urges former president to reflect on his morality issues

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) expects indicted former President Chen Shui-bian to reflect on the morality issues pertaining to himself and his family, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Wednesday.

In an interview with reporters following a meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee, Cheng said that DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen had made the appeal to the former president in a letter to the editor of a local newspaper.

In the letter published in the Chinese-language China Times Wednesday, Tsai said, "We expect him to set an example for the society. He must reflect upon the morality issues pertaining to himself and his family, and face the law bravely."
Cheng noted that the DPP chairwoman had already apologized to the Taiwan people on behalf of the DPP over the corruption and money laundering scandals implicating the former president and his family.

Cheng said Tsai's apology represented the party's own introspection, as the former president was a part of the DPP although he and his wife withdrew from the party in August after admitting that they had wired large sums of money abroad.
Asked whether the former president also needs to engage in introspection, Cheng said, "We do have expectations."

The DPP's call on Chen and his family to face the law came a day after DPP Legislator Chiu Yi-ying, a former staunch supporter of the ex-president, urged the four indicted members of the former first family, especially former first lady Wu Shu-jen, to "face the law, instead of telling more lies and fooling around with the feelings of the DPP members."
Chen and his wife were indicted last week on charges of embezzlement, bribe- taking, money laundering and forgery in four cases.

According to the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutor's Office, Chen and his wife embezzled NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They also took bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.
The prosecutors recommended that the former president be given the harshest possible sentence for his alleged crimes involving nearly half a billion new Taiwan dollars.

They also demanded severe penalties for his wife, son and daughter-in-law for their "unrepentant attitude" in the course of investigations, and recommending commuted sentences for 10 other defendants whom prosecutors said had been cooperative and helpful in the process of the investigations.

Chen was released Dec. 13 upon his own recognizance shortly after the indictment, despite a request by prosecutors to keep him in custody, after he had been detained for 32 days as prosecutors prepared their cases against him.

The prosecutors have filed an appeal with the Taiwan High Court against Chen's release, contending that, as they still need to investigate several other corruption cases involving Chen and his wife, some of the witnesses might not dare to tell the truth if he is allowed to remain free.

The prosecutors also said they still need to trace NT$570 million (US$17.29 million) in bribe money, and that if Chen is not in custody, he could erase the evidence, as he tried to do before he was detained.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 18, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Ruling Kuomintang Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung holding a pre-departure news conference on his visit to China to attend a cross-strait economic and cultural forum. Date and Time: 05:00 p.m., Thursday, Dec. 18, 2008. Place: KMT headquarters, No.232-234, Bade Road, Sec.2, Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung. Press Contact: Tel.2343-4567.
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

TEXT.P: The air carrier that is scheduled to transport a gift of two giant pandas from China to Taiwan abandoned a plan Wednesday to invite passengers to travel aboard the same flight with the animals.

The area adjacent to the poultry farm has also been closely monitored, and nothing unusual has been detected, he noted.
Close to 400 chickens were found dead at the Luchu poultry farm in late October, giving rise to speculations that the deaths may have been caused by an outbreak of avian flu.

COA officials initiated an investigation into the cause of the chicken deaths and the preliminary findings showed that the birds had been infected with low- pathogenic H5N2 bird flu virus -- a species that is not known to jump to infect humans, Huang said.

As the fatality rate among chickens at the poultry farm was below 3 percent, which is far lower than the average mortality rate in cases of the low- pathogenic H5N2 virus, the COA is hesitant to categorize it as an epidemic, Huang explained, adding that the council had never tried to cover up any bird flu outbreak.
All the remaining 18,000 chickens at the farm were culled in an effort to keep the situation under control, he added.
Later Wednesday, Japan announced that it will immediately halt poultry meat imports from Taiwan on a temporary basis.
Japan's Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries announced on its official Web site that it made the decision to prevent the H5N2 bird flu virus from entering the country.
The Japanese ministry said that the problem was not one of food safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: District court ordered to reconsider ex-president's release

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court ordered the Taipei District Court Wednesday to reconsider its earlier decision to release former President Chen Shui-bian without bail pending trial on corruption and money laundering charges.
The high court gave the order after the Supreme Prosecutors Office's Special Investigation Division (SID) filed an appeal Tuesday against Chen's release early last Saturday.

In the appeal presented to the Taiwan High Court, the prosecutors said they will soon begin to investigate several other corruption cases allegedly involving Chen and his wife, and that if he is allowed to remain free, some of the witnesses, including three of his former close aides, might not dare to tell the truth.

High court spokesman Wen Yao-yuan echoed the SID prosecutors' concerns, saying that the possibility of Chen colluding with witnesses and co-defendants in the cases to tamper with or destroy evidence before the trial cannot be excluded.
Against this backdrop, Wen said, the district court should reconsider the case and return a new ruling.

In response, Taipei District Court spokesman Huang Chun-ming said that as the SID prosecutors stated in their appeal that they hoped the high court itself would return a new ruling, the district court had sent all relevant files and documents to the high court.
"Therefore, we have to wait until all those documents are sent back to the district court to hand down a new ruling," Huang said.
If all goes well, he added, the district court will open a hearing on the appeal Thursday afternoon at the earliest.

Chen was released Dec.13 upon his own recognizance, despite a request by prosecutors to keep him in custody, after he had been detained for 32 days as prosecutors prepared four cases against him. After four months of investigations, he and 13 other people were indicted Dec. 12 on charges of embezzlement, bribe-taking and money laundering.
Chen and his wife were indicted for embezzling NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They were also charged with accepting bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.
The prosecutors recommended that the former president be given the harshest possible sentence for his alleged crimes involving nearly half a billion new Taiwan dollars.

They also demanded severe penalties for his wife, son and daughter-in-law for their "unrepentant attitude" in the course of the investigations, and recommended commuted sentences for 10 other defendants whom prosecutors said had been cooperative and helpful in the process of the investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP urges former president to reflect on his morality issues

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) expects indicted former President Chen Shui-bian to reflect on the morality issues pertaining to himself and his family, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Wednesday.

In an interview with reporters following a meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee, Cheng said that DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen had made the appeal to the former president in a letter to the editor of a local newspaper.

In the letter published in the Chinese-language China Times Wednesday, Tsai said, "We expect him to set an example for the society. He must reflect upon the morality issues pertaining to himself and his family, and face the law bravely."
Cheng noted that the DPP chairwoman had already apologized to the Taiwan people on behalf of the DPP over the corruption and money laundering scandals implicating the former president and his family.

Cheng said Tsai's apology represented the party's own introspection, as the former president was a part of the DPP although he and his wife withdrew from the party in August after admitting that they had wired large sums of money abroad.
Asked whether the former president also needs to engage in introspection, Cheng said, "We do have expectations."

The DPP's call on Chen and his family to face the law came a day after DPP Legislator Chiu Yi-ying, a former staunch supporter of the ex-president, urged the four indicted members of the former first family, especially former first lady Wu Shu-jen, to "face the law, instead of telling more lies and fooling around with the feelings of the DPP members."
Chen and his wife were indicted last week on charges of embezzlement, bribe- taking, money laundering and forgery in four cases.

According to the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutor's Office, Chen and his wife embezzled NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They also took bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.
The prosecutors recommended that the former president be given the harshest possible sentence for his alleged crimes involving nearly half a billion new Taiwan dollars.

They also demanded severe penalties for his wife, son and daughter-in-law for their "unrepentant attitude" in the course of investigations, and recommending commuted sentences for 10 other defendants whom prosecutors said had been cooperative and helpful in the process of the investigations.

Chen was released Dec. 13 upon his own recognizance shortly after the indictment, despite a request by prosecutors to keep him in custody, after he had been detained for 32 days as prosecutors prepared their cases against him.

The prosecutors have filed an appeal with the Taiwan High Court against Chen's release, contending that, as they still need to investigate several other corruption cases involving Chen and his wife, some of the witnesses might not dare to tell the truth if he is allowed to remain free.

The prosecutors also said they still need to trace NT$570 million (US$17.29 million) in bribe money, and that if Chen is not in custody, he could erase the evidence, as he tried to do before he was detained.

DOC.HEADLINE: Air carrier aborts plan to take passengers on panda flight

TEXT.P: The air carrier that is scheduled to transport a gift of two giant pandas from China to Taiwan abandoned a plan Wednesday to invite passengers to travel aboard the same flight with the animals.

Eva Airways, which will fly to Chengdu, Sichuan province, Dec. 22 and bring them back to Taiwan the next day, announced Tuesday that it was making seats available for 100 people on the flight to Taiwan.
However, the airline abruptly withdrew the offer Wednesday after it drew flak from animal conservationists.

The conservationists argued that pandas are shy animals and that they should be disturbed as little as possible during the transportation process. In response, EVA Air said it "decided to accept the suggestion of the experts."
Eva officials said those travel agents that have accepted reservations will cancel them.

China first offered the pandas as a gift in 2005, but the offer was rejected by the then Democratic Progressive Party government, which feared that China would use the "domestic" transfer of the endangered animals to denigrate Taiwan's sovereign status.
