DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 18, or the 21th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1787: New Jersey becomes the third state of the United States.
1825: Tsar Nicholas I succeeds to the Russian throne.
1829: Jean Baptiste Pierre Antoine de Monet Lamarck, one of France's best scientists, dies at the age of 75. His most important work was the study of evolution.
1865: The United States abolishes slavery.
1911: Wu Ting-fang, representative of anti-Ching revolutionaries, holds peace talks in Shanghai with Tang Chao-yi, representative of the Ching government.
1913: Willy Brandt, German statesman and chancellor of West Germany from 1969 to 1974, is born.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty and was a leader of the "Miaoli Incident," is arrested by the Japanese in Tamsui.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, who was appointed commander of the National Revolutionary Army on June 5, 1926, captures Wuhan (Hankow), which had been proclaimed the capital of the Nationalist government by a left-wing group of the Kuomintang on Jan. 1, 1927.
1941: German forces retreat in North Africa during World War II.
1956: Japan is admitted into the United Nations.
1961: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic ties with Upper Volta.
1965: Nine African states break diplomatic ties with Britain over Rhodesia.
1969: Britain formally abolishes the death penalty.
1969: The ROC's first satellite ground station is established, enabling satellite communications with the United States, Japan and Thailand.
1976: Thanat Khoman, former Thai foreign minister, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1980: Soviet Premier Aleksei Nikolayevich Kosygin, who succeeded Nikita Khrushchev but was often overshadowed by the Communist Party secretary, Leonid Brezhnev, dies at the age of 76.
1985: Chang Fu-lin, the first Chinese-American astronaut, flies aboard the space shuttle Columbia.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government announces that it will cease to issue lottery tickets starting in 1988.
1987: In South Korea, Roh Ta-woo is declared the winner of the first presidential election to be held in 16 years. However, students riot, claiming electoral corruption.
1987: The "Hai Lung," a submarine purchased by the Republic of China from the Netherlands, arrives in Kaohsiung.
1989: The European Economic Community signs a 10-year trade pact with the Soviet Union.
1991: The first international project to save the world's rainforests is launched when the World Bank, the European Commission, and the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations grant Brazil US$250 million for conservation work in the Amazon basin.
1992: Kim Young-sam, a member of South Korea's Democratic Liberal Party, is elected the country's first civilian president after 32 years of military rule.
1998: Andrew Lavern Smith is put to death in the state of South Carolina, becoming the 500th person to be executed in the United States since capital punishment was reinstated in 1977.
1999: Construction on Taiwan's first national children's hospital, to be operated by National Taiwan University Hospital, is begun.
1999: TransAsia Airways formally opens passenger flight services between Taipei and the Thai island of Phuket.
2000: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world's biggest semiconductor manufacturer, sets a record by delivering the world's first batch of 12-inch wafers ordered by a customer.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian presides over a ceremony marking the commissioning of the nation's first F-16 fighter wing into service held at Chiayi Air Base in southern Taiwan.
2001: The Central News Agency (CNA) and the MiTAC-Synnex Group enter into a strategic alliance to offer speedy corporate news and commercial and industrial information services in Chinese to domestic and global enterprises.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Study without thinking is labor lost. Thinking without study is perilous. To give oneself up to the study of metaphysical theories -- that is very injurious indeed. Shall I teach you what is understanding? To know what it is that you know, and to know what it is that you do not know -- that is understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Suspected bird flu outbreak causes tens of millions in losses: COA

TEXT.P: A suspected outbreak of bird flu reported recently in southern Taiwan has caused the local poultry industry tens of million of New Taiwan dollars in losses, the Council of Agriculture (COA) estimated Thursday.
COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung reiterated that Taiwan should be considered free of bird flu unless a second test of the suspected case turns up positive.

The council has asked Taiwan's representative office in Japan help communicate with Japanese authorities following their decision to suspend poultry meat imports from Taiwan over the incident, Chen said.

On Wednesday, the COA reported that approximately 400 chickens were found dead at a poultry farm in Luchu township, Kaohsiung County in late October and that preliminary findings showed the birds had been infected with low-pathogenic H5N2 bird flu virus -- a strain that is not known to jump to humans.
A reexamination is still under way to determine the cause of the deaths. All the remaining 18,000 chickens at the farm were culled as a precautionary measure, according to the COA.
The COA disclosed the information in an attempt to clarify a media report that accused the COA of trying to cover up a bird flu outbreak.
Japan announced later that day that it will halt poultry meat imports from Taiwan on a temporary basis to prevent the H5N2 bird flu virus from entering the country.

Hsu Tien-lai, head of the COA's Animal Husbandry Department, said Thursday that even if the second test ruled out a bird flu infection, Japanese authorities will not resume the imports immediately but will first conduct an evaluation, which can take several months.
COA statistics show that the poultry meat and egg exports from Taiwan to Japan are valued at around US$28 million per year.

In the first 11 months of this year, Taiwan exported to Japan 4,733 tons of duck meat worth US$22.86 million, 1,758 tons of chicken meat worth US$2.19 million, and 639 tons of eggs worth US$2.48 million, according to the COA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Zoo simulates opening of panda house

TEXT.P: The Taipei Zoo conducted a simulation exercise Thursday morning to see whether its panda house could accommodate the expected influx of visitors after two giant pandas from China are delivered to Taiwan on Dec. 23.
According to zoo authorities, the panda house was opened for an hour Thursday morning for the simulation activity.

Taipei City government spokesperson and the Department of Information and Tourism Commissioner Yang Hsiao-tung, who joined the activity, said the gift of the two pandas from China will take just under three hours to be delivered to the Taiwan.
The animals, named Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, will be taken from
their home at the China Panda-protection Research Center in
Ya'an to the international airport in Chengdu where they will be
put on board an EVA Air flight at around 2 p.m., Dec. 23,
according to Yang.
Immediately after their arrival at Taiwan's Taoyuan International airport, the two pandas will be taken directly to their new home at the Taipei Zoo under police escort, he added.
Mainland Chinese authorities are scheduled to hold a farewell ceremony for the pandas before they leave China, he said.
Eva Air had originally offered 100 seats to passengers on the flight to Taiwan carrying the pandas, but it aborted the plan on Wednesday on animal rights concerns.

After discussions with animal protection experts from mainland China, EVA Air called off the plan to have 100 tourists travel on the same flight with the animals, Yang said, stressing that "this was not a Taipei City government decision."
The animal protection experts contended that as pandas are very shy animals they should endure as little disturbance as possible on the flight from China to Taiwan.
On the question of whether the panda house would be open to the public during the Lunar New Year holidays, Yang said this would depend on the health of the two animals.

However, he added, the fact that the Taipei Zoo has been able to secure the right to house the rare pandas is a reflection of the recognition it has gained for its animal protection and environmental conservation efforts.
"I am very confident that these two pandas will receive the best possible care at the zoo," said Yang.

While the pandas will be housed at the zoo immediately after they are delivered to Taiwan, they will remain in quarantine for at least a month before public viewing will be allowed. Zoo officials hope the pandas can make their public debut in Taiwan around the Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan. 26.
China offered the two pandas as gift to Taiwan in 2005 during an ice-breaking visit to Beijing by then opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan.
The names Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, which together mean "reunion" or "unification" in Chinese, were selected by the Chinese authorities by means of an online poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cancer patient dies in hospital fire

TEXT.P: A cancer patient died after a fire broke out at the National Taiwan University Hospital while he was undergoing surgery, the hospital said Thursday.

The patient, a man suffering from esophageal cancer, was one of two patients being operated on when a fire broke out around 7:22 p.m. Wednesday in the operating room on the 4th floor of the hospital's new building, according to the hospital.

The automatic sprinkler system was activated after the fire started, but smoke continued to belch out in the surgical rooms where 11 surgeons and nurses were performing surgeries on the patient and another patient suffering from heart disease.
Both patients were under general anaesthesia.

The cancer patient was rushed to the intensive care ward of the hospital and urgently fitted with an ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation) device, which is similiar to a heart-lung machine, but he died at 0:05 a.m. Thursday, the hospital said.

The 11 medical professionals as well as the other patient suffered various degrees of smoke inhalation. The medical staff as well as the heart patient were in stable situation after receiving treatment, the hospital said.
The hospital evacuated 800 patients and urgently arranged 23 patients who had to rely on respirators to be transferred to other hospitals.
The fire was put out at 9:10 p.m.
It was the first serious fire that occurred at the hospital's new building since it was inaugurated in September 1991.
Police are investigating the cause of the blaze.
The hospital resumed between 60 percent to 70 percent of its scheduled surgeries Thursday. A health examination service which was suspended Thursday will also be resumed Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices finished higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 46.79 points, or 1.0 percent, to close at 4,694.81.

Posting gains for the fourth consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,674.36 and fluctuated between 4,694.81 and 4,625.69. A total of 4.14 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$62.12 billion (US$1.92 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp shares rising the most at 5.3 percent. Construction stocks gained 4.53 percent, cement shares moved up 3.44 percent, foodstuff issues advanced 3.06 percent, textile stocks increased 2.37 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks rose 0.86 percent, banking and financial shares were up 0.62 percent, and machinery and electronics shares rose 0.47 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 880 to 573, with 287 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$2.05 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Direct cross-strait links aimed at boosting private sector: premier

TEXT.P: The government's policy of establishing direct air, shipping and postal links between Taiwan and China is aimed at benefiting the local private sector, Premier Liu Chao-shuan said during an Executive Yuan meeting Thursday.

I hope that all businesses in the private sector will reap the advantages and benefits of the direct links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, " said Liu. "I also hope that all government agencies will be able to meet the needs of the people and answer their questions on this issue."

Noting that the establishment of direct air transportation, shipping links and postal exchanges between Taiwan and China was implemented on Dec. 15, Liu said this was achieved by the current administration under the principle of doing what is best for the people.
"In the past, direct links were discussed but were not realized," said Liu, adding that President Ma Ying-jeou has fulfilled his election promise on this issue.

Given the significantly lower costs and shorter time to transport cargo and passengers now between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan's economy is expected to get a shot in the arm from the new links, the premier said.
"The government should grasp this opportunity to do what is best for the private sector so that businessmen and ordinary citizens would be able to take advantage of the new openings," he suggested.
The private sector estimates that the establishment of two-way direct cross- strait transport links would save Taiwan up to US$90 million per year in travel and shipping costs.

Because the investment environment in mainland China has undergone drastic changes in recent years, particularly in the areas of environmental protection and labor and tax laws, operation costs for Taiwan businessmen in China have increased, according to Liu.
Therefore, we would also like to use the direct cross-strait transportation and shipping links to lure Taiwan businessmen in the China to invest at home," he said.

With this in mind, the premier said, he has directed all government agencies to evaluate the current situation and propose new plans to enhance Taiwan's competitiveness so as to maximize the benefits of the direct cross-strait links.
Liu said while the benefits of the exchanges between the two sides will increase exponentially, it can also be expected that some problems will emerge.
"I am asking the Mainland Affairs Council to look at the possible issues that could arise," he said.

Liu said that he hopes that the establishment of regular dialogue between the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), will lead to the peaceful and fruitful development of cross-strait relations.
The launch of direct cross-strait shipping links is one of four agreements sealed by the two sides Nov. 4 to expand transport exchanges, postal services and establish a food safety mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins 6 golds in international student science olympiad

TEXT.P: Taiwan has won six gold medals in an international high school student science competition in South Korea, with each of its six participants bringing home gold, an official of the Ministry of Education said late Wednesday.
The six award-winning students are Tung Yu-hung, Chao Ling-ya, and Huang Po-wei from northern Taiwan, Chen Yu-hsiang and Hsu Tzu-min from central Taiwan, and Wu Kuan-jung from southern Taiwan.
The students were selected this summer and received coaching at National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU) in Taipei City in preparation for the competition.
The 2008 International Junior Science Olympiad, held from Dec. 6-15, drew 253 students from 43 countries.
The competition is held annually for students under the age of 16 to test their knowledge in physics, chemistry, and biology.
The competition is held in three areas -- an examination in pure physics, chemistry and biology; a theoretical segment; and a practical segment that combines the three subjects.

Lo Pei-hua, a science coach and an associate researcher at NTNU's Science Education Center, said in Taipei that Tung, a junior high school student from Taipei Fuhsing Private School, had the top score in the theoretical tests, which won him the Best Theory prize.
The Taiwan and South Korea teams were the only two that had the distinction of all their members winning gold, although overall South Korea's scores were slightly higher than Taiwan's, Lo said.

While the Taiwan students were coached to ensure that they all attained the required level of proficiency in science, they had to rely on their own ability to achieve success in the competition, and they sacrificed many of their other interests to do so, Lo said.
Taiwan won five golds and one silver in each of the first three years of the contest, and took six golds in last year's competition, which it hosted, the education official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for December advancing 74 points to end at 4,699, with 87,267 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for January gained 74 points to finish at 4,699, with 87,267 contracts traded, while February futures increased 65 points to close at 4,675, with 263 contracts changing hands.

March futures advanced 59 points to close at 4,657, with 20 contract transactions, while June futures rose 36 points to finish at 4,598, with 25 contract transactions. September futures gained 60 points to close at 4,434, with six contracts changing hands.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,625 for January, 4,610 for February, 4,598 for March, 4,562 for June and 4,374 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 46.79 points to finish at 4,694.81, on turnover of NT$62.12 billion (US$1.92 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
January TE futures rose 1.65 points to close at 178, with 4,683 contracts traded, while February TE futures dropped 1.15 points to finish at 176.95, with seven contract transactions.
September TE futures fell 8.6 points to finish at 162, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March and June.
January TF futures gained 2.4 points to finish at 594.6, with 3,794 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures increased 1 point to finish at 592.2, with 19 contracts traded.

March TF futures lost 3.8 points to end at 580, with one contract traded, while June TF futures dropped 3.6 points to close at 575, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.249 to close at NT$32.471.
A total of US$1.71 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.72 before dropping to a low of NT$32.432 during the day's session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholar urges government to prepare Taiwan for immigrant issues

TEXT.P: In a conference held Thursday to mark International Migrants day, a scholar warned that the government should consider and better prepare the country for issues regarding to immigrants, especially a second wave of immigrants - their dependents, including elderly parents and children.

Dependent migrants will become the biggest challenge on the migrant population issue in the future, Ko Chyong-fang, researcher of the Institute of European and American Studies at the Academia Sinica, told a conference.

The conference, which focused on immigration trends worldwide, was organized by the National Immigration Agency (NIA) under the Ministry of the Interior to mark International Migrants Day, which falls on Dec. 18 each year.
Ko said foreign spouses married to Taiwanese residents here will eventually bring to Taiwan his or her family members from their original countries.

Up to now, Taiwan's laws have made it difficult for the island's largest group of immigrants - those from mainland China - to sponsor their family members from China here, but the government recently announced it plans to lift restrictions to make Taiwan's immigration rules on par with developed countries, such as the United States, where family unification is considered an immigration priority.

If an amendment to the law is passed by Taiwan's legislature, mainland spouses will be able to sponsor children under 12 from a previous marriage to come to Taiwan, without having to waiting the prohibitive 13 years as they do now.
Ko said that receiving immigrants who hold dependent visas is becoming a global trend of human rights, urging the government to look into the issue.

To reduce social problems due to inter-cultural or inter-racial marriages, Ko suggested that the government also enhance gender rights education and improve the mechanism of interviewing foreign spouses. Other than mainland women, Southeast Asian women from Vietnam and other countries, are also marrying Taiwanese men in large numbers. Many of them arrive without an understanding of the local language or culture.
Ko stressed that Taiwanese residents should fully understand the new immigrantsoriginal cultures and histories, in order to avoid conflicts.

Difference (between us and new immigrants) is not a problem of right and wrong or superior and inferior,Ko said. The divorce rate in marriages involving Taiwanese and foreign spouses is considered by some government officials and scholars to be high, although the divorce rate in marriages between Taiwanese people is also high.

In terms of education and counselling for new immigrants, Ko said awell- organized system of learning Mandarin should be established and that local authorities need to set up cross-border marriage service centers.
The United Nations designated the International Migrants Day in 2000 to raise awareness of the world's 200 million migrants' contribution to social and economic development.
According to the NIA, the number of new immigrants in Taiwan has reached 410,000, including 270,000 from China and the rest coming mostly from Southeast Asia.

If foreign workers and other white-collar migrants are included, the number would be more than 900,000. There are around 365,000 blue collar foreign laborers in Taiwan, many of whom work in the manufacturing, household services, caretaker and construction sectors. Some of them fall victim to high fees charged by recruitment agencies and other abuses.

Along with the conference, two exhibitions displaying immigrants' cultures, also organized by the NIA, will be staged over the weekend at the Taichung train station in central Taiwan's Taichung city and at the Central Park metro station in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
In Taipei, a fair will be held at the Huashan Cultural and Creative Industry Center Saturday, to allow people a chance to appreciate new immigrants' dances, music and foods.

DOC.HEADLINE: Live-fire Hankuang war games to take place every two years: MND

TEXT.P: The live-fire Hankuang war games will now be held every two years instead of annually, Defense Minister Chen Chao-min said Thursday.
Speaking at a meeting at the Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee, Chen said that the 25th Hankuang war games, which were scheduled for 2009, will held in 2010 instead.

Chen said that the annual schedule does not allow enough time to work out the kinks in the computerized warfare simulation, live-fire military drills and other demonstrations that are part of the Hankuang war games.
"Since I assumed the post of defense minister in May, I've found that the problems have been piling up without being effectively tackled," Chen said.

He added that this prompted him to reschedule the frequency of the military exercises, which are intended to solidify the military's joint warfare plan among the branches of the armed forces and sharpen their defense and combat readiness.

When asked by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang whether the computer- simulated war games, code-named "Yu Shan," will continue to be held annually as they were under the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party administration from 2000-2008, Chen said that the National Security Council (NSC) was in charge of the "Yu Shan" war games and it would be up to the NSC to determine whether or not the exercises should continue annually.
The "Yu Shan" simulation was aimed at countering a possible invasion by Chinese armed forces.

Meanwhile, effective from 2009, the regular troop training cycle will be changed from one year to 18 months, according to Chiu Kuo-cheng, deputy chief of General Staff for Operations and Planning, Ministry of National Defense, who was also at the interpellation session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumption vouchers to be distributed Jan. 18: interior ministry

TEXT.P: The shopping vouchers that will be issued by the government to stimulate consumption will be ready for distribution to the public Jan. 18, with more than 23.18 million people eligible to receive them, the Ministry of the Interior said Thursday.

Under the program, all Taiwanese citizens -- with the exception of those living abroad without an identity card, household registration or residency rights -- and their foreign spouses will be eligible to each receive NT$3,600 in vouchers.
The restriction, however, does not apply to diplomatic officials and their dependents whose household registrations have been invalidated because they have lived overseas for long periods of time.
Children born by the end of March 2009 who are registered as citizens of the Republic of China will also be eligible to receive the vouchers.

Vice Minister of the Interior Chien Tai-land told a news conference that the vouchers can be picked up in person at designated distribution centers that will operate from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Jan. 18, or a proxy can be assigned to collect the vouchers on the behalf of the principal recipient.

Those who are not able to turn up Jan 18. can pick up the vouchers at designated stations between Feb. 7 and April 30, Chien said, adding that those who fail to claim the vouchers by the deadline will automatically waive their right to obtain them.
In the event of the death of an eligible recipient before the vouchers are obtained, his or her legal heirs can get the vouchers instead, Chien said.
According to the government's plan, the deadline for exchanging the vouchers for goods or services is Sept. 30, 2009.
Each set will consist of six vouchers valued at NT$500, and three at NT$200. Users will not be issued change from a purchase that is less than the face value of the voucher used.
Also on Thursday, the Government Information Office unveiled samples of the vouchers, which have various security features to prevent counterfeit.

For example, the vouchers were printed using the gravure technology and a color-shifting ink that changes from copper to green, said Chou Chung-hsing, director of the Technical Research and Development Office at the Central Engraving and Printing Plant.
Other features include invisible characters, a watermark in the shape of a plum blossom and invisible fluorescent fibers, Chou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung launches test run of hybrid buses

TEXT.P: Taiwan's southern city of Kaohsiung has launched a test run of two hybrid buses that use both hydrogen and fuel, in an attempt to determine whether the hybrid technology can help reduce fuel cost, city government officials said Thursday.

As the first city in Taiwan to test the hybrid bus, Wang Kwo- tsai -- director- general of the city's transportation bureau -- noted that if the six-month test run produces satisfactory results, all of the city's 440 public buses will use the hybrid system.
Wang said that after using the hybrid technology developed by a Taiwan-based manufacturer, Epoch Energy Technology Corp., each bus will use much less fuel and emit much less carbon dioxide.

The technology uses a catalyst to break down water into hydrogen and oxide. While the hydrogen is used to power the car, the oxide is used to amplify the combustion effect, according to the Web site of the company which produced the technology.

For each bus, 2,500 liters of diesel fuel can be saved every year -- representing a NT$50,000 (US$1,540) reduction in annual fuel cost, while carbon emissions will be 6.7 tons less per bus per year, according to the city government.
Switching all buses to hybrid fuel will help the city reduce its annual fuel cost by NT$22 million and total carbon emissions by 2, 948 tons, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poultry farmers complain of impact of unconfirmed bird flu reports

TEXT.P: Japan's decision to halt poultry imports from Taiwan following a news report about a suspected bird flu outbreak on the island has sparked widespread discontent among Taiwan's poultry farmers, who demanded Thursday that the government swiftly resolve the problem.
Poultry farmers, particularly those in southern Taiwan, complained that their livelihood will be impacted and lashed out at what they called irresponsible media reports.

The problem was sparked Wednesday when the Liberty Times reported that a large number of chickens at a poultry farm in Tainan County were confirmed by a government laboratory to have died from the H5N2 bird flu virus last month. The report alleged that the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) sought to cover up the matter so as not to mar the launch of direct air, shipping and postal links between Taiwan and mainland China on Monday.

The COA denied the report. Huang Kuo-ching, deputy director of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, said Wednesday that there is no H5N2 avian flu outbreak in Taiwan, except for an incident in late October at a poultry farm in Luchu township, Kaohsiung County.

As the fatality rate among chickens at the farm was below 3 percent, which is far lower than the average mortality rate in cases of the low-pathogenic H5N2 virus, the COA was hesitant to categorize it as an epidemic, Huang explained, adding that the council did not try to cover up any bird flu outbreak.
All the remaining 18,000 chickens at the farm were culled in an effort to prevent a spread, Huang said, adding that the situation was under control and that nothing unusual has been detected so far.

Despite the COA's explanation, Japan announced later Wednesday that it was immediately halting poultry meat imports from Taiwan on a temporary basis to prevent the H5N2 bird flu virus from entering its territory.

Tang Jung-sheng, chairman of the Kaohsiung County chicken-raising association, said Thursday that such unconfirmed reports will hurt the domestic industry, particularly at the current time of economic recession when consumers are paring back spending and buying less chicken.

Representatives of industry associations across the country will call a meeting Thursday in central Taiwan's Changhua County to discuss countermeasures in the face of the latest development, said Tang.

An executive at the Taiwan's largest frozen poultry meat exporting company said the Liberty Times report has dealt a heavy blow to Taiwan's frozen duck meat exports to Japan. One of his company's duck meat containers shipped to Japan has been destroyed there, he said.

Taiwan's frozen chicken meat exports are uncompetitive in the international market, but the company's duck meat exports are popular in Japan and are sold in the quality-conscious Japanese market at a similar price level as U.S. beef, he said.
Duck farmers urged the COA to quickly provide a clear explanation to Japan to help farmers reduce possible losses.

Chen Chien-chu, a duck raiser in Fongyuan township in Changhua County in central Taiwan said he felt very distressed after learning of the news, since most of his ducks are exported to Japan at a very stable price.

"Poultry farmers suffer a lot of monetary losses every time there are such news report," Chen complained. "I lost some NT$2 million (U$60,000) in just one month last time when there was a similar false report," he said.
The value of Taiwan's poultry meat exports to Japan totals around US$23 million per year, with frozen duck meat as the bulk.
In 2007, Japan imported 5,128 tons of poultry meat and 148 tons of chicken eggs from Taiwan, Japanese government statistics showed.
The COA is still trying to track the cause of the deaths among the dead chickens, and will publish the findings upon completion of tests, the COA's Huang said.
Meanwhile, the impact of the Japan's newest measure is relatively small in the rest of the country where the poultry industry is not prominent.

DOC.HEADLINE: First review of draft FDA act approved by legislative committees

TEXT.P: Two legislative committees jointly approved a draft law Thursday to set up the Taiwan Food and Drug Administration (TFDA) , paving the way for its submission to the Legislative Yuan for further discussion.

At the meeting, which was attended by members of the Health, Environment and Labor Committee and the Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee, the TFDA Organic Law was approved with several modifications, including a clause added to set up a review committee to ensure the effectiveness and safety of food and drug products.

Under the organic law approved by the Cabinet in late November, four offices and bureaus presently under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) will be integrated to form the TFDA, with a staff of 505 people.
The four bureaus are the Bureau of Food Safety, the Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, the Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis and the National Bureau of Controlled Drugs.
DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said the new institution will help strengthen control at source, speed up procedures at customs and enhance consumer safety.

He added that the DOH has been censured twice by the Control Yuan recently -- once because of its inept handling of the recent scandal of melamine-tainted milk powder imported from China and again because of its handling of a case in which dragon fruit imported from Vietnam was found to be contaminated by pesticide residue -- an indication that improvements need to be made in border controls.
"Three management centers will be set up in northern, central and southern Taiwan, respectively, in order to enhance border controls and testing at seaports and airports," said Yeh.
At present, border controls and testing is under the purview of the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
In addition, food and drinks businesses will be included under the TFDA's management, Yeh noted.
The TFDA is also expected to be tasked with helping to develop Taiwan's bio- medicine.

Legislators at the meeting also suggested that the DOH should enforce more controls on Chinese products, especially with the implementation of direct flights and shipping links that began earlier in the week.

Chang Hsien-yao, a ruling Kuomintang legislator who also presented his own version of the draft law, proposed that in addition to border controls, the TFDA should further undertake offshore controls on imported goods in regions deemed to be high-risk.

The process of the TFDA's establishment was expedited after the melamine scandal of September in which milk powder, creamers and some other milk products imported from China were found to contain melamine, a toxic industrial compound that can cause kidney stones and in extreme cases, renal failure.
The incident, which sparked panic among consumers, helped raise awareness among the public and the government of the necessity of better food safety measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin school children help consume oranges

TEXT.P: School children in southern Taiwan's Yunlin County will be treated to orange juice twice a week from Thursday as part of the county government's efforts to promote the locally produced fruit amid a glut in supply.

Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen led teachers and students of Nanyang Elementary School to drink a cup of orange juice in the school's sports field, in a gesture endorsing a campaign launched by the county government to encourage the public to consume more home grown oranges.

The agricultural-based Yunlin County in southwestern Taiwan is one of the country's major orange production areas. It has been suffering from a severe price drop in Taiwan's market due to excessive supply and insufficient demand.

Starting Thursday, some 80,000 students at local primary and junior high schools will be able to enjoy a cup of orange juice twice a week during lunch, after a decision was made in a meeting between county officials and school principals earlier this week.

Su thanked the school authorities for agreeing to take part in the promotion campaign and hailed it as a great help to farmers. As many as one ton of oranges can be consumed during one lunch by students at the Nanyang and Beikang elementary schools alone, Su noted.
Some 3,500 hectares of farmland in Yunlin are reserved for cultivating oranges -- and the land can yield more than 80,000 metric tons of the fruit this year.
The amount of oranges produced is apparently more than the domestic market can consume, as more growers have dedicated more land to cultivating the fruit in recent years.
Apart from elementary and middle schools, the Yunlin county government is also cooperating with restaurantes and supermarkets across the country to sell its oranges.

Last week, the Yunlin county government launched an "Orange Day" activity from Dec. 15 - Jan. 25, a period during which Taiwanese consumers can buy fine- quality Yunlin oranges at 120 specially designated venues across the country.
Yunlin authorities have also managed to sell the produce to overseas markets, including China, Southeast Asia, Europe and the United States.
Last month, China ordered 1,200 metric tons of Taiwanese oranges at above market prices of NT$13 (US$0.4) per kilogram as a goodwill gesture during its top negotiator Chen Yunlin's visit to Taiwan.
The first batch of the order was shipped to China on board a Taiwanese vessel on Monday when direct shipping links were inaugurated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes financial MOU with China could cover insurance sector

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to sign a financial memorandum of understanding (MOU) with China covering the banking, securities and insurance sectors in the next round of cross-strait talks, an official of the nation's top financial regulatory body said Thursday.
Lee Jih-chu, vice chairwoman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, noted that the talks on the signing of an MOU on banking and securities have been going smoothly.

Lee noted that China requires the signing of an MOU before foreign, including Taiwanese, financial institutions can engage in financial operations in China, but the requirement only covers the banking and securities sectors, without including the insurance sector.
Despite Taiwan and China not having signed such an MOU, two Taiwanese insurance companies - Cathay Life Insurance and Taiwan Life Insurance - have begun insurance operations in China, Lee said.
The MOU is expected to provide protection for Taiwanese companies operating in China.

Under Chinese law, foreign insurance institutions with at least US$5 billion assets and 30 years of experience in the insurance sector and have set up representative offices in China for at least two years can apply to set up branches and engage in insurance operations.
Currently four Taiwanese insurance companies meet the above requirement, Lee said.
Under the circumstances, Taiwanese insurance companies that enter China will be big companies, and the FSC will definitely want to have access to information on their operations in China, she added.
"If an MOU is not signed between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, then the FSC will be unable to regulate Taiwan's insurance companies operating in China," she added.
Lee said that it has reached initial consensus with Beijing-based China Insurance Regulatory Commission on covering the insurance sector in the MOU to be signed between the two sides.
But as the part on insurance sector is not as urgent as the banking and securities sectors, Lee said she is not sure whether an MOU will eventually cover this part.

The FSC was established on July 1, 2004 to promote an integrated financial supervision. The primary objectives of the commission are to consolidate the supervision of the banking, securities and insurance sectors, and to act as a single regulator for all of these industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Owner of Asia's largest container ship eyeing Kaohsiung Harbor

TEXT.P: China's COSCO Group, owner and operator of one of the largest container ships in the world, is eyeing Kaohsiung Harbor as a transshipment center to bolster its transshipping and logistics services.

The 10,000-TEU (20-foot equivalent unit) COSCO Oceania anchored at Kaohsiung Harbor Wednesday after the historic inauguration of direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping links Monday, unloading around 50 containers and loading some 900 containers before heading for Hong Kong en route to Europe.

The COSCO Oceania, the largest container ship in Asia and one of the largest in the world, embarked from the Chinese port of Tianjin Monday and arrived at Kaohsiung 55 hours later to become the first Chinese ship from Tianjin to visit a Taiwanese port via direct shipping links since 1949.

COSCO Group Chairman Wei Jiafu, who flew into Taiwan Monday to witness the inauguration of the direct links, attended a cocktail reception at Kaohsiung Harbor Thursday and said in an address that the COSCO Group is having an even bigger container ship built -- a 13,500-TEU vessel to be named the "COSCO Kaohsiung" -- which will ply its global routes with Kaohsiung Harbor as one of its key transshipping points.

Also speaking at the reception, Kaohsiung Harbor Administration Director-General Hsieh Ming-hui said the harbor's history will be rewritten when the COSCO Kaohsiung makes its maiden voyage to Kaohsiung Harbor in 2010.

Businessman Lee Wei-ying, who operates an export company and a customs brokerage house in Kaohsiung, said Chinese commercial ships mostly carry out their transshipment business via seaports in South Korea and Japan, but said Kaohsiung will be a hot spot for them now that direct cross-strait shipping links have been launched as they will want to capitalize on Kaohsiung's geographic convenience and excellent harbor facilities.

After a hiatus of nearly six decades, Taiwan and China resumed daily direct passenger flights, direct cargo flights and direct shipping links Dec. 15, seen by many as a step toward ending decades of hostility and cutting the cost of travel and trade between the two countries.
Ceremonies were held at seaports in China, as well as at Taiwan's Keelung, Taichung and Kaohsiung harbors, to send off the first commercial vessels plying the direct cross-strait routes.
Ships will now be able to sail between 11 ports in Taiwan and 63 ports in China, including Tianjin, Dalian, Qingdao and Shanghai, without being required to transit through a third region.

The launch of the direct links is one of four agreements sealed by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait Nov. 4 to further expand transport exchanges, set up direct postal services and address food safety issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ukrainian children's choir to perform in Changhua County

TEXT.P: A world-renowned Ukrainian children's choir will perform Saturday in Changhua County, central Taiwan, as part of a nationwide tour, a county official said Thursday.

According to the official of the county's Cultural Affairs Bureau, the Ukrainian Children's Choir of Odessa will present a variety of music, from classical pieces to folk songs, at the county's Yuanlin Performance Hall.
The choir was established in 1981 and has 80 members aged between 10 and 18, both boys and girls. However, only the 36 best of them are selected to take part in the choir's world tours.

Under the baton of Ukrainian conductor Larysa Garbuz, the choir has given performances in Yilan, Taipei, Hsinchu, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung since Dec. 11. Its next performance after Changhua will be in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan.
The official added that American pianist Thomas Hecht will perform at the same venue Dec. 21.
The piano soloist will present a piece of his own composition and will give a brief introduction to his performance at the recital.

Hecht is the head of Piano Studies at the Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music, National University of Singapore. He obtained his doctorate in piano performance from the Peabody Institute at Johns Hopkins University.

Hecht is also a chamber musician and member of the internationally acclaimed duo-piano team of Hecht and Shapiro, winners of the Munich International Two Piano Competition and the USA National Duo Piano Competition.
He will also perform in Taichung City after his Changhua show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to step up interactions with international NGOs: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/08 20:51:38 (By Jian Chen and Andrew Lee)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it will encourage international non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to set up offices in Taiwan, as part its efforts to strengthen contacts and cooperation between such groups and their Taiwanese counterparts.
David Wu, vice chairman of the ministrys NGO Affairs Committee, told a media gathering that Taiwan will modify relevant regulations to encourage more global NGOs to be located here.

Wu said it is his hope that the loosening of restrictions, including taxation and length-of-stay rules for those working for the NGOs will enable Taiwan to attract such organizations to set up their headquarters, regional branches or secretariats here.

"We wish to establish alliances with international non-profit organizations, " said Wu, speaking at a gathering the ministry organized Thursday to tell reporters about the results of Taiwan's participation in international NGO affairs.
Wu said Taiwan's NGOs are playing an ever- increasing role in the areas of human rights, politics, environmental protection and education.
"We hope to further that with their participation in international affairs," he said.
Wu said Taiwan will model itself after countries such as Thailand, where a large number of international NGOs have operations, to formulate favorable laws specifically targeting the groups.

He did not elaborate on which groups Taiwan is trying to attract, but Taiwan has long yearned for greater inclusion of the island in the activities of international health, humanitarian, and other groups.

One of the hopes of President Ma Ying-jeou in pursuing his policy of building warmer ties with China is to convince China it is not against Beijing's interest to give Taiwan more international space to operate, including in global non- governmental groups.

Beijing is opposed to Taiwan joining groups normally reserved for countries, including the United Nation and World Health Organization. It is unclear whether China will put up obstacles to Taiwan's desire for greater participation in non- governmental groups.

Meanwhile, Wu said that his committee invited the heads of 13 prominent international NGOs to visit Taiwan in the past two months alone, including a current visit by World Alliance for Citizen Participation Secretary General Ingrid Narasimhan, to promote mutual understandings and facilitate cooperation.

Wu said the ministry will at the same time provide assistance to Taiwanese NGOs in their bids to host international conferences next year, build alliances with global NGOs, as well as set up websites to share information.
The ministry has already helped Taiwanese NGOs take part in international conferences or activities, with finances provided to over 650 of them, Wu added.
From just January to November, the MOFA assisted Taiwan's various NGOs to participate in 2,028 international NGO events, Wu said.

In the preface of a book released at the media gathering Thursday, Foreign Minister Francisco H. L. Ou said that Taiwanese NGOs have come to play a vital role in the past years in domestic public affairs, including human rights, environment, public health, and humanitarian relief.
Many of them, Ou said, have also reached out to those in need around the world bearing theirLove from Taiwan" signs, which can be seen in many countries suffering from natural disasters.
Therefore, Ou said, the goal of Taiwan's NGOs to "Plant roots in Taiwan and reach out globallyis no longer a dream, but has gradually become a reality.
In 2000, the ministry established its NGO International Affairs Committee to assist Taiwan's NGOs with elevating their profile on the international stage.

The goal of the Committee is to serve as a liaison for various NGO international affairs and to coordinate and integrate relevant resources for governmental and civic groups' international participation.

DOC.HEADLINE: More temporary jobs to be created for unemployed workers: CEPD

TEXT.P: More people are expected to benefit from a temporary job creation program sponsored by the government, with over 70 new plans added to the existing project, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Thursday.
The expansion is expected to help some 69,000 jobless workers find employment under the program, an increase from the original estimate of about 56,000 people, CEPD officials said.
To date, as many as 31,000 workers have found jobs through the six-month program instigated by the Executive Yuan in November, the officials went on.
With the additional plans to be added, the program's length will also be prolonged until the end of next October, they added.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan approved funding of NT$10 billion (US$303 million) Oct. 31 to create the temporary jobs and help people in need as part of the government's efforts to improve the slipping economy and growing unemployment rate.
The short-term jobs offered in the program are mainly in the public sector, including street cleaning, community services and river inspecting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Novel method of chaotic communication proposed by physicists

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese physicists have invented a new method of chaotic communication that has proved better than the conventional ones in terms of fending off intrusions and external noise, academic sources reported Thursday.

The duo, both of whom are research fellows at Academia Sinica's Institute of Physics, uses the message carriers themselves as binary codes rather than hiding the message in the carrier, to achieve higher transmission security, according to a press release from Taiwan's top research institute.

On the receiver side, according to the press release, the user can analyze the code-embedded carriers to decrypt the message by using temporal transfer entropy, a new technology developed by Hu Chin- kun and Hung Yao-chen.

Hu explained that chaotic communications usually involve interweaving a weak message into a strong chaotic carrier -- protecting the message with the help of the carrier's randomness and disorderliness.

However, the method has become antiquated since the realization of time-series analysis, Hu continued, adding that the development necessitates a more secure communication method, such as nonlinear encryption.
In addition to use in communications, Hu went on, temporal transfer entropy can also be applied to many different scientific fields, such as neurophysiology, economics and climatology.

Their research paper on the topic -- titled Chaotic Communication via Temporal Transfer Entropy -- has been published in the Dec. 12 issue of Physical Review Letters, a leading international physics journal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei wireless e-services to include tourism, transport facilities

TEXT.P: Taipei City will work toward further developing itself into an "intelligent fiber city, " with wireless e-services to include tourism and transport facilities, Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Thursday.

Hau made the remarks during a seminar organized by the Mount Jade Science and Technology Association of Taiwan, saying that an overall plan for digital construction and application of digital technology will "make the city full of immense possibilities."

The new e- services under discussion, he went on, will include guides on the city's cycle paths and tourist attractions and notification of bus timetables, as well as information on car parking -- an expansion from the city's current offerings via wireless applications.

The mayor cited the 1999 free hotline provided by the city government as an example, saying that through synchronous computer-based processes, the government is able to respond to reports such as malfunctioning streetlamps or illegal parking with "on-the-spot limited-time solutions."

The city has also adopted digital technology in its disaster response system and public security network, Hau added, while stressing that e-services, in categories such as e-Government, e-Community and e-Life, will help increase administrative efficiency and facilitate more prompt assistance to the city's residents

He said Taipei's efforts to establish itself into an "intelligent fiber city" have gained global recognition and have been chosen as the model for the wireless and broadband city at the World Expo to be held in Shanghai in 2010.
According to the organizer, Taipei won top prize for the Intelligent Community Awards in 2006 and was also certified as the world's largest Wi-Fi network city that same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: President appeals to businesses to refrain from `excessive' layoffs

Prizes up for grabs will be 10 luxury cars, 100 TFT-LED TV sets, scores of refrigerators and many other hi-tech health and entertainment gear.

DOC.HEADLINE: Army helicopter crashes in southern mountains; 5 injured

TEXT.P: An army CH-47SD helicopter crashed into a ditch in a mountainous training battleground near Cishan township in the southern county of Kaohsiung Thursday, injuring five officers aboard, a Defense Ministry statement confirmed later that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police bust 1st drug smuggling case via cross-strait cargo charter

TEXT.P: Aviation police have seized an express delivery containing 30 kg of ketamine that was smuggled aboard a direct all-cargo charter flight across the Taiwan Strait, the Aviation Police Bureau said in a statement Thursday.

According to the statement, customs officers discovered suspicious substances when they X-rayed eight cases of articles that were shipped from the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou via a China Southern Airlines cargo charter Wednesday.
The articles were declared on the flight manifesto as hair decorations, but the ketamine -- a third-grade contraband drug -- was found concealed in the cases.

The Aviation Police Bureau formed a special team to investigate the case and based on the address on the shipment, traced a man in Changhua City in central Taiwan and arrested his wife, a Chinese citizen suspected of being involved in the smuggling.

Police said the woman, identified only by her family name of Gong, denied being aware of the drugs in the parcel, but police said they suspect she was lying because she informed a man in China of her arrest via cell phone while supposedly retaining the services of a lawyer during police questioning.

TEXT.P: A group of journalists from various Chinese provincial or municipal news media outlets arrived in Taipei Thursday to begin news coverage of Taiwan.

They were the first group of regional Chinese media journalists to be posted in Taipei since the once-icy relations across the Taiwan Strait began to warm up following the May 20 inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou who campaigned on a pledge to improve cross-strait ties by adopting a conciliatory approach.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun said the opening of the door to regional Chinese media professionals is aimed at expanding cross-strait journalistic exchanges to boost mutual understanding and good will.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ukrainian children's choir to perform in Changhua County

TEXT.P: A world-renowned Ukrainian children's choir will perform Saturday in Changhua County, central Taiwan, as part of a nationwide tour, a county official said Thursday.

According to the official of the county's Cultural Affairs Bureau, the Ukrainian Children's Choir of Odessa will present a variety of music, from classical pieces to folk songs, at the county's Yuanlin Performance Hall.
The choir was established in 1981 and has 80 members aged between 10 and 18, both boys and girls. However, only the 36 best of them are selected to take part in the choir's world tours.

Under the baton of Ukrainian conductor Larysa Garbuz, the choir has given performances in Yilan, Taipei, Hsinchu, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung since Dec. 11. Its next performance after Changhua will be in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan.
The official added that American pianist Thomas Hecht will perform at the same venue Dec. 21.
The piano soloist will present a piece of his own composition and will give a brief introduction to his performance at the recital.

Hecht is the head of Piano Studies at the Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music, National University of Singapore. He obtained his doctorate in piano performance from the Peabody Institute at Johns Hopkins University.

Hecht is also a chamber musician and member of the internationally acclaimed duo-piano team of Hecht and Shapiro, winners of the Munich International Two Piano Competition and the USA National Duo Piano Competition.
He will also perform in Taichung City after his Changhua show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to step up interactions with international NGOs: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/08 20:51:38 (By Jian Chen and Andrew Lee)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it will encourage international non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to set up offices in Taiwan, as part its efforts to strengthen contacts and cooperation between such groups and their Taiwanese counterparts.
David Wu, vice chairman of the ministrys NGO Affairs Committee, told a media gathering that Taiwan will modify relevant regulations to encourage more global NGOs to be located here.

Wu said it is his hope that the loosening of restrictions, including taxation and length-of-stay rules for those working for the NGOs will enable Taiwan to attract such organizations to set up their headquarters, regional branches or secretariats here.

"We wish to establish alliances with international non-profit organizations, " said Wu, speaking at a gathering the ministry organized Thursday to tell reporters about the results of Taiwan's participation in international NGO affairs.
Wu said Taiwan's NGOs are playing an ever- increasing role in the areas of human rights, politics, environmental protection and education.
"We hope to further that with their participation in international affairs," he said.
Wu said Taiwan will model itself after countries such as Thailand, where a large number of international NGOs have operations, to formulate favorable laws specifically targeting the groups.

He did not elaborate on which groups Taiwan is trying to attract, but Taiwan has long yearned for greater inclusion of the island in the activities of international health, humanitarian, and other groups.

One of the hopes of President Ma Ying-jeou in pursuing his policy of building warmer ties with China is to convince China it is not against Beijing's interest to give Taiwan more international space to operate, including in global non- governmental groups.

Beijing is opposed to Taiwan joining groups normally reserved for countries, including the United Nation and World Health Organization. It is unclear whether China will put up obstacles to Taiwan's desire for greater participation in non- governmental groups.

Meanwhile, Wu said that his committee invited the heads of 13 prominent international NGOs to visit Taiwan in the past two months alone, including a current visit by World Alliance for Citizen Participation Secretary General Ingrid Narasimhan, to promote mutual understandings and facilitate cooperation.

Wu said the ministry will at the same time provide assistance to Taiwanese NGOs in their bids to host international conferences next year, build alliances with global NGOs, as well as set up websites to share information.
The ministry has already helped Taiwanese NGOs take part in international conferences or activities, with finances provided to over 650 of them, Wu added.
From just January to November, the MOFA assisted Taiwan's various NGOs to participate in 2,028 international NGO events, Wu said.

In the preface of a book released at the media gathering Thursday, Foreign Minister Francisco H. L. Ou said that Taiwanese NGOs have come to play a vital role in the past years in domestic public affairs, including human rights, environment, public health, and humanitarian relief.
Many of them, Ou said, have also reached out to those in need around the world bearing theirLove from Taiwan" signs, which can be seen in many countries suffering from natural disasters.
Therefore, Ou said, the goal of Taiwan's NGOs to "Plant roots in Taiwan and reach out globallyis no longer a dream, but has gradually become a reality.
In 2000, the ministry established its NGO International Affairs Committee to assist Taiwan's NGOs with elevating their profile on the international stage.

The goal of the Committee is to serve as a liaison for various NGO international affairs and to coordinate and integrate relevant resources for governmental and civic groups' international participation.

DOC.HEADLINE: More temporary jobs to be created for unemployed workers: CEPD

TEXT.P: More people are expected to benefit from a temporary job creation program sponsored by the government, with over 70 new plans added to the existing project, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Thursday.
The expansion is expected to help some 69,000 jobless workers find employment under the program, an increase from the original estimate of about 56,000 people, CEPD officials said.
To date, as many as 31,000 workers have found jobs through the six-month program instigated by the Executive Yuan in November, the officials went on.
With the additional plans to be added, the program's length will also be prolonged until the end of next October, they added.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan approved funding of NT$10 billion (US$303 million) Oct. 31 to create the temporary jobs and help people in need as part of the government's efforts to improve the slipping economy and growing unemployment rate.
The short-term jobs offered in the program are mainly in the public sector, including street cleaning, community services and river inspecting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Novel method of chaotic communication proposed by physicists

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese physicists have invented a new method of chaotic communication that has proved better than the conventional ones in terms of fending off intrusions and external noise, academic sources reported Thursday.

The duo, both of whom are research fellows at Academia Sinica's Institute of Physics, uses the message carriers themselves as binary codes rather than hiding the message in the carrier, to achieve higher transmission security, according to a press release from Taiwan's top research institute.

On the receiver side, according to the press release, the user can analyze the code-embedded carriers to decrypt the message by using temporal transfer entropy, a new technology developed by Hu Chin- kun and Hung Yao-chen.

Hu explained that chaotic communications usually involve interweaving a weak message into a strong chaotic carrier -- protecting the message with the help of the carrier's randomness and disorderliness.

However, the method has become antiquated since the realization of time-series analysis, Hu continued, adding that the development necessitates a more secure communication method, such as nonlinear encryption.
In addition to use in communications, Hu went on, temporal transfer entropy can also be applied to many different scientific fields, such as neurophysiology, economics and climatology.

Their research paper on the topic -- titled Chaotic Communication via Temporal Transfer Entropy -- has been published in the Dec. 12 issue of Physical Review Letters, a leading international physics journal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei wireless e-services to include tourism, transport facilities

TEXT.P: Taipei City will work toward further developing itself into an "intelligent fiber city, " with wireless e-services to include tourism and transport facilities, Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Thursday.

Hau made the remarks during a seminar organized by the Mount Jade Science and Technology Association of Taiwan, saying that an overall plan for digital construction and application of digital technology will "make the city full of immense possibilities."

The new e- services under discussion, he went on, will include guides on the city's cycle paths and tourist attractions and notification of bus timetables, as well as information on car parking -- an expansion from the city's current offerings via wireless applications.

The mayor cited the 1999 free hotline provided by the city government as an example, saying that through synchronous computer-based processes, the government is able to respond to reports such as malfunctioning streetlamps or illegal parking with "on-the-spot limited-time solutions."

The city has also adopted digital technology in its disaster response system and public security network, Hau added, while stressing that e-services, in categories such as e-Government, e-Community and e-Life, will help increase administrative efficiency and facilitate more prompt assistance to the city's residents

He said Taipei's efforts to establish itself into an "intelligent fiber city" have gained global recognition and have been chosen as the model for the wireless and broadband city at the World Expo to be held in Shanghai in 2010.
According to the organizer, Taipei won top prize for the Intelligent Community Awards in 2006 and was also certified as the world's largest Wi-Fi network city that same year.

The executive pointed out that Taiwan will have about 106,600 job vacancies in technology industries in the coming three years, including 35,800 in the semiconductor sector and 17,000 in the image display sector, with other vacancies in digital content, biotechnology and communications.

He pointed out that academic training at the college will help students better prepare for future job opportunities, as those who have masters or doctoral degrees are much more likely to fill these vacancies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court upholds decision to release former president

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court rejected Thursday a request by prosecutors to detain former President Chen Shui-bian again.

In its second ruling in six days on the issue, the panel of three judges at the court stood by its decision last Saturday to free Chen on his own recognizance, a ruling that prosecutors are likely to see as detrimental to their investigation into other criminal activities in which Chen is allegedly involved.

The district court handed down the ruling after the Taiwan High Court Wednesday allowed an appeal by prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office for the court to review its earlier decision to free Chen.
In the appeal presented to the Taiwan High Court Tuesday, the prosecutors noted that they will soon begin to investigate several other corruption cases allegedly involving Chen and his wife.
If Chen is allowed to remain free, the prosecutors argued, some of the witnesses, including three of his former close aides, might not dare to tell the truth.

In its previous ruling Dec. 13, the court ordered that Chen, who was detained Nov. 12, be released without bail following his indictment, along with 13 other people, on charges of embezzlement, corruption and money laundering.
Chen and his wife are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police bust 1st drug smuggling case via cross-strait cargo charter

TEXT.P: Aviation police have seized an express delivery containing 30 kg of ketamine that was smuggled aboard a direct all-cargo charter flight across the Taiwan Strait, the Aviation Police Bureau said in a statement Thursday.

According to the statement, customs officers discovered suspicious substances when they X-rayed eight cases of articles that were shipped from the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou via a China Southern Airlines cargo charter Wednesday.
The articles were declared on the flight manifesto as hair decorations, but the ketamine -- a third-grade contraband drug -- was found concealed in the cases.

The Aviation Police Bureau formed a special team to investigate the case and based on the address on the shipment, traced a man in Changhua City in central Taiwan and arrested his wife, a Chinese citizen suspected of being involved in the smuggling.

Police said the woman, identified only by her family name of Gong, denied being aware of the drugs in the parcel, but police said they suspect she was lying because she informed a man in China of her arrest via cell phone while supposedly retaining the services of a lawyer during police questioning.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st batch of reporters from regional Chinese media arrive

TEXT.P: A group of journalists from various Chinese provincial or municipal news media outlets arrived in Taipei Thursday to begin news coverage of Taiwan.

They were the first group of regional Chinese media journalists to be posted in Taipei since the once-icy relations across the Taiwan Strait began to warm up following the May 20 inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou who campaigned on a pledge to improve cross-strait ties by adopting a conciliatory approach.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Te-hsun said the opening of the door to regional Chinese media professionals is aimed at expanding cross-strait journalistic exchanges to boost mutual understanding and good will.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 19, or the 22nd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1036: Chinese poet Su Tung-po is born.
1154: Henry II accedes to the throne of England.
1741: Vitus Bering, the Danish navigator and explorer who in 1728 sailed through the Bering Strait while exploring a route around Siberia to China, dies of scurvy at the age of 60.
1793: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte capture Toulon.
1842: The United States recognizes the independence of Hawaii.
1932: The third plenary session of the fourth Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the convening of an assembly that will meet regularly and which will give the public a voice in governmental affairs.
1941: Adolf Hitler dismisses his chief of staff and takes personal command of the German army after military setbacks.
1946: War breaks out in Indochina as Ho Chi Minh's troops launch widespread attacks against the French.
1950: General Dwight D. Eisenhower is named by the North Atlantic Council as Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers, Europe.
1965: Charles de Gaulle defeats Francois Mitterand in the French presidential election runoff.
1969: President Apollo Milton Obote of Uganda is shot and injured. He would later be overthrown by the Ugandan army in 1971.
1972: The Apollo 17 spacecraft splashes down on target in the Pacific Ocean, bringing to an end the United States' Apollo program of landing men on the moon.
1980: The States-General of the Netherlands approves the selling of two submarines to the Republic of China.
1984: Britain and mainland China sign an agreement determining the fate of Hong Kong after a 99-year lease of the territory to Britain expires in 1997. The joint declaration signed by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang spells out the terms for Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.
1985: U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy announces that he will not run in the 1988 presidential campaign.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi visits Beijing.
1990: The first stock exchange on the Chinese mainland opens in Shanghai.
1990: Albanian authorities formally recognize the country's first non-Communist party.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president of the United Soviet Socialist Republic, a country that effectively ceased to exist on Dec. 12 of the same year.
1992: The Kuomintang wins 53.02 percent of the popular vote and the Democratic Progressive Party gets 31.03 percent in the elections for the Second Legislative Yuan.
1996: The ceiling on foreign institutional investments on the Taiwan Stock Exchange is raised from US$400 million to US$600 million.
1997: A Singapore SilkAir Boeing 737-300 airliner crashes near Palembang in Indonesia, killing all 104 people on board.
1997: South Korea's newly elected president, Kim Dae-jung, proposes dialogue with North Korea as a step toward reconciliation.
1999: Chen Shui-bian calls on voters to support the DPP's Chen-Lu ticket in the March 18 presidential election and says he will do what he can to finish off the KMT's "black gold" dealings and to distribute the money held by the KMT to the populace.
1999: Macau is formally handed over to mainland China at midnight after 442 years of Portuguese colonial rule.
2000: Peter Banko, managing director Taiwan and country manager of the Bank of America, is elected as the new president of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei.
2001: ROC Vice President Annette Lu departs for Gambia to attend the inauguration of re-elected Gambian President Yahya Jammeh Dec. 21 on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius: "Read and learn everything, but suspend your judgment on anything of which you are in doubt; for the rest, be careful in what you say: in that way you will give few occasions for men to criticize what you say. Mix with the world and see everything, but keep away and do not meddle with anything that may bring you into trouble; for the rest, be careful in what you do: in that way you will have few occasions for self-reproach."
