DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Expanded links not expected to boost southern economy immediately

TEXT.P: Pingtung Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung said Friday that he does not see the launch of direct air and sea links across the Taiwan Strait Dec. 15 producing positive results overnight for business in Taiwan's southernmost county.

Tsao said that although it is undeniable that the long-expected launch of cross- strait direct daily charter flights, direct shipping and postal deliveries will be a boon to Taiwan's agricultural and tourism sectors in the long run, the results will not be immediately apparent.

Taking his county's fruit exports to China as an example, Tsao said that despite the convenience and time efficiency that the expanded direct links offer, fruit exports from Pingtung County are not expected to instantly grow by leaps and bounds.

Tsao attributed his feelings mainly to the fact that fruit constitutes only a very small portion of the typical Chinese diet, adding that it is unwise to assume the Chinese will start consuming as much fruit as the Taiwanese do.

He said Pingtung County had originally expected that the opening of direct air and sea links would bring about an increased number of Chinese tourists, who in turn would purchase fruit and other agricultural products from the county.
"This idea also did not live up to our expectations instantly, " Tsao noted.

Echoing Tsao's opinion, Tsai Shun-teh, chairman of the Taiwan Wax Apple Development Association, noted that Taiwan has exported fresh, top-quality wax apples -- also known as bell fruit -- to China for the past several years, but all to upscale markets in Beijing or Shanghai.
The Dec. 15 launch of direct air and sea links will quicken deliveries by about one day, which will help prolong the fruit's shelf live in China and ensure quality, Tsai said.

The expanded links, however, are not expected to help Pingtung's bell fruit growers to increase their top-shelf shipments to China because Chinese buyers of such expensive fruit are not likely to increase their purchases simply because of the opening of cross-strait links, Tsai continued.
"Only when we begin exporting medium-quality bell fruit to China in large quantities will Pingtung's growers begin reap noticeably increased rewards, but that day in still distant," Tsai said.
Bell fruit are a flagship agricultural product of Pingtung County, with sales to markets in Taiwan and abroad increasing year on year.

At present, most Taiwan-grown fruit is transported to China's southeastern port city of Xiamen through the Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu, a channel considered as the most economical way in terms of both travel time and shipping cost.

DOC.HEADLINE: Online purchases valued at NT$85 billion in past year: survey

TEXT.P: Nearly half of Taiwan's Internet users are online shoppers, with the value of their total purchases estimated at more than NT$85 billion (US$2.62 billion) over the past year, according to the results of an annual survey on the country's digital divide released Friday.
The survey conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) found that 49.5 percent of Internet users have made online purchases.

Seventy-one percent of the online shoppers mentioned "convenience" as their motivation for making online purchases, with the five most popular products listed as clothing and accessories; books; hotel reservations and flights, train and bus tickets; household items; and home electronics.
The results revealed that on average, each online shopper spent NT$13,565 over the past year.
The survey was carried out between July 20 and Sept. 3 among 16,131 people via telephone. It had a margin of error of 0.8 percentage points.

Based on the results, the RDEC estimated that there are 13.71 million Internet users aged 12 and older in Taiwan, up 700,000 from last year, with the increase most obvious among the older segment of the population.

The results show that 64.2 percent of those in the 41-50 age group are Internet users, compared with 58.6 percent last year, while the rate of Internet use among the 51-60 age group has risen from 35.5 percent to 40.5 percent.
The results also show that web2.0 technology is popular among Internet users under 30, especially those aged 15-20.
Among users in this age group, 57.7 percent often visit their own blogs or those of others, and that 35.1 percent do so occasionally.

More than 60 percent of Internet users aged under 20 have set up their own personal blogs, and young users are especially active in raising questions and expressing their opinions on the Internet, according to the results.

On the regional divide in terms of digitization, Hsinchu City, Taipei City and Taichung City -- where more than 70 percent of residents have used the Internet -- have been rated as the country's three most digitized cities.

However, the rate of Internet use is lower than 60 percent among residents in Pingtung County, Penghu County and Chiayi County, where farming is the dominant economic activity and where there is a relatively large elderly population.

The survey also discovered an obvious gender divide in terms of computer and Internet access among those aged 50 and older, with the rate of computer and Internet use among women lagging behind that of men by 7 percentage points to 10 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kuomintang Chairman heads to China for financial forum

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said the consensus that will be reached at the upcoming cross-Taiwan Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum will benefit both Taiwan and China, if implemented.

Wu left for Shanghai Friday morning to participate in the Dec. 20-21 forum, which will focus on establishing a mechanism for economic exchanges and expanding cooperation in the financial and service sectors.

I will make every effort so that the consensus of the forum will be to Taiwan's advantage, said Wu before boarding the plane to Shanghai.Given the global economic crisis, this forum is of great significance and importance to both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The trip marks the first time that a KMT chairman is attending the fourth such forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China as head of Taiwan's ruling party.

Wu, who is being accompanied by by government officials from the Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) and the Financial Supervisory Comission, said 140 people will participate in the conference.

He predicted that by the end of the two-day meeting, the KMT and the CPC will reach a common agenda on issues ranging from the establishment of a mechanism for economic exchanges and the expansion of cooperation in the financial and service sectors, to the promotion of cross-strait investments and cultural exchanges.
Wu said the "common agenda" will carry more weight this year because both the CPC and the KMT are ruling parties this year.
"The greatest difference between this forum and the previous one in April of 2007, is that in 2007, the KMT was Taiwan's opposition party, " Wu said.
"The KMT could talk about issues and future policies but did not have the power to implement them. Now, the KMT is the ruling party in Taiwan and therefore, has the power to implement policies."

Wu emphasized, however, that the KMT-CPC dialogue would not replace the official communication channel between China and Taiwan established through the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its counterpart in China, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

"The KMT-CPC Forum is a platform for exchanging views. It is non-official, and non-decision making. Although government officials are participating, its purpose is to provide realistic solutions to issues," Wu said.

KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan and KMT Vice Chairman Lin Feng-cheng, who are already in China to celebrate the launch of direct shipping links between the two countries, will proceed to Shanghai to attend the forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices flat on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices finished slightly lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, edging down 0.29 points to close at 4,694.52.

Suffering a small drop after gains made the previous day, the local bourse opened at 4,661.69 and fluctuated between 4,723.7 and 4,622.49. A total of 4.41 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$70.74 billion (US$2.17 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 3.54 percent. Cement stocks were down 2.27 percent, paper and pulp issues declined 1.91 percent, foodstuff issues dropped 1.83 percent, textile stocks fell 1.79 percent, plastics and chemicals shares lost 1.37 percent, and banking and financial shares shed 0.31 percent.
Machinery and electronics shares gained ground, advancing 0.15 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 763 to 706, with 250 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$1.78 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.059 to close at NT$32.530.
A total of US$745 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.476 and reached a high of NT$32.550.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative Yuan approves setting up of national vaccine fund

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan on Friday passed the final reading of an amendment to the Law on the Control of Communicable Diseases, which allows the establishment of a national vaccine fund in Taiwan.

The fund, which is expected to be operational by 2009, will help improve health care and public health in Taiwan, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said in a statement.
With the approved bill, the DOH will have a stable fund to use to pay for its procurement of vaccines and will be able to ensure a stable supply of inoculations.
The establishment of the vaccine fund "will create more financial sources for the purchase of vaccines, " said Lin Ying, the CDC's deputy director-general.
Currently, financial support for vaccines come only from the government, and it is not easy to increase the budget, Lin said.

But in the near future after the national vaccine fund is set up, when the World Health Organization suggests new vaccines to be listed as regular vaccines, Taiwan will be able to keep pace with other countries in the area of inoculation, Lin noted.

Revenue for the vaccine fund will be drawn from government budgets, the health and welfare charges on tobacco, as well as earnings from the pubic welfare lottery and donations. But donors are not allowed to specify which vaccines should be purchased from the fund.
Decisions on what items to purchase will be made by a committee, which will also evaluate the priority of vaccines to be purchased.

Although the vaccine fund has yet to be created, Lin said that the budget to buy vaccines next year has already been increased from NT$400 million to NT$528 million, with two more vaccines listed as regular vaccines: new three-in-one vaccines for around 255,000 first grade students and streptococcus pneumoniae vaccines for children under five years old, a high risk group for the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP lawmakers applaud judge's decision to keep ex-president released

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday welcomed judges' decision to uphold an original court ruling to release former president Chen Shui-bian without bail.

Several DPP lawmakers jointly told the media that they applaud the panel of three judges for having themorale courageto not cave under pressure from media reports about the risks of allowing Chen to be free and ruling party lawmakers' desire to keep Chen behind bars pending the trial.
We have to give high confirmation to the judge for his morale courage,said DPP Legislator Chiu Yi-ying.We also hope that Chen's case will proceed smoothly without any interference.
Lawmaker Lee Chun-yee, however, criticized judges' request to the former president to not threaten the witnesses involved in the case.
This is an incredible assumption, said Lee.Former president Chen is not a rascal nor gangster. It is impossible for him to do such a thing as threatening the witnesses.

Judges made the request to Chen due to arguments by the prosecutors that Chen, if allowed to remain free while prosecutors' investigations are ongoing, will try to influence the witnesses involved in the case.
Prosecutors had argued that some of the witnesses and defendants, including three of Chen's former close aides, might not dare to tell the truth unless Chen was behind bars.
As to the allegations from the prosecutors, Lee said thatthe prosecutors are trying to make up strange and far-fetched reasons to persuade the judge to place Chen back into custody.
The Taipei District Court had rejected on Thursday a request by prosecutors to detain Chen again.

This was the second ruling in six days on the same case. The panel of three judges at the court stood by its decision last Saturday to free Chen on his own recognizance, a ruling that prosecutors are likely to see as detrimental to their investigation into other criminal activities in which Chen is allegedly involved.

In its previous ruling on Dec. 13, the court had ordered that Chen, who was first detained on Nov. 12, be released without bail following his indictment, along with 13 other people, on charges of embezzlement, corruption and money laundering.
Chen and his wife are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan drug company reaches pact with Chinese firm on medicine supply

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese pharmaceutical company has signed a letter of intent (LOI) with a Chinese company on forming a strategic alliance to ensure an adequate and steady supply of Chinese herbal medicine to Taiwan's market, company officials said Friday.

The agreement was reached between Taipei City-based Scientific Pharmaceutical Elite Company and Guangdong Kangmei Pharmaceutical Holding Co. at the closing in Taipei City Thursday evening of a two-day cross-Taiwan Strait forum on cooperation in herbal medicine and technical exchanges.
The signing of the LOI was important to Taiwan as 90 percent of the country's herbal medicine are imported from China. The quality of herbal medicine imported from China, however, is uneven.
It is hoped that the agreement will ensure not only the quantity but also the quality that Taiwan needs.

The agreement is expected to achieve three goals -- increase China's supplies of herbal medicine to Taiwan, enable the companies to jointly develop new herbal drugs, and allow the two companies mutual reciprocity in tapping the world herbal medicine market.
The Taipei company is one of the largest drug companies in Taiwan.

Two other agreements were also inked between the two companies: one on exchanges and cooperation to develop the Chinese herbal medicine industry and the other on joint research and development of Chinese herbal medicine.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Friday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for January falling 17 points to end at 4,680, with 108,922 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for February lost 19 points to finish at 4,655, with 290 contracts traded, while March futures declined 14 points to end at 4,643, with 29 contracts traded.
June futures rose 28 points to close at 4,626, with 15 contract transactions, while September futures lost 25 points to end at 4,409, with 12 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,697 for January, 4,674 for February, 4,657 for March, 4,598 for June and 4,434 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 0.29 points to finish at 4,694.52, on turnover of NT$70.74 billion (US$2.17 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
January TE futures gained 0.3 points to close at 178.5, with 5,118 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 0.1 points to finish at 176.85, with 17 contracts traded.

March TE futures decreased 1.2 points to finish at 175.95 points, with two contracts traded, while September TE futures moved down 10.4 points to end at 162.05, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.
January TF futures were down 3.2 points to close at 591, with 5,555 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures decreased 1.4 points to finish at 590.8, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former national security chief released on bail

TEXT.P: Former national security chief Chiou I-jen who was held for 50 days as a suspect in a corruption investigation, was released Friday on NT$500,000 (US$15,382) bail.

The Taipei District Court approved a request by prosecutors to free him after determining there was no longer a need to keep him in custody, but Chiu was barred from traveling abroad or sailing off the country's shores.

He left the court with his lawyer and an aide without comment, but in a written statement issued later through an aide, Chiu reiterated his innocence and insisted he would clear his name when the truth came out.
He thanked his many friends who rallied behind him during his ordeal.
Chiou was detained on Oct. 30 on suspicion of siphoning off public funds during his term as secretary-general of the National Security Council from mid-2004 to early 2007.

According to documents presented by prosecutors to the court at the time, Chiou took US$500,000 in travelers' checks from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 2004 to use for what he claimed was a secret diplomatic mission that year.
The checks however were found cashed later by a casino in Las Vegas, United States, which suggested the funds were not used for public purposes, the prosecutors claim.
The prosecutors even suspected that some of the so-called secret diplomatic spending found its way into foreign bank accounts held by ex-president Chen Shui-bian's family members.
Chiou is one of 11 people, including the former president himself, detained by prosecutors in their probe of Chen's alleged corruption and money laundering.
He was the last one to be released from custody but the only one who was not indicted along with Chen on Dec. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to work to bring down suicide rate: President Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has urged government officials to get to the bottom of what causes people to take their own lives, as the number of people committing suicide in Taiwan remains high.
At a meeting with Taiwan LifeLine International President Lee Cheng-hsiung at the Presidential Office Thursday, Ma said many factors cause mental disturbances in a modern society.

To help people overcome these various mental health problems, former President Lee Teng-hui established a telephone hot line "1995" in the country's 23 cities and counties during his term in office, a program that has saved many lives in recent years, Ma said.
An average of more than 110,000 calls are made to the hot line in search of help annually, with the number of calls exceeding 120,000 last year, Ma said.
The importance of the hot line is evident, given that suicide has been among the top ten causes of death for the past 10 years, the president added.

The Department of Health reported earlier this year that Taiwan's suicide mortality rate dropped to 17.2 people out of every 100,000 in 2007, but it still remained higher than the world average of 15 per 100,000 people.
Also, more than 2,000 people have taken their own lives in Taiwan every year since 1997, growing every year to a peak of 4,406 in 2006 before falling to 3,933 in 2007.

Of the suicide deaths, there has been a big increase among the 25-45 age group, Ma noted, citing statistics. He said people in the age bracket are supposed to be full of vitality and represent the hope and future of the country, and them giving up their lives represents a major loss to society.

Attributing the increasing rate of suicide to the current adverse economic, social and political situation, Ma urged the public to help address the problems with love, patience and tolerance, while promising that the government will do its utmost to help those with mental problems overcome their issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior officials, servicemen to be allowed to visit China soon

TEXT.P: Political appointees, military servicemen and senior executives of state-owned enterprises will soon be allowed to visit China for business purposes or sightseeing, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Friday.

Liu made the announcement at a luncheon with reporters after being asked about complaints by senior executives of state-owned companies that the restrictions on visiting China have hurt their ability to drum up business.

The premier said that the Ministry of the Interior and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- a Cabinet-level body in charge of China policy planning -- have reached a consensus on amending relevant regulations to make it easier for senior officials, state-owned enterprise executives and military servicemen to take business or pleasure trips to China.
At present, the three groups are only allowed to visit China on invitations from international organizations, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said later in the day.
In the future, the MAC official said, restrictions on the purposes of their trips to China will be relaxed, but the details still have to be worked out.
Liu Te-shun indicated, however, that a number of deputy ministerial-level officials have already traveled to China on official business.
In August this year, Minister of Education Cheng Jei-cheng and Minister-without- Portfolio Ovid J. L. Tzeng also traveled to Beijing to attend the opening of the 2008 Olympic Games.
But the MAC official acknowledged that the number of instances of ministerial- level officials visiting China remained limited.

Hsieh Chih-kung, deputy director-general of the National Immigration Agency, said the agency is working on a raft of amendments to the regulations governing China-bound visits by civil servants and those with special status.
"Liberalization is our guiding principle, " Hsieh said, adding that the package will be referred to the Executive Yuan for approval when it is finalized.
The once-icy relations across the Taiwan Strait have warmed since the May 20 inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou, who has adopted a conciliatory approach toward China.
In the latest symbol of improved ties, direct air, shipping and postal links took effect Dec. 15 to facilitate trade and civilian exchanges between Taiwan and China.
Relaxing restrictions on visits to China by government personnel is a matter of course, government sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1 dies, 3 poisoned on Panama-registered ship

TEXT.P: A crewman was killed and three others were poisoned Friday in an accident on a Panama-registered cargo vessel sailing off the coast of Taiwan's northern county of Hsinchu, rescue authorities said.

According to the National Airborne Service Corps (NASC), the four victims -- all of whom were Chinese nationals -- had lost consciousness when the corps received a distress call from the ship at around 10:20 a.m.

A helicopter was sent immediately to airlift the victims separately to two hospitals in Taichung City. One of the victims had no vital signs upon arrival at the hospital he was sent to, the NASC said.

Chan Yu-che, a toxicologist at the Taichung Veterans General Hospital, who treated two of the patients, said the accident took place when the crewmen were performing a routine inspection on the lower deck of the vessel, which was transporting fuel coke.
Chan speculated that the crewmen were overcome by methane gas, which had accumulated because of poor ventilation.
The three surviving crewmen were hospitalized for treatment and in stable condition, doctors said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tycoon signs agreement to donate NT$15 billion for cancer research

TEXT.P: Terry Gou, one of the wealthiest people in Taiwan, signed a formal agreement on Friday to donate NT$15 billion (US$461.2 million) to establish a hospital for cancer patients and to conduct biomedical engineering research.

Gou, who heads Hon Hai Precision Co. - one of the world's largest contract electronics manufacturers, made the donation in his capacity as founder of the Yonglin Foundation, a non-profit organization established by Gou and his late wife Serena Lin in 2000 to conduct educational and charity missions.

The money will go to National Taiwan University, which plans to build a biomedical science park that can accommodate the planned 500-bed cancer hospital, as well as a proton center for cancer treatment and a preventive medicine center.
Gou's wife died of breast cancer in 2005 and his younger brother died from leukemia this July.
Gou said he had never changed his mind about making the donation to NTU since he first indicated he would do it in Sept. 4, 2007.
As long as the planned cancer hospital achieves top world standards, his donations to the hospital will only increase, Gou said.
Charges by the hospital will be fair and affordable, he added.

Gou said humbly that his donation is only "a small drop of water in a big pond." Once the NTU cancer hospital becomes the world's top-notch cancer hospital, it is expected to contribute to a structural change of Taiwan's medical resources in a direction that boosts Taiwan's research in the prevention and control of cancer diseases, and the development of the country's biomedical industry, he added.
NTU President Lee Si-chen accepted the donation on behalf of the university and expressed his gratitude for the donation.
Lee pointed out that the planned cancer hospital will be a separate hospital from the university's National Taiwan University Hospital, although the two will be overseen by the university management.

In September 2007 when Gou signed a memorandum of understanding to make the donation, he mentioned that the hospital will be a non-profit and public interest medical care facility, and that the Yonglin Foundation will play a major role in stem cell implant research and preventive medicine.

DOC.HEADLINE: Animal rescue vehicles fitted with warning lights hit the road

TEXT.P: Animal rescue vehicles fitted with flashing yellow lights hit the road Friday, and an animal protection group urged the public to give them priority road rights.

The Life Caring and Animal Rescue Organization Taiwan introduced the new green vehicles at a press conference and hoped they would help rescue animals that would not have been reached quickly enough in the past to save.

Though the animal protection group has rescued many stray dogs and cats over the past four years, it has complained that due to legal restrictions that did not allow animal rescue vehicles to have warning lights and road rights, they often reached animals past the prime treatment period.

After concerted efforts by animal protection groups, the Council of Agriculture and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications approved regulations governing animal rescue vehicles' special equipment and logo.
Taipei City Councilman Chen Chien-ming touted the new regulations as "a major step toward a more humane spirit."
The vehicle will not only make rescue operations more efficient, but will also protect the safety of rescue personnel, he said.
He urged the public to join the dog and cat rescue mission and more importantly, to give priority road rights when they see the green vehicles.

The association, which relies solely on private donations, said money received should be used for saving animals rather than to pay for the traffic tickets and ambulance repair costs it amassed that will now be averted with the new vehicles.

DOC.HEADLINE: Film director protests dismantling of aborigines' houses
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/08 20:58:28 (By Deborah Kuo and Elisabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Renowned Taiwanese film director Hou Hsiao-hsien shaved his head Friday to protest against the government's dismantling of aborigines' houses in Sansia township, Taipei County.
Hou shaved his head in a sit-in demonstration staged in front of the Taipei Guest House aimed at attracting the media's attention to the demolition that has left dozens of indigenous people homeless.

Scores of indigenous people mainly from the Amis Tribe, whose houses in the Sanying aboriginal community in Sansia had been dismantled by the Taipei county government, also participated in the demonstration.
Local indigenous people had been forced to relocate eight times over the past 30 years, according to Hou.

"It's regretful that these people -- whose ancestors had lived on the Taipei Basin at times earlier than the Chinese Han people and any of the first Western immigrants in Taiwan had arrived -- have now been deprived of their basic rights to residence, " Hou said.

However, Chu Ching-yi, director of the Taipei county bureau of aboriginal affairs, explained later that the indigenous community in Sansia was built against the law on the flood plain of a river. Every time a typhoon approaches, the county government must evacuate the residents for the sake of their safety.
The indigenous dwellers' request for permission to "stay on where they live now" violates the Water Act, Chu said.
"Although the county government wants to take care of their wish, it cannot act to violate the law," Chu said.
According to the bureau, the illegal community under the Sanying Bridge consists of around 23 households, with a total of 40-50 people, who mostly work as carpenters.
The best solution is to relocate them, according to the bureau.

The county government said it has built a new residential area for the Sansia indigenous people just 200 meters from where the illegal dwellings were destroyed and that many indigenous residents had already moved into the community.

But Chiang Yi-hao, a consultant to the Sanying Community Self-Help Group, said some of the Sanying Community dwellers could not move into the new residential area because of household registration problems.
Even if they manage to move in, Chiang added, they feel insecure about not having a permanent home because they have to pay rent and they are allowed to live there for only two years.
Director Hou called for the government to show some respect to indigenous people, particularly toward their way of living.

Meanwhile, Chiang urged the Taipei county government to first resume water and electricity supplies to the community and to ask community members about their needs before continuing with the demolitions.

Chiang said all the aboriginal residents want is a piece of land for them to build their homes to live in permanently, a humble desire that the Taipei county government seemed to have paid a deaf ear to so far.
Chiang called for President Ma Ying-jeou to "treat these people as people."

Controversies surrounding the community had drawn criticism from Taiwanese society and legislators after county government officials and policemen in March forcibly tore down some of the houses that were illegally built near the area's Dahan River several years ago.

The county government said it demolished those illegal houses for water conservation and river management purposes, but Chiang said a factory was built there after some of the illegal houses were torn down.
According to Chiang, the county officials had disregarded protests from the remaining tribe members and will continue their forcible demolition next week.

A press statement issued by the county government late Friday said many of the current residents in the Sanying community have moved there over the past year, rather than being the originally documented dwellers.

In consideration of their livelihoods, the statement added, demolition of illegal structures there scheduled for next Tuesday will be postponed indefinitely, and no such work will be carried out before the Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan.26.

DOC.HEADLINE: Greenhouse Gas Reduction Act to be reviewed by legislature next week

TEXT.P: The head of the Environmental Protection Administration on Friday pushed for passage of landmark legislation on managing greenhouse gas emissions that he said would serve as an important legal basis for Taiwan in adapting to climate change.

The Legislative Yuan is expected to review the draft Greenhouse Gas Reduction Act next week, which if approved would set up a system to control greenhouse gas emissions and the trade in carbon credits to help reach government emission reduction targets.
EPA chief Shen Shu-hung publicly backed the bill after briefing President Ma Ying-jeou on the year's achievements and key future environmental policy challenges.

According to the EPA, after hearing Shen's report, Ma said that in addition to the current priority of encouraging domestic industries to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, the Ministry of Economic Affairs should encourage large-scale enterprises to acquire carbon credits abroad and figure carbon dioxide reduction costs into industrial development costs as a whole.
The GGRA draft was mapped out by the Cabinet-level EPA in 2006 to establish a domestic legal framework to manage greenhouse gas emissions in Taiwan.

Legislators began to review the draft bill in committee earlier this year but have yet to reach consensus on a number of clauses, including whether to put a schedule of carbon reduction targets in the act.
Once a political figure declares (his target), he has the duty to make efforts to achieve it, " said Shen when asked about whether the target should be included.
He stressed that the carbon reduction targets have already been announced by the president and was noted in the Sustainable Energy Policy Guidelines approved by the Cabinet in June.

In accordance to Ma's promises and the Guidelines, the government vowed to maintain Taiwan's total greenhouse gas emissions at 2008 levels during 2016 and 2020, reduce the emissions to 2000 levels by 2025, halve the emissions from 2000 levels by 2050, and increase the low-carbon energy proportion of the country's total energy supply to more than 55 percent by 2025.

In order to promote voluntary emission reductions among private companies, the EPA set up a national Greenhouse Gas Registry in 2007 to allow enterprises to voluntarily report their emission inventories.
To date, 136 enterprises have registered their greenhouse gas emission data, Shen said.

At present, three "carbon-reduction" draft laws are all pending in the Legislative Yuan for review, including the GGRA, the Statute on the Development of Renewable Energy and the Energy Management Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Farmers in Tainan County learn to sell produce on Internet

TEXT.P: Farmers in Tainan County have begun to use the Internet to sell their fresh produce, thanks to a vocational training program provided by a local office of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

A class of 29 farmers from Guantian township -- the first in the southern county to have completed the 108-hour program at the COA-run Tainan Vocational Training Center -- presented their newly acquired skills Friday.

They demonstrated a "Conscience Store" set up on the Ruten Auction Web site to promote sales of the produce they grow, including water caltron, mushrooms, watermelons and tomatoes, as well as their fish culture products.

According to Huang Chun-chang, director of the vocational training center, the program also taught the farmers how to package and produce photos of their products to promote sales, as well as other skills related to the management of a Web site, the delivery of goods and monetary transactions through bank accounts.

The cyberspace knowledge allows them to fill orders received directly through the Internet, enabling to improve their profit margins, Huang said, adding that the program has changed their former production-based operation into a full- fledged small business.
Huang said that more such classes will be held in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Baseball legend to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: The legendary Sadaharu Oh, the Japanese home-run king of Chinese descent, will arrive in Taiwan Saturday for a visit, said officials of the Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Friday.
President Ma Ying-jeou will meet with Oh, who holds Republic of China citizenship, on Dec. 22.

Prior to the encounter, SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling will meet the former star player and manager to ask for tips on what Taiwan can do to develop the sport of baseball on the island, SAC officials said.

The 68-year-old Oh, known as Wang Chen-chih in Taiwan, is the son of a Chinese father and a Japanese mother. He set the world record for home runs at the professional level with 868, before retiring from the Yomiuri Giants in 1980 at the age of 40.

As a manager, Oh led Japan to the championship in the inaugural World Baseball Classic in 2006, beating out Cuba in the final, and managed the Fukuoka Daiei Hawks to Japan Series titles in 1999 and 2003.

Oh maintains a close relationship with Taiwan's baseball community and has contributed his services to the sport's development in Taiwan. Wang enjoys the respect of baseball players and operators in the country, SAC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Musician hopes to draw attention to environment at Alishan concert

TEXT.P: Renowned Canadian environmental musician Matthew Lien hopes that his sunrise concert on Alishan Jan. 1 will concentrate the attention of more local residents on environmental issues.

In an interview with the Central News Agency on Friday, Lien said that with the concert being held in an area where some precious animals and rare plants are found, it will offerthe best wayfor the audience tothink about the natural environment and cultures that we live with in this world.

Though most people are currently caught up in the global economic downturn, Lien stressed it was even more important to focus investment and government attention on environmental degradation, as it is "far more serious and will have far greater impact than our economy.
That way, he went on, we could really do a lot to save, protect and revive our ecology in the world.

Lien said he finds the concertvery specialbecause it will take place as the sun rises, which he felt was "much more meaningful" than most year-end performances that begin late on New Year's Eve to usher in the new year.

"The idea of opening a new year during a time when our Earth actually begins to warm up and rolls into the sun at the first moment of light is a timeless event, he said, adding that this is what people have been celebrating over many generations.

Meanwhile, Chung Fu-song, head of the Alishan National Scenic Area Administration, one of the concert's organizers, also said at a press conference earlier in the day that Lien's music will sit well with Alishan's beautiful ecology andprovide a spiritual feastto the event participants.

Alishan, one of Taiwan's most popular mountain resorts, will be the scene of two concerts to ring in the new year. The first concert on Dec. 31, to be held at the Alishan Tourist Service Center, features a band, singers and the Hamowana Dancing Group of the indigenous Tsou Tribe.

The second concert will take place in the early morning of Jan. 1 at the Jhushan Helicopter Apron -- a favorite spot for tourists to watch the sunrise on Alishan -- as the first gleam of sunlight of 2009 can be seen from there.
The Jan. 1 concert will feature performances by Lien, who will play from 7: 20 a.m. to 8: 20 a.m. that day, as well as the Ten Drum Art Percussion Ensemble.
According to the organizer, there will be an increase of train service to coincide with the event, while those hoping to stay on the mountain the night before are advised to book rooms in advance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Firs and arrow bamboo lost in forest fire

TEXT.P: A forest fire on Hsuehshan, also known as Snow Mountain, was put out Friday afternoon, but not before four hectares of firs and arrow bamboo trees burned to the ground.

The fire on the 3,886-meter mountain in northern Taiwan was ignited Thursday afternoon when a six-member mountain-climbing group raised a fire to alert a rescue helicopter of the exact location of a injured climber, who fractured a bone in a fall near a mountain lodge.
While the injured climber surnamed Wu was taken by helicopter to a hospital in Chiayi for treatment, the fire quickly spread.
Local firefighters rushed to the scene, but hampered by a lack of water and the mountainous winding terrain, they called on the Ministry of the Interior to send a helicopter to help combat the blaze.

A helicopter loaded with 26.4 tons of water flew two missions to the mountain and sprayed the blaze from the air. The fire came under control Friday at noon and was fully extinguished at 4: 51 p.m., but some rangers stayed on the scene to prevent it from reigniting.
Forestry Bureau officials said they will ask for compensation for the damage done to the forest. Shei-Pa National Park police have also questioned members of the mountain climbing team.
For the safety of visitors, Shei-Pa National Park also announced that most of the mountain trails will be temporarily closed to hikers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Renewable Energy Development Bill likely to be passed in January

TEXT.P: A senior official in charge of Taiwan's energy development said Friday the legislature is expected to pass the draft Renewable Energy Development Bill at its third reading before the current legislative session ends Jan. 13.

Wang Yunn-Ming, deputy director of the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that the bill would authorize the government to provide incentives to invest in power facilities and promote the use of renewable energy up to a total installed capacity of 6.5 million kilowatts.

The measure would guarantee a return on investment and strengthen the willingness to invest in power generation using renewable energy. It would establish mechanisms for the linking of renewable-energy generating facilities to the power industry and for a guaranteed price for their electricity.
Under the proposed law, large public construction projects in the future must use solar energy to meet a stipulated percentage of their total energy consumption.

According to a Bureau of Energy estimate, once the Renewable Energy Development bill becomes law, Taiwan's annual solar energy output could be increased from 2.8 million kilowatts in 2007 to 8.45 million kilowatts by 2025, accounting for 8 percent of Taiwan's total electricity generation capacity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Miaoli County legislative by-election slated for March 14

TEXT.P: A by-election will be held March 14 in Miaoli County's first electoral district to fill the seat vacated by Lee I-tin, whose election was formally invalidated because of vote-buying, the Central Election Commission (CEC) announced Friday.
The proposal to hold the legislative by-election on the second Saturday of March 2009 was unanimously approved at a meeting of CEC commissioners, a CEC statement said.
According to the CEC schedule, an election gazette will be issued Jan. 5, and hopefuls are eligible to register their candidacy from Jan. 12-16.

Qualified candidates will draw lots Feb. 18 to determine the order in which their names will appear on the ballots and can present their platforms in officially organized campaign forums from March 4-13.

CEC officials said the Miaoli County government originally suggested that the by-election be held March 7, but with six national civil service exams taking place that day, CEC commissioners decided to hold the by-election a week later on March 14.

Lee, of the ruling Kuomintang, was elected as a first-term lawmaker on Jan. 12 earlier this year but lost the seat Dec. 10 when the Taiwan High Court's Taichung branch rejected his appeal against a May 28 Miaoli District Court ruling, which had annulled his election on vote-buying charges.

Lee was the first member of the current legislature to lose a seat. The loss is not expected to have much impact on the lawmaking body, where the KMT and its allies hold nearly three-fourths of seats.

Lee, a former secretary-general of the Miaoli County Farmers' Association, garnered 64,817 votes in the Jan. 12 election to 46,905 votes for two-term legislator Tu Wen-ching of the Democratic Progressive Party.
Tu filed a civil suit seeking the invalidation of Lee's election.
The court verdict said Lee made 16 visits to temples in Yuanli and Jhunan -- two of the eight townships in one of Miaoli's County's two electoral districts -- between June and October last year.
During that time he made donations and solicited support, via his campaign aides, for his election bid.
Because Lee had not been previously known to make donations to temples and had only done so during the election campaign, the court ruled they were designed to improperly influence voter behavior.
The high court had the final say on the case.

As Lee's remaining term in office exceeded one year, the CEC must hold a by- election in the county's first electoral district within three months from the day it receives the relevant court verdict under the existing Public Officials Election and Recall Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 ING Taipei International Marathon to take place Dec. 21

TEXT.P: The 2008 ING Taipei International Marathon will take place Dec. 21 in Taipei, with more than 100,000 runners from 34 countries taking part in five categories of road racing.

Taipei Deputy Mayor Samuel Wu told a press conference Friday that this will be the fifth international marathon held in Taipei, and that the number of runners participating in the races will have exceeded half a million -- more than any other marathon race held anywhere else.
The race is sponsored by the Taiwan-based ING Antai Life Insurance Co. The 42-kilometer marathon and the 21-km half marathon will start at 7 a.m. from the plaza in front of Taipei City Hall Sunday.
There will be three other categories -- a 9-km race for policemen and firefighters, a race for children, and another race for recreational runners.
The organizers have made NT$1.33 million available in cash awards for those runners who break any records.
Accomplished Taiwanese marathon runners, such as Wu Wen-chien and Hsu Yu-fang, will compete with top-class runners from other countries, including Kenya and Japan, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Carrier promises quiet, stable flight for pandas

TEXT.P: EVA Airways, which has been commissioned to fly a pair of pandas from the southwestern Chinese province of Sichuan to Taiwan Dec. 23, promised Friday it will do its best to ensure a quiet and stable flight for the two rare animals.

EVA Air spokesman Nieh Kuo-wei said the company has sent an advance team to Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, to go over technical details regarding the charter flight from Shuangliu Airport to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.

"Every arrangement will be made in terms of the principle of doing the best for the pandas," Nieh said, adding that the plane will not take off until the optimal moment to ensure a stable flight for the animals.
In the 180-cubic meter main cargo cabin, the temperature will be first set at 12 degrees Celsius and gradually raised to 18-20 C, the level most suitable for pandas.
During the flight, only animal caretakers, conservationists and veterinarians will be allowed to stay with them in the cabin, Nieh said.

Taipei Zoo has prepared a penthouse-sized outdoor garden decorated with ferns and a footbridge, a bedroom with all-season air conditioning and imported bamboo to welcome the two pandas, named Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan.
The pandas, whose names together mean "reunion," are set to reach this zoo compound Dec.23 as a goodwill gift from China, which claims sovereignty over Taiwan.
The once-icy relations between Taiwan and China have warmed since the May 20 inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou, who adopts a conciliatory approach toward China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 20, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 20, or the 23rd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysian prime minister, is born.
1927: Kim Young-sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by U.S. Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion-worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of a stroke at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The ROC chooses 26 new members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Arthur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 U.S. troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae-jung pardons Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Tae-woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
1998: Nkem Chukwu of Houston, Texas, becomes the first woman to give birth to eight live babies.
1999: The Wang Kuang-ying Library, dedicated to a public-spirited ROC man who collected garbage for 35 years and used the money he earned to buy books and donate them to the local and overseas institutions, is inaugurated in Taipei.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui tells visiting U.S. Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that the ROC's ultimate goal of seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China remains unchanged.
2000: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says when receiving a seven- member Japanese parliamentary delegation that maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is in the common interest of the ROC, Japan and the United States.
2001: Twenty-one city and county chiefs from around Taiwan are sworn in at official ceremonies, vowing to better serve the local people and to deliver on their campaign promises.
2001: A consortium of leading telecommunication companies launches services on the Asia Pacific Cable Network 2 (APCN 2), the world's first Asian submarine ring system that comprises 19,000 km of cable connecting mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore.
Confucius: "Now, if in your conversation you give few occasions for men to criticize you, and in your conduct you have few occasions for self-reproach, you cannot help getting preferment."
