DOC.HEADLINE: Fishing gear businesses thrive as unemployed take solace in angling

TEXT.P: Taiwan's experienced recreational fishermen have long enjoyed outings on the island's picturesque coasts and river estuaries, able to catch plenty of fish in peace while enjoying the great outdoors.
Not any more.

The global economic downturn has swollen the ranks of Taiwan's unemployed desperate for inexpensive ways to pass their expanded leisure time, leading to an explosion of anglers at major fishing spots around the island and a sharp increase in sales at fishing tackle stores.

The prime fishing areas on Taiwan's northern coastline are now often jammed with anglers, leading to complaints among the old hands that they are finding it increasingly difficult to find space to enjoy their favorite pastime.
Hsiaolee, an enthusiastic angler who has been fishing at Keelung's Badouzih fishing port for more than 10 years, says the area has never been more congested.
"Maybe it's because of the dramatic increase in the number of unemployed," he sighs.

Hsiaolee says that in the past, whenever he received information from weather reports or other anglers that shoals of fish were passing through, he would only have to leave home early in the morning to get a prime spot around Badouzih.
"But these days, I have to brave the early morning chill and leave home well before dawn. Even then, I often can't find a spot at a coastal fishing site, far less an ideal one, " he grumbles.
The increase in the number of fishermen can also be seen at nearby Bisha fishing port, located just to the east of Keelung City.

A-chang, a ruddy-faced fish vendor at the port who fishes both as a hobby and sometimes as a way to supplement his income, says the number of coastal anglers has increased substantially in the past few months, with many of them novices.
He's found a positive side, however, to the phenomenon.
"In recent months, I have from time to time experienced the joy of helping some of these novice anglers catch their first fish, " he says. "It's a feeling second to none in the angling world."

Among his new fishing buddies is Bill Ting, a middle-aged textile mechanic who lost his job two months ago. Ting says he finds angling to be a really good way for unemployed people to kill time and try their luck.
"The experience of throwing a line from shore in the cool autumn air is comfortable and even therapeutic," Ting smiles.
A fishing greenhorn, Ting says he felt a "love and respect" for the first fish he caught last week with the assistance of A-chang -- so much so that he released it back into the sea.
"I don't care whether I catch a fish or not. I just like the feeling of sitting on the shore and watching the clear water shimmering under rays of sunlight in the gentle breeze or at dusk, " he adds.

Not all anglers are as lyrical as Ting, but many talk about their great joy and sense of achievement in catching a fish, while others say they like the sense of a shared passion and chatting with fellow anglers.

Lin Chia-han, a computer hardware engineer at Taiwan's high-tech heartland, the Hsinchu Science Park, says he has long been passionate about fishing and that the Fongshan stream in Jhubei City near the northern Taiwan science park is one of his favorite haunts.

"In the past, the number of anglers would usually be in the single digits on weekdays, but now they turn up in hordes and pack both sides of the river, " says Lin, forced to take unpaid leave by his employer, a memory chip vendor.
While many newcomers are on unpaid leave, others are new retirees who accepted early retirement buyouts from employers looking to trim their payrolls.

Lin says he takes comfort in their company. "Even though most of us are new acquaintances, we have similar career backgrounds and can easily make small talk or share our views on topics of common interest," he says.

According to the latest government statistics, the unemployment rate surged to a five-year high of 4.37 percent for October, with 35,000 laid off during the month due to downsizing or company closures. More than 470,000 people were out of work around the country.
The growing number of anglers has helped the fishing tackle business emerge as a rare bright spot in the generally gloomy local retail sector.
While industry-wide sales figures are hard to come by, anecdotal evidence indicates revenues have grown considerably at fishing gear outlets around the country.

Chiu Ching-tung, the owner of a fishing tackle shop in the northeastern coastal town of Suao in Yilan County, says the area has seen a noticeable rise in the number of anglers in the area, though partly because winter is the peak fishing season.

"While old customers remain the mainstay of my clientele, there have also been many fresh faces, " says Chiu, who estimated that his turnover has grown 20 percent to 30 percent in the past couple of months alone.

At the other end of the country, meanwhile, Lin Ming-hua, the proprietor of a tackle shop in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, echoes Chiu's estimates, also saying that his business has risen by around 30 percent in recent months.
"In addition to old patrons, I am also serving many newcomers, including those from neighboring cities and counties or even from central and northern Taiwan," Lin says.
First-timers, he observes, tend to purchase cheap fishing rods costing only a few hundred new Taiwan dollars, but often spend a lot on bait and flavored bait enhancers.
Lin, himself an avid angler, says that nearly all riverbanks and harbor estuary embankments in the city are now all packed with anglers even on weekdays.
"This is a phenomenon I have never seen before," he adds.
Even Taiwan's political figures have taken solace in fishing.

Hualien County Magistrate Hsieh Shen-san, a self-admitted avid fisherman, went fishing in his rural home in the eastern county to heal his wounds after losing a tight battle for Taipei County magistrate in 1997.
"Fishing is good exercise that can help cultivate the essential qualities of mental well-being such as concentration and serenity, " Hsieh said.
His political career regained momentum by winning the Hualien County magistrate by-election in August 2003 and re-election in 2005, but there has been a downside to this professional resurgence.
"Nowadays, I don't have any time to go fishing," he laments.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ship repair demand expected to jump on opening of shipping links

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading shipbuilder CSBC Corp. unveiled a plan Saturday to expand its ship repair services to meet a possible rise in repair demand following the recent opening of direct shipping links with China.

CSBC Corp. Chairman Cheng Wen-lon noted that revenue from ship repairs currently contribute to 5 percent of the company's total revenues, but the segment is expected to get a significant boost thanks to the launch of direct cross-Taiwan Strait shipping.
In particular, the lack of any large shipbuilding or ship repair facilities along the Chinese coast between Shanghai and Guangzhou means the business would be even more lucrative, Cheng said.
Targeting this new business opportunity, the company is planning to set up floating docks in coastal areas to strengthen its ship repair capacity, he said.

This year, the company, which completed its privatization Dec. 18, is expected to post profits amounting to NT$6 billion, before deductions for the retirement pension reserve fund. Its profits will be the highest recorded in the 35 years since the company was established, Cheng said.
The company is holding shipbuilding orders amounting to a total of NT$120 billion, which will keep its production lines busy for the next three and a half years, he said.

He said that in the future, the privatized CSBC Corp. will work to enhance its international competitiveness, upgrade its production efficiency and strengthen cost control to further improve its performance.

Meanwhile, CSBC Vice President Wang Ko-hsuan noted that the global shipbuilding industry has suffered becuase of the worldwide recession, with orders for more than 240 bulk carriers and 27 container vessels having been canceled around the world.

However, the CSBS has not faced such problems because its main clients are all top reputable ship owners, such as Taiwan-based Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp. and Wan Hai Lines and Japan-based Marubeni Corp, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges students, parents to support voucher program

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou appealed to elementary school children and their parents Saturday to make full use of the shopping vouchers they will receive from the government next month to help stimulate the economy.

Speaking at a celebration hosted by the Affiliated Experimental Elementary School of Taiwan Municipal University of Education (TMUE) in Taipei, Ma appealed to the gathering to help his administration in its efforts to boost the country's flagging economy.

Harking back to his days as a pupil at the elementary school and his participation in student council elections, Ma said that was when he learned that the "government must listen to the people so as to have their support."
The president, who walked to the venue from his home, was welcomed on arrival by students performing a lion dance.
"I recall that my elementary school days were the happiest times in my life, " Ma told them, adding that it was there he learned to interact with others.

He wrote the characters "Love at elementary school, " in Chinese calligraphy in a show of affection for his alma mater, while Control Yuan President Wang Chien- shien, who also attended the function, captured the president's artistic efforts on camera.

Mentioning his government's plan to issue NT$3,600 worth of shopping vouchers to each Taiwan citizen on Jan. 18 next year, the president said, "please, all school children and parents, make full use of the coupons to help Taiwan's economy."

The central government has allocated NT$85.7 billion (US$2.6 billion) to fund the shopping voucher program, under which all Taiwan citizens and foreign spouses of Taiwan citizens will be eligible to receive the coupons.
The vouchers will be distributed from Jan. 18, one week before the Lunar New Year holiday, and will remain valid until Sept. 30, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Baseball legend cancels trip to Taiwan

TEXT.P: The legendary Sadaharu Oh, the Japanese home-run king of baseball, on Saturday canceled his plans to visit Taiwan, due to the death of his older brother.

Oh was scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Saturday evening, but called off the trip after learning that his brother, older by 10 years, had died in Tokyo in earlier that morning, said the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association (CTBA) in a statement.
Oh will reschedule his visit after the funeral services, the CTBA said, but did not specify a date.

CTBA Secretary-General Lin Chung-sheng said that although Oh, who is of Chinese heritage and is known as Wang Chen-chih in Taiwan, cannot make it to Taiwan this year, this will not affect Oh's plans to assist Taiwan in developing the sport on the island.

The 68-year-old Oh, who holds Republic of China citizenship, was scheduled to meet with President Ma Ying-jeou during his visit. Oh, the son of a Chinese father and a Japanese mother, set the world record for home runs at the professional level with a score of 868, before retiring from the Yomiuri Giants team in 1980 at the age of 40.

He later became manager of the Japan national team, which in 2006 won the inaugural World Baseball Classic, beating Cuba in the final. He was also manager of the Fukuoka Daiei Hawks which won the Japan Series titles in 1999 and 2003.

Oh maintains a close relationship with Taiwan's baseball community and has contributed his services to the sport's development in Taiwan. He enjoys the respect of baseball players and operators in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mandarin Airlines launches direct Kaohsiung-Shanghai flight

TEXT.P: The Taiwan carrier Mandarin Airlines embarked on its first direct flight from Kaohsiung to Shanghai Saturday morning with 310 passengers, including Taiwanese business people, on board.
The newly established air route, which was launched as result of an agreement between Taiwan and China on direct links, cuts travel time between the two cities by almost half.

The Mandarin Airlines flight on the new route from Kaohsiung International Airport to Shanghai Pudong Airport takes two hours, departing at 7: 30 a.m., while the return leg takes two hours and 10 minutes, departing Shanghai at 10: 50 a.m.
A Taiwanese businesswoman surnamed Lin, who was taking the maiden flight on the route with three of her family members, said it will be very convenient for her as she operates a business in Shanghai.
"I wish these direct links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait were in place a long time ago, " she said. "This will shorten my travel time considerably."

Another passenger surnamed Chang said that although he spends most of his time in Shanghai, he needs to return to Taiwan at least once every two months as he is in the real estate business. The new route would cut his total travel time by almost half, he said, explaining that it usually takes him five to six hours to get from his office in Shanghai to his home in Kaohsiung.

"I am so glad these direct links between Taiwan and mainland China are available now," said Chang. "I hope all the airlines will increase their number of direct cross-strait flights, once the government regulations permit them to do so."
A total of 17 tour groups were also on the Mandarin Airlines flight, which was doused by celebratory jets of water on the tarmac just before take-off.

Daily cross-strait charter flights between Taiwan and China were launched Dec. 15 on the basis of a set of accords signed between the two sides in early November, which also paved the way for the establishment of direct postal and shipping links.

On the first day of the direct daily flights, three Taiwanese carriers on the routes filled 3,753 of the 4,899 seats available from Taiwan to four Chinese destinations, while six Chinese carriers flew 1,829 passengers, or 67 percent of the total 2,722-seat capacity, from China to Taiwan, according to Civil Aeronautics Administration statistics.

Other Taiwanese airlines, such as China Airlines, EVA Airways and TransAsia Airways, are operating 16 two-way daily charter flights from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Taipei Songshan Airport to Shanghai, Hangzhou, Shenzhen and Guangzhou in China.
Mainland Chinese airlines flew a total of 16 charter flights from Shanghai, Tianjin, Hangzhou, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen to Taoyuan and Taipei in northern Taiwan on Dec. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local civic groups call for release of Chinese dissident

TEXT.P: Civic groups in Taiwan urged Beijing authorities Saturday to release Liu Xiaobo, a prominent Chinese dissident writer and human rights activist who has been in police custody since Dec. 8, and to cease harassment of other Chinese signatories to a charter drafted by Liu to appeal for greater freedoms in China.

The groups voiced the demands at a press conference, calling on China to respect freedom of speech and embrace the terms of Liu's "Charter '08", which they said "will be beneficial to China's democratic development and the welfare of its citizens."

They also urged President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen to openly support Chinese dissidents, bringing to bear Taiwan's stature as a beacon of human rights and civic freedoms in East Asia.

"Taiwan cannot focus just on economic and animal exchanges with China and ignore its role in promoting human rights, democracy and freedom in China, " said CEO of Deng Liberty Foundation Yang Chang-chen.

According to Tsai Chi-hsun, secretary-general of the Taiwan Association For Human Rights, since the civic groups learned of Liu's detention they have set up a Web site where people can go to sign online petitions.

Charter 08, crafted by Liu and endorsed by over 300 prominent Chinese citizens, was conceived in the spirit of Charter 77, which was signed by more than 200 Czech and Slovak intellectuals from 1977 to 1992 to push for human and civil rights in what was then Czechoslovakia.

Liu, along with another Chinese scholar Zhang Zuhua, was taken away by Chinese police Dec. 8, two days before the 60th anniversary of the United Nations' adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Charter 08 was announced on Dec. 10.
According to Zhang, who was later released, he and Liu were detained on suspicion of gathering signatures for the charter, which appealed for reforms and greater respect for human rights in China.
The United States government issued a statement Dec. 11, expressing concern over the reports of Liu's detention and calling on the Chinese government to release him.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Immigrant Exhibition opens in Taipei

TEXT.P: An immigrant exhibition opened in Taipei Saturday, featuring performances, food demonstrations, and services provided in Taiwan by immigrants of diverse ethnic, cultural and religious backgrounds.

Noting that Taiwan is a multicultual country, Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi pledged at the opening ceremony that his ministry will promote respect for the country's immigrants and further strengthen relevant services.

The International Immigrant Exhibition, held at the city's Huashan Cultural Park, featured various talent shows, tourism services and a display of delicacies from countries such as Malaysia, Korea and Vietnam.

In addition to the exhibition, two achievement shows featuring immigrants in Taiwan have are also being held over a two-day period starting Saturday at central Taiwan's Taichung train station and at the Central Park station on the Kaohsiung MRT's Red Line, said Hsieh Li-kung, deputy director-general of the National Immigration Agency.

According to recent government figures, the number of immigrants in Taiwan, including white-collar and migrant workers, stands at around 900,000. The number of marriage immigrants alone is approximately 410,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: China visits by senior officials will not undermine dignity: MOI

TEXT.P: The government will make sure Taiwan's dignity and sovereign status are not undermined when it lifts its restrictions on visits to China by senior officials and military personnel, Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi said Saturday.
Liao said he believes the liberalization policy will meet the public's expectations and that a related plan has been presented to the Cabinet for review.
The minister, however, declined to elaborate on the details of the plan.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan first indicated on Friday that the Cabinet is working toward the goal of lifting the travel restrictions, which apply to civil servants at grade 11 or higher, political appointees, top executives of state- owned enterprises and military personnel.

According to officials at the Ministry of the Interior, the liberalization plan would allow all civil servants at grade 11 or higher to travel to China for the purposes of sightseeing and visiting relatives.

While political appointees are currently only allowed to visit China for international conferences or activities, the restriction would be relaxed to allow them to take part in activities related to their work, the officials said.

Military personnel, security personnel, officials posted overseas and personnel engaging in the research and development of secret technologies, would be allowed to visit China on official business, to visit sick relatives or to attend the funeral of close relatives, according to the officials.
Meanwhile, they added, the MOI is also planning to ease the restrictions on visits to Taiwan by Chinese officials.

Chinese officials are currently permitted to visit Taiwan only in a private capacity and if they are invited by a school or civil organization in Taiwan. However, in the future they would be allowed to come to Taiwan in an official capacity at the invitation of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, the MOI officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: H5N2 confirmed as cause of chicken deaths in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) confirmed Saturday that the recent chicken deaths on a poultry farm in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County were caused by the low-pathogenic H5N2 bird flu virus.
The COA reiterated, however, that the H5N2 virus is, so far, not known to jump to humans.
COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung told a news conference that his agency has been undertaking disinfection measures and monitoring wild and migratory birds.
The COA said it is still investigating the source of the infection.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP pushes for efforts to lower accidental death rate among children

TEXT.P: Taiwan should do more to reduce accidental deaths among children, as the number of local children who die in accidents remains high, Vice President Vincent Siew said Saturday.
Speaking at an award ceremony for a painting contest that featured themes of promoting children's safety, Siew said that up to 450 local children under age 14 died in accidents last year.
"The figure translated into more than one accidental death per day among local children, " Siew lamented, adding that the ratio was too high to be overlooked.
With an ever-declining birth rate, Siew said, Taiwan's population is aging. "And children are not only the pillar of the country but also the source of family happiness," Siew said.
There is still ample room for the government and the private sector to work together to provide a safer living environment for children, he added.

For its part, Siew said, the government should formulate a sound policy and detailed measures to protect children's safety. In the process, he said, civic groups should also come together to promote the cause of ensuring children's safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan needs competitive edge to benefit fully from links: experts

TEXT.P: While most Taiwan businesses appear to be pleased with the opening of direct transport, trade and postal links between Taiwan and China, some people are urging that if Taiwan wants to take full advantage of the links, it should move swiftly to sharpen its competitiveness and improve its investment environment.
The head of a Taiwanese businessmen association in Beijing, Lin Ching-fa, described the "major three links" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as a "good thing."

However, Lin said, the Taiwan economy will not benefit from the opening unless the country has a sound plan to maximize the effects of the direct links and integrates its resources to more effectively reach international markets.

For example, Lin said, the harbors he has visited in mainland China are mostly capable of accommodating big cruise ships. By comparison, Taiwan's harbors, including the largest Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan, will have to be expanded if they are to host bigger ships and if Taiwan is to serve as a major transshipment hub in the region, he added.

Taiwan's seaports should be transformed into tariff-free harbors so that they can keep pace with the changes in cross-strait relations and attract the expected increase in business opportunities, Lin suggested.

To Taiwanese businessmen, the expanded direct links represent channels for "inflows of persons, goods and money," Lin added, urging the government to help local enterprises to acquire a competitive edge in the new cross-strait environment as soon as possible.

Chang Wu-yueh, dean of the Graduate Institute of China Studies at the Taipei- based Tamkang University, said Taiwan's ability to maximize the advantages of the new marine and air transport links is dependent on its competitive edge, its support for the global development projects of local enterprises, and its efficiency in forging links with the international market through the new cross-strait economic openings.

Expanded direct cross-strait charter flight services were launched Dec. 15, with carriers from both sides providing passenger service every day of the week instead of on weekends only. The number of flights have been increased from 36 to 108 per week and the carriers are now permitted to fly directly to destinations in northern China without having to detour through Hong Kong air space.

Also, with the opening of direct shipping links, vessels operating on cross- strait shipping routes are allowed to sail across the Taiwan Strait without having to detour to Japan's Ishigaki port. The number of ports in Taiwan and China open to cross-strait shipping services has also been increased to 74.
In his analysis of the benefits of the expanded direct transport links, Chang said that politically they have established a foundation for peace in the strait.

In terms of the economy, the links will boost bilateral cross-strait trade, which has reached US$130.2 billion a year, he said. In the short term, the links will be beneficial to airline and shipping companies, traders, fruit shippers and passengers traveling between the two sides, he added.

In the long term, other industries, such as those in the tourism sector, will profit as a result of the direct air links, especially if more Chinese tourists come to Taiwan for sightseeing as a result, Chang forecast.

Chang said that in general Taiwan's ability to take full advantage of the links is dependent of whether or not it can effect fast and convenient passenger and cargo service between the two sides of the strait.
He further forecast that positive interaction between the two sides will attract investments to Taiwan from around the globe.

However, he warned, wider opening for personnel exchanges could lead to a flight of Taiwanese talent to mainland China if Taiwan does not improve and upgrade its investment and industrial environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Avian flu virus caused chicken deaths in southern Taiwan: COA

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) confirmed Saturday that the recent chicken deaths on a poultry farm in southern Taiwan were caused by the low-pathogenic H5N2 bird flu virus, but stressed that the virus is not the same as the high- pathogenic H5N1 strain in China.
The Cabinet-level COA reiterated that the H5N2 virus is so far not known to be communicable to humans and gave the assurance that domestic poultry products are still safe for consumption.

COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung told a press conference that his agency will step up its monitoring of wild and migratory birds and will continue for at least three months its disinfection of 76 poultry farms within a radius of three kilometers of the farm in Luchu township in Kaohsiung County where 400 chickens were found dead in late October.
Local authorities have also been instructed to strengthen epidemic prevention and control measures, the COA said.
The source of the avian flu infection is still being investigated, according to Sung Hwa-tsung, director general of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the COA.

Earlier this week, Japan suspended imports of poultry from Taiwan although it had not yet been confirmed that the chickens had died from the H5N2 avian flu virus. According to COA statistics, poultry meat and egg exports from Taiwan to Japan are valued at around US$28 million per year.
Chen said that the government will provide a series of special subsidies to help industries that may suffer as a result of the avian flu outbreak.

The subsidies will include raising the maximum value of loans to farmers from NT$20 million to NT$30 million and those to related agricultural industries from NT$30 million to NT$40 million, and lowering the annual interest rate on such loans to 1.5 percent, he added.
The COA said it will also activate a mechanism to stabilize the price of poultry meat, if there is a price drop.

Addressing concerns about the COA's delay in publicizing the results of its findings, Lee Shu-hwae, deputy director general of the Animal Health Research Institute under the COA, said that under standard operating procedure, it requires 19 to 40 days to obtain the most precise and accurate test results.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma rejects proposal to import larger numbers of foreign workers

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that in light of the rising unemployment in Taiwan, it would be difficult at this time for the government to increase the foreign labor force.
"The society will not forgive" the government for such a move, Ma said in response to a request from local enterprises to allow the import of larger numbers of foreign workers.

In a meeting between the president and more than 100 company owners and representatives at the Taiwan Industrial Park in the northern county of Taoyuan, some businessmen complained that local workers appear reluctant to take certain types of jobs and they asked Ma to consider allowing the recruitment of larger numbers of foreign labor.

In response, Ma said that he knows local companies are facing tough challenges in maintaining their business in the current economic environment which is being impacted by the global financial crisis.

However, the president said, he has instructed the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to contact those companies that have asked for a larger foreign work force and to try to supply them with local workers.

The CLA announced a few days ago, amid calls for the government to help local people gain employment, that it will conduct an overall review to Taiwan's foreign laborer policy to safeguard job opportunities for Taiwanese.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing urged to open infrastructure market to Taiwan bidders
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec.20 (CNA) 12/20/08 23:02:59 (By Chang Ming-kun, Kuo Mei-lan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China should open its infrastructure construction projects to Taiwanese bidders as part of mutual cooperation efforts to cope with the current global economic recession, the head of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday.
KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung made the appeal at the opening session of the fourth Cross-Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum, co-organized by the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC).
Wu said he looks forward to China's opening of its immense public infrastructure construction market to Taiwanese bidders.
In the next two years, China will pump 4 trillion yuan (about US$586 billion) into its economy to help spur domestic demand and sustain overall growth amid the lingering global financial crisis.
"Hopefully, Taiwanese bidders will be given access to China's public works construction projects," Wu said, adding that Taiwan will also be willing to open its market to Chinese contractors.
By so doing, Wu said, the two sides will be able to mutually invest and learn from each other's experience in project management and the development of new engineering technologies.

Wu further expressed hopes that the two sides will explore a feasible mode for mutual cooperation in the financial field, and in particular devise measures to help a large number of Taiwan-owned businesses in China obtain working capital or bank loans to keep their companies afloat in the midst of the current worldwide economic downturn.

Promotional efforts should also be intensified to galvanize more Chinese citizens into making pleasure trips to Taiwan now that direct cross-strait charter flights have been expanded to a daily service from the weekends-only formula, Wu added.

Speaking on the same occasion, KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan said the two sides should forge a viable mechanism for normalizing their trade and economic relations, since China has become Taiwan's most important trade partner and largest export market.

"It's strategically significant for our two sides to thrash out a comprehensive mechanism for normal trade and economic exchanges and cooperation across the Taiwan Strait," Lien explained, adding that he hopes the ongoing two-day KMT-CPC forum can come up with concrete proposals in this regard.
Five Taiwan government officials, including Shan Chi, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, are attending the party-to-party forum in a private capacity.

Shan delivered a speech on Taiwan's general economic situation and prospects for cross-strait economic cooperation, making him the first senior Taiwan government official ever to speak in the KMT-CPC forum.
In his address, Shan suggested that the two sides explore the feasibility of taking part in each other's economic stimulus projects to accelerate recovery of their economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: China travel ban will not be lifted unconditionally: premier

TEXT.P: Certain restrictions or conditions will remain in place when the current regulations are revised to make it easier for senior officials and military personnel to visit China, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Saturday.
Liu was responding to criticism that the planned lifting of restrictions on visits to China by senior officials and servicemen could put national security at risk.

Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Huang Kun-huei suggested earlier in the day that civil servants in charge of tasks related with classified intelligence should not be allowed to visit China.

In response, Liu said relevant government agencies are still working on a legal amendment package which, while paving the way for senior civil servants, political appointees, top executives of state-owned enterprises and military personnel to visit China for business purposes or pleasure trips, will retain certain restrictions on such travel.

The premier first indicated Friday that the Cabinet is working toward the goal of lifting the travel restrictions, which apply to civil servants at grade 11 or higher, political appointees, top executives of state-owned enterprises and military personnel.

Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said Saturday that the government will make sure Taiwan's dignity and sovereign status are not undermined when it lifts its restrictions on visits to China by senior officials and military personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 21, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

"It's strategically significant for our two sides to thrash out a comprehensive mechanism for normal trade and economic exchanges and cooperation across the Taiwan Strait," Lien explained, adding that he hopes the ongoing two-day KMT-CPC forum can come up with concrete proposals in this regard.
Five Taiwan government officials, including Shan Chi, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, are attending the party-to-party forum in a private capacity.

Shan delivered a speech on Taiwan's general economic situation and prospects for cross-strait economic cooperation, making him the first senior Taiwan government official ever to speak in the KMT-CPC forum.
In his address, Shan suggested that the two sides explore the feasibility of taking part in each other's economic stimulus projects to accelerate recovery of their economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: China travel ban will not be lifted unconditionally: premier

TEXT.P: Certain restrictions or conditions will remain in place when the current regulations are revised to make it easier for senior officials and military personnel to visit China, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Saturday.
Liu was responding to criticism that the planned lifting of restrictions on visits to China by senior officials and servicemen could put national security at risk.

Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Huang Kun-huei suggested earlier in the day that civil servants in charge of tasks related with classified intelligence should not be allowed to visit China.

In response, Liu said relevant government agencies are still working on a legal amendment package which, while paving the way for senior civil servants, political appointees, top executives of state-owned enterprises and military personnel to visit China for business purposes or pleasure trips, will retain certain restrictions on such travel.

The premier first indicated Friday that the Cabinet is working toward the goal of lifting the travel restrictions, which apply to civil servants at grade 11 or higher, political appointees, top executives of state-owned enterprises and military personnel.

Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said Saturday that the government will make sure Taiwan's dignity and sovereign status are not undermined when it lifts its restrictions on visits to China by senior officials and military personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 21, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 21, or the 24th day of the 11th month of Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: Pilgrims on the ship Mayflower come ashore at Plymouth, Massachusetts.
1804: Mohammed Ali Jinnah, founder and first governor-general of Pakistan, is born.
1817: Governor Lachlan Macquarie formally adopts the name "Australia" for the British colony located on the continent with the same present-day name.
1876: Joseph Stalin, Soviet leader, is born.
1898: Scientists Pierre Curie and Marie Curie discover radium.
1901: The "Ching Yi Pao," a newspaper founded by Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in 1898, ceases publishing after the 100th issue.
1930: Hwang Thu-sui, Taiwan's first sculptor, dies at the age of 35.
1935: Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premieres in the United States.
1940: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the American author who chronicled the Jazz Age in books such as "Tender is the Night" and "The Great Gatsby," dies at the age of 44.
1945: George Smith Patton Jr., the U.S. general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany during World War II, dies in a car crash at the age of 60.
1958: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France after a new constitution is adopted, marking the beginning of the Fifth Republic.
1968: The Apollo 8 spacecraft, as a part of the United States' Apollo program to land men on the moon, is launched.
1971: Hsieh Kuan-sheng, president of the Judicial Yuan, dies in Taipei.
1971: Kurt Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat who later become president, is chosen to be the secretary-general of the United Nations on his birthday.
1972: East and West Germany sign a treaty ending more than two decades of enmity.
1975: The convention of the World Chinese Language Education Association opens in Taipei.
1975: Oil ministers from 12 countries are taken hostage after terrorists raid an OPEC meeting in Vienna, Austria.
1975: The Executive Yuan announces that Taiwan's economy grew by 2.8 percent in 1975, with a GNP of US$14.4 billion and per capita income of US$700.
1988: Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Vladimir Titov return to earth after a record 365 days in space.
1988: A Pan American jumbo jet crashes in the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, killing all 258 people on board.
1990: The building of the ROC Navy's first missile frigate begins at the Kaohsiung shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp.
1991: The ruling Kuomintang wins 71 percent of the vote and 254 of the 325 seats in elections for the Second National Assembly.
1995: Under an agreement signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1995, Israeli troops withdraw from Bethlehem, ending their 28 years of occupation.
1998: Beijing sentences mainland Chinese dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai to prison terms of more than 10 years each for trying to register the China Democracy Party.
1999: Taiwan is listed as the 12th-most important maritime country in the world for the year.
2000: Taiwan's non-profit Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) announces the development of a commercial software package, dubbed Fast Local Alignment for Gigabases (FLAG), allowing rapid genomic DNA searches and comparisons.
2001: The Legislative Yuan approves an amendment to the Employment Services Act allowing foreign workers to work in Taiwan up to six years instead of three years.
Confucius: "Uphold the cause of the just and put down every cause that is unjust, and the people will submit. But uphold the cause of the unjust and put down every cause that is just, then the people will not submit."
