DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing urged to open infrastructure market to Taiwan bidders
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec.20 (CNA) 12/21/08 10:51:49 (By Chang Ming-kun, Kuo Mei-lan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China should open its infrastructure construction projects to Taiwanese bidders as part of mutual cooperation efforts to cope with the current global economic recession, the head of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday.
KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung made the appeal at the opening session of the fourth Cross-Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum, co-organized by the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC).
Wu said he looks forward to China's opening of its immense public infrastructure construction market to Taiwanese bidders.
In the next two years, China will pump 4 trillion yuan (about US$586 billion) into its economy to help spur domestic demand and sustain overall growth amid the lingering global financial crisis.
"Hopefully, Taiwanese bidders will be given access to China's public works construction projects," Wu said, adding that Taiwan will also be willing to open its market to Chinese contractors.
By so doing, Wu said, the two sides will be able to mutually invest and learn from each other's experience in project management and the development of new engineering technologies.

Wu further expressed hopes that the two sides will explore a feasible mode for mutual cooperation in the financial field, and in particular devise measures to help a large number of Taiwan-owned businesses in China obtain working capital or bank loans to keep their companies afloat in the midst of the current worldwide economic downturn.

Promotional efforts should also be intensified to galvanize more Chinese citizens into making pleasure trips to Taiwan now that direct cross-strait charter flights have been expanded to a daily service from the weekends-only formula, Wu added.

Speaking on the same occasion, KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan said the two sides should forge a viable mechanism for normalizing their trade and economic relations, since China has become Taiwan's most important trade partner and largest export market.

"It's strategically significant for our two sides to thrash out a comprehensive mechanism for normal trade and economic exchanges and cooperation across the Taiwan Strait," Lien explained, adding that he hopes the ongoing two-day KMT-CPC forum can come up with concrete proposals in this regard.
Five Taiwan government officials, including Shan Chi, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, are attending the party-to-party forum in a private capacity.

Shan delivered a speech on Taiwan's general economic situation and prospects for cross-strait economic cooperation, making him the first senior Taiwan government official ever to speak in the KMT-CPC forum.
In his address, Shan suggested that the two sides explore the feasibility of taking part in each other's economic stimulus projects to accelerate recovery of their economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma rejects proposal to import larger numbers of foreign workers

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that in light of the rising unemployment in Taiwan, it would be difficult at this time for the government to increase the foreign labor force.
"The society will not forgive" the government for such a move, Ma said in response to a request from local enterprises to allow the import of larger numbers of foreign workers.

In a meeting between the president and more than 100 company owners and representatives at the Taiwan Industrial Park in the northern county of Taoyuan, some businessmen complained that local workers appear reluctant to take certain types of jobs and they asked Ma to consider allowing the recruitment of larger numbers of foreign labor.

In response, Ma said that he knows local companies are facing tough challenges in maintaining their business in the current economic environment which is being impacted by the global financial crisis.

However, the president said, he has instructed the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to contact those companies that have asked for a larger foreign work force and to try to supply them with local workers.

The CLA announced a few days ago, amid calls for the government to help local people gain employment, that it will conduct an overall review to Taiwan's foreign laborer policy to safeguard job opportunities for Taiwanese.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magistrate revs up local economy in fun, humanistic ways

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer

Spanish tenor Jose Carreras thrilled a packed audience of over 50,000 at the Miaoli County Stadium on a warm November evening this year, in the kind of show that is rarely seen in the predominantly agricultural county in north-central Taiwan.
In an innovative show of generosity, the Miaoli county government gave out 40,000 free tickets for the show, but more than 50,000 people showed up on the night.

Although the organizers opened the side gate of the stadium to let in some of the disappointed hopefuls half an hour after the concert began, there were still some 10,000 people left sitting on a riverbank near the stadium who had to make do with listening to a live broadcast of the internationally renowned maestro's performance.

Despite causing traffic jams in the normally serene hilly city, the unprecedented concert raised the self-esteem of Miaoli folks, who felt privileged and respected by the county government as a result of the concert.

The county government spent NT$20 million (US$597,000) to line up the concert -- a move initiated by Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung, who once said that it makes his heart ache to see Miaoli County, long considered a "cultural desert, " left out each time a major cultural event has taken place in Taiwan.
The rare concert, open to all, also helped attract many visitors from further afield than Miaoli who spent money in the county, which Liu had anticipated.
Liu, a six-term Kuomintang legislator, in 2005 became the first non-Hakka magistrate in the history of Miaoli County -- a major Hakka area in Taiwan with a Hakka population of 70 percent.

"Hakka" literally means "guest people." Roughly 27 percent of Taiwan's population consider themselves descendants of Hakka ancestors, believed to have emigrated from the Yellow River area some 1,000 years ago to southern China to escape war and famine and who thereafter moved to Taiwan and represent a sizeable diaspora elsewhere in the world.

The happy times didn't stop with Carreras. Miaoli residents were entertained Dec. 3-5 by another globally famous group -- the Irish River Dance -- with tickets available to the locals at giveaway prices, also partially financed by the county government.

Meanwhile, when the motion picture 1895, a Hakka-language epic portraying one of the biggest battles in the history of Taiwan, was released in early November, Liu's office treated Miaoli residents to free screenings.

Not a dry eye in the house as the movie, based on a novel by one of Taiwan's best-known Hakka writers, Li Chiao, brings to life Hakka militia resistance to Japanese troops after Qing Dynasty China was defeated in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-95) and ceded Taiwan to Tokyo under the Treaty of Shimonoseki.

During those days of cultural entertainment, reservations for rooms in hotels, hostels and guest houses scattered around Miaoli County were all booked, shops and restaurants were packed, and business operators were smiling from ear to ear at their good fortune.
The treats were actually feedback to the Miaoli folks, paid for out of prize money that Liu and his administration won from the central government in an investment inducement competition.

Miaoli County won first prize -- a handsome NT$100 million -- in the Level B investment inducement competition for successfully inducing several manufacturing companies to relocate some of their investments to Miaoli, traditionally an agricultural area and a relative backwater in terms of business and industry.

Liu personally gave briefings during the competition on how the county succeeded in persuading leading hi-tech manufacturing companies, including the Hon Hai Group -- the world's largest contract maker of consumer electronics by revenue -- into establishing factories in Miaoli to take advantage of the area's inexpensive land, labor force and all relevant costs, an endeavor Liu said has in turn infused new life and energy into the county's economy.

In order to rev up the county's slumping economy, Liu has pulled out all the stops, including moves to take full advantage when the Executive Yuan distributes free shopping vouchers nationwide in January to spur spending and bolster economic growth.

Liu, the shrewd and industrious son of a farmer who became head of farmers' associations in the Miaoli area at a very young age before climbing the political ladder to become a legislator and then magistrate, has decided to invest NT$10 million to generate business on the back of the shopping vouchers.

His office announced recently that every person who spends NT$5,000 in the county, including the NT$3,600 shopping vouchers that each Taiwan citizen will receive from Jan. 18, will be entered in a lucky draw, with prizes including 10 luxury cars, 100 TFT-LED televisions, refrigerators and many other hi-tech health and entertainment gear.

Liu reckons that if all 560,000 Miaoli residents spend their shopping vouchers in the county, business worth over NT$2.8 billion will be generated in a span of nine months, which in turn will create over NT$70 million in tax revenues for the county coffers. The vouchers will remain valid from Jan. 18 until Sept. 30 next year.

Liu, who has been learning the Hakka dialect since being elected magistrate and who has even sat Cabinet-sponsored Hakka language tests in order to bridge the conversation gap with his constituents, is not all business, however.

With the remaining funds that his administration won in the investment inducement competition, he was instrumental in helping care for youths from destitute families or those who were marked for special discipline because of behavioral problems.

After finding out from social workers that many young people in the county have never gone on a leisure outing with their parents because of poverty or other reasons, Liu decided to give each such youth -- around 3,300 -- NT$1,500 so that they could go out with their parents or guardians to spend some "quality time," even just once.

Liu, who has never ceased striving over the past three years to improve the county's development, told CNA that his greatest aspiration is to turn Miaoli into a city suitable for investment, good for living and attractive for tourists by the time he finishes his two four-year stints in 2013.

He echoed the motto that his predecessor, Hsieh Chin-ting, passed on to him when he was sworn in three years ago that as a magistrate, he will "leave morality to the offspring, development to the county and only my name to myself."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
SEF pushes for increased number of cross-strait charter flights

TEXT.P: Taiwan's intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) has been working to secure an agreement on increasing the number of direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights to 168 per week during the upcoming Lunar New Year holidays from the current 108, according an SEF official.

SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian was quoted by the Hong Kong-based daily Wen Wei Po as saying Saturday that the SEF is currently negotiating with the relevant Chinese authorities to increase the number of charters over the Chinese New Year to accommodate the many Taiwanese businesspeople and their dependents who usually return to Taiwan at that time.

Kao was quoted as telling the 20-odd heads of Taiwanese business associations around China during a meeting in the southern Chinese city of Xiamen that "there might be good news in this regard before the 2009 Chinese New Year's Day," which falls on Jan. 26.

Kao, who doubles as secretary-general of the quasi-official SEF, made the remarks after a Wuhan-based Taiwanese businessman Yu Ming-chin stated at the meeting that the current 108 cross-strait flights per week can only accommodate around 1.5 million Taiwanese travelers a year.

"That is inadequate by far to meet actual demand, as Taiwanese make roughly 6 million visits to and from China each year, " said Yu, who is a vice chairman of the Association of Taiwanese Invested Enterprises on the Mainland.
"About 70 percent of the Taiwanese who frequently visit China will not be able to enjoy the convenience of traveling via the existing cross-strait charter flights," Yu claimed.

Meanwhile, according to the Wen Wei Po report, Kao said that following his own visits to China to listen to the needs and problems of Taiwanese businesspeople there, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung will also meet with Taiwanese business leaders in Guangdong Province and Jiangsu Province from Jan. 7-11.

Issues expected to be discussed during the meetings between Chiang and the Taiwanese business leaders include fund constraints, ways of extending loans to Taiwanese businesses, and the problems they have been facing as result of higher taxes and overhead costs since China's implementation of new labor contract and land use laws.

According to Kao, Chiang and the SEF officials will also discuss the reduction of customs tariffs with their Chinese counterparts, a move that may eventually lead to developing the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as free trade zones, the Wen Wei Po reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kenyans win ING Taipei international marathon titles

TEXT.P: Kenyan runners won both the men's and women's titles in the 2008 ING Taipei International Marathon Sunday.
Sammy Chumba won the men's title in a time of in 2 hours, 15 minutes, 37 seconds, while Caroline Kilel took the women's title, clocking 2:30:44.

Kilel took home NT$1.33 million in prize money, as she not only won the 42-km race, but also broke the 151-minute record set by her countrywoman Jane Auro in 2006. Chumba collected the first prize of NT$100,000 (US$3,072) for his win.
The organizers have made NT$1.33 million available in cash awards for record- breaking winners in the competition.
Kilel said she will use her prize money to buy a piece of land in her home country. As a professional athlete, Kilel said, she depends entirely on her sport for a living.
Chumba said he will use his prize money to make improvements to his home and to help his family to lead a better life.

Local marathoner Wu Wen-chien won the Taiwanese men's title in a time of 2: 17: 24, while Hsu Yu-fang won the Taiwanese women's title in 2: 47: 00. Wu finished fourth in the men's marathon and Hsu finished 19th in women's.

The 2008 ING Taipei International Marathon kicked off at 7 a.m. at the plaza in front of Taipei City Hall Sunday, with 121,000 runners from 40 countries taking part in five categories of road racing, according to ING Antai Insurance Co., a key sponsor of the event.
A record 27,000-plus runners competed this year, representing a year-on-year increase of 30 percent, the ING said.

DOC.HEADLINE: People with problems urged to call social welfare hotline for help

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) on Sunday encouraged people facing sudden financial difficulties and other problems due to the current economic recession to phone the "1957 national welfare hotline" for help.

The central government, in collaboration with local governments, set up the hotline in November 2006 to provide timely help to people with dire problems. The service offers on-site visits, emergency relief, employment assistance and legal counseling.

So far this year, an average of 1,000-1,990 calls per month were made to the hotline, with most callers seeking emergency relief, unemployment support, and medical treatment aid, according to the ministry.
Many people have successfully overcome their difficulties with the help of the service provided via the hotline, the MOI said.

The ministry cited the example of a man surnamed Hsiung in Taoyuan County, who was granted urgent financial subsidies at first and later landed a job with the help of the local government's employment center after he made a call earlier in the year to the hotline seeking assistance.

At the time, Hsiung had suffered a number of blows in quick succession and was reeling from the death of his wife, the loss of his job and his financial inability to look after his young child, according to the MOI.
Usually, there is a spike in the number of calls just before the Chinese New Year, the MOI said, noting that 1,991 calls were recorded in January, the highest number for the year so far.

The ministry anticipates that more and more people will be seeking urgent help, in light of the increasing number of businesses that are failing and the rising unemployment in the country due to the economic slowdown.
Therefore, it said, it is urging people with problems to call the hotline to obtain help.

DOC.HEADLINE: Application process opens for housing subsidies

TEXT.P: The second round of applications for a government-sponsored housing subsidy that will help cover rental and interest payments has now been opened, the Construction and Planning Agency announced Sunday, urging eligible families to apply at their local household registry office.
Under the program, the government will offer a subsidy of up to NT$3,000 per month for one year to eligible families to help them cover their rent, the agency under the Ministry of the Interior said.

The government will also subsidize the interest payments by new home buyers on loans of up to NT$2.2 million with a 20-year repayment period. Borrowers of house repair loans of up to NT$800,000 with an 15-year repayment period are also elegible to apply for subsidies to help pay the interest, according to the agency.
Applications for the rental subsidy will expire Dec. 31 this year, while applications for government-subsidized home loans will expire Feb. 25, 2009, the agency said.
The agency first announced the program earlier in the year, calling for applications, which closed on Aug. 15.
In the second application phase, there are 8,000 openings for rental subsidies, 25,445 for home loan subsidies, and 3,720 for home improvement loan subsidies, according to the agency.

Under the program, the preferential interest rate on loans to eligible households is 1.617 percent, and on those to disadvantaged families 1.042 percent. The country's central bank lowered its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point earlier in the month, the agency noted.

This home purchase loan scheme will be administered in conjunction with another preferential home loan program launched on Sept. 22, under which the government will allocate an additional NT$200 billion until Sept. 21, 2010 to grant each qualified household in Taipei City a maximum loan of NT$3.5 million at a preferential interest rate, the agency added.
For eligible households outside Taipei City, the maximum figure for such loans is NT$3 million.

Families with an annual combined income of less than NT$970,000 and who do not own a home can apply for a home purchase loan or a housing rental subsidy, while those who own a house that is more than 10 years old can apply for a house improvement loan, according to the agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: China willing to extend economic support to Taiwanese firms: official
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/08 19:06:08 (By Chang Ming-kun, Kuo Mei-lan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: China's top official in charge of Taiwan affairs announced 10 measures Sunday to boost business and trade exchanges with Taiwan and increase financial assistance to Taiwanese businesspeople operating on the mainland.

Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, said Chinese banking institutions, including China Development Bank, Bank of China and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, will be authorized to increase their loans and credit services, to a maximum of 130 billion Chinese yuan (US$18.99 billion), to China-based Taiwanese enterprises over the next three years to help them tide over the difficulties they face in the global economic downturn.

Wang made the announcement at the fourth joint Cross-Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum held by Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China (CPC). The forum opened in Shanghai Saturday and closed Sunday.
According to Wang, the Chinese authorities will help China-based Taiwanese enterprises to upgrade or restructure so as to sharpen their competitiveness.

China will push for increased bilateral investment across the Taiwan Strait and will help boost cooperation among industrial manufacturing sectors on both sides to make them more competitive in the international market, Wang said.
Mainland Chinese TFT-LED TV manufacturers will increase purchases of display panels from Taiwanese makers, with the shopping list to total US$2 billion in the initial stage, Wang said.

China will also expand agricultural cooperation with Taiwan, Wang said, adding that three Chinese provinces -- Jiangsu, Guangdong and Yunnan -- will make tracts of land available exclusively for Taiwanese farmers to develop farms in China.

China and Taiwan should expedite negotiations on affairs pertaining to customs clearance and quarantine procedures so as to speed up Taiwan's sale of seafood and other fresh grocery products to Chinese markets, Wang suggested.
China will also allow Taiwanese lawyers to practice in China once they comply with certain conditions set by the Chinese government, he added.

KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan led a party delegation at the forum. Five Taiwan government officials, including San Gee, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, also attended the party-to-party forum in a private capacity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Smoking lawmakers to adjust to smoke-free work environment

TEXT.P: Inveterate smokers in the legislature are preparing to adjust to a smoke-free work environment from Jan. 11, when Taiwan's newly amended Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act becomes effective.

Asked on Friday to comment on the change dictated by law, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said the legislature will do everything in accordance with the law, and that from Jan. 11, none of the legislators, their constituents or staff will be allowed to smoke on the premises of the legislature.
Under the amended Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act, smoking is banned in all indoor workplaces staffed by three or more employees.
The law also prohibits smoking in other public indoor areas, such as KTV lounges, bowling alleys, cybercafes, and passenger waiting rooms.
Smoking is also banned, under the law, in outdoor public areas, including train station platforms, gymnasiums, swimming pools, college campuses, and entertainment areas.
Violators will risk fines of between NT$2,000 and NT$10,000 (US$605).

Legislative Yuan Secretary-General Lin Hsi-shan pointed out that under the new law the legislature is not permitted to designate a smoking area within the building and that legislators who wish to smoke will have to do so outside the building.

Lee Hung-chun, a legislator of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) who has been a smoker since he was a student more than 30 years ago, said it may be time now for him to quit the habit because of the inconvenience of finding a place to smoke.
KMT Legislator Tsai Chin-lung, who has already kicked his 30-year habit, encouraged his colleagues to follow his example and quit smoking.
"If they really cannot kick the habit, they must be more observant of the new law than the ordinary public," he said.
KMT Legislator Shuai Hua-ming said he will respect other people's right to refuse to inhale second-hand smoke, and that when he feels like smoking, he will go outside the building.

Legislator Ker Chien-ming, the chain-smoking legislative caucus convener of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said he still has reservations about whether it might be difficult to comply with the law, but added that he will do his best.
DPP Legislator Pan Meng-an said jokingly that he will probably go into depression because of the new law, but he added, "I am afraid that I may have to quit smoking."
DPP Legislator Tien Chiu-chin, who has campaigned hard against smoking, said that smoking has become such a serious public hazard that it is necessary to maintain a smoke-free work environment.

She quoted an estimate by the Cabinet-level Department of Health which shows that smoking-induced diseases have cost the Bureau of National Insurance an extra NT$30 billion (US$922.58 million) a year in terms of medical expenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait trade cooperation not yet on agenda: SEF chair

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Sunday that economic and trade cooperation agreements will not be part of his third meeting with President of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) Chen Yunlin.

"However, although economic and trade cooperation will not be discussed in our next meeting, we do hope that our governments will raise this issue at an appropriate time," Chiang said at a conference held to discuss Taiwan's future.

His remarks came one day after the honorary chairman of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Lien Chan said at a joint forum of the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Shanghai that establishing amechanism for economic and trade cooperation would be of strategic value to both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lien said the two sides should forge a viable mechanism for normalizing their trade and economic relations, since China has become Taiwan's most important trade partner and largest export market.

"Lien made those comments because President Ma Ying-jeou promised in his election campaign to raise the issue of economic and trade cooperation between Taiwan and China, " Chiang said. "This is very important to the future development of cross-strait ties."

Chiang said that Taiwan could find itself at a disadvantage in the region as it is not a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and in light of an agreement among ASEAN and the plus three nations -- China, Japan and South Korea -- to end trade tariffs.
Therefore, economic and trade cooperation with mainland China will be crucial to Taiwan's future economic development, Chiang said.
The SEF chairman said his third meeting with Chen next year will focus on mutual investment, food safety, tax issues, intellectual property rights and crime fighting.
"However, we will discuss economic and trade cooperation with mainland China in the near future," he added.

In their second meeting Nov. 3-7 in Taiwan, Chen and Chiang sealed four agreements on expanded direct cross-strait air services, direct shipping and postal links, and a communication channel on food safety issues. Their historic first meeting was held six months earlier in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ruling, opposition parties to pay smaller staff bonuses

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party have each decided to cut their year-end bonuses to their staff, as both parties are feeling the squeeze of the global economic downturn.

However, the administrations of the two parties gave the assurance that despite the challenging financial environment, their workers will receive bonuses, albeit smaller ones, because they have worked hard during the year.
"No matter how tough the economic situation, we will take care of our staff," said Lin Yung-rey, a KMT administrative official. "We will tighten our belts and withstand these tough economic times."
Lin said that the KMT will pay an average of half a month's salary to all staff members, which will amount to least NT$10,000 (US$303) each.
"No matter what, the KMT will not lay off staff or cut salaries," he added.

Noting that in the past, when the economy was good, the KMT paid year-end bonuses of around one to one and a half months' salary, he said that with a current staff of 900, it will cost the party a lot to pay even the reduced bonuses this year.
Meanwhile, the DPP has decided to give an across-the-board bonus of NT$10,000 to its staff, according to the party's chief communications officer Cheng Wen- tsang.
The DPP, in the past, gave its staff one month to one and a half months' salary in bonuses when the economy was stronger," Cheng recalled.
However this year, because of the economic situation, the 102 staff members of the party will each receive a fixed amount of NT$10,000, he added.
Cheng commended the staff of the opposition party for their

work in the past year, adding that the DPP will host a traditional Lunar year- end party for its workers and that DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen will pay for it from her own pocket. The KMT will hold its end-of-year party for its staff on Jan. 21, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation seeking innovative ideas on caring for the elderly

TEXT.P: People with sound ideas on providing care for the elderly have a chance to win NT$30,000 (NT$992) in a competition sponsored by the Hondao Foundation in Taichung City to solicit such ideas.

The foundation, which is dedicated to the welfare of the country's senior citizens, said in a press release that it is seeking to develop an innovative action program to care for the society's "grandpas and grandmas".

Proposals should be presented before the dealine of Dec. 25 in no more than 100 Chinese characters, and will be judged at three different levels -- kindergarten and elementary school students, middle school to university students, and other adults.
The foundation has suggested that the proposals detail any of six broad areas of elderly care -- diet, clothing, accommodation, transportation, education and recreation.

In order to instill in the public a sense of appreciation for the elderly, the foundation has designated the second Sunday of January each year as "Grandpa and Grandma Day, " and will mark it with activities to show care and respect for senior citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police seize NT$170 million worth of marijuana in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Law-enforcement agents in southern Taiwan have seized 40 kilograms of marijuana that was smuggled into the country from Latin America via China, the southern Taiwan mobile unit of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice disclosed Sunday.

A spokesman for the unit said that its investigators and police officers from Tainan County, headed by prosecutors from Kaohsiung, raided the residence of Chen Chin-chang, 52, in Baihe township, Tainan County, and seized 40 marijuana bricks, each weighing one kilogram.
The confiscated marijuana has a street value of NT$170 million (US$5.23 million) and would have been enough to supply 400,000 addicts, according to an estimate by the investigators.

The spokesman said that Chen worked with Dai Shun-yi, 52, a member of Yungan Township Council in Kaohsiung County, by hiring a fishing boat to transport the marijuana that was concealed in vacuum sealed tea packages.
He added that Chen, a Taiwanese businessman in China, was in desperate need of money because he was deeply in debt as a result of his gambling habit.
Chen and Dai will face charges of violating the Narcotics Endangerment Prevention Act and the Act for the Control and Punishment of Smuggling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien County tourism festival aimed at attracting foreign visitors

TEXT.P: Hualien County is slated to hold its first Pacific International Tourism Festival Dec. 26 to Jan. 2009 at its Meiluen Brewery, in the hope of attracting more visitors from around the world, an event organizer said Monday.

In the face of the global economic recession, Taiwan has been working hard to attract foreign tourists by highlighting its special features and cultural characteristics, according to Kuomintang Legislator Fu Kun-chi of Hualien.

With this in mind, Hualien County plans to launch the festival with a focus on luring foreign tourists to view the first sunrise of 2009 from the coastal county overlooking the Pacific Ocean, Fu said.

The festival will target tourists from China, Europe and North America who plan to ring in the Chinese New Year in Asia, urging them to make Hualien their destination instead of Thailand or the Philippines, Fu said.
By staging the festival, the county hopes to sell itself as aworld-famous landmark on the Western Pacific Coast, Fu added.

Activities during the 10-day festival will include a large scale pop concert that will feature nearly 100 local performers, international concerts, light aircraft shows, and several exhibitions of defense weapon systems, motorcycles, art works and aboriginal handicraft.
The event organizers will also hold a lucky draw, with 200 tickets for Taipei- Hong Kong air travel at stake, Fu said.
He added that members of the Travel Agent Association of R.O.C have also promised to include the festival on their itineraries for foreign visitors to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of cross-strait flights may be increased during Lunar New Year
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/08 22:35:13 (By Chang Ming-kun and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of charter flights between Taiwan and China is likely to be increased from the current 108 per week to 168 during the Lunar New Year holiday, which begins Jan. 25, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Deputy Chairman Kao Koong-lian said in Shanghai Sunday.
Kao, who also serves as the SEF's secretary-general, is in Shanghai to attend the fourth Cross-Straits Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum as part of the Taiwan delegation.

He told Taiwanese businessmen in Shanghai that the SEF, aware that tickets for cross-strait flights during the Lunar New Year holiday have been sold out, is trying to negotiate with its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- to increase the number of flights to 168 per week.

Lee Lung-wen, director-general of Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), appeared optimistic about the proposal, saying that the agreement on direct flights across the Taiwan Strait, signed in Taipei in early November, allows for flexibility in terms of the number of flights.
Lee said there is still enough time to thrash out the issue so that the airline companies can adjust their flight schedules in time.
However, ARATS Deputy Secretary-general Li Ya-fei declined to comment on the issue, saying only that he needs to look into the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 22, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Opening of the Cross-Strait Forum on Bridge and Tunnel Engineering. Date and Time: 9.30 a.m., Monday, Dec. 22, 2008. Place: 1, ZhongShan North .Road.,Sec.4,Taipei, The Grand Hotel Taipei. Host and/or main speakers: Chiang Pin-kung. Organizers: Chinese Union of Professional Civil Engineer Associations. Press Contact:2748-1699
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: China visit ban will not be lifted unconditionally: premier

TEXT.P: Certain restrictions or conditions will remain in place when the current regulations are revised to make it easier for senior officials and military personnel to visit China, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Saturday.
Liu was responding to criticism that the planned lifting of restrictions on visits to China by senior officials and servicemen could put national security at risk.

Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Huang Kun-huei suggested earlier in the day that civil servants in charge of tasks related with classified intelligence should not be allowed to visit China.

In response, Liu said relevant government agencies are still working on a legal amendment package which, while paving the way for senior civil servants, political appointees, top executives of state-owned enterprises and military personnel to visit China for business purposes or pleasure trips, will retain certain restrictions on such travel.

The premier first indicated Friday that the Cabinet is working toward the goal of lifting the travel restrictions, which apply to civil servants at grade 11 or higher, political appointees, top executives of state-owned enterprises and military personnel.

Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said Saturday that the government will make sure Taiwan's dignity and sovereign status are not undermined when it lifts its restrictions on visits to China by senior officials and military personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing urged to open infrastructure market to Taiwan bidders
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec.20 (CNA) 12/21/08 10:51:49 (By Chang Ming-kun, Kuo Mei-lan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China should open its infrastructure construction projects to Taiwanese bidders as part of mutual cooperation efforts to cope with the current global economic recession, the head of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday.
KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung made the appeal at the opening session of the fourth Cross-Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum, co-organized by the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC).
Wu said he looks forward to China's opening of its immense public infrastructure construction market to Taiwanese bidders.
In the next two years, China will pump 4 trillion yuan (about US$586 billion) into its economy to help spur domestic demand and sustain overall growth amid the lingering global financial crisis.
"Hopefully, Taiwanese bidders will be given access to China's public works construction projects," Wu said, adding that Taiwan will also be willing to open its market to Chinese contractors.
By so doing, Wu said, the two sides will be able to mutually invest and learn from each other's experience in project management and the development of new engineering technologies.

Wu further expressed hopes that the two sides will explore a feasible mode for mutual cooperation in the financial field, and in particular devise measures to help a large number of Taiwan-owned businesses in China obtain working capital or bank loans to keep their companies afloat in the midst of the current worldwide economic downturn.

Promotional efforts should also be intensified to galvanize more Chinese citizens into making pleasure trips to Taiwan now that direct cross-strait charter flights have been expanded to a daily service from the weekends-only formula, Wu added.

Speaking on the same occasion, KMT honorary Chairman Lien Chan said the two sides should forge a viable mechanism for normalizing their trade and economic relations, since China has become Taiwan's most important trade partner and largest export market.

"It's strategically significant for our two sides to thrash out a comprehensive mechanism for normal trade and economic exchanges and cooperation across the Taiwan Strait," Lien explained, adding that he hopes the ongoing two-day KMT-CPC forum can come up with concrete proposals in this regard.
Five Taiwan government officials, including Shan Chi, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, are attending the party-to-party forum in a private capacity.

Shan delivered a speech on Taiwan's general economic situation and prospects for cross-strait economic cooperation, making him the first senior Taiwan government official ever to speak in the KMT-CPC forum.
In his address, Shan suggested that the two sides explore the feasibility of taking part in each other's economic stimulus projects to accelerate recovery of their economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma rejects proposal to import larger numbers of foreign workers

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that in light of the rising unemployment in Taiwan, it would be difficult at this time for the government to increase the foreign labor force.
"The society will not forgive" the government for such a move, Ma said in response to a request from local enterprises to allow the import of larger numbers of foreign workers.

In a meeting between the president and more than 100 company owners and representatives at the Taiwan Industrial Park in the northern county of Taoyuan, some businessmen complained that local workers appear reluctant to take certain types of jobs and they asked Ma to consider allowing the recruitment of larger numbers of foreign labor.

In response, Ma said that he knows local companies are facing tough challenges in maintaining their business in the current economic environment which is being impacted by the global financial crisis.

However, the president said, he has instructed the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to contact those companies that have asked for a larger foreign work force and to try to supply them with local workers.

The CLA announced a few days ago, amid calls for the government to help local people gain employment, that it will conduct an overall review to Taiwan's foreign laborer policy to safeguard job opportunities for Taiwanese.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magistrate revs up local economy in fun, humanistic ways

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer

Spanish tenor Jose Carreras thrilled a packed audience of over 50,000 at the Miaoli County Stadium on a warm November evening this year, in the kind of show that is rarely seen in the predominantly agricultural county in north-central Taiwan.
In an innovative show of generosity, the Miaoli county government gave out 40,000 free tickets for the show, but more than 50,000 people showed up on the night.

Although the organizers opened the side gate of the stadium to let in some of the disappointed hopefuls half an hour after the concert began, there were still some 10,000 people left sitting on a riverbank near the stadium who had to make do with listening to a live broadcast of the internationally renowned maestro's performance.

Despite causing traffic jams in the normally serene hilly city, the unprecedented concert raised the self-esteem of Miaoli folks, who felt privileged and respected by the county government as a result of the concert.

The county government spent NT$20 million (US$597,000) to line up the concert -- a move initiated by Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung, who once said that it makes his heart ache to see Miaoli County, long considered a "cultural desert, " left out each time a major cultural event has taken place in Taiwan.
The rare concert, open to all, also helped attract many visitors from further afield than Miaoli who spent money in the county, which Liu had anticipated.
Liu, a six-term Kuomintang legislator, in 2005 became the first non-Hakka magistrate in the history of Miaoli County -- a major Hakka area in Taiwan with a Hakka population of 70 percent.

"Hakka" literally means "guest people." Roughly 27 percent of Taiwan's population consider themselves descendants of Hakka ancestors, believed to have emigrated from the Yellow River area some 1,000 years ago to southern China to escape war and famine and who thereafter moved to Taiwan and represent a sizeable diaspora elsewhere in the world.

The happy times didn't stop with Carreras. Miaoli residents were entertained Dec. 3-5 by another globally famous group -- the Irish River Dance -- with tickets available to the locals at giveaway prices, also partially financed by the county government.

Meanwhile, when the motion picture 1895, a Hakka-language epic portraying one of the biggest battles in the history of Taiwan, was released in early November, Liu's office treated Miaoli residents to free screenings.

Not a dry eye in the house as the movie, based on a novel by one of Taiwan's best-known Hakka writers, Li Chiao, brings to life Hakka militia resistance to Japanese troops after Qing Dynasty China was defeated in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-95) and ceded Taiwan to Tokyo under the Treaty of Shimonoseki.

During those days of cultural entertainment, reservations for rooms in hotels, hostels and guest houses scattered around Miaoli County were all booked, shops and restaurants were packed, and business operators were smiling from ear to ear at their good fortune.
The treats were actually feedback to the Miaoli folks, paid for out of prize money that Liu and his administration won from the central government in an investment inducement competition.

Miaoli County won first prize -- a handsome NT$100 million -- in the Level B investment inducement competition for successfully inducing several manufacturing companies to relocate some of their investments to Miaoli, traditionally an agricultural area and a relative backwater in terms of business and industry.

Liu personally gave briefings during the competition on how the county succeeded in persuading leading hi-tech manufacturing companies, including the Hon Hai Group -- the world's largest contract maker of consumer electronics by revenue -- into establishing factories in Miaoli to take advantage of the area's inexpensive land, labor force and all relevant costs, an endeavor Liu said has in turn infused new life and energy into the county's economy.

In order to rev up the county's slumping economy, Liu has pulled out all the stops, including moves to take full advantage when the Executive Yuan distributes free shopping vouchers nationwide in January to spur spending and bolster economic growth.

Liu, the shrewd and industrious son of a farmer who became head of farmers' associations in the Miaoli area at a very young age before climbing the political ladder to become a legislator and then magistrate, has decided to invest NT$10 million to generate business on the back of the shopping vouchers.

His office announced recently that every person who spends NT$5,000 in the county, including the NT$3,600 shopping vouchers that each Taiwan citizen will receive from Jan. 18, will be entered in a lucky draw, with prizes including 10 luxury cars, 100 TFT-LED televisions, refrigerators and many other hi-tech health and entertainment gear.

Liu reckons that if all 560,000 Miaoli residents spend their shopping vouchers in the county, business worth over NT$2.8 billion will be generated in a span of nine months, which in turn will create over NT$70 million in tax revenues for the county coffers. The vouchers will remain valid from Jan. 18 until Sept. 30 next year.

Liu, who has been learning the Hakka dialect since being elected magistrate and who has even sat Cabinet-sponsored Hakka language tests in order to bridge the conversation gap with his constituents, is not all business, however.

With the remaining funds that his administration won in the investment inducement competition, he was instrumental in helping care for youths from destitute families or those who were marked for special discipline because of behavioral problems.

After finding out from social workers that many young people in the county have never gone on a leisure outing with their parents because of poverty or other reasons, Liu decided to give each such youth -- around 3,300 -- NT$1,500 so that they could go out with their parents or guardians to spend some "quality time," even just once.

Liu, who has never ceased striving over the past three years to improve the county's development, told CNA that his greatest aspiration is to turn Miaoli into a city suitable for investment, good for living and attractive for tourists by the time he finishes his two four-year stints in 2013.

He echoed the motto that his predecessor, Hsieh Chin-ting, passed on to him when he was sworn in three years ago that as a magistrate, he will "leave morality to the offspring, development to the county and only my name to myself."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
SEF pushes for increased number of cross-strait charter flights

TEXT.P: Taiwan's intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) has been working to secure an agreement on increasing the number of direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights to 168 per week during the upcoming Lunar New Year holidays from the current 108, according an SEF official.

SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian was quoted by the Hong Kong-based daily Wen Wei Po as saying Saturday that the SEF is currently negotiating with the relevant Chinese authorities to increase the number of charters over the Chinese New Year to accommodate the many Taiwanese businesspeople and their dependents who usually return to Taiwan at that time.

Kao was quoted as telling the 20-odd heads of Taiwanese business associations around China during a meeting in the southern Chinese city of Xiamen that "there might be good news in this regard before the 2009 Chinese New Year's Day," which falls on Jan. 26.

Kao, who doubles as secretary-general of the quasi-official SEF, made the remarks after a Wuhan-based Taiwanese businessman Yu Ming-chin stated at the meeting that the current 108 cross-strait flights per week can only accommodate around 1.5 million Taiwanese travelers a year.

"That is inadequate by far to meet actual demand, as Taiwanese make roughly 6 million visits to and from China each year, " said Yu, who is a vice chairman of the Association of Taiwanese Invested Enterprises on the Mainland.
"About 70 percent of the Taiwanese who frequently visit China will not be able to enjoy the convenience of traveling via the existing cross-strait charter flights," Yu claimed.

Meanwhile, according to the Wen Wei Po report, Kao said that following his own visits to China to listen to the needs and problems of Taiwanese businesspeople there, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung will also meet with Taiwanese business leaders in Guangdong Province and Jiangsu Province from Jan. 7-11.

Issues expected to be discussed during the meetings between Chiang and the Taiwanese business leaders include fund constraints, ways of extending loans to Taiwanese businesses, and the problems they have been facing as result of higher taxes and overhead costs since China's implementation of new labor contract and land use laws.

According to Kao, Chiang and the SEF officials will also discuss the reduction of customs tariffs with their Chinese counterparts, a move that may eventually lead to developing the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as free trade zones, the Wen Wei Po reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kenyans win ING Taipei international marathon titles

TEXT.P: Kenyan runners won both the men's and women's titles in the 2008 ING Taipei International Marathon Sunday.
Sammy Chumba won the men's title in a time of in 2 hours, 15 minutes, 37 seconds, while Caroline Kilel took the women's title, clocking 2:30:44.

Kilel took home NT$1.33 million in prize money, as she not only won the 42-km race, but also broke the 151-minute record set by her countrywoman Jane Auro in 2006. Chumba collected the first prize of NT$100,000 (US$3,072) for his win.
The organizers have made NT$1.33 million available in cash awards for record- breaking winners in the competition.
Kilel said she will use her prize money to buy a piece of land in her home country. As a professional athlete, Kilel said, she depends entirely on her sport for a living.
Chumba said he will use his prize money to make improvements to his home and to help his family to lead a better life.

Local marathoner Wu Wen-chien won the Taiwanese men's title in a time of 2: 17: 24, while Hsu Yu-fang won the Taiwanese women's title in 2: 47: 00. Wu finished fourth in the men's marathon and Hsu finished 19th in women's.

The 2008 ING Taipei International Marathon kicked off at 7 a.m. at the plaza in front of Taipei City Hall Sunday, with 121,000 runners from 40 countries taking part in five categories of road racing, according to ING Antai Insurance Co., a key sponsor of the event.
A record 27,000-plus runners competed this year, representing a year-on-year increase of 30 percent, the ING said.

DOC.HEADLINE: People with problems urged to call social welfare hotline for help

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) on Sunday encouraged people facing sudden financial difficulties and other problems due to the current economic recession to phone the "1957 national welfare hotline" for help.

The central government, in collaboration with local governments, set up the hotline in November 2006 to provide timely help to people with dire problems. The service offers on-site visits, emergency relief, employment assistance and legal counseling.

So far this year, an average of 1,000-1,990 calls per month were made to the hotline, with most callers seeking emergency relief, unemployment support, and medical treatment aid, according to the ministry.
Many people have successfully overcome their difficulties with the help of the service provided via the hotline, the MOI said.

The ministry cited the example of a man surnamed Hsiung in Taoyuan County, who was granted urgent financial subsidies at first and later landed a job with the help of the local government's employment center after he made a call earlier in the year to the hotline seeking assistance.

At the time, Hsiung had suffered a number of blows in quick succession and was reeling from the death of his wife, the loss of his job and his financial inability to look after his young child, according to the MOI.
Usually, there is a spike in the number of calls just before the Chinese New Year, the MOI said, noting that 1,991 calls were recorded in January, the highest number for the year so far.

The ministry anticipates that more and more people will be seeking urgent help, in light of the increasing number of businesses that are failing and the rising unemployment in the country due to the economic slowdown.
Therefore, it said, it is urging people with problems to call the hotline to obtain help.

DOC.HEADLINE: Application process opens for housing subsidies

TEXT.P: The second round of applications for a government-sponsored housing subsidy that will help cover rental and interest payments has now been opened, the Construction and Planning Agency announced Sunday, urging eligible families to apply at their local household registry office.
Under the program, the government will offer a subsidy of up to NT$3,000 per month for one year to eligible families to help them cover their rent, the agency under the Ministry of the Interior said.

The government will also subsidize the interest payments by new home buyers on loans of up to NT$2.2 million with a 20-year repayment period. Borrowers of house repair loans of up to NT$800,000 with an 15-year repayment period are also elegible to apply for subsidies to help pay the interest, according to the agency.
Applications for the rental subsidy will expire Dec. 31 this year, while applications for government-subsidized home loans will expire Feb. 25, 2009, the agency said.
The agency first announced the program earlier in the year, calling for applications, which closed on Aug. 15.
In the second application phase, there are 8,000 openings for rental subsidies, 25,445 for home loan subsidies, and 3,720 for home improvement loan subsidies, according to the agency.

Under the program, the preferential interest rate on loans to eligible households is 1.617 percent, and on those to disadvantaged families 1.042 percent. The country's central bank lowered its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point earlier in the month, the agency noted.

This home purchase loan scheme will be administered in conjunction with another preferential home loan program launched on Sept. 22, under which the government will allocate an additional NT$200 billion until Sept. 21, 2010 to grant each qualified household in Taipei City a maximum loan of NT$3.5 million at a preferential interest rate, the agency added.
For eligible households outside Taipei City, the maximum figure for such loans is NT$3 million.

Families with an annual combined income of less than NT$970,000 and who do not own a home can apply for a home purchase loan or a housing rental subsidy, while those who own a house that is more than 10 years old can apply for a house improvement loan, according to the agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: China willing to extend economic support to Taiwanese firms: official
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/08 19:06:08 (By Chang Ming-kun, Kuo Mei-lan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: China's top official in charge of Taiwan affairs announced 10 measures Sunday to boost business and trade exchanges with Taiwan and increase financial assistance to Taiwanese businesspeople operating on the mainland.

Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, said Chinese banking institutions, including China Development Bank, Bank of China and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, will be authorized to increase their loans and credit services, to a maximum of 130 billion Chinese yuan (US$18.99 billion), to China-based Taiwanese enterprises over the next three years to help them tide over the difficulties they face in the global economic downturn.

Wang made the announcement at the fourth joint Cross-Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum held by Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China (CPC). The forum opened in Shanghai Saturday and closed Sunday.
According to Wang, the Chinese authorities will help China-based Taiwanese enterprises to upgrade or restructure so as to sharpen their competitiveness.

China will push for increased bilateral investment across the Taiwan Strait and will help boost cooperation among industrial manufacturing sectors on both sides to make them more competitive in the international market, Wang said.
Mainland Chinese TFT-LED TV manufacturers will increase purchases of display panels from Taiwanese makers, with the shopping list to total US$2 billion in the initial stage, Wang said.

China will also expand agricultural cooperation with Taiwan, Wang said, adding that three Chinese provinces -- Jiangsu, Guangdong and Yunnan -- will make tracts of land available exclusively for Taiwanese farmers to develop farms in China.

China and Taiwan should expedite negotiations on affairs pertaining to customs clearance and quarantine procedures so as to speed up Taiwan's sale of seafood and other fresh grocery products to Chinese markets, Wang suggested.
China will also allow Taiwanese lawyers to practice in China once they comply with certain conditions set by the Chinese government, he added.

KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung and KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan led a party delegation at the forum. Five Taiwan government officials, including San Gee, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, also attended the party-to-party forum in a private capacity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Smoking lawmakers to adjust to smoke-free work environment

TEXT.P: Inveterate smokers in the legislature are preparing to adjust to a smoke-free work environment from Jan. 11, when Taiwan's newly amended Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act becomes effective.

Asked on Friday to comment on the change dictated by law, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said the legislature will do everything in accordance with the law, and that from Jan. 11, none of the legislators, their constituents or staff will be allowed to smoke on the premises of the legislature.
Under the amended Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act, smoking is banned in all indoor workplaces staffed by three or more employees.
The law also prohibits smoking in other public indoor areas, such as KTV lounges, bowling alleys, cybercafes, and passenger waiting rooms.
Smoking is also banned, under the law, in outdoor public areas, including train station platforms, gymnasiums, swimming pools, college campuses, and entertainment areas.
Violators will risk fines of between NT$2,000 and NT$10,000 (US$605).

Legislative Yuan Secretary-General Lin Hsi-shan pointed out that under the new law the legislature is not permitted to designate a smoking area within the building and that legislators who wish to smoke will have to do so outside the building.

Lee Hung-chun, a legislator of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) who has been a smoker since he was a student more than 30 years ago, said it may be time now for him to quit the habit because of the inconvenience of finding a place to smoke.
KMT Legislator Tsai Chin-lung, who has already kicked his 30-year habit, encouraged his colleagues to follow his example and quit smoking.
"If they really cannot kick the habit, they must be more observant of the new law than the ordinary public," he said.
KMT Legislator Shuai Hua-ming said he will respect other people's right to refuse to inhale second-hand smoke, and that when he feels like smoking, he will go outside the building.

Legislator Ker Chien-ming, the chain-smoking legislative caucus convener of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said he still has reservations about whether it might be difficult to comply with the law, but added that he will do his best.
DPP Legislator Pan Meng-an said jokingly that he will probably go into depression because of the new law, but he added, "I am afraid that I may have to quit smoking."
DPP Legislator Tien Chiu-chin, who has campaigned hard against smoking, said that smoking has become such a serious public hazard that it is necessary to maintain a smoke-free work environment.

She quoted an estimate by the Cabinet-level Department of Health which shows that smoking-induced diseases have cost the Bureau of National Insurance an extra NT$30 billion (US$922.58 million) a year in terms of medical expenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait trade cooperation not yet on agenda: SEF chair

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Sunday that economic and trade cooperation agreements will not be part of his third meeting with President of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) Chen Yunlin.

"However, although economic and trade cooperation will not be discussed in our next meeting, we do hope that our governments will raise this issue at an appropriate time," Chiang said at a conference held to discuss Taiwan's future.

His remarks came one day after the honorary chairman of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Lien Chan said at a joint forum of the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Shanghai that establishing amechanism for economic and trade cooperation would be of strategic value to both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lien said the two sides should forge a viable mechanism for normalizing their trade and economic relations, since China has become Taiwan's most important trade partner and largest export market.

"Lien made those comments because President Ma Ying-jeou promised in his election campaign to raise the issue of economic and trade cooperation between Taiwan and China, " Chiang said. "This is very important to the future development of cross-strait ties."

Chiang said that Taiwan could find itself at a disadvantage in the region as it is not a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and in light of an agreement among ASEAN and the plus three nations -- China, Japan and South Korea -- to end trade tariffs.
Therefore, economic and trade cooperation with mainland China will be crucial to Taiwan's future economic development, Chiang said.
The SEF chairman said his third meeting with Chen next year will focus on mutual investment, food safety, tax issues, intellectual property rights and crime fighting.
"However, we will discuss economic and trade cooperation with mainland China in the near future," he added.

In their second meeting Nov. 3-7 in Taiwan, Chen and Chiang sealed four agreements on expanded direct cross-strait air services, direct shipping and postal links, and a communication channel on food safety issues. Their historic first meeting was held six months earlier in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ruling, opposition parties to pay smaller staff bonuses

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party have each decided to cut their year-end bonuses to their staff, as both parties are feeling the squeeze of the global economic downturn.

However, the administrations of the two parties gave the assurance that despite the challenging financial environment, their workers will receive bonuses, albeit smaller ones, because they have worked hard during the year.
"No matter how tough the economic situation, we will take care of our staff," said Lin Yung-rey, a KMT administrative official. "We will tighten our belts and withstand these tough economic times."
Lin said that the KMT will pay an average of half a month's salary to all staff members, which will amount to least NT$10,000 (US$303) each.
"No matter what, the KMT will not lay off staff or cut salaries," he added.

Noting that in the past, when the economy was good, the KMT paid year-end bonuses of around one to one and a half months' salary, he said that with a current staff of 900, it will cost the party a lot to pay even the reduced bonuses this year.
Meanwhile, the DPP has decided to give an across-the-board bonus of NT$10,000 to its staff, according to the party's chief communications officer Cheng Wen- tsang.
The DPP, in the past, gave its staff one month to one and a half months' salary in bonuses when the economy was stronger," Cheng recalled.
However this year, because of the economic situation, the 102 staff members of the party will each receive a fixed amount of NT$10,000, he added.
Cheng commended the staff of the opposition party for their

work in the past year, adding that the DPP will host a traditional Lunar year- end party for its workers and that DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen will pay for it from her own pocket. The KMT will hold its end-of-year party for its staff on Jan. 21, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foundation seeking innovative ideas on caring for the elderly

TEXT.P: People with sound ideas on providing care for the elderly have a chance to win NT$30,000 (NT$992) in a competition sponsored by the Hondao Foundation in Taichung City to solicit such ideas.

The foundation, which is dedicated to the welfare of the country's senior citizens, said in a press release that it is seeking to develop an innovative action program to care for the society's "grandpas and grandmas".

Proposals should be presented before the dealine of Dec. 25 in no more than 100 Chinese characters, and will be judged at three different levels -- kindergarten and elementary school students, middle school to university students, and other adults.
The foundation has suggested that the proposals detail any of six broad areas of elderly care -- diet, clothing, accommodation, transportation, education and recreation.

In order to instill in the public a sense of appreciation for the elderly, the foundation has designated the second Sunday of January each year as "Grandpa and Grandma Day, " and will mark it with activities to show care and respect for senior citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police seize NT$170 million worth of marijuana in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Law-enforcement agents in southern Taiwan have seized 40 kilograms of marijuana that was smuggled into the country from Latin America via China, the southern Taiwan mobile unit of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice disclosed Sunday.

A spokesman for the unit said that its investigators and police officers from Tainan County, headed by prosecutors from Kaohsiung, raided the residence of Chen Chin-chang, 52, in Baihe township, Tainan County, and seized 40 marijuana bricks, each weighing one kilogram.
The confiscated marijuana has a street value of NT$170 million (US$5.23 million) and would have been enough to supply 400,000 addicts, according to an estimate by the investigators.

The spokesman said that Chen worked with Dai Shun-yi, 52, a member of Yungan Township Council in Kaohsiung County, by hiring a fishing boat to transport the marijuana that was concealed in vacuum sealed tea packages.
He added that Chen, a Taiwanese businessman in China, was in desperate need of money because he was deeply in debt as a result of his gambling habit.
Chen and Dai will face charges of violating the Narcotics Endangerment Prevention Act and the Act for the Control and Punishment of Smuggling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien County tourism festival aimed at attracting foreign visitors

TEXT.P: Hualien County is slated to hold its first Pacific International Tourism Festival Dec. 26 to Jan. 2009 at its Meiluen Brewery, in the hope of attracting more visitors from around the world, an event organizer said Monday.

In the face of the global economic recession, Taiwan has been working hard to attract foreign tourists by highlighting its special features and cultural characteristics, according to Kuomintang Legislator Fu Kun-chi of Hualien.

With this in mind, Hualien County plans to launch the festival with a focus on luring foreign tourists to view the first sunrise of 2009 from the coastal county overlooking the Pacific Ocean, Fu said.

The festival will target tourists from China, Europe and North America who plan to ring in the Chinese New Year in Asia, urging them to make Hualien their destination instead of Thailand or the Philippines, Fu said.
By staging the festival, the county hopes to sell itself as aworld-famous landmark on the Western Pacific Coast, Fu added.

Activities during the 10-day festival will include a large scale pop concert that will feature nearly 100 local performers, international concerts, light aircraft shows, and several exhibitions of defense weapon systems, motorcycles, art works and aboriginal handicraft.
The event organizers will also hold a lucky draw, with 200 tickets for Taipei- Hong Kong air travel at stake, Fu said.
He added that members of the Travel Agent Association of R.O.C have also promised to include the festival on their itineraries for foreign visitors to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of cross-strait flights may be increased during Lunar New Year
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/08 22:35:13 (By Chang Ming-kun and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of charter flights between Taiwan and China is likely to be increased from the current 108 per week to 168 during the Lunar New Year holiday, which begins Jan. 25, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Deputy Chairman Kao Koong-lian said in Shanghai Sunday.
Kao, who also serves as the SEF's secretary-general, is in Shanghai to attend the fourth Cross-Straits Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum as part of the Taiwan delegation.

He told Taiwanese businessmen in Shanghai that the SEF, aware that tickets for cross-strait flights during the Lunar New Year holiday have been sold out, is trying to negotiate with its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- to increase the number of flights to 168 per week.

Lee Lung-wen, director-general of Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), appeared optimistic about the proposal, saying that the agreement on direct flights across the Taiwan Strait, signed in Taipei in early November, allows for flexibility in terms of the number of flights.
Lee said there is still enough time to thrash out the issue so that the airline companies can adjust their flight schedules in time.
However, ARATS Deputy Secretary-general Li Ya-fei declined to comment on the issue, saying only that he needs to look into the matter.

The weighted price index finished almost unchanged at 4,694.52 Friday.
