DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 22, or the 25th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1666: Shah Jahan, the mighty Mogul emperor of India who built the Taj Mahal as a mausoleum for his beloved wife Mumtaz-i-Mahal, dies at the age of 74.
1771: Spain agrees to cede the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic to Britain.
1775: Andre Ampere, the French physicist and discoverer of electromagnets who gave his name to the "amp" as a unit of electricity, is born.
1901: After a 64-year reign, Queen Victoria, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, dies at Osborne House on the Isle of Wight at the age of 81.
1905: Tsarist troops fire salvo after close-range salvo into a crowd in St. Petersburg, Russia, leaving the snow red with the blood of at least 500 strikers.
1922: Pope Benedict XV, originally Giacomo della Chiesa, who sponsored World War I relief efforts and sought to mediate peace, dies in Rome. He was succeeded by Pope Pius XI.
1924: Ramsay MacDonald becomes Britain's first Labor prime minister, replacing Stanley Baldwin.
1935: After long negotiations, Japan pays 140 million yen for Soviet interests in the Chinese Eastern Railway, the last legal trace of Russian influence in Manchuria.
1944: Allied landings begin at Arizo, Italy, involving an estimated 50,000 U.S. and British troops.
1945: More than 500 U.S. warplanes launch air-raids on Okinawa and Taiwan.
1945: The land route to China -- the Ledo Road across Burma from India to China -- reopens.
1946: U.S. President Harry Truman orders the establishment of the Central Intelligence Agency.
1949: The guerrilla army of China's Mao Tse-tung marches toward Beijing after crossing the Yangtze River to defeat the Nationalist army at Huai Hai north of Beijing.
1955: Adm. Felix B. Stump, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, says that the United States will help defend Taiwan if attacked following the signing of the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty in Washington on Dec. 3, 1954.
1965: Peng Ming-min, a professor at National Taiwan University, and two students, are charged with subversion against the government by military prosecutors.
1973: Prince Tuipelehake, C.B.E., prime minister of the Kingdom of Tonga, arrives in Taipei for a one-week visit.
1973: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th U.S. president, who succeeded John F. Kennedy, dies of a heart attack in Texas at the age of 64.
1975: Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the Sankei Shimbun newspaper and the Fuji Television Corporation of Japan, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1979: Demonstrations are held at Kaohsiung railway station and Chiaotou township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County against the arrest of Yu Teng-fa for sedition.
1980: Dr. Andrei Dimitrievich Sakharov, the Soviet physicist who helped develop the first Soviet hydrogen bomb, is arrested, stripped of his honor and banished to Gorky from Moscow. An outspoken advocate of human rights and nuclear disarmament, he won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the offshore island county of Penghu, killing 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in 20 years, and the Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help the victims.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives the chiefs of administrative branches under the Executive Yuan, and urges them and other government officials to persevere in discharging their duties and to endeavor to promote political reform.
1990: The Yugoslav Communist Party renounces its monopoly on power after 45 years of rule.
1996: The Pentagon announces for the first time the size of the U.S. chemical weapons arsenal, and says all 3.6 million weapons will be destroyed by 2004.
2000: Taiwan's Wei Yun-chieh shoots a five-under-par 67 to win the Chunghua Cup Women's Golf Tournament, the first leg of the 2000 Women's Asian Circuit, with a three-day total of 213.
2001: ROC Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzeng-ping conveys his congratulations to Ang Lee, a Taiwan-born director whose "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" won the 58th Golden Globe best director and best foreign film awards.
2002: U.S. Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Market Access and Compliance William H. Lash, III arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
2002: Republic of Chad Ambassador to the Republic of China Hissein Brahim Taha presents his credentials to President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Those who know it are not as those who love it; those who love it are not as those who find their joy in it."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Experts discuss possibility of building cross-strait expressway

TEXT.P: After the long-expected direct air, shipping and postal links between Taiwan and China were put in place last week, academics and experts from both sides gathered Monday to discuss the possibility of building a physical structure to link Taipei to Beijing.
The formal opening of a two-day academic conference to discuss the feasibility of constructing a cross-Taiwan Strait expressway was attended by representatives from both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation Chiang Pin-kung said at the opening that the exchange of ideas and expertise on the design for such a route has the same "historical significance" as the improvement of cross-strait relations which was facilitated by his meeting in November with his counterpart Chen Yunlin of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

"The construction of a Taiwan Strait expressway will further narrow the cultural and economic gap between the two sides", said Chiang, adding that "it is the common desire of the people of both Taiwan and China to see the realization of such a historic project."

The idea of a physical route to link Taipei and Beijing has been in the works in China for years. The project was included in an expressway network plan announced by China in 2005 to build 85,000 kilometers of expressways over a 30-year period at an estimated cost of 2 trillion yuan (about US$240 billion), including one from Beijing to Taipei.
Chiang said that a Beijing-Taipei expressway would further facilitate the transportation of Taiwanese products to China, Russia and Eastern Europe.

The Taiwan Strait Crossing Route Academic Conference has been held twice a year for the past 12 years in China, with the participation of experts from Taiwan and China, but this is the first time that it is being held in Taiwan.
The conference will discuss basic aspects of the proposed Taiwan Strait expressway, including design philosophy, concept, and basic requirements.

Such a route would involve the construction of infrastructure such as undersea tunnels and bridges. It would also require studies on weather, seawater depth, marine sediments and seafloor characteristics -- topics that will be discussed at the conference in order to contribute to the preliminary planning and design stages of the proposed project.

According to Hsai Yang-fang, a professor at the University of North Carolina, Charlotte, the term "Taiwan Strait Tunnel" was first coined in the summer of 1948 in Taipei by thousands of anti-civil war students who were marching to demand the coexistence of all Chinese people.

Since the Kuomintang (KMT) returned to power in May, President Ma Ying-jeou's administration has been working to melt the ice between the two sides of the strait and forge links with China, particularly on the economic front.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations responsible for handling cross-strait engagements in the absence of official relations between the two sides of the strait.

In their second round of their talks held in Taipei Nov. 3-7, Chiang and Chen signed four agreements to allow direct flights, shipping links, postal services and the establishment of a food safety mechanism between the two sides.
Chen was the highest-ranking Chinese official to have set foot on Taiwan since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: Peace accord, greater international space remain top goals: KMT
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/08 14:11:23 (By Chang Ming-kun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Wu Poh-hsiung, chairman of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , said Sunday that securing a peace accord with China and seeking greater international space for Taiwan remain the party's top goals and this will not change under any circumstances.

The two goals were included in a five-point statement issued jointly in 2005 by Chinese President Hu Jintao and then KMT Chairman Lien Chan after their historic meeting in Beijing on April 29 that year, Wu said at a news conference prior to his departure for Taiwan.

Wu and a KMT delegation have been in Shanghai to attend the fourth joint Cross- Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum held by the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Shanghai Saturday and Sunday.

In response to reporters' questions on whether he had exchanged views with the CPC officials at forum about the prospects of Taiwan's attendance at the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer in May 2009, Wu said the forum was focused on economic and business matters, therefore the WHA and other political issues were not raised.

However, he said, Taiwan's goals of seeking greater maneuvering space in the international community and securing a peace accord with Beijing remain the two top priorities of the KMT as the ruling party.
"The peace accord, nevertheless, is a more challenging goal for the time being," Wu admitted.
With both sides facing challenges amid a global economic downturn the forum decided to temporarily shelve controversial issues and seek consensus on negotiable matters, he said.
"It takes time and patience for both sides to address their political differences," he added.

Meanwhile, Wu said, he will report to President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan Monday evening on the conclusions of the forum and the suggestions that were made by the KMT and CPC on the development of cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group encourages unemployed women to work as babysitters

TEXT.P: The Peng Wan-ru Foundation, an organization that helps local women to enter the labor force, encouraged unemployed women of middle age and older to seek positions as babysitters for newborns and as caregivers for new mothers.
Liu Yu-hsiu, director of the foundation, said Sunday at a party for 300 babysitters and family caregivers that the demand for home caregivers remains high despite the current economic recession.
The foundation has been providing training courses on babysitting and postpartum health care for five years, but not many women have joined the program, Liu said.

She added that some mothers would offer around NT$42,000 per month to hire a babysitter that can look after their newborns and help the women themselves during the post-delivery recuperation period. This would cost such families much less than if they have to pay NT$150,000 per month for similar services provided by some nursing centers, Liu said.

Noting that babysitting and home care services are less affected by the economic slowdown, Liu called on women who want to work in this area to join the foundation's professional training program to gain the skills required by their potential employers.

At a time when all sectors have being hit by the overall economic slump, an increasing number of people have been contacting the foundation to explore job opportunities, according to Wang Hui-chu, chief executive of the foundation.

Therefore, the foundation decided to enroll more babysitting trainees in their 40s and 50s so that middle-aged women can re-enter the workplace and earn a stable living by caring for babies and new mothers, according to Wang.
Describing the job as a physically demanding, Wang said that caregivers need to help postpartum women bind or bandage their bellies after birth, give them massages, and help to bathe them.
Moreover, the job requires tender and compassionate care and good communication skills, Wang added.
Trainees can acquire all the necessary knowledge, skills and techniques in the six-week training programs offered by the foundation, according to Wang.
At the party, a babysitter known as Li-hsue, said that she began working in that field four years ago after she was forced out of her job of more than 10 years as an accountant.
According to Li-hsiu, she has worked for about 40 families in the last four years and has gained a sense of accomplishment from providing professional services to those families.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature not yet decided on tobacco tax increase rate

TEXT.P: A Legislative Yuan committee on Monday initially approved a draft amendment to the Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act, but set aside a controversial article on the increase of the health tax on tobacco products for further discussion by political party caucuses.
The legislature's Health, Environment and Labor Committee approved amendments to raise the "health and welfare surcharge" on tobacco products and remove the ceiling on such increases.

The draft amendment also aims to use the revenues from the health tax to subsidize medical treatment for the disadvantaged, including the indigent, those with rare diseases, and those living in areas where medical resources are inadequate.
Although the legislators in the committee all agreed that the surcharge should be increased, they failed to reach consensus on the percentage by which it should raised.

The Cabinet-level Department of Health's (DOH) proposal was to raise the surcharge from the current NT$10 (US$0.31) to NT$20, a hike that most of the legislators supported. But Chang Sho-wen, a 37-year-old Kuomintang legislator who has been smoking for 20 years, insisted that the tax should be increased to NT$40.
The purpose of raising the surcharge is to reduce the number of smokers in the country," he said, adding that, in view of that goal, an increase of NT$10 seems to be insignificant.
He further suggested that the revenue from the tax should be used in the prevention of cancer and other diseases related to smoking.
However, DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan contended it would be "difficult" to raise the surcharge on tobacco to NT$40. There is "a gap between the ideal and reality," he said.
Taiwan spends about NT$45 billion annually on health insurance to cover medical treatment of diseases related to smoking, according to the DOH.

In its review of the bill, the committee suggested that the DOH and the Ministry of Finance implement on a one-year trial basis a tobacco certification system in order to reduce the smuggling of cigarettes.

The Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act, which will go into effect on Jan. 11 next year, bans smoking in schools, medical and financial institutions, government units, restaurants, transport stations and shopping centers.

According to the World Health Organization, non-smoking environments and high tobacco prices are the two most effective means of reducing tobacco use among young people. A 1999 World Bank report stated that when the price of tobacco is raised by 10 percent, consumption decreases by 4 percent to 8 percent, and even by as much as 10 percent among youngsters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pandas to arrive at Taipei Zoo Dec. 23: Taipei City

TEXT.P: A pair of giant pandas China promised to give Taiwan in 2005 will finally arrive at Taipei Zoo Dec. 23, a Taipei city government official confirmed Monday.

Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, whose names together mean "reunion, " should arrive at the zoo before 7 p.m, according to zoo officials, who added that the zoo has prepared an outdoor enclosure decorated with ferns and a footbridge, a sleeping area with all-season air conditioning and imported bamboo to welcome the two pandas.
Estimating that the pandas will consume up to 80 kilograms of bamboo shoots every day, the zoo will allocate NT$1.02 million (US$31,000) for bamboo expenses per year.

Upon their arrival, the pandas will be kept in quarantine for at least one month before they are introduced to the public, with zoo officials hopeful that the animals can make their debut around the Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan. 26 next year.

EVA Airways, which has been commissioned to fly the pandas from the southwestern Chinese province of Sichuan to Taiwan, has already sent an advance team to Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province, to go over technical details regarding the charter flight from Shuangliu Airport to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
"Every arrangement will be made in the best interests of the pandas," said EVA Air spokesman Nieh Kuo-wei.
Chinese President Hu Jintao first offered the pandas to Taiwan as a gift of friendship in May 2005 when then-opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan made an ice-breaking visit to Beijing.

However, the delivery was blocked by political bickering between Beijing and Taipei during Taiwan's time under the rule of the now-opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which objected to China's treatment of the panda transfer as a "domestic transfer" between zoos because it implies that Taiwan is part of China.

As giant pandas are an endangered species subject to the protection of the Convention of International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), cross-border transfers of the animal must follow strict CITES guidelines.

According to the guidelines, the two parties must supply export and import permits confirming that all conditions for the transfer have been met. This implies that the transaction is between two countries.

However, the issue was resolved under the governance of the China-leaning administration of President Ma Ying-jeou when both sides decided to sidestep the country name issue by agreeing to identify the importer as "Taiwan Taipei" and accepting "Chengdu" as the origin of export.
The two sides signed a formal agreement Nov. 6 on exchanges of indigenous rare fauna and flora species to symbolize their amity and determination to cooperate in wildlife conservation.

According to the Taipei city government, the pandas are expected to attract 6 million domestic and overseas visitors to the zoo each year. More than 5 million people visit the zoo each year to see its koalas, another of the zoo's flagship denizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-CPC forum consensus provides only 'directions': SEF head

TEXT.P: The conclusions that were reached and the suggestions made in a just-concluded forum between the ruling Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China (CPC) will provide only "directions" for policy makers, the head of the intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Monday.

"Solid negotiations on concrete matters and issues across the Taiwan Strait will still have to rely on the quasi-official SEF and its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS)," said SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.

The fourth joint Cross-Strait Economic, Trade and Cultural Forum held by the KMT and CPC in Shanghai over the weekend made nine suggestions, including that the number of charter flights between Taiwan and China be increased from the current 108 per week to 168 during the Lunar New Year holiday, which begins Jan. 25 this year.

During the forum, Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, also said that Chinese banking institutions, including the China Development Bank, the Bank of China and the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, will be authorized to increase the size of the loans and credit services they are allowed to offer to China-based Taiwanese enterprises to help tide them over the difficulties they face amidst the global economic downturn.
These loans could top 130 billion Chinese yuan (US$18.99 billion) over a span of three years, Wang said.

In response to the remarks by China's top official in charge of Taiwan affairs, Chiang said he will pay closer attention to the loan promise and will make follow-up suggestions after he visits China next month to meet Taiwanese businessmen operating there.

He added that after two rounds of SEF-ARATS meetings -- in June and November this year, respectively -- the third one will be mainly devoted to technical matters to help facilitate implementation of the policies and measures that were recommended in the previous two meetings.

For example, he said, the issue of signing a financial memorandum of understanding (MOU) with China covering the banking, securities and insurance sectors is expected to be discussed in the third round of talks, the date of which has yet to be determined.
Meanwhile, SEF Deputy Chairman Kao Koong-lian said that day that it would be unrealistic to attach too many expectations to the conclusions reached at the forum.

Upon the conclusion of the forum, China's top official in charge of Taiwan affairs Wang Yi announced 10 measures to boost business and trade exchanges with Taiwan and increase financial assistance to Taiwanese businessmen operating in China.

In addition to the loan promise, the measures include a promise that Chinese TFT-LED TV manufacturers will increase purchases of display panels from Taiwanese makers, with the shopping list to total US$2 billion in the initial stage.
Commenting on Wang's promises, Kao said they reflect that China is extending increased goodwill to Taiwan.
Nevertheless, he went on, the crucial element is whether and when those promises will be delivered and carried out.

Kao noted that the Chinese authorities promised some time ago that they would make some 50 billion yuan available out of two Chinese state funds to be loaned to Taiwanese businessmen to help facilitate their China operations.
However, he went on, none of these businessmen were able to secure the loans because the threshold set by the Chinese was too high.
Kao said the Chinese authorities must first lower the threshold for such "incentives" if they want to provide help to allow Taiwanese businessmen in China to ride out the global financial meltdown.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local Airline to fly Taipei-Siem Reap route

TEXT.P: Taiwan's TransAsia Airways is slated to launch its first direct charter flight Friday between Taipei and the Cambodian city of Siem Reap, the gateway to the world renowned temple complex of Angkor Wat.

Joe Chu, the airline's sales manager, said that the new service will fill a gap in market demand left by the previous airline that flew the route. It will also save travel time to the famous Cambodian tourist attraction, which is listed as a world heritage site by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

Far Eastern Air Transport, which in cooperation with the Cambodia-based Angkor Airways used to provide regularly scheduled flights on the route, canceled the service in May due to financial difficulties.

Chu said that TransAsia Airways, which will be the only airline serving the route, will fly 15 charters a month, serving only tour groups and travelers that join foreign independent travel (FTI) packages offered by the travel agencies.
The initial response to the charter scheme, which will continue for at least for one year, has been good, with the first two scheduled charters already fully booked, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares plunge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Monday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 158.98 points, or 3.38 percent, to close at 4,535.54.
The local bourse opened at 4,735.17 and fluctuated between 4,750.96 and 4,535.54.
A total of 4.33 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$67.15 billion (US$2.04 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks falling the most at 5.9 percent, textile shares shedding 5.4 percent, cement issues dropping 4.6 percent, paper and pulp issues moving down 4.2 percent, banking and financial shares falling 3.9 percent, plastics and chemicals issues losing 3.7 percent, machinery and electronics stocks shedding 2.9 percent, and foodstuff stocks falling 2.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,393 to 198, with 160 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$2.01 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA charter arrive in Chengdu in preparation for panda delivery

TEXT.P: A special EVA Airways flight arrived at the Chengdu Shuangliu International Airport in Sichuan Province, southwestern China Monday in preparation for delivering a pair of celebrity giant pandas to Taiwan the following day.
The pandas, named Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, are a gift from the Chinese government to Taiwan as a symbol of good will and friendship.
The EVA Airways charter plane took off Monday morning from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport for Sichuan on a special flight to pick up the animals.

On board was a group of 76 people who were slated to welcome the rare animals. The group included animal keepers from the Taipei City Zoo, where the pandas will be housed, and Taipei City officials headed by Yang Hsiao-tung, director of the city's Department of Information and Tourism.

Before boarding, Yang said that an advance mission from Taiwan had completed all arrangements in Sichuan last week for the shipment of the animals. He further said that after being apprised of the weather and the pandas' condition, he expects that they will be brought to Taipei without a hitch.
Taipei City Zoo Director Jason Yeh, also a member of the welcoming delegation, said Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin asked him to take good care of the pandas and bring them to Taipei safely.
To this end, the zoo assigned an executive official responsible for animal affairs and three experts in animal preservation to the welcoming team, he said.

The newly expanded direct air links between Taiwan and China, which have considerably cut the travel time between the two sides, will also help to make the shipment smoother, Yeh said. Immediately afer the animals arrive at the Taoyuan airport in Taiwan, they will be transported to the city zoo in an air conditioned vehicle, he added.

The EVA Airways "panda flight" is scheduled to take off from the Chengdu airport at 2 p.m. Tuesday and arrive in Taiwan at around 5 p.m. the same day. A group from China, comprised of panda keepers and other personnel, will be traveling with the animals, while the flight will also transport 17 dove tree seedlings -- also a gift from China -- and 480 kg of China-grown bamboo and other food for Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan.
The crew on the special flight is comprised of experienced pilots and flight attendants, headed by EVA Vice Chairman Hsieh Chih-chien.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st batch of honey dates from Pingtung County exported to Canada

TEXT.P: A 2.5-ton batch of fresh Chinese dates produced in Pingtung County has been shipped to Canada recently, the first fruit of this kind from Taiwan's southernmost county to be exported abroad this year, the Pingtung Department of Agriculture said Monday.

New orders for the juicy sweet Chinese dates, also known as jujube, or honey dates, have also been received from China and shipments bound for there are expected to be dispatched shortly, department officials said.
Pingtung-produced jujube have been exported to China, Canada, Singapore and Australia for the last three years during the fruit's high season between late December and February.

Meanwhile, Cheng Shuang-chuan, chief of Pingtung's Yenpu township, is scheduled to lead some 80 jujube farmers to Taipei City Dec. 26-27 to boost sales of the fruit in the nation's capital, a first for the Yenpu farmers.
Fresh jujubes are poised to become the second flagship fruit from Pingtung County behind bell fruit, which have been good earners for Pingtung's farmers over the past decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market fell sharply Monday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for January dropping 151 points to close at 4,529, with 100,125 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for February lost 153 points to finish at 4,502, with 331 contracts traded, while March futures declined 150 points to end at 4,493, with 38 contracts traded.
June futures fell 176 points to close at 4,450, with 39 contract transactions, while September futures lost 149 points to finish at 4,260, with 17 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 4,680 for January, 4,655 for February, 4,643 for March, 4,626 for June and 4,409 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 158.98 points to finish at 4,535.54, on turnover of NT$67.15 billion (US$2.04 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

January TE futures fell 5.1 points to close at 173.2, with 5,287 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 5.05 points to finish at 171.8, with 44 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

January TF futures were down 22.8 points to close at 568, with 3,571 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures decreased 23.8 points to finish at 567, with 22 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.4 to close at NT$32.930.
A total of US$901 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.580 and fluctuated between NT$32.526 and NT$33.100.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly one fourth of Taiwan's workers hold part-time jobs: poll

TEXT.P: Around 22 percent of Taiwan's office workers have part time jobs, with 56 percent of them being driven to do such jobs because of the economic downturn, according to results of a poll released Monday.
Of the part-time job holders, 12.28 percent also have full-time jobs in addition to their part-time work; while 9.64 percent have no other jobs, the poll conducted by the 1111 job bank found.
The study also showed that office workers and others with temporary jobs can earn an extra NT$16,021 (US$327) per month on average from their part-time employment.

According to the job bank, an increasing number of people are starting small businesses, returning to school for skills training or working part-time because they are having problems finding full-time work.

A higher percentage of workers of both genders aged over 41 years have part-time jobs, compared to their counterparts aged below 40 -- reflecting a rising jobless rate among middle-aged office workers, a job bank executive said.

In addition, he pointed out, a larger percentage of women than men have temporary work as more and more housewives hope to share their family's financial burden amid growing financial difficulties in the current economic recession.
Meanwhile, the number of job application forms filled out on the job bank's website increased by 43.39 percent in November, compared to the same month last year.

According to statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , in the first three quarters of this year, Taiwanese workers' permanent salaries rose by 1.02 percent year-on-year on average -- the lowest level in three years.
Their real income recorded a negative 2.95 percent growth -- the largest decrease since 1980, after taking into consideration the consumer price index, the DGBAS statistics showed.

It is estimated that the number of Taiwan's jobless workers would further rise to around 500,000 in November, affecting more than 1 million people, including the jobless person and his or her family members. This is up from 476,000 unemployed people in October, which recorded a jobless rate of 4.37 percent.
Taiwan's jobless rate stood at 3.84 percent in May, according to DGBAS statistics.

The survey also found that close to 47 percent of the office workers surveyed do not moonlight because they have not found suitable part-time jobs, while some 33 percent cited a lack of time or their irregular work schedule as the reasons why they do not hold part-time jobs.
About 16 percent of the survey respondents voiced concern over their heavy workload, the questionnaire discovered.

DOC.HEADLINE: Garment importers victimized by Chinese remittance fraudsters

TEXT.P: More than 10 local garment stores have suffered combined losses of NT$50 million (US$1.51 million) as a result of remittance fraud committed by a Chinese brokerage firm known to them as Guangda Co., the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said in a news release Monday.
The stores, as well as various other Taiwanese importers, are vulnerable to this type of remittance fraud due to the lack of direct remittance services between Taiwan and China, CIB officials noted.

According to the officials, many store owners have expressed strong hopes that with the Dec. 15 implementation of direct transport and postal links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, it is now time to consider direct remittance services so that importers can avoid being exploited by middlemen or becoming targets for fraudsters.

A store on the renowned Wufenpu business circle in Taipei's Sungshan district, owned by a woman identified by her surname Wang, has been importing garments from China for over 10 years. Wang recently began to use Guangda Co. as her remittance broker, thinking she would be able to make savings on service charges.

She received a phone call one day from a person claiming to be Guangda's accountant, who asked her to wire her payment to a different bank account. After remitting NT$1 million to the designated account, the company of course vanished.
The CIB said a garment store in Taichung County lost NT$400,000 in a similar manner, while another in Taichung City lost NT$460,000.

Further investigation by the CIB led to the discovery that Guangda Co. staff called more than 10 garment stores in Taiwan at about the same time in early December, asking them to wire their payments into a designated bank account.
After raking some NT$50 million from the Taiwanese buyers, Guangda Co. dropped under the radar, taking its clients' money with it, according to the CIB.

DOC.HEADLINE: Employers and workers ask suspension of labor premium rate increase

TEXT.P: Representatives of employers and workers on Monday expressed hopes that a planned increase in labor insurance premium rate, which is scheduled to go into effect next year, can be postponed for one year, in order to avoid additional pressure on management and employees under the current economic downturn.

The representatives expressed their opinions at a public hearing held in the Legislative Yuan. In attendance were legislators, representatives of workers' unions and employers from around the island, as well as officials from the Council of Labor Affairs.

We suggested that the government postpone the implementation of the new premium rate, or prepare a special budget to help employers and workers afford the increase in premiums, said Lu Fu-tsai, a member of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.

The CLA should postpone the insurance premium increase for one year in order not to create another financial burden for both laborers and employers, said Huang Ying-hua, a representative of a workers' union from Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan.
According to an amendment to the Labor Insurance Act approved in July, the premium rate is supposed to be raised from the current 6.5 percent to 7.5 percent from January 1 next year.

Pan Shih-wei, CLA deputy minister, told the employers and employees' representatives that changing the labor insurance premium rate is a question of amending the act, adding that the CLA supported all that is beneficial to workers.
Pan, however, did not say what the CLA would do to address the groups' demand.
Employers and workers, meanwhile, disagreed on whether Taiwan should allow more foreign workers or reduce the number of such workers during these economic times.

Huang stressed that the government should suspend introduction of foreign workers in the manufacturing and construction industries and that enterprises should not renew contracts with foreign workers already working in Taiwan.
He also noted that a fund must be set up immediately to help laborers file lawsuits against employers and protect their rights.

Pan reiterated that the CLA vowed to undertake strict checks on the proportion of national workers and foreign workers in factories and will not allow employers to hire more foreign workers without legitimate reasons.
In addition, he said, when an enterprise plans to lay off Taiwanese workers, the employer should ask if these workers are willing to undertake foreign workersjob, which is usually more arduous.
If Taiwanese workers agree, the CLA plans to cancel the enterprises quota of foreign workers, so as to protect local workersright to work.
A plan regarding imposing a stricter policy on hiring foreign workers will be presented soon, Pan added.

Ho Yu, who represents the Chinese National Federation of Industries, said however that quotas of foreign workers should not be canceled, especially for the so-called "3K" industries, which means "dirty, dangerous and difficult", in case of an economic revitalization in the future.

The Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan reported Monday that the latest unemployment rate has soared to 4.64 percent in November, an increase of 0.27 percent over October.
The total number of jobless people increased to 507,000.
The average unemployment rate from January to November this year is 4.06 percent, 0.14 percent higher compared to the same period last year, according to the agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's unemployment rate climbs to 4.64 percent: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's workers faced an increasingly gloomy economic environment in November as the unemployment rate rose to 4.64 percent, from 4.37 percent a month earlier, the Directorate-General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Monday.
The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 4.62 percent, or 0.33 percentage points higher than in October.

Taiwan had 507,000 jobless in November, with 202,000 of them having lost their jobs through downsizing or company closures, a six-year high for the month, according to DGBAS official Huang Jiann-jong.
Particularly worrisome, Huang said, is that the number of laid-off workers increased by 71,000 -- more than a third of the existing total -- during the past three months.

In addition, the number of jobless in the 45 to 64 age bracket averaged 86,000 from January to November, 14.94 percent higher than for the same period last year. That represented the highest growth rate of unemployed among all age brackets.
Huang suggested that the sharp rise in jobless middle-aged workers required attention, as the trend could impact families and society as a whole.

Also worth noting, Huang said, is that the average unemployment rate during January and November for workers with a bachelor's degree or higher reached 4.73 percent, the highest number among all educational levels.
With the inclusion of November's numbers, unemployment in the first 11 months of the year averaged 4.06 percent, or 0.14 percentage points higher than the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: China links may be taking toll on domestic travel

TEXT.P: The opening of daily nonstop charter flights between Taiwan and China has effectively cut cross-Taiwan Strait travel times and costs, but it may also be luring away local residents from traveling within the country, business sources said Monday.
According to industry insiders, many small hotels and inns in the Kending National Park area in southern Taiwan's Hengchun Peninsula are facing sluggish advanced bookings -- the worst in history.

Rooms at local hotels were almost fully booked as the new year approached last year, sources said, and hotel operators had hoped that the upcoming four-day extended holiday from Jan. 1 to Jan. 4 would generate even stronger momentum for their businesses.
But those hopes have yet to be realized.

Chung Tien-hui, who runs an inn in Kending targeting retail clients, said potential occupancy rates for the coming holiday at most of the hotels and bed and breakfast inns in the area remain "low" -- about 20 percent or 30 percent -- even though New Year's Day is only nine days away.

Chung acknowledged that the recession has played a role in the area's poor advance bookings but also suggested that the nonstop daily charters to China inaugurated Dec. 15 deserved a share of the blame.
The new service has made China-bound travel even more affordable and convenient, to the point where a weekend in Shanghai might cost less than a few days in Kending.

A five-day tour from Taiwan to Hangzhou in China's Zhejiang province, for instance, can cost as little as NT$5,000 (US$155), less than a two-day trip from other parts of Taiwan to Kending -- one of the country's most popular tourism destinations.
Many small hotels and homestays are now trying to fight back, offering 20 percent discounts on accommodation.

They also remain concerned that if the sluggish economic environment persists, they will also fare poorly during the coming Lunar New Year holiday -- one of the peak periods for domestic travel when hotels can usually charge premiums for rooms.
The Lunar New Year's Day falls on Jan. 26, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei nightlife scene remains lively despite economic downturn

TEXT.P: Most of Taiwan's economy is facing a serious revenue slump, but Taipei's nightlife scene has apparently remained as popular and lively as ever, according to the management of various nightclubs in the city.

We have not seen the economic downturn have an impact on our business as it has others, " remarked Moon Feng, supervisor of the Department of Marketing and Promotion of Room 18, one of the hottest places in Taipei for night-fun seekers.
She told the Central News Agency that the club's number of patrons have remained on an equal footing with turnout in past years, averaging 1,500 every open night.
Other indicators such as frequency of visits and nightly expenditures on food and drink have also stayed steady, she said, and Christmas may be even stronger than in years past.

With the pub's 25 private rooms completely booked and various promotions being offered to coincide with the holiday theme, we are confident that more than 2,000 people will attend our event, Feng said.
People probably want even more to seize the opportunity of a holiday to have fun and be merry when the economy is not doing so well,she suggested, explaining her club's success.

Meanwhile, Joanna Su, marketing manager of LOOP Production, which ownsLuxy, another club worshiped by party animals in downtown Taipei, said her club had also been relatively immune to the impact of the sluggish economy.
The club's advanced sales for its Christmas Eve festivities have been strong, she said, with pre-sold tickets to its three ballrooms nearly all gone.
With free drinks offered to guests before 11 p.m. as well as the planned appearance of a popular singer on Taiwan's music scene, Su hoped the club's draw on Wednesday night would also exceed 2,000.
Taipei-basedPrimotold CNA that not only has the club not suffered from more thrifty consumer spending behavior as a result of the weak economy, it has actually thrived.

According to Primo's project planner, Manson Yu, the club, which caters to upscale customers such as celebrities and entrepreneurs, saw business double in the past month compared to February when it opened.
With privacy a major concern for most of his patrons, Yu suggested thatexquisite attention to serviceplays a pivotal role in pursuing their trust and gaining their loyalty.

For example, each new club employee must sign aprivacy clause" that forbids them to leak out the identities of club guests. At the same time, Primo has 20 security guards covering an area of less than 660 square meters.
The club has also cultivated repeat business, Yu said, through its membership system.
"We know what a customer's favorite drink is, and we will also offer to throw him or her a birthday party when that special day arrives,Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to pay attention to the hidden jobless

TEXT.P: Taiwan has entered a period of low interest rates, low wages and low confidence, a job market expert warned Monday.

Ryan Wu, chief operating officer of Internet-based 1111 Job Bank, said the November jobless figures released by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics earlier Monday might have underestimated the seriousness of Taiwan's unemployment problem because the "hidden unemployed" were not reflected in the statistics.
DGBAS figures showed that 507,700 people in Taiwan were unemployed in November, representing a rise of 31,000 people, or 4.64 percent, over October -- the highest single-month increase ever recorded.
The unemployed total included 202,000 people who became jobless because their companies either downsized or ceased operations.

Wu pointed out that many part-time workers who were paid less than NT$10,000 per month -- lower than the lowest unemployment benefit of NT$10,368 paid by the Bureau of Labor Insurance -- were not counted as unemployed.
He said the official jobless figures might have underestimated Taiwan's unemployment situation because underemployed part-time workers constituted a main part of the hidden unemployed group.
Wu also said that a domino effect has already appeared in Taiwan, with many companies reducing their workforces, further aggravating the unemployment situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Daily cross-strait charters 70% full in first week: CAA

TEXT.P: Carriers from both Taiwan and China had passenger load factors exceeding 70 percent in the first week of daily nonstop cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) reported Monday.

According to the CAA under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, five Taiwan-based carriers and seven China-based aviation companies operated nonstop charters during the first week of the service, which kicked off Dec. 15.
The five Taiwanese carriers had an average passenger load factor of 73.8 percent during the first week of operations to Monday, with 22,089 of the 29,920 available seats filled, according to the CAA.
The seven Chinese airlines sold 11,593 of 15,964 seats available for a load factor of 72.6 percent.
Taiwanese carriers provided round trip flights to 13 destinations in China during the first week of operations, while their Chinese counterparts flew to four destinations in Taiwan, the CAA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Survey finds majority expects Ma government to improve governance

TEXT.P: The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has earned the trust of many of Taiwan's citizens, who believe it will reduce official corruption and improve the level of public sector integrity in the future, a Transparency International-Taiwan survey has found.

According to the results of the group's 2008 survey on clean governance, released by the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) Monday, more than 58 percent of respondents had faith the government would be less corrupt in the coming years.
The results marked the first time that more than half of the respondents to the annual survey voiced confidence in the ability of Taiwan's government to deal with corruption in the public sector.

MOJ officials speculated that the result may have been caused by the people's wish for the new government to be different from the previous administration led by former President Chen Shui-bian, who has been indicted on embezzlement and money laundering charges.
The survey was conducted by Transparency International-Taiwan July 4-8, with randomly chosen adults aged above 20 being interviewed by telephone.
A total of 1,626 valid samples were collected, and the survey had a margin of error of plus/minus 2.4 percentage points.

Under a 1-10 rating system for the degree of incorruptibility of public servants, with 10 representing the best score, civil servants and elected officials scored an average of 5 this year, slightly higher than the 4.88 recorded at the same time last year.

The public servants responsible for river gravel management were seen as the least trustworthy, receiving the lowest score of 3.7 points, trailing just behind officials in charge of government procurement and public construction projects, who received an average score of 3.98.
Legislators finished third from the bottom with a score of 4.04, the survey found.
Local elected officials all received low scores, with county and city councilors averaging 4.15, and elected township representatives averaging 4.36.

According to the survey, medical personnel at public hospitals received the highest score of 6.08, followed by common public servants at 5.8, and government employees in charge of land administration at 5.75.
With no category of government personnel scoring a 7 or better, TI-Taiwan suggested that the government expand anti-corruption efforts to further gain the people's trust.
The organization also urged that public officials be made subject to a proposed law that would make it illegal for officials to have assets from sources they cannot identify.
The survey results will be presented to the central government's anti-corruption commission, the MOJ said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unpaid leave affects 741,000 workers in Taiwan

TEXT.P: More workers in Taiwan -- especially those in the photonics, semiconductor and computer manufacturing industries -- were forced by their employers to take unpaid leave in November, according to official statistics released Monday.

The statistics, compiled by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, showed that as a result of the unpaid leave practice, 741,000 people worked less than 35 hours per week in November, an increase of 205,000 over October's total of 536,000.

DGBAS official Huang Chien-chung said the mandatory unpaid leave plans being implemented by the high-tech sector are expected to increase in intensity and lead to a further decline in the nation's already negative growth in wages.
Previous statistics from the DGBAS showed that Taiwan recorded nominal wage growth of minus 0.27 in October -- the third negative monthly growth rate in a row.

Meanwhile, labor rights groups expressed concern that the unpaid leave practice might affect workers' future pensions and other benefits. They called on the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to intervene on behalf of the employed.
CLA officials explained that irrespective of how long an unpaid leave may be, the monthly wage should not be lower than the minimum NT$17,280 required by law.
They added that the unpaid leave practice should not affect any severance payments and pension plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors will again appeal ex-president's release

TEXT.P: Prosecutors will again appeal the Taipei District Court's decision to release former President Chen Shui-bian on his own recognizance, a Supreme Prosecutors Office (SPO) official said Monday.

Chen Yun-nan, director of the SPO's Special Investigation Division (SID) , said that SID prosecutors decided to renew their request for Chen's detention after studying the Dec. 18 Taiwan District Court ruling that upheld its earlier decision to free Chen without bail.
"Prosecutors have come to such a decision as they think judges have not presented sufficent and fully convincing reasons to back up their ruling," Chen said.

Because the SID team handling the corruption and money laundering case against the ex-president did not receive the court verdict until Monday evening, team members have yet to draft their petition, Chen said.
He indicated, however, that prosecutors will definitely file their appeal before the deadline in one week's time.

As to whether prosecutors will ask the high court to hand down a ruling on their request instead of sending the case back to the district court for a new hearing, Chen said the SID team will study the issue and address it in detail in the petition.
Asked whether prosecutors are likely to request that the former president be detained on suspicions of his involvement in other criminal cases, Chen said the SID team has no such plans at the moment.

Last Thursday, the district court rejected the request to detain the former president on the grounds that prosecutors failed to prove that Chen Shui-bian might flee Taiwan, intimidate witnesses or co-defendants into going back on their previous testimony, or collude with others to tamper with evidence.
It was the district court's second ruling in six days on the issue.
The district court handed down the ruling after the Taiwan High Court Wednesday upheld an appeal by prosecutors asking for the case to be reheard.
In its appeal to the Taiwan High Court Dec. 16, the prosecutors also noted that they would soon begin to investigate several other corruption cases allegedly involving Chen and his wife.
If Chen is allowed to remain free, the prosecutors argued, some of the witnesses, including three of his former close aides, might not dare to tell the truth.

In its earlier ruling Dec. 13, the court ordered that Chen, who was detained Nov. 12, be released without bail following his indictment, along with 13 other people, on charges of embezzlement, corruption and money laundering.
Chen and his wife are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Insulator failure causes serious train delays

TEXT.P: An insulator failure tripped a power line between the Taiwan trunk railway's Cidu and Sijhih stations Monday evening, causing serious delays to 44 trains and disrupting the travel plans of about 35,000 passengers.
Taiwan Railway Administration officials said passengers of express trains that were canceled or delayed by 60 minutes or more are eligible to claim full refunds within 15 days.

The power failure took place at 6: 47 p.m., the officials said, adding that repair work was started immediately, with the westward line resuming operations at 8: 30 p.m. and the eastward line resuming operations at 10:20 p.m.

The Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan reported Monday that the latest unemployment rate has soared to 4.64 percent in November, an increase of 0.27 percent over October.
The total number of jobless people increased to 507,000.
The average unemployment rate from January to November this year is 4.06 percent, 0.14 percent higher compared to the same period last year, according to the agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's unemployment rate climbs to 4.64 percent: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's workers faced an increasingly gloomy economic environment in November as the unemployment rate rose to 4.64 percent, from 4.37 percent a month earlier, the Directorate-General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Monday.
The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 4.62 percent, or 0.33 percentage points higher than in October.

Taiwan had 507,000 jobless in November, with 202,000 of them having lost their jobs through downsizing or company closures, a six-year high for the month, according to DGBAS official Huang Jiann-jong.
Particularly worrisome, Huang said, is that the number of laid-off workers increased by 71,000 -- more than a third of the existing total -- during the past three months.

In addition, the number of jobless in the 45 to 64 age bracket averaged 86,000 from January to November, 14.94 percent higher than for the same period last year. That represented the highest growth rate of unemployed among all age brackets.
Huang suggested that the sharp rise in jobless middle-aged workers required attention, as the trend could impact families and society as a whole.

Also worth noting, Huang said, is that the average unemployment rate during January and November for workers with a bachelor's degree or higher reached 4.73 percent, the highest number among all educational levels.
With the inclusion of November's numbers, unemployment in the first 11 months of the year averaged 4.06 percent, or 0.14 percentage points higher than the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: China links may be taking toll on domestic travel

TEXT.P: The opening of daily nonstop charter flights between Taiwan and China has effectively cut cross-Taiwan Strait travel times and costs, but it may also be luring away local residents from traveling within the country, business sources said Monday.
According to industry insiders, many small hotels and inns in the Kending National Park area in southern Taiwan's Hengchun Peninsula are facing sluggish advanced bookings -- the worst in history.

Rooms at local hotels were almost fully booked as the new year approached last year, sources said, and hotel operators had hoped that the upcoming four-day extended holiday from Jan. 1 to Jan. 4 would generate even stronger momentum for their businesses.
But those hopes have yet to be realized.

Chung Tien-hui, who runs an inn in Kending targeting retail clients, said potential occupancy rates for the coming holiday at most of the hotels and bed and breakfast inns in the area remain "low" -- about 20 percent or 30 percent -- even though New Year's Day is only nine days away.

Chung acknowledged that the recession has played a role in the area's poor advance bookings but also suggested that the nonstop daily charters to China inaugurated Dec. 15 deserved a share of the blame.
The new service has made China-bound travel even more affordable and convenient, to the point where a weekend in Shanghai might cost less than a few days in Kending.

A five-day tour from Taiwan to Hangzhou in China's Zhejiang province, for instance, can cost as little as NT$5,000 (US$155), less than a two-day trip from other parts of Taiwan to Kending -- one of the country's most popular tourism destinations.
Many small hotels and homestays are now trying to fight back, offering 20 percent discounts on accommodation.

They also remain concerned that if the sluggish economic environment persists, they will also fare poorly during the coming Lunar New Year holiday -- one of the peak periods for domestic travel when hotels can usually charge premiums for rooms.
The Lunar New Year's Day falls on Jan. 26, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei nightlife scene remains lively despite economic downturn

TEXT.P: Most of Taiwan's economy is facing a serious revenue slump, but Taipei's nightlife scene has apparently remained as popular and lively as ever, according to the management of various nightclubs in the city.

We have not seen the economic downturn have an impact on our business as it has others, " remarked Moon Feng, supervisor of the Department of Marketing and Promotion of Room 18, one of the hottest places in Taipei for night-fun seekers.
She told the Central News Agency that the club's number of patrons have remained on an equal footing with turnout in past years, averaging 1,500 every open night.
Other indicators such as frequency of visits and nightly expenditures on food and drink have also stayed steady, she said, and Christmas may be even stronger than in years past.

With the pub's 25 private rooms completely booked and various promotions being offered to coincide with the holiday theme, we are confident that more than 2,000 people will attend our event, Feng said.
People probably want even more to seize the opportunity of a holiday to have fun and be merry when the economy is not doing so well,she suggested, explaining her club's success.

Meanwhile, Joanna Su, marketing manager of LOOP Production, which ownsLuxy, another club worshiped by party animals in downtown Taipei, said her club had also been relatively immune to the impact of the sluggish economy.
The club's advanced sales for its Christmas Eve festivities have been strong, she said, with pre-sold tickets to its three ballrooms nearly all gone.
With free drinks offered to guests before 11 p.m. as well as the planned appearance of a popular singer on Taiwan's music scene, Su hoped the club's draw on Wednesday night would also exceed 2,000.
Taipei-basedPrimotold CNA that not only has the club not suffered from more thrifty consumer spending behavior as a result of the weak economy, it has actually thrived.

According to Primo's project planner, Manson Yu, the club, which caters to upscale customers such as celebrities and entrepreneurs, saw business double in the past month compared to February when it opened.
With privacy a major concern for most of his patrons, Yu suggested thatexquisite attention to serviceplays a pivotal role in pursuing their trust and gaining their loyalty.

For example, each new club employee must sign aprivacy clause" that forbids them to leak out the identities of club guests. At the same time, Primo has 20 security guards covering an area of less than 660 square meters.
The club has also cultivated repeat business, Yu said, through its membership system.
"We know what a customer's favorite drink is, and we will also offer to throw him or her a birthday party when that special day arrives,Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to pay attention to the hidden jobless

TEXT.P: Taiwan has entered a period of low interest rates, low wages and low confidence, a job market expert warned Monday.

Ryan Wu, chief operating officer of Internet-based 1111 Job Bank, said the November jobless figures released by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics earlier Monday might have underestimated the seriousness of Taiwan's unemployment problem because the "hidden unemployed" were not reflected in the statistics.
DGBAS figures showed that 507,700 people in Taiwan were unemployed in November, representing a rise of 31,000 people, or 4.64 percent, over October -- the highest single-month increase ever recorded.
The unemployed total included 202,000 people who became jobless because their companies either downsized or ceased operations.

Wu pointed out that many part-time workers who were paid less than NT$10,000 per month -- lower than the lowest unemployment benefit of NT$10,368 paid by the Bureau of Labor Insurance -- were not counted as unemployed.
He said the official jobless figures might have underestimated Taiwan's unemployment situation because underemployed part-time workers constituted a main part of the hidden unemployed group.
Wu also said that a domino effect has already appeared in Taiwan, with many companies reducing their workforces, further aggravating the unemployment situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Daily cross-strait charters 70% full in first week: CAA

TEXT.P: Carriers from both Taiwan and China had passenger load factors exceeding 70 percent in the first week of daily nonstop cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) reported Monday.

According to the CAA under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, five Taiwan-based carriers and seven China-based aviation companies operated nonstop charters during the first week of the service, which kicked off Dec. 15.
The five Taiwanese carriers had an average passenger load factor of 73.8 percent during the first week of operations to Monday, with 22,089 of the 29,920 available seats filled, according to the CAA.
The seven Chinese airlines sold 11,593 of 15,964 seats available for a load factor of 72.6 percent.
Taiwanese carriers provided round trip flights to 13 destinations in China during the first week of operations, while their Chinese counterparts flew to four destinations in Taiwan, the CAA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Survey finds majority expects Ma government to improve governance

TEXT.P: The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has earned the trust of many of Taiwan's citizens, who believe it will reduce official corruption and improve the level of public sector integrity in the future, a Transparency International-Taiwan survey has found.

According to the results of the group's 2008 survey on clean governance, released by the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) Monday, more than 58 percent of respondents had faith the government would be less corrupt in the coming years.
The results marked the first time that more than half of the respondents to the annual survey voiced confidence in the ability of Taiwan's government to deal with corruption in the public sector.

MOJ officials speculated that the result may have been caused by the people's wish for the new government to be different from the previous administration led by former President Chen Shui-bian, who has been indicted on embezzlement and money laundering charges.
The survey was conducted by Transparency International-Taiwan July 4-8, with randomly chosen adults aged above 20 being interviewed by telephone.
A total of 1,626 valid samples were collected, and the survey had a margin of error of plus/minus 2.4 percentage points.

Under a 1-10 rating system for the degree of incorruptibility of public servants, with 10 representing the best score, civil servants and elected officials scored an average of 5 this year, slightly higher than the 4.88 recorded at the same time last year.

The public servants responsible for river gravel management were seen as the least trustworthy, receiving the lowest score of 3.7 points, trailing just behind officials in charge of government procurement and public construction projects, who received an average score of 3.98.
Legislators finished third from the bottom with a score of 4.04, the survey found.
Local elected officials all received low scores, with county and city councilors averaging 4.15, and elected township representatives averaging 4.36.

According to the survey, medical personnel at public hospitals received the highest score of 6.08, followed by common public servants at 5.8, and government employees in charge of land administration at 5.75.
With no category of government personnel scoring a 7 or better, TI-Taiwan suggested that the government expand anti-corruption efforts to further gain the people's trust.
The organization also urged that public officials be made subject to a proposed law that would make it illegal for officials to have assets from sources they cannot identify.
The survey results will be presented to the central government's anti-corruption commission, the MOJ said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unpaid leave affects 741,000 workers in Taiwan

TEXT.P: More workers in Taiwan -- especially those in the photonics, semiconductor and computer manufacturing industries -- were forced by their employers to take unpaid leave in November, according to official statistics released Monday.

The statistics, compiled by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, showed that as a result of the unpaid leave practice, 741,000 people worked less than 35 hours per week in November, an increase of 205,000 over October's total of 536,000.

DGBAS official Huang Chien-chung said the mandatory unpaid leave plans being implemented by the high-tech sector are expected to increase in intensity and lead to a further decline in the nation's already negative growth in wages.
Previous statistics from the DGBAS showed that Taiwan recorded nominal wage growth of minus 0.27 in October -- the third negative monthly growth rate in a row.

Meanwhile, labor rights groups expressed concern that the unpaid leave practice might affect workers' future pensions and other benefits. They called on the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to intervene on behalf of the employed.
CLA officials explained that irrespective of how long an unpaid leave may be, the monthly wage should not be lower than the minimum NT$17,280 required by law.
They added that the unpaid leave practice should not affect any severance payments and pension plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors will again appeal ex-president's release

TEXT.P: Prosecutors will again appeal the Taipei District Court's decision to release former President Chen Shui-bian on his own recognizance, a Supreme Prosecutors Office (SPO) official said Monday.

Chen Yun-nan, director of the SPO's Special Investigation Division (SID) , said that SID prosecutors decided to renew their request for Chen's detention after studying the Dec. 18 Taiwan District Court ruling that upheld its earlier decision to free Chen without bail.
"Prosecutors have come to such a decision as they think judges have not presented sufficent and fully convincing reasons to back up their ruling," Chen said.

Because the SID team handling the corruption and money laundering case against the ex-president did not receive the court verdict until Monday evening, team members have yet to draft their petition, Chen said.
He indicated, however, that prosecutors will definitely file their appeal before the deadline in one week's time.

As to whether prosecutors will ask the high court to hand down a ruling on their request instead of sending the case back to the district court for a new hearing, Chen said the SID team will study the issue and address it in detail in the petition.
Asked whether prosecutors are likely to request that the former president be detained on suspicions of his involvement in other criminal cases, Chen said the SID team has no such plans at the moment.

Last Thursday, the district court rejected the request to detain the former president on the grounds that prosecutors failed to prove that Chen Shui-bian might flee Taiwan, intimidate witnesses or co-defendants into going back on their previous testimony, or collude with others to tamper with evidence.
It was the district court's second ruling in six days on the issue.
The district court handed down the ruling after the Taiwan High Court Wednesday upheld an appeal by prosecutors asking for the case to be reheard.
In its appeal to the Taiwan High Court Dec. 16, the prosecutors also noted that they would soon begin to investigate several other corruption cases allegedly involving Chen and his wife.
If Chen is allowed to remain free, the prosecutors argued, some of the witnesses, including three of his former close aides, might not dare to tell the truth.

In its earlier ruling Dec. 13, the court ordered that Chen, who was detained Nov. 12, be released without bail following his indictment, along with 13 other people, on charges of embezzlement, corruption and money laundering.
Chen and his wife are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Insulator failure causes serious train delays

TEXT.P: An insulator failure tripped a power line between the Taiwan trunk railway's Cidu and Sijhih stations Monday evening, causing serious delays to 44 trains and disrupting the travel plans of about 35,000 passengers.
Taiwan Railway Administration officials said passengers of express trains that were canceled or delayed by 60 minutes or more are eligible to claim full refunds within 15 days.

The power failure took place at 6: 47 p.m., the officials said, adding that repair work was started immediately, with the westward line resuming operations at 8: 30 p.m. and the eastward line resuming operations at 10:20 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Tuesday, moving down 18.49 points at 4,517.05 on a turnover of NT$1.34 billion (US$40.69 million).
The weighted price index lost 158.98 points, or 3.38 percent, to close at 4,535.54 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Tuesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$33.148 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.218 from Monday.
