DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 23, or the 26th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar.
Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1888: Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh cut off one of his ears in an epileptic attack.
1948: Japanese war criminal Eiki Tojo is executed.
1957: Republic of China Premier Yu Hung-chun is impeached by the Control Yuan, the highest watchdog body.
1958: The construction of the 333-meter Tokyo Tower is complete.
1974: The test-flight of B-1 bombers by U.S. pilots proves successful for the first time.
1986: Soviet human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov is released from exile and he returns to Moscow.
1989: Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife are arrested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Kuo finally finds niche in setup role

TEXT.P: The "This Year in Baseball Awards" lack the prestige of their official counterparts like the Cy Young and Most Valuable Player awards that define excellence in U.S Major League Baseball.
Chosen by fans rather than the Baseball Writers' Association of America, they amount to a post-season popularity contest that keep people interested in the game.

Yet for Taiwan's Kuo Hong-chih, who last week won the This Year in Baseball Award for best setup man, simply appearing in enough games at the major league level to be even considered for the honor is nothing short of amazing and a testament to Kuo's persistence.
Signed by the Los Angeles Dodgers for US$1.25 million as a teenager in 1999, he blew out his elbow in his first professional game in 2000 and has faced considerable roadblocks since.
He missed the entire 2003 and 2004 season from his second Tommy John surgery and has been unable to remain healthy at the major league level since he first pitched for the major league club in 2005.
As recently as 2007, Kuo had rotator cuff problems and elbow surgery, leaving his career in jeopardy, according to MLB.com.

Long nurtured as a starter by the Dodgers, the club has been reluctant to use him as a reliever because it felt his surgically repaired left arm was not suited to the quick warm-up routines of pitchers coming out of the bullpen.
But after three poor starts to start the 2008 season, in which he yielded six earned runs in 10 2/3 innings, Kuo was moved to the bullpen.
He began as an uncelebrated middle reliever, but claimed the setup role midway through the season when closer Takashi Saito was injured in July and was nearly unhittable after that.
Though Kuo still showed signs of physical frailty, sitting out most of September with a sore biceps, he nonetheless posted impressive numbers.

He went 5-2 with a 1.69 ERA in relief, the best in the league, and struck out 86 in 69 1/3 innings of work. Most impressive was the 42 games he pitched in (including the three starts), nearly doubling his 45 appearances in his first three major league seasons.

Those numbers, and the legions of Taiwanese fans who closely follow U.S. baseball, helped him garner 30.3 percent of the 1.2 million votes cast to win the setup man award, beating out Grant Balfour (19.2 percent) of the Tampa Bay Rays and Carlos Marmol (17.2 percent) of the Chicago Cubs.

With Saito not tendered a contract for the 2009 season, Kuo will compete with Jonathan Broxton for the Dodgers' closer role, a much different role than he may have envisioned years ago but now accepts.
"I think I'm better suited to being a reliever because I don't have a big assortment of pitches," Kuo told local media. "But I may need another two to three years to be ready as a closer."

DOC.HEADLINE: Obama won't pick a fight with China over Taiwan: U.S. expert

TEXT.P: The Barack Obama administration is not likely to pick a fight with China by establishing closer formal commercial ties with Taiwan, given Washington's many common interests with Beijing, a former assistant United States trade representative said Tuesday.

Charles Freeman, an expert on U.S-China relations, said signing a U.S.-Taiwan Free Trade Agreement or U.S. support of Taiwan's participation in the P4 group of countries -- consisting of New Zealand, Singapore, Chile, and Brunei -- could easily "upset China."

"Any move by the U.S to support Taiwan's participation in organizations such as the P4 will require Beijing's approval, " Freeman said in Washington during a videoconference with representatives of Taiwan's Office of Trade Negotiations to discuss the new U.S. administration's approach to trade, China and Taiwan.

Freeman said, however, that the Obama administration will continue to urge China to be a responsible stakeholder and will also try to pressure it into expanding domestic consumption in its export-driven economy and appreciating its currency.

Noting that Obama as a senator supported legislation to name China as a currency manipulator, Freeman said Treasury Secretary-designate Timothy Geither, who speaks Cantonese and lived in China where his father worked on aid projects, will be in charge of continuing the Strategic Economic Dialogue (SED) and monitoring the currency manipulation issue.

"It is very likely that Geithner will work harder than (U.S. Treasury Secretary) Henry Paulson to get the EU, Japan and others to work with the U.S. in the International Monetary Fund and other multilateral settings against China's currency interventions, " Freeman said.

Asked about the Obama administrations's action plan for a US-P4 agreement, Freeman said there will not be much political cost for the USTR negotiators to play an active role in the talks, as the agreement is still being negotiated.

"Indeed there may be some political support because the P4 promises to give the U.S additional opportunities in markets which China has increasingly dominated," Freeman noted, adding that markets in the Asia-Pacific region have been growing on their own and therefore deserved the attention of U.S trade policy.
Freeman currently holds the Freeman Chair in China Studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indigenous communities to get subsidies to attract tourists

TEXT.P: The Council of Indigenous Peoples will select eight indigenous communities and provide them with subsidies to develop into tourism and leisure centers, a council official said Tuesday.
Alang Manglavan, director of the council's Department of Health and Welfare, said the program also hopes to help indigenous communities nurture management talent and increase employment.
The council will decide in late January or early February the list of the eight indigenous communities that will each receive up to NT$5 million (US$151,500) in subsidies, he said.

At talks Tuesday with representatives of indigenous communities from Chiayi, Kaohsiung, and Pingtung cities and counties, the council official invited those communities with at least three years of experience in community development to apply to join the program.
There are approximately 430,000 indigenous people in Taiwan, accounting for 1.9 percent of the population.
The Atayal, Saisiyat, Bunun, Tsou, Rukai, Paiwan, Puyuma, Amis, Yami, Thao, Kavalan, Truku, Sakizaya and Sediq make up the 14 officially recognized indigenous tribes of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Zoo hopes to use panda fever to promote wildlife preservation goals

TEXT.P: The arrival of giant pandas in Taiwan has triggered debate on the legitimacy of exchanging endangered species between countries but the director of the Taipei City Zoo said international exchanges were necessary to sustain the existence of endangered species.

To preserve a diversity of life forms, efforts must be made to educate the public that a species is on the brink of extinction and inspire people to protect and take care of species that share the planet with humans, Jason Yeh contended.

The zoo manager acknowledged that in the field of biological conservation, the so-called "flagship species" such as the giant panda not only help generate long-term benefits for the endangered species itself but also raise public awareness of the need to protect all animals facing extinction.

By guiding people to love and care for pandas, people may begin caring for other species and pay attention to the deterioration of the animals' natural habitats, which are being destroyed by human acivity.
"This is the most important task" of the zoo in putting an animal on public display, Yeh said.

Since China announced in 2005 it would offer a pair of giant pandas to Taiwan as a gift of good will and friendship, the Taipei City Zoo has been planning and building a modern panda house that it hopes will reflect the zoo's role in educating the public and biological and ecological conservation.

Yeh said that since 2005, the zoo has sent 17 veterinarians and animal keepers to Beijing, Xian, Shanghai and Hong Kong as well as San Diego and Washington in the United States, and Chiang Mai in Thailand to see how other captive facilities have managed pandas.
They have also spent time at the giant panda habitat in the Wolong Nature Reserve in Sichuan, southwestern China, to gain knowledge and skills in breeding and attending the shy and sensitive animals.

To provide a living environment most suitable for pandas, Taipei City Zoo experts and staff have also thoroughly researched the "sunglasses-wearing" animal, including where they live, what they eat, how they breed and raise their offspring, how to acquire food for the animal, and managing breeding, Yeh said.

In addition, the zoo has invited domestic and foreign experts in biological, veterinary and livestock sciences to join a special team responsible for taking care of the new tenants during their permanent stay in Taipei, he added.

One problem the zoo has prepared for is feeding the pair of celebrities, having planted a six-hectare bamboo forest that will provide at least five different kinds of fresh bamboo to the giant pandas.
In addition, Yeh said, the zoo has begun planting at least 10 different kinds of bamboo, which will can be harvested in about a year.
Yeh reiterated that introducing pandas into Taiwan is not to create a circus show or for commercial gain.
"All the efforts the zoo has made over the past several years to acquire knowledge in caring and breeding the nearly-extinct animal reflect its devotion to wildlife preservation," he said.

The Taipei Zoo has created a complete databank on its Web site concerning the giant panda that offers detailed information on the endangered species plight, including the threats it faces and its vulnerability to climate change, human hunting and the destruction of its natural habitat.
The zoo hopes the import of pandas will open the doors for Taiwan to join in international research and cooperation on all aspects of wildlife conservation, including ethnic genetics, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.155 to close at NT$33.085.
A total of US$952 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.980 and fluctuated between NT$32.900 and NT$33.155.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market fell sharply Tuesday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for January dropping 178 points to close at 4,349, with 104,865 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for February lost 174 points to finish at 4,330, with 447 contracts traded, while March futures declined 178 points to end at 4,315, with 44 contracts traded.
June futures fell 166 points to close at 4,284, with 12 contract transactions, while September futures lost 171 points to finish at 4,089, with 35 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,527 for January, 4,504 for February, 4,493 for March, 4,450 for June and 4,260 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index fell 129.68 points to finish at 4,405.86, on turnover of NT$51.18 billion (US$1.55 billion).

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower, with September TF futures falling by the maximum allowable 7 percent.
January TE futures fell 8.2 points to close at 164.95, with 5,091 contracts traded, while February TE futures lost 7.75 points to finish at 164.05, with 24 contracts traded.

March TE futures decreased 8.8 points to end at 162, with two contracts traded, while September TE futures dropped 11.7 points to close at 155.7, with five contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.
January TF futures were down 14.6 points to close at 554.4, with 4,543 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures decreased 15.2 points to finish at 551.8, with 29 contracts traded.
September TF futures declined 28 points to end at 512, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Infotech institute launches Moblin Enabling Center

TEXT.P: The semi-official Institute for Information Industry (III) has launched its own Moblin Enabling Center to help foster Taiwan's Moblin industry, the institute announced Tuesday.
III Acting President Ke Jyh-sheng noted that the center's priority is to help domestic IT manufacturers produce Moblin 2.0-compatible laptops, nettops, and other mobile internet devices.
Moblin, an open-source project led by Intel, aims to develop a Linux-based software platform for mobile internet devices and other new categories of devices such as netbooks and nettops.
With the platform, developers can build visually rich, dynamic, and ready-to- use applications that run on Intel CPU-using devices.

Joined by major Taiwanese electronics companies, such as Asustek Computer Inc., Acer Inc., Quanta Computer Corp. and Compal Electronics Inc., Intel and Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs signed a cooperation agreement in late October to set up a Moblin enabling center and help strengthen the development of WiMAX technology in the country.

Leading a staff of 30 software engineers, Liu Ying-hui, the director of III's Moblin project, said his job is to help Taiwan quickly amass a research and development capacity for Moblin software, and help integrate existing hardware production technologies with the new trends to develop a Moblin supply chain in Taiwan.

Liu said the center will focus on developing technologies related to three- dimensional user interface, fast start-up, and power-saving, while also aiming to upgrade the center as an accreditation institute for Moblin 2.0 compatibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor groups protest unpaid leave, foreign workers policy

TEXT.P: Hundreds of workers from around Taiwan gathered Tuesday outside the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) building, demanding that the agency safeguard laborers' right to work by investigating illegal unpaid leave practices and tightening foreign worker policies.

Although Tuesday was a work day, many of the protesters from Taipei, Taoyuan, and Hsinchu in northern Taiwan and Tainan and Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, who attended the protest were on unpaid leave.

"Under the pressure of mass layoffs, the CLA is supposed to be on the side of workers, but it remains mute, said Mao Chen-fei, president of a labor group from Taoyuan County, in urging the Cabinet-level agency to take a firmer stance on the issue.
The CLA announced last week that all unpaid leave plans must result from negotiations between employers and employees, and that employers must not pay workers less than the minimum wage.
The labor groups estimated, however, that about 500,000 people have been forced to take unpaid days off without their consent.

They said that many large-scale enterprises, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company and United Microelectronics Corporation, have unilaterally announced unpaid leave programs and cutbacks in personnel, violating the CLA guidelines and negatively impacting workers' lives.

The groups accused Tainan City-based Efun Technology Company of having some of its employees work only one day per week, and not paying them the minimum wage, while some other workers had their monthly wage reduced by 10 percent.
The protesters also stressed that unpaid leave must not affect labor insurance, health insurance and retirement pension payments, which are calculated on the basis of workersaverage monthly wage.

The labor groups also wanted the CLA to implement rules barring enterprises from dismissing workers or forcing workers to take upaid leave unless they were posting losses, out of fear that some companies might replace local employees with cheaper foreign laborers.

To safeguard their right to work, the protesters demanded that the CLA suspend the introduction of foreign workers and strengthen checks on labor conditions and the ratio of domestic to foreign workers at local enterprises.
A fund used to help workers survive their economic plight, such as loans, should also be established right away, they added.
At present, there are around 380,000 foreign workers in Taiwan, mostly from Southeast Asian countries, working in the construction and manufacturing industries or as caretakers.
The angry workers, of all different ages, attempted to break into the CLA building at 12: 05 p.m. in a bid to get CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan to answer their demands, but they were stopped by police.

Wang did not respond to the workers' requests. Instead, CLA senior counselor Lin Jenn-yeu, reiterated that the government stressed in a press release that companies were forbidden to give workers on unpaid leave less than the minimum wage of NT$17,280 (US$523.5).
He promised that the CLA will also undertake checks on labor conditions to see if companies are respecting the CLA's guidelines.
Lin noted that a mechanism will be set up for workers to file complaints regarding illegal unpaid leave practices.
As for the introduction of foreign workers, Lin only said that the CLA is undertaking a stricter policy on foreign workers that it will continue to review.
Unsatisfied with Lin's answers, the workers broke several glasses to symbolize the frailty of their rights to work.

If the government does not provide satisfactory answers to their demands in the near future, the labor associations asserted that they will mobilize more workers to protest in front of the Office of the President before the Chinese New Year, which falls on January 26 next year.

Many enterprises have ordered their workers to take unpaid days off recently to reduce personnel costs. The Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics also reported Monday that 741,000 people worked less than 35 hours per week in November, affected by unpaid leave shemes.
The DGBAS reported Monday that unemployment had climbed to 4.64 percent in November, with around a total of 507,000 jobless people in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shares plunge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Tuesday, with the Taiwan stock exchange's weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 129.68 points, or 2.86 percent, to close at 4,405.86.
Finishing lower for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 4,517.05 and fluctuated between 4,523.13 and 4,359.55.
A total of 3.25 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$51.18 billion (US$1.55 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 5.2 percent. Construction issues declined 5 percent, textile stocks dropped 4.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares fell 3 percent, banking and financial shares and plastics and chemicals shares both lost 2.5 percent, paper and pulp issues shed 1.7 percent, and foodstuff issues were down 1.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,403 to 162, with 165 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$4.24 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wang signs one-year US$5 million deal with Yankees
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/08 17:40:40 (By Huang Chao-ping and Luke Sabatier)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese starter Wang Chien-ming agreed Monday to a one-year US$5 million contract with the New York Yankees, avoiding another contentious arbitration hearing.
Still two seasons away from having the opportunity to declare for free agency, Wang's return to the Yankees was a foregone conclusion.

The only question was how much the club was willing to pay him after a season that ended for the 28-year-old right-hander in mid-June when he injured his Lisfranc joint and tore a tendon in his right foot running the bases in a game against the Houston Astros.

In the end, the Yankees' offer represented a US$1 million raise, and it was accepted by Wang and his agent to avoid a repeat of the two sides' acrimonious arbitration hearing held before the 2008 season.
At the time, the Yankees offered Wang a one-year US$4 million deal, while the Taiwanese pitcher's agents demanded US$4.6 million.
Wang was stung by the adversarial nature of the proceedings, in which the club pointed to the Taiwanese pitcher's failings. In the end, the arbitrator sided with the Yankees.

Aborting its youth movement after a disappointing 2008 season, the first in which the Yankees did not reach the playoffs since 1994, New York has made the biggest splash in free agency of any team, signing veteran starters C.C. Sabathia and A.J. Burnett.
The presence of the two veterans should take some of the pressure off of Wang, who despite having won 19 games in both 2006 and 2007 seemed uncomfortable in his role as the ace of the staff.
Wang went 8-2 in 2008 with a 4.07 ERA prior to being injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese pandas to meet Taiwanese visitors on Jan. 25

TEXT.P: Arriving in Taiwan Tuesday, two Chinese pandas, Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, will live under excellent care in their new home at the Taipei Zoo, where they will formally meet their curious visitors in Taiwan on Jan. 25 - just in time for Chinese New Year.
The zoo's new display facility is a three-storey building claiming a "six-star" rating, which was constructed with a NT$310 million (US$9.37 million) sponsorship by the Shin Kong Group.
There is an international conference hall on the top floor and a visitor center on the second floor.
At the ground floor of the facility are two air-conditioned showrooms measuring 245 square meters and 210 square meters, respectively, which are enough to house two pairs of pandas.
According to zoo spokesman Chao Ming-chieh, during summer, the temperature of the showrooms will be maintained at between 18-22 degrees Celsius, with the humidity kept at 60-70 percent.

"The giant pandas have originated from a place where the average temperature records no higher than 25 degrees Celsius. The air-conditioning will help prevent an uncomfortable situation such as panting during summer time," Chao said.
During winter time, the rooms will be left naturally ventilated, he said.

The pandas' new home will also include an outdoor display area simulating the pandas' natural habitat. It is formed by a wide grassy ground, tall trees, rocks and a waterfall to provide the animals with a place for various activities.

A store room is set aside especially to deposit fresh bamboos -- the main food of the pandas. It is spacious enough to keep 560 kilograms of the plants to meet one week's demand by the animals. The room's temperature will be maintained at 4-7 degree Celsius and installed with a water spray system to keep the bamboos fresh.
A separate room is designed for the preparation of other supplementary food, such as corn and bamboo cakes, fruit and vegetables.
Meanwhile, there is a den designed as a place for mating, delivery or nursing.
The biggest expectation of the pandas is that they will reproduce in Taiwan.
To ensure successful breeding of the pandas in Taiwan, Tuan Tuan was matched with Yuan Yuan through DNA analysis to determine they are not close to each other genetically.
Tuan Tuan the male panda was born Sept. 1, 2004 to father Ling Ling and mother Hua Mei, and was registered number 588 worldwide.
Yuan Yuan the female panda was born Aug. 30, 2004 was born to father Lin Lin and mother Lei Lei, and registered number 587.

According to zoologists, giant pandas living in the wild usually reach sexual maturity between the ages of six and seven, while those in captivity can reach sexual maturity two to three years earlier because they are provided with better nutrition.
Yuan Yuan began to show signs of puberty in the spring this year, and Tuan Tuan is expected to become sexually mature by 2010, Taipei Zoo officials said.

The mating season of giant pandas runs between March and May, but the estrous cycle of the female panda lasts only three days. The fact that the male panda's penis is very short further increases the difficulty of mating.
Chao said the zoo will monitor the hormonal changes of the pandas through urine tests and observe other signs, such as their scream, behavior and appetite to judge if they are ready for mating.
The zoo is also planning to show Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan videos of mating pandas to try to arouse their interest in mating.
If a natural fertilization is unsuccessful, the zoo will consider artificial insemination, Chao said.

In the future, when the children of Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan reach productive age, they will not mate with each other but will be matched with other pandas in China, said Taipei Zoo Director Jason Yeh.
Setting a precedent, the zoo will assign keepers to take care of the pair on a rotational basis to ensure their safety and prepare for any emergencies, Yeh said.
The zoo estimated that the care of the pair of pandas will cost NT$38 million per year, including NT$1.02 million on the purchase of fresh bamboos as food for the animals.
In addition to individual and corporate sponsorship, the sales of related theme products will also provide a source of funding, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Superstar pandas arrive in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Two celebrity giant pandas arrived in Taiwan Tuesday evening as a gift of good will from China.

An EVA Airways charter plane carrying the pair of rare animals "Tuan Tuan" and "Yuan Yuan" landed at Taoyuan International Airport in northern Taiwan after a three-hour flight from Chengdu in Sichuan Province, southwestern China.

The pandas' arrival followed the Dec.15 opening of direct shipping and postal links and expansion of direct flight services across the Taiwan Strait in a further sign of rapidly warming ties between Taiwan and China.
The pandas were transported from Taoyuan airport to Taipei Zoo in an air- conditioned vehicle under police escort immediately after they were taken off the plane.

The two pandas will be held in quarantine at the zoo for one month before they will be allowed to meet curious visitors in Taiwan form the first time on the eve of the Chinese New Year which falls on Jan.26.

DOC.HEADLINE: Famous restaurant reports profit slowdown amid economic slump

TEXT.P: Din Tai Fung, a world famous dumpling house based in Taipei, reported Monday that its profits so far this year have declined by almost 30 percent compared with the same period last year and that it has suspended its plans to open branches in the Philippines and Thailand, as a result of the economic downturn.

Din Tai Fing, a innocuous-looking shop located in Taipei City's Yungkang commercial circle, specializes in small steamed pork dumplings, called "hsiaolungpao," but its chicken soup and vegetable and meat dumplings are also favorites among visitors from all over the world.
The restaurant not only attracts many international tourists every year eager to sample its "hsialungpao, " it is also a popular gourmet eatery among numerous local people.

It is particularly popular among Japanese tourists, including celebrities. When Japanese pop singer Ayumi Hamasaki was in Taiwan to hold a concert at Taipei Arena last year, she invited one of the restaurant's chefs to make the famous dumplings on the spot before the start of the show.

Another Japanese singer Kosuke Atari, who was one of the stars in the Taiwan- made box office hit Cape No. 7, also talked about his obsession with Din Tai Fung's dumplings, during a promotional event for the film earlier in the year.
Din Tai Fung was rated as one of the top 10 gourmet restaurants in the world by the New York Times in 1993 and has established branches in many foreign countries.
It also embarked on a "soft power diplomacy" effort last year, dispatching its chefs to Britain and France to demonstrate their renowned culinary skills.

Over the years, the long lines of customers waiting outside the dumpling house to be served became a common sight, but with the whole world reeling in the current economic storm, the lines have been getting shorter.

"The number of customers has actually dwindled," said Hu Huei-yi, chief of the restaurant's public-relations section. "Usually, the restaurant is full of customers all the time, but now there's a noticeable difference between peak and off-peak periods."
Although Din Tai Fung registered a drop in profits due to the adverse economic conditions, it is still a profitable enterprise, according to Hu.
Hu attributed the profit drop mainly to a decline in the number of local customers, adding that statistics have shown no apparent decrease in the number of tourists from other countries to Taiwan.
She said the restaurant's economic resilience is due to its successful diversification of service, which now includes home delivery and take-out, and its participation in food fairs and exhibitions.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-CPC forums will continue until peace accord is reached: KMT

TEXT.P: The joint forums held by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and its Chinese counterpart, the Communist Party of China, will continue in the years ahead until a peace accord is reached between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a whip of the KMT legislative casus said Tuesday.

Legislator Chang Sho-wen, secretary-general of the KMT caucus, told reporters that the fourth forum between the KMT and the CPC held in Shanghai Dec. 20-21 was "very constructive," and that there is no need to stop the meetings now.

"Had it not been for the forums, there would not have been the opening of the direct transport and postal links between Taiwan and China, and nor would Taiwan have received the two giant pandas -- Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan -- from China today," Chang said.
He commended the contributions made by KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan and KMT Chair Wu Poh-hsiung in this regard.
Lien and Wu both attended the fourth KMT-CPC forum in Shanghai, which focused on cross-strait economic, trade and cultural exchanges.
Chang said that they deserve credit for working out deals that are beneficial to Taiwan.
The KMT lawmaker also addressed concerns expressed by some critics that the forums signify party supremacy over the government.

"The forum is a party-to-party apparatus. There is no question of the administration keeping a low profile in the contacts," he said, adding that after the conclusion of the meetings, the KMT always presents a full report to the president on what was achieved.

The party-to-party dialogue between the KMT and the CPC began in April 2005 when then KMT leader Lien made a historic visit to China and met with Chinese Communist Party Secretary General Hu Jintao -- the first contact between the two parties in 60 years.

After the ice-breaking visit, the two parties held a forum on economic and trade affairs in Beijing in April 2006, a second forum on agricultural cooperation at Boao in Hainan province in October 2006, and the Cross-Strait Youth Forum in Beijing in December the same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: November export orders down 28.51 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export orders plunged 28.51 percent to US$22.8 billion in November due to the global economic recession, marking the largest decrease ever recorded for a single month, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
For the first 11 months of this year, export orders were valued at US$330.94 billion, an increase of US$16.15 billion, or 5.13 percent, over the year-earlier level.
The largest contributors to the fall in November were electronic products, which saw orders drop by US$2.03 billion, or 27.69 percent, to US$5.3 billion.
Orders for precision devices fell US$1.47 billion, or 51.12 percent, to US$1.4 billion.
Orders for base metals and related products were down US$1.12 billion, or 40.75 percent, to US$1.63 billion.
Orders for information and communications products declined by 11.52 percent to US$6.41 billion, and those for rubber, plastics and related products dropped by 29.69 percent to US$1.19 billion.

Orders for electrical products decreased by 39.73 percent to US$992 million, orders for chemicals fell 39.24 percent to US$977 million, and those for machinery dropped 40.55 percent to US$815 million.
By region, orders from China and Hong Kong plummeted by 45.38 percent to US$4.55 billion in November, representing the second largest decrease ever recorded for a single month.
Orders from the United States lost 29.29 percent falling to US$5.36 billion, and those from Europe dropped by 15.46 percent to US$5.21 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Manufacturing sector shows pessimism on prospects

TEXT.P: Manufacturing sector businesses in Taiwan appear more pessimistic on economic growth in November than in the previous month, according to an economic outlook survey released Tuesday by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER).

The survey results show that the number of respondents in the manufacturing and services sectors predicting better economic growth in November than in October fell by 6 percentage points, while those predicting poorer growth increased by 10.4 percentage points.
In their predictions for the business climate in the coming six months, 67.1 percent of the respondents expressed pessimism, up from the 64.8 percent in October.
Those forecasting a better future increased from 4.3 percent to 5.8 percent, while those predicting an unchanged economic climate fell from 30.9 percent to 27.1 percent.

TIER Macroeconomic Forecasting Center Director Chen Miao pointed out that the pessimistic atmosphere was mainly caused by the global economic slowdown, which brought down demand and affected consumption around the world.

According to the TIER survey, under the institute's calculation model, the November business climate index in the manufacturing industry stood at 78.24 points in November, representing a drop of 9.56 points from the previous month's 87.8 points and marking the lowest level since 1979, Chen said.
The November business climate index in the services industry stood at 89.56 points -- a drop of 4.87 points from the 94.43 recorded in October, the results show.

The survey also shows that the manufacturing businesses who said the economy will worsen in November while forecasting that the economy will deteriorate even more in the coming six months include electronics manufacturers, retail and wholesale traders, banking and insurance operators and textile and ready-to-wear garment makers.
Only the manufacturers of bicycles and bicycle parts and components said the economy improved in November and predicted that it will get even better in the next half-year, according to the poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung residents urged to eat chicken without fear

TEXT.P: Nothing unusual has been detected in areas adjacent to a Kaohsiung County poultry farm that was stricken by the H5N2 bird flu virus, and the public should not be afraid to eat cooked chicken or eggs, local officials said Tuesday.

Yeh Kun-song, chief of the animal disease prevention institute in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, said the low-pathogenic H5N2 virus is not communicable to humans, and the public can eat chicken without fear of contracting the virus.

Starting Dec. 23, blood samples of chickens at the 76 poultry farms within a radius of three kilometers of the infected poultry farm in Luchu township will be tested each month by county authorities for avian flu, Yeh said.
Meanwhile, protective fences have been erected around the township's poultry farms in an effort to prevent the intrusion of migratory birds that may be carrying the virus.

Kaohsiung City officials said that people can also feel free to eat their homegrown chickens, stressing that there is no record of the high-pathogenic bird flu viruses in Taiwan and the low-pathogenic H5N2 strain is not known to jump from birds to humans.

In a bid to prevent an outbreak or the spread of bird flu, municipal authorities are monitoring birds at bird shops and ports and collecting samples for testing, Economic Affairs Bureau officials said.
In late October, close to 400 chickens died at the Luchu poultry farm of what was later confirmed to be the H5N2 avian flu virus.
Following the confirmation last week by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), the poultry farmer agreed to cull his remaining 18,000 chickens and the farm has suspended operations.
COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung confirmed a day earlier that there have been no other cases of bird flu in Taiwan since late October and he urged the public not to panic over speculations of an outbreak.
In line with the central government's bird flu prevention efforts, the Taipei county government announced Monday that all 98 samples collected from birds within the county had tested negative.

County authorities have demanded that local poultry owners disinfect their farms during the period Jan.9-15 next year to prevent any possible outbreak of bird flu in the winter, which is the high season for flu.

On the offshore county of Kinmen, plant and animal disease prevention officials disinfected local poultry farms Monday -- the latest round of such operations -- in the wake of the outbreaks of bird flu in China and Taiwan proper in recent months. China's outbreaks were caused by the high-pathogenic H5N1 virus, different from the H5N2 strain that affected the Luchu poultry farm.

Kinmen animal disease prevention bureau chief Chuang Chien-kung said that during the first 11 months of this year, 374 samples collected on 21 local poultry farms and 90 samples from other birds had all tested negative for the virus. This indicates that Kinmen is free from bird flu, he said.
Meanwhile, the county has stepped up patrols along its coastlines, in collaboration with the Coast Guard Administration, to prevent the introduction of bird flu via contraband products.
According to Chuan, the Kinmen authorities carried out 190 rounds of disinfection from the beginning of the year to Nov. 20, in view of its proximity to China.
The Kinmen county government said it will step up the frequency of its disinfection programs, depending on the bird flu situation in China.
Kinmen Island is located in the Taiwan Strait and lies closer to China's Fujian province than to Taiwan proper.
Kinmen maintains direct ferry links with several Fujian ports via what are commonly known as the mini links.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan graded `above acceptable' for living environment: poll

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been rated as "above acceptable" with an average score of 67.9 out of a possible 100 for the overall international living environment by white-collar foreign workers living in the country, according to the results of a government survey released Tuesday.

Speaking in a press conference, Sung Yu-hsieh, deputy minister of the Cabinet- level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) , said the survey will help the government better understand foreigners' living experience in Taiwan and serve as a reference for the establishment and implementation of future policies and measures.

According to Lin Chi-fan, a professor from Shih Hsin University, which was commissioned by the RDEC to conduct the survey, Taiwan received the highest scores in the categories of friendly attitudes toward foreigners, which received 87 points, and social cohesion, with 82.2 points.
He noted that the scores serve as indicators that most Taiwanese treat foreigners living in the country well.

The scores were compiled on a five-rank system: very satisfactory, satisfactory, acceptable, dissatisfactory, and very dissatisfactory, Lin explained, adding that both of the highest figures cross the satisfactory level.

The other areas evaluated, listed in order of the highest scores to the lowest, are government performance, service facilities provided for foreigners, bilingual signage, bilingual websites and emergency assistance information, Lin went on.

In the area of government performance, the airport and customs garnered the highest score of 75.8, while foreign worker employment consultation received the lowest score of 63.8, barely passing the acceptable level, according to the survey.

Lin said that in terms of bilingual signage, most of the respondents complained about the lack of bilingual markings on product packaging, or the covering up of English labels on some imported items with Chinese labeling.
As for emergency assistance information, he said the low scores result from the lack of English communication abilities of the staff working in places such as police stations and fire departments.

Sung said that as part of the government's efforts to provide foreigners with easier access to its information, a Web site portal for the English versions of every government agency has been set up at english.www.gov.tw.

He advised foreigners to call 0800-024-111 -- a 24-hour hotline -- to assist them in solving problems including medical treatment, visas, housing, employment, taxation and insurance in Chinese, English and Japanese.

He said the international hotline service, which he described as the first of its kind in the country, has gained a good reputation among the foreigners who have used it, but he admitted that over 50 percent of the survey respondents were unaware that the service even exists.

Sung concluded that Taiwan overall provides a friendly environment for foreigners but still has a great deal of room for improvement, especially in terms of bilingual facilities and English communication abilities.
The survey, conducted Aug. 8-Sept. 16, received a total of 1,088 effective responses, with a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-speed rail free shuttle bus services to stop in April

TEXT.P: Free shuttle bus services at high-speed rail stations will be terminated at the end of March, and from April on, passengers on the high-speed rail will have to pay for the cost of the services, ranging from NT$27 (US$0.81) to NT$76.
The free shuttle bus services are offered by the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) based on the BOT contract until Jan. 31, 2009.

The Directorate General of Highways (DGH) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has asked the THSRC to prolong the services until March 31, after the Chinese New Year holiday -- one of the most important festivals in Taiwan, DGH officials said Tuesday.
After that time, the DGH will take over the shuttle bus operation, but will charge passengers. The scope of the service will also be enlarged from seven to 12 routes, the DGH officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China links will help Taiwan build pivotal regional role: MAC

TEXT.P: The opening of daily flight services as well as direct shipping and postal links across the Taiwan Strait will help Taiwan reinforce its pivotal role in the region, but the government will never exchange Taiwan's independent sovereignty for economic gains, a government official said Tuesday.
Fu Dong-cheng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Taiwan's economic situation has remained stable since the Dec. 15 inauguration of direct links with China.
The changing cross-strait relations will serve as a new start in Taiwan's ambition to become a financial center and a transportation hub in the Asia- Pacific region, he added.

Over the past 10 years, he said, Taiwan has slid to the bottom among the four Asian dragons due to its lack of normalized trade and economic ties. This situation developed because there were no direct air transportation or shipping networks between the two sides of the strait, he added.

The MAC vice chairman made the remarks at a seminar on cross-strait exchanges in Tainan City, southern Taiwan that was held as part of efforts by President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to explain its China policy.

Since he came to office in May, Ma has been moving to make good on his pledge to build better and closer ties with China, in part to reinvigorate Taiwan's economy, but many people in southern Taiwan fear that his policies will compromise Taiwan's interests.

However, Fu said that although improved cross-strait ties will help Taiwan regain momentum to boost its economic clout and strategic importance, the government will not forswear Taiwan's national sovereignty for economic gains in its dealings with China.
"The government will definitely prioritize the interests of the Taiwan people in its dealings with China," he stressed.
From now on, co-prosperity and reconciliation will replace confrontation between the two sides, he said.
However, Fu added, it will take some time for Taiwan to benefit from the positive effects of the direct cross-strait links.

Turning to the forthcoming third round of bilateral talks between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , he said joint efforts relating to crime-fighting, food safety, financial supervision and currency exchange settlement, and the protection of Taiwan business interests in China will be discussed.
Developing mutually beneficial economic ties is the centerpiece of the current Taiwan-China relationship until such time as the two sides can move to talk about political issues, he said.
The MAC oversees the operations of the semi-official SEF, which is responsible for handling cross-strait contacts and negotiations through two-way dealings with the ARATS.

DOC.HEADLINE: President wants investigators out of shadow of former head's scandal

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou encouraged members of the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice Tuesday to emerge from the shadow cast by their former boss being sentenced to 10 years in prison for his role in helping the former first family with its money laundering activities.

Ma made the exhortation to boost the morale of the investigators at a ceremony marking the end of a training program for 73 new bureau recruits after noting that the former bureau head's misconduct had dealt a severe blow to their esprit de corps.

Former Investigation Bureau Director-General Yeh Sheng-mao was charged with concealing government documents and of leaking confidential information related to money laundering activities by former President Chen Shui-bian, his wife, son and daughter-in-law. He has been held in custody since Oct. 6.

Urging all investigators to be clear about their duties, Ma said that "you should be loyal to the nation, the people and the Constitution rather than the president, the minister (of the justice department), the prosecutor-general, or other superiors."
He told the new recruits to maintain a sense of righteousness and integrity in their work and to avoid succumbing to corruption.
"If any one of you finds that members of my family have engaged in any irregularities, you should report them to prosecutors, not to me," Ma said.

In January this year, the Investigation Bureau received a report from the international anti-money laundering organization Egmont Group regarding suspicions raised by a Cayman Islands' financial intelligence unit about the former first family laundering money through an account created under the name of Chen's daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching at the Merrill Lynch Bank in Geneva, Switzerland.

Based on the report, the bureau's Anti-Money Laundering Center on Jan. 29 compiled a file intended for delivery to the Supreme Prosecutors Office. Yeh later requested that the file be handed over to him, saying that he would pass it to State Public Prosecutor General Chen Tsung-ming in person.

However, instead of giving the file to Chen Tsung-ming or ordering an investigation into the suspected money laundering, Yeh leaked its contents to Chen Shui-bian -- the chief suspect who should have been the target of the investigation -- during a visit to the former president's official residence in late January.

DOC.HEADLINE: The wait is over - the pandas have finally arrived

TEXT.P: The long-anticipated arrival of a pair of giant pandas from China has finally come as Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, landed at Taoyuan International Airport aboard a EVA Airways charter flight and were whisked away by police motorcade to the Taipei City Zoo, their new home, Tuesday evening.
The pair of endangered animals arrived in Taoyuan International Airport at 5: 04 p.m. after a three-hour flight from Chengdu in Sichuan province, southwestern China.
Shortly after landing, the pandas were transported to the Taipei City Zoo in an air-conditioned vehicle, traffic-free, escorted by a police motorcade and jumping all red lights.
They settled into their new home at the zoo around 7:45 p.m.
With a month of quarantine ahead for Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, the new residents of Taipei City are expected to go on display on Jan. 25, just in time for the Chinese New Year holidays.
Yang Hsiao-tung, director of Taipei City's Department of Information and Tourism, told reporters that the pandas slept through almost the entire flight.
"The pandas behaved very well during the trip", said Yang, adding that their well-being was monitored by experts every minute of the way.

The pandas' arrival, however, is not without controversy. While supporters, including the government administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, see the pandas as a step towards easing tensions between China and Taiwan, opponents, including the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), criticized Taiwan's welcoming of the animals as buying into Beijing's ploy to win over the hearts and minds of Taiwanese people and eventually reunify with the island.
Since 1957, Beijing has used pandas as goodwill ambassadors, giving them to countries, such as the United States, with which it wants to form good relations.

In the case of Taiwan, Beijing is giving the pandas without charging fees, which it normally charges receiving countries. Not by accident, China gave the pandas names that mean "reunite" or "reunion" if said together in Chinese, symbolizing Beijing's hopes to eventually reunite with Taiwan, which has been ruled separately since the end of a bloody civil war in 1949.

Some opposition lawmakers have vowed to not only boycott the pandas, but not allow their family members to see them. Another was seen on TV suggesting that Taiwan give a pair of monkeys native to the island to China and name them "Tai Tai" and "Du Du" - which said together in Chinese means "Taiwan independence."

Regardless of how the Taiwanese public will see the pandas, Taipei's city government is hoping the animals will boost visitors at the zoo, with Mayor Hau Lung-bin saying recently that he expects six million visitors at the zoo a year as a result of the pandas.
The zoo has prepared an outdoor enclosure decorated with ferns and a footbridge, a sleeping area with all-season air conditioning and bamboo to welcome the two pandas.
Constructed with a NT$310 million sponsorship by the Shin Kong Group, the zoo's new display facility is considered by many experts as a three-storey, "six-star" mansion.
Taipei's zoo is pulling out all the stops to make the pandas feel at home and hopes the pair will eventually reproduce.

A storage room is set aside especially to deposit fresh bamboo -- which is the staple food for the pandas in their natural habitat. It is large enough to keep 560 kilograms of bamboo shoots to meet one week's demand by the animals. The room's temperature will be maintained between 4 to 7 degrees Celsius, and to satisfy the pandas' picky appetite, a water spray system was installed to keep the bamboos fresh.
Along with the two Chinese giant pandas, some 30 dove tree seedlings, China's rare plant species, were also given to Taiwan as a token of peace.

The exotic plants were allowed entry after testing negative to soil residues and infectious insects. The plants will be nurtured in a greenhouse at the Fushan Botanical Garden in northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County until they are mature enough to be transplanted, after which they will be moved to another location.
Chinese President Hu Jintao first offered the pandas to Taiwan as a gift of friendship in May 2005 when then-opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan made an ice-breaking visit to Beijing.

However, the gift was blocked by political bickering between Beijing and Taipei during Taiwan's time under the rule of the now-opposition DPP, which objected to China's treatment of the panda transfer as a "domestic transfer" between zoos because it implies that Taiwan is part of China.

As giant pandas are an endangered species subject to the protection of the Convention of International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITIES) , cross-border transfers of the animals must follow strict CITIES guidelines.

According to the guidelines, the two parties must supply export and import permits confirming that all conditions for the transfer have been met. This implies that the transaction is between two countries.

However, the issue was resolved under the governance of the administration of President Ma, which favors improving ties with China. Both sides decided to sidestep the issue of country name by agreeing to identify the importer as "Taiwan Taipei" and accepting "Chengdu" as the origin of export.

During a landmark visit to Taiwan in November by top Chinese negotiator on Taiwan affairs, Chen Yunlin, the two sides signed a formal agreement on exchanges of indigenous rare fauna and flora species to symbolize their amity and determination to cooperate in wildlife conservation.

The pandas' arrival are the latest steps by the two sides to improve relations. On Dec. 15, direct daily flights, direct shipping and direct postal links across the Taiwan Strait were launched and over the weekend, China's banks pledged to give US$19 billion in loans to Taiwanese businesses in China to help them cope with the economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese hackers condemned for breaking into DPP Web site

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) condemned Chinese hackers Tuesday for breaking into its Web site for a third time.

Liao Chih-chien, deputy director of the DPP's Information and Culture Department, confirmed that the Web site had been taken offline after staff found that the DPP's party flag on the site had been replaced by China's national flag.

The Chinese hackers also posted the words "protesting the release" of former President Chen Shui-bian. Chen was recently released from detention on his own recognizance by the Taipei District Court after prosecutors indicted him and his wife on charges of embezzlement, bribe-taking and money laundering.
According to Liao, IT engineers would need one full day to check whether important information on the site has been lost, and he added that it was not expected to be back up until Wednesday.

It is the third time Chinese hackers have broken into the DPP's Web site. The previous two break-ins occurred in June 2004 when Chen Shui-bian was DPP chairman and again later during the chairmanship of Yu Shyi-kun.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's status not belittled in pandas' delivery: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's sovereign status remains intact and was by no means belittled in the delivery of two giant pandas to Taiwan from China, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday in a statement.

The council, which coordinates and plans Taiwan's policy toward China, issued the statement after the Secretariat of the Convention of International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) said earlier this week that the transfer of pandas from China to Taiwan was in the category of internal/domestic trade and consequently need not be reported to the organization.
Noting that CITES is a United Nations-affiliated international organization, the MAC said that there is no way the transfer could alter the U.N.'s perception of Taiwan's political status.
As Taiwan is not a CITES signatory, it is not obligated to report to the CITES Secretariat its acceptance of the two pandas, the MAC said.
Nevertheless, it added that Taiwan has consistently followed the strict CITES provisions regarding imports of endangered animal and plant species, including the giant pandas.

In the process, the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs first issued an import permit for the pair of pandas offered by China as a gift of goodwill and friendship. With the import permit in hand, the Taipei City Zoo then applied to the relevant Chinese agencies for an export permit. China's endangered species export-import management office then issued export documents for customs declaration.
According to the MAC, the delivery of the pandas followed the mode of a country- to-country transfer. If it was an internal/domestic transfer, no customs declaration would be needed, the MAC added.

After a long wait, the pair of rare animals -- Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan -- finally arrived in Taiwan Tuesday to settle in Taipei Zoo in a further sign of rapidly warming ties between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: November export orders down 28.51 percent

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export orders plunged 28.51 percent to US$22.8 billion in November due to the global economic recession, marking the largest decrease ever recorded for a single month, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
For the first 11 months of this year, export orders were valued at US$330.94 billion, an increase of US$16.15 billion, or 5.13 percent, over the year-earlier level.
The largest contributors to the fall in November were electronic products, which saw orders drop by US$2.03 billion, or 27.69 percent, to US$5.3 billion.
Orders for precision devices fell US$1.47 billion, or 51.12 percent, to US$1.4 billion.
Orders for base metals and related products were down US$1.12 billion, or 40.75 percent, to US$1.63 billion.
Orders for information and communications products declined by 11.52 percent to US$6.41 billion, and those for rubber, plastics and related products dropped by 29.69 percent to US$1.19 billion.

Orders for electrical products decreased by 39.73 percent to US$992 million, orders for chemicals fell 39.24 percent to US$977 million, and those for machinery dropped 40.55 percent to US$815 million.
By region, orders from China and Hong Kong plummeted by 45.38 percent to US$4.55 billion in November, representing the second largest decrease ever recorded for a single month.
Orders from the United States lost 29.29 percent falling to US$5.36 billion, and those from Europe dropped by 15.46 percent to US$5.21 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Manufacturing sector shows pessimism on prospects

TEXT.P: Manufacturing sector businesses in Taiwan appear more pessimistic on economic growth in November than in the previous month, according to an economic outlook survey released Tuesday by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER).

The survey results show that the number of respondents in the manufacturing and services sectors predicting better economic growth in November than in October fell by 6 percentage points, while those predicting poorer growth increased by 10.4 percentage points.
In their predictions for the business climate in the coming six months, 67.1 percent of the respondents expressed pessimism, up from the 64.8 percent in October.
Those forecasting a better future increased from 4.3 percent to 5.8 percent, while those predicting an unchanged economic climate fell from 30.9 percent to 27.1 percent.

TIER Macroeconomic Forecasting Center Director Chen Miao pointed out that the pessimistic atmosphere was mainly caused by the global economic slowdown, which brought down demand and affected consumption around the world.

According to the TIER survey, under the institute's calculation model, the November business climate index in the manufacturing industry stood at 78.24 points in November, representing a drop of 9.56 points from the previous month's 87.8 points and marking the lowest level since 1979, Chen said.
The November business climate index in the services industry stood at 89.56 points -- a drop of 4.87 points from the 94.43 recorded in October, the results show.

The survey also shows that the manufacturing businesses who said the economy will worsen in November while forecasting that the economy will deteriorate even more in the coming six months include electronics manufacturers, retail and wholesale traders, banking and insurance operators and textile and ready-to-wear garment makers.
Only the manufacturers of bicycles and bicycle parts and components said the economy improved in November and predicted that it will get even better in the next half-year, according to the poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung residents urged to eat chicken without fear

TEXT.P: Nothing unusual has been detected in areas adjacent to a Kaohsiung County poultry farm that was stricken by the H5N2 bird flu virus, and the public should not be afraid to eat cooked chicken or eggs, local officials said Tuesday.

Yeh Kun-song, chief of the animal disease prevention institute in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, said the low-pathogenic H5N2 virus is not communicable to humans, and the public can eat chicken without fear of contracting the virus.

Starting Dec. 23, blood samples of chickens at the 76 poultry farms within a radius of three kilometers of the infected poultry farm in Luchu township will be tested each month by county authorities for avian flu, Yeh said.
Meanwhile, protective fences have been erected around the township's poultry farms in an effort to prevent the intrusion of migratory birds that may be carrying the virus.

Kaohsiung City officials said that people can also feel free to eat their homegrown chickens, stressing that there is no record of the high-pathogenic bird flu viruses in Taiwan and the low-pathogenic H5N2 strain is not known to jump from birds to humans.

In a bid to prevent an outbreak or the spread of bird flu, municipal authorities are monitoring birds at bird shops and ports and collecting samples for testing, Economic Affairs Bureau officials said.
In late October, close to 400 chickens died at the Luchu poultry farm of what was later confirmed to be the H5N2 avian flu virus.
Following the confirmation last week by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), the poultry farmer agreed to cull his remaining 18,000 chickens and the farm has suspended operations.
COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung confirmed a day earlier that there have been no other cases of bird flu in Taiwan since late October and he urged the public not to panic over speculations of an outbreak.
In line with the central government's bird flu prevention efforts, the Taipei county government announced Monday that all 98 samples collected from birds within the county had tested negative.

County authorities have demanded that local poultry owners disinfect their farms during the period Jan.9-15 next year to prevent any possible outbreak of bird flu in the winter, which is the high season for flu.

On the offshore county of Kinmen, plant and animal disease prevention officials disinfected local poultry farms Monday -- the latest round of such operations -- in the wake of the outbreaks of bird flu in China and Taiwan proper in recent months. China's outbreaks were caused by the high-pathogenic H5N1 virus, different from the H5N2 strain that affected the Luchu poultry farm.

Kinmen animal disease prevention bureau chief Chuang Chien-kung said that during the first 11 months of this year, 374 samples collected on 21 local poultry farms and 90 samples from other birds had all tested negative for the virus. This indicates that Kinmen is free from bird flu, he said.
Meanwhile, the county has stepped up patrols along its coastlines, in collaboration with the Coast Guard Administration, to prevent the introduction of bird flu via contraband products.
According to Chuan, the Kinmen authorities carried out 190 rounds of disinfection from the beginning of the year to Nov. 20, in view of its proximity to China.
The Kinmen county government said it will step up the frequency of its disinfection programs, depending on the bird flu situation in China.
Kinmen Island is located in the Taiwan Strait and lies closer to China's Fujian province than to Taiwan proper.
Kinmen maintains direct ferry links with several Fujian ports via what are commonly known as the mini links.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan graded `above acceptable' for living environment: poll

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been rated as "above acceptable" with an average score of 67.9 out of a possible 100 for the overall international living environment by white-collar foreign workers living in the country, according to the results of a government survey released Tuesday.

Speaking in a press conference, Sung Yu-hsieh, deputy minister of the Cabinet- level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) , said the survey will help the government better understand foreigners' living experience in Taiwan and serve as a reference for the establishment and implementation of future policies and measures.

According to Lin Chi-fan, a professor from Shih Hsin University, which was commissioned by the RDEC to conduct the survey, Taiwan received the highest scores in the categories of friendly attitudes toward foreigners, which received 87 points, and social cohesion, with 82.2 points.
He noted that the scores serve as indicators that most Taiwanese treat foreigners living in the country well.

The scores were compiled on a five-rank system: very satisfactory, satisfactory, acceptable, dissatisfactory, and very dissatisfactory, Lin explained, adding that both of the highest figures cross the satisfactory level.

The other areas evaluated, listed in order of the highest scores to the lowest, are government performance, service facilities provided for foreigners, bilingual signage, bilingual websites and emergency assistance information, Lin went on.

In the area of government performance, the airport and customs garnered the highest score of 75.8, while foreign worker employment consultation received the lowest score of 63.8, barely passing the acceptable level, according to the survey.

Lin said that in terms of bilingual signage, most of the respondents complained about the lack of bilingual markings on product packaging, or the covering up of English labels on some imported items with Chinese labeling.
As for emergency assistance information, he said the low scores result from the lack of English communication abilities of the staff working in places such as police stations and fire departments.

Sung said that as part of the government's efforts to provide foreigners with easier access to its information, a Web site portal for the English versions of every government agency has been set up at english.www.gov.tw.

He advised foreigners to call 0800-024-111 -- a 24-hour hotline -- to assist them in solving problems including medical treatment, visas, housing, employment, taxation and insurance in Chinese, English and Japanese.

He said the international hotline service, which he described as the first of its kind in the country, has gained a good reputation among the foreigners who have used it, but he admitted that over 50 percent of the survey respondents were unaware that the service even exists.

Sung concluded that Taiwan overall provides a friendly environment for foreigners but still has a great deal of room for improvement, especially in terms of bilingual facilities and English communication abilities.
The survey, conducted Aug. 8-Sept. 16, received a total of 1,088 effective responses, with a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-speed rail free shuttle bus services to stop in April

TEXT.P: Free shuttle bus services at high-speed rail stations will be terminated at the end of March, and from April on, passengers on the high-speed rail will have to pay for the cost of the services, ranging from NT$27 (US$0.81) to NT$76.
The free shuttle bus services are offered by the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) based on the BOT contract until Jan. 31, 2009.

The Directorate General of Highways (DGH) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has asked the THSRC to prolong the services until March 31, after the Chinese New Year holiday -- one of the most important festivals in Taiwan, DGH officials said Tuesday.
After that time, the DGH will take over the shuttle bus operation, but will charge passengers. The scope of the service will also be enlarged from seven to 12 routes, the DGH officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China links will help Taiwan build pivotal regional role: MAC

TEXT.P: The opening of daily flight services as well as direct shipping and postal links across the Taiwan Strait will help Taiwan reinforce its pivotal role in the region, but the government will never exchange Taiwan's independent sovereignty for economic gains, a government official said Tuesday.
Fu Dong-cheng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Taiwan's economic situation has remained stable since the Dec. 15 inauguration of direct links with China.
The changing cross-strait relations will serve as a new start in Taiwan's ambition to become a financial center and a transportation hub in the Asia- Pacific region, he added.

Over the past 10 years, he said, Taiwan has slid to the bottom among the four Asian dragons due to its lack of normalized trade and economic ties. This situation developed because there were no direct air transportation or shipping networks between the two sides of the strait, he added.

The MAC vice chairman made the remarks at a seminar on cross-strait exchanges in Tainan City, southern Taiwan that was held as part of efforts by President Ma Ying-jeou's administration to explain its China policy.

Since he came to office in May, Ma has been moving to make good on his pledge to build better and closer ties with China, in part to reinvigorate Taiwan's economy, but many people in southern Taiwan fear that his policies will compromise Taiwan's interests.

However, Fu said that although improved cross-strait ties will help Taiwan regain momentum to boost its economic clout and strategic importance, the government will not forswear Taiwan's national sovereignty for economic gains in its dealings with China.
"The government will definitely prioritize the interests of the Taiwan people in its dealings with China," he stressed.
From now on, co-prosperity and reconciliation will replace confrontation between the two sides, he said.
However, Fu added, it will take some time for Taiwan to benefit from the positive effects of the direct cross-strait links.

The MAC oversees the operations of the semi-official SEF, which is responsible for handling cross-strait contacts and negotiations through two-way dealings with the ARATS.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's status not belittled in pandas' delivery: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's sovereign status remains intact and was by no means belittled in the delivery of two giant pandas to Taiwan from China, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday in a statement.

The council, which coordinates and plans Taiwan's policy toward China, issued the statement after the Secretariat of the Convention of International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) said earlier this week that the transfer of pandas from China to Taiwan was in the category of internal/domestic trade and consequently need not be reported to the organization.
Noting that CITES is a United Nations-affiliated international organization, the MAC said that there is no way the transfer could alter the U.N.'s perception of Taiwan's political status.
As Taiwan is not a CITES signatory, it is not obligated to report to the CITES Secretariat its acceptance of the two pandas, the MAC said.
Nevertheless, it added that Taiwan has consistently followed the strict CITES provisions regarding imports of endangered animal and plant species, including the giant pandas.

In the process, the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs first issued an import permit for the pair of pandas offered by China as a gift of goodwill and friendship. With the import permit in hand, the Taipei City Zoo then applied to the relevant Chinese agencies for an export permit. China's endangered species export-import management office then issued export documents for customs declaration.
According to the MAC, the delivery of the pandas followed the mode of a country- to-country transfer. If it was an internal/domestic transfer, no customs declaration would be needed, the MAC added.

After a long wait, the pair of rare animals -- Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan -- finally arrived in Taiwan Tuesday to settle in Taipei Zoo in a further sign of rapidly warming ties between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
