DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan graded `above acceptable' for living environment: poll

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been rated as "above acceptable" with an average score of 67.9 out of a possible 100 for the overall international living environment by white-collar foreign workers living in the country, according to the results of a government survey released Tuesday.

Speaking in a press conference, Sung Yu-hsieh, deputy minister of the Cabinet- level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) , said the survey will help the government better understand foreigners' living experience in Taiwan and serve as a reference for the establishment and implementation of future policies and measures.

According to Lin Chi-fan, a professor from Shih Hsin University, which was commissioned by the RDEC to conduct the survey, Taiwan received the highest scores in the categories of friendly attitudes toward foreigners, which received 87 points, and social cohesion, with 82.2 points.
He noted that the scores serve as indicators that most Taiwanese treat foreigners living in the country well.

The scores were compiled on a five-rank system: very satisfactory, satisfactory, acceptable, dissatisfactory, and very dissatisfactory, Lin explained, adding that both of the highest figures cross the satisfactory level.

The other areas evaluated, listed in order of the highest scores to the lowest, are government performance, service facilities provided for foreigners, bilingual signage, bilingual websites and emergency assistance information, Lin went on.

In the area of government performance, the airport and customs garnered the highest score of 75.8, while foreign worker employment consultation received the lowest score of 63.8, barely passing the acceptable level, according to the survey.

Lin said that in terms of bilingual signage, most of the respondents complained about the lack of bilingual markings on product packaging, or the covering up of English labels on some imported items with Chinese labeling.
As for emergency assistance information, he said the low scores result from the lack of English communication abilities of the staff working in places such as police stations and fire departments.

Sung said that as part of the government's efforts to provide foreigners with easier access to its information, a Web site portal for the English versions of every government agency has been set up at english.www.gov.tw.

He advised foreigners to call 0800-024-111 -- a 24-hour hotline -- to assist them in solving problems including medical treatment, visas, housing, employment, taxation and insurance in Chinese, English and Japanese.

He said the international hotline service, which he described as the first of its kind in the country, has gained a good reputation among the foreigners who have used it, but he admitted that over 50 percent of the survey respondents were unaware that the service even exists.

Sung concluded that Taiwan overall provides a friendly environment for foreigners but still has a great deal of room for improvement, especially in terms of bilingual facilities and English communication abilities.
The survey, conducted Aug. 8-Sept. 16, received a total of 1,088 effective responses, with a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-speed rail free shuttle bus services to stop in April

TEXT.P: Free shuttle bus services at high-speed rail stations will be terminated at the end of March, and from April on, passengers on the high-speed rail will have to pay for the cost of the services, ranging from NT$27 (US$0.81) to NT$76.
The free shuttle bus services are offered by the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) based on the BOT contract until Jan. 31, 2009.

The Directorate General of Highways (DGH) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has asked the THSRC to prolong the services until March 31, after the Chinese New Year holiday -- one of the most important festivals in Taiwan, DGH officials said Tuesday.
After that time, the DGH will take over the shuttle bus operation, but will charge passengers. The scope of the service will also be enlarged from seven to 12 routes, the DGH officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: The wait is over - the pandas have finally arrived

TEXT.P: The long-anticipated arrival of a pair of giant pandas from China has finally come as Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, landed at Taoyuan International Airport aboard a EVA Airways charter flight and were whisked away by police motorcade to the Taipei City Zoo, their new home, Tuesday evening.
The pair of endangered animals arrived in Taoyuan International Airport at 5: 04 p.m. after a three-hour flight from Chengdu in Sichuan province, southwestern China.
Shortly after landing, the pandas were transported to the Taipei City Zoo in an air-conditioned vehicle, traffic-free, escorted by a police motorcade and jumping all red lights.
They settled into their new home at the zoo around 7:45 p.m.
With a month of quarantine ahead for Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, the new residents of Taipei City are expected to go on display on Jan. 25, just in time for the Chinese New Year holidays.
Yang Hsiao-tung, director of Taipei City's Department of Information and Tourism, told reporters that the pandas slept through almost the entire flight.
"The pandas behaved very well during the trip", said Yang, adding that their well-being was monitored by experts every minute of the way.

The pandas' arrival, however, is not without controversy. While supporters, including the government administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, see the pandas as a step towards easing tensions between China and Taiwan, opponents, including the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), criticized Taiwan's welcoming of the animals as buying into Beijing's ploy to win over the hearts and minds of Taiwanese people and eventually reunify with the island.
Since 1957, Beijing has used pandas as goodwill ambassadors, giving them to countries, such as the United States, with which it wants to form good relations.

In the case of Taiwan, Beijing is giving the pandas without charging fees, which it normally charges receiving countries. Not by accident, China gave the pandas names that mean "reunite" or "reunion" if said together in Chinese, symbolizing Beijing's hopes to eventually reunite with Taiwan, which has been ruled separately since the end of a bloody civil war in 1949.

Some opposition lawmakers have vowed to not only boycott the pandas, but not allow their family members to see them. Another was seen on TV suggesting that Taiwan give a pair of monkeys native to the island to China and name them "Tai Tai" and "Du Du" - which said together in Chinese means "Taiwan independence."

Regardless of how the Taiwanese public will see the pandas, Taipei's city government is hoping the animals will boost visitors at the zoo, with Mayor Hau Lung-bin saying recently that he expects six million visitors at the zoo a year as a result of the pandas.
The zoo has prepared an outdoor enclosure decorated with ferns and a footbridge, a sleeping area with all-season air conditioning and bamboo to welcome the two pandas.
Constructed with a NT$310 million sponsorship by the Shin Kong Group, the zoo's new display facility is considered by many experts as a three-storey, "six-star" mansion.
Taipei's zoo is pulling out all the stops to make the pandas feel at home and hopes the pair will eventually reproduce.

A storage room is set aside especially to deposit fresh bamboo -- which is the staple food for the pandas in their natural habitat. It is large enough to keep 560 kilograms of bamboo shoots to meet one week's demand by the animals. The room's temperature will be maintained between 4 to 7 degrees Celsius, and to satisfy the pandas' picky appetite, a water spray system was installed to keep the bamboos fresh.
Along with the two Chinese giant pandas, some 30 dove tree seedlings, China's rare plant species, were also given to Taiwan as a token of peace.

The exotic plants were allowed entry after testing negative to soil residues and infectious insects. The plants will be nurtured in a greenhouse at the Fushan Botanical Garden in northeastern Taiwan's Yilan County until they are mature enough to be transplanted, after which they will be moved to another location.
Chinese President Hu Jintao first offered the pandas to Taiwan as a gift of friendship in May 2005 when then-opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan made an ice-breaking visit to Beijing.

However, the gift was blocked by political bickering between Beijing and Taipei during Taiwan's time under the rule of the now-opposition DPP, which objected to China's treatment of the panda transfer as a "domestic transfer" between zoos because it implies that Taiwan is part of China.

As giant pandas are an endangered species subject to the protection of the Convention of International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITIES) , cross-border transfers of the animals must follow strict CITIES guidelines.

According to the guidelines, the two parties must supply export and import permits confirming that all conditions for the transfer have been met. This implies that the transaction is between two countries.

However, the issue was resolved under the governance of the administration of President Ma, which favors improving ties with China. Both sides decided to sidestep the issue of country name by agreeing to identify the importer as "Taiwan Taipei" and accepting "Chengdu" as the origin of export.

During a landmark visit to Taiwan in November by top Chinese negotiator on Taiwan affairs, Chen Yunlin, the two sides signed a formal agreement on exchanges of indigenous rare fauna and flora species to symbolize their amity and determination to cooperate in wildlife conservation.

The pandas' arrival are the latest steps by the two sides to improve relations. On Dec. 15, direct daily flights, direct shipping and direct postal links across the Taiwan Strait were launched and over the weekend, China's banks pledged to give US$19 billion in loans to Taiwanese businesses in China to help them cope with the economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 24, or the 27th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1491: Ignatius Loyola, Spanish founder of the Jesuit order, is born.
1524: Vasco da Gama, the Portuguese explorer who discovered the sea route to India around the Cape of Good Hope, dies.
1814: The War of 1812 between Britain and the United States ends with the signing of the Treaty of Ghent.
1851: Fire destroys part of the Capitol building in Washington, D.C., and the whole of the Library of Congress.
1905: Howard Hughes, American billionaire industrialist and film producer, is born.
1908: French President Armand Fallieres opens the first international aviation show in Paris.
1914: The first German bomb lands on British soil.
1919: Wealthy U.S. merchant John D. Rockefeller donates US$100 million for charitable use.
1921: Mahatma Gandhi is sworn in as chairman of India's Congress (I) Party, on a platform of non-cooperation.
1937: Japanese forces capture Hangchow in eastern China.
1943: President Roosevelt appoints Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as supreme commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force preparing for the invasion of France.
1945: Pope Pius XII promotes Republic of China Bishop Tien Keng-hsin of Chingtao to cardinal, making him the first cardinal in East Asia.
1951: Libya declares independence.
1967: Communist China conducts its seventh nuclear test, detonating a small device in northeastern China.
1976: Takeo Fukuda organizes a new Japanese Cabinet.
1978: Local movie and television actor Ku Ming-lun jumps to his death from the top of a building.
1983: The Taipei City Fine Arts Museum formally opens to the public.
1992: President George Bush pardons former U.S. Defense Secretary Casper Weinberger and five other Reagan aides involved in the Iran-Contra affair.
1993: Former ROC President Yen Chia-kan dies at the age of 90.
1999: Gen. Joao Batista Figueiredo, the Brazilian military ruler who ended 20 years of military government by restoring civilian rule in 1985, dies at the age of 81.
1999: Taipei's fifth rapid transit line -- the Pangnan Line -- is inaugurated, completing the foundation of the city's rapid transit network.
2000: About 5,000 Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan and 18 other countries and areas take part in a peaceful street march in Taipei to call world attention to mainland China's persecution of Falun Gong practitioners.
2000: Thai Rangsit University confers an honorary doctoral degree on former ROC Premier Vincent Siew in recognition of his contributions to promoting political democratization and economic liberalization in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in virtue and learning in order to profit from their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Opposition lawmakers seek 'Taiwanese' nicknames for Chinese pandas

TEXT.P: A group of opposition legislators invited the public Wednesday to think up some "Taiwanese" nicknames for the pair of giant pandas presented by China, which bear names the lawmakers contend are suggestive of Beijing's efforts to suppress Taiwan's sovereignty.
Submissions and voting for the new names are being accepted on the personal blog of Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Twu Shiing-jer, and results of the vote will be announced Dec. 31.
Among the names that have received the most support so far are "Chih-ming, Chun- chiao, " "one China, one Taiwan, and "Wang-yao, Wang-shih."
The pandas that arrived at the Taipei Zoo Tuesday are called Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, which together mean "reunion, " a term which implies the unification of Taiwan and China.

The group of lawmakers from the pro-independence DPP, including Twu, Kuan Bi- ling, Chen Ting-fei and Chen Chi-yu, noted that pandas are always a "political tool" of the Chinese communists and asked the public to be aware of what the animals' presence in Taiwan represented.

"The DPP isn't trying to make things difficult for these two pandas. But when Taiwan's people are visiting the pandas (at the zoo), they should not be ignorant of the hidden meaning behind them," Kuan said.

Kuan pointed out that the use of pandas by the Chinese communists as a tool to build rapport with other countries began as early as the late 1950s when a pair of pandas were given to the now-defunct Soviet Union.

Besides giving five pandas to North Korea in the 1960s, Beijing further presented the rare animals to the United States, Japan, France, the United Kingdom, Germany, Mexico and Spain between 1972 and 1978, she noted.

The export of pandas had been interrupted for more than 20 years when China gave a pair of the animals to Hong Kong in 1999 to celebrate the second anniversary of the handover of the former British colony to China.
Another pair of pandas were presented to Hong Kong in 2007 to mark the 10th anniversary of the handover, Kuan said.
Now, she claimed, the acceptance of the gift by the Kuomintang (KMT) administration is a prelude to Taiwan's unification with China and to the end of the Republic of China.
The two pandas were offered to Taiwan in 2005 after a visit to China by then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan.
The offer, however, was rejected by the Council of Agriculture (COA) under the then DPP administration on the grounds that Taiwan did not have adequate conditions to raise the animals.
The COA approved the Taipei Zoo's application to house the animals in August 2008, three months after the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou of the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien tourism festival hopes to lure foreign visitors

TEXT.P: The first Pacific International Tourism Festival, one of the largest tourism events to be held in Taiwan, hopes to attract visitors from around the globe to Hualien County instead of other popular Southeast Asian tourist spots, an event organizer said Wednesday.

Kuomintang Legislator Fu Kun-chi, who represents the eastern county and is helping organize the event, said Hualien's abundant natural beauty and the opportunity to witness the first sunrise of 2009 from the county's Pacific Ocean shores will be the festival's main selling points.

The event will target tourists from China, Europe and North America who plan to ring in the New Year in Asia, urging them to make Hualien their destination instead of Thailand or the Philippines, Fu said.

During the festival, slated to kick off Dec. 26 at the Meiluen Brewery and run until Jan. 4, 2009, 189 stalls will be set up on the two sides of the road leading to the brewery to improve the fortunes of local businesses, Fu added.
One of the festival's highlights will be its opening ceremony on Dec. 27, which will be jazzed up by a pop concert and a fireworks display and attended by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan.

Hakka music, indigenous dance and performances by local pop stars and international entertainers will also liven up the 10-day event. Visitors will also be able to enjoy light aircraft shows and military displays.
Several exhibitions will also be staged to showcase Taiwan's top 100 premium products, alternative energy products, weapons systems, motorbikes, works of art and indigenous handicrafts.

Fu said that at a time when Taiwan is reeling from the global economic downturn, tourism remains one sector that can still inject vitality into the country's economy, which is why the Cabinet decided to sponsor the 10-day festival by drawing on the resources of many government agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Zoo working to open panda house in one month's time

TEXT.P: The Taipei Zoo is working toward the goal of opening its new panda house to the public in a month's time, an official said Wednesday.

However, it remains uncertain if the public will be able to visit the panda house on Chinese New Year's Eve on Jan. 25 because the zoo is usually closed for the holiday, said zoo spokesman Chin Shih-chien.
A gift from China of a pair of giant pandas, named Tuan Tuan and Yuan Yuan, was delivered to the zoo Tuesday.
According to Taiwan's regulations, imported animals must remain in quarantine for a minimum period of 30 days, during which they will be observed for any infectious diseases or parasites.

Chin said that during that period, animal quarantine officials will examine the pandas every day, and the process is expected to be completed Jan. 23 once the animals are determined to be in good health.
Otherwise, the quarantine period could be extended, he said.

After being given quarantine clearance, the pandas will have to be immunized against canine distemper and rabies -- the two diseases most likely to infect pandas -- before they could be put on public display at the zoo, Chin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: People 'without a life' keep e-businesses healthy amid recession

TEXT.P: Individuals who stay at home hooked to their computers during their free time are often accused of not having a life, but they have played a major role in helping online businesses resist the global economic downturn.
These people -- derisively described as "home boys" or "home girls" -- may not socialize much but are doing their part to stimulate consumption during the tough economic times.
Though they live to save money by shopping on the Internet, they can be big spenders once they find products online that they like.

According to the results of an annual survey on Taiwan's digital divide released Dec. 19, nearly half of Taiwan's 13.71 million Internet users aged 12 and older are online shoppers, with the value of their total purchases totaling an estimated NT$85 billion (US$2.62 billion) over the past year based on survey results.
While this represents only about 1 percent of all consumption in Taiwan, it is an important niche that seems to be recession-proof.
"Home girls, " like Cindy, contribute heavily to this total. As soon as she gets off work, Cindy jumps on a bus to get home before rush hour.

Once at home, she immediately switches on her computer to access PTT, the biggest bulletin board system in Taiwan, because she needs to place her order for a pair of shoes together with other online shoppers before a 7 p.m. deadline.

"What else can be more important than this? " Cindy told the Central News Agency, explaining that by joining with others to order 30 pairs of shoes from one vendor, she can buy a pair she has long coveted for NT$1,500, 30 percent less than normal.

Cindy also often browses another mass order Web site called "ihergo, " meaning "I love group purchases, " because "one can find almost everything there, " including egg rolls made by inmates at Tainan Prison that she once bought.
Buying goods online, she says, is no different from going out and shopping at brick and mortar outlets, and it gives her the freedom to follow her own inclinations.
In order to make online shopping even more convenient, Cindy even bought a card reader so she can use an online ATM system to pay for her purchases.
In her early 20s and having just started a job, Cindy said she has been "living on the Internet" since college, and fully qualifies to be described as a "home girl."
Some 30 percent to 40 percent of her spending is done on the Internet, and many of her friends also live like this.
As every weekend approaches, she stocks up on supplies so that she can spend her off days at home, listening to music, watching movies and television series and shopping online.
Different from Cindy, who spends most of her income on clothing and accessories, "home boy" Eric, prefers buying high-end 3C products and bicycle parts online.
Their "shopping spirit, " so to speak, is on a par.
According to Eric, there are many online bicycle boutiques that not only serve the needs of amateurs but also professionals.

The owner of several mountain and foldable bicycles and skilled at modifying them, Eric told the CNA that one can find almost everything in online professional bicycle stores -- from parts such as stems, handlebars, pedals to accessories such as headlights, bike racks, bicycle pumps, and jerseys.

Eric says e-commerce is highly appealing because you can find detailed product descriptions, specify delivery location and time, return products during trial periods, and pay online without any problem.
"More importantly, online products are 'always' cheaper than brick and mortars," Eric said.
Like Cindy, Eric stocks up on food for the weekend at a supermarket so that he can spend even more time online looking for cheap deals.

In Taiwan, the number of people like Cindy and Eric, who satisfy their daily needs through e-commerce, is increasing. It is because of these "home girls" and "home boys" that the online purchasing market is growing vigorously despite a severe slump in overall retail sales.

Song Ju-ping, senior public relations manager of Yahoo! Kimo Online Shopping Mall, told the CNA that the e-commerce platform offers all kinds of discounts on a daily basis that effectively attract repeat business and boost revenues, even in a weak economy.

According to Song, the e-commerce market has grown steadily, citing as proof an underwear company that opened its Internet platform in mid-2008 and recorded online sales of NT$12 million in October, more than it had ever sold in a month at any retail outlet.

Yahoo! Kimo Shopping Mall itself set sales records of 2000 boxes of toilet paper in 28 minutes, over 4000 bottles of make-up removal oil in one hour, 200 laptops and 180 motorcycles in a day, all after the global financial tsunami swept Taiwan in October, Song said.

Song said the timeless nature of online shopping has been a key factor in expanding the business. For Yahoo! Kimo Shopping Mall, for instance, 9 p.m. to 2 a.m. is the peak sales period, with around 30 percent of sales occurring during this time slot.
"Compared to retail stores, one absolute advantage of online shopping is the flexibility of transaction time," she said.

Regardless of whether browsing an online auction or online shopping mall or placing a bid or an order, the development of online shopping has only entrenched the trend of "home boys" and "home girls" to stay at home, as well as changed the shopping behavior of an increasing number of consumers.
Despite the sluggish economy, many expect that with the e-commerce market growing more mature, its share of Taiwan's retail spending will only continue to expand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local universities offer free online courses for lifelong learning

TEXT.P: A group of local universities formed an alliance Wednesday to provide the public with free online access to some of their formal course materials in the hope that more people will make use of the country's higher education resources.

Speaking at the inaugural meeting of the Taiwan OpenCourseWare Consortium (TOCWC), Wu Chung-yu, president of the National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) , said the joint effort will help break space and time barriers to knowledge exchange and communication.
It will also create favorable conditions for lifelong learning as well as helping self-educators in their pursuit of learning, he went on.

According to Pai Chi-kaung, director-general of NCTU's Open Education Office, as most OCW programs available online are in foreign languages, the setup of Taiwan's own Web portal will enrich online Chinese educational resources.
Students in China curious about how university classes are taught in Taiwan can also gain an understanding via the online materials, she added.

Pai said that her school currently offers over 40 online courses in calculus, physics and chemistry, with outlines, handouts, assignments and exams for the courses all available on the Web site, "just like those you would get if you attended classes in person." She also noted that video clips are available for some of the courses.
The other 15 universities that have joined the association, she continued, are expected to offer a minimum of 10 courses over a two-year period from next semester in their own competitive fields.

Noting that the new service does not require registration, Pai added that as a general rule, no degrees or certifications are awarded and the courses are purely for people who are interested in the subjects and would like to educate themselves.

However, she said NCTU has made it an exception that if high school graduates who apply to enter the school can pass the September exam on the subject they have been self-learning when their freshman semester begins, they will be eligible to apply for advanced credit standing.

She also noted that TOCWC-allied schools have also agreed on the terms on which their published online materials can be extracted, revised and redistributed, so long as it is for non-commercial purposes and the author or reference is stated along with the works.

The OCW scheme, now viewed by more than 1 million visitors per month, was launched by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the United States in 2002, followed by Japan and Vietnam, according to Wu.
According to MIT statistics, as of the end of 2007, the Web site hit-rate of its database in Asia reached 21 percent, next only to 41 percent by North American users.
In addition, Taiwan was ranked third in the world in 2004 in terms of most Web hits on the MIT's OCW courses, Pai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan to have new international baseball stadium by end of 2009

TEXT.P: Construction of the Taoyuan International Baseball Stadium began Wednesday at a site near the Taiwan High Speed Rail's Taoyuan Station, with its completion scheduled for the end of 2009.
Taoyuan County Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu presided over the groundbreaking ceremony for the NT$836.3 million (US$25.31 million) project.

Chu said the stadium, built to meet international standards, will be the best baseball stadium in Taiwan, and that after its completion, Taoyuan County will be able to host national and international baseball tournaments.

Baseball is the most popular sport in Taiwan. In the northern county of Taoyuan alone, there are 106 amateur baseball teams. This is why the county government pushed for central government funding to build an international baseball stadium, according to Chu.
The stadium, to be built on a 9.7-hectare site, will have 12,000 infield seats, with room for future construction of outfield stands.

Adjacent to the stadium will be other sports facilities, including a practice field for baseball and softball, a soccer field, eight basketball courts, three tennis courts, two rollerblading rinks, a sports park for parents and their children, and bicycle trails.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Motion service' motorcade devoted to narrowing digital gap

TEXT.P: The Tainan county government has recently dispatched two vehicles on a countywide tour of remote areas to teach people living there how to use a computer, surf the Internet and build a personal blog.

The vans made their first stop in Baihe township Dec. 18, where they opened a services headquarters at the Chumen community center in a ceremony in which Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih invited residents to enjoy surfing the Internet with him.
Many grandparents showed up with their grandchildren, eager to take advantage of the free computer courses.

According to Su, one of the vehicles, dubbed a "motion service vehicle" is an old van owned by the county's department of social affairs into which a modern office equipped with computers, a broadcasting system and video and audio recording systems has been fitted.

The van, staffed with technicians and voluntary workers, was commissioned to conduct digital education in remote areas, along with the PunCar -- a van equipped with Internet technology and online communication devices.
The PunCar is operated by the non-profit Association of Digital Culture Taiwan to promote Internet applications in schools and local communities in an effort to narrow the urban-rural digital gap.
Su said the vans will continue to offer the digital teaching in more than 200 other communities around the county.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu Biomedical Science Park to be complete by 2013

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Biomedical Science Park will be fully operational by 2013, following a modification to the development strategy earlier this year, science park administration officials said Wednesday.

Randy Tzong-Ming Yen, director-general of the Hsinchu Science Park Administration, said that from now on, most of that area of the park will be devoted to a national medical center that focuses on clinical research and translational medicine.
Yen said he hopes the center will bridge the gap between clinical practice and biomedical research to boost Taiwan's biomedical industry.

The Hsinchu Biomedical Science Park, a section of the Hsinchu Science Park system, was planned by the Executive Yuan in 2003 and expected to be completed by 2009. However, the park's development strategy was changed from fostering a medical center to soliciting private companies by the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration.
The new Kuomintang administration, however, decided to return to the original plan and began the development of the medical center after it came to power in May.
Construction of the medical center will take at least four to five years, which means the park will not be fully operational until after 2013.
To date, the government has spent some NT$10 billion to acquire the land and build the facilities. The medical center will require an injection of up to NT$10 billion, according to Yen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's 1st regional foreign assistance center opens in Hsinchu

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first local government-run foreign assistance center was inaugurated Wednesday in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan, offering consultancy services to foreign visitors and residents.

At the inauguration ceremony, Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer expressed his gratitude to the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) , which offered financial and manpower support for the center.

He also thanked Hsinchu-based National Tsinghua University for allowing its students to serve as voluntary workers at the center to help foreigners acquire information about sightseeing travel, residency and investment, medical treatment and health care, traffic, cultural activities and education in Taiwan.

Lin said he hopes the new facility will become a model for other cities and counties, while RDEC Minister Jiang Yi-huah revealed at the opening ceremony that other cities and counties have indeed shown interest in establishing regional foreign assistance centers of their own.

Rowena Lines, principle of the Hsinchu Holland International School, praised Hsinchu as the most friendly city toward foreigners in Taiwan and she expressed her thanks for the mayor's efforts to build a bilingual living environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Negotiations with China must start from strong position: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday Taiwan will not negotiate with China in fear but must instead start such negotiations from a position of strength.

"We should not be lax in combat preparedness, and effective deterrence is our basic strategy. We want to stop war but will not be afraid of war, and we will prepare for war but refrain from provoking war, " Ma said while reviewing a live-fire military exercise in southern Taiwan.
It marked the first time that Ma was presiding over a live-fire training drill since his inauguration May 20.

At the suggestion of the military, Ma wore a bullet-proof vest and helmet for safety reasons. In 2006, an anti-tank missile malfunctioned and exploded on a beach just 200 meters away from an observation stand from which then-President Chen Shui-bian was reviewing the annual Hankuang training exercise.
A total of 1,686 officers and enlisted men were mobilized to take part in Wednesday's live-fire exercise, code-named Lienyung, at the Baolishan military base in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County.

The drill was designed to hone the joint defense capabilities of various branches of the military in the event of an invasion by an enemy force and to verify the effectiveness of joint forces combat command and coordination.

In the exercise, marines demonstrated their amphibious combat skills, traveling from one field to another to lend support in thwarting invading forces, with the assistance of naval, air and army airborne units.
AAV-7 amphibious assault vehicles, which are in active service in the U.S. military, made their debut in the land-based segment of the war games, carrying marines to beachhead landings.

The drill began with F-16 jet fighters scrambling to carry out a mock bombing mission and Jiyang-class frigates joining the attack later. OH-58D Kiowa reconnaissance helicopters and AH-IW attack helicopters from the Army Aviation and Special Force Command then launched a counterattack on presumed invading enemy forces.
Army artillery brigades also launched beach attack on invading mock enemies, which was followed by a mopping-up operations by the marines.
The small-scale Lienyung drill capped the military's live-fire training exercises for the year.
Ma said at the conclusion of the exercise that it embodied the results of the military's long-term training and combat preparedness.
The smooth operation of the exercise indicates that the military has not been slacking off in combat preparedness because of the recent improvement in relations across the Taiwan Strait, Ma said.
Even though a glimmer of hope has appeared on the horizon for cross-strait peace, Ma continued, the goal of building up an elite force to deter invasion remains valid and alive.

Unlike the often much-hyped large-scale military exercises staged under the previous administration, the Lienyung drill was pragmatic and practical, Ma said, adding that the drill will help the local people to understand that the military has continued to upgrade its combat tactics and strategies despite the warming of cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity founder denies embezzling donations

TEXT.P: The founder of a local charity dedicated to caring for people in a vegetative state denied Wednesday that he used donations to his organization to buy land for himself.

Cao Ching, founder of the Genesis Social Welfare Foundation, admitted that he did buy a lot of land in Miaoli County under his own name with foundation funds, but claimed he did so only to sidestep legal limitations.
According to Cao, the land consists of 19 plots, including one of two farm fields that according to the law cannot be sold to any legal entity such as his foundation.
In order to acquire the land for Genesis, Cao said he bought it and entrusted its ownership to his foundation, thereby stripping himself of the right to dispose of it.
He said he had explained this to the Next Weekly, a local tabloid, but could not stop it from publishing a story earlier that day accusing him of misappropriating the foundation's funds.
Cao said the Genesis Foundation owns about 200 buildings and four pieces of land around the island, with a combined market value of NT$2.4 billion (US$72.66 million.).

All of the real estate and buildings have been used by the foundation as nursing houses for people in a vegetative state or as service centers for street people and elderly people who live alone, he went on.
He said the foundation provides accommodation for 360 people in a vegetative state, using both its own properties as well as an additional 26 rented properties.
At the same time, it also provides home delivery and home care services for another 618 people in their own homes.

Among its annual outlay of about NT$1 billion, Cao went on, about NT$100 million comes from government grants with the rest coming from private donations, including NT$100 million from lottery prizes for uniform invoices collected from the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local governments banned from opening offices in China: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central government will not allow local authorities to open offices in China in the short term, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te- shun said Wednesday.

The central government will not permit individual city or county authorities to open offices on their own in China in the near future due to guidelines in its cross-Taiwan Strait policy and Taiwan's overall national interests, Liu stressed.

"There is no legal basis for this and the existing Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area prohibits local governments from doing so, " Liu told reporters.

In accordance with the stipulation of the statute's Article 33, individuals, institutional persons, groups or other organizations from Taiwan are banned from setting up "any form of cooperative ties" with administrative or political organizations of any Chinese district, Liu emphasized.
"This also includes opening or exchanging offices between similar groups of both sides," he pointed out.

Individual local governments must not handle their own affairs with China unilaterally, and negotiations on issues that might infringe upon the central government authorities must be settled by the MAC or the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , Liu said.

The MAC vice chairman's statement came at a time when some local city and county governments in Taiwan are reportedly planning to establish offices in China, in different ways and through different channels, to facilitate increased two-way exchanges.

For instance, Nantou and Yunlin counties in central Taiwan are planing to open offices in China or set up a mainland affairs department in the local government, respectively, in their bid to sell agricultural and farm produce to China and to court more Chinese tourists.

Through the network set up between local farmer associations on both sides of the strait, Nantou is working to set up a service center in Zhejiang Province where returning Chinese tourists can pick up items they buy in Taiwan instead of having to carrying them on board airplanes.

The agriculture-based Yunlin County is meanwhile eyeing the huge Chinese market for its fresh vegetables and fruits. Some 1,200 metric tons of Yunlin oranges purchased by China in early November at above local market price were delivered to China last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese pianist to give recital in Taipei

TEXT.P: World-renowned Chinese pianist Lang Lang will perform at the National Concert Hall in Taipei Dec. 26, organizers of the show announced Wednesday at a press conference.

Blending traditions from the West and the Far East through his music, the young piano maestro will delight piano-lovers all over Taiwan with his readings of the classical works of Schubert, Bartok and Chopin.
"Being so close to the holiday season, it is more like a late Christmas recital for me," 26-year-old Lang said.

Heralded as the "hottest artist on the classical music planet, " Lang has played sold-out recitals and concerts in every major city in the world and is the first Chinese pianist to be engaged by the Berlin Philharmonic, the Vienna Philharmonic and various top American orchestras.
Asked his opinion about being chosen by People Magazine as one of the top 10 sexiest men alive, he responded that he only feels sexy when he is playing the piano.
"The rhythm of the notes makes my blood pressure high, " said Lang.

In August 2008, over 2 billion people -- almost a third of the world's population -- watched Lang's performance at the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics, where he was seen as a symbol of the youth and future of China.

"I would like to spend my spare time doing charity work and convincing people that music can change the world, " Lang said, adding that he is serving as an international goodwill ambassador to the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF).

Meanwhile, to fulfill his commitment to society, the Lang Lang International Music Foundation was established in 2008 with the purpose of expanding young audiences and inspiring future generations of musicians through its outreach programs.

"Growing up in China, I am living proof that music can change the world, " said Lang, adding that "there are more than 40 million people learning piano in China today compared to zero a few decades ago."
Lang also serves on the Weill Music Institute Advisory Committee as part of Carnegie Hall's educational program and is the youngest member of Carnegie Hall's Artistic Advisory Board.

"I am very anxious to contribute to the development of classical music in the information era we are living in, " said Lang. "I want to share my experience with more young people through my participation in educational programs," he went on.

Despite his young age, Lang has performed for numerous international dignitaries, including former U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan, U.S. President George Bush, Britain's Queen Elizabeth II, Chinese President Hu Jintao and President Horst Koehler of Germany, as well as former Russian Prime Minister Vladmir Putin and French President Nicolas Sarkozy.

He began playing at the age of 3 and by the age of 5 had won the Shenyang competition and given his first public recital. Entering Beijing's Central Music Conservatory aged 9, he won first prize at the Tchaikovsky International Young Musicians Competition and played the complete 24 Chopin Etudes at the Beijing Concert Hall at age 13.

Lang's break into stardom came at 17, when he was called upon for a dramatic last-minute substitution at the "Gala of the Century, " playing the Tchaikovsky concerto with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.
He has recently been added as one of the 250 Young Global Leaders picked by the World Economic Forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. report on lawmakers' citizenship not final: KMT lawmaker

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Ching-an, who is alleged to be an American citizen, said Wednesday that the report of Washington's probe on Taiwan lawmakers' U.S. citizenship is not final, but the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said the report confirmed that Lee has dual nationalities.

Lee said in a news conference that the U.S. State Department is still investigating whether she holds U.S. citizenship and that the report from the American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT) Washington office is not the final result of the investigation.

She said even though her name was mentioned in the report, the report also said that the U.S. government's review of whether Taiwanese lawmakers hold U.S. citizenship is based on the records of the U.S. State Department, which may not have the most up to date status of one's citizenship, meaning the report should not be viewed as giving the final word on the issue.
"People should not quote the report out of context and should let the Legislative Yuan handle the case when the final result comes out," Lee said.

Earlier this year, Lee became the focus of attention in a controversy about lawmakers having foreign citizenship after a local tabloid magazine revealed that she allegedly possesses a U.S. passport. However, Lee repeatedly argued that she had lost her U.S. citizenship after she was sworn in as a Taipei city councilor in 1994.
According to Taiwan's relevant stipulations, any lawmaker, if found to possess foreign nationality, will be stripped of his or her duties at the Legislative Yuan.

Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) was commissioned by the legislature to facilitate the probe on the citizenship status of Taiwan's legislators, but was criticized by the DPP for not publicizing the results.

The Legislative Yuan decided Tuesday to classify the AIT's report as confidential and give it to individual legislators. The legislature's plenary session will determine later how to deal with the report.

After reviewing the report, DPP caucus whip Lai Ching-te said earlier Wednesday in a news conference that according to the U.S. State Department, Lee still holds a valid U.S. passport and therefore indeed possesses American citizenship.

He urged Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to immediately strip Lee of her legislative position, and retrieve all salary she has gained since she was elected as a public servant and subject her to criminal liability.
Lai also singled out another KMT legislator Lee Ming-hsing, who failed to renounce his foreign citizenship before his swearing-in in February, asking Wang to revoke his position as well.

Considering the DPP caucus reported Lee's case to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office in March and that Lee has been under investigation, the prosecutor's office said Wednesday that it had requested the MOFA to provide a related report from Washington and will clarify whether Lee violated any law after reviewing it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Greenhouse gas reduction bill stalled in legislative committee

TEXT.P: Legislators in the Health, Environment and Labor Committee failed to reach consensus Wednesday in their review of a greenhouse gas reduction bill, which if passed, would represent a milestone in Taiwan's environmental protection efforts.
The legislators disagreed on several clauses in the bill, including those on carbon trade mechanisms and carbon emissions reduction targets.
The committee will continue its review of the draft bill Thursday.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tien Chiu-chen said at the meeting that the legislation requires a "carrot and stick "approach that would include provisions for carbon trading as well as greenhouse gas reduction targets.
In the Executive Yuan's version of the bill, however, carbon emission targets are not stipulated.

Legislator Huang Sue-ying, also of the DPP, suggested that an emission reduction schedule should be included in the bill. She presented her own version of the draft bill, in which short-, mid- and long-term targets are set to reduce Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions to 2000 levels by 2050.

In response, Shen Shu-hung, minister of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), said that his agency does not favor putting an emissions reduction schedule into the act, as the government has already made promises regarding greenhouse gas reduction and that some flexibility will be required in future international negotiations.

"Even if we put the targets into the act, they would only be declarative and there would be no penalties for violations, " said the Cabinet-level EPA head. The targets set in the government's version of the bill are tighter than those in Huang's version, he added.

President Ma Ying-jeou has vowed to hold Taiwan's total greenhouse gas emissions at 2008 levels from 2016 to 2020, reduce the emissions to 2000 levels by 2025, and halve them from 2000 levels by 2050. The targets are also noted in the Sustainable Energy Policy Guidelines approved by the Cabinet in June.

Environmentalists protesting outside the Legislative Yuan Wednesday backed the opinions of the opposition legislators, calling the bill a "blank cartridge" in terms of emissions reduction and urging that the carbon trading proposal be minutely detailed in the act to prevent big businesses from using the mechanism as a profit-making tool.
Some legislators have expressed worries that carbon trading would allow some companies to produce high levels of emissions in Taiwan while planting trees abroad to obtain carbon credits.
Pan Han-shen, secretary-general of the Green Party Taiwan, criticized the draft bill proposed by the Cabinet as lacking emission reduction targets and ineffective in terms of emissions control.

Noting that carbon dioxide emission is a global problem, Shen said that a carbon offset program should be given priority in Taiwan and that carbon trading is a vital part of a solution that would favor both the environment and the economy.
The bill was drafted by the EPA in 2006 to establish a domestic legal framework to manage greenhouse gas emissions in Taiwan.
Legislators began to review the draft in committee in April this year but failed to agree on a number of clauses.

If approved, the new act is expected provide the legal framework for the establishment of a system to control greenhouse gas emissions and for trade in carbon credits to help attain the government's emission reduction targets.

In 2007, The EPA set up a national greenhouse gas registry to allow enterprises to voluntarily report their emission inventories, in a bid to encourage voluntary emission reduction among private companies.
According to the EPA, 136 enterprises have registered their greenhouse gas emission data to date.

According to Shen, greenhouse gas emissions in Taiwan totalled 280 million tons in 2007, a decrease of 3 million tons from 2006. He forecast that the decrease this year would be even bigger, considering the government's carbon-reduction and energy-saving policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Broadway classic debuts in Taipei with Taiwanese flavors

TEXT.P: A Broadway classicSmokey Joes Cafe blended with Taiwanese flavors will make its debut in Taipei in mid-January next year, with an American veteran director employing Taiwanese performers as the entire cast for the revue.

Director Brook Hall, who has participated in over 20 celebrated Broadway shows, told a press conference Tuesday that he hopes to introduce a new style of musical theatersthat the local audience has not seen before in other plays such as "Chicago, " "Lion King" or "Cats."

Apart from the diverse music styles including the blues, R&B, rock and roll and even gospel, Hall said that he has added roles, romantic twists as well as a story line to the revue, the ideas of which are adopted from a dozen other shows and revolve around the concept ofsearching.

He named the songKansas Cityas an example, saying it is about going to another place and finding your dreams, while another pieceCause I am a Woman, written at the time when women were identifying with their other potential roles besides housewives in the 1960s, demonstrates womens will to achieve the same accomplishments as men while still remaining beautiful.
Meanwhile, Hall said that from the choreography to the cast, he has also chosen to put in some Taiwanese characteristics to his work.
He described the 13 performing Taiwanese crew asvery talented, stressing that they arejust as good as many people I have seen in New York.
The whole show will be in English, he added.

Chien Chao-lun, who will be playing the character Victor in the show, said that some of the dance steps will be first seen in Taiwan, while adding that every song has a particular meaning to correspond with the sectional theme.
The show will be held at the National Taiwan Arts Education Center from Jan. 16-18, with Chinese subtitles provided.

"Smokey Joes Cafe, " which was nominated for seven Tony Awards and won a Grammy Award in 1995, is the longest running musical revue in Broadway history, showcasing rock and roll and R&B songs such as Stand by Me,Jailhouse Rock,Love Potion No. 9,and many more, according to the organizer Infine Art and Culture Exchange.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawyer accuses court judge of dereliction of duty

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) filed a plea with the Control Yuan -- Taiwan's highest watchdog body -- Wednesday, accusing a court judge of dereliction of duty and urging members of the Control Yuan to institute an investigation into the judge's conduct.

Legislator Chiu Yi, who has earned fame for exposing corruption in the past, said in the plea that Chou Chan-chun, a Taipei District Court judge, "misused his judicial power" by freeing former President Chen Shui-bian on his own recognizance, even though the charges against Chen -- a chief defendant in four corruption and money laundering cases -- could carry a 30-year prison sentence.

Chiu pointed out that from 2006 to 2008, Chou has handled 37 cases in which the defendants requested bail. "Chou Chan-chun has only allowed two defendants to be released on bail, and there is no record showing that he has ever released anyone without bail," Chiu said.
Chiu said the decision to free the former president without bail was "inconsistent" with the judge's previous rulings.
Furthermore, Chiu added, Chou is known to have canvassed for Chen in the lead-up to the 2000 and 2004 presidential elections and was a member of an association in support of Chen for president.

According to Chiu, Chou is also known to have said on private occasions that if he had been the presiding judge in the trial of the case involving President Ma Ying-jeou's use of his special allowance during his tenure as Taipei mayor, he would have sentenced Ma to 10 years in prison without even bothering to look at the written indictment.
In a ruling in April, the Taiwan High Court found Ma not guilty of misusing his special allowance during his two four-year terms as Taipei mayor.

Chiu concluded in his plea that Chou has apparently exceeded his limits as a judge, and that based on Article 18 of the Criminal Procedure Law, Chou's "bias" in executing his duty has made it necessary that he be removed from the panel of judges trying the corruption and money laundering cases in which the former president and three members of his family are defendants.
Chen, his wife, son and daughter-in-law have been indicted on charges of embezzlement, bribe-taking and money laundering.

According to the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutor's Office, Chen and his wife embezzled NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They also took bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.
Prosecutors have recommended that the former president be given the harshest possible sentence for his alleged crimes involving nearly half a billion new Taiwan dollars.

They also demanded severe penalties for his wife, son and daughter-in-law in light of their "unrepentant attitude" in the course of the investigations, and recommended commuted sentences for 10 other defendants whom prosecutors said had been cooperative and helpful in the process of the investigations.

Chou, the presiding judge, and two other justices on his panel ruled on Dec. 13 that Chen should be freed on his own recognizance after being detained for 32 days while the prosecutors prepared their cases against him.

However, the prosecutors appealed in the Taiwan High Court against Chen's release. The high court sent the case back to the Taipei District Court for reconsideration, but in a ruling on Dec. 18, Chou and the two other judges on the panel upheld their previous decision, although they added a warning that Chen should not intimidate or collude with the other defendants and witnesses in the four cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's localities seeking to increase presence in China

TEXT.P: Despite a ban on local governments opening representative offices in China, local authorities are studying feasible ways to handle growing exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

On Wednesday, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said that the central government will not permit local governments to open offices in China at the present time, due to Taiwan's cross-Taiwan Strait policy, which forbids such a practice, and considerations about overall national interests.

According to Article 33 of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, Taiwanese individuals, groups or other organizations are banned from setting up "any form of cooperative ties" with administrative or political organizations of any Chinese district, Liu said.

Individual local governments must not handle their own affairs with China unilaterally, and negotiations on issues that might infringe upon the central government's authority must be settled by the MAC or the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , Liu said.

Nonetheless, local governments are seeking to establish a presence in China through different approaches, such as through farmers' associations or by forming special task forces to deal with increased two-way activities.

For instance, Taiwan's offshore Kinmen County, which has maintained direct ferry services with the ports of Xiamen and Mawei in China's Fujian province since 2001 and with Quanzhou in Fujian a few years later, has already created a mainland affairs section under its transportation and tourism bureau in 2004.
Kinmen authorities are hoping to open an office in Xiamen, which lies opposite Kinmen across the Taiwan Strait, to deal with frequent exchanges between the two sides.

Relations between Taiwan and China have significantly improved after President Ma Ying-jeou came to power in May. He sees improving ties with China as a key to breathing life into Taiwan's economy and easing tensions between the two sides.
Many local governments, while initially wary of being bombarded by an influx of Chinese imports, are now seizing the opportunity to boost trade and tourism with China.

In central Taiwan, Nantou County is seeking to establish offices in China through local farmers' associations, with coastal China's Zhejiang Province being its first target, Nantou County Deputy Magistrate Chen Chih-ching said.

Two years ago, Nantou and Zhejiang began negotiating setting up sisterhood ties between Sun Moon Lake in Nantou and West Lake in Hangzhou. Authorities from both sides are slated to jointly sponsor a "twin lakes" forum in February or March in Taiwan to pave the way for clinching the sisterhood agreement, Chen said.

Meanwhile, the Chungtai Buddhist Temple in Taiwan's Puli township -- the largest of its kind in Southeast Asia -- is also a major attraction in Nantou and a must-see spot for Chinese tourists thanks to its sisterhood ties with Linying Temple in Hangzhou.

Currently, Nantou-Zhejiang exchanges mainly focus on agriculture, tourism and religion, Chen said. Through trade fairs in Zhejiang, Nantou County has sold agricultural products worth US$7 million this year, and has signed a contract worth NT$50 million (US$1.55 million), Chen said.

Encouraged by the prospects for potential business opportunities between the two sides, a Zhejiang delegation has visited Nantou County recently, and the two sides are considering signing accords on agricultural cooperation, he said.
Nantou County hopes to open an office in Zhejiang that will serve as a pickup center of speciality items purchased by Chinese visitors in Nantou.

Once such a facility is set up in Zhejiang, Chinese tourists from the province can have their items on hand as soon as they return home, without having to take them onboard airplanes - a measure which Chen said would be helpful to attracting more Zhejiang tourists to Nantou.

Nantou authorities hope to open such a service center in Zhejiang through the network maintained between farmers associations on both sides. Meanwhile in northern Taiwan, Taoyuan County has also already set up a unit in February 2007 to deal with foreign affairs, including those relating to China.
Agriculture-based Yunlin County in central-southern Taiwan is assessing the possibility of setting up a mainland affairs bureau to help promote sales of its agricultural goods to China.

In southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, China affairs are handled by the city's economic affairs bureau, while neighboring Kaohsiung County is planning to create a section in its civil affairs bureau aimed at handling foreign affairs, including those concerning China.

Taiwan's Hualien, Miaoli, Chiayi and Pingtung counties, although not projecting to set up a permanent unit for that purpose at present, said that they will consider doing so in the future, if cross-strait exchanges further increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: American priest granted honorary citizenship of Nantou County

TEXT.P: A 74-year-old American Catholic priest, Robert Crawford, was granted honorary citizenship of Nantou County Wednesday, in recognition of his decades of work to provide care and services for mentally and physically challenged people in the central county.

Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chao-ching presented the honorary citizenship certificate to Crawford at the county hall, citing the priest's devotion to equipping disabled young people with basic living skills.
Crawford first came to Taiwan in 1961 as a missionary, and since then has been devoting his efforts to social welfare work on the island.

In 1988, Crawford joined efforts to establish an educational center in Changhua County, central Taiwan for people with mental disabilities, and in 1992 founded a similar facility in Puli township, Nantou County.

In 2004, the priest established a training center for persons with multiple disabilities at the Holy Rosary Church in Nantou's Chushan township. He started a day care service, basic living skills training and home education for mentally and physically challenged youth over the age of 15.

Crawford, also known by the Chinese name Yu Jen-teh, said his efforts to establish and operate educational facilities for people with mental disabilities was inspired by his own brother who suffers from Down Syndrome.

As special education programs in Taiwan cater mainly to teenagers and children, Crawford said, he founded the Rosary training center to help those who are older but cannot manage their daily routines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan respects its citizens' rights, freedoms: MOFA

TEXT.P: Responding to the concerns expressed by some members of the U.S Congress over the human rights trend in Taiwan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday that Taiwan has always respected the rights and freedoms of its citizens, and in no way violated their human rights during a recent visit by a Chinese official.

The statement by MOFA spokesman Henry Chen was made in response to a letter sent to U.S. President George W. Bush Tuesday by 14 members of the U.S. Congress, asking him to keep a watchful eye on the current human rights situation in Taiwan.

The U.S congressmen also urged Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou to respect the people's rights and freedom, adding that in accordance with Article II of the Taiwan Relations Act, the United States aims to preserve and improve the human rights condition of all Taiwanese people.

In their letter to Bush, the members of Congress mentioned the violent clashes in early November between the police and pro-independence protesters who were demonstrating over a visit to Taipei by China's top cross-strait negotiator Chen Yunlin.

The letter stated that President Ma's administration limited the freedom of its citizens when the police violently arrested protesters who brandished the Republic of China's national flag, and when people who were wearing anti-China or pro-independence clothing were detained. The U.S government should therefore monitor the current situation in Taiwan, it suggested.
"We will look into the matter," said Henry Chen, adding that the government had a responsibility to protect the visiting Chinese delegation against any kind of violence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alternative route may replace planned Suao-Hualien freeway

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Wednesday that his ministry was considering using an alternative mountain route to replace the planned and controversial Suao-Hualien freeway, which environmentalists have opposed.

Mao told reporters at a weekly briefing held by the Cabinet that the original plan to build a Suao-Hualien freeway has been suspended, and that another plan is being considered to build an expressway along the mountains on Taiwan's east coast between Suao in Yilan County and Chongde in Hualien County.
He said the new plan is expected to be completed in the second half of 2009 before the new mountain route is subjected to an evaluation on its possible effects on local environments.
Mao added that he had no idea yet about the price tag of the alternative route, but added that the funding will come from the budget of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

He also said that the government plans to turn eastern Taiwan into a "paradise for cyclists" in two to three years, with plans to build bike trails, set up rental shops, and provide repair services, so that it will become more convenient for people to observe the beautiful sceneries along Taiwan's eastern corridor.

The original 86-kilometer four-lane Suao-Hualien freeway project, mapped out in 1994, was approved by the Cabinet in 1998. The proposed freeway, with 40 km of tunnels and 37 km of bridges, would be part of a planned 259-km freeway linking Suao to Taitung in southeastern Taiwan.
Construction was to begin in 2003 and be completed in eight years at a cost of NT$93 billion, but was halted because of strong opposition from some local groups who voiced environmental concerns.
Supporters for the project have contended that mountainous Hualien County, which is relatively underdeveloped compared with counties to its west, needs a freeway to stimulate the local economy.
Opponents, however, argued that the freeway would ruin the beauty and ecological environment of one of the most scenic parts of Taiwan.

The debate over whether to build the freeway has continued, with both the central and local governments unable to resolve the issue. Environmental activists continued their opposition although project planners tried to allay their concerns by changing the route of the freeway to minimize the impact on the local ecology.

Hualien County is linked to Suao by an 87-km provincial highway expanded in the 1980s. The highway is often blocked by landslides during the typhoon and rainy seasons. The county is also served by a railway between Hualien and Taipei, but passengers often complain that tickets are hard to get.

DOC.HEADLINE: Blood donation drive launched

TEXT.P: A blood donation drive was launched Wednesday around the country, with a cycling event held in Taipei City a day earlier to help promote the one-month campaign, Taiwan Blood Services Foundation Chairman Kuo-Sin Lin said that day.
According to Lin, the cycling event was aimed at persuading the public to donate blood, as people are unwilling to go out and give blood in cold weather.
The campaign is being organized by six blood donation centers in northern Taiwan's Taipei and Hsinchu, central Taiwan's Taichung, southern Taiwan's Tainan and Kaohsiung and eastern Taiwan's Hualien.
Lin suggested that would-be donors should take good care of their health, as only healthy donors are allowed to donate.

According to the foundation's statistics, 1,099,942 people have donated blood to date this year, with students making up the lion's share of 22.69 percent, followed by people from the industrial sector, accounting for 19 percent.
Held as part of the cycling event was a ceremony in which 10 people were presented with prizes for designing slogans aimed at exhorting the public to donate blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Investigation Bureau chief released on NT$5 million bail

TEXT.P: The former director-general of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB), Yeh Sheng-mao, who has been sentenced to 10 years in prison for withholding information about ex-President Chen Shui-bian's alleged involvement in money laundering, was released on NT$5 million (US$151,515) bail Wednesday.
The Taiwan High Court granted Yeh bail after holding its first hearing on Yeh's appeal against the Taipei District Court's harsh prison sentence for him.

Reasons on why the court decided to grant Yeh bail was not immediately revealed. Yeh's lawyer told reporters that Yeh's continued detention after being sentenced in the trial of first instance would have violated the due process of law, as Yeh was appealing the ruling.
Despite his release, Yeh is required to report any change in his residence and is barred from leaving the country.
Yeh was indicted Aug. 28 for concealing and not investigating information on overseas bank accounts allegedly held by the ex-president's family members in the Caymen Islands in the Caribbean.
The information was provided to the Investigation Bureau by international anti- money laundering association Egmont Group on Jan. 28, but went missing after being submitted to Yeh.

At the third hearing in his trial, the district court ordered Yeh's detention on the grounds that Yeh, by passing the information to Chen, might have "unduly profited others, " a felony which gave the court the power to detain potential offenders at its discretion.
The district court did not grant Yeh bail even after handing down its sentence on Dec. 4 in view of the severity of the offenses with which Yeh was charged.
The court found Yeh guilty of corruption, concealing a government file and of leaking confidential information, for which he was given a prison sentence of eight and a half years.
In the second case, Yeh was also convicted of leaking confidential information, for which he was sentenced to two and a half years in prison.
The two sentences combine into a jail term of 10 years, the verdict stated.

At the center of the money-laundering case was a report delivered to the MJIB in January by the international anti-money laundering organization Egmont Group, in which the Cayman Islands' financial intelligence unit raised the suspicion that the former first family was laundering money through an account created under the name of Chen's daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching at the Merrill Lynch Bank in Geneva, Switzerland.

Based on the report, the bureau's Anti-Money Laundering Center on Jan. 29 compiled a file intended for delivery to the Supreme Prosecutors Office. Yeh later requested that the file be handed over to him, saying that he would pass it to State Public Prosecutor General Chen Tsung-ming in person.

However, instead of giving the file to Chen Tsung-ming, Yeh leaked its contents to Chen Shui-bian during a visit to the former president's official residence between Jan. 31 and Feb. 1, according to the court's findings.
The district court said in its verdict that Yeh's actions had undermined the independence of Taiwan's justice institutions and caused "immeasurable damage" to the country's image.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors to appeal ex-president's release Thursday

TEXT.P: Prosecutors are ready to again appeal the Taipei District Court's decision to release former President Chen Shui-bian on his own recognizance, Supreme Prosecutors Office (SPO) sources said Wednesday.

Prosecutors with the SPO's Special Investigation Division (SID) have finalized preparations of all documents needed for the appeal, the sources said, adding that barring unexpected developments, the appeal will be filed Thursday afternoon at the earliest.

According to the sources, the SID team handling the corruption and money laundering case against the ex-president will ask the Taiwan High Court to hand down a ruling on its request to have Chen detained again instead of sending the case back to the district court for a new hearing as it did in the past.
On Dec. 18, the Taipei District Court rejected prosecutors appeal and upheld its earlier decision to free Chen without bail.

In its Dec.13 ruling, the court ordered that Chen, who was detained Nov. 12, be released without bail following his indictment, along with 13 other people, on charges of embezzlement, corruption and money laundering.
Chen and his wife are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.
