DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't preparing to launch project to bolster Taiwan's exports

TEXT.P: The administration will soon put forth a new project to help bolster Taiwan's exports in the face of the global economic downturn, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday.

Under the new "Zheng He" project -- named after a Ming Dynasty Chinese explorer -- the administration will assist Taiwan's suppliers and manufacturers to churn out more goods for exports, with the country's entire export trade being targeted to turn from negative to positive growth, to top NT$500 billion (US$15.15 billion) in 2009, Liu said during a regular Executive Yuan meeting.

"It is hoped that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) makes concerted efforts under the banner of the new 'Zheng He' project to help Taiwanese companies as a whole reach the target of receiving export orders worth over NT$540 billion for 2009," Liu said.
Mainland China and markets in emerging economies will be the main targets of the "Zheng He" project, Liu added.

Under the project, the government will invest NT$5.58 billion between 2009 and 2010 to improve Taiwan's environment for the export trade, including increasing loans to exporters and providing export insurance, according to Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade.
As part of the project, the MOEA will allocate NT$1 billion between 2009 and 2010 to help Taiwanese companies to increase exports of foodstuffs and processed food products to China, Huang said.

Huang added that the MOEA will also spend NT$1.8 billion between early 2009 and 2012 to assist Taiwanese companies to crack the markets of India, Russia, Brazil, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia and countries in the Middle East.

Zheng He was a ranking official of the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) , who led a giant fleet of Chinese junk ships to Southeast Asia, from where the Ming vessels are believed to have reached the west coast of Africa. He was instrumental in building China into one of the maritime super powers in the world between the 14th and 17th centuries.

Also on Thursday, Premier Liu urged relevant Cabinet agencies to be nimble in carrying out the economic stimulus programs that the administration has laid out in order to create more jobs to tackle Taiwan's rising unemployment problem.
Taiwan had 507,000 jobless people in November, representing an unemployment rate of 4.62 percent, with 202,000 of them having lost their jobs through downsizing or company closures.
The 4.62 percent jobless rate was a six-year high for the month, according to the Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

At the meeting Thursday, the premier said that Taiwan's recent accession to the World Trade Organization's (WTO's) Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) will help create huge and numerous trade opportunities for Taiwanese companies as the accession gives Taiwanese companies open access to public contracts in the 40 other economies which have signed the GPA, including the United States, Japan and the European Union.
The WTO Committee on Government Procurement formally approved on Dec. 9 the accession of Taiwan to the GPA -- under the name of Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu.

The accession, however, will need formal approval by the Legislative Yuan to make the WTO initiative legally effective, Liu said, adding that relevant Cabinet agencies should waste no time to increase communications with legislators so as to facilitate the formal accession.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20 percent of companies not offering year-end bonuses: poll

TEXT.P: A record high of nearly 20 percent of Taiwan companies will not be paying year- end bonuses to their workers this year, and those that plan to do so will offer an average 1.08 months' salary, according to the results of an online survey released Thursday.
The 1.08-month bonus offer is a drop of 0.53 months from the 2007 average, according to the results of the survey conducted by the 104 job bank.

The companies that will not offer year-end bonuses this year are mostly businesses in the mass communications, transportation and warehousing, construction and real-estate, tourism and leisure, and service sectors, the survey found. Close to 30 percent of the firms in each of these sectors will not pay any year-end bonuses to their employees this year.

Among those enterprises that plan to give year-end bonuses to their workers, the financial insurance sector is offering the biggest pay of 1.93 months' salary on average, despite the economic slump, the survey indicated. However, even in that sector the year-end bonus payment will be lower compared to last year's 2.6-month average.
The hi-tech sector, though seriously hurt by the financial crisis, will pay bonuses of 1.15 months' salary on average -- the second-highest among all sectors, the survey found.

In third place is the construction and real-estate sector, which will offer an average of 1.11 months' salary to its workers, followed by the retail sector with bonuses of 1.05 months and the manufacturing sector with 1.04 months' pay.
Apart from paying year-end bonuses, it is also customary for companies in Taiwan to hold a lavish banquet for their workers at the end of the year.
However, while some 48 percent of the enterprises polled said they will maintain the tradition, 21.4 percent indicated that they will not be doing so.
About 24 percent said they will hold lucky draws and give cash gifts at the parties for their workers.

Meanwhile, 40 percent of Taiwan businesses have decided not to increase wages in the coming year, while around 8.8 percent said they are planning salary cuts for "some workers," according to the survey.
About 6 percent said they will cut salaries to all their employees in 2009 -- up by 5.1 percentage points over the 2008 level.

Most of the firms said they will slash salaries by some 10 percent, while 28.1 percent said the cut will be between 6 percent and 10 percent, and 41.3 percent of the companies said it will be lower than 5 percent.
Only 3.7 percent of the companies said they will increase the salaries of all of their staff members, down by 15 percentage points from last year, according to the survey.
Around 49 percent of the businesses said they will adjust their workers' salaries "depending on their performance."

Some 31 percent said they will cut salaries based on the workers' positions -- meaning that middle and high ranking personnel should be braced for pay reductions next year, as the companies battle with operation difficulties in an economic recession.

With profits shrinking as a result of the economic crisis, 65.5 percent of the businesses said they thought their workers' morale has been affected, with 25 percent of the firms offering guarantees to protect their staffs' work rights, the survey found.

DOC.HEADLINE: Telecom Technology Center accredited to test cryptographic modules

TEXT.P: The government-founded Telecom Technology Center (TTC) said Thursday it has been authorized by the U.S. National Voluntary Laboratory Accreditation Program (NVLAP) to conduct cryptographic module validation in Taiwan.

Officials of the Kaohsiung-based center explained that after receiving the accreditation, the center's InfoCom Security Testing Laboratory will be able to validate all cryptographic modules before they are exported to the United States, reducing the time and cost of having them tested in the States.

A cryptographic module is a security device that controls access to sensitive data, secured service, or restricted areas. Common products include the digital signature recognition module for e- commerce or online banking service, and the fingerprint reader for household and office access monitoring.
Officials said that TTC is the first institute in Taiwan and in Asia to be accredited by NVLAP, a laboratory accreditation program run by the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology.
Once a product is verified by the center, they said, it will automatically be approved by the Federal Information Processing Standard 140-2 (FIPS 140-2), allowing its sale in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet eases restrictions on China visits by senior officials

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Cabinet revised regulations governing China visits by government employees Thursday, greatly relaxing travel restrictions on high-ranking officials.
Also amended were regulations concerning Taiwan visits by Chinese professionals to ease the restrictions for Chinese government officials.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said the liberalization policy will facilitate the exchanges between the two sides and help Taiwan's civil servants gain an in- depth understanding of the situation in China, thus contributing positively to establishing healthy relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Liu pledged that the government will make sure not to undermine Taiwan's security when promoting the policy.
The revised regulations will take effect on the date of their proclamation by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

They will allow police officers at rank 3 or higher and career civil servants at grade 11 or higher who have no access to state secrets to visit China for any purposes, including official business and pleasure, after obtaining permission from a screening committee under the MOI, said Deputy Minister of the Interior Lin Join-sane.

For political appointees, local government chiefs and ordinary civil servants with access to state secrets, they can visit China for any purpose other than pleasure, after obtaining permission from the MOI's screening committee, Lin said.

Political appointees are currently only allowed to visit China for international conferences or activities, and local government chiefs can only do so to take part in conferences related to their work.

Meanwhile, Lin said, the China travel ban on officials engaging in "special services with access to state secrets" will remain to uphold national security and interests, meaning that they are strictly forbidden from visiting China unless given special permission.

These officials include personnel posted overseas, personnel engaging in the research and development of defense or secret technologies, as well as staff of the National Security Bureau, the Ministry of National Defense and the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau.

For civil servants at grade 10 or lower, they will be able to visit China after gaining the approval of the agencies they serve and will no longer be required to apply for permission with the MOI, Lin said.

On visits to Taiwan by Chinese officials, the revised regulations will allow them to come to Taiwan for exchange activities at the invitation of a local authority, a central government agency or the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, Lin said.
Chinese officials are currently permitted to visit Taiwan only in a private capacity and if they are invited by a school or civil organization in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign aid to be transparent, professional, sustainable: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that the principles of transparency and professionalism, along with the global goal of sustainable development, will be the pillars of its foreign aid policy, which will be laid out in a white paper to be released in January.

Shih Wen-bin, director-general of the MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, said at a press briefing that transparency and professionalism are pivotal to enhancing the effectiveness of Taiwan's overseas aid.

The ministry has therefore slashed its annual budget for secret diplomacy to NT$3.8 billion (US$115.15 million) for next year, down by NT$2 billion from the previous fiscal year, he said. This decision is also in line with the Legislative Yuan's request to gradually reduce the amount of non-transparent diplomatic funds, he added.

In addition, Shih said, the government will help Taiwan's diplomatic allies to achieve sustainable development through the transfer of Taiwan's expertise in various fields, as part of its efforts to help realize the United Nations' Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).

For instance, techniques passed on by Taiwan's overseas agricultural teams could help relieve extreme hunger and poverty in some areas of countries that have diplomatic ties with Taiwan, he said. Also, the dispatch of mobile medical missions would also assist those allies that are fighting against infectious diseases and help to reduce infant mortality rates, he added.

Meanwhile, Shih said, Taiwan will also strengthen cooperation with relevant international financial institutions, such as the Asian Development Bank, the Central American Bank for Economic Integration, and the Inter-American Development Bank.

He made particular mention of possible cooperation schemes with Australia and New Zealand to implement aid programs in the South Pacific region, adding that the government will cooperate with relevant domestic non-governmental organizations and the private sector to help with its aid programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's R&D spending accounts for 2.62 percent of GDP: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan spent NT$331.4 billion (US$10 billion) on research and development in 2007, accounting for 2.62
percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) for the year, a National Science Council (NSC) official said Thursday.

Citing results of the National Science and Technology Survey conducted by the NSC, the council's Deputy Minister Chen Cheng-hong said the spending marked a continuous increase for the past five years.
Still, Taiwan's spending on R&D fell behind its major competitor in the high-tech field -- South Korea, whose R&D spending accounted for 3.23 percent of its GDP last year.

The results also showed that Taiwanese private sectors' investment in research and development increased every year since 2003. It accounted for more than 70 percent of the national level for 2007, while the government's investment did not increase by much, Chen said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan had 6,128 patent applications approved in the United States in 2007, dropping one notch to rank fifth place in the world and trailing behind South Korea for the first time, according to Chen, who was also quoting the survey results. Taiwan ranked fourth place in 2006. In terms of the Science Citation Index - an index of how often scientific papers from various countries are cited, Taiwan ranked 15th in the world, up two notches from the level a year earlier. Each research paper was cited 3.05 times, up from 2.92 times in 2006, Chen said. Meanwhile, Taiwan ranked the ninth in terms of the number of research papers covered in the Engineering Index, up two notches from the previous year, Chen said. The index is a comprehensive bibliographic database of engineering research literature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nanjing tree to be planted in Taipei County

TEXT.P: Seedlings of the official city tree of China's southeastern city of Nanjing, cedrus deodara, are expected to be planted in Taipei County sometime next year, a county government source said Thursday.

Paperwork pertaining to quarantine and exports of the seedlings is currently in the pipeline in Nanjing City for the shipment of several thousand seedlings of the conifer, as well as other trees, to Taipei County -- the largest and most populous administrative district in Taiwan -- said Chen Yuan-chuan, a division chief of the Taipei County Bureau of Agriculture.

A total of 1,000 seedlings of cedrus deodara, 3,000 willow seedlings and 100 plum seedlings that the Nanjing city government promised to Taipei County are expected to be delivered once Nanjing city officials complete the quarantine paperwork and the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture approves the imports, Chen said.

Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei visited Nanjing in July to promote two-way tourism and cultural exchanges, during which he signed a memorandum of understanding with Nanjing Mayor Jiang Hongkun and the city's Communist Party leader Zhu Shanlu aimed at enhancing bilateral exchanges and cooperation.

A botanist and a Nanjing city government official visited Taiwan recently to probe the feasibility of the donation and gain a better understanding of the suitability of Taipei County to grow the seedlings, according to Chen.

After consulting with the botanist, the county government decided to first cultivate the seedlings at a nursery in the county's Sansia township and to eventually transplant the trees at Bitan, in Taipei City's southern outskirts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen County keen to open office in Xiamen

TEXT.P: The offshore Kinmen County urged the central government Thursday to allow it to open an office in Xiamen in China's Fujian Province, so as to better serve Taiwanese people, especially those traveling between the two sides.

Lin Chen-chia, director of the county's tourism bureau, suggested the central government in Taipei face up to the fast-growing direct ferry services maintained between Kinmen and Xiamen since January 2001 -- popularly known as the "mini three links" which are also put in place between Taiwan-held Matsu Island and Fujian's Mawei port.
The number of passengers using the Kinmen-Xiamen mini links reached nearly one million this year, an astounding jump from the 21,500 in the first year the links were opened, Lin said.
Kinmen authorities are particularly keen on opening an office to serve Kinmen people in Xiamen given that more than 20,000 county residents are residing there, he said.

Now that direct air, shipping and postal links have also been put in place between Taiwan proper and China this month, Lin suggested the central government retool its current policy which bans city and county authorities from setting up offices in China.
Doing so will help boost exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Liu said.

Several cities and counties in Taiwan have expressed an interest in setting up representative offices in China. Lin proposed the central government first allow Kinmen County and Lienchiang County of Matsu Island to do so, due to their proximities to China.
The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Wednesday that Taiwan's local governments are prohibited from opening offices in China because there is no legal basis for such a practice.

A ban on local governments opening offices in China has pushed some cities and counties to create special units or form task forces to deal with issues arising from growing cross-strait activities. Some local authorities are also considering setting up de facto representative offices in China through farmers' associations or other trade or tourism-related groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Green' policy generates NT$6 billion in benefits: economic official

TEXT.P: The government's policy of promoting "green" technology has helped generate economic benefits of over NT$6 billion (about US$182 million) so far this year, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Development Bureau (IDB).

IDB officials noted Thursday that the government will integrate more resources to provide private manufacturers with more improved technologies in the areas of cleaner production process and eco- friendly waste treatment.

Officials said the government will also assist private companies in earning eco- friendly accreditations from the U.S., European countries, and other nations, which will enhance their abilities to enter the overseas markets.
According to the bureau, a subproject of Eco-Technology Assistance and Promotion has conducted 298 rounds of consultations, helping industrial players save cost and increase production.
The total monetary benefits resulting from the consultations have reached nearly NT$4.3 billion so far this year, according to the bureau.

And the technologies of microbe-based defatting procedures, composite chelating agents, and other three inventions have also helped generate economic benefits of NT$1.5 billion this year, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fireworks at Taipei 101 to read `2009 Taiwan'

TEXT.P: The year "2009" and the English wording "Taiwan" embedded in huge hearts will be lit up during the New Year's Eve fireworks display on the facade of Taipei 101, one of the highest skyscrapers in the world, an official said Thursday.

Steven Kuo Su, deputy director-general of the Tourism Bureau, announced this year's design at a news conference, adding that the Tourism Bureau, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd. together won the bid for the right to stage the display.
"The spectacular fireworks display at Taipei 101 has become one of the best ways to promote tourism and raise Taiwan's international profile," said Kuo.

He noted that last year, 75 television networks in 26 countries broadcast footage of the New Year's Eve fireworks over Taipei 101, creating media publicity that he estimated as being worth more than NT$100 million (US$3.03 million).

Chen Chun-liang, designer of this year's lighting, said at the news conference that the word "Taiwan" embedded in four hearts will be displayed on the facade of Taipei 101, symbolizing "embracing Taiwan with great love."

Appearing in green, red, blue and yellow, Chen said the four hearts also represent sustainability, happiness, openness and friendliness, adding that the various colors mean that everyone should tolerate each other's differences to welcome in 2009.

Liu Si-lin, head of the Tourism Bureau's international affairs section, said that the NT$21 million lighting show will be lit for an hour when the clock strikes midnight Dec. 31, and from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. Jan. 1-15.

Last year's fireworks -- also sponsored by the Tourism Bureau -- lasted 188 seconds and was highlighted by the appearance of "2008" and the word "Taiwan" illuminated on the building's facade after the fireworks ended.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's mobile medical missions `cause sensation' in allies: ICDF

TEXT.P: Two mobile medical missions Taiwan sent to Guatemala and Haiti, respectively, to help deal with the aftermath of natural disasters in those allied countries "caused sensation, " the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) said Thursday.

As the mission to Guatemala reached out to several "very remote rural settlements to which even the country's own medical staff would not go, " it was very much welcomed by the local residents, ICDF Secretary-General Chen Lien-gene told a press conference.

He said the 10-member mission, consisting of physicians, surgeons, pharmacists and nurses from the Taipei Medical University Hospital, visited eight towns in the provinces of Izabal and Chiquimula during its two-week stay in the Central American country.

The mission provided much-needed medical assistance and supplies, benefiting around 3,000 people, in the wake of widespread flooding and landslides caused by a week of incessant rain in October, Chen went on.
In addition, Taiwan's first mobile medical mission to Haiti also provided medical care to around 2,650 people who suffered from recent disasters in the capital, Port-au-Prince, Chen added.

A series of devastating storms killed nearly 800 Haitians and left hundreds injured in the August-September period, while approximately 500 students and teachers perished when a school in Port-au-Prince collapsed in November.
Chen disclosed that including these two medical missions, the ICDF has dispatched 18 missions, comprising 165 medical staff, to 13 countries this year, helping around 30,000 people.

The ICDF is tasked by the government with providing technical assistance, investment and loans, international human resources and humanitarian aid to countries in need, whether or not they have diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
The ICDF sent its first mobile medical mission to northern India in December 2005 and as of the end of 2007, had dispatched a total of 32 medical teams overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free public bus rides to be launched on Penghu

TEXT.P: Free public bus rides will be available from Jan. 1 for all registered residents of the offshore Penghu County, the Penghu county government announced Thursday.
Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien-fa encouraged residents to use the free buses instead of using their cars or motorbikes, to help reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

The county government recently allocated NT$20 million (US$606,060) to support the initiative after several county councilors proposed that the county government should provide its residents with better social welfare programs and help promote environmental protection awareness, Wang said.
Students on Penghu have been allowed to ride the public buses free of charge from Dec. 1.
Penghu is one of the very few counties in the country to provide its residents with free buses.

The outlying island of Kinmen was the first county to do so eight years ago after the Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc. -- the island's cash cow -- regularly paid huge amounts of taxes to the county government, which in turn spent the money on improving welfare programs for the people there.
The number of registered Kinmen residents stands at about 80,000, but only around 40,000 to 50,000 people regularly reside there.
Penghu's population stands at around 91,000, but the number of those who regularly use public buses is no more than 50,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority of Taiwanese welcome China links, but suspect China: poll

TEXT.P: More than two-thirds of respondents to a recent opinion poll believe the government's recent launching of daily flight services, direct shipping and postal links with China is beneficial to local residents and will raise Taiwan's competitiveness, pollsters said Thursday.
The results of the survey, however, showed lingering distrust by alarge number of Taiwanese people toward the Chinese government.

The survey was supervised by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and conducted by the China Credit Information Service between Dec. 19 and Dec.21 with a margin of error of 3 percent. The 1,068 eligible respondents were composed of Taiwanese adults aged 20-69 accessible through telephone interviews.

The survey took place after the launching of daily flight services and direct shipping and postal links between Taiwan and China on Dec. 15 -- the first time in 60 years that the transportation links were allowed between the two sides.

Asked about the improvement in bilateral relations between Taiwan and China, 48.2 percent of the respondents regarded the Chinese government as being friendly towards Taiwan, but 49.2 percent believed the opposite.

And while they favor improved ties with China, a vast majority of Taiwanese people did not favor unification with China, with the survey showing that 91.8 percent of the respondents preferred to maintain the status quo when asked what they thought about independence from or reunification with China.

"Sixty-one point seven percent of the citizens believe that the agreements signed with China will have a very positive effect on the economy of Taiwan, " said Fu Dong- cheng, vice chairman of the MAC during a weekly routine press conference.
Fu said that the survey also showed that 54.8 percent of Taiwanese people believe direct shipping and daily flight services across the Taiwan Strait can attract more foreign investors to the island.

Eighty-one percent of the respondents said they would take the daily charter flight services if they visit China. Meanwhile, more than 60 percent of the participants believed cross-Strait relations have improved since last year and are confident that President Ma Ying-jeou's administration has done a good job in maintaining peace and stability in the region.

"The MAC is glad to see that Taiwanese people have felt a conciliatory trend in cross-Strait relations, and believe that such a trend will serve the foundation of a peaceful development in the region," said Fu.

Since the Kuomintang (KMT) returned to power in May, Ma's administration has been working to melt the ice between the two sides of the strait and forge links with China, particularly in the economic front.

In their second round of talks held in Taipei from Nov. 3-7, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, and his counterpart Chen Yunlin of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , signed four agreements to allow daily direct flights, direct shipping links and direct postal deliveries, as well as the establishment of a food safety mechanism between the two sides.

Chen was the highest-ranking Chinese official to set foot on Taiwan since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949. The MAC supervises the operations of the SEF. The SEF and the ARATS are quasi-official organizations responsible for handling cross-Strait engagements in the absence of official government-to- government relations between the two sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmaker takes voluntary suspension over citizenship dispute

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Ching-an announced Thursday that she will temporarily step down from office and stop receiving her salary until the U.S. authorities release a "final outcome" of their investigation into her U.S. citizenship status.
The decision was made "to prevent any further waste in social resources" as a result of the controversy, Lee said.

Lee claimed that a report on her dual citizenship -- strictly forbidden for public office-holders -- delivered recently by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on her case is "not final" and urged the public to wait for the end result before censuring her.

She was referring to a letter released to the media a day earlier by legislators from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , in which the U.S. State Department says Lee "has previously been documented as a U.S. citizen with a U.S. passport and that no subsequent loss of U.S. citizenship has been documented."

Lee's qualification as a legislator has been challenged since it was reported early this year that she has never officially renounced her U.S. citizenship even though she has been in public office in Taiwan since 1994.
The Nationality Act forbids Republic of China nationals with foreign citizenship from assuming public office and requires those with foreign citizenship to be removed from their posts.

Lee admitted that she obtained U.S. citizenship in 1991, but argued that she lost her status as a U.S. citizen "legally" when she was sworn in as a Taipei city councilor in 1994, citing U.S. law which lists serving in a foreign government as one of the legal conditions for the loss of nationality.
Under pressure from the DPP, the Legislative Yuan requested the MOFA in May to help verify with foreign governments whether any of the sitting legislators hold foreign citizenship.
A reply by the U.S. was received by the MOFA in early December and the letter was distributed as a classified document to each legislator Wednesday.

While saying there is no record of loss of U.S. citizenship by Lee, the letter also states that "U.S. citizens who hold the nationality of a foreign country and who accept employment with the government of that country that requires an oath, affirmation or declaration of allegiance may have committed an expatriating act if they do so with the intent to relinquish their U.S. nationality."

"While the Department (of State) has not made any determination regarding loss of nationality for the individual named above, it could do so based on evidence that he or she committed a potentially expatriating act with the intention of relinquishing U.S. nationality. Any such determination would be retroactive to the date of the expatriating act," the letter reads.

Asked to comment on Lee's claim that the U.S. reply means that her case is still under review by the U.S. government, a U.S. State Department official told a CNA correspondent in Washington, D.C. Wednesday that "we cannot comment on the individual citizenship of any one person."
However, the official from the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also said "we now consider this issue closed."
Also Thursday, the DPP argued that the U.S. reply clearly indicates that Lee holds U.S. citizenship and demanded that the Legislative Yuan act immediately to strip her of her legislative post.
Lee should also surrender salary totaling NT$110 million that she has received from public office since 1994, according to Lai Ching-te, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Workers joining on-job training program to be subsidized

TEXT.P: In a bid to help workers forced to take unpaid leave amid the current economic recession, those who take part in an on-the-job training program will be subsidized by the government, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Wang Ju- hsuan announced Thursday.

The program is slated to kick off in February and will provide participating workers with extra monetary assistance and an opportunity to sharpen their professional skills while forced to take their unpaid leave, Wang said, adding that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has promised to back up the plan.
According to Wang, the CLA is deeply concerned that more workers will lose their jobs after the Lunar New Year, which falls on January 26 next year.
"I believe that the program will help increase workers' competitive edges and help stabilize the employment market, " the CLA minister said.

Private companies participating in the program are required to open courses for their workers on unpaid leave, while the CLA will offer a subsidy of NT$100 (about US$3) for every hour of training, she said.
Eligible workers should take at least 24 hours of training per month and will receive subsidies up to NT$10,000 per month for a maximum period of six months, she went on.
Companies are not allowed to dismiss their workers who take part in the program, Wang added.

The CLA has estimated that the program will subsidize about 5,600 companies, 600 of which are large enterprises employing over 200 people. It has predicted that some 168,000 workers will benefit from the measure.
The program will require a budget totaling NT$15.97 billion in 2009, according to CLA estimates.

DOC.HEADLINE: President supports recording comfort women stories in textbooks

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that he supports the inclusion of the historical truth of comfort women during World War II in textbooks, as it is part of Taiwan's history.

Ma made the remarks at a meeting with eight former Taiwanese comfort women -- a euphemism for women who were coerced or abducted by the Japanese military and forced to provide sexual services to its servicemen.

The eight survivors of Japan's sex-slave system visited Ma in the company of Kevin Liao, chairman of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, which has long been striving for justice for the former comfort women.
The former comfort women, including 92-year-old Wu Hsiou-mei and Chen Tao, aged 87, appealed to Ma that the truth about comfort women be formally included in history education.
Ma said he supports their appeal, as accounts of the former Taiwanese comfort women are also part of Taiwan's history and the mistakes of history should not be forgotten.

Ma said the issue of the comfort women is not a racial one but a human rights issue that also involves other Asian countries overrun by the Japanese. He vowed to help the victims demand an apology and compensation from the Japanese government.

Ma said he has developed deep affection for some of former Taiwanese comfort women since he started striving for justice for them in 1997, and he added that he will continue caring about them and providing them with assistance.
During World War II, the Japanese army kidnapped or coerced at least 400,000 women in China, Korea, Taiwan, Indonesia and the Philippines to satisfy its soldiers' sexual needs.
In Taiwan, the estimated number of victims varies from 1,200 to 2,000, but only 58 have been confirmed by the foundation. Now with an average age of 85, there are only 20 still alive.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opening to Chinese performers will be beneficial: GIO

TEXT.P: Allowing Chinese entertainers to come to Taiwan to act in TV dramas will increase jobs opportunities for locals rather than decrease them, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Vanessa Yea-ping Shih predicted Thursday.
Shih made the remarks one day after announcing that the GIO is mapping out a draft proposal to allow Chinese performers and technicians to work in Taiwan.

"The proposed plan to allow a certain number of Chinese actors and technicians to work on local TV films will not affect the work rights of local performers and technicians. Instead, it will increase job opportunities," she said.

She explained that Taiwan has in the past banned Chinese performers and workers in cross-strait joint-venture TV dramas, resulting in the job opportunities generated, such as set design or extras, all going to China.
She also said that the opening will also help upgrade the development of Taiwan's TV and film industries, saying that if the films are shot in Taiwan, then it will help promote Taiwanese culture.
But lawmakers from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party were unconvinced by Shih's explanation.
DPP lawmaker Yu Tian said the opening will seriously impact Taiwan's entertainment circles, especially since many middle-aged and elderly performers are facing difficulty finding work.
Yu, an entertainer-turned-lawmaker, suggested that the GIO hold public hearings and work out complementary measures.
Two other DPP lawmakers, Kuan Bi-ling and Chen Ting-fei, questioned whether the opening to Chinese entertainers is a precursor to Taiwan's opening to Chinese laborers.
According to Chen, although President Ma Ying-jeou has said he will not open the country to Chinese laborers, Chinese entertainers are in fact Chinese laborers.
"The opening to Chinese entertainers is a water-testing move and if the policy is adopted, then Chinese laborers will follow, " Chen claimed.

Shih said the government will first allow Chinese TV actors to enter Taiwan to work, followed by singers, subject to coordination with the Ministry of Education and the Immigration Agency, and subject to approval by the Mainland Affairs Council.
Opening to Chinese movie actors will require public hearings and will take a longer time, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors appeal again on ex-president's release

TEXT.P: Prosecutors launched a new bid Thursday to detain former President Chen Shui- bian ahead of his trial on a raft of corruption charges.

Prosecutors with the Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office launched the bid by re-appealing to the Taiwan High Court against the Taipei District Court's Dec. 18 decision to release Chen on his own recognizance.

It marked the second time the district court had rejected prosecutors' request that Chen continue to be detained after he was indicted Dec. 12 on charges of embezzling government funds and laundering money.
In their Thursday appeal for Chen's detention, prosecutors said they believe Chen might flee Taiwan and conspire with witnesses to tamper with or destroy evidence if he remains free.

Although National Security Bureau (NSB) personnel are obliged to escort Chen all day long to protect him, the prosecutors argued that such an escort is not compulsory and that Chen can easily dodge them.
For instance, prosecutors argued, Chen answered SID subpoenas July 24 and Aug. 15 in the company of staff members of his office instead of NSB bodyguards.
The prosecutors asked the Taiwan High Court to hand down a ruling on their appeal instead of sending the case back to the district court as it did when it dealt with their previous appeal.
The high court was expected to make a decision on the appeal the following day.

In its Dec. 13 ruling, the court ordered that Chen, who was taken into custody by prosecutors Nov. 12, be released without bail following his indictment along with 13 other people on charges of embezzlement, corruption and money laundering. He is Taiwan's first former president to face criminal prosecution.
Chen and his wife are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers' Foundation demands probe into high commodity prices

TEXT.P: The government should look into why domestic commodity prices have not dropped significantly to reflect an average 50 percent fall in prices of major raw materials and grain on the world market, the Consumers' Foundation said Thursday.

Wu Chia-cheng, secretary-general of the Consumers' Foundation, quoted Chicago Mercantile Exchange data as showing that international prices for soybeans and wheat have plunged by 48 percent and 56 percent, respectively, from their peaks recorded earlier this year.
Regrettably, Wu said, domestic prices for relevant products, including cooking oil, flour and bread, have so far not reflected such dramatic falls in international raw material prices.
In his view, Wu said, domestic cooking oil prices should be lowered by up to 56 percent and bread prices should be cut by 30 percent.
Wu urged the Fair Trade Commission and the Executive Yuan's special task force on commodity price stabilization to launch a thorough probe into the issue and work out feasible countermeasures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet eases restrictions on China visits by senior officials

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Cabinet revised regulations governing China visits by government employees Thursday, greatly relaxing travel restrictions on high-ranking officials.
Also amended were regulations concerning Taiwan visits by Chinese professionals to ease the restrictions for Chinese government officials.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said the liberalization policy will facilitate the exchanges between the two sides and help Taiwan's civil servants gain an in- depth understanding of the situation in China, thus contributing positively to establishing healthy relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Liu pledged that the government will make sure not to undermine Taiwan's security when promoting the policy.
The revised regulations will take effect on the date of their proclamation by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

They will allow police officers at rank 3 or higher and career civil servants at grade 11 or higher who have no access to state secrets to visit China for any purposes, including official business and pleasure, after obtaining permission from a screening committee under the MOI, said Deputy Minister of the Interior Lin Join-sane.

For political appointees, local government chiefs and ordinary civil servants with access to state secrets, they can visit China for any purpose other than pleasure, after obtaining permission from the MOI's screening committee, Lin said.

Political appointees are currently only allowed to visit China for international conferences or activities, and local government chiefs can only do so to take part in conferences related to their work.

Meanwhile, Lin said, the China travel ban on officials engaging in "special services with access to state secrets" will remain to uphold national security and interests, meaning that they are strictly forbidden from visiting China unless given special permission.

These officials include personnel posted overseas, personnel engaging in the research and development of defense or secret technologies, as well as staff of the National Security Bureau, the Ministry of National Defense and the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau.

For civil servants at grade 10 or lower, they will be able to visit China after gaining the approval of the agencies they serve and will no longer be required to apply for permission with the MOI, Lin said.

On visits to Taiwan by Chinese officials, the revised regulations will allow them to come to Taiwan for exchange activities at the invitation of a local authority, a central government agency or the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, Lin said.
Chinese officials are currently permitted to visit Taiwan only in a private capacity and if they are invited by a school or civil organization in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign aid to be transparent, professional, sustainable: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that the principles of transparency and professionalism, along with the global goal of sustainable development, will be the pillars of its foreign aid policy, which will be laid out in a white paper to be released in January.

Shih Wen-bin, director-general of the MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, said at a press briefing that transparency and professionalism are pivotal to enhancing the effectiveness of Taiwan's overseas aid.

The ministry has therefore slashed its annual budget for secret diplomacy to NT$3.8 billion (US$115.15 million) for next year, down by NT$2 billion from the previous fiscal year, he said. This decision is also in line with the Legislative Yuan's request to gradually reduce the amount of non-transparent diplomatic funds, he added.

In addition, Shih said, the government will help Taiwan's diplomatic allies to achieve sustainable development through the transfer of Taiwan's expertise in various fields, as part of its efforts to help realize the United Nations' Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).

For instance, techniques passed on by Taiwan's overseas agricultural teams could help relieve extreme hunger and poverty in some areas of countries that have diplomatic ties with Taiwan, he said. Also, the dispatch of mobile medical missions would also assist those allies that are fighting against infectious diseases and help to reduce infant mortality rates, he added.

Meanwhile, Shih said, Taiwan will also strengthen cooperation with relevant international financial institutions, such as the Asian Development Bank, the Central American Bank for Economic Integration, and the Inter-American Development Bank.

He made particular mention of possible cooperation schemes with Australia and New Zealand to implement aid programs in the South Pacific region, adding that the government will cooperate with relevant domestic non-governmental organizations and the private sector to help with its aid programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's R&D spending accounts for 2.62 percent of GDP: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan spent NT$331.4 billion (US$10 billion) on research and development in 2007, accounting for 2.62
percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) for the year, a National Science Council (NSC) official said Thursday.

Citing results of the National Science and Technology Survey conducted by the NSC, the council's Deputy Minister Chen Cheng-hong said the spending marked a continuous increase for the past five years.
Still, Taiwan's spending on R&D fell behind its major competitor in the high-tech field -- South Korea, whose R&D spending accounted for 3.23 percent of its GDP last year.

The results also showed that Taiwanese private sectors' investment in research and development increased every year since 2003. It accounted for more than 70 percent of the national level for 2007, while the government's investment did not increase by much, Chen said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan had 6,128 patent applications approved in the United States in 2007, dropping one notch to rank fifth place in the world and trailing behind South Korea for the first time, according to Chen, who was also quoting the survey results. Taiwan ranked fourth place in 2006. In terms of the Science Citation Index - an index of how often scientific papers from various countries are cited, Taiwan ranked 15th in the world, up two notches from the level a year earlier. Each research paper was cited 3.05 times, up from 2.92 times in 2006, Chen said. Meanwhile, Taiwan ranked the ninth in terms of the number of research papers covered in the Engineering Index, up two notches from the previous year, Chen said. The index is a comprehensive bibliographic database of engineering research literature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nanjing tree to be planted in Taipei County

TEXT.P: Seedlings of the official city tree of China's southeastern city of Nanjing, cedrus deodara, are expected to be planted in Taipei County sometime next year, a county government source said Thursday.

Paperwork pertaining to quarantine and exports of the seedlings is currently in the pipeline in Nanjing City for the shipment of several thousand seedlings of the conifer, as well as other trees, to Taipei County -- the largest and most populous administrative district in Taiwan -- said Chen Yuan-chuan, a division chief of the Taipei County Bureau of Agriculture.

A total of 1,000 seedlings of cedrus deodara, 3,000 willow seedlings and 100 plum seedlings that the Nanjing city government promised to Taipei County are expected to be delivered once Nanjing city officials complete the quarantine paperwork and the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture approves the imports, Chen said.

Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei visited Nanjing in July to promote two-way tourism and cultural exchanges, during which he signed a memorandum of understanding with Nanjing Mayor Jiang Hongkun and the city's Communist Party leader Zhu Shanlu aimed at enhancing bilateral exchanges and cooperation.

A botanist and a Nanjing city government official visited Taiwan recently to probe the feasibility of the donation and gain a better understanding of the suitability of Taipei County to grow the seedlings, according to Chen.

After consulting with the botanist, the county government decided to first cultivate the seedlings at a nursery in the county's Sansia township and to eventually transplant the trees at Bitan, in Taipei City's southern outskirts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen County keen to open office in Xiamen

TEXT.P: The offshore Kinmen County urged the central government Thursday to allow it to open an office in Xiamen in China's Fujian Province, so as to better serve Taiwanese people, especially those traveling between the two sides.

Lin Chen-chia, director of the county's tourism bureau, suggested the central government in Taipei face up to the fast-growing direct ferry services maintained between Kinmen and Xiamen since January 2001 -- popularly known as the "mini three links" which are also put in place between Taiwan-held Matsu Island and Fujian's Mawei port.
The number of passengers using the Kinmen-Xiamen mini links reached nearly one million this year, an astounding jump from the 21,500 in the first year the links were opened, Lin said.
Kinmen authorities are particularly keen on opening an office to serve Kinmen people in Xiamen given that more than 20,000 county residents are residing there, he said.

Now that direct air, shipping and postal links have also been put in place between Taiwan proper and China this month, Lin suggested the central government retool its current policy which bans city and county authorities from setting up offices in China.
Doing so will help boost exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Liu said.

Several cities and counties in Taiwan have expressed an interest in setting up representative offices in China. Lin proposed the central government first allow Kinmen County and Lienchiang County of Matsu Island to do so, due to their proximities to China.
The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Wednesday that Taiwan's local governments are prohibited from opening offices in China because there is no legal basis for such a practice.

A ban on local governments opening offices in China has pushed some cities and counties to create special units or form task forces to deal with issues arising from growing cross-strait activities. Some local authorities are also considering setting up de facto representative offices in China through farmers' associations or other trade or tourism-related groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Green' policy generates NT$6 billion in benefits: economic official

TEXT.P: The government's policy of promoting "green" technology has helped generate economic benefits of over NT$6 billion (about US$182 million) so far this year, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Development Bureau (IDB).

IDB officials noted Thursday that the government will integrate more resources to provide private manufacturers with more improved technologies in the areas of cleaner production process and eco- friendly waste treatment.

Officials said the government will also assist private companies in earning eco- friendly accreditations from the U.S., European countries, and other nations, which will enhance their abilities to enter the overseas markets.
According to the bureau, a subproject of Eco-Technology Assistance and Promotion has conducted 298 rounds of consultations, helping industrial players save cost and increase production.
The total monetary benefits resulting from the consultations have reached nearly NT$4.3 billion so far this year, according to the bureau.

And the technologies of microbe-based defatting procedures, composite chelating agents, and other three inventions have also helped generate economic benefits of NT$1.5 billion this year, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fireworks at Taipei 101 to read `2009 Taiwan'

TEXT.P: The year "2009" and the English wording "Taiwan" embedded in huge hearts will be lit up during the New Year's Eve fireworks display on the facade of Taipei 101, one of the highest skyscrapers in the world, an official said Thursday.

Steven Kuo Su, deputy director-general of the Tourism Bureau, announced this year's design at a news conference, adding that the Tourism Bureau, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd. together won the bid for the right to stage the display.
"The spectacular fireworks display at Taipei 101 has become one of the best ways to promote tourism and raise Taiwan's international profile," said Kuo.

He noted that last year, 75 television networks in 26 countries broadcast footage of the New Year's Eve fireworks over Taipei 101, creating media publicity that he estimated as being worth more than NT$100 million (US$3.03 million).

Chen Chun-liang, designer of this year's lighting, said at the news conference that the word "Taiwan" embedded in four hearts will be displayed on the facade of Taipei 101, symbolizing "embracing Taiwan with great love."

Appearing in green, red, blue and yellow, Chen said the four hearts also represent sustainability, happiness, openness and friendliness, adding that the various colors mean that everyone should tolerate each other's differences to welcome in 2009.

Liu Si-lin, head of the Tourism Bureau's international affairs section, said that the NT$21 million lighting show will be lit for an hour when the clock strikes midnight Dec. 31, and from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. Jan. 1-15.

Last year's fireworks -- also sponsored by the Tourism Bureau -- lasted 188 seconds and was highlighted by the appearance of "2008" and the word "Taiwan" illuminated on the building's facade after the fireworks ended.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's mobile medical missions `cause sensation' in allies: ICDF

TEXT.P: Two mobile medical missions Taiwan sent to Guatemala and Haiti, respectively, to help deal with the aftermath of natural disasters in those allied countries "caused sensation, " the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) said Thursday.

As the mission to Guatemala reached out to several "very remote rural settlements to which even the country's own medical staff would not go, " it was very much welcomed by the local residents, ICDF Secretary-General Chen Lien-gene told a press conference.

He said the 10-member mission, consisting of physicians, surgeons, pharmacists and nurses from the Taipei Medical University Hospital, visited eight towns in the provinces of Izabal and Chiquimula during its two-week stay in the Central American country.

The mission provided much-needed medical assistance and supplies, benefiting around 3,000 people, in the wake of widespread flooding and landslides caused by a week of incessant rain in October, Chen went on.
In addition, Taiwan's first mobile medical mission to Haiti also provided medical care to around 2,650 people who suffered from recent disasters in the capital, Port-au-Prince, Chen added.

A series of devastating storms killed nearly 800 Haitians and left hundreds injured in the August-September period, while approximately 500 students and teachers perished when a school in Port-au-Prince collapsed in November.
Chen disclosed that including these two medical missions, the ICDF has dispatched 18 missions, comprising 165 medical staff, to 13 countries this year, helping around 30,000 people.

The ICDF is tasked by the government with providing technical assistance, investment and loans, international human resources and humanitarian aid to countries in need, whether or not they have diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
The ICDF sent its first mobile medical mission to northern India in December 2005 and as of the end of 2007, had dispatched a total of 32 medical teams overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free public bus rides to be launched on Penghu

TEXT.P: Free public bus rides will be available from Jan. 1 for all registered residents of the offshore Penghu County, the Penghu county government announced Thursday.
Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien-fa encouraged residents to use the free buses instead of using their cars or motorbikes, to help reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

The county government recently allocated NT$20 million (US$606,060) to support the initiative after several county councilors proposed that the county government should provide its residents with better social welfare programs and help promote environmental protection awareness, Wang said.
Students on Penghu have been allowed to ride the public buses free of charge from Dec. 1.
Penghu is one of the very few counties in the country to provide its residents with free buses.

The outlying island of Kinmen was the first county to do so eight years ago after the Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc. -- the island's cash cow -- regularly paid huge amounts of taxes to the county government, which in turn spent the money on improving welfare programs for the people there.
The number of registered Kinmen residents stands at about 80,000, but only around 40,000 to 50,000 people regularly reside there.
Penghu's population stands at around 91,000, but the number of those who regularly use public buses is no more than 50,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority of Taiwanese welcome China links, but suspect China: poll

TEXT.P: More than two-thirds of respondents to a recent opinion poll believe the government's recent launching of daily flight services, direct shipping and postal links with China is beneficial to local residents and will raise Taiwan's competitiveness, pollsters said Thursday.
The results of the survey, however, showed lingering distrust by alarge number of Taiwanese people toward the Chinese government.

The survey was supervised by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and conducted by the China Credit Information Service between Dec. 19 and Dec.21 with a margin of error of 3 percent. The 1,068 eligible respondents were composed of Taiwanese adults aged 20-69 accessible through telephone interviews.

The survey took place after the launching of daily flight services and direct shipping and postal links between Taiwan and China on Dec. 15 -- the first time in 60 years that the transportation links were allowed between the two sides.

Asked about the improvement in bilateral relations between Taiwan and China, 48.2 percent of the respondents regarded the Chinese government as being friendly towards Taiwan, but 49.2 percent believed the opposite.

And while they favor improved ties with China, a vast majority of Taiwanese people did not favor unification with China, with the survey showing that 91.8 percent of the respondents preferred to maintain the status quo when asked what they thought about independence from or reunification with China.

"Sixty-one point seven percent of the citizens believe that the agreements signed with China will have a very positive effect on the economy of Taiwan, " said Fu Dong- cheng, vice chairman of the MAC during a weekly routine press conference.
Fu said that the survey also showed that 54.8 percent of Taiwanese people believe direct shipping and daily flight services across the Taiwan Strait can attract more foreign investors to the island.

Eighty-one percent of the respondents said they would take the daily charter flight services if they visit China. Meanwhile, more than 60 percent of the participants believed cross-Strait relations have improved since last year and are confident that President Ma Ying-jeou's administration has done a good job in maintaining peace and stability in the region.

"The MAC is glad to see that Taiwanese people have felt a conciliatory trend in cross-Strait relations, and believe that such a trend will serve the foundation of a peaceful development in the region," said Fu.

Since the Kuomintang (KMT) returned to power in May, Ma's administration has been working to melt the ice between the two sides of the strait and forge links with China, particularly in the economic front.

In their second round of talks held in Taipei from Nov. 3-7, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, and his counterpart Chen Yunlin of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , signed four agreements to allow daily direct flights, direct shipping links and direct postal deliveries, as well as the establishment of a food safety mechanism between the two sides.

Chen was the highest-ranking Chinese official to set foot on Taiwan since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949. The MAC supervises the operations of the SEF. The SEF and the ARATS are quasi-official organizations responsible for handling cross-Strait engagements in the absence of official government-to- government relations between the two sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmaker takes voluntary suspension over citizenship dispute

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Ching-an announced Thursday that she will temporarily step down from office and stop receiving her salary until the U.S. authorities release a "final outcome" of their investigation into her U.S. citizenship status.
The decision was made "to prevent any further waste in social resources" as a result of the controversy, Lee said.

Lee claimed that a report on her dual citizenship -- strictly forbidden for public office-holders -- delivered recently by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on her case is "not final" and urged the public to wait for the end result before censuring her.

She was referring to a letter released to the media a day earlier by legislators from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , in which the U.S. State Department says Lee "has previously been documented as a U.S. citizen with a U.S. passport and that no subsequent loss of U.S. citizenship has been documented."

Lee's qualification as a legislator has been challenged since it was reported early this year that she has never officially renounced her U.S. citizenship even though she has been in public office in Taiwan since 1994.
The Nationality Act forbids Republic of China nationals with foreign citizenship from assuming public office and requires those with foreign citizenship to be removed from their posts.

Lee admitted that she obtained U.S. citizenship in 1991, but argued that she lost her status as a U.S. citizen "legally" when she was sworn in as a Taipei city councilor in 1994, citing U.S. law which lists serving in a foreign government as one of the legal conditions for the loss of nationality.
Under pressure from the DPP, the Legislative Yuan requested the MOFA in May to help verify with foreign governments whether any of the sitting legislators hold foreign citizenship.
A reply by the U.S. was received by the MOFA in early December and the letter was distributed as a classified document to each legislator Wednesday.

While saying there is no record of loss of U.S. citizenship by Lee, the letter also states that "U.S. citizens who hold the nationality of a foreign country and who accept employment with the government of that country that requires an oath, affirmation or declaration of allegiance may have committed an expatriating act if they do so with the intent to relinquish their U.S. nationality."

"While the Department (of State) has not made any determination regarding loss of nationality for the individual named above, it could do so based on evidence that he or she committed a potentially expatriating act with the intention of relinquishing U.S. nationality. Any such determination would be retroactive to the date of the expatriating act," the letter reads.

Asked to comment on Lee's claim that the U.S. reply means that her case is still under review by the U.S. government, a U.S. State Department official told a CNA correspondent in Washington, D.C. Wednesday that "we cannot comment on the individual citizenship of any one person."
However, the official from the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also said "we now consider this issue closed."
Also Thursday, the DPP argued that the U.S. reply clearly indicates that Lee holds U.S. citizenship and demanded that the Legislative Yuan act immediately to strip her of her legislative post.
Lee should also surrender salary totaling NT$110 million that she has received from public office since 1994, according to Lai Ching-te, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Workers joining on-job training program to be subsidized

TEXT.P: In a bid to help workers forced to take unpaid leave amid the current economic recession, those who take part in an on-the-job training program will be subsidized by the government, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Wang Ju- hsuan announced Thursday.

The program is slated to kick off in February and will provide participating workers with extra monetary assistance and an opportunity to sharpen their professional skills while forced to take their unpaid leave, Wang said, adding that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has promised to back up the plan.
According to Wang, the CLA is deeply concerned that more workers will lose their jobs after the Lunar New Year, which falls on January 26 next year.
"I believe that the program will help increase workers' competitive edges and help stabilize the employment market, " the CLA minister said.

Private companies participating in the program are required to open courses for their workers on unpaid leave, while the CLA will offer a subsidy of NT$100 (about US$3) for every hour of training, she said.
Eligible workers should take at least 24 hours of training per month and will receive subsidies up to NT$10,000 per month for a maximum period of six months, she went on.
Companies are not allowed to dismiss their workers who take part in the program, Wang added.

The CLA has estimated that the program will subsidize about 5,600 companies, 600 of which are large enterprises employing over 200 people. It has predicted that some 168,000 workers will benefit from the measure.
The program will require a budget totaling NT$15.97 billion in 2009, according to CLA estimates.

DOC.HEADLINE: President supports recording comfort women stories in textbooks

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that he supports the inclusion of the historical truth of comfort women during World War II in textbooks, as it is part of Taiwan's history.

Ma made the remarks at a meeting with eight former Taiwanese comfort women -- a euphemism for women who were coerced or abducted by the Japanese military and forced to provide sexual services to its servicemen.

The eight survivors of Japan's sex-slave system visited Ma in the company of Kevin Liao, chairman of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, which has long been striving for justice for the former comfort women.
The former comfort women, including 92-year-old Wu Hsiou-mei and Chen Tao, aged 87, appealed to Ma that the truth about comfort women be formally included in history education.
Ma said he supports their appeal, as accounts of the former Taiwanese comfort women are also part of Taiwan's history and the mistakes of history should not be forgotten.

Ma said the issue of the comfort women is not a racial one but a human rights issue that also involves other Asian countries overrun by the Japanese. He vowed to help the victims demand an apology and compensation from the Japanese government.

Ma said he has developed deep affection for some of former Taiwanese comfort women since he started striving for justice for them in 1997, and he added that he will continue caring about them and providing them with assistance.
During World War II, the Japanese army kidnapped or coerced at least 400,000 women in China, Korea, Taiwan, Indonesia and the Philippines to satisfy its soldiers' sexual needs.
In Taiwan, the estimated number of victims varies from 1,200 to 2,000, but only 58 have been confirmed by the foundation. Now with an average age of 85, there are only 20 still alive.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opening to Chinese performers will be beneficial: GIO

TEXT.P: Allowing Chinese entertainers to come to Taiwan to act in TV dramas will increase jobs opportunities for locals rather than decrease them, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Vanessa Yea-ping Shih predicted Thursday.
Shih made the remarks one day after announcing that the GIO is mapping out a draft proposal to allow Chinese performers and technicians to work in Taiwan.

"The proposed plan to allow a certain number of Chinese actors and technicians to work on local TV films will not affect the work rights of local performers and technicians. Instead, it will increase job opportunities," she said.

She explained that Taiwan has in the past banned Chinese performers and workers in cross-strait joint-venture TV dramas, resulting in the job opportunities generated, such as set design or extras, all going to China.
She also said that the opening will also help upgrade the development of Taiwan's TV and film industries, saying that if the films are shot in Taiwan, then it will help promote Taiwanese culture.
But lawmakers from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party were unconvinced by Shih's explanation.
DPP lawmaker Yu Tian said the opening will seriously impact Taiwan's entertainment circles, especially since many middle-aged and elderly performers are facing difficulty finding work.
Yu, an entertainer-turned-lawmaker, suggested that the GIO hold public hearings and work out complementary measures.
Two other DPP lawmakers, Kuan Bi-ling and Chen Ting-fei, questioned whether the opening to Chinese entertainers is a precursor to Taiwan's opening to Chinese laborers.
According to Chen, although President Ma Ying-jeou has said he will not open the country to Chinese laborers, Chinese entertainers are in fact Chinese laborers.
"The opening to Chinese entertainers is a water-testing move and if the policy is adopted, then Chinese laborers will follow, " Chen claimed.

Shih said the government will first allow Chinese TV actors to enter Taiwan to work, followed by singers, subject to coordination with the Ministry of Education and the Immigration Agency, and subject to approval by the Mainland Affairs Council.
Opening to Chinese movie actors will require public hearings and will take a longer time, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors appeal again on ex-president's release

TEXT.P: Prosecutors launched a new bid Thursday to detain former President Chen Shui- bian ahead of his trial on a raft of corruption charges.

Prosecutors with the Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office launched the bid by re-appealing to the Taiwan High Court against the Taipei District Court's Dec. 18 decision to release Chen on his own recognizance.

It marked the second time the district court had rejected prosecutors' request that Chen continue to be detained after he was indicted Dec. 12 on charges of embezzling government funds and laundering money.
In their Thursday appeal for Chen's detention, prosecutors said they believe Chen might flee Taiwan and conspire with witnesses to tamper with or destroy evidence if he remains free.

Although National Security Bureau (NSB) personnel are obliged to escort Chen all day long to protect him, the prosecutors argued that such an escort is not compulsory and that Chen can easily dodge them.
For instance, prosecutors argued, Chen answered SID subpoenas July 24 and Aug. 15 in the company of staff members of his office instead of NSB bodyguards.
The prosecutors asked the Taiwan High Court to hand down a ruling on their appeal instead of sending the case back to the district court as it did when it dealt with their previous appeal.
The high court was expected to make a decision on the appeal the following day.

In its Dec. 13 ruling, the court ordered that Chen, who was taken into custody by prosecutors Nov. 12, be released without bail following his indictment along with 13 other people on charges of embezzlement, corruption and money laundering. He is Taiwan's first former president to face criminal prosecution.
Chen and his wife are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.
