DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers' Foundation demands probe into high commodity prices

TEXT.P: The government should look into why domestic commodity prices have not dropped significantly to reflect an average 50 percent fall in prices of major raw materials and grain on the world market, the Consumers' Foundation said Thursday.

Wu Chia-cheng, secretary-general of the Consumers' Foundation, quoted Chicago Mercantile Exchange data as showing that international prices for soybeans and wheat have plunged by 48 percent and 56 percent, respectively, from their peaks recorded earlier this year.
Regrettably, Wu said, domestic prices for relevant products, including cooking oil, flour and bread, have so far not reflected such dramatic falls in international raw material prices.
In his view, Wu said, domestic cooking oil prices should be lowered by up to 56 percent and bread prices should be cut by 30 percent.
Wu urged the Fair Trade Commission and the Executive Yuan's special task force on commodity price stabilization to launch a thorough probe into the issue and work out feasible countermeasures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Friday, moving down 14.92 points at 4,398.53 on a turnover of NT$689 million (US$20.86 million).
The weighted price index lost 9.64 points, or 0.22 percent, to close at 4,413.45 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.968 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.062 from Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 26, or the 29th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1792: Charles Babbage, British mathematician and inventor of the first computer, is born.
1797: John Wilkes, British political reformer noted for his published attacks on George III and for his support of the rights of American colonists, dies at the age of 70.
1890: Heinrich Schliemann, the German archaeologist who discovered the ruins of ancient Troy and excavated Mycenae, dies in Naples, Italy, at the age of 58.
1893: Mao Zedong, chairman of the Chinese Communist Party who proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, is born in Hunan Province.
1908: American boxer Jack Johnson defeats world heavyweight champion Tommy Burns at Rushcutter's Bay in Sydney, Australia, with a dazzling display of fighting skills, becoming the first black boxer to win the title.
1912: Mackay Memorial Hospital is inaugurated in Taipei.
1914: The United States pays back the remainder of a large sum of indemnities, totaling $11 million, that China was forced to pay in the signing of the Treaty of Peking in 1901.
1916: Tsai Yuan-pei becomes president of National Peking University.
1938: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates China's determination to carry on the war of resistance against Japan and charges that a recent statement by Japanese Prime Minister Prince Fumimaro Konoye clearly reveals Japan's intention to conquer China.
1941: The Unites States declares Manila an open city as Japanese forces approach.
1943: The British Royal Navy sinks the mighty German battle cruiser Scharnhosrt, making the sea lanes of the North Sea safer for Allied convoys.
1971: Sixteen U.S. veterans of the Vietnam War seize the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor to dramatize their anti-war stance.
1972: The Association of East Asian Relations of the Republic of China and the Interchange Association of Japan sign an agreement in Taipei to establish offices in each other's country.
1972: Harry S. Truman, U.S. president between 1945-53, dies in Kansas City at the age of 88.
1974: Hironori Ito, former director of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association, returns to Japan for a new assignment.
1975: The Legislative Yuan passes the Radio and Television Act.
1976: The 11th Convention of the Committee on Constitutional Research of the National Assembly opens at the Taipei City Auditorium.
1976: A two-day discussion on the electronic calculator opens at National Taiwan University.
1985: The Futehkeng landfill formally opens in Mucha, Taipei.
1989: Nobel Prize-winning Irish dramatist Samuel Beckett dies in Paris at the age of 83.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan chooses the Taiwan black bear as the one animal most representative of wildlife indigenous to Taiwan.
1999: The China Democracy Party, banned by Beijing a year earlier, issues a bold call to end one-party rule, challenging both the Communist Party's constitutional hold on supreme power and the Beijing regime's threat to use force to reunify Taiwan.
2000: Kuomintang heavyweight John Chang says in Xiamen that the purpose of his ongoing visit in mainland China is to promote the development of Taiwan-funded companies and to establish a bridge of communication with related mainland officials.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung presides over the inaugural ceremony of an administrative coordination center on the frontline island of Kinmen for managing affairs related to the "mini three links."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman never competes in anything he does, except perhaps in archery. But even then, when he wins he courteously makes his bow before he advances to take his place among the winners; and, when he has lost, he walks down and drinks his cup of forfeit. Thus, even in this case of competition, he shows himself to be a gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Workers joining on-job training program to be subsidized

TEXT.P: In a bid to help workers forced to take unpaid leave amid the current economic recession, those who take part in an on-the-job training program will be subsidized by the government, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Wang Ju- hsuan announced Thursday.

The program is slated to kick off in February and will provide participating workers with extra monetary assistance and an opportunity to sharpen their professional skills while forced to take their unpaid leave, Wang said, adding that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has promised to back up the plan.
According to Wang, the CLA is deeply concerned that more workers will lose their jobs after the Lunar New Year, which falls on January 26 next year.
"I believe that the program will help increase workers' competitive edges and help stabilize the employment market, " the CLA minister said.

Private companies participating in the program are required to open courses for their workers on unpaid leave, while the CLA will offer a subsidy of NT$100 (about US$3) for every hour of training, she said.
Eligible workers should take at least 24 hours of training per month and will receive subsidies up to NT$10,000 per month for a maximum period of six months, she went on.
Companies are not allowed to dismiss their workers who take part in the program, Wang added.

The CLA has estimated that the program will subsidize about 5,600 companies, 600 of which are large enterprises employing over 200 people. It has predicted that some 168,000 workers will benefit from the measure.
The program will require a budget totaling NT$15.97 billion in 2009, according to CLA estimates.

DOC.HEADLINE: President supports recording comfort women stories in textbooks

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that he supports the inclusion of the historical truth of comfort women during World War II in textbooks, as it is part of Taiwan's history.

Ma made the remarks at a meeting with eight former Taiwanese comfort women -- a euphemism for women who were coerced or abducted by the Japanese military and forced to provide sexual services to its servicemen.

The eight survivors of Japan's sex-slave system visited Ma in the company of Kevin Liao, chairman of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, which has long been striving for justice for the former comfort women.
The former comfort women, including 92-year-old Wu Hsiou-mei and Chen Tao, aged 87, appealed to Ma that the truth about comfort women be formally included in history education.
Ma said he supports their appeal, as accounts of the former Taiwanese comfort women are also part of Taiwan's history and the mistakes of history should not be forgotten.

Ma said the issue of the comfort women is not a racial one but a human rights issue that also involves other Asian countries overrun by the Japanese. He vowed to help the victims demand an apology and compensation from the Japanese government.

Ma said he has developed deep affection for some of former Taiwanese comfort women since he started striving for justice for them in 1997, and he added that he will continue caring about them and providing them with assistance.
During World War II, the Japanese army kidnapped or coerced at least 400,000 women in China, Korea, Taiwan, Indonesia and the Philippines to satisfy its soldiers' sexual needs.
In Taiwan, the estimated number of victims varies from 1,200 to 2,000, but only 58 have been confirmed by the foundation. Now with an average age of 85, there are only 20 still alive.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors appeal again on ex-president's release

TEXT.P: Prosecutors launched a new bid Thursday to detain former President Chen Shui- bian ahead of his trial on a raft of corruption charges.

Prosecutors with the Special Investigation Division (SID) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office launched the bid by re-appealing to the Taiwan High Court against the Taipei District Court's Dec. 18 decision to release Chen on his own recognizance.

It marked the second time the district court had rejected prosecutors' request that Chen continue to be detained after he was indicted Dec. 12 on charges of embezzling government funds and laundering money.
In their Thursday appeal for Chen's detention, prosecutors said they believe Chen might flee Taiwan and conspire with witnesses to tamper with or destroy evidence if he remains free.

Although National Security Bureau (NSB) personnel are obliged to escort Chen all day long to protect him, the prosecutors argued that such an escort is not compulsory and that Chen can easily dodge them.
For instance, prosecutors argued, Chen answered SID subpoenas July 24 and Aug. 15 in the company of staff members of his office instead of NSB bodyguards.
The prosecutors asked the Taiwan High Court to hand down a ruling on their appeal instead of sending the case back to the district court as it did when it dealt with their previous appeal.
The high court was expected to make a decision on the appeal the following day.

In its Dec. 13 ruling, the court ordered that Chen, who was taken into custody by prosecutors Nov. 12, be released without bail following his indictment along with 13 other people on charges of embezzlement, corruption and money laundering. He is Taiwan's first former president to face criminal prosecution.
Chen and his wife are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.12 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opening to Chinese performers will be beneficial: GIO

TEXT.P: Allowing Chinese entertainers to come to Taiwan to act in TV dramas will increase jobs opportunities for locals rather than decrease them, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Vanessa Yea-ping Shih predicted Thursday.
Shih made the remarks one day after announcing that the GIO is mapping out a draft proposal to allow Chinese performers and technicians to work in Taiwan.

"The proposed plan to allow a certain number of Chinese actors and technicians to work on local TV films will not affect the work rights of local performers and technicians. Instead, it will increase job opportunities," she said.

She explained that Taiwan has in the past banned Chinese performers and workers in cross-strait joint-venture TV dramas, resulting in the job opportunities generated, such as set design or extras, all going to China.
She also said that the opening will also help upgrade the development of Taiwan's TV and film industries, saying that if the films are shot in Taiwan, then it will help promote Taiwanese culture.
But lawmakers from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party were unconvinced by Shih's explanation.
DPP lawmaker Yu Tian said the opening will seriously impact Taiwan's entertainment circles, especially since many middle-aged and elderly performers are facing difficulty finding work.
Yu, an entertainer-turned-lawmaker, suggested that the GIO hold public hearings and work out complementary measures.
Two other DPP lawmakers, Kuan Bi-ling and Chen Ting-fei, questioned whether the opening to Chinese entertainers is a precursor to Taiwan's opening to Chinese laborers.
According to Chen, although President Ma Ying-jeou has said he will not open the country to Chinese laborers, Chinese entertainers are in fact Chinese laborers.
"The opening to Chinese entertainers is a water-testing move and if the policy is adopted, then Chinese laborers will follow, " Chen claimed.

Shih said the government will first allow Chinese TV actors to enter Taiwan to work, followed by singers, subject to coordination with the Ministry of Education and the Immigration Agency, and subject to approval by the Mainland Affairs Council.
Opening to Chinese movie actors will require public hearings and will take a longer time, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers' Foundation demands probe into high commodity prices

TEXT.P: The government should look into why domestic commodity prices have not dropped significantly to reflect an average 50 percent fall in prices of major raw materials and grain on the world market, the Consumers' Foundation said Thursday.

Wu Chia-cheng, secretary-general of the Consumers' Foundation, quoted Chicago Mercantile Exchange data as showing that international prices for soybeans and wheat have plunged by 48 percent and 56 percent, respectively, from their peaks recorded earlier this year.
Regrettably, Wu said, domestic prices for relevant products, including cooking oil, flour and bread, have so far not reflected such dramatic falls in international raw material prices.
In his view, Wu said, domestic cooking oil prices should be lowered by up to 56 percent and bread prices should be cut by 30 percent.
Wu urged the Fair Trade Commission and the Executive Yuan's special task force on commodity price stabilization to launch a thorough probe into the issue and work out feasible countermeasures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Build Kinmen into an 'academic island': Taiwanese literati

TEXT.P: Renowned Taiwan-raised modern Chinese poet Cheng Chou-yu called for concerted efforts Thursday to build the outlying island of Kinmen into an "academic island" to attract students from both Taiwan and China.

Speaking at an academic forum held in Kinmen, Cheng, who teaches at the National Kinmen Institute of Technology's (NKIT's) General Education Center and Graduate Institute of Culture and History of South Fujian, urged the Ministry of Education to help NKIT upgrade into a university that can serve as a bedrock for developing the former frontline bastion into an oasis of academia.

Cheng also called for the central government to open Taiwan's doors, including NKIT, to Chinese students, saying that there are too many young men and women in China who cannot enter tertiary education institutes because there are too few such institutes there, while Taiwan's institutes, mostly privately run, have too many vacancies.

The poet added that after NKIT is upgraded to a university, he hopes that a college of general education can be established under the university so that students from Taiwan and China can travel to Kinmen to receive general education there for at least a year.

Also speaking at the forum, Control Yuan member Chou Yang-shan, a former legislator and university professor, urged Taiwan-based universities to branch out to Kinmen, in anticipation that Kinmen is poised to become an academic bridge between China and Taiwan.
NKIT President Lee Chin-chen said that following repeated calls by Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng, the Ministry of Education had recently approved the institute's application to upgrade.
He said that of NKIT's current 2,200 students, 85 percent are from Taiwan, each of whom is entitled to receive NT$14,000 (US$424) per person per year as tuition and transport subsidies.
"We have allocated a much higher budget -- to the tune of NT$130 million -- for 2009 to induce more students from Taiwan and China to study at NKIT," Lee added.

Zhuang Zongming, a professor at Xiamen University who doubles as an assistant to the university's president, said at the forum that the just-launched direct air and sea links across the Taiwan Strait has opened a new era for both sides.

"Kinmen and Xiamen, which are located across a narrow channel of water like two neighboring doors, are now being provided with unlimited opportunities for cultural, education and business exchanges," Zhuang said.

Zhuang said that at present, Chinese colleges and universities treat Taiwanese students the same as local ones, granting them lower tuition charges and dormitory benefits. He added that "Taiwan can do the same as well."

Meanwhile, writer Lung Ying-tai, a chair professor at the University of Hong Kong, called for President Ma Ying-jeou to deliver on his campaign promise to develop Taiwan into an "exporter of Hoklo culture."

"The Hoklo language, or Taiwanese, which derives from southern Fujian Province, should not be restricted to being just an ethnic or political tongue, it should be part of Taiwan's 'soft strength, '" Lung said at the forum.

"Taiwan should pull out all the stops, including making use of the media, to develop itself into a Hoklo culture exporter, as there is a market of 50 million Hoklo-speaking people around the world, " Lung said.

Hoklo commonly refers to those Taiwanese people who claim Han Chinese ancestry from the southern part of Fujian Province. It has a large diaspora in Malaysia, China's Guangdong Province, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Singapore, Burma, Thailand and Indonesia, where they are usually referred to as Hokkien, meaning Fujian in the Minnan language.
In Taiwan, the Hoklos are the largest ethnic group. Most trace their paternal ancestry to men who migrated to Taiwan from Fujian in the 17th and 18th centuries.
Because about 70 percent of the population in Taiwan are Hoklo, Taiwanese is often used interchangeably to describe Hoklo.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT legislator urged to prove loss of U.S. citizenship by Jan. 31

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will see whether ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Ching-an can produce a document certifying the loss of her U.S. citizenship by Jan. 31 before taking any action against her, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday.
Wang also said that the legislature is expecting the U.S. authorities to clarify if Lee lost her U.S. citizenship as early as 1994 when she was first elected to public office in Taiwan.
Wang made the remarks in response to calls by opposition legislators that the legislature should act immediately to remove Lee from her post, claiming that she holds U.S. citizenship.
Lee, who was sworn in to her fourth legislative term Feb. 1, was discovered in March to have never formally renounced her U.S. citizenship.

Dual citizenship is strictly forbidden for public office-holders in Taiwan, and the Nationality Act requires those with dual nationality renounce their foreign citizenship before assuming public office and to obtain a certificate testifying to the loss of citizenship within one year of their inauguration.

Lee admitted that she obtained U.S. citizenship in 1991, but argued that she legally lost her status as a U.S. citizen when she was sworn in as a Taipei city councilor in 1994, citing U.S. law, which lists serving in a foreign government as one of the legal conditions for possible loss of nationality.

Replying to Taiwan's inquiry on the citizenship status of sitting legislators, the U.S. State Department said in a recent letter to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) that Lee "has previously been documented as a U.S. citizen with a U.S. passport and that no subsequent loss of U.S. citizenship has been documented."

The State Department, however, also says that U.S. citizens serving in a foreign government "may have committed an expatriating act if they do so with the intent to relinquish their U.S. nationality."

"While the Department (of State) has not made any determination regarding loss of nationality for the individual named above, it could do so based on evidence that he or she committed a potentially expatriating act with the intention of relinquishing U.S. nationality. Any such determination would be retroactive to the date of the expatriating act," the letter reads.

According to Wang, the MOFA thinks the reply means Lee's U.S. citizenship status is not "ultimately determinative" and has requested that the U.S. side make a further investigation for a more specific answer.

A State Department official stated clearly Wednesday that the U.S. government considers the case closed, but the Legislative Yuan nevertheless passed a resolution Friday to ask the MOFA to request that the U.S. authorities further investigate Lee's citizenship status.

The resolution was adopted without the support of the minority Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which believes the State Department letter confirms Lee's status as a U.S. citizen and that there is no excuse for any further delay in handling the case.
Kuan Bi-ling, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, demanded that the Central Election Commission nullify Lee's four elections as legislator.

Kuan further demanded that the Ministry of the Interior impose an overseas travel ban on Lee and that the Ministry of Justice order a provisional seizure of her assets, adding that if they fail to do so, the DPP will file a complaint with the relevant authorities against the three agencies.

Meanwhile, former DPP Legislator Chiang Chao-yi, who is an accountant, said Lee's salaries from public office in Taiwan are taxable income in the United States and estimated that the tax owed by Lee has exceeded NT$10 million, including interest.
In addition to asking for her removal from the legislative post, the DPP is demanding that Lee surrender salary totaling NT$110 million that she has received from her public office jobs since 1994.

In the face of mounting pressure for her to leave, Lee announced Thursday that she would temporarily step down from office and stop receiving her salary until the U.S. authorities release a "final outcome" of their investigation into her U.S. citizenship status.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Aid for Trade programs cited by WTO

TEXT.P: Aid programs that Taiwan has launched in two of its diplomatic allies have been recognized by the World Trade Organization (WTO) as "successful cases of Aid for Trade, " a non-profit foundation said Friday.

A program launched in Guatemala to help that nation export papayas and another launched in Panama to help produce and export safe vegetables and fruit were cited in a workshop sponsored by the WTO and other global organizations in October, said Chen Lien-chun, secretary-general of the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The workshop was sponsored by the WTO's Committee on Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures (SPS) , the Standards and Trade Development Facility (STDF) and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).

The papaya export program, initiated by a Taiwanese agrotech mission in Guatemala, is an integrated operation ranging from planting papayas and quarantine checks to packaging and export promotion, while the safe vegetables and fruit program, initiated by Taiwan's agrotech mission in Panama, is an operation that uses technology developed by the mission to detect pesticide and chemical residues in locally produced vegetables and fruit before the produce is put on the market, Chen said.
This technology has also helped Panamanian farmers to export their produce, Chen went on.

He noted that the Aid for Trade initiative was first espoused at a WTO ministerial-level meeting held in Hong Kong in 2005 to give financial aid -- via multilateral mechanisms such as the WTO and the World Bank -- to help developing or least-developed countries expand business opportunities and trade prospects.

Aid for Trade has gradually become the mainstay of official development aid (ODA) programs worldwide in recent years, and the Aid for Trade programs that Taiwan has launched have also been incorporated into the ODA system as a core aid strategy, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumption voucher budget bill clears legislature

TEXT.P: Taiwan's legislature on Friday approved the funding bill for a shopping voucher program that the government hopes will stimulate consumption and give a lift to the slumping retail sector.

The special budget bill passed Friday authorized NT$85.65 billion (US$2.58 billion) for the program, slightly less than the NT$85.702 billion requested by the government, and permitted the plan to be fully financed by government-issued debt.
In approving the bill, the Legislative Yuan left authorities enough time to print and prepare NT$3,600 in consumption vouchers for all citizens by the targeted distribution date of Jan. 18, 2009.

Though the government had most of its requested budget approved, lawmakers cut proposed spending on the operation of an information platform, bank processing fees to cash the vouchers, and the cost of contracting state-run Chunghwa Post Co. to distribute the vouchers.

The bill included a number of resolutions related to the program, including one that required that any publicity for the program be free of politically charged language, advertising, hints, or images.

Another resolution allowed diplomatic officials posted overseas and their dependents with Republic of China citizenship to be eligible to receive the vouchers. They were not originally included the plan because they do not have household registrations in Taiwan.
The bill also required that college and university students from middle- and low-income families be hired to help distribute the vouchers.

Under regulations governing the program approved Dec. 5, all Taiwanese citizens born before the end of March 2009 who hold valid household registrations are eligible to receive NT$3,600 in vouchers. They must be used by Sept. 30, 2009.

According to the Ministry of the Interior, the vouchers will be distributed the same way ballots are handed to eligible voters in national elections. The vouchers can be picked up in person at designated distribution centers around the country on Jan. 18 between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m.
Those unable to collect their vouchers that day can pick them up at designated post offices between Feb. 7 and April 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.005 to close at NT$33.025.
A total of US$492 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.05 and fluctuated between NT$32.959 and NT$33.05.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices move higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 11.63 points to close at 4,425.08.
The local bourse opened higher at 4,398.53 and fluctuated between 4,466.75 and 4,396.26. A total of 2.23 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$29.9 billion (US$905.6 million).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals issues moving up the most at 1.45 percent. Cement shares rose 0.94 percent, and machinery and electronics shares were up 0.36 percent.

Foodstuff shares fell 1.19 percent, followed by construction issues, which dropped 1.06 percent. Textile stocks lost 0.47 percent, banking and financial stocks shed 0.38 percent, and paper and pulp issues fell 0.02 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 770 to 581, with 333 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of NT$307 million worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA to set up new offices in China to assist Taiwanese companies

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will set up four new offices in China to help Taiwanese companies based there shift their focus from exports to China's domestic market, TAITRA's chairman said Friday.
Wang Chih-kang, who became chairman of the foreign-trade promoting body in July, announced at a year-end news conference that the agency will add branches in Guangzhou, Nanjing, Dalian and Wuhan.
TAITRA already has offices in Beijing, Shanghai, Qingdao, Chengdu, and Xiamen.

With Taiwan's exports battered by the global economic downturn, Wang said his agency's two main missions for the coming year will be to help Taiwanese companies tap into China's domestic demand and shift Taiwan's target markets from Europe and the United States to emerging markets, such as Russia, the Middle East and Central and South America.
"TAITRA has only one goal and that is to expand exports, " Wang said. "Expanding domestic demand is important, but expanding foreign demand is even more important, especially the market in China."

Wang noted that Taiwan recorded a trade surplus of US$13 billion in the first 11 months of 2008 despite the weak global economy, but warned that surplus had fallen 48 percent from the same period a year earlier.
"This is a scary number that worries us very much," he said.

Although they represent only a small portion of Taiwan's overall trade, emerging markets such as Russia, Central and South America, and Islamic countries are full of potential, Wang said, and will be key targets of TAITRA's trade- promotion efforts.
Wang cited as a source of his optimism the growth in exports to these emerging markets from July to November, when the worldwide financial tsunami hit the hardest.
Total exports to the markets totaled US$360 million during the period, with shipments to Brazil and Saudi Arabia growing by 91.93 and 84.01 percent, respectively, year-on-year.
"This indeed greatly boosted our confidence, " Wang said, adding that TAITRA has already deployed staff in these countries to handle related business.

Founded in 1970 to help promote foreign trade, TAITRA is a non- profit trade promotion organization in Taiwan jointly sponsored by the government, industry associations, and several commercial organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st direct flight from Chengdu to Taipei arrives

TEXT.P: A Sichuan Airlines flight, carrying 87 passengers, landed at Taipei Songshan Airport from Chengdu Friday afternoon, the first direct nonstop passenger charter from Sichuan to Taiwan since air links between Taiwan and China were expanded on Dec. 15.

The Sichuan Airlines flight, an Airbus A320 single-aisle jetliner, was piloted by Captain Chang Lu-chen, a native Taiwanese who formerly worked for Taiwan's TransAsia Airways, according to the Chengdu-based carrier.

The inaugural A320 flight was dubbed "Gan En, " meaning "gratitude, " and had characters reading "Sichuan's people thank Taiwan compatriots for their unselfish aid following the May 12 earthquake" painted on the body of the aircraft.
Taiwan's people donated huge sums of money to help Sichuan respond to and recover from the devastating magnitude 8.0 earthquake that struck the province in mid-May.

Most of the flight attendants were dressed in attire worn by China's indigenous peoples. Two others donned giant panda cartoon dresses, in recognition of the pair of pandas that arrived in Taipei from Sichuan Dec. 23 as tokens of China's friendship.
Meanwhile, the menu on the flight included twice-cooked pork, the most popular Sichuan dish, and san-bei chicken, one of the most representative Taiwanese dishes.
The A320 aircraft is scheduled to leave Taipei for a return flight to Chengdu at around 6 p.m. Friday, with 74 Taiwanese passengers on board.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices drop on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved down Friday, with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for January losing 18 points to close at 4,378, with 68,148 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for February fell 21 points to close at 4,350, with 148 contracts traded, while March futures were down five points to end at 4,325, with 45 contracts traded.
June futures were up eight points to close at 4,306, with seven contract transactions, while September futures declined eight points to end at 4,112, with 13 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,396 for January, 4,371 for February, 4,330 for March, 4,298 for June, and 4,120 for September.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index moved up 11.63 points to finish at 4,425.08, on turnover of NT$29.9 billion (US$905.6 million).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were both lower.
January TE futures fell 0.65 points to close at 165.5, with 2,925 contracts traded, while February TE futures advanced 0.25 points to finish at 164.55, with nine contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June and September.
January TF futures were down 3.8 points to close at 559.4, with 2,478 contracts changing hands, while February TF futures decreased three points to finish at 556.6, with 16 contracts traded.
March TF futures dropped one point to finish at 553.4 with one contract changing hands. No transactions were recorded for the other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Underprivileged groups given tickets to Cirque du Soleil show

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government and several enterprises donated tickets Friday to underprivileged children and art students to see the world renowned Cirque du Soleil, which will perform in Taiwan for the first time early next year.
Before main the event, the entertainment company will perform the show "Alegria" on January 13, mainly for about 800 underprivileged people.

"In these times of economic hardship, the donation of tickets is truly an encouragement (to underprivileged children)," said Yang Jen-feng, who represented the United Daily News Group, the main organizer of the Taipei tour by the Canadian company. Among other sponsors, the Taipei City Government donated 520 tickets to children from orphanages and halfway houses.
The Taipei-based Chinatrust Charity Foundation also invited 60 children, who have long-term sponsorship, to see the show.
A financial institution, the ING Group, donated 50 tickets for online auction and the proceeds will be used to pay for underprivileged children to attend the show.
Also, Far Eastern Group, one of the sponsors of Cirque du Soleil's tour of Taipei, will invite around 100 dance and theater students from low-income households to attend the performance.

The Quebec-based Cirque du Soleil is scheduled to perform its classic show "Alegria " -- Spanish for 'joy' -- in January and February next year in Taipei. The company's shows usually feature acrobatics and dazzling costumes that are the hallmark of top notch circus performances, but also incorporate a wide element of theater.
Cirque's will pitch its famous "Grand Chapiteau," a large tent that can seat around 2,500 spectators, on January 7 next year for the first time in Taipei.
The show was first staged in 1994 in Montreal and has been performed in 65 cities worldwide, attracting more than 10 million spectators, according to the organizers.
Taiwanese fans have not balked at the high admission prices for the show, paying NT$1, 900 to NT$7,000 (US$57.50 to US$212) for the tickets, which are almost sold out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Beer to hit Chinese market in 2009

TEXT.P: Taiwan Beer, the leading beer brand in Taiwan, will be marketed in China next year, the Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. (TTLC) said Friday.

According to TTLC Chairman Wei Po-tao, Chinese authorities have completed screening of Taiwan Beer's application for trademark registration and will announce its official approval of the trademark on Feb. 6.
Wei predicted that the new market will help increase the beer's total sales by 10 percent, or NT$3 billion, next year.
As of the end of November 2008, Taiwan Beer had seized an 81 percent share of Taiwan's beer market, with its revenue expected to reach NT$26 billion for the year, Wei said.

TTLC President Hsu An-hsuan said that in the initial stage, Taiwan Beer's marketing in China will focus on canned products exported directly from Taiwan and will target consumers in the southern provinces of Fujian and Guangdong, whose food preferences are similar to those of Taiwanese consumers.

In the future, the company will develop various beer flavors to cater to the preferences of local consumers in southern China, central China and northern China, and will outsource the production to Chinese manufacturers or establish partnership with them, Hsu said.
According to the TTLC, the beer will have the same packaging in China as it does in Taiwan, except that simplified Chinese characters will be used on the labels.

DOC.HEADLINE: Welfare groups to treat 12,000 underprivileged people to dinner

TEXT.P: Three social welfare foundations that usually organize a year-end dinner for the homeless and other underprivileged people, said Friday that in light the hardships brought on by the current economic slump, they will increase the number of table places to 12,000.

Wu Wan-lan, who heads the department of social resources and public relations of the Zenan Homeless Social Welfare Foundation, told the Central News Agency that the foundations plan to provide 1,200 tables at the year-end dinner, which means it will be almost twice as large as the last one.
The dinner is usually held at the end of the lunar year, which falls early in the new year of the Western calendar.

The Zenan foundation, along with the Huashan Social Welfare Foundation and the Genesis Social Welfare Foundation, in February 2008 provided 808 tables at which they seated the needy, the homeless, elderly people who live alone, and people from low-income households, in a festive atmosphere.

Due to the increasingly high unemployment rate and general economic downturn, it is likely that more people will be needing the free dinner that is expected to be hosted Jan. 24 next year, the day before the Chinese New Year's eve, Wu said.

She further noted that the number of people who go to the foundation's centers around the island for free lunches and dinners every day has increased by 20 percent compared to the same period last year.
"All the new faces are middle-aged and even younger people, " Wu said. "They have lost their jobs and cannot find another one at the moment."
Half of those who go to the centers for free meals are jobless, while the rest are disabled and elderly people, she added.

The number of needy people in Taiwan is rapidly increasing, she said, citing the foundation's statistics that showed it provided meals, counselling and employment services to about 200,000 people at its centers islandwide in 2006, while from January to October this year the figure was 420,000.

Wu said that although 60 percent of the funds for the year-end meal has already been donated by individuals and groups, she is urging people to donate their shopping vouchers or other resources, such as winter clothes and sleeping bags, which are indispensable to homeless people in winter.

The government is launching an 85.6-billion project to distribute shopping vouchers to all Taiwan citizens on January 18 next year, in the hope of stimulating consumption and boosting economic growth. Taiwan citizens and their foreign spouses will each receive NT$3,600 (US$109) worth of vouchers.
People who wish to make donations to the charity foundation can call (02) 2836-1600, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 7th Taoyuan National Book Exhibition to open Dec. 31

TEXT.P: The seventh Taoyuan National Book Exhibition will open Dec. 31 in Taoyuan County Arena for a six-day run, with 38 of Taiwan's major publishing companies operating more than 100 stalls.

Taoyuan County Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu will formally open the annual fair during a gala night on New Year's Eve, and visitors will be treated to six hours of entertainment lasting until after midnight into 2009.
According to the county government's Cultural Affairs Bureau, the organizer of the event, many exhibitors will hold drawings for NT$3,600 book vouchers and off NT$3,600 value packages.
The NT$3,600 is a play on the central government's voucher program, in which NT$3,600 in shopping vouchers will be issued to all citizens Jan. 18 in a bid to stimulate Taiwan's economy.
Ten renowned writers and three experts with different specialties will be invited to speak on various subjects during the exhibition.

In addition to the book exhibition, the county government will set up four theme areas to demonstrate the county's cultural pluralism, and to introduce the county to the public as an "aviation city," as the place housing the mausoleums of late presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo, and as a county renowned for its thousands of agricultural irrigation ponds.

The county government will provide free shuttle bus service to carry visitors from the Taoyuan rail station to the exhibition venue. The weekend bus runs begin from 9:30 a.m. and the weekday schedule starts from 12:30 p.m., with service every 20 minutes.
Exhibitions in previous years have drawn between 200,000 and 300,000 visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indigenous Atayal children experience university life for a day

TEXT.P: A dozen indigenous children from the Atayal tribe were invited Friday to attend a general education course at National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu City, an experience educators hoped will inspire them to become university students.

Organized by Tsing Hua University professors Huang Yi-nung and Wang Chun-hsiu and entering its third year, the charity project is part of their general education course called "crossing boundaries and exploring, " which aims to encourage children to take action and pursue their dreams.

The course consists of a first assignment, a mid-term exam and a final. The first assignment is a "field trip of life, " in which students have to interview one of their family members and tell their story based on an old picture.
The mid-term requires students to pursue a small personal dream, such as climbing the tallest mountain in Taiwan or talking to a foreigner in English for two hours.
The final exam asks a group of five to eight students to accomplish a common dream, and experiencing life as university students for a day on Friday was one of the group's dreams.

Compressing university life into a one-day activity, the Atayal children first registered and received their student ID and then were joined by university students to tour the campus, dorms and library, and attend general education courses and extra-curricular activities.
At the end of the day, the children received a certificate for their efforts.
"The children's joy and sense of humor affected our university students and they actually learned from each other," Wang said.
He added that this is just a start because an adoption mechanism is being mapped out for university students to play a role in encouraging indigenous children to complete their education.
University students can also visit indigenous tribes to experience a different kind of learning, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic indicators drop to lowest point in nearly seven years

TEXT.P: The monitoring score for Taiwan's economic indicators in November dropped one point from the previous month to 11 -- the lowest score in nearly seven years, according to a report released by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Friday.
A blue light continued to flash for the third consecutive month, indicating the economy is mired in a recession.

The CEPD uses five colors to measure domestic economic health, with "red" indicating serious overheating, "yellow-red" for slight overheating, "green" for steady growth, "yellow-blue" for a slowdown and "blue" for recession.
The composite index of leading indicators -- a barometer for the economy's outlook in the coming three months -- fell by 0.8 percent from the previous month to 110.3.
Hung Jui-bin, director-general of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, attributed the worsening results to continuing slumps in external trade, consumption and financial activities.

With leading indicators in many industrial countries also falling, and exports slumping dramatically, domestic consumption slowing and unemployment rising, Taiwan will have a hard time extracting itself from the recession in the near future, Huang warned.
The index of coincident indicators, which represents the current economic situation, stood at 92.1 in November, down 5.8 percent from the previous month, according to the CEPD report.

DOC.HEADLINE: China should dismantle missiles pointed at Taiwan: MAC committee

TEXT.P: The Consultative Committee of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said recently that China should, as soon as possible, dismantle its missiles that are pointed at Taiwan and stop boycotting Taiwan's participation in international organizations.

The 169th consultative committee meeting of the MAC on Wednesday agreed that, alongside the recent closer economic ties forged with China, the Taiwan government should also find ways to fight for Taiwan's dignity and international space.
Taiwan should also urge China to take the initiative to show its willingness to further improve the bilateral relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the committee suggested.

The committee members said that China should understand very well feelings of the Taiwanese people, and in the interest of further promoting positive interaction between the two sides, should remove its missiles that are aimed at Taiwan.
Reports have put the number of ballistic missiles deployed along China's east coast and targeting Taiwan at more than 1,000.

Turning to the recent launch of direct air and shipping links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, some members of the committee said that the links should not be seen as a panacea for Taiwan's economic woes.
In touting the recent economic cooperative efforts between the
two sides, the Taiwan government should emphasize that they are part of the process of normalizing bilateral cross-strait ties, the committee members advised.

Meanwhile, the ruling party Kuomintang (KMT) and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should find ways to resolve their differences and reach some agreement on cross-strait policy, as meaningless debates and accusations between the two parties will neither win the public's support nor serve the best interests of Taiwan, the majority of committee members said.
The committee members urged the MAC not to be swayed by any particular party of interest group, as its role is to serve as a platform for communication and negotiations on cross-strait matters.

However, the MAC also has a role to promote and strengthen interaction between the ruling and opposition parties in order to be able to design proper and unbiased policies in the future, the committee said.

As for the just-concluded forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (PCP), the committee members said that was held in a period of transition and that the future necessity of a such a forum should be discussed among the ruling and opposition parties and non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmaker surrenders party rights over dual citizenship issue

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) surrendered her party rights Friday, pending clarification of her dual citizenship issue.

Legislator Lee Ching-an informed the KMT in a written notice that effective immediately, she has temporarily given up her party rights and will refrain from taking part in any activities of the KMT legislative caucus until the dispute over her dual citizenship issue is resolved.

The KMT's head office later confirmed it had received the notice and had agreed to her decision. It urged the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to contact the U.S. government to clarify the issue as soon as possible.
In a separate notice to the legislature, Lee said that with immediate effect, she will not accept any salary from the legislature.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng indicated earlier in the day that the legislature will wait until Jan. 31 to see whether Lee can produce a document certifying the loss of her U.S. citizenship, before considering the next move.
Wang said the legislature was expecting U.S. authorities to clarify whether Lee had lost her U.S. citizenship as early as 1994 when she was first elected to public office in Taiwan.
The dual citizenship issue surfaced in March with reports that Lee, sworn in to her fourth legislative term Feb. 1, had never formally renounced her U.S. citizenship.

Taiwan's Nationality Act requires all public office holders with dual nationality to renounce their foreign citizenship. Within one year of being sworn in, they must submit a certificate certifying the loss of their foreign citizenship, the act stipulates.

Lee, who obtained U.S. citizenship in 1991, contended that she legally lost her status as a U.S. citizen when she was first sworn in as a Taipei city councilor in 1994. She cited U.S. law, which lists serving in a foreign government as one of the legal conditions for losing U.S. nationality.

Replying to Taiwan's inquiry on the citizenship status of sitting legislators, the U.S. State Department said in a recent letter to the foreign ministry that Lee "has previously been documented as a U.S. citizen with a U.S. passport and that no subsequent loss of U.S. citizenship has been documented."

The State Department, however, also said that U.S. citizens serving in a foreign government "may have committed an expatriating act if they do so with the intent to relinquish their U.S. nationality."

"While the Department (of State) has not made any determination regarding loss of nationality for the individual named above, it could do so based on evidence that he or she committed a potentially expatriating act with the intention of relinquishing U.S. nationality. Any such determination would be retroactive to the date of the expatriating act," the letter reads.

Although a State Department official said the U.S. government now considers the case closed, the Taipei government still sees Lee's U.S. citizenship status as not "ultimately determinative" and is requesting that the U.S. give a clear-cut answer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic planner pitches for gambling industry on offshore islands

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic planning authorities announced Friday that it supports allowing casinos as part of leisure resorts on the country's outlying islands, including Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) made the announcement at its year-end news conference, with CEPD Vice Chairman Huang Wan-hsiang assessing that the new industry will create approximately 5,000 jobs, and 15,000-25,000 indirect employment opportunities.

The long debate on whether or not to allow the development of the gambling business in Taiwan concluded Friday, with the government agreeing that gambling facilities will be allowed, but only if they are part of a comprehensive leisure resort.
According to a government survey conducted in July, 44 percent of the population support the idea of lifting the ban on casinos while 36 percent oppose it.
Among the proponents, 44 percent said gambling facilities should be established only on the outlying islands, while 9 percent said they should also be allowed on Taiwan proper.

Among the residents on the outlying islands who were polled, 47 percent expressed support for the proposal, while 36 percent were opposed to it. Among those in support of the idea, 45 percent said casinos should be allowed on the outlying islands.
CEPD officials concluded that the majority of residents on Taiwan proper and on the outlying islands agree that the islets should be opened to the gambling business.
At the press conference, CEPD Chairman Chen Tain-jy said that as soon as gambling is legalized in the country, the administration will allow casinos to be established first on the outlying islands.
An amendment to lift the ban on gambling businesses on the outlying islands is in a long line of bills backed up in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Another ex-president being probed over alleged money laundering

TEXT.P: A leading prosecutor of the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office confirmed Friday that his office is looking into allegations of money laundering by former President Lee Teng-hui.
Chen Yun-nan, the chief of the division, said the case has been referred to prosecutor Lin Che-hui for investigation, in collaboration with other prosecutors from the division.

Chen, whose division was catapulted into the limelight when it indicted ex- President Chen Shui-bian on money-laundering, forgery and corruption charges Dec. 12, also confirmed news reports that the most recent probe resulted from information provided by Chen Shui-bian.

In testimony given Sept. 5 to the Taipei Prosecutors Office in its investigation of former Investigation Bureau Chief Yeh Sheng-mao, Chen Shui-bian reportedly claimed that his predecessor Lee had engaged in money laundering while in office.
Chen Shiu-bian said Lee has used the bank accounts of at least four bodyguards to launder US$56 million.
As Lee is a former head of state, the information was referred to the Special Investigation Division which is responsible for investigations involving senior officials.

Yeh was sentenced to 10 years in prison by the Taipei District Court on Dec. 4 for warning Chen Shui-bian that his alleged money laundering via overseas banks had come to the attention of the international anti-money laundering enterprise, the Egmont Group.
However, one of Chen Shui-bian's attorneys said that the prosecutors were investigating Lee on their own initiative rather than on a tip-off by Chen Shui- bian.

Meanwhile Lin Chih-chia, secretary-general of the Taiwan Solidarity Union of which Lee is the spiritual leader, said Chen Shui-bian is trying to distract public attention from his own offenses and is using the allegations against Lee as a red herring.
Lin urged the prosecutors to clear Lee's reputation as soon as possible by conducting a thorough investigation into the allegations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to revitalize 60,000 hectares of fallow land

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural authorities plan to revitalize 60,000 hectares of fallow farmland in 2009 to increase food production, a senior agriculture official disclosed Friday.

Yu Sheng-feng, deputy director-general of the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said the plan to revitalize the fallow land has been submitted to the Cabinet for consideration.
Noting that Taiwan currently has 220,000 hectares of farmland lying idle, Yu said his agency hopes to allow food crops to be grown on 60,000 hectares of that land.

The plan would allow subsidies of NT$50,000 per hectare each year for the owner of the farmland -- higher than the NT$45,000 paid by the government to the owners not to farm the land. Of the NT$50,000 subsidy, NT$40,000 will be paid by the government, while the remaining NT$10,000 will come from the tenant farmers, according to Yu.

The Council of Agriculture has been working on a program to increase Taiwan's rice farming by 20,000 hectares in order to raise the national rice reserves from 300,000 metric tons in 2008 to 400,000 metric tons in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 27, or the first day of the 12th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1571: Johannes Kepler, German astronomer and mathematician, is born. Considered the founder of modern astronomy, he formulated three laws to clarify the theory that the planets revolve around the sun.
1822: Louis Pasteur, French chemist and bacteriologist who founded modern microbiology, is born. He invented the process of pasteurization and developed vaccines for anthrax, rabies and chicken cholera.
1831: Under the command of Capt. Robert Fitzroy, the Royal Navy's HMS Beagle sets sail from Devonport, England, on a five-year voyage of scientific exploration around the world.
1927: Leon Trotsky, Russian revolutionary theoretician, is expelled form the Soviet Communist Party for his opposition to the authoritarianism of Stalin and for his emphasis on world revolution.
1945: The International Monetary Fund is set up in Washington, D.C.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Chengtu, the capital of Szechwan Province.
1949: Ahmed Sukarno, leader of the Indonesian Nationalist Party, returns to Batavia (Jakarta) after A.H.J. Lovink, representative of the Netherlands government, signed a protocol transferring sovereignty to an Indonesian delegation.
1958: More than 10,000 Tibetans die in armed resistance against Communist Chinese atrocities.
1959: Japanese Prime Minister Shegeru Yoshida visits Taipei.
1969: Egypt, Sudan and Libya agree to the formation of a political, economic and military alliance.
1972: Lester Pearson, the former Canadian prime minister who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1957 for his part in settling the Suez crisis in 1956, dies at the age of 75.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Chad.
1975: Ten people are honored by the Young Entrepreneurs Association in Taipei for their inventions.
1975: The First International Children's Camp opens for two days of activities sponsored by the Camping Association of the Republic of China.
1975: The ROC's Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen announces it had given aid to 251,563 former servicemen as of the end of November.
1976: Jacques Baumel, member of the National Assembly of France, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1976: Dr. Charles E. Bishop, president of the University of Arkansas, and Rev. Malcolm Carron, president of the University of Detroit, arrive in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1978: Some 10,000 people demonstrate at the airport when a delegation led by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrives in Taipei for talks after the United States severed diplomatic relations with Taipei in favor of Beijing.
1979: Afghan President Hafizullah Amin is executed by the Soviets. Babrak Karmal, a former deputy prime minister in exile in Czechoslovakia, is installed in his place.
1980: Twenty-two supplementary members are elected to Taiwan's Control Yuan from among 54 candidates by members of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, the Taipei City Council and the Kaohsiung City Council.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government issues its last lottery tickets.
1995: France stages the fifth in a series of nuclear weapon tests in the South Pacific.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan expresses his appreciation to Chinese-Japanese baseball star Sadaharu Oh for his active efforts after the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake hit Taiwan Sept. 21.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou says that the current political instability mainly results from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's failure to respect the Republic of China Constitution and its "one China" spirit.
2001: The National Taiwan Museum in Taipei represents an exhibition introducing the achievements of the late Dr. Joseph Needham (1900-1995) and the British scholar's contributions to Chinese and world civilization.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Gentlemen, why should you be concerned at your present want of official position! The world has long been without the order and justice of good government; now God is going to make use of your teacher as a tocsin to awaken the world." ENDITEM Today in history
