An amendment to lift the ban on gambling businesses on the outlying islands is in a long line of bills backed up in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to revitalize 60,000 hectares of fallow land

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural authorities plan to revitalize 60,000 hectares of fallow farmland in 2009 to increase food production, a senior agriculture official disclosed Friday.

Yu Sheng-feng, deputy director-general of the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said the plan to revitalize the fallow land has been submitted to the Cabinet for consideration.
Noting that Taiwan currently has 220,000 hectares of farmland lying idle, Yu said his agency hopes to allow food crops to be grown on 60,000 hectares of that land.

The plan would allow subsidies of NT$50,000 per hectare each year for the owner of the farmland -- higher than the NT$45,000 paid by the government to the owners not to farm the land. Of the NT$50,000 subsidy, NT$40,000 will be paid by the government, while the remaining NT$10,000 will come from the tenant farmers, according to Yu.

The Council of Agriculture has been working on a program to increase Taiwan's rice farming by 20,000 hectares in order to raise the national rice reserves from 300,000 metric tons in 2008 to 400,000 metric tons in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County tilapia receives certification

TEXT.P: A fish farming group in the southern county of Tainan received two certifications for the quality of its tilapia, Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih announced Saturday.

The group, consisting of 11 fish farmers with a combined aquaculture area of 50.06 hectares, received ISO 22000 certification for food safety management from Australia and the Taiwan Good Agricultural Practice from Taiwan, Su said.
Su said the group went through strict process and standards in controlling and improving its tilapia farming in order to get the two certifications.
Group leader Chen Lien-yi, who is also the president of the county's Nan Ying Aquaculture Association, said the aquaculturists worked very hard to get the certifications.

Su said the group will need to make continuous efforts to make sure the certifications are renewed every year, and he added that it is also working on obtaining GlobalGAP, a certification necessary for exporting Taiwanese tilapia to the European Union.

He expressed hope that the two certifications will help increase the tilapia selling price in both local and foreign markets, and said the county government will help the aquaculturists with marketing to create a niche market for safe and healthy Taiwanese tilapia that are a cut above cheaper tilapia sold by other countries.
The county has about 2,260 hectares given over to tilapia, with annual production of 26,317 tons worth NT$791.6 million (US$23.9 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO to cooperate with Michelin Guide in publishing Taiwan guide

TEXT.P: Taiwan will cooperate with Michelin -- the French publisher of the acclaimed Le Guide Michelin -- to publish a guidebook for Taiwan in both French and English, a Government Information Office (GIO) official said Saturday.

Manfred Peng, director of the GIO's Department of International Information, revealed that tourism, pop music and gourmet cuisine in Taiwan will be the major themes in the government's publicity plan for 2009.

Sealing a contract with Michelin to promote tourism in Taiwan will be the GIO's first task in 2009, Peng went on, noting that it is the Michelin Guide's international approach and professionalism that persuaded the office to cooperate with the publisher.

Addressing the GIO's publicity policy, Peng stated that unlike the previous Democratic Progressive Party government, which concentrated on publicizing Taiwan's political situation and its bids for membership of international organizations, the ruling Kuomintang administration thinks Taiwan's cultural side is equally worthy of promotion on the international stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pandas expected to get used to Taiwan soon: Taipei Zoo

TEXT.P: The pair of giant pandas that arrived at the Taipei Zoo from China early this week is expected to get used to their new environment in a couple of weeks, despite a slight drop in their weights, an official said Saturday.
According to Lin Hua-ching, head of the zoo's conservation center, Tuan Tuan -- the male panda -- is more active at night than Yuan Yuan, his female companion.
Although they are eating more compared with when they just arrived, the animals' weights have dropped by nearly four kilograms, he said.

He attributed the weight loss to an increase in physical activity as a result of their exploring the new environment and a decrease in appetite because of nervousness and anxiety toward their new surroundings. The situation should not be a cause for concern as long as the weight loss remains within a normal range and the pandas remain energetic, he added.
In a bid to lessen the animals' anxiety, the zoo has included in their diet fresh bamboo from their original habitat in China's Sichuan Province, Lin said.
However, the zoo will not import any more of the bamboo from Sichuan because the pandas are adapting well to Taiwanese bamboo, he went on.
The pandas, which were delivered to the zoo Dec. 23, are a gift from China.

The zoo has said it is working toward the goal of opening its new panda house to the public in a month's time, as the animals are required to stay in quarantine for a minimum of 30 days after their arrival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan donates rice to Kiribati

TEXT.P: Taiwan has recently donated 200 metric tons of rice to Kiribati in a bid to help relieve a food shortage in the Pacific nation, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday.
The rice, which was handed over to the Kiribati government on Christmas Eve, is intended for distribution to hospitals, clinics and public boarding schools, MOFA officials said.

The officials quoted Republic of China Ambassador to Kiribati Chen Shih-liang as saying that the rice arrived just in time for Christmas and demonstrates Taiwan's care and friendship for the people of Kiribati.
In the future, Taiwan agricultural missions will continue to promote farming, stockraising and aquaculture in Kiribati to help resolve the country's food shortage, the officials said.
According to the MOFA, few crops are grown in Kiribati because the country is comprised mainly of coral atolls, and the people there rely heavily on imported rice.
As a result, soaring global food prices earlier this year have seriously impacted the Pacific island nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Guest House to open Jan. 1

TEXT.P: The Baroque-style Taipei Guest House, a century-old national historical landmark, will open to the public from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Jan. 1 to coincide with various government-held New Year celebrations, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Saturday.

Visitors are required to present identification documents in order to be allowed entry and advised to show up before 3: 30 p.m., when the latest admissions will be allowed, according to the announcement.
As part of efforts to protect the historical compound, the ministry warned that photography will be prohibited and that certain areas will be off-limits to visitors.
Traffic controls in the surrounding area will be imposed, as the nearby Presidential Office will also be opened to the public on that day, the ministry added.

Meanwhile, in order to meet growing visitor demand, the MOFA also announced that it will open the guest house once per month starting January -- double the 2008 opening times -- and estimated that the move will attract approximately 60,000 visitors throughout next year.
Cultural and public welfare groups, as well as architecture departments of universities will also be permitted to visit the compound after submitting applications to the ministry, the MOFA went on.

Members of the public will no longer be required to make reservations to visit, the ministry said, adding that visitors will, however, need to provide identification documents and submit to security checks.
The Taipei Guest House, designed by Japanese architects and completed in 1901, used to serve as the residence of the governor-general during the Japanese occupation.

Its name was changed to its current one in 1950 and it is now used to receive state guests or hold national banquets, meetings or other events. It has been opened to the public on a bi-monthly basis since July 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Experts warn of risk of cross-strait economic cooperation

TEXT.P: The government should take notice of the risks involved in cross-Taiwan Strait economic and financial cooperation and map out precautionary measures to deal with adverse circumstances, economic scholars and former government officials said Saturday.

Taiwan Stock Exchange former Chairman Wu Rong-i, Financial Supervisory Commission former Chairman Shih Chun-chi, Mega Holdings former General Manager Tung Rei-bin, National Central University Professor Chiu Chun-jung and Chen Po- chih, chairman of the Taiwan Thinktank -- a pro-independence non-government think tank -- made the remarks at a symposium held in Taipei.
The symposium, titled "Honey or Knife? The Effects and Consequences of Cross-Taiwan Strait Economic and Financial Cooperation" was the first of four sessions of the Taiwan Thinktank Forum.

Chen said that as all policies have their pros and cons, one should conduct risk assessment and take precautions or countermeasures to minimize the harm such policies might cause. However, he claimed, the government has only focused on the benefits of economic and financial cooperation with China while neglecting the potential risks and possible consequences that might occur in the long term.
"If someone wants to eat honey on a knife, at least you have to let them know that he might get hurt," Chen said.

Noting that 40 percent of Taiwan's total exports are China-bound and that shipments to China suffered a dramatic 38 percent drop in November, Chen said this has significantly impacted the country's economy. "It is like putting all your eggs in one basket," he said.

Noting that a financial memorandum of understanding (MOU) covering the banking and securities sectors might be inked during the next round of cross-strait talks, Shih said Taiwanese banks will not stand on an equal footing with their Chinese counterparts in terms of market opportunities because the scales of Chinese banks are much bigger than Taiwanese ones.

He cautioned that the signing of such an MOU will be in China's favor because according to Chinese regulations, only about 10 Taiwanese banks will be able to meet the thresholds for setting up branches and will not be allowed to accept renminbi deposits for three years after their establishment, placing severe restrictions on their profitability.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County recycling, river cleaning show achievements

TEXT.P: The southern county of Tainan has performed well in terms of environmental protection, as its resource recycling rate continues to increase while its river-cleaning efforts have helped cut pollution, a local official said Saturday.

Chiang Shih-min, director-general of the county's Bureau of Environmental Protection, said the county's recycling rate increased from 10.6 percent in 2004 to 11.22 percent in 2007, with this year's figure predicted to reach 30 percent.

In 2007, the county's resource recycling created NT$26.8 million (US$81,126) of revenue and saved NT$29.85 million in incineration expenses, creating a total economic benefit of more than NT$56 million, Chiang said.

According to another official of the same department, the county has reduced the polluted reaches of the Erren River from 4.91 km to 3. 53 km by carrying out a series of pollution control and prevention projects.
Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih designated 2007 as the county's river-cleaning year to focus on these efforts, the official noted.
The projects included setting up a river patrol of 190 volunteers to gather evidence on river pollutions and increasing the frequency of government inspections on river polluters.
The county has also established an electronic river pollution map and a fingerprint archive to facilitate its pollution inspection efforts, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister backs state enterprises venturing overseas

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming voiced his support Friday for state- run businesses expanding their overseas markets after the country's oil refiner -- CPC Corp., Taiwan -- signed four cooperation agreements on oil exploration with its Chinese counterpart earlier that day.

Yiin said the government-run companies' moves to explore trade opportunities in foreign countries, including China, will win government support as long as they hold the core technologies and invest according to regulations.
In addition to CPC, Taiwan Sugar Corp. has also registered its trademark in China in preparation for making inroads into that vast market with its population of over 1.3 billion people.

Earlier that day, CPC Chairman Wenent Pan and Fu Chengyu, general manager of the Beijing-based China National Offshore Oil Corp. (CNOOC) signed agreements that include a letter of intent for closer cooperation in oil exploration, market expansion, technical exchanges and personnel training.

The two enterprises also agreed to extend a contract on joint exploration in the Tainan Basin in the Taiwan Strait and the Chaozhou-Shantou Basin off the coast of southern China's Guangdong Province until Dec. 31, 2010, as well as agreeing on a joint study of the Nanjihtao Basin near the midline of the strait and a transfer of a 30 percent stake of CNOOC's onshore Block 9 in Kenya to CPC.

The CPC-CNOOC cooperation in oil exploration began in 1998 with the start of a joint venture in the Tainan Basin and the Chaozhou-Shantou Basin and continued with the establishment of their first joint well in the strait in 2002.
According to CPC, it also refined crude oil under contract from CNOOC -- China's largest offshore oil and gas producer -- in the early 2000s.

China has a greater demand for diesel than for other oil products, while Taiwan has a bigger demand for gasoline, so that CNOOC's payment for CPC refining -- paid in the form of gasoline -- was a win-win situation, CPC said.
The cooperation ended after international crude oil prices began surging and domestic demand for CPC products increased, according to CPC.
However, the company stressed that it will boost cooperation with CNOOC in the future on business that is mutually beneficial.

DOC.HEADLINE: CCA pledges to promote cultural, creative industry internationally

TEXT.P: Council of Cultural Affairs (CCA) Minister Huang Pi-twan said Saturday that the CCA will invest NT$5 billion (US$1.5 billion) over the next four years to promote the transformation of Taiwan's cultural and creative industry and market it to the international community.

Huang made the remarks at the 2008 Taiwan Cultural and Creative Industry Summit, in which she discussed with 11 representatives from local and foreign cultural industry and academic sectors how to turn Taiwan into a center for the cultural and creative industry.

The summit, which took place at National Taiwan Normal University, was attended by Han Pao-teh, honorary curator of the Taipei County-based Museum of World Religions, and Chen Li-heng, chairman of Franz Porcelain Co.

"Creative elements can be easily found in many small streets in Taiwan and are full of potential, " Huang said. "However, we still require an overall plan to integrate and develop the various sectors of the cultural and creative industry in Taiwan, which the CCA is willing to provide assistance with," she added.

In a recent discussion about the beauty of Taiwan with noted theater director Stan Lai, movie director Hou Hsiao-hsien and Lin Hwai-min, founder of Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, Huang said one view these people share is that Taiwan is such a lovely place that many foreigners who visit the island fall in love with it.

According to Huang, people can find the beauty of Taiwan from the friendliness of Taiwanese, the gourmet food, and cultural diversions such as theater. She said many international visitors enjoy simply walking the streets because every now and then they can find lovely small shops or cafes, making a stroll full of surprises.

Han said the appreciation of beauty needs to be cultivated from school age and suggested that courses be set up to increase young people's aesthetic perceptions and creativity. By so doing, he said, Taiwan's cultural and creativity industry will become more competitive on the international stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County continues providing addicts with clean needles

TEXT.P: Tainan County in southern Taiwan is continuing to provide clean hypodermic needles at street vending machines and convenience stores for drug addicts in an effort to curb the spread of AIDS, a local health official said Saturday.

The official said the county started providing clean needles in June 2007 and was the first local government to adopt the measure to stop addicts from sharing needles, which is a common way for the AIDS virus to spread.
According to Tainan Deputy Magistrate Yen Chun-tzuo, the county government provided about 520,000 clean needles from last June to this May, 28 percent of which were recycled after use.
Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih said providing clean needles is only part of the county's efforts to combat drug addiction and AIDS infection.
The county also offers methadone replacement therapy at local health centers to heroin addicts with the aim of reducing heroin addiction, Su said.
Methadone is synthetic form of opiate given to heroin addicts to reduce withdrawal symptoms when coming off heroin.
The health official said the county started offering the therapy in 2006 and has benefited more 220,000 people in the county, with three hospitals and five therapy centers providing the drugs.
The county's efforts have taken it to second place in terms of last year's national drug prevention performance, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president condemns corrupt politicians, supporters

TEXT.P: Taiwan's strength is being sapped not only by corrupt politicians but also by their supporters, former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday.

Speaking at the annual meeting of the Chiayi chapter of the Friends of Lee Teng- hui Association in central Taiwan, Lee suggested that political power transfer, which is normal in any democracy, has only brought one disaster after another to Taiwan.
Without mentioning the name of his successor, Chen Shui-bian, Lee said the country's power transfer of 2000 only "provided someone with the opportunity to take bribes and launder money."
"It is a pity that one man was able to mess up the administration's governance so badly," Lee said.
Chen, who was swept to power in the 2000 presidential election was indicted Dec. 12, seven months after his second four-year term ended, on charges of money laundering and corruption.
"What is even more pitiful is that some people continue to support the corrupt politician in defiance of his approaching court trial, " Lee went on.
"The country is seriously afflicted by this pervasive corruption," he said.
Lee himself is under investigation for alleged money laundering, thanks to a tip-off provided by Chen to prosecutors.
According to Lee, the country only jumped out of the frying pan and into the fire when another power shift took place in 2008, putting the Kuomintang back into power with Ma Ying-jeou as president.

"Justice and human rights have regressed under the new administration in the last year," Lee claimed, citing as examples the way protesters were roughed up by police during a visit to Taiwan in November by a Chinese envoy, and claiming that students who staged a sit-in to press their demands for changes to rules governing assemblies and marches were violently driven away by police.
"And Ma's administration is at a total loss about what to do in the face of the economic slowdown caused by international financial crisis," he continued.

He predicted that the government's plan to hand out shopping vouchers to the public in an attempt to boost consumption will bring only temporary relief, as the root causes of the current crisis remain unaddressed.
"Instead, the government should boost both public and private investment and increase exports," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Peace Taiwan Awards presented in Taipei

TEXT.P: Three individuals or groups received the Peace Taiwan Awards Saturday for their efforts to promote the concepts of fairness and justice and to narrow the gaps observed in various areas in Taiwan or worldwide, according to the Taiwan Grassroots Alliance for Peace (TGAP), which organized the awards.

Speaking at the award-presentation ceremony, alliance Director-General Chen Chien-fu said the winning individual and groups serve as good examples of the country's grassroots "peaceful force" to deal with conflict in fields such as class, regions and human rights.

Carol Chang, president of the Macedonia-based Taiwan News International and also author of many Balkan-related books published in Taiwan, garnered the award in the individual category for her "long-term care for global underprivileged refugees as well as the rights of war correspondents," according to the TGAP.
Chang said she will continue to write reports on the issues if her work "will make the world a better place."

Meanwhile, the Taitung-based Austronesian Community College, a lifelong learning institution on Taiwan's east coast, was credited in the group category for launching various programs to revive the area's diverse aboriginal cultures and transform the natives' traditional practices into tourist attractions, the TGAP said.

In addition, the youth award was given to the Lo Sheng Living Community for their attempts to prevent the Lo Sheng Sanatorium -- the country's only government-run leprosy institution -- from being dismantled to make way for development and their efforts to protect what they described as the basic human rights of the elderly patients who have lived in the sanatorium for almost their entire lives, according to the TGAP.

Opposition Democratic Development Legislator Twu Shiing-jer, who presented one of the awards, lauded the winners, saying that civil forces at the basic level play an important role in pushing for Taiwan's peaceful development.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to convene national affairs conference in 2009

TEXT.P: The chairwoman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) revealed Saturday that the party will convene a national affairs conference next year to outline new guidelines and attempt to integrate the country's opposition parties.

Tsai Ing-wen made the announcement during talks with DPP members in the central county of Taichung. She also said the party will continue movements in the Legislative Yuan and on the streets to convey what she described as "the people's" discontent with the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).

Tsai accused President Ma Ying-jeou of leaning toward China at the expense of Taiwan's national sovereignty and claimed that people are worried that the Ma government is retreating from defense and diplomatic frontlines to please communist China.

Talking about the country's economic problems, Tsai said the ruling party has appeared reluctant to help local small- and medium-sized enterprises ride out the recession caused by the global financial meltdown.
According to Tsai, the ruling party's incompetence is the reason for the worsening domestic recession.
The DPP lost power to the KMT in the March 20 presidential election after governing the country for eight years between 2000 and 2008.
Its defeat was attributed to a series of corruption scandals involving top- ranking officials, including former President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: Parade held in Taipei to boost New Year ambience

TEXT.P: A parade featuring traditional Chinese folk activities was held Saturday in Taipei to perk up the ambience for the coming New Year celebration and to promote the 2010 Taipei International Gardening and Horticulture Exposition.

The parade featured student groups and amateur associations that performed dragon and lion dances, diabolo displays, skating and drumming, attracting local and foreign tourists at the center of Xinyi district, one of the capital's busiest areas.
A festooned vehicle decorated with hundreds of real flowers was also part of the parade to promote the international flower exposition slated for 2010.

In a speech before the start of the parade, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin invited the public to attend a New Year's eve countdown concert at the square in front of City Hall featuring Mayday, one of Taiwan's most popular rock bands.
But some foreign tourists seemed uninterested in Hau's invitation.

Jennifer Dunkle, making a short visit to Taiwan from Colorado in the United States, said she planned instead to watch the countdown fireworks display at Taipei 101, Taiwan's highest building, while Rhudy Chan, a Filipino, said he would prefer to stay at home and watch television to avoid the air pollution caused by the fireworks that are set off all over the city on New Year's eve.
Scheduled to leave Taiwan next week after the New Year, he said he would like to see the pandas that recently arrived from China if he has time to visit once they have ended their quarantine.
The two pandas given by China arrived in Taiwan Dec. 23 and will remain quarantined at the Taipei Zoo for 30 days before being put on display.

DOC.HEADLINE: President yet to decide on administrative border redrawing

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has yet to make a final decision on the redrawing of the nation's administrative borders, a spokesman for the Presidential Office said Saturday.
Wang Yu-chi said the president heard a briefing by the Ministry of the Interior Friday and that "the matter is still under assessment."
He denied that the possible redrawing is to cater to a plan to merge Taichung city and county into a single administrative district, which the Cabinet said earlier could be completed by 2010.

Wang was responding to reports by the United Daily News that in a bid to upgrade Taiwan's international competitiveness, Ma had decided to redraw the nation's administrative borders to include three metropolitan areas and 15 counties from the present 23 cities and counties and two special municipalities after a meeting with relevant government agencies Friday.

The three metropolises will revolve around the cities of Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung, according to the reports. Taipei will be a merger of Taipei City, Taipei County and Keelung City, while Taichung city and county will be merged and Kaohsiung City will be merged with Kaohsiung County.

The 15 counties will be Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Changhua, Nantou, Yunlin, Chiayi (a merger of the present city and county) , Tainan (a merger of the present city and county) , Pingtung, Yilan, Hualien, Taitung, Penghu, Kinmen and Lienchiang, the reports also said.
Meanwhile, Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei said the same day that if the goal of three metropolises and 15 counties is implemented, his county will be willing to work with the policy.
But he also said the central government should coordinate with the local governments to clearly define their respective rights and responsibilities.
Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, who has harbored the hope of merging his city with Tainan County and having it upgraded to a municipality, expressed disappointment Saturday about the possible redrawing.

Attending a cerebration for the 110th anniversary of the founding of National University of Tainan, Hsu said the city, a cultural capital, plays a major role in Taiwan's history and that "if its status is downgraded, the government will be a sinner in the nation's history."

But Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who attended the same event, said Hsu's remarks were over the top and that the conditions under which the city and county could be merged and upgraded are not yet ripe.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 28, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: President yet to decide on administrative border redrawing

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has yet to make a final decision on the redrawing of the nation's administrative borders, a spokesman for the Presidential Office said Saturday.
Wang Yu-chi said the president heard a briefing by the Ministry of the Interior Friday and that "the matter is still under assessment."
He denied that the possible redrawing is to cater to a plan to merge Taichung city and county into a single administrative district, which the Cabinet said earlier could be completed by 2010.

Wang was responding to reports by the United Daily News that in a bid to upgrade Taiwan's international competitiveness, Ma had decided to redraw the nation's administrative borders to include three metropolitan areas and 15 counties from the present 23 cities and counties and two special municipalities after a meeting with relevant government agencies Friday.

The three metropolises will revolve around the cities of Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung, according to the reports. Taipei will be a merger of Taipei City, Taipei County and Keelung City, while Taichung city and county will be merged and Kaohsiung City will be merged with Kaohsiung County.

The 15 counties will be Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Changhua, Nantou, Yunlin, Chiayi (a merger of the present city and county) , Tainan (a merger of the present city and county) , Pingtung, Yilan, Hualien, Taitung, Penghu, Kinmen and Lienchiang, the reports also said.
Meanwhile, Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei said the same day that if the goal of three metropolises and 15 counties is implemented, his county will be willing to work with the policy.
But he also said the central government should coordinate with the local governments to clearly define their respective rights and responsibilities.
Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, who has harbored the hope of merging his city with Tainan County and having it upgraded to a municipality, expressed disappointment Saturday about the possible redrawing.

Attending a cerebration for the 110th anniversary of the founding of National University of Tainan, Hsu said the city, a cultural capital, plays a major role in Taiwan's history and that "if its status is downgraded, the government will be a sinner in the nation's history."

But Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who attended the same event, said Hsu's remarks were over the top and that the conditions under which the city and county could be merged and upgraded are not yet ripe.

DOC.HEADLINE: District court ordered to reconsider ex-president's release again

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court ordered the Taipei District Court Sunday to reconsider its Dec. 18 decision to release former President Chen Shui-bian pending trial on corruption and money laundering charges.
The high court gave the order after the Supreme Prosecutors Office's Special Investigation Division filed an appeal Thursday against the Taiwan District Court's decision to release Chen.

The court said the reasons behind the district court's decision to reject prosecutors' request to detain Chen are flawed and inconsistent with the public's experience and thereby should be replaced by an appropriate ruling made by the district court itself.

In the appeal presented to the Taiwan High Court, the prosecutors said they will soon begin to investigate several other corruption cases allegedly involving Chen and his wife, and that if he is allowed to remain free, some of the witnesses, including three of his former close aides, might not dare to tell the truth.

It was the second time the Special Investigation Division had succeeded in having the Taiwan High Court to threw out the Taipei District Court's decision in the case. Chen and his wife Wu shu-chen were indicted for embezzling NT$104 million (us$3.12 million) from a special presidential office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to 2008.

They were also charged with accepting bribes worth NT$100 million and NT$200 million in connection with a land procurement deal and another NT$90.93 million in kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project, according to the indictment.

The district court rejected the Special Investigation Division's request to detain Chen on Dec. 13, but that ruling was overthrown on Dec. 17 by the Taiwan High Court which ordered the district court to reconsider the issue as requested by the Special Investigation Division.
However, the Taipei District Court upheld its decision in its second ruling on Dec. 18 which led to the Special Investigation Division's second appeal on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 28, or the 2nd day of the 12th month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: Spain recognizes Mexico's independence.
1856: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, American statesman and Democratic president (1913-21), is born.
1881: China's first telegraph line linking Tientsin and Shanghai is made available for public use.
1908: The most violent earthquake ever recorded in Europe destroys the city of Messina in Sicily, killing more than half of its 150,000 inhabitants and causing a giant tidal wave.
1912: City-run streetcars in San Francisco, California, begin operating.
1919: Feng Kuo-chang, a warlord who led the Chihli faction of the powerful Peiyang army during the first decade of the Republic of China, dies in Peking (Beijing) at the age of 62.
1923: Alexandre Gustave Eiffel, the French engineer who designed the 300-meter- high Eiffel Tower for the Paris Exhibition of 1889, dies at the age of 91.
1931: The ROC government is reformed, with Lin Sen made chairman.
1945: The Big Three Foreign Ministers' Conference in Moscow announces agreements on the establishment of a Commission and Allied Council for Japan, the ultimate establishment of a free Korea, and the withdrawal of Soviet and U.S. troops from China.
1950: Mainland Chinese troops cross the 38th parallel in Korea.
1962: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs declares that the border agreements signed between the Beijing regime and Outer Mongolia and Pakistan are illegal and non- binding for the Republic of China.
1966: Mainland China detonates its fifth atomic bomb.
1968: The ROC opens a telecommunications satellite earth station on Yangmingshan.
1971: Grand Justice Tien Chun-chin is appointed as president of the ROC's Judicial Yuan.
1972: The Republic of China's Embassy in Tokyo and the consulates-general in Osaka, Yokohama and Fukuoka are formally closed.
1974: The Republic of China-Bahamas Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Gambia following the latter's recognition of the Peiping (Beijing) regime.
1976: The millionth visitor of the year to the Republic of China, Wilhelm Mulmann, professor of sociology and anthropology at the University of Heidleberg, Germany, and his wife are welcomed by officials of the Tourism Bureau.
1976: Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang presents a gold medal and citation to Yen Tjing-ling, board chairman of the Yue Loong Motors Co. Ltd., for his contribution to an industrial research center at National Taiwan University.
1987: The Development Bank of Shenzhen, the first private share-holding bank on the Chinese mainland, is inaugurated.
1988: The first instance of a baby born with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) in Taiwan is recorded.
1993: A plane belonging to mainland China's Fujian Airlines is hijacked to Taiwan by Luo Chang-hua and his wife Wang Yu-ying in the 10th hijacking of the year.
1995: In Beijing, judges reject an appeal by dissident Wei Jingsheng, upholding his 14-year sentence on charges of trying to overthrow the Beijing government.
1995: Beijing names the committee responsible for steering Hong Kong through its transition from British colony to Chinese Special Administration Region in 1997.
1999: Taiwan changes the name of its representative office in Macau from Taipei Economic and Cultural Office to Taipei Economic and Cultural Center, Macau.
2000: The Formosa Plastics Group presents its first sedan -- the Formosa Magnus 2.0 -- which was manufactured via technical cooperation with South Korea's Daewoo Group.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Possession of power without generosity; courtesy without seriousness; mourning without grief -- I have no desire to look at such a state of things."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Cross-strait postal remittance service to begin in mid-February

TEXT.P: Two-way postal remittance services between Taiwan and China will begin in mid- February after the Lunar New Year holiday, with Citibank New York serving as the intermediary bank, Chunghwa Post Co. officials said Sunday.

A spokesman for Chunghwa Post noted that one of four agreements signed Nov. 4 in Taipei between Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- allows Taiwan and China to begin direct mail and postal remittance services.
The direct cross-Taiwan Strait mail service began Dec. 15, and the direct postal remittance service was originally scheduled to begin after the Lunar New Year holiday.

According to the spokesman, Chunghwa Post decided that because the estimated volume of direct remittances in the initial stage will not be large, it will be most cost-effective to use the services of Citibank.
Taiwan's post offices have provided services for outward remittances bound for China through Citibank New York since 1991, but have not accepted inward remittances from China.
From around mid-February, the postal remittance service between the two sides will work in both directions, with Citibank New York continuing to be the intermediary.

The spokesman continued that the Postal Savings Bank of China will join the Bank of China and the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China as a newcomer among the Chinese banks at which remittances can be paid.

All remittance transactions will be made in American dollars, with each transfer limited to US$30,000. The service charge in Taiwan will be NT$500 for each wire transfer and NT$400 for each mail transfer.
Statistics compiled by Chunghwa Post show that between 1991 and 2007, the average annual remittances from Taiwan to China amounted to NT$1.46 billion (US$44.36 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Local Deaflympics gold medalists promote 2009 event in Taipei

TEXT.P: Four Deaflympics gold medal winners will be featured on a poster promoting the 21st Summer Deaflympics slated to be held in Taipei in 2009, a Taipei organizing committee executive said Sunday.

The four are tennis player Ho Chiu-mei, table tennis gold medalists Wen Chih- hsuan and Yang Jung-tsung, and Tseng Shu-ning, a gold winner for swimming and world record holder in the 50 meters freestyle at the 2005 event, according to Yang Chao-kai.
They were among the Taiwanese Deaflympics athletes who won nine gold, four silver and three bronze medals at the 2005 Deaflympics in Melbourne, Australia, Yang added.

The committee invited the athletes to pose for the poster shoot in an attempt to give the public a better understanding of the 2009 Deaflympics and drum up interest for the event, Yang went on, adding that the posters will be distributed around the country.

The poster was the latest publicity effort following an earlier launch of an advertisement featuring movie star Jackie Chan that was highlighted on outdoor billboards at several Taipei MRT stations and at the Taipei Arena, and was put online and aired on TV, Yang said.
The Deaflympics, formerly called the World Games for the Deaf, an International Olympic Committee-sanctioned sports event for hearing impaired athletes, will be held in Taipei Sept. 5-15 next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taxi operators feeling economic pinch call for license controls

TEXT.P: "The economy is so bad, I quite often roam around looking for passengers but do not get a single one for a whole morning, " laments Ho Chin-chuang, a taxi driver of eight years who was queuing up in front of a hospital in Taipei earlier in the month.

Ho, in conjunction with a number of local taxi operators whose businesses have been decimated by the economic downturn, recently issued a call for the government to impose a quota on the number of taxis operating in Taiwan.

At present, the number of registered taxi drivers in Taiwan is estimated at more than 90,000, of which more than 31,000 are operating in Taipei City with its population of about 2.63 million people, which translates into a ratio of residents to taxis of about 85:1, according to official statistics. The figures also do not take into account the numerous unlicensed cabs.
But with the low threshold for entry to the taxi industry, many people laid off in the financial storm have turned to driving taxis, so that the true number is likely to be larger than estimated.
The taxi business has already gone down since the city's mass rapid transit (MRT) system began operations 12 years ago, along with improvements to the country's public transport networks.

According to a Taipei City report, local taxi drivers in 2007 worked an average of 10.4 hours per day, during which their cars were left empty for an average of 3.5 hours. They worked about 27-28 days per month, but only earned an average of NT$1,754 (US$53) per day before deducting daily gasoline costs of about NT$617.

The situation is even worse this year as the economic crisis has hit almost everybody, leading to fewer people using cabs, said Chen Yuan-min, secretary- general of the Taipei City Transportation Federation, which represents more than 1,000 taxi companies and 20,000 taxi drivers in the city.
Owing to the excessive number of taxis and a dramatic fall in passenger numbers, about 70 percent of the taxis cruising Taipei City streets are empty, Chen said.
"As a result, many cabbies have been forced to extend their working hours to 12 hours per day, earning a meager NT$2,000 per day before deducting other costs, said Chen.

He suggested that the government should map out measures to bring the number of registered taxi licenses down from the present 90,000 to around 35,000 by 2013, when the third stage of the Taipei MRT is completed, which he estimated could help drive the rate of unoccupied taxis in the city down from 70 percent to 35 percent.

He also expressed support for a proposal issued by taxi operators that the government buy back operation licenses that are not being leased or used and have those who are interested in becoming taxi drivers bid for the licenses.

Taiwan's taxi business is made up of three major groupings: taxi companies, which lease cars or operating certificates to drivers with vocation certificates; taxi cooperatives, each of which comprises at least 20 individual taxi drivers, with each paying NT$600-NT$800 in monthly dues; and individual taxi drivers who operate with their own operating certificates.

Acting on the suggestion of an advisory committee, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications' (MOTC's) Directorate General of Highways has suspended issuing new taxi license plates to taxi companies and taxi cooperatives, while only granting licenses to so-called "excellent taxi drivers, " referring to those who have been members of a taxi company or cooperative as a taxi driver for six years with a good record, according to agency officials.
The number of new licenses issued to those individual taxi drivers is around 1,000 per year, the officials added.

Meanwhile, Wang Mu-han, chief of the Transportation Corporation and Management Division of the MOTC's Institute of Transportation, said that even if the government were to agree to buy back taxi licenses, it would not solve the industry's problems but would cause many employees in the sector to lose their jobs, while also increasing the number of illegal cabbies.

He added that creating demand for taxi services could be another option to help the industry, citing as an example a new carpool pilot program being implemented in Taipei City and around various high speed rail stations that is seen as a good way to attract passengers.

In contrast to the official concerns about the plight of taxi drivers, however, customers are taking a much dimmer view of the issue. Wang Mei-yu, who takes a cab only once in a while, questioned why despite the fact that taxis were allowed to increase fares when oil prices were high, fares have not now been adjusted back down to normal levels at a time when oil prices have plummeted to a new low.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan gets world's highest full-score success rate in math exam

TEXT.P: Taiwan enjoyed the highest full-score rate in the world in the recent American Mathematics Contest 8 (AMC8) , with 124 of the country's junior high school students attaining full marks among the 9,100 registrants, the 99 Cultural and Educational Foundation announced at a press conference Sunday.

Although the United States generated the most full-mark students, Taiwan ranked first in terms of the ratio of students within the top 5 percent, according to the foundation, which deals with AMC8 registrations in Taiwan.

Foundation CEO Yan Chi-Lin said, however, that in contrast to the U.S. -- where all junior high students are required to take the exam -- in Taiwan it is an elective test, which he said suggests that some degree of prior selection is exercised.
Therefore, he noted, the good local results should not be viewed as a general reflection of the abilities of the country's students.

Yan said an analysis of the test results show that Taiwanese students generally perform more poorly on questions that involve longer descriptions or require more complex thinking than others that can be worked out simply by calculating.

As AMC centers on the development of logical thinking, the foundation's Chairman Ho Yan-ming expressed hope that the exam can serve as inspiration for improvement in Taiwan's math education, which places most of the emphasis on calculation skills.

Chang Fu-Kuo, president of the Tainan-based Ying-Hai High School in southern Taiwan, which produced the most full-score students in the country, echoed Ho's statement, saying that "mathematical ability is not just all about solving questions."
He said his school has designed a course based on the AMC spirit, which trains students in logical thinking in the process of dealing with math questions instead of simply pursuing answers.

In addition, the foundation noted that the number of Taiwan's full-mark students, which made up 30 percent of the 412 students who received perfect scores worldwide, also broke the country's own record, up from the 2006 figure of 121.
Meanwhile, eight elementary students also achieved perfect scores in the upper- level exam, which also broke the country's record, the foundation added.
The AMC8 was held in November, with a worldwide participation of 155,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: 52 Taiwanese artists to help Chou Ta-kuan Foundation muster funds

TEXT.P: A charity auction of artworks by 52 local artists will begin Monday and run through Jan. 16 at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall's art gallery to help the Taipei-based Chou Ta-kuan Cultural and Educational Foundation raise operating funds, foundation staff members said Sunday.
Among the 52 artists who have donated works for the auction are renowned painters such as Au Ho-nien and Lee Chi-mao.

Au is an outstanding third-generation painter of the Lingnan School, a master who depicts all subjects and is known for his ability to combine poetry, calligraphy and painting, while Lee is well-known for combining Western skills with his Chinese painting techniques in watercolor and ink works.
Other donating artists include Lee Hsiu-fang, Lien Sheng-yen, Chang Ko-chi, Hsu Hai-chin, Pai Tsung-jen, Liu Ping-heng, Chou Cheng and Sun Chia-chin.

The National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Management Office launched the auction by seeking help from the artists after its executives learned that the foundation had exhausted its funds and was badly in need of new donations.
The Chou Ta-kuan Foundation was down to just NT$565 (US$17) in October, prompting its members to take to the streets to seek donations from the public for its Melody of Hope Awards and Scholarships.

The foundation was established in 1997 by the parents of Chou Ta-kuan -- a young poet who died of cancer at the age of 10 -- to commemorate his deep love for life and his unwavering spirit in fighting his cancer.

It has sponsored various activities and programs, including presenting the Chou Ta-kuan Love for Life Awards each year to select individuals from around the world. The 2008 awards were presented in September to 26 people, including eight foreign nationals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosan black bears spotted near mountain trail in Yushan park

TEXT.P: Formosan black bears, an ursine subspecies indigenous to Taiwan, have recently been spotted on lower-altitude mountain trails in the Yushan National Park in southern Taiwan, park rangers said Sunday.

Formosan black bears, or Selenarctos thibetanus formosanus, used to be widely distributed in forests throughout Taiwan, but the expansion of human settlement and land development has gradually forced the animals to retreat deeper and deeper into the mountains to avoid humans.
In recent years, Yushan National Park Administration (YNPA) officials said only people who often frequent forests at high elevations can have much chance of spotting a bear.

However, some rangers said they found black bear pawprints last month around a mountain hut in the Yushan park at a medium elevation where mountain climbers like to camp out. Early this month, park rangers also spotted fresh claw scratches made by the animals on tree trunks along a mountain trail between Dongpu and Guangao in Nantou County's Sinyi township.
"Reports from rangers show that a trend is taking shape with Formosan black bears venturing into mountainous regions frequented by humans," said a YNPA official.
As to why the bears are appearing in lower-altitude forests again, the official said they could be attracted by the smell of food left by mountain climbers.

In addition, the official went on, the number of other species such as barking deer and goats along mountain trails has increased in recent years, which could also have drawn the bears down from the heights.
With the chances of encountering Formosan black bears increasing, the official reminded mountain climbers to remain calm and composed if they happen to come across any of the animals.

"While Formosan black bears can be ferocious and dangerous, they will usually not attack unless they are threatened, hurt or feel that their cubs are in danger, " the official said, adding that the best thing to do in the event of an encounter is to stay calm, try not to provoke the animal, and leave the vicinity as soon as possible.

The official further said that Formosan black bears, although strong, sturdy and skilled at mountain climbing, are less agile and slower than other carnivores. He also advised mountain climbers to refrain from climbing trees or feigning death should they come across a bear.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold continental air mass to sweep Taiwan Dec. 30

TEXT.P: A cold front will move into the Taiwan area Monday, followed by the arrival of a cold continental air mass Dec. 30 that will send the mercury plunging to as low as 11 degrees Celsius in central and northern Taiwan through the New Year holiday until Jan. 4, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) forecast Sunday.
CWB meteorologists said the cold front will bring rain to nearly all parts of Taiwan in the next three days apart from southern Taiwan.
From Jan. 1, most parts of Taiwan will see cold, dry weather under sunny skies, while the northeastern area might have showers, with the eastern area falling under cloudy skies.

On the Taiwan-controlled outlying island of Matsu, temperatures between Jan. 1 and Jan. 4 will dip to a chilly 6 degrees Celsius, while Kinmen, another outlying island, will see lows of 10 degrees Celsius, the weathermen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ties with China do not jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that the closer economic ties with China have in no way jeopardized Taiwan's sovereignty or dignity and that the government's recent launch of daily direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, and direct shipping and postal links with China, is beneficial to Taiwanese citizens and will raise Taiwan's competitiveness in the region.
Ma made the remarks during a speech he gave at a workshop for senior officials on programs related to China.

"My administration has always aimed to serve the best interests of Taiwan," Ma said, adding that four accords signed in November are all economic issues of major concern to Taiwan and are absolutely irrelevant to the delicate sovereignty issue.

The results of recent opinion polls show that the majority of the public favor the launch of the direct links with China, as more than two-thirds of the respondents believe the agreements signed with China will have a very positive effect on the economy, said Ma.

Using the panda issue as an example, Ma said that despite the fact that the Secretariat of the Convention of International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild and Fauna and Flora (CITES) said earlier this month that the transfer of pandas from China to Taiwan was in the category of internal/domestic trade, the delivery of the animals followed the mode of a country-to-country transfer and has in no way belittled Taiwan's status, adding that if it was an internal/domestic transfer, no customs declaration would have been needed.

As giant pandas are an endangered species subject to the protection of the CITES, cross-border transfers of the animals must follow strict CITES guidelines. According to the guidelines, the two parties must supply export and import permits confirming that all conditions for the transfer have been met. This implies that the transaction is between two countries.
"The logic behind it is simple, " said Ma. "No-one is required to present a passport or customs declaration when traveling within the borders of a country."

Turning to a just-concluded forum between the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China, Ma said Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- cannot replace all the the functions of Non-Government Organizations (NGOs).

"We need all the help we can get, " said Ma adding that in the near future, the SEF and the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will not be able to handle the daily increasing matters between Taiwan and China.

Emphasizing that there are more than 60 channels of communication between the United States and China, Ma noted that NGOs and academics are a vital part of the non-official communication channels between the two sides of the strait that can contribute significantly to the improvement of cross-strait ties and cooperation.

Ma also said the various government agencies should strengthen communications among themselves in order to better serve the interests of the public in the planning of future negotiations with China, as the new era in cross-strait ties requires the participation of the entire government system.

"The pacts with China represent an opportunity to boost Taiwan's economy but should not be regarded as a panacea for Taiwan's economic woes, " said Ma, adding that the government should always hope for the best but prepare for the worst.

Urging both Taiwan and China to show their willingness to further improve bilateral relations, Ma said Taiwan should find ways to increase positive interaction with China, as the development of two-way ties is a vital priority.
Since the KMT returned to power in May, Ma's administration has been working to melt the ice between the two sides of the strait and to forge links with China, particularly on the economic front.

In their second round of talks held in Taipei from Nov. 3-7, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, and his Chinese counterpart, ARATS President Chen Yunlin, signed four agreements to allow daily direct cross-strait flights, direct shipping links and direct postal services, as well as the establishment of a food safety mechanism between the two sides.

According to the MAC, which charts the country's China policies and oversees the SEF, the agenda for the next cross-strait dialogue will include cross-strait cooperation in the areas of combating crime, strengthening food safety, the inspection and quarantine of agriculture produce, and on investment, financial, fishery, cultural and educational cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Panda delivery not internal/domestic transfer: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that the delivery of two giant pandas to Taiwan from China was not an internal/domestic transfer as described by a United Nations agency, as the animals went through customs and into quarantine when they arrived in the country.

Speaking at a workshop for government officials on Chinese affairs, Ma said that since China issued an export permit for the pandas stating the importer as "Taiwan Taipei" and accepting "Chengdu" as the origin of export which was later accepted by Taiwanese customs, it clearly followed the mode of a country-to-country delivery.

In addition, a correction letter was sent Saturday to the secretariat of the U.N.-affiliated Convention of International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), which referred to the panda transfer as an internal/domestic transfer, according to the Forestry Bureau under the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture.

Bureau officials said the letter was designed to clarify Taiwan's standpoint on the issue as total adherence to the strict CITES provisions regarding imports of endangered animal and plant species, regardless of the fact that Taiwan is not a CITES signatory.

The officials further explained that the export permit issued by the Chinese authorities followed the form of the certificates used in previous transfers of Chinese endangered fauna and flora to Taiwan.
The procedures, the officials went on, complied with the standards stipulated by CITES between signatory and non-signatory countries.

Critics have argued that the pandas, offered by China as a gift of goodwill and friendship and now settling into their new quarters at the Taipei Zoo, are a sign of China's belittlement of Taiwan's sovereignty.

The debate became even more heated when opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators pointed out that CITES categorizes the transfer as internal/domestic trade which therefore did not need to be reported to the organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC to launch pioneer taxi-sharing scheme Dec. 31

TEXT.P: A traffic route between Jiantan Station on the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit system's Red Line and Chinese Culture University on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei has been selected for the implementation of a carpool trial for taxis that will begin Dec. 31, a Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) official said Sunday.

The MOTC initiated the program in a bid to solve the problem of an oversupply of taxis by cutting the ratio of taxis running without passengers, boosting cabbies' incomes, decreasing the use of private vehicles and cutting carbon emissions, according to the official.

The route was picked from among eight possible routes because of the heavy traffic volume on it, the official said, adding that a Taipei City-based taxi fleet has been granted the right to operate the carpool service.

A total of 1,500 passengers are expected to take taxis on the route per day, which can be translated into an estimated NT$30 million in revenue per year for taxi operators, according to Lin Huei-ling, deputy chief executive of the taxi fleet.
Under the preliminary plan, passengers would be charged a flat taxi fare between the two destinations and can enter or leave the taxi at any point along the route, the MOTC official said.

However, passengers will be charged different rates if different numbers of passengers take the taxi together. The rate for the carpool will differ from the ordinary one, which charges passengers by the number of kilometers traveled, the official added.

For example, according to the existing taxi fare of between NT$250 to NT$260, each passenger will be charged NT$125 for a one-way trip if two passengers share a taxi, while each passenger will pay NT$85 if three share a taxi and NT$65 if there are four passengers, the official explained.

The MOTC also plans to expand the carpool service to those traveling between Jiantan Station and Chutzuhu, as well as other scenic spots on Yangmingshan, with a flat fare of NT$115, to coincide with the Yangmingshan Flower Festival between February and March and the calla lily season from May to June.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC reaffirms equality in direct cross-strait shipping services

TEXT.P: Taiwan-owned but foreign-registered ships are entitled to operate direct shipping services across the Taiwan Strait on an equal basis, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Sunday.

Lai was responding to media reports that the 20 Taiwan-owned, foreign-registered vessels would all be barred from entering Chinese ports from the beginning of next year, which critics said would eventually lead to China's monopoly of cross-strait gravel shipping services and even its dominance of Taiwan's gravel market.

According to the bilateral agreement signed Nov.4 on the launch of direct shipping links, Lai said, the two sides agree that all those ships can ply direct cross-strait routes on an equal basis so long as they had been operating gravel shipping business before the Dec.15 inauguration of direct shipping links.

"Equal participation is the guiding principle in dealing with issues regarding direct cross-strait shipping services, " Lai said, adding that if there is any problem or discrimination in relevant operations, the government will address it through negotiations.

Meanwhile, MAC Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng said the two intermediary bodies -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- clearly outlined the "equal participation" principle for direct shipping service operations when they signed direct shipping links accord.

"The equal participation principle applies to all vessels that had been involved in indirect cross-strait shipping services, including gravel shipment, before the opening of direct shipping links," Fu reiterated.

On a reported incident in which a Taiwanese gravel ship was barred from entering China's Huangpu port last week even though it had a certificate issued by Taiwan's Taichung Harbor Bureau, Fu said he had gained a better understanding of China's stance through a communication channel.

According to Fu, China has offered two formulas for Taiwanese vessels to apply for permissions to enter its ports. The first way is to file an online application for each voyage and the other is to apply for a long-term permit. Vessels that had operated indirect cross-strait shipping services in the past can apply for long-term entry permits through their shipping agents.

Quoting Chinese sources, Fu said, Chinese authorities have so far not yet received any application from Taiwanese shipowners. Fu said the MAC has asked the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to look into the situation.

Fu further said some differences still exist between the two sides' shipping regulations. Among others, China would not allow entry of commercial vessels older than 33 years. As gravel shipping charges are usually very low, shipping companies tend to use old vessels.

"We'll ask the MOTC to study whether China's 'age' limit is reasonable, " Fu said, adding that if necessary, the two sides will negotiate a solution through two non-governmental intermediary bodies -- Taiwan's Taiwan Strait Shipping Association and China's Association for Shipping Across the Taiwan Strait.
